https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/03/world.main_headline: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: IN WASHINGTON;U.S. JET ON MISSION FOR NATO IS SHOT DOWN OVER BOSNIA; SERBS FREE SOME U.N. TROOPS -- White House Denounces Serbs; Aides Voice Fear for Pilot's Fate
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/03/world.print_headline: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: IN WASHINGTON;U.S. JET ON MISSION FOR NATO IS SHOT DOWN OVER BOSNIA; SERBS FREE SOME U.N. TROOPS -- White House Denounces Serbs; Aides Voice Fear for Pilot's Fate
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/03/world.body_text: **********The White House upbraided the Bosnian Serbs today for shooting down an American F-16 jet fighter, calling them "outcasts and international pariahs." Officials said they feared the pilot had been killed or captured. **********Only a few hours later, on a day of shifting emotions and confusing developments, the White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, applauded the reported release of more than 120 United Nations peacekeepers whom the Bosnian Serbs had been holding as hostages. But he demanded that the rest of the hostages, who numbered more than 200, be freed at once. **********The events in Bosnia and Herzegovina clouded this evening's meeting at the White House between President Clinton and his two top military advisers, Defense Secretary William J. Perry and Gen. John Shalikashvili, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to discuss future American actions in the region. The two Pentagon officials left afterwards for a gathering in Paris on Saturday of ministers from countries that have contributed peacekeepers. **********Mr. Clinton said little about the loss of the aircraft and nothing about the  hostages or the meeting. Appearing briefly in the Rose Garden at midday, he said he was "very concerned" about the fate of the pilot. He made no mention of reprisals, but in such situations retaliatory air strikes on enemy anti-aircraft sites are usually carried out. **********If hostages are still being released, one ranking Administration official said, retaliation might have to be postponed or eliminated altogether to avoid stalling the release or harming the hostages, most of whom are British and French. **********A senior military officer, briefing reporters tonight, said that air strikes  would be difficult in the next few hours, given what he called the "fluidity" of the hostage situation. **********Referring to his offer, announced this week, to deploy American troops to help move peacekeepers to safer positions, the President said, "I want to reiterate and make absolutely clear that our policy on Bosnia remains firm." Mr. McCurry said Mr. Clinton believes the United States has "a moral obligation" to  support allies "who have troops on the ground in Bosnia who might come under peril." **********Nonetheless, the downing of the F-16 greatly complicated his situation. **********As he attempts to placate Capitol Hill, which has roundly condemned the new policy, and to convince the American public that he is not being sucked into a debacle like that in Vietnam, the President is confronted with unwelcome evidence of how dangerous a place Bosnia can be. **********If the pilot is not rescued, he would be the first American casualty or prisoner-of-war of the intractable four-year conflict, and a rallying point for  those who oppose involvement. Dozens of French, British and other troops have died in Bosnia since the peacekeeping mission began more than two years ago. **********Mr. McCurry said that the downing of the warplane was "one more piece of evidence that, in a wanton and irresponsible way," the Bosnian Serbs "are making themselves outcasts and international pariahs." **********Pentagon officials said that the F-16 Fighting Falcon was on a routine patrol, of a type flown more than 20,000 times since a no-flight zone was created over the former Yugoslavia in April 1993. The single-seat fighter was flying, the officials said, at about 20,000 feet, in the region of a heavily defended Serbian air base at Banja Luka when it was hit by a Russian-made SA-6 missile. **********According to the Pentagon, the pilot of a second F-16 flying in formation with the first did not see a parachute before the stricken plane exploded in clouds below, but the pilot could conceivably have ejected out of the wingman's  view. **********A Bosnian Serb military source quoted by The Associated Press said a chute had been sighted shortly before the plane crashed on the outskirts of the town of Mrkonjic Grad. Adm. Leighton Smith, the NATO commander in the region, told the Cable News Network that he had an unconfirmed report that the pilot had been captured by Serbs. **********Search and rescue efforts launched by helicopters from the amphibious assault ship Kearsarge, in the Adriatic, were initially hampered by stormy weather and clouds, then curtailed by darkness. The hunt was expected to resume at dawn. **********An officer accompanying Mr. Perry said aboard his plane that it seemed unlikely that the pilot had survived. He had probably not had time to take evasive action, the officer said, because he had been flying just above the cloud cover when he was hit. **********Reaction in Congress to the Serbs' attack was muted. **********Sen. John Warner of Virginia, the chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said in Richmond that he was puzzled by the Serbs' success in downing as sophisticated a plane as an F-16. Mr. Warner, a Republican, said "we have adequate assets in the region to suppress enemy missiles." **********Considerable confusion remained about whether the Europeans would ultimately  ask formally for American help in strengthening and repositioning the peacekeepers. **********In the Balkans, it was taken for granted that such a request was coming. But  some American officials expressed doubts. One said that Britain and France had had second thoughts about pulling out of enclaves such as Gorazde, where more than 400 British troops are encircled and cut off by Bosnian Serbs. **********Plans for such an extraction have been formulated. They would involve several hundred American troops on the ground, with American helicopters lifting the peacekeepers to safety and American jets flying cover. But that sort of redeployment would constitute a retreat and might expose the enclaves to almost  immediate takeover by the Bosnian rebel forces. **********Saturday's meeting in Paris is expected to reach no final decisions. A main topic will be the rapid-reaction force sponsored by the French and British, to which the United States will contribute equipment but no personnel. The meeting  will also serve to include the French, who have said they will not attend the meeting of NATO foreign ministers scheduled for Thursday in Brussels. **********Mr. Clinton met at the White House from about 5:40 P.M. to 7 P.M. with Mr. Perry and General Shalikashvili to discuss contingency planning, the status of the F-16 pilot and the hostage situation, White House aides said. The three also discussed the Paris meeting.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/11/world.main_headline: Terms of Muslim-Croat Alliance Are Set at Dayton Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/11/world.print_headline: Terms of Muslim-Croat Alliance Are Set at Dayton Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/11/world.body_text: **********A wide-ranging agreement to invigorate a tenuous Muslim-Croat alliance in Bosnia was announced today by senior Administration officials and portrayed as an important step toward an overall Bosnian peace settlement. But the effectiveness of the accord and the strategy behind it remain uncertain. **********Secretary of State Warren Christopher, on a one-day visit to the peace talks  here, said the accord would bring the Muslim-Croat federation established last year "to life" and described it as "an essential building block of peace in Bosnia-Herzegovina as a whole." Up to now, the federation has done little more than stop the fighting that raged in 1993 between Muslims and Croats. **********The agreement, signed after 10 days of negotiations here that have scarcely  begun to address the most contentious issues of an overall Bosnian peace, amounts to the first serious attempt to divide authority between the central Government of Bosnia and the federation, establish the rudiments of economic life, and integrate divided Muslim and Croatian communities. **********But it hardly touches on one of the most difficult questions: the degree of integration between Croat forces and the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Army. During a recent offensive in western Bosnia, fighting twice broke out between Croatian and Bosnian units, bringing the federation to the verge of collapse. **********Moreover, it remains unclear whether the American strategy of strengthening the military and economic power of the Muslim-Croat federation as a counterbalance to the Serbs will ultimately prove compatible with the stated American aim of maintaining Bosnia as a single state. The stronger and more integrated the federation becomes, the more the Serbs of Bosnia may feel their future lies elsewhere. **********"If the federation can succeed as a multi-ethnic democracy, then so can Bosnia-Herzegovina as a whole," Mr. Christopher said. But if this is to happen,  then the relationship between the Muslim-Croat federation and the Serb republic  within Bosnia foreseen in any peace plan will have to be one of cooperation rather than hostility. **********It is far from clear how such cooperation will be worked out in that the basic aim of the Serbs' current leaders remains that of ruling themselves with a view to eventual confederation with Serbia or secession. **********As the agreement was signed today by the Bosnian President, Alija Izetbegovic, and the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, Croatia moved troops and heavy artillery close to Eastern Slavonia, the one remaining Serb-held part  of Croatia. **********The troop movement may amount to no more than saber rattling. But it nevertheless underscored the fragility of the negotiations here. President Tudjman has vowed to retake Eastern Slavonia by the end of this month through negotiation or military might. **********The agreement signed today gives the federation government extensive powers,  including control over defense, justice, customs collection, taxation, agriculture, health and internal affairs. **********The central Bosnian Government, whose form and function remain to be defined  in any overall peace accord, would retain control over foreign policy, foreign trade, air traffic control, immigration and citizenship, and monetary policy. **********Over the last 20 months, since the formation of the federation, Croats and Muslims have argued over how authority should be divided. The Muslim-led Government has been reluctant to cede any real authority to the federation, while Bosnian Croats have seen the federation as a means to weaken the Government and strengthen their ties with Croatia. **********In practice, Croatian-controlled areas, amounting to about 20 percent of Bosnia and Herzegovina, have been governed by the self-styled authorities of Herzeg-Bosna and have pushed ahead with integration with Croatia. **********The agreement seeks to undo this process by dissolving the institutions of Herzeg-Bosna. At the same time, four federation ministries -- commerce, traffic  and communications, energy and industry, and education, science and culture -- are to be established in Mostar. **********Every fourth session of the federation's government, which is to meet weekly, will be held in Mostar. The remainder will be held in Sarajevo. **********In one of its most important stipulations, the accord says a new customs system is to be set up by Dec. 10 and internal customs checkpoints between Croatian and Bosnian Government-controlled areas removed. **********Because Croatia and Herzeg-Bosna control geographic access to landlocked Bosnia, Croats have been able to take an enormous cut on all goods going into Bosnia. This practice has infuriated the Bosnian Government. Beginning with the  1996 budget year, the agreement says an agreed proportion of customs revenue will accrue to the central budget of the Bosnian republic. An annex to the agreement establishes steps to bring about the reunification of Mostar, the magnificent city on the Neretva River whose Old Bridge, a marvel of Ottoman architecture, was destroyed by Croatian shelling during the 1993 war. The city has remained divided along the front lines of that conflict. **********On the central issue of military integration, the agreement calls only for greater integration between senior Croat and Muslim commanders. It adds that "international assistance" will be sought in the creation of a "joint planning staff." **********In practice, "international assistance" almost certainly means American help. This in turn raises the difficult issue of how American military aid to the federation will prove compatible with a large American presence in the NATO force that would be sent to police any overall settlement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/26/world.main_headline: On Quebec Border, Fear of Secession
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/26/world.print_headline: On Quebec Border, Fear of Secession
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/26/world.body_text: **********Like many of his confreres, Raymond Durocher, 45, a quality control manager in an Ontario polyester yarn plant, commutes to work every day across the Ottawa River from this small border town in Quebec. **********During lunch recently at the Grand Papa restaurant on the Quebec side of the  two-mile bridge to Hawkesbury, Ontario, Mr. Durocher and other diners were fretting about the possibility of frontier controls should Quebec secede from Canada in a referendum on Monday. **********What a hassle that would be," Mr. Durocher complained over a sandwich and fries at a table by the window. "Imagine a green card and proofs of citizenship  every time you cross. It would be a real hardship on people here. Like entering  the States every day to go to work." **********A few weeks ago, that scenario seemed far-fetched. Opponents of independence  for Quebec had a comfortable lead in a referendum campaign led by a separatist provincial government seeking to make Canada's largest province a nation to preserve its cultural identity. **********This is the second time in 15 years that Quebec has gone through a wrenching  sovereignty exercise. In 1980, 60 percent of voters were against breaking away and only 40 percent voted in favor of secession. **********Fearing a second defeat could doom their cause, secession strategists have boosted the emotional content of their campaign, playing to Quebecers' fears of being overwhelmed by a sea of North American English-speakers. **********Polls now show the separatists' gaining momentum, and in some soundings they  actually lead, a development that has rattled financial markets in advance of what could be the greatest geopolitical changes in North America since Canada's  confederation in 1867. **********But the large number of undecided poll respondents, which has been estimated  at as many as 10 percent, raises questions about the reliability of the polling  results. In 1980, when the Yes side was also deemed to be ahead, undecided voters flocked to the No side. And even after the vote, it is not clear what would happen. Only a simple majority is necessary for the secessionists to win,  but a small majority could lead to something short of sovereignty -- legal challenges, a second referendum, or even extended constitutional negotiations. **********Any changes that would lead Quebec to nationhood seemed to be the last thing  anyone having lunch at the Grand Papa craved. Diners were troubled by a recent warning from Ontario's Premier, Mike Harris, that if Quebecers voted in favor of the "divorce," new border posts could affect the flow of goods as well as people between Ontario and Quebec. **********"If Quebec were suddenly no longer part of the country, there would be no reason for the rest of Canada to consider Quebec's interests," Mr. Harris said.  He suggested that secession might lead to a system of border controls similar to the one that exists between Canada and the United States. **********Sitting with Mr. Durocher was Phil Theriault, who owns Bonichoix, a mini-supermarket on the Grenville side of the bridge. It does $2.5 million a year of business, much of that in beer sold to Ontarians after provincially-owned liquor outlets have closed for the day at 6 P.M. **********"If you had an international border here," fumed Mr. Theriault, "that Ontario business would dry up, and I might even have to close my store." **********For the last 50 years the family of Jacques Desforges has run the Desforges Funeral Home in Grenville. Though most of the 100 funerals a year at Desforges are for Quebec families from Grenville, a town of 1,400, most of those people die across the river in Hawkesbury, a town of 15,000 with a hospital and nursing homes. Grenville is too small for such services. **********"A border would be particularly bad news for us," said Mr. Desforges, a former member of the Grenville town council and a leader of the Grenville No committee. "Can you imagine the red tape in transporting dead bodies across a national frontier?" **********In all the talk about new customs and immigration procedures and identity checks on people, secessionists accuse the federalists of scaremongering. **********Henri Tetu and his wife, Anita, live a few miles east of Grenville along the  shores of the Ottawa River. Ontario spreads out a canopy of gray-green fields across the water. A bright red, yellow and green "Oui" sign is nailed to a tree  on his front lawn. **********Mr. Tetu, a retired Ottawa civil servant, invites a reporter into his sunny living room to assert with a gallic shrug, "The border business doesn't bother me a damn bit. It will be a little tougher for a while, but it will readjust itself because business interests on the other side of the river are still there, and the people here who work in Hawkesbury and live here will have to carry on with the job. If you're a good nurse and have a job in Hawkesbury, I don't see how they would kick you out because you reside in Grenville." **********On one point, there is no disagreement: the deteriorating condition of the 64-year-old, two-lane span that represents the only fixed link between the two provinces in more than 100 miles. **********A new $45 million bridge is supposed to replace it. Financing has been settled -- two-thirds by the federal government and one-third by the two provincial governments. **********"It took years to work out that formula," said Mr. Desforges. "Can you imagine how long it would take to work out a new agreement with an independent Quebec?"

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/13/busin.main_headline: Market Place;Analysts say Allmerica Financial came to market at a low price.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/13/busin.print_headline: Market Place;Analysts say Allmerica Financial came to market at a low price.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/13/busin.body_text: **********LIKE many companies making their stock market debut, the Allmerica Financial  Corporation was priced to sell, and its 11-million- share offering on Wednesday  was quickly snapped up by a relatively small number of favored customers at the  securities firms handling the sale. **********When Allmerica Financial stock rose $3.625, or 17.3 percent, in the first two days of New York Stock Exchange trading to a closing price of $24.625 yesterday, it was good news not just for the favored few who bought the initial offering but also for about 100,000 life insurance customers -- soon to be shareholders -- of the State Mutual Life Assurance Company of America, the predecessor company of Allmerica, based in Worcester, Mass. **********In the next few weeks as State Mutual converts from a mutual company owned by policyholders to a stock company owned by shareholders, it will distribute 37.4 million shares to policyholders. They will want to know why the stock was so attractive to professional investors. **********"All you really need to know is that Allmerica's businesses appear to be at least as good as the industry average, but its shares were offered at $21 while  the book value was over $29," said one Boston portfolio manager, who spoke on condition he not be identified. On average, other insurance company stocks trade at prices above their book value. **********Many analysts said the offering price was a low-cost way to buy into the life insurance company. Allmerica Financial has a stake in a fellow company, Allmerica Property and Casualty. Because more than $16 of every new share of Allmerica Financial represents the value of Allmerica Property and Casualty stock, investors paid less than $5 a share for the life insurance and related businesses of the old State Mutual, which earned $52.6 million before taxes in the first half of this year, up $30.7 million from the comparable period last year. Allmerica Property and Casualty was 58 percent owned by State Mutual and 42 percent by public investors. **********The Allmerica companies are being overhauled and growing faster as new managers, led by John F. O'Brien, formerly a top executive at Fidelity Investments, have cut expenses and developed new products. **********Dan Theriault, an insurance analyst at T. Rowe Price Associates, the Baltimore-based mutual fund company, said Allmerica Financial was willing to set a low price for the new shares "because they will probably be back to the market with other offerings, perhaps to buy a mutual fund company or asset manager, and they want to leave investors with a good feeling." **********He added that "if Mr. O'Brien has one iota of the success at Allmerica he had at Fidelity," then the Allmerica Financial stock should do very well indeed. **********Unlike some other insurance companies that have at times traded well below book value, Allmerica Financial does not have problems like bad real estate investments or unpaid claims for environmental cleanups hanging over its balance sheet. **********Before the new stock offering, the reorganization of State Mutual had already caught the eye of some investors. Three years ago, State Mutual said it planned  to merge with the property insurance group and simultaneously de-mutualize, but  dropped the merger idea to simplify the de-mutualization. **********Many investors expect the merger plan to be revived, and some, including Archie F. MacAllaster, chairman of the securities firm MacAllaster Pitfield MacKay, expect Allmerica Property stock to be bought at about $27 a share, even  as high as $30. Allmerica Property closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $23.375, down 37.5 cents, somewhat below its peak of $24.625 on Sept. 26. **********An alternative, said Ira Zuckerman, an analyst at UBS Securities, would be for Allmerica Financial to sell its stake in the property and liability insurer  at a price well above its current level. And if there is no sale or merger of the property insurer, he said, "you still have a company with a good record and above average earnings potential." **********Mr. Theriault of T. Rowe Price expects that Allmerica Property is likely to be merged with its namesake, but doubts that the terms of that combination will  be much of a windfall for investors in the property insurer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/world.main_headline: U.S. Is Cast in the Role Of Serbia's New Best Pal
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/world.print_headline: U.S. Is Cast in the Role Of Serbia's New Best Pal
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/world.body_text: **********In a play that is drawing packed houses here, the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, returns from the peace talks in Dayton, Ohio, with a souvenir bed cover fashioned from an outsized American flag. **********And his wife, Mira Markovic -- played by a man in drag with a Stalin mustache -- jealously berates her husband about the new love affair he seems to be having with Richard, as in Richard C. Holbrooke, the Assistant Secretary of State, who  held lengthy tete-a-tete sessions with Mr. Milosevic on the Bosnia peace plan. **********In creating their script, the writers were only satirizing what has become the official line: Washington has suddenly become Serbia's best friend, a notion that overturns four years of propaganda that portrayed the United States as the  archenemy. **********The morning after the signing of the Bosnian peace accord in Paris, a portrait of President Clinton and one of President Milosevic were displayed cheek by jowl on the front page of Politika, the state-run newspaper. **********The juxtaposition of the photographs was viewed as the kickoff of a new campaign in the media that Mr. Milosevic controls very closely. **********The same day, an article by the newspaper's defense correspondent, Miroslav Lazanski, said that Serbia should be considered as a candidate for NATO. **********"What are we waiting for?" Mr. Lazanski asked in an article headlined "More Than a Flirt." He cited past Yugoslav cooperation on military training and equipment with the United States as well as a pact Yugoslavia signed under Tito  in the 1950's with two other NATO members, Greece and Turkey. The article was viewed here as a reflection of the military's desire to be included in the Partnership for Peace, created for East European nations as a step toward possible NATO membership. **********After Mr. Milosevic delivered on major ingredients in the Bosnia peace accord, the Clinton Administration no longer relegated him to the pariah status  he had even a few months ago. But there are also limits on how far and how quickly the Administration wants to elevate his position, officials said. **********Mr. Clinton, for example, told Cable News Network that it was "very difficult" for him to shake Mr. Milosevic's outstretched hand at the Elysee Palace after the signing of the Bosnia peace plan in Paris last week. **********In accordance with the agreement, Washington is suspending economic sanctions against Yugoslavia, but Administration officials said that the acceptance of Serbia into Western organizations will depend on its future behavior. Mr. Milosevic is expected to push very soon for admission to the United Nations, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, all of which have declared the seat held by Yugoslavia to be vacant. **********For Mr. Milosevic to achieve any of this, Washington is looking for the Bosnia accords to be carried out and for an improvement in the human rights policies toward ethnic Albanians in the Kosovo region, an Administration official said. **********In Belgrade, the sudden emphasis on friendly ties with Washington is seen as  a power play by Mr. Milosevic, a former Communist who shows no signs of privatizing the state-run economy that is now in a shambles. **********"The United States is the only way for Milosevic to secure his place in power," said Milan Portic, the director of the Center for Serbian Studies, a small research group financed by expatriate Serbs. "His whole system is collapsing here -- the politics, the economics. He's in trouble and he needs the biggest power in the world to show to the people that he's respected." **********The United Nations sanctions, which made misery out of the daily lives of many Serbs, was seen by much of the population as the fault of Washington. Until very recently, many Belgrade taxi drivers, upon discovering their passengers were Americans, would vent their anger at the United States on the riders. **********But the metamorphosis was easy, said Milan Dozic, the chief adviser to Vuk Draskovic, the opposition leader who supports Mr. Milosevic's peace plan. **********"As a pragmatist, Milosevic knows that all satellites of the United States are in a better position than those that are not satellites," Mr. Dozic said. "It's a clumsy but aggressive try to fix relations with the United States."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/28/busin.body_text: **********The European plane maker Airbus Industrie said today that it would develop a  long-range version of its A-330 twin-engine jet, a model that would directly compete with the Boeing 767. **********The Airbus consortium said it would cost an estimated $450 million to develop the new version of the wide-body aircraft. **********Its supervisory board decided on Friday to press ahead with the new jet, which has no orders yet but is expected to enter service in the spring of 1998. **********The new model, called the A330-200, is to carry 256 passengers in a three-class configuration and with a range of more than 6,400 nautical miles. The current A330, which entered service late in 1994, can seat 335 passengers in two classes and has a range of more than 4,500 nautical miles. **********The new model will be powered by engines from the current A330 suppliers: Rolls-Royce, the Pratt & Whitney division of United Technologies, and General Electric. **********Airbus estimates overall market demand of roughly 3,000 planes in the 250-to-300-seat category over the next 20 years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/31/world.body_text: **********In this town of aluminum smelters and pulp paper mills, a small but potentially significant majority voted for a sovereign Quebec today, mirroring the broader support of the French-speaking towns and villages and articulating a resentment that Prime Minister Jean Chretien cannot afford to ignore. **********The political stakes have been particularly high in Shawinigan because this gritty factory town 100 miles northeast of Montreal forms the core of Mr. Chretien's St. Maurice election district. He climbed to political prominence cultivating a populist image as "le petit gars de Shawinigan," which is Quebecois slang for "the little guy from Shawinigan." **********The federalists won the election, but a vote for sovereignty by 55.8 percent of voters in Mr. Chretien's own constituents rejected not only his appeal to keep Canada intact, but also his claim to represent his constituents in Ottawa.  If Quebec had become sovereign, his power base would have disappeared. **********But supporters of Mr. Chretien here, while conceding that he would have to work to regain trust within his own constituency, were heartened by the narrow victory to keep Canada intact. **********"There was a wave outside Montreal and we were caught in that," said Roland Desaulniers, a former Mayor of Shawinigan who worked hard in support of Mr. Chretien. "Because we did work hard, we did move our voters to the polls." Despite the drama, voters who bundled up to go out in the chill wind looked more emotionally exhausted than excited. During the last few weeks, the debate has divided families and estranged neighbors, leaving as many as one in seven concealing how they planned to vote. **********Like many other young Quebecers, Frederick Lemire admires Lucien Bouchard, the Quebec separatist who led the campaign for sovereignty. But when it came time to cast the first vote of his life, Mr. Lemire, 18, a freshman at the local community college, chose to remain with Canada because, he said, "I'm not voting for a man, I'm voting for a country." **********But Mr. Lemire's older sisters, Stephanie, 25, and Catherine, 22, decided to  vote for separation. Stephanie, who has looked for work since graduating from college three years ago, told her mother, Marie Lajoie, "We have nothing to lose." **********Mrs. Lajoie, who like her son voted against separation, confessed that her daughters' vote upset her. But, she added, "in every family in Quebec, they are  divided." **********With more than 33,000 voters in a district that is 99 percent French-speaking, Shawinigan presented a tempting target. In the most recent provincial election, last December, the electoral district of St. Maurice voted  47.7 percent for the Parti Quebecois, which supports independence, and 39.7 percent for the Liberal Party headed by Mr. Chretien. **********This time, both sides scoured Shawinigan for votes, from high schools to nursing homes, with some campaign workers predicting a turnout of 90 percent. Marianne Paquin, who is 98, was fetched by Roger Bellmare today to vote against  sovereignty. **********Gilles Trudel, a retired journalist who calls Quebec his motherland and Canada his country, voted today to remain Canadian. He scoffed at the separatists' notion of retaining some links with Canada. "They want us to lose what we have and then negotiate to get it back," Mr. Trudel said. **********It was as if, he quipped, "you divorce your wife and you still want to go to  bed with her." **********"Chretien will have to do something in our riding," he said, using the Canadian term for election district. "He's not here, he's always having things to do." **********At Chez Sauvageau, a popular coffee shop downtown, Quebec politics usually rank just behind ice hockey as a topic for debate. But Guy Sauvageau said his customers were not talking about how they voted. "Maybe they don't want people to know what they think of it," he said. But then Mr. Sauvageau himself wasn't saying how he voted either. **********Sharon Leclair, a physical education teacher, watched Mr. Chretien emerge from voting in the suburb of LaFlorette. Like the Prime Minister, she opposes separation, but did not try to convince her neighbors. "People don't talk about  it objectively anymore; they're too close," Mrs. Leclair said. "Even at church yesterday, there were tears in their eyes." **********In Shawinigan, as in other towns, young Quebecers embraced the notion of a sovereign Quebec more vigorously than their elders. "For the young people, the yes option presents to them a different way of thinking," said Guy Laliberte, an engineer who worked in the pro-sovereignty campaign. "They have diplomas from university and they are unemployed." **********Shawinigan has been battered by economic decline for the last quarter of a century. With plentiful power from hydroelectric dams on the bend of the St. Maurice River, the town prospered until the 1970's, when the chemical industry moved out, leaving some aluminum and paper mills. The unemployment rate is estimated at 13 percent or more, forcing young people to seek jobs elsewhere. **********But Dominic Levasseur, who is 19, voted to remain part of Canada because, he  said, "it's my country and I don't want to lose it." **********"A lot of young people my age want to vote yes because it is fun, but they really don't know why," said Mr. Levasseur, a college freshman. "Canada is not perfect, but I don't know any country on this planet which is perfect, so we have to work on it."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/29/world.print_headline: BRITISH AND IRISH BREAK ULSTER JAM
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/29/world.body_text: **********The British and Irish Governments broke a logjam in the Northern Ireland peace effort tonight, forging an agreement that they said should lead to participation by political representatives of the Irish Republican Army in negotiations over the future of the embattled province. **********But in a clear sign of how difficult the path toward full-fledged negotiations remains, tonight's agreement deferred any immediate attempt to resolve the issue that has held up the start of talks for months: Prime Minister John Major's insistence that the I.R.A. give up some of the weapons it used in its long guerrilla campaign against Britain if it wants its political wing, Sinn Fein, to have a seat at the talks. The I.R.A. has refused to turn over any weapons. **********The agreement came just hours before President Clinton was to arrive here for the start of a four-day European trip that includes a visit to Northern Ireland on Thursday. **********Its main achievement was to set a target date of the end of February for the  start of the first full-scale negotiations among the British and Irish Governments and political parties representing both the province's Protestant majority and its Catholic minority. **********The Governments said they would try to deal with the weapons issue by creating an independent three-member international commission, to be headed by former Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, to study the question and make recommendations to the Governments by mid-January. **********The recommendations would be nonbinding and the British Government could still postpone the start of full negotiations if the I.R.A. proves unwilling to  give up any guns or bombs or the two sides cannot reach a compromise. **********The deal also called for an immediate start to "preparatory" talks in which the parties will discuss with one another in various combinations how full-fledged negotiations would proceed. Mr. Major and Prime Minister John Bruton of Ireland said the combination of the independent commission and the preparatory talks would give the peace effort new momentum after months of stalemate. **********Leaders of unionist parties representing Protestants in Northern Ireland said the agreement was a "fudge" that provided no assurances that the I.R.A. would renounce violence completely. **********Gerry Adams, the leader of Sinn Fein, said he had not seen the text of the agreement. **********"When Sinn Fein is briefed on the detail of tonight's agreement, we will explore this as positively as we have all other propositions to reestablish the  peace process," he said. **********The agreement came after days of negotiations between London and Dublin. After reaching a deal around 8 P.M. today, Mr. Bruton flew to London from Dublin to announce the agreement alongside Mr. Major in a late-night news conference at No. 10 Downing Street. **********The two Prime Ministers said they had not been pressed by the American Government to reach a deal before Mr. Clinton's arrival, although they were clearly happy to have done so. Mr. Bruton said the Clinton Administration, which has taken an active role in the peace effort and has sought to portray progress  as evidence of its growing foreign policy prowess, had played some part in working out tonight's compromise. **********A White House official said tonight in London that Administration officials "played a facilitating role," but that "credit belongs to the Governments." **********As he left the White House tonight to fly to London, Mr. Clinton saluted the  leaders of Britain and Ireland "for their vision, their courage and for their leadership for peace." **********He said that today's announcement "brings the people of Northern Ireland one  step closer to the day when the only barriers that their children will face are the limits of their dreams." **********The agreement was reached 15 months after the I.R.A. unilaterally announced that it would halt its campaign of bombings and other attacks in favor of trying to negotiate a political settlement. **********Both Prime Ministers said at the news conference that their aim was to restore momentum to the peace effort without forcing any side to compromise any  of its principles at this point. **********"Reaching this agreement has been neither easy nor quick," Mr. Major said. **********Mr. Major has long argued that unless the I.R.A. is willing to give up some arms as evidence that it has forsaken violence for good, the Protestant Unionist parties that support keeping Northern Ireland part of Britain will never agree to take part in negotiations involving Sinn Fein. **********In a gesture to the Ulster Unionists, the largest of the Protestant parties and one that Mr. Major relies on as a political ally in Parliament, the agreement mentions that the preparatory talks could include consideration of creating an elected Northern Ireland Assembly, an idea promoted by the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble. **********The preparatory talks are to take place simultaneously with the work of the independent panel studying the weapons issue in what British and Irish diplomats call the "twin track" approach. **********Mr. Major said he was in no way signaling any change in his position on the need for the I.R.A. to turn in some weapons. The agreement also explicitly rejects a demand by Sinn Fein that the presence of British troops and police forces in Northern Ireland be considered as part of any disarmament moves recommended by the international commission. **********The agreement said the commission would "identify and advise on a suitable and acceptable method for full and verifiable decommissioning" of weapons and would "report whether there is a clear commitment on the part of those in possession of such arms to work constructively to achieve that." **********The Governments said they would agree on two other members of the panel. British officials said that they would probably be a Scandinavian and a Canadian, and that they would be appointed in coming days. **********Both Britain and Ireland are clearly hoping that Mr. Clinton's visit to Belfast and Londonderry on Thursday will help strengthen opinions among both Protestants and Catholics in the province that there should be no return to violence and that both sides will need to compromise to forge a lasting peace.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/26/busin.main_headline: EARNING IT;Michael Ovitz: The 5 Million Option Man at Walt Disney
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/26/busin.print_headline: EARNING IT;Michael Ovitz: The 5 Million Option Man at Walt Disney
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/26/busin.body_text: **********SO just how much will Michael Ovitz make at Disney? That's been the big question since he stunned Hollywood, where money is a serious topic indeed, by leaving his mighty empire at the Creative Artists Agency. **********After all, when Mr. Ovitz was being courted by Edgar Bronfman Jr., president  of Seagram's, to run MCA, the numbers being tossed about would have made even Bill Gates notice, with the rumor mill putting a possible pay package around $300 million. But whatever it was, it wasn't enough, and in June Mr. Ovitz declared that nothing could lure him from his beloved agency. **********But in August he was indeed lured away. How -- in cold, hard numbers -- did  Disney do it? Nobody was talking at first, but the Walt Disney Company did let on two weeks ago that Mr. Ovitz had been granted options to buy five million of  its shares. Options are nebulous things, though; you can't run out right away and buy groceries, or Ferraris, with them. Disney won't say what they're worth,  so some figuring is in order. **********Who better to turn to than Graef S. Crystal, relentless tallier of corporate  pay -- and critic of pay that's too high. **********Mr. Crystal, as it happens, helped work out Mr. Ovitz's pay package -- as a favor to Michael Eisner, Disney's chairman. But Mr. Crystal had a condition: that he be allowed to comment freely after it became public. "You'll make those  comments anyway," Mr. Eisner said, agreeing to the inevitable. **********The options give Mr. Ovitz the right to buy the stock at $57, about what Disney shares sold for when the options were granted. One could argue that since the stock might not go up, the options could wind up worthless. But as Mr. Crystal points out, even if Disney goes, say, from $57 to $77 in 10 years, for a feeble 3.1 annual rise -- if, as Mr. Crystal puts it, "he only hits a slow grounder" -- Mr. Ovitz still pockets $100 million. **********So those options are clearly worth something, and Mr. Crystal, of the University of California at Berkeley, uses what he calls an "elegant mathematical model" based on projected stock action for estimating that value. Here's what he came up with: **********For one thing, "to say he has five million is a misnomer," Mr. Crystal said,  because Mr. Ovitz gets access to a million options a year starting after three years, and he has a five-year contract. "Suppose in five years Disney said, 'Hey, Michael, you didn't do as well as we'd hoped' and let him go? He'd forfeit two million of them." **********So Mr. Crystal treated the first three million separately. Those, his formula told him, were worth $23.65 each, or $71 million. Because of the uncertainty, he put a lower, "purely arbitrary" value on the remaining two million: $18 apiece,  or $36 million. That makes a grand total of $107 million, about a third of the rumored MCA deal. **********But that's still serious money -- up there with the $111 million that Mr. Crystal estimates Ted Turner is getting over five years at Time Warner. It would put Mr. Ovitz far ahead of other No. 2 executives. **********Mr. Crystal would have preferred more moderation -- that's a big crusade of his. And, as he said, "the Disney board would have loved to get Ovitz on the cheap." But the agent is a "great bargainer," he said. **********"That's how he made his living," Mr. Crystal said. "And you can bet he was plying his negotiating skills to the hilt." **********And Mr. Ovitz, he said, "had tremendous bargaining power -- he wasn't your typical No. 2, a faceless M.B.A. with a good track record running the steam turbine division." Also, he added, you must factor in "the grim-reaper factor" -- the fact that Mr. Eisner had heart surgery recently and Disney was desperate  for a strong No. 2. **********For all the huge numbers, Mr. Crystal ticked off some goodies that Mr. Ovitz  didn't get: an upfront bonus or a guaranteed future bonus, both increasingly common. **********You can bet there will be a hefty bonus, though. Mr. Eisner's has averaged $5.7 million for 10 years, and Mr. Crystal's rule of thumb is that No. 2 executives get roughly 75 percent of the boss's bonus -- an added $4.3 million a year. **********And his salary? "Your eyebrows will not rise when you see it." Mr. Eisner gets $750,000 and has for years, and Mr. Crystal said Mr. Ovitz's will be in that range. But you can probably get by on such a paltry paycheck when you've already been given a $100 million welcome.
