https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/06/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Comedy Central Account in Review
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/06/busin.body_text: **********The Comedy Central cable television network said yesterday that it was talking to several New York agencies about its account, which has been at Korey  Kay & Partners in New York for the last two years. The billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million. **********Tony Fox, a spokesman for Comedy Central in New York, which is a joint venture of Time Warner Inc. and Viacom Inc., confirmed reports of the review this week in trade publications. He said it was prompted by management changes at the network and added that Comedy Central wanted an agency that would work closely with its in-house team. Korey Kay will participate in the review, he added, but he declined to disclose the others involved. A decision is expected in the next two weeks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/13/busin.body_text: **********In September 1993, Arnold P. Cohen arrived in Eldersburg, Md., as chief executive of the London Fog Corporation, the raincoat maker. He soon announced that he was closing the company's five plants there, moving production overseas  and the headquarters to Darien, Conn. **********"The reality is that the fashion industry is located in Manhattan and we wanted to move closer," Mr. Cohen told reporters. **********The reality is also that Darien is even closer to Westport, Conn. -- about a 20-minute drive -- than to New York's Fashion Avenue. And Mr. Cohen had a home in Westport. **********In August 1994, with the company dizzy and near financial collapse, Mr. Cohen, who said his predecessors had decided to move to the New York area, exited. In January of this year, only two months after the migration was completed, a new chief offered a new idea, since adopted: head back to Eldersburg. **********An isolated case? Hardly. London Fog's move was just one of many corporate relocations in which a declaration of high corporate purpose happens to coincide with making the boss's life more convenient. **********Earlier this year, Albert J. Dunlap, an avid golf and tennis player, announced plans to move the Scott Paper Company from Philadelphia to Boca Raton, Fla. The announcement came just days after he bought a $1.8 million home there.  Over dinner before the move, he had told a local member of Congress that it could be his first home or his second. Mr. Dunlap confirmed recently that his wife was not so coy. According to an account that he did not dispute, she had said, "I don't know about you, Al, but it's going to be my first home." **********Just last month, Tenneco Inc. announced a move from Houston to Greenwich, Conn. Dana G. Mead, the chief executive, said he wanted to shuck his company's oil-patch image. Yes, he lived in Greenwich for four years until he joined Tenneco in 1992, he said, but wanting to go back there played no role in the decision. **********Mr. Mead might study the example of Armco Inc. , the steelmaker. The company, wanting to diversify and distance itself from its smokestacks, moved in 1985 from Middletown, an Ohio steel town, to Parsippany, N.J. Eight years later, after continuing losses, the company moved back to steel country, to Pittsburgh, under a new chief, a Pittsburgh native. **********Executives seldom need prompting to provide business rationale for relocations. But many bosses seem most alert to the rationale for moving to Connecticut's executive havens or, increasingly, to southern Florida's beachfront resort areas, where the golf season never ends. Larry Pelton, a business recruiter in Palm Beach County, which includes Boca Raton, boasts that  he is in relocation talks with four Fortune 500 companies whose top executives all have local homes. **********Although statistics are few, relocation specialists and attentive investors say corporations are becoming more mobile, with executive fancy figuring ever larger in their moves. "It seems to be escalating," said Anne S. Hansen, deputy  director of the Council of Institutional Investors, representing pension funds with $800 billion in assets. "It's our money, and it's being used to pay for moving expenses we are not really convinced are necessary." **********Having fought to limit executive pay, shareholders are starting to watch out  for bosses who turn a headquarters move into another perk. "It's just a sneakier way of getting more compensation," Ms. Hansen said. "Now that people are attuned to these sky-high compensation agreements, you're getting paid in different ways. One of the current ways to escape scrutiny for higher compensation is to move the company to your favorite place to live." **********The ability to manage by telephone, fax and computer has made it easier for a core of executives to plop down in a verdant suburb or resort, leaving everyone  else behind. Mr. Mead's new headquarters, for just 100 employees, will have the  latest in video-conferencing gear, allowing the Greenwich bosses to glare at division managers in places like Evanston, Ill.; Newport News, Va., and Houston. **********Companies moving only their top management put the cost at a few million dollars to $25 million, depending on how many go, whether the new headquarters are bought or leased and what the company considers as a relocation expense. But that does not include the human costs of dislocation or layoffs for underlings. **********As much as 90's-style chief executives talk about re-engineering, right-sizing and maximizing shareholder value, real estate agents sense a different message. "That's always been the big joke in the real estate business," said Randy Strait, a senior vice president with the Transwestern Property Company in Houston. "You try to find out where the chairman lives and show him a building nearby." **********This inspiration helps Palm Beach County convince many an executive that the  business climate is as balmy as the beaches. Besides Scott Paper, in the last few years the county has snared W. R. Grace & Company and the Thompson Medical Company from New York, and several more concerns, including the Wackenhut Corporation, from the Miami area. **********Two years ago, county planners quietly began approaching virtually any executive with a local home valued at $1 million or more. "They don't have to live in the Northeast nine months of the year and visit here three months," said Mr. Pelton, with the Business Development Board of Palm Beach County. "They can reverse that, and just visit the Northeast for three months." Instead of blowing its budget on a national publicity campaign, the development board has found it can reach all the right people just by advertising in The Palm Beach Post over the winter. **********W. R. Grace became the first big corporation to hit the local beaches when it moved to Boca Raton from New York in 1991. Chuck Suits, a spokesman, says the company's chairman at the time, the late J. Peter Grace Jr., and J. P. Bolduc, then the president, were absolutely not influenced by having vacation homes nearby. "The decision to relocate was part of an extensive three-year study of 100 cities on the Eastern Seaboard," he said. **********It was Mr. Bolduc, Mr. Dunlap said, who helped lure him and Scott Paper. Mr.  Dunlap had bought a home and moved to Boca Raton, wanting to retire there. In April 1994, Scott Paper hired and brought him to Philadelphia, buying his Boca Raton home for $3.3 million. **********But Philadelphia proved too chilly for Mr. Dunlap. In a December speech at the Union League Club, he derided the wintry climate and the city's failure to appreciate his rescue of Scott Paper and the huge payoff for shareholders. Instead, he said, reporters vilified him, presenting the plaints of workers caught in vast layoffs. **********Other cities, he said, named buildings for him, held parades for him. "Of course," said John Claypool, executive director of Greater Philadelphia First, a business development group, "those were situations where he had moved companies  to town.' **********Having slashed the size of the office staff, Mr. Dunlap next wanted to dispose of Scott's tranquil 55-acre headquarters in Philadelphia. "We had a pond, we had geese, we had walking trails," Mr. Dunlap said recently. "It was idyllic, except nothing much happened there." **********Development officials of Boca Raton took full advantage of Mr. Dunlap's discontent, offering $780,000 in local and state subsidies. Local bankers, developers, medical leaders and politicians trooped up to see him. In March, Mr. Dunlap closed on a $1.8 million mansion at the Boca Raton Hotel and Resort. A week later, he announced that he was moving the company, too. **********"My decision to move down here was done solely on economics," Mr. Dunlap said. And any demands from his wife? "She had zero influence." **********Then, four months later, Mr. Dunlap agreed to sell the company to the Kimberly-Clark Corporation for $7 billion. The merged company will keep enough jobs in Boca Raton to justify the incentives, he said. **********Tenneco, however, has decided to go for the geese, reversing the usual, southward course of the corporate flock. **********As an executive of the International Paper Company, Mr. Mead had a major role in moving the company from Manhattan to Purchase, N.Y., in 1987. He lived across the Connecticut border in the Cos Cob neighborhood of Greenwich until Tenneco recruited him as president in 1992. **********When he became chief executive of Tenneco early last year, he followed through on his predecessor's search for a new corporate home. He announced the move to Connecticut, costing as much as $25 million, last month. The destination is an estate once owned by Henry R. Luce, the co-founder of Time magazine. There, a flock of Canada geese will find a new protector. **********Mr. Mead, a Midwesterner, said Tenneco was becoming less of an energy company than a maker of auto parts, packaging and other goods, and thus needed to be near New York deal makers. "This is a business decision," he said. "We clearly picked a place where we'd like to live. But when you get down to it it's one word: New York." **********Or maybe two or three words, among them "Greenwich." Greenwich, Mr. Mead said, is "as close as you can get to New York and still be in Connecticut." **********The consultants who help corporate chiefs choose their new quarters can readily serve their own cause, too. As Moran, Stahl & Boyer, the relocation agency, prepared to move out of Manhattan in May, it was pulled in two directions. Charles K. Elliott, the second-in-command, lives in Irvington, N.Y.  But the agency's new chief lives in Atlanta. **********Trust the consultants to find a solution. Several members of the firm are going to Atlanta and others to Valhalla, N.Y., the home of the agency's parent company, a unit of the Prudential Insurance Company. Valhalla is about 15 minutes from Mr. Elliott's house. **********"We didn't think this out strategically," said W. Kurt Foreman, a consultant  at Moran, Stahl & Boyer. "We sort of did the Boca thing."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/busin.main_headline: Senate Puts Off A Vote on Veto Of Securities Bill
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/busin.print_headline: Senate Puts Off A Vote on Veto Of Securities Bill
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/busin.body_text: **********The Senate tonight put off until Friday a vote on whether to hand President Clinton the first veto override of his Presidency, as both sides in the legislative fight to rewrite the nation's security laws remained unsure of the depth of their support. **********Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat, assailed President Clinton for his Tuesday night veto of legislation that would limit fraud suits brought in the name of stockholders. Mr. Dodd, who spent much of Monday evening  trying without success to persuade Mr. Clinton to sign the bill, called Mr. Clinton's objections minor. Far worse, he said, the President had not raised his objections during the many months of negotiations over the issue. **********Mr. Dodd's public comments mirrored the private irritation that many Democratic senators felt today over Mr. Clinton's 11th-hour veto. The Senate will vote on Friday whether to enact the bill into law over Mr. Clinton's veto. **********The House voted on Wednesday to override the Presidential veto by 319 to 100, more than the needed two-thirds majority as no Democrat defected despite Mr. Clinton's plea to draft a modified measure. The vote is expected to be much closer in the Senate, where Mr. Dodd needs 66 other senators to vote against the President to obtain the needed two-thirds majority. **********That is clearly something that may be accomplished only if some Democrats who approved the measure reverse their positions to support Mr. Clinton. **********It appeared that Mr. Clinton, occupied with budget and welfare matters, did not much bestir himself today to prevent an override of his veto. A check of several Democratic senators who would be likely targets of a White House effort  to enlist support showed that few were contacted. A spokesman for Senator Jeff Bingaman, a New Mexico Democrat, said that the President had briefly spoken to Mr. Bingaman today but failed to persuade him to change his vote. **********Mr. Dodd is also the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and his comments assailing the President were an unusually harsh and public display of impatience with Mr. Clinton. "In all the months of discussion, in all the hours  of negotiations with the White House, these issues never came up," Mr. Dodd said of Mr. Clinton's reasons for vetoing the legislation. **********Just before the legislation would have become law at midnight on Tuesday without his intervention, Mr. Clinton said he thought the measure had serious flaws that would mean small investors would not even get past the courthouse door to test their claims of fraud. **********He urged Congress to modify the measure, saying he would sign a new version if a few changes were made. A senior staff aide to a Democratic senator said that many in the Senate were baffled that Mr. Clinton took so long to state his position and that it would be difficult to persuade anyone to support the President on grounds of party loyalty when Mr. Dodd, the party chairman, was so  vociferous in opposition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/08/busin.main_headline: Market Place;A Chip Order Is Cut. Result: Technology Stocks Reel.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/08/busin.print_headline: Market Place;A Chip Order Is Cut. Result: Technology Stocks Reel.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/08/busin.body_text: **********In an indication that demand may be slowing for some types of personal computers and the parts used to build them, Cirrus Logic Inc. said yesterday that one of its largest clients had too much inventory and was reducing orders for the graphics and audio computer chips that account for the largest part of Cirrus's sales and profits. **********The announcement took much of Wall Street by surprise, coming only two weeks  after many technology companies, including Cirrus, reported strong earnings for  the September quarter and predicted robust growth for the remainder of the year. The selling that followed pummeled technology stocks. [Page D12.] **********Investors and analysts were left wondering if other vendors of computer parts and products would be similarly affected. But there was no immediate consensus. **********Thomas Kurlak, a semiconductor industry analyst for Merrill Lynch, the largest institutional holder of Cirrus stock, cut his investment ratings for six chip makers. But Drew Peck, an analyst at Cowen & Company, said he believed that the news meant "in the aggregate, nothing" for broader personal computer sales. **********Cirrus said the slowdown was limited to a single customer and would not affect sales and earnings beyond the current fiscal year, which ends in March. But technology investors, who for months have feared that personal computer sales may be peaking or that computer-chip inventories are too high, expressed their doubt by selling. **********Shares of Cirrus, which said its profits in the December quarter would fall 10 to 15 percent from the September quarter, lost 31 percent of their value, falling $12.75, to $28, on volume of more than 22.5 million shares. **********The Intel Corporation, the biggest maker of computer chips, fell $4.4375, to  $66.375, as 28.2 million shares changed hands, making it the most heavily traded stock in the United States markets yesterday. Micron Technology fell $3.375, to  $61.125, and Applied Materials, a leading maker of semiconductor manufacturing equipment, fell $5.125, to $48.75. And Microsoft, which makes neither computers  nor chips but rather the software to run them, fell $4.375, to $93. **********The announcement also came a day before the Semiconductor Industry Association's monthly announcement of the book-to-bill ratio, a widely watched indicator of future demand for computer chips. The figure, which indicates the ratio of new chip orders to shipments in October, is scheduled to be released after the close of stock-market trading today. Analysts forecast that it will fall to a seasonally adjusted 1.08 from September's estimate of 1.11. That was a decline from 1.17 in August. **********Cirrus declined to specify which client had informed it of the order reduction. But Wall Street analysts speculated that the problem centered on chips sold by Cirrus to Intel, which uses them to construct the "mother boards"  that serve as the brains inside a computer. **********Mr. Peck of Cowen said that demand appeared to be declining more rapidly than expected for low-end computers, particularly those built by Packard Bell Electronics that use motherboards powered by Intel's 75- megahertz Pentium chip. **********"Consumers are moving away from the low-end computers faster than anyone thought," Mr. Peck said. But, he said, consumers are opting for more powerful machines rather than stopping their purchases of personal computers, and yesterday's announcement by Cirrus thus meant little for broader PC sales. **********Intel declined to comment on Cirrus's announcement, but Howard High, an Intel spokesman, said the company still expected orders for new products to exceed the pace of shipments during the last three months of the year. Mal Ransom, vice president of marketing for Packard Bell, also declined to comment on Cirrus's announcement but he said in a statement that the company "is experiencing a healthy demand and we are expecting a strong fourth quarter." **********Tom Rigoli, a spokesman for Cirrus, based in Fremont, Calif., said the company learned of the customer's order reduction only within the last few days. As a result, revenue for the quarter ending Dec. 31 will grow more slowly  than expected, at a rate of 3 to 5 percent from the September quarter's $317 million. **********On Oct. 23, the company said that revenue grew to a ninth consecutive record  in the September quarter and that profit rose to $33 million, up 166 percent from the comparable period a year earlier and up 45 percent from the June quarter. **********At the same time, Cirrus announced a $2 billion, five-year manufacturing expansion program, which it intended to pay for, in part, by selling six million new shares of stock and $500 million in new bonds. **********Yesterday's announcement "does not impact the company's commitments in this phased expansion," Cirrus said in a release. But Mr. Rigoli said that Cirrus "will reassess our financing alternatives" to pay for the new manufacturing plants.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/11/world.main_headline: Nobel Winner Urges End to War 'Altogether'
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/11/world.print_headline: Nobel Winner Urges End to War 'Altogether'
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/11/world.body_text: **********As he accepted the Nobel Peace Prize today, Joseph Rotblat, an 87-year-old, Polish-born physicist who now lives in Britain, called upon the nuclear powers to "abandon the out-of-date thinking of the cold war" and work to "abolish war altogether." **********Speaking at the awards ceremony here, Mr. Rotblat told the audience, which included Norway's royalty, top leaders and foreign diplomats, that a heavy duty  rests upon scientists to spurn doomsday programs and even to expose plans for nuclear weaponry. **********He added that the recent resumption of nuclear tests by France at the Mururoa atoll in the South Pacific was evidence of a dangerous trend toward greater reliance on such weapons. **********"If scientists heeded this call," he said, "there would be no new nuclear warheads, no French scientists at Mururoa, no new chemical and biological poisons. The arms race would be over.". **********Mr. Rotblat was interrupted with applause when he cited the example of Mordechai Vanunu of Israel, who is serving an 18-year prison sentence for leaking details of Israel's nuclear program. **********Mr. Rotblat shares the $1.1 million peace prize with his colleagues in the Pugwash Conferences on Science and World Affairs, the anti-nuclear group he helped found after quitting the Manhattan Project, a team of scientists working  to develop the first atomic bomb during World War II, because he said he believed the project was not necessary for an Allied victory. **********Mr. Rotblat and other scientists, including Albert Einstein and Linus Pauling, founded Pugwash in 1957 to enable scientists to take responsibility for their inventions, especially nuclear weapons. **********The white-haired, ramrod-straight Mr. Rotblat smiled broadly upon receiving the gold medal and diploma at the awards ceremony here. **********He was later honored with a traditional torchlight parade through downtown Oslo and a banquet. **********Even if nuclear stockpiles are destroyed, the technology and risk of a new arms race will remain, he said. **********"The only way to prevent it is to abolish war altogether," Mr. Rotblat said.  "The quest for a war-free world has a basic purpose: survival."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/28/busin.body_text: **********Marriott International Inc. said today that Marriott Management Services, which it owns, had acquired Taylorplan Services Ltd., a British provider of custodial and food services. Financial terms were not disclosed. Marriott Management Services said Taylorplan had annual sales of nearly $100 million and  clients that included the British Ministry of Defense, the European Parliament, the European Commission and a number of hospitals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/20/world.body_text: **********When Nadine Tweig discovered she was pregnant four years ago, she filed a form and began to collect $150 a month starting in her fourth month of pregnancy. It is a subsidy that is extended to every mother in France regardless of economic or marital status. **********Two years ago, when Ms. Tweig became pregnant again, the subsidy doubled, and it will continue until her two boys reach 18. Throughout pregnancy all Ms. Tweig's medical needs, check-ups and medication were free of charge and free of  burdensome paper work or delays at a government-financed clinic not far from her upper-middle-class neighborhood around Avenue Daumesnil in Paris. **********Last year Ms. Tweig's companion, Alfred, a photographer, was seriously wounded covering the conflict in Chechnya. He was flown back to France and spent nearly two months in a specialized hospital for war wounds in Paris, incurring no expenses, then recuperated at home for another two months with full pay guaranteed by the state. **********Ms. Tweig went to the Office of Family Allocations in her neighborhood to explain that she needed some help around the house to cope with her convalescing companion, her job as a free-lance writer and her children. After an hourlong interview, she was assigned a housekeeper for a few weeks. She paid about $3 an  hour and the social security fund picked up the remaining $7 per hour. **********"This is the foundation of our Republican system," Ms. Tweig said in an interview. "It goes back to the French revolution. Equality and fraternity are not mere slogans here.  For me the engagement by the state is an expression of solidarity that gives us values." **********Indeed, the message that people matter more was at the heart of a three-week  strike by public workers and the hundreds of thousands of demonstrators who filled the streets of every major city in France. The strike, the country's most serious labor unrest in a decade, was called to protest Prime Minister Alain Juppe's proposal to slash medical, social welfare and benefit payments in an effort to plug a widening budget deficit. **********The Government, and most economists, say the very economic strength that has  permitted France's generous benefits is in serious jeopardy. But the attitude of citizens like Ms. Tweig, multiplied millions of times over, shows why France appears headed for more confrontation over spending policies. **********"I think most French people want France's values to be decided by this spirit, not by cold, remote, economic summits that speak of deficits and competition," says Ms. Tweig. "That was the message of the strikes. People are worried the Government is retreating with its austerity plans and talk of balanced budgets. They told it to find another way." **********Larger, poorer families can and do benefit from an amazing array of Government-financed benefits that include paid yearly holidays and transportation to a sea or mountain resort. The Government pays for moving expenses, care at home for older people, subsidized apartments, and even dishwashers and washing machines for those who cannot afford them and have large families. **********In the greater Paris region, where people are encouraged to use mass transit, employers are required to pick up half the commuting cost for their employees. Apartment building owners cannot evict tenants who are unable to pay the rent during winter months and are granted tax breaks to alleviate the financial burden until warmer weather. **********Welfare includes issues like the right of each office employee to have a window from where the person can see "either sunset or sunrise." Five weeks of vacation is mandatory. In so-called high-stress jobs, like medical professions or journalism, vacations extend to nine weeks and are complemented by tax breaks. **********Throughout France, citizens are entitled by law to free schooling through a university education.  From day care through high school, subsidized meals are included. Together these benefits and many others constitute a form of subsidy that, in the end, allows people of limited income to stretch their life style beyond their means. **********Ms. Tweig says the safety net has allowed her considerable peace of mind. More importantly, she says she believes that it fulfills an essential social purpose. **********One of the most memorable comments on the upheaval cited by many here was made by a middle-aged railroad worker whose income is about $1,400 a month. He stared into the camera and declared that what drove him to revolt was that "you  can't go the theater anymore." **********Numa Murard, a sociology professor, said, "This worker's comment captured a wonderful moment in my opinion because it showed how, through decades of social  engagement, we have created a sophisticated people to a point that a simple worker believes it is his right -- indeed his human right -- to go to the theater and to eat at a decent restaurant on Sunday." **********"In some other countries these are considered privileges deserved by only a few," he said. **********Polls showed an astonishing amount of sympathy on the part of those who did not participate in the strike and who suffered the paralysis of mass transit and essential services. Many people explained that they supported the strike because the Government's austerity programs are stripping layer after layer of subsidies that permitted French families of even the most modest means to sample the cultural and culinary treasures that only the rich can afford. The strike and the protests were a defense of a way of life that brought cohesion and social peace to France for decades. **********With the strike now slowly winding down, sociologists, labor union leaders and most politicians agree that the three weeks of unrest will remain a decisive moment that political leaders can ignore at their peril. They see the public solidarity as a wake-up call comparable to other uprisings like the 1968 student-worker upheaval or even, some say, the French revolution itself. **********"The French have rediscovered they can revolt after years of listening to politicians telling them that such bursts of anger produce catastrophes," said Dr. Gerard Miller, a psychoanalyst and political commentator. "The message was:  market rules are not our problems, and don't expect us to be 'reasonable' anymore or put ourselves in the place of our bosses." **********In an editorial, the left-leaning French daily Liberation wondered: "At this  point what is the fight about? Salaries? Jobs? The absence of a future? The survival of Public Service? The cancellation of the Juppe plan?" It added that the malaise touched on "all of it in the same time without doubt, and probably a thousand other things." **********Those thousand other things that have made France a far more egalitarian society than most Western industrial countries provide a cushion that also permits children of the disadvantaged a fair chance to jump to the middle class  in one generation. **********Sociologists and political scientists have argued during the last three weeks that the principal reform should start with the politicians. **********They said the best and the brightest of the ruling establishment, like President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Juppe, are increasingly the product  of an elitist system. **********"They have become cold machines disconnected from reality except at the level of taxi drivers and their cleaning ladies," noted Marc Bessin, a sociologist at  Rouen, in a conversation here. "When someone cries very loudly at your window, you don't order double-pane windows." **********That message seems to have registered even with hardened right-wingers among  French politicians this week, including Charles Pasqua, the tough former Interior Minister known for his aggressive bulldog demeanor. "What's more important is not the confidence of the market but the confidence of the French people," Mr. Pasqua, who remains a formidable power in the conservative coalition Government, said on television the other day. **********"You cannot run a country without the people."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/10/busin.main_headline: EARNING IT;In This Buyback, the Stock Is Your Frequent-Flier Mileage
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/10/busin.print_headline: EARNING IT;In This Buyback, the Stock Is Your Frequent-Flier Mileage
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/10/busin.body_text: **********IF employees were asked to chisel Ten Commandments for their chief executives, many lists would probably include, "Thou shalt not covet thy workers' frequent-flier mileage." **********But a small but growing band of companies, concerned about travel costs, are  breaking that commandment by cutting employees a deal: If you use your frequent-flier miles to get a ticket for a business trip, the company will pay you a percentage of what that ticket would have cost. **********According to Randy Petersen, who runs Frequent Flyer Services, which helps companies capture mileage earned by employees, the number of such buyback programs has doubled in each of the last four years, to about 3,000 nationwide. **********Unisys, the computer maker, has one of the more established programs. Since 1989, the company has been offering to pay its employees half the value of the ticket. Ed Sterba, director of corporate travel, said the program had saved Unisys about $200,000 to $400,000 a year out of its $50 million annual air travel budget. About 200 to 400 people are in the voluntary plan, he said. **********Corporations that adopt a buyback program generally follow a 50 percent rule. It works like this: If employees need to take flights with a lowest available fare of, say, $600, they can choose to use their own frequent-flier mileage and  are paid $300 to do so, less the income tax, Social Security tax and other payroll taxes on that amount. **********But the programs do meet resistance. Airlines object strongly, for example, noting that frequent-flier mileage is not supposed to be purchased, sold or bartered. **********"It is definitely outside of our rules and violates the spirit of our agreements," said Tim Smith, a spokesman for American Airlines, who added that it was a difficult problem to police. **********Nine out of 10 companies allow employees to keep their miles, according to recent surveys by American Express and Runzheimer International, and workers often oppose efforts to take them away. **********Texaco, for example, perceived that the mileage from employees' flights was its property. But the oil company quickly backed away from any action after deciding that the destructive effects on morale and the administrative headaches were not worth the savings. **********"Most companies throw in the towel," said Rolfe Shellenberger, senior consultant in travel management for Runzheimer. In some cases, Mr. Shellenberger said, companies that keep frequent-flier miles find that the policy hurts recruiting efforts.    BUT the forces pushing for buyback plans are also powerful. Industry experts  say the plans can save companies 10 percent of their travel budgets. **********Many companies have also been concerned that when employees are allowed to keep frequent-flier mileage, they may be tempted to take longer or more expensive trips to pad their mileage accounts. **********Such a concern helped the Boeing Company decide to keep mileage for its own use ever since frequent-flier programs were introduced in the early 1980's. **********"To put our employees in that kind of subtle tug on their integrity is something we don't think is a healthy thing," Bob Jorgensen, a spokesman for Boeing, said. **********To counter the argument of Boeing employees that the mileage should be a form of compensation for business trips that cut into weekends, the company told them to travel only during workdays. If they travel on Saturday or Sunday, they are paid overtime. **********There have been other corporate initiatives that have put employee frequent-flier miles at risk. A group called the Business Travel Contractors Corporation, for instance, is trying to help companies use their collective buying power to strip air fares of traditional costs, like commissions, and base them on distance flown. **********One of the group's early proposals had been to cut out frequent-flier mileage. It has since dropped that idea, because the airlines said such a move would dilute the value of the programs, and they have refused to negotiate about it. **********"We jettisoned it as a requirement because we didn't want to throw the baby out with the bath water," said Kevin P. Mitchell, president of Business Travel.  "The objection from the airlines was strong." **********Use or Lose **********A reminder to members of American Airlines' frequent-flier program: Some of your miles may be worthless on Jan. 1. **********According to the rules of American's mileage plan, which has about 28 million members, miles earned in 1992 expire at the end of this calendar year. Although  other airlines also have time limits, American is the only major airline with an end-of-year deadline. **********Some members may have enough miles for a certificate for a free trip or an upgrade that would be valid for another year. Members can also donate miles to various charities with which American is affiliated. **********The toll-free number for American's frequent-flier program is (800) 882-8880.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/05/world.main_headline: Deadly Virus Spreads From Horses to Men in Australia
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/05/world.print_headline: Deadly Virus Spreads From Horses to Men in Australia
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/05/world.body_text: **********Troy Rail, 24, an Australian jockey, was born to race. His father, Vic Rail,  was a renowned horse trainer along Australia's sun-soaked Gold Coast, where thoroughbred racing is a sporting obsession second only to surfing. **********Despite their shared mastery of horse care, neither father nor son could figure out why the horses in the family's stables outside Brisbane were beginning to die. **********They wouldn't eat," Troy Rail said. "That was the first sign that something was wrong -- and then they really began to suffer." He shuddered at the memory of the animals' tortured deaths last year. "First they'd get a twitch," he said. "Then they began to shake, bashing themselves into the wall." **********Within days, 14 horses had died, their lungs filling with so much blood and other fluid that they drowned. And whatever killed the horses was beginning to kill Vic Rail. The 49-year-old trainer died a week after he entered the hospital in September 1994, his lungs dissolving. **********Only a few months before the attention of the world's scientists was drawn to an outbreak of the deadly Ebola virus in the central African country of Zaire last spring, Australian scientists were scrambling to solve a viral mystery of their own. **********It has turned out to be among the most ominous medical mysteries in this country's history -- a threat to human lives as well as to Australia's $2 billion horse racing industry. **********After a yearlong investigation that is considered a model of its kind, Australian scientists have identified the killer, a cross-species virus related  to measles, and believe they know how it was spread from the horses to Mr. Rail. **********But the threat may not have been contained. Investigators were startled in October when a 35-year-old Australian horse farmer in Mackay, about 475 miles northwest of here, died after contracting the virus. Investigators say it may have lain dormant in his body for several months before killing him. **********"There is no sense of panic, but there is a sense of urgency about this," said Steve Bishop, a spokesman in Brisbane, the capital of the state of Queensland, for the state Health Ministry. "There is a desire to determine exactly where this comes from." **********The organism has been identified as a morbillivirus, the viral family that includes canine distemper and human measles. Equine morbillivirus, as the Australians called it, is the first member of that virus family to afflict more  than one species. **********It is also the first member of that virus family discovered in humans since measles were first described nearly 1,000 years ago by the Persian physician Rhazes. **********Dr. Keith Murray, chief of the Australian Animal Health Laboratory, which first isolated the virus, said investigators were trapping and taking blood samples from small animals in Queensland to test a theory about the source of the virus -- that the virus thrives in the bloodstream of small animals and becomes deadly only when transmitted to horses, humans and other large creatures. **********"Everybody would love to know what the source is," Dr. Murray said in an interview at the high-security animal laboratory outside Melbourne, its futuristic autopsy rooms and crematory reachable only through a series of air locks and bolted steel doors. "If you know what the source is, you know how to deal with it." **********Investigators say the farmer who died this fall, Mark Preston, may have been  infected when he took part in the autopsy of a horse last year, a bloody procedure that would have allowed for transmission of the virus. **********Mr. Rail, the first victim, apparently contracted the virus when he force-fed the dying horses in his stables, pushing his hand down their throats. **********"Vic Rail was very dedicated to his horses and trying desperately to save them," said Chris Baldock, an epidemiologist who was a member of the scientific  team sent to the Rail farm. "So he was left with scratches all over his arms and hands." **********Medical investigators were called to the stables on Sept. 22, 1994, and took  samples of lung, spleen and blood from horses that had died hours earlier. Initially, investigators suspected that the horses had died of poisoning. **********But tests on the samples showed that the cause was a previously unidentified  virus that caused the cells lining the blood vessels of the lungs to clump together, creating holes in the vessel walls so that fluid leaked into the lungs. **********The Government declared a emergency, placing horses in other nearby stables under quarantine, and ordered a halt to racing around Brisbane for several days. Later tests on humans and horses in the area found no sign of the virus, which had apparently been contained by the quick action of the investigators. **********But the scientists' peace of mind was shattered this fall with the death of Mr. Preston. Medical investigators have descended on his farm, performing blood  tests on dozens of horses and on Mr. Preston's neighbors. The farmer's wife, a veterinarian, has tested negative for the virus. **********Mr. Bishop, the ministry spokesman, said, "We're testing everybody."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Tacos and ice cream for Christmas? More companies are sporting red and green.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Tacos and ice cream for Christmas? More companies are sporting red and green.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/busin.body_text: **********SANTA CLAUS, reindeer, snowflakes and ribbons are fast becoming the shock troops in a seasonal marketing war. **********While many advertisers traditionally rewrap their prosaic products in colorful, eye-catching holiday dress, this year's seasonal push is already showing signs of being more aggressive and more broad based than in Christmases past. **********Not only is the assault of holiday packaging this year beginning earlier, but marketers who have not previously participated are also clambering aboard the tinsel-bedecked bandwagon -- much to the dismay of critics of commercialism  or those who wince at whimsy. **********"For the holidays, we thought it would be good to do something festive, decorative, bright and fun," said Vivien Godfrey, vice president at Haagen-Dazs  North America in Minneapolis. "It really does jump out at you." **********In the company's initial holiday foray, Haagen-Dazs, a unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., is festooning pints and quarts of its vanilla ice cream with red-ribbon graphics. And as long as they appear to be wrapped, why not give them away? Television commercials and billboards by Partners & Shevack in New York, owned by the Mickelberry Corporation, promote Haagen-Dazs as a "cool gift." Ms. Godfrey suggested taking ice cream to a party or someone's home rather than "flowers, chocolate or a bottle of wine." **********Elsewhere on the nontraditional gift front, the Taco Bell Corporation, a unit of Pepsico Inc., is for the first time offering booklets redeemable for $5 worth of fast food at its restaurants. The "Border Bucks" gift promotion will be supported by spots scheduled to start running on Dec. 3, which were created by Bozell/Salvati Montgomery Sakoda, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt in Costa Mesa, Calif. **********The gift booklets are being offered in response to "so many requests" for such a promotional item, said Laurie Gannon, a spokeswoman for Taco Bell in Irvine, Calif., who added that they were tested among consumers before being introduced. The promotion is meant to supplement a holiday decoration program that will return for a second year, Ms. Gannon said, which includes "fun, edgy"  western-themed designs for cups, tray liners and the restaurants themselves. **********Perhaps the most intensive holiday bombardments are being ordered by the nation's soft-drink giants, Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola, which are taking advantage of high-tech innovations in graphics to produce particularly elaborate seasonal  packaging. **********On 743 million cans of its Coca-Cola Classic, the Coca-Cola Company is adding a series of drawings of the familiar "Sundblom Santa" -- the jolly Santa Claus created for the company from 1931 to 1966 by the artist Haddon Sundblom. The promotion is the focus of a 60-second commercial, laden with special effects that simulate a "Christmas caravan" of lighted Coke trucks, by W. B. Doner & Company in Southfield, Mich. **********"What we've tried to do this year is use the Santa as a vehicle to connect with consumers in a more meaningful way than we have in the past," said Frank Bifulco, vice president for marketing at the Coca-Cola USA operations unit of Coca-Cola in Atlanta. **********"People are trying to re-create an idealized holiday time in their minds," he added, "and we've found through research that we are part and parcel of that." **********Pepsi-Cola, as is its wont, is taking a hipper tack. Holiday cans of four varieties of Pepsi products, covered with stylized reindeer, stars and skiers, are being packed inside more than 10 million shiny silver holographic versions of the company's Cube, or 24-pack of cans. **********"The real key is to enhance your imagery during the holiday period," said Rob Meyer, package innovation director for the Pepsi-Cola Company unit of Pepsico in Somers, N.Y. **********"It's fun and exciting and impactful for the consumer," he added, "as well as for the retailer, because it dresses up the store a little." **********The marketers dispute a suggestion that their efforts serve to replace the S's in Christmas with dollar signs. **********"I would hope we would not be viewed as guilty of doing that," said Mr. Bifulco of Coca-Cola USA, because "we're doing in many ways what consumers say they're expecting."
