https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/01/busin.main_headline: Dow Chemical in the Center of a Storm
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/01/busin.print_headline: Dow Chemical in the Center of a Storm
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/01/busin.body_text: **********Earlier this year, executives of the Dow Chemical Company regarded the legal  storm over silicone breast implants with a certain level of calm. But suddenly the company is finding itself heading down the treacherous road already traveled by several implant makers. **********Just a few months ago, the giant chemical company figured that its liability  would be, at worst, the $330 million value of its 50 percent stake in the Dow Corning Corporation. Dow Corning was the largest producer of breast implants in  the country, but a much smaller company than Dow Chemical, which last year had $20 billion in revenues. **********Also, Dow Chemical had not had to contribute to the $4.25 billion class action settlement on implant claims reached in late 1993, and Judge Sam C. Pointer Jr. of Federal District Court in Birmingham, Ala., had effectively dismissed it from liability in other breast implant lawsuits. **********But in the world of high-stakes litigation, events can quickly turn. **********In rapid succession, Judge Pointer reversed his decision, the global settlement failed and Dow Corning plunged into bankruptcy. **********Then, this week, a Nevada jury ordered Dow Chemical to pay $14.1 million in compensatory and punitive damages to a woman who said she was injured by breast  implants, the first time the company has been held solely liable in such a case. **********The company, which contends that it had nothing to do with the development or testing of the implants, has said that it will appeal and will fight every breast implant case. **********The Nevada case has focused a sudden light on the long and sometimes tangled  relationship between Dow Chemical and Dow Corning. And it has raised questions about Dow Chemical's strategy in the litigation and its eventual cost. **********More than 13,000 implant suits are pending in which Dow Chemical is the defendant or co-defendant, and even company lawyers acknowledge that it is only  a matter of time before some more come to trial. **********Referring to the Nevada case, Herbert L. Zarov, a lawyer for Dow Chemical, said, "This decision will encourage plaintiffs." **********The award has already caused some jitters. On Monday, James Wilbur, a chemical industry analyst with Smith Barney, downgraded Dow Chemical stock to "neutral" from "buy," citing falling chemical prices and the short-term uncertainty produced by the Nevada case. Dow's stock price dropped 87.5 cents on Monday and $1.25 yesterday, ending at $68.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. That represents a two-day loss of 3 percent of its value. **********As part of its defense in the Nevada trial, Dow Chemical pointed to numerous  studies that failed to find a link between silicone and serious health problems. But it also made clear that it was ready to play legal hardball. Its lawyers argued, for example, that the injuries claimed by Charlotte Mahlum, the plaintiff in the case, had resulted from spousal abuse rather than her implants. **********But the jury proved more interested in the relationship between Dow Chemical  and Dow Corning, one that dates back to 1943, when military officials asked Dow  Chemical and Corning Inc. to produce silicone coatings to insulate the electrical wiring of high-altitude aircraft. That military marriage created Dow  Corning, and the two larger companies have continued to hold equal stakes in their offspring. **********Until the recent bankruptcy filing, Dow Chemical and Corning each held five seats on Dow Corning's board, with the other five filled by Dow Corning employees. But because Dow Corning and Dow Chemical have headquarters about four miles apart in Midland, Mich., the chemical company's role as a parent may have  been the closer one. **********Some Dow Chemical employees had temporary assignments at Dow Corning and, at  times, the smaller company used its parents' laboratories, court papers indicate. Also, as the debate over the safety of the implants intensified in 1992, Keith McKennon, a Dow Chemical executive who had weathered the litigation  over Agent Orange, was appointed Dow Corning's chief executive. **********Initially, lawyers representing women with implants tried to shift liability  by holding the larger and richer Dow Chemical and Corning responsible for the action of their offspring. But Judge Pointer turned back that bid in late 1993,  holding that traditional "corporate control" theories were not applicable because Dow Corning was not a joint venture or partnership. **********Undeterred, plaintiffs' lawyers returned to Judge Pointer's courtroom last year, providing what they said was new evidence showing that Dow Chemical was involved in the development of silicone and knew about the dangers of breast implants. **********Earlier this year, Judge Pointer held that Dow Chemical could be held directly liable in breast implant cases because of its involvement in silicone work. Mr. Zarov, the Dow Chemical lawyer, said the company had asked Judge Pointer to reconsider because of what he said was misleading information provided by plaintiffs' lawyers. **********He said that Dow Chemical had performed tests in the 1950's on the types of silicones that were eventually used in breast implants but that the company had  no idea at the time about that future application. **********"Dow Chemical was never asked to opine on the safety of breast implants and never did," he said. **********Whatever the case, a legal storm has broken over Dow Chemical, which appears  headed for skyrocketing legal costs and, potentially, more jury awards. With lawsuits against Dow Corning frozen, Dow Chemical is the stuff of a plaintiff lawyer's dream. That raises the prospect that Dow Chemical may change its tactics, said Judith Resnik, a law professor at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles. **********"In this litigation, the science is still new, and when there is a battle of  experts who disagree, juries say, 'Manufacturers, you bear the risk,' " Ms. Resnik said. "Dow Chemical's choices are to take the line that this didn't happen on our watch, or explore forms of settlement that adequately recognize any role they may have played."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/25/busin.main_headline: Market Place;Investors frown, but Snapple distributors see a new age.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/25/busin.print_headline: Market Place;Investors frown, but Snapple distributors see a new age.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/25/busin.body_text: **********WHEN Philip A. Marineau resigned abruptly as president and chief operating officer of the Quaker Oats Company on Monday, many on Wall Street assumed he was walking the plank for what Business Week had recently rated as the worst billion-dollar deal of the 1990's -- the acquisition of Snapple, the iced-tea and fruit-drink subsidiary that has sorely disappointed Quaker and Wall Street since Quaker paid $1.7 billion for it last year. **********But Mr. Marineau, 49, said that his decision to resign after 23 years with the company had not been sudden, that in view of the company's recent restructuring and the sale of its pet-food operations, he simply "concluded there were no longer two jobs here," for him and the company's 57-year-old chairman and chief executive, William D. Smithburg. Mr. Smithburg will now oversee the company's beverage businesses, including Snapple and Gatorade, as well as the rest of Quaker's food and international operations. **********The company depicted the resignation of Mr. Marineau as an efficiency measure. But the move did nothing to help the company's cause on Wall Street. Quaker's shares tumbled $1.25, to $33.50, on Monday and even though they edged up 12.5 cents, to $33.625, yesterday, they were still about one-third lower than they were before the Snapple acquisition last year. **********Tomorrow, Quaker is expected to report, along with its earnings, that Snapple's sales are up for the first time since the acquisition, and perhaps even that the unit has finally begun contributing to profits. Still, most analysts say it will be too little, too late to make Quaker attractive to investors. **********But those in the trenches, including Snapple distributors and the Quaker managers they are just getting used to working with, do not share Wall Street's  pessimism. They see a powerhouse just starting to roll. **********"People have to understand that the game has only just begun," said Ken Adamson, chief executive of the Capital Coors Company, a beer and beverage distributor based in West Sacramento, Calif. "Quaker has mapped a really excellent game plan for 1996." **********That represents a big change from previous years, Snapple distributors said.  Quaker came on the scene just as Snapple was reeling from its first substantial  competition since it had almost single-handedly created the "new age" category of teas and fruit drinks. Until then, Snapple's main problem had simply been to  keep up with demand. The more than 300 distributors experienced huge sales leaps each year, despite minimal support or direction from Snapple. **********By 1994, with giants like Coca-Cola and Pepsico plunging into the field and new competitors like Arizona iced tea springing up, the investors and managers who controlled Snapple were focusing their attention on finding a deep-pocketed  backer. **********But by the time the deal closed last November, there was no time to plan an effective sales and marketing campaign for 1995. The transition was also hampered by an inevitable culture clash. For Gatorade, Quaker relied primarily on a highly efficient, warehouse-based distribution system to fill sales orders  taken by brokers and Quaker sales teams. Snapple relied on sales and distribution by independent businesses, many of which had little familiarity with the kinds of detailed market research Quaker took for granted. **********"There are a lot of differences in the distributors' desire and abilities to  move Snapple forward," said John Marquardt, a Gatorade veteran who now manages Snapple distributors in the Northeast and mid-Atlantic states. Some relied on Snapple for 90 percent of their business, others only 5 percent. Winning agreements from such a varied group and communicating promotion plans to retailers proved daunting. **********The results were brutal. In the canned and bottled tea segment, Pepsico's Lipton brands raced by Snapple. Information Resources Inc., which tracks supermarket sales, said Lipton's sales rose more than 20 percent, while Snapple's fell nearly 10 percent in the selling year that ended in mid-August. Snapple also lost ground to smaller brands that grew even faster than Lipton, including Arizona. **********Now Quaker has gradually whittled away at the confusion and suspicions among  the distributors, demonstrating superior operating skills. Where they once waited up to three weeks for Snapple to fill orders and often ran out of popular products, companies like Millrose Distributors Inc. of New Brunswick, N.J., now  get 72-hour service. **********Quaker has also been introducing programs to cut down on breakage and to stimulate investment in vending machines. New packaging innovations, like 12-packs, and products like Snapple cider teas, intended for sale this fall to extend the peak summer selling season, have also helped win over distributors. **********"We'd be in much bigger trouble if Snapple hadn't sold to Quaker," said Joseph Rosamilia, Millrose's chief executive, adding that a strong rebound starting in August had lifted this summer's results 30 percent from last year. **********Still, Mr. Rosamilia's results were exceptional, and Quaker needs a lot more, including a substantial increase in Gatorade sales through the Snapple system, to quiet critics of the acquisition. **********Of course, if Snapple finally starts to outperform Wall Street's diminished expectations, it is Mr. Smithburg's reputation as a manager that will benefit, not Mr. Marineau's. "That's life in a big corporation," Mr. Marineau said cheerfully yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/23/busin.main_headline: A Zapata Director Resigns in Dispute
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/23/busin.print_headline: A Zapata Director Resigns in Dispute
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/23/busin.body_text: **********A director of the Zapata Corporation resigned last week because of his disagreement over the energy company's plans for entering the food services business. **********In his Nov. 16 resignation letter, the former director, Peter Holt, accused Zapata officials of planning to change the company's direction without adequately informing the board and after "misleading" shareholders about new investments. **********The resignation letter and a lengthy rebuttal from the company were included this week in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********Zapata officials said their proposed plan to invest in or combine with the two restaurant companies in which the company's chairman, Malcolm Glazer, owns substantial interests, were in keeping with stated and board-approved plans. **********Zapata, based in Houston, has already sold some of the oil and natural gas production assets held in its Energy Industries Inc. and Zapata Energy Industries L.P. units.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/24/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;British Water Utility Accepts Bid From France
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/24/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;British Water Utility Accepts Bid From France
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/24/busin.body_text: **********Lyonnaise des Eaux announced today that Northumbrian Water Group had accepted its $1.28 billion takeover offer. **********Lyonnaise, the first French water company to agree to buy out a big British counterpart, said it had won unanimous approval from Northumbrian's board and would pay Northumbrian shareholders L11.65 ($18.22) a share and a special dividend of 14 pence. Northumbrian shares began rising about a month ago on speculation about an offer. **********Shares of Northumbrian, one of Britain's biggest water and sewage companies, surged 41 pence today to a new high of L11.75, almost five times its value at privatization in 1989. **********"It is very clear that the water business is booming worldwide," said Jacques Petry, president of the international water division of Lyonnaise, adding that the takeover would lift earnings per share. **********He said in an interview that the takeover "will contribute to our growth worldwide and strengthen our position as a leader in the international water industry." **********Lyonnaise plans to merge Northumbrian with Lyonnaise's other British units, North East Water and Essex and Suffolk Water. Lyonnaise officials said the merger would lead to job cuts but promised that no one would be forced out, Bloomberg Business News reported. **********Customers, who paid an average of L200 ($313) a year, would also see benefits. Bills are expected to fall 15 percent by the end of 2001. The British  Government insisted on the reduction as a condition of approving the takeover earlier this month. **********Lyonnaise has a vast array of international interests, serves about 49 million people worldwide, and has won some of the world's largest water contracts, including deals in Argentina and Australia. **********The Paris-based group, which has a market capitalization of about L12 billion ($19 billion), said it had no plans to buy another water company in the next 10  years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/16/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;ITT WILL SPLIT INTO THREE COMPANIES ON TUESDAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;ITT WILL SPLIT INTO THREE COMPANIES ON TUESDAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/16/busin.body_text: **********The ITT Corporation set a date of Tuesday for its breakup into three separate companies after receiving a favorable tax ruling on the spinoffs, its chairman,  Rand V. Araskog, said yesterday. The $25 billion conglomerate announced in June  that it planned to divide itself into three parts: an insurance company, an industrial products manufacturer, and a casino, hotel and sports company. Its shareholders approved the breakup in September, but the deal was contingent on obtaining a ruling from the Internal Revenue Service that the spinoffs would be  tax free for shareholders. The company has now received the ruling from the I.R.S. Shareholders will get one share in each new company for every share they  own in ITT.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/world.main_headline: Algerian Militants Now Ready to Negotiate
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/world.print_headline: Algerian Militants Now Ready to Negotiate
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/world.body_text: **********Appearing to acknowledge a serious setback after Algeria's presidential elections, the outlawed Islamic Salvation Front called today for negotiations with President Liamine Zeroual to end the country's civil strife, which has taken tens of thousands of lives. **********Mr. Zeroual, a former army general who was appointed President by the military Government in January 1994, emerged from last week's election with 61 percent of the vote, which was taken by most analysts to be a strong mandate despite a boycott of the election by major opposition groups. **********Mr. Zeroual is certainly the valid negotiator to lead the talks on the side of the effective power," said Rabih Kebir, who lives in exile in Germany and is  the Islamic Salvation Front's most senior spokesman outside Algeria. **********Islamic militants began a campaign of violence to bring down the Government by force in January 1992 after the Government canceled legislative elections that the front was expected to win. The front was subsequently outlawed by the Government and its top leaders jailed. **********The offer from Mr. Kebir constitutes a significant retreat by the Islamic party. Previously, it repeatedly called for the resignation of Mr. Zeroual's Government, contending that that the only way to end the conflict between secular and religious political forces in Algeria was to form a national unity government. **********While Mr. Kebir is very influential, it is not certain whether he speaks for  all of the militant factions that have been fighting the Government. **********The front and two secular opposition parties called on Algerians to boycott the elections, only to find that -- according to Government figures -- 75 percent of the Algeria's 16 million eligible voters cast their ballots. Mr. Zeroual defeated three candidates, including two moderate advocates of Islamic rule. **********The moderates would accept coexistence with the secular parties. The militants demand a state in which there would be no tolerance for secular practices. **********Mr. Zeroual ran on a platform of continuing to fight radical Islamic militants while widening the political spectrum to include the secular and moderate Islamic opposition. **********Several French, Western and Arab experts view the high turnout and the results as reflecting Algerian weariness with the civil conflict and a desire to have a strong Government in place to reform the economy and to maintain stability. **********Mr. Kebir appeared to concede that the Algerian Army, which Mr. Zeroual represents, emerged as the strongest political entity in Algeria, with a degree  of popular support that cannot be ignored. **********"The Islamic Salvation Front is ready for a global solution negotiated between the effective power and opposition, a solution that could lead to peace  and stability," Mr. Kebir said in written answers to questions forwarded by the  Reuters news agency. **********He did not repeat earlier charges that the Government had tampered with the election or doctored the voter turnout figures. **********Election observers, including representatives of a number of Western and Arab Governments, said the voting had been reasonably orderly and that the results by and large appeared to reflect a fundamental change in the mood of the electorate. **********Back in 1991, when the first free parliamentary elections were held, voters chose hard-line Islamic opposition candidates, giving them 40 percent of the vote. **********By comparison, in Thursday's presidential election the two moderate Islamic candidates, Mahfoud Nehnah and Nouredin Boukrouh, received a total of 25 percent. Saeed Saadi, a secular candidate, won 9 percent. **********Algerian and Arab journalists and diplomats say the shift reflects a conviction among Algerians that the Islamic militants have been largely responsible for the blood spilled in the civil strife during the last four years, with attacks on artists, journalists, writers, teachers, unveiled women and other civilians. Islamic opposition forces often accused Government troops of indiscriminate violence against their civilian adherents, but commentators place most of the blame on the Islamic forces. **********"Between the last elections and this election, four hard years have gone by in which around 40,000 Algerian were killed," said Jihad al-Khazen, editor of the London-based Arabic daily Al Hayat. "The Islamic Salvation Front has paid the price for the rocky road it has chosen. **********"While the militants threatened to turn ballot boxes into coffins, Algerians  responded in the only way that was decisive: by going to vote in a large proportion, which must have been a surprise even for the Government." **********Commentators have praised Mr. Zeroual for daring to give his people a free choice. "He could have sat on his presidential seat without taking risks and declared the familiar 99 percent triumph vote like other Presidents in the region," wrote Abdel rahman al-Rashid, editor of the Saudi-owned London weekly Al Mijallah. **********France, the former colonial power in Algeria, which has suffered from terrorist bombings by Algerian militants in recent months because of its support of Mr. Zeroual's Government, endorsed the results but urged Algeria to move on toward municipal and parliamentary elections. **********Prime Minister Alain Juppe said the vote legitimized Mr. Zeroual. But he said the Algerian Government should engage in a discussion with all parties that accepted democratic government. He stopped short of saying the front should be included. **********Algerian officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said it was too early to say whether Mr. Zeroual would respond to the front's invitation to talk. But they said they expect the President to begin preparations soon for parliamentary elections sometime next year. **********The officials, in telephone interviews from Algeria, said moderate Islamic parties including those led by Mr. Nehnah and Mr. Boukrouh would be allowed to field candidates in the elections. But they expressed little enthusiasm for allowing the front to take part. **********In his remarks to Reuters today, Mr. Kebir said it was too early to disclose  his party's negotiating positions if Mr. Zeroual accepted the proposal for talks. He indicated that the Islamic Salvation Front's agenda would be set by the party's top leaders, who are in jail in Algeria, and by the Islamic militants organized in several underground factions that have been battling Government forces.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/02/world.main_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Apartheid-Era Minister Is Linked to Zulu Gangs
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/02/world.print_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Apartheid-Era Minister Is Linked to Zulu Gangs
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/02/world.body_text: **********A former Defense Minister was charged with murder today in a landmark indictment that alleges collusion between the apartheid-era security forces and  President Nelson Mandela's chief rival, the Zulu leader Mangosuthu G. Buthelezi. **********The former official, Gen. Magnus Malan, and 19 others were charged in 13 murders committed in 1987 by members of a Zulu paramilitary unit. **********Mr. Buthelezi was not charged, but the indictment says he asked the security forces to train the unit for "offensive capability." General Malan reportedly approved the request. **********The charges support longstanding allegations that the former white-minority Government tried to undermine black opposition by fueling fighting between the African National Congress and the Zulu-based Inkatha Freedom Party. **********Mr. Buthelezi has said the investigation is politically motivated.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/02/busin.main_headline: Fight for Rockefeller Center Joined by David Rockefeller
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/02/busin.print_headline: Fight for Rockefeller Center Joined by David Rockefeller
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/02/busin.body_text: **********The battle for Rockefeller Center got a new recruit yesterday -- David Rockefeller, the head of the family that founded the landmark property. **********An investor group made up of Mr. Rockefeller, Tishman-Speyer Properties Inc.  and the Whitehall Street Real Estate L.P., a real estate investment fund managed by Goldman, Sachs & Company, yesterday offered to pay $296.5 million, or $7.75 a share, for all the shares of Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., the real estate investment trust that is poised to take ownership of Rockefeller Center. **********The group would also assume about $800 million of the real estate investment trust's debt, about $191 million of which is owed to Whitehall and a Goldman, Sachs subsidiary. **********The proposal competes with a complex deal that the real estate investment trust, or REIT, has already made with an investor group led by Sam Zell, the Chicago financier. That group, which included the General Electric Company and the Walt Disney Company, has offered $250 million, or $5.50 a share, in exchange for a 50 percent stake in the REIT. **********And it follows a proposal made on Thursday by Gotham Partners L.P., an investment firm that is one of the REIT's largest shareholders. The Gotham proposal would recapitalize the REIT through a rights offering that would not dilute the holdings of existing shareholders. It is intended to raise up to $150 million. **********"We have had a very long-term involvement with both this company and this REIT, and we think that by combining our forces with Tishman-Speyer, we are bringing together very capable financial and property management expertise," said Daniel M. Neidich, the Goldman partner who manages Whitehall. "The involvement of David Rockefeller should put to rest anyone's concerns about our  long-term interest in this property." **********Gotham's proposal seems to have served as a catalyst to the Whitehall proposal. Under Gotham's plan, Whitehall would end up with at least a 20 percent stake, but it has aimed to gain control of the property. **********Shareholders, who have favored using a rights offering to recapitalize the company, said the simplicity of the Whitehall proposal and the fact that it was  an all-cash offer made it attractive. They also predicted that it would lead to  a new round of bidding. **********A spokesman for the Zell group declined to comment, saying the group wanted to study the offer. One large shareholder said Mr. Zell had already suggested he was ready to sweeten his offer. **********Stephanie Leggett-Young, a spokeswoman for the REIT, did not return messages  left last night. William A. Ackman, a principal in Gotham, declined to comment. **********Mr. Neidich and Jerry Speyer, a principal in Tishman Speyer, declined to describe how the partners in yesterday's proposal would divide ownership of the  property. **********Other people involved in negotiations with the REIT said, though, that Whitehall, which has more than $1 billion to invest, was probably putting up the bulk of the money. Whitehall previously proposed a more complex recapitalization plan that was rejected by the REIT. **********Tishman-Speyer, a New York real estate developer and manager, would manage the property and likely have a minority stake. Previously, Tishman-Speyer allied itself with the Mitsubishi Estate Company, the current controlling owner of the  property, to buy control of the REIT. **********While Mr. Rockefeller is probably putting up some money, most importantly he  is lending his name to the proposal. That gives Whitehall some very respectable  window dressing. And it provides Mr. Rockefeller a chance to polish his reputation and restore his family's ties to the property, which was built by his father, John D. Rockefeller. **********Mr. Rockefeller fought hard to keep Mitsubishi from putting Rockefeller Center into bankruptcy protection in May. Mitsubishi has an 80 percent stake in  Rockefeller Center through a company that it owns with the Rockefeller family trusts. **********Mr. Rockefeller and William Bowen, the trustee in charge of the Rockefeller trusts, flew to Tokyo last spring to try to assemble a rescue plan to keep the two partnerships out of bankruptcy protection. **********As a show of good faith, Mitsubishi asked the Rockefeller trusts to contribute somewhat more than 20 percent of the money needed to save the center, terms to which Mr. Bowen said the trusts could not agree. **********Some people close to Mr. Rockefeller believe that decision created tension between Mr. Rockefeller and Mr. Bowen. Mr. Rockefeller, Mr. Bowen and their spokesmen could not be reached last night.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/busin.main_headline: Real Estate;Lower interest rates are causing another surge in refinancings of home mortgages.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/busin.print_headline: Real Estate;Lower interest rates are causing another surge in refinancings of home mortgages.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/busin.body_text: **********THE wave of home-mortgage refinancing of three years ago is back, though not  quite as strong. **********"There's a real surge," said Ellen Bitton, president of the Manhattan Mortgage Company. "Normally the week before Christmas is dead, but it hasn't abated at all. We're crazed." **********Mark Schwabber, president of Skyscraper Mortgage, mortgage brokers with offices in Connecticut and New York, said 28 percent of his business was now refinancing, compared with 5 percent a year ago. Toward the end of 1993 -- considered the height of the refinancing market -- he said refinancings made up  35 percent of his business. **********Within the last few weeks, bond yields, to which many mortgages are keyed, hit the lowest they have been in 24 months. And a drop in short-term interest rates this week by the Federal Reserve, followed by lower market rates, contributed to the public's perception that the timing might be right to take another look at the terms of home mortgages. **********These rate drops are "setting the stage for a New Year's gift" for consumers  and mortgage lenders alike, according to Paul Havemann, vice president of HSH Associates, an organization that tracks the mortgage industry. **********Currently, Mr. Havemann said, refinancing makes up about 25 percent of all mortgage loans. Last year, he said, refinanced mortgages were "negligible, trivial, hardly anything" statistically. **********And more refinancing business is expected, he said, echoing the voices of others in the mortgage business. "It's a real possibility that rates could come  down more," Mr. Havemann said. **********He pointed out that the average interest rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage in January 1995 stood at 9.33 percent -- while this week the national average was 7.23 percent. **********Today's upswing in refinancing is coming not only from people who missed the  last wave of refinancing. Some other homeowners refinanced last time with 30-year mortgages carrying rates that are adjusted ever three years -- and the three years are up. Another group of customers refinanced only a year or two ago, but are trying to get an even better deal. **********"The conventional wisdom," Mr. Schwabber said, "was that it pays to refinance only if your new rate will be at least two percentage points less than your current rate. That thinking is now out the window. There are people refinancing  with only one point lower -- and saving money." **********As an example, Mr. Schwabber said a homeowner might have received a mortgage  for $100,000 at 8 percent interest earlier this year. The mortgage rate for the same loan is now at 7 percent, he said, and if the person refinanced now, he could borrow $110,000 -- for $2 less a month. **********Increasingly, buyers are taking advantage of a procedure called Consolidation Extension and Modification, he said. Under this procedure refinancers can switch to a lower rate mortgage and pay only $300 in lawyer's fees and $500 for a title update. For a $200,000 mortgage taken out a year ago for a percentage point higher, the homeowner now could save $1,656 a year. Even with the refinancing costs figured in, the homeowner could break even in less than a year and start saving money, the mortgage broker said. **********"Customers with mortgages over $500,000 are refinancing with one- half percent difference," Mr. Schwabber said. **********Nevertheless, mortgage brokers and lenders point out that rates are still higher than they were for houses or apartments bought or refinanced at the end of 1993. While a home buyer who closed on a house at the beginning of January 1994 might have gotten a 30-year fixed-interest loan at 6.75 percent, in today's market, that same loan would be almost a full percentage point higher. And while one-year adjustable loans were written back then as low as 4 percent, the same loan now averages 5.64 percent interest. **********Yet Abe Eisner, executive vicepresident of GFC Mortgage Bankers Inc., a company lending in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Florida, still sees a definite boom right now and predicts "it will continue into 1996 as rates are projected to come down even more." **********While there appears to be a boomlet in refinancing, mortgage brokers also report more new purchases, which they say reflects an upturn in the residential  real estate market. **********But whether they are buying or refinancing, mortgage brokers say customers seem to be more creative than ever in shopping for deals. And they suggest that  banks are becoming more flexible in accommodating consumers' needs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/17/busin.body_text: **********Dissident shareholders of the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company are gearing up for the company's annual meeting Thursday. **********A campaign by investors to withhold re-election votes from the board of the company, which is under Federal investigation because of price-fixing accusations, is gathering momentum. Some are considering forming a shareholders' committee or trying to force a special meeting of the company's board. **********Investors have been critical of the board's response to the Justice Department investigations of suspected price-fixing and secret payments to executives. The company has denied wrongdoing. **********Over the last two weeks, some large institutional investors have said that they will withhold votes at the meeting. Today, as expected, the California Public Employees Retirement System, or Calpers, announced that it would vote its 3.6 million shares against the re-election of the current board. **********"It is indeed unfortunate that the existing A-D-M board has not gotten the message that there are grave problems with the management," said Charles Valdes, Calpers vice chairman. **********Also today, New York State said it would withhold its 2.9 million shares from supporting the board. New York City has done the same, joining the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the states of Florida and New Jersey, and others. **********But despite the opposition, the board is unlikely to be unseated because it is running unopposed. **********Still, the company had more bad news for shareholders today. Archer-Daniels said that its financial performance for the last quarter was below expectations. Its fiscal first-quarter earnings rose 5.6 percent, slightly less than Wall Street expected. **********Archer-Daniels, a corn and soybean processor, said net income increased to $163.1 million, or 31 cents a share, in the three months ended Sept. 30, from $154.5 million, or 28 cents, a year earlier. **********The results fell short of the average estimate of 32 cents from six analysts  surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. **********The per-share results are adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend in September and a 3-for-2 stock split in December 1994. **********As usual, Archer-Daniels did not disclose revenue for the quarter. That figure is not required until the next Securities and Exchange Commission filing. **********Shares in Archer-Daniels closed at $15.625, off 12.5 cents in trading on the  New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/world.main_headline: U.N. Panel Says Iraq May Still Be Trying to Produce Missiles
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/world.print_headline: U.N. Panel Says Iraq May Still Be Trying to Produce Missiles
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/world.body_text: **********The Government of President Saddam Hussein may be continuing to try to produce a long-range missile system with the help of prohibited imports, a United Nations commission on Iraqi disarmament told the Security Council today. **********Rolf Ekeus, the commission's chairman, showed the Council and reporters a muddied gyroscope used to guide missiles that divers had recently retrieved from the Tigris Canal in Baghdad on the instructions of his inspectors. The gyrscopes had apparently been disposed of in the canal to avoid detection. **********Mr. Ekeus said the missile parts, which may have been imported earlier this  year, were similar to those in a shipment enroute to Iraq that was intercepted by Jordan in November. Iraq is prohibited by the United Nations from producing missiles with a range longer than 90 miles. **********Iraq has failed to provide convincing accounts of what happened to dozens of  Scud missile engines and other missile components, the commission says. **********Mr. Ekeus, presenting the commission's six-month report to the Council, also  said that Iraq had experimented in the late 1980's with radioactive bombs, and that 80 of the bomb casings were unaccounted for. Three bombs were tested before the Iraqis decided the radioactive material -- irradiated zirconium oxide -- did not travel far enough from the bomb crater to be a significant deterrent to enemy troops. **********The Iraqi Government, already embarrassed in recent months by new disclosures of its chemical and biological weapons programs during and since the 1991 Persian Gulf war, has now admitted it produced much larger quantities of a lethal nerve agent known as VX than it had acknowledged earlier, the report says. The fatal nerve agent, which enters the body through the skin, cuts off nervous transmissions and ultimately causes victims to stop breathing. **********On biological weapons, the Iraqis are still failing "to provide definite figures on amounts of biological weapons agents and munitions produced, weaponized and destroyed," the commission report said. **********Under a cease-fire resolution of April 1991, Iraq was required to account for and eliminate all its weapons of mass destruction before Baghdad would be allowed to resume selling oil. This embargo and other sanctions imposed since August 1990, when Iraq invaded Kuwait, have crippled the Iraqi economy, causing  hardships and suffering. **********Although the Security Council has offered Iraq opportunities to sell oil under United Nations supervision to pay for urgent civilian needs, President Hussein has refused, saying these plans would infringe on Iraqi sovereignty. **********Repeatedly over the last four years, Iraq said it had given the inspection commission "full, final and complete disclosures" of its weapons programs. A year ago, several members of the Security Council, especially Russia and France, began to argue for an easing of the oil-sale sanction. **********But the commission headed by Mr. Ekeus, a Swedish diplomat, forced Iraq's hand on several occasions by presenting independently collected evidence of Iraqi dissimulations. In the summer, when a high-level Iraqi defector to Jordan  threatened to make revelations about the weapons programs, the Iraqi Government  was forced to turn over thousands of pages of new documents. **********During the period covered in the report, Iraq's credibility has probably been discounted more severely than at any time since the end of the war, diplomats say.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/17/busin.main_headline: Market Place;Coram Healthcare surges after a reprieve from its creditors.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/17/busin.print_headline: Market Place;Coram Healthcare surges after a reprieve from its creditors.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/17/busin.body_text: **********INVESTORS who bought the Coram Healthcare Corporation's shares on Friday for  $3.125 found themselves with a hefty profit yesterday when Coram's creditors gave the troubled home health care company a five-month chance to straighten up. But even at yesterday's closing price of $4.75 a share, Wall Street analysts said Coram remained a risky bet. **********Coram's chairman, James M. Sweeney, started the year with plans to create a $2-billion-a-year provider of intravenous drugs and nutrition for patients in their homes. By last month, after many setbacks, his revenue goal was closer to  $600 million, and Coram shares had plunged from $26 in April and $19 as recently as July. **********The longterm future of Coram is still very much in doubt," said Randall S.  Huyser, a health-care industry analyst in San Francisco with Furman, Selz Securities. **********Still, there is some reason for optimism about Coram. The company announced yesterday that it had hired Donald J. Amaral as president and chief executive of Coram. **********"Don Amaral has a very good reputation as a turnaround guy," said Vivian Wohl, an analyst in San Francisco with Robertson Stephens. **********Robert M. Wasserman of Southeast Research Partners in Boca Raton, Fla., also  praised Mr. Amaral. "He is a professional manager, and Jim Sweeney is more of an entrpreneur," he said. **********Mr. Amaral is a 43-year-old health care executive who ran a number of small companies. Until last month, he was president and chief operating officer of Ornda Healthcorporation, a hospital chain. Ornda had merged with Mr. Amaral's previous company, Summit Health. **********Mr. Sweeney, who watched as the options he held to buy several million shares become worthless when Coram fell below $11 a share, has had turnaround successes of his own. He created Coram by combining four money-losing home health care companies with a fifth, T-Square, which was in trouble with Government regulators. Next he struck a deal with the Caremark Corporation to buy a home-health unit for $209 million in cash, mostly borrowed, and $100 million in  Coram securities. **********That looked like a bargain because Mr. Sweeney had sold the core of that same business to Caremark's parent at the time, Baxter Travenol in 1987 for $580 million. **********But Mr. Sweeney apparently had been having difficulty integrating Coram's first five components. Absorbing the Caremark unit just made those troubles worse, analysts said. Caremark and Coram recently filed lawsuits against each other, contending deception in the deal, and the accompanying airing of dirty laundry seemed unlikely to encourage timid investors. **********By April, Coram was announcing yet another merger, with Lincare Holdings Inc., a company specializing in providing oxygen to home patients. But the deal  with Lincare collapsed and with it, Mr. Sweeney's talk of a $2 billion conglomerate in home health care any time soon. **********Mr. Sweeney said yesterday that Coram's lenders had agreed to restructure $450 million in debt. The creditors, headed by Chemical Bank, agreed to postpone the first payment on the principal until next March 31. The banks were granted warrants for 2.57 million Coram shares. **********Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Coram's investment banker, agreed to accept additional promises of future payment in lieu of interest on a $150 million bridge loan to Coram. Coram said its banking group also provided a new $25 million credit line. Donaldson, a unit of the Equitable Companies, said it had taken a $25 million pretax charge, apparently related to the deal. **********Some analysts sense an opportunity in Coram's struggles. Theodore E. James of Genesis Merchant Group Securities in San Francisco said Coram might have "close  to $700 million in revenues and a market capitalization of less than $200 million." He reasons that it could be a valuable acquisition for another home care company. **********Mr. Wasserman of Southeast Research was also interested in Coram. "You can't  look at Coram as a book-value play," he said. "The book value and good will are  probably a negative number." But he added, "We're thinking about jumping back in."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/01/busin.main_headline: Kerkorian Bid for Chrysler Is Ended, at Least for Now
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/01/busin.print_headline: Kerkorian Bid for Chrysler Is Ended, at Least for Now
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/01/busin.body_text: **********Kirk Kerkorian withdrew his hostile bid of $55 a share for the Chrysler Corporation today, but at the same time announced he had hired an investment bank to advise him on options, including another takeover attempt. **********The only step Mr. Kerkorian's representatives ruled out today was selling his 36 million Chrysler shares, roughly 10 percent of the company. **********Mr. Kerkorian's bid died with a whimper. Because he had lined up no investors to supply the capital he needed and no banks to finance the debt, Wall Street had long since dismissed the offer, made on April 12. **********Withdrawing the offer permits Mr. Kerkorian to wipe the slate clean and perhaps return with a more credible bid, this time with the assistance of an investment bank. He has hired Wasserstein Perella & Company, which built its reputation in mergers and acquisitions. **********Chrysler shares initially fell slightly on the announcement, but rallied with the rest of the auto stocks, closing up $1 on the New York Stock Exchange at $43.625. Investors may have concluded that Mr. Kerkorian would return with a stronger proposal. **********As usual, Mr. Kerkorian did not tip his hand today. "Withdrawing our offer will permit us to take a fresh look at the situation and evaluate our alternatives," said Alex Yemenidjian, an executive with Mr. Kerkorian's company, Tracinda, in a prepared statement. **********But, he said, "Tracinda's 36 million shares of Chrysler stock are not for sale." Mr. Kerkorian, who has been frustrated by the languishing price of Chrysler stock in recent months, would continue to seek ways to enhance its value, Mr. Yemenidjian said. Two weeks ago, Chrysler rejected a proposal by Mr.  Kerkorian to raise the annual dividend to $5. **********Another Tracinda spokesman, Michael Claes, said that Lee A. Iacocca remained  a member of Mr. Kerkorian's team. "Nothing has changed with regard to Lee's involvement," he said, adding that Tracinda had not ruled out another bid for the company. **********Chrysler declined to comment today on Mr. Kerkorian's moves, but company executives had said previously that they did not believe the collapse of the initial bid would cause Mr. Kerkorian to give up. **********Given the lack of other investors, Wall Street was not surprised by today's withdrawal. "They held a dance, and no one came," said Joseph S. Phillippi, auto analyst with Lehman Brothers in New York. "What do you do? You turn out the lights and go home." **********Several of Chrysler's largest investors had backed the company's board in its rejection of Mr. Kerkorian's original bid, valued at $22.8 billion. The company  also enlisted major banks, convincing them not to lend to Mr. Kerkorian. **********Mr. Kerkorian and Mr. Iacocca had said they would contribute their own shares, worth about $2 billion, and seek additional investment of $3 billion. They would then have taken on about $10 billion in debt, and used $5.5 billion from Chrysler's own cash reserves to finance the deal. **********The last provision -- raiding the cash that Chrysler had set aside to sustain it through the next sales downturn -- proved to be a grave miscalculation. It enabled Chrysler to paint Mr. Kerkorian's offer as a threat to the survival of the oft-beleaguered company. Last Friday, Representative James A. Leach of Iowa, chairman of the House Banking and Financial Services Committee, said he intended to hold public hearings on the attempted buyout, if Mr. Kerkorian proceeded with it. **********"The plundering of Chrysler's reserves would not only result in a financially fragile enterprise, it would also jeopardize the stability of its work force and sap U.S. competitiveness in the auto industry," Mr. Leach said. **********Mr. Kerkorian's withdrawal prompted Duff & Phelps, the credit rating agency,  to remove today a watch it had placed on Chrysler for a possible downgrade because of the bid. **********Leaders of the United Automobile Workers Union hailed the development, but added that with Mr. Kerkorian still on the prowl they would "remain vigilant." **********Analysts said they were astonished that Mr. Kerkorian's original offer turned out to be so slipshod. "The thing was so poorly executed and poorly thought out, I was shocked," said Ted Shasta of Loomis, Sayles & Company, a fund manager that owns about three million Chrysler shares. **********In retrospect, Mr. Shasta said, he wished he had sold his shares when they peaked at $48 after Mr. Kerkorian announced his bid, then bought them back at $40 when the price collapsed again. "I wasn't that smart," he said. "I took this guy very seriously." **********Still, he said he was not prepared to count out another bid by Mr. Kerkorian, particularly since he has engaged a strong investment bank. But, he added, Mr. Kerkorian would need to line up at least $5 billion in equity on top of his own  shares to be credible, an extremely high hurdle. **********In a prepared statement, Bruce Wasserstein, chairman of Wasserstein Perella,  said: "Kirk Kerkorian is a serious long-term investor whose track record speaks  for itself. We hope to provide a new perspective and play a constructive role in achieving Tracinda's objectives."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/23/world.main_headline: THE U.N. AT 50: CLINTON;U.S. Freezes Assets of Cartel In New Effort Against Drugs
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/23/world.print_headline: THE U.N. AT 50: CLINTON;U.S. Freezes Assets of Cartel In New Effort Against Drugs
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/23/world.body_text: **********Seeking to rally world leaders against international drug traffickers and terrorists, President Clinton announced today that he had moved to freeze any assets of Colombia's biggest drug cartel that are in the United States and to stop American firms from doing business with any of its front organizations. **********Mr. Clinton also said he had directed members of his Cabinet to identify nations that help in money laundering and to put them on notice that unless they adhere to international standards, the Administration would consider imposing sanctions that could prevent them from doing business in the United States. **********Criminal enterprises are moving vast sums of ill-gotten gains through the international financial system with absolute impunity," Mr. Clinton, who by prior agreement spoke almost three times longer than the five minutes allotted other leaders, said in his address to the United Nations at ceremonies marking its 50th anniversary. "We must not allow them to wash the blood off profits from the sale of drugs from terror or organized crimes." **********The Clinton Administration had hoped to announce a plan today for erasing its $1.25 billion debt to the United Nations. But its efforts foundered in the face  of a Republican Congress that has been cutting foreign aid. **********Mr. Clinton vowed to keep pressing Congress. "I don't think the United States wants to be known as the biggest deadbeat in the U.N.," he said, speaking to reporters before a meeting with President Nelson Mandela of South Africa. "That's not the kind of reputation I think we should cultivate." **********Mr. Clinton outlined the measures today as an effort to lead by example in calling for an international effort to combat the security threats posed by terrorism, criminal rings, narcotics and weapons proliferation. He urged countries to join in a declaration against international crime, including a pledge of no sanctuary for criminals, terrorists and smugglers. **********Mr. Clinton petitioned more countries to sign anti-terrorism treaties and take more aggressive actions against drug cartels. He also called for a greater  effort against the sale and smuggling of illegal arms and deadly materials like  plutonium and biological weapons. **********United States officials estimate that the Colombian drug group, known as the  Cali cartel, is responsible for 80 percent of the cocaine entering the United States and 15 percent of the heroin. **********Mr. Clinton's measures against the drug traffickers came in an executive order, issued under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, which allows the President to take action in the case of an "unusual and extraordinary threat to national security." **********The same act was used by President Carter to freeze Iranian assets in the United States after Americans were taken hostage in Teheran and was used by the  Clinton Administration to stop the flow of funds to terrorist groups like Hamas  in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. **********Under the directive, which took effect at midnight on Saturday, American financial institutions must search for and freeze accounts held in the names of  persons or companies determined by the Government to assist or play a significant role in international drug trafficking centered in Colombia. The order also forbids American businesses and officials to trade with those individuals and front companies. **********The United States has so far identified 4 principal figures in the Cali cartel, 33 businesses and 43 other individuals whose property would be subject to the freeze, but they are all based overseas. Administration officials said it was too early to tell which holdings would be affected. The officials could not  say what kind of assets those listed might have in the United States. **********The officials said the ban on trade might prove more damaging to the cartel,  since the firms identified include export-import firms, auto dealers, chemical companies and Colombia's largest pharmaceutical chain. **********"We have just, by making it impossible for that chain of stores to do transactions in dollars or do transactions with American companies, greatly devalued the market value of that company to the criminals who owned it," said Dick Clarke, a special assistant to the President. **********Mr. Clinton also instructed the Attorney General and the Secretaries of the Treasury and State to identify the countries most involved in money laundering.  Officials said the United States would push those countries to enter agreements  that prohibit money laundering or face the possibility of sanctions. **********While the officials declined to publicly identify the countries that would be targets, the United States has long considered a wide range as offenders, including Antigua, the Cayman Islands, Turkey, Panama, Thailand, Greece and Venezuela. **********On Monday, Mr. Clinton is to meet with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia at the Hyde Park home of Franklin D. Roosevelt. On Tuesday, he is to meet with the Chinese President, Jiang Zemin, and with Presidents Franjo Tudjman of Croatia and Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/11/world.body_text: **********Some were so afraid that they dared not even look at the road in front of them. Still, the 750 refugees slowly began to cross into Bosnia, their homeland. **********Behind them was a refugee camp in Croatia that they said was no longer tolerable; forward lay a country where they were hated rebels. **********These refugees took part in a rebellion here in northwest Bosnia against the Bosnian Government, killing thousands of Government troops, many their own neighbors and family members, and maintaining a semi-independent state for most  of the last two years. **********While in other parts of Bosnia it was Croats and Serbs who rebelled against the Muslim-led Government, here it was fellow Muslims who took up arms. And though the agreement reached in Dayton, Ohio, last month requires that any of the 1.3 million refugees who wishes to go home be allowed to do so, right now this is the only place in Bosnia where the side in control is permitting substantial numbers of former enemies to come home. The return here began last week and has already brought some 3,000 people from a camp of about 21,000. **********Today, refugees moved forward past glowering Bosnian border guards. First a few buses, then the chugging tractors with families perched on them and towing homemade wagons with the families' few possessions. **********Finally, the poorest of the refugees came through on horse-drawn carts. They  looked worn out and fragile, bundled in blankets and shaking in the freezing fog. **********Senad Sakanovic, 24, once a soldier in the rebel army, stood next to his horse, both of them sweating from the effort of a 15-mile journey through the snow-covered mountains from the camp, yet shivering from the biting cold. He said: "The only possible future for all of us is to overcome our differences. We will have to learn how to do that one step at a time." **********To help both sides learn reconciliation there are more than a dozen international relief organizations here, including various branches of the United Nations. The Bosnian Government has replaced most of the local military units that fought the rebels here with police officers from other parts of the country. **********In addition, the Government is allowing the work of those police officers to  be monitored by a unit of 200 police officers comprising Croats, Bosnians and Turks. **********Still, the local commander of the United Nations Civilian Police, which has had a post here through most of the war, is skeptical. The commander, Inspector  Kurt Bannerhoff, said that as long as the international community is vigilant it will be difficult for officials to act against the returning refugees, but there is probably no way to protect them from revenge at the hand of their neighbors who supported the Government. **********"This project is a good idea, maybe it will succeed, but personally I doubt it," he said. "There will be serious problems in the future." **********When Yugoslavia began to tear apart in 1991, people in this region here increasingly turned for leadership to the most prominent local citizen, Fikret Abdic. **********Mr. Abdic's business combine provided most of the jobs for the approximately  50,000 residents, and though he was convicted of embezzlement in 1987, he became the economic and political strong man. Then he became a warlord. **********In 1993 Mr. Abdic accused the Government in Sarajevo of being dominated by Muslim fundamentalists. He declared the way to peace was through political and business deals with the Croatian and Serbian governments and with the local military forces those governments were fostering. **********The Bosnian Government disagreed. But in this region most people followed Mr. Abdic, even when he effectively seceded from Bosnia and set about making hugely  profitable business alliances with Croats and Serbs and, to protect his remote dominion, initially successful military alliances with them as well. **********That turned him and his followers into Muslim rebels against the mostly Muslim Government. **********Last August, after the Croatian Government and local Croat militias became Bosnian allies, Bosnian Government forces recaptured the area controlled by Mr.  Abdic. People who had fled because they supported the Government returned as victors and Mr. Abdic's supporters fled to the camp in Croatia. **********He is now reported by diplomats to be running his remaining businesses from Croatia. But here in Velika Kladusa, and the dozens of surrounding villages, people who four months ago were on opposite sides of the firing line are now faced with the challenge of how to be neighbors again. **********Relief workers say so far the reintegration has gone well enough, despite scattered threats by Government supporters and reports that several hundred returning men found themselves almost immediately conscripted into the Government army. **********Even so, watching today's group of refugees returning, Fatmira Keseravic, an  elderly woman who supported the government, did not sound very forgiving. "Well, if someone has done something wrong, they might have reason to expect trouble,"  she said. **********Husein Sadikovic, 62, who said his son had joined the Abdic army while he supported the Government, predicted that the hostility would be controlled here  in town but not in the rural areas. **********"In villages it will be much worse," he said. "No government will be able to  control that, even with all these international forces here." **********That is also the fear of many of the relief workers in the camp, especially,  they say, as the mandate of the United Nations is to expire in mid- January and  with the question of what responsibility NATO and other foreign forces will exercise over reconciliation efforts still unclear. **********But the ultimate responsibility belongs to the people here, said Burhan Tansu, the commander of the Turkish police unit. "My men tell them, sooner or later you will have to live together," he said. "You are a family. We will leave someday, but this is your country."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/world.main_headline: Experts Begin to Ponder a Crash Without an Obvious Cause
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/world.print_headline: Experts Begin to Ponder a Crash Without an Obvious Cause
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/world.body_text: **********Investigators struggled today to begin explaining how two experienced pilots  flying an apparently airworthy jet in good weather went off track and slammed into a mountain in Colombia. There is no evidence so far of any terrorism, experts said. **********The plane, American Airlines Flight 965, carried 164 people, and reports tonight said several had survived. **********The National Transportation Safety Board, the Federal Aviation  Administration and the F.B.I. sent experts to the scene, in the Andes Mountains  near Cali. But aviation experts said that unless they found evidence of a bomb or missile, firm information would probably have to await decoding of the "black boxes," the flight data recorder and the cockpit voice recorder. **********The board, which analyzes most recorders from American-built planes that crash, had not heard late today whether the boxes had been found. **********The F.B.I. office in Miami said today that a Caracas newspaper, El Universal, had received a letter on Monday, postmarked from Miami and written in fluent English, expressing hatred of immigrants and threatening to bomb a plane bound to Miami from Colombia or Venezuela. **********The letter said copies would be sent to The Miami Herald and The New York Times. The Times had not received the letter by today, and Paul L. Miller, a spokesman for the F.B.I., said the bureau did not believe that it was connected  to the crash. **********The airline has no theory as to the cause of the crash in Colombia. Nor do Government safety officials. The Safety Board sent a team of five people, and the F.A.A. sent three. **********The weather at the crash scene was good, according to Robert Crandall, American Airlines' chief executive. But in response to a question at a briefing  today in Fort Worth, he said the plane was "somewhat to the east" of where it should have been. Other reports put it 13 miles off course and about 40 miles from the airport. **********Jets navigate in Colombia the same way they do in the continental United States, using radio beacons on the ground that tell instruments on the plane which beacon is sending the signal, and what direction on the compass the plane  is approaching the beacon from. The planes also carry inertial navigation instruments to keep track of each turn. **********But there is a difference in air traffic control. In the continental United States and in nearby offshore areas, there is blanket radar coverage, and a plane that strays from its assigned course is likely to be warned by an air traffic controller. **********"There are areas in Columbia where there is no radar coverage for air traffic control," said Robin Deyoe, vice president of BDM International, Inc., a McLean, Va., company that sells air traffic equipment. **********The Federal Aviation Administration said today that neither pilot had any violations or disciplinary actions in his record. The captain, Nicholas Tafuri,  57, of Marco Island, Fla., joined American in 1969, was certified to fly the Boeing 757 in April 1992, and had logged 10,400 hours of flying time. The first  officer, Don Williams, 39, of New Smyrna Beach, Fla., had been with the company  for nine years and had 6,000 hours. **********The plane was delivered to American on Aug. 27, 1991, and had logged seven "service difficulty reports," or mechanical malfunctions of sufficient severity  to require reporting to the Government. That is a small number, aviation experts said. Three were for problems with the emergency floor lights, and three were for dents in cargo doors. **********The crash was the first ever involving a Boeing 757; since 1983, nearly 700 have been sold.
