https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/world.main_headline: U.S. General Has Talks on Bosnian Accord
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/world.print_headline: U.S. General Has Talks on Bosnian Accord
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/world.body_text: **********In a bombed-out guest house covered with snow and surrounded by mines, Maj. Gen. William L. Nash gathered military leaders of the three warring factions here today to talk together for the first time about how they will comply with the NATO-enforced peace agreement. **********The hourlong meeting in this front-line village was largely symbolic: The hotel and restaurant, with its toppled brick arches and bullet-battered walls, is part of the Serbian defense position along the road that will carry Americans soldiers from Croatia throughout the sector that will be patrolled by the American contingent. **********General Nash, the commander of American military forces in Bosnia, met with  the three regional military leaders over coffee and cigarettes at a folding table in a room with walls blasted open to the cold and falling snow here, about 35 miles north of Tuzla. **********"They are professional soldiers gathering together to talk through the issues at hand," General Nash said at a news conference later this afternoon at the American base near Tuzla. "They were very friendly to each other. All of them focused on peace and pledged their determination to succeed with respect to the  peace accord." **********General Nash also responded to published comments by Col. Gregory Fontenot, commander of the First Brigade of the First Armored Division, whose troops will  be among the first to reach Bosnia in large numbers. **********In an article today in The Wall Street Journal, Colonel Fontenot was quoted as questioning whether a year would be long enough to make a real difference in  Bosnia. **********"They think I don't trust them -- and they're right," he is quoted as saying. "These are people who kill women and children and attack their neighbors. They're offended by me? Hell, I'm offended that I had to come here because of all their fighting." **********The article depicts him as turning to two black American soldiers and saying, "It'll be interesting to hear what you two see, because Croatians are racists. They kill people for the color of their skins." **********General Nash said he had seen the article, adding: "I am very disappointed with what I read. I am looking into it." **********[In Washington, a senior Administration official said of the statements attributed to Colonel Fontenot: "They were very serious remarks of serious concern. Clearly if they are accurately reported they represent bad judgment, extremely bad judgment." **********[The official said General Nash had instructed Brig. Gen. Stanley Cherrie, the assistant division commander of the First Armored Division, to go to the area where Colonel Fontenot is stationed and find out whether the remarks attributed to him are accurate. **********["The direction he went in his comments is totally unacceptable," the official said. The official declined to say what action might be taken.] **********After today's meeting here, Gen. Nash shook hands outside with the three officers leading troops in this region, considered one of the most dangerous in  the American sector. **********The men were Gen. Novica Simic of the Bosnian Serbs, Gen. Djuro Matuzovic of  the Bosnian Croats and Col. Efendic Muharem of the Bosnian Army, who was representing the Bosnian Muslim commander based in Tuzla, Brig. Sead Delic. **********On a day when snow buried nearly a week of warm weather and the soldiers at the base bundled up to fight off the cold, General Nash repeated forcefully that the American drive to bring troops into Bosnia was on schedule: He said the pontoon bridge over the Sava River -- a thin floating ribbon that will funnel all ground troops in the area, from Croatia to the north into Bosnia -- should be in place by the end of the month. **********Until the bridge is built, the bulk of the American troops cannot arrive into Bosnia, and some military officials had said the bridge would be in place a few  days before Christmas. But General Nash said he would not move forward until all pieces of the operation were in place, including building ramps on both sides of the river, securing the Bosnian side with advance troops and making sure the operation did not unduly effect local towns. **********"To create a quagmire would defeat what I am tyring to accomplish," he said. **********Despite the extended prologue, he said, troops would begin rolling across immediately after the bridge was complete. **********"As soon as we put the bridge in and connect the ends and test it -- that will be a very short time, I mean a 20-mintues type thing -- we'll start rolling folks across," he said. **********At the meeting with the regional military leaders, General Nash said he presented each with copies of the peace agreement, along with maps of the zones  of separation and areas that must be turned over in the coming months. Some already had copies of the accord, the general said, but he gave them autographed copies anyway. **********The meeting also focused heavily on clearing mines, which is the responsibility of the warring parties. Today, they agreed that the parties would begin clearing main routes, then move on to smaller roads and later to pockets specified by General Nash. **********He said the snow, which began falling at dawn, had complicated the efforts to clear mines, now becoming more crucial because of the wave of troops expected to enter Bosnia in the coming days. **********"It just increases the danger," the general said. "This will cause us to concentrate even more on where we know there are no mines and work slowly in those areas where there is a possibility there are mines." **********The meeting here, in sight of a church and other heavily shelled buildings, was chosen in part because of its location. The restaurant, connected to ditches and fortified by bunkers made of logs, was a Serbian defense point a few hundred yards north of the Bosnian Government line and about a mile west of a major Croatian unit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/12/busin.main_headline: In Peru, a Fight for Fresh Air
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/12/busin.print_headline: In Peru, a Fight for Fresh Air
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/12/busin.body_text: **********Every night before she goes to bed, Anna Gilapa gets down on her knees and stuffs cloth in the cracks around her doors and windows to protect her family from the acrid smoke released by the nearby smelter of the Southern Peru Copper  Corporation. **********Mrs. Gilapa fears for the health of her 1-year-old son, Brian, who suffers from severe respiratory problems and often coughs up thick mucous. And for that, she and other residents of this bleak coastal town 580 miles south of Lima blame the largest local company, Southern Peru Copper, which environmentalists say spews 2,000 tons of sulfur dioxide into the air each day, or 10 to 15 times the  limit for similar plants operating in the United States. **********At times, the smoke from the smelter is so thick that it hovers over the city like a heavy fog, forcing motorists to turn on their headlights during the  day and sending residents to hospitals and clinics coughing, wheezing and vomiting. On those days, children are told to play indoors. **********"All we want is an end to the pollution," said Ilo's Mayor, Ernesto Herrera Becerra, who said emissions from the smelter had ruined agriculture and fishing  in the area. "This situation would not be allowed to exist in the United States." **********But officials of Southern Peru Copper, which is controlled by three big American companies -- Asarco Inc., the Phelps Dodge Corporation and the Marmon Group -- maintain that their smelter is not to blame for the town's health problems and that their workers have never complained. Nevertheless, Southern Peru will spend $151 million on environment projects in the region. **********Environmental groups concede the plant complies with Peruvian environmental standards but say that is precisely the problem. All too often, they say, the absence of strong laws in many developing countries enables giant multinationals -- especially in the mining and chemical industries -- to play fast and loose with the local environment and the local population's health. **********"I'm afraid these countries are at the mercy of the multinational corporations," said Kenny Bruno, a toxins investigator for Greenpeace, the environmental group. **********Although some multinational corporations have voluntarily adopted policies that require their overseas operations to comply with the same environmental standards they must follow in the United States, there are currently no agreements between industrialized nations or policing mechanisms to insure compliance, Mr. Bruno noted. **********As a result, foreign corporations often come under attack from political and  environmental activists in the third world, accused by them of putting profits ahead of ethics. **********For example, Royal Dutch/Shell, the world's largest oil company, has been denounced in both Nigeria and abroad for participating in a $3.8 billion natural gas plant in Nigeria, despite international condemnation of the military Government for the recent executions of Ken Saro-Wiwa, a prominent Nigerian playwright, and eight other critics of Shell's environmental record and of the Government. **********Nigerian courts convicted the nine for involvement in four killings. The men  had insisted they were innocent and had been framed to silence their criticism of the oil industry's environmental record. Shell has defended its role in Nigeria. **********In addition, the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, which provides insurance and financing for American companies doing business overseas, last month canceled Freeport-McMoran Copper and Gold Inc.'s political risk insurance  for a huge mining project in the Indonesian province of Irian Jaya because of supposed environmental problems. **********Environmental groups say that the company, a unit of Freeport-McMoran Inc., which is based in New Orleans, has done little to contain the runoff of toxic wastes that they contend have killed fish in nearby rivers. They also say that local villagers can no longer drink water from the river. The company strongly denies the mine tailings are toxic. In newspaper advertisements that appeared recently, it accused "foreign special interest groups" of conducting a smear campaign against it. **********For its part, Southern Peru Copper denies that a health problem exists in Ilo. In a recent interview at the company's offices in Lima, Hans A. Flury, its  vice president for legal affairs, said that in the 30 years the company has operated in Ilo, it had never received a complaint from any of its 2,000 workers. That alone, he said, was proof that the environment is healthy. **********But in several early-morning interviews with Southern Peru employees waiting  for company buses to take them to their jobs, dozens of workers said that they and their families suffered respiratory problems, including difficulty in breathing, coughing up heavy mucous and vomiting in reaction to the smelter's smoke. **********The workers, who requested anonymity for fear of reprisals, said they had reported these ailments to supervisors to no avail. They said they continued to  work for Southern Peru because there were no other jobs available. **********Asked how the company accounted for Ilo's health problems, Mr. Flury, the vice president, said: "I don't live in Ilo so I don't know. I have not been there on one of those smoky days." He also declined to comment on environmentalists' estimates of the magnitude of the smelter's discharges, saying the company had made no studies on the subject. **********The company has recently made some gestures to the local residents, including the announcement of a project to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions. But Ilo residents said Mr. Flury's cavalier response was more typical of the way Southern Peru Copper had responded to their cries for help. So they have filed a lawsuit against the company, its owners and its creditors in a Texas court, seeking damages for what they say are decades of environmental harm. Residents said that previous suits filed in Peru had been dismissed or were stalled in the courts. **********Robert Hilliard, a lawyer who filed the suit for Ilo residents, said that Southern Peru Copper had "visited environmental terrorism on the families of Ilo" and that the company had destroyed a 12-mile stretch of coastline by dumping 30 million metric tons of untreated mining wastes into the ocean each year. **********Southern Peru declines to comment on the lawsuit. But a walk along Ilo's beaches is an excursion that few local residents make: A narrow stream of blackened water flows into the ocean while a bleak terrain of slate-colored silt stretches in both directions, reflecting fluorescent hues of green, yellow and blue. **********Still, Ilo residents face an uphill struggle in their legal battle. **********Though the provincial health ministry said that respiratory ailments are the  leading health problem reported among the people of Ilo, there are no medical studies showing a direct link between the town's health problems and Southern Peru Copper's operations. The ministry declined to release specific figures, but said that the incidence of respiratory ailments, cancer, urinary diseases, and diseases affecting the circulatory system has risen steadily in the last five years. **********Meanwhile, Southern Peru, the eighth-largest copper producer in the world, remains a vital part of the Peru's economy, providing 5,500 jobs and 17 percent  of the country's export income. **********The company's main owners -- Asarco Inc. of New York, with a 51.8 percent stake; the Phelps Dodge Corporation of Phoenix, with 13.4 percent, and the Marmon Group of Chicago, which is controlled by the Pritzker family, with 16.7 percent -- all declined to comment on the lawsuit and the mining company's practices. The remaining 17.3 percent of the company is traded on the Lima Stock Exchange. **********Southern Peru Copper's profits have boomed recently as copper prices have risen. Net income increased last year to $110 million from $43.6 million in 1993. Revenues in the same period increased to $677 million from $450 million. **********Charles Preble, Southern Peru's president, took a more conciliatory attitude  toward Ilo's residents than his vice president. In an interview, Mr. Preble said that Southern Peru Copper had always operated within the confines of Peruvian law. While he acknowledged that Peru does not set limits on emission rates, he said his company had been "a good corporate citizen," providing workers with housing, education, electricity, water, medical care and food. **********Southern Peru has also announced plans to spend $151 million on environment projects, including a $108 million sulfuric acid plant to reduce sulfur dioxide  emissions at Ilo, a tailings dam near Toquepala, and a water treatment plant and a retention wall to keep waste from entering the Pacific at Ilo. **********"We have a good relationship with the community, and I'd like to comment further but I can't because of this lawsuit," Mr. Preble said. **********Corrine Schmidt, editor of Equilibrio, an environmental newsletter based in Lima, said that Southern Peru "is being disingenuous to say that they didn't know what was going on." She added: "They knowingly did things that they shouldn't have done but were allowed to do. But the question is who's to blame,  the Government or Southern? Probably both." **********The company gets a mixed review from a local environmental group.  Jose Luis  Lopez Follegatti, director of the Association of Civil Labor, said that once built, the tailings dam and the retention wall should eliminate Southern Peru's  pollution of the ocean. But he said that the sulfuric acid plant was expected to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions by only 15 percent. **********Southern Peru has built a village for its mostly American and other foreign engineers and executives and their families in Ilo's hills. It has ranch houses, a hospital, school, playground, cinema, and verdant trees and lawns, in sharp contrast to the arid streets of the town itself. **********Women who work as maids in the village say their employers often complain about the smoke and sometimes wear masks in their homes when the smoke is heavy. "They are comforted by the fact that they only have to spend a few years here and then they move back to the States to clear their lungs," said a maid who identified herself as Suzy. "We are not so lucky."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/18/busin.main_headline: British Media Get New Ownership Rules
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/18/busin.print_headline: British Media Get New Ownership Rules
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/18/busin.body_text: **********Britain's media industry appeared to be heading for a possible shake-up of ownership after the publication of new proposals on Friday aimed at increasing cross-holdings between the television and newspaper sectors. **********The National Heritage Secretary, Virginia Bottomley, said the new Broadcasting Bill, which should take effect by the start of 1997, would prompt British companies to consider mergers between newspaper and television companies. **********A key element of the bill was the surprise removal from an earlier proposal  of a restriction on any one company holding more than two regional television licenses. That sent television stocks soaring as the smaller franchises were immediately seen as takeover targets. **********Under the new rules, newspaper companies with less than a 20 percent share of total national circulation would be allowed to own television companies that reach up to 15 percent of the total television audience and vice versa. **********The new rules would not apply to big newspaper groups like News International P.L.C., which is 40 percent owned by the News Corporation, and the Mirror Group, which both have more than 20 percent of national newspaper circulation. **********Both, though, may continue to invest in cable and satellite stations and would be allowed to own and operate a set of the new digital television channels that are due to start in mid-1997.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/busin.main_headline: Acquisition Done, Kimberly Plans to Eliminate 6,000 Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/busin.print_headline: Acquisition Done, Kimberly Plans to Eliminate 6,000 Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/busin.body_text: **********The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said yesterday that it would shed 6,000 jobs by next summer and sell as many as 12 plants, moving to reap the benefits of its $9.4 billion acquisition of the Scott Paper Company. **********The Dallas-based maker of Kleenex tissues and Huggies diapers expects to take a $1.4 billion pretax charge in the fourth quarter to cover the moves, Kimberly-Clark's chairman, Wayne R. Sanders, told analysts. **********The cuts, which affect 10 percent of the company's work force, will save an  estimated $1.2 billion by 1998, more than double the company's original forecast of $588 million, Mr. Sanders said. **********The disclosures follow by a day the announcement by Kimberly-Clark that it had agreed to sell Scott's facial tissue and baby wipes businesses to settle Justice Department antitrust concerns. Earlier on Tuesday the acquisition won approval by shareholders of both companies. **********The acquisition, which was completed yesterday, adds Scott bathroom tissue and Viva paper towels to Kimberly-Clark's lineup, which includes Kotex feminine-hygiene products. The company will have annual sales of about $12 billion, making it the second-largest consumer-products company behind the Procter & Gamble Company. **********Kimberly-Clark shares closed up $1.375, at $79.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Earlier in the day, shares set a 52-week high of $81.875. **********The company forecast that the restructuring would save $250 million next year, $400 million in 1997 and $500 million annually thereafter. **********About 3,300 jobs to be eliminated are at the company's plants, and 2,700 are  corporate staff and administrative posts, Mr. Sanders said. Workers were scheduled to be told today whether their jobs were in jeopardy. **********Another 2,000 jobs will be cut by 1997 through attrition, he said. After that, the company will have 52,000 employees. **********Most of the plants to be sold are in Europe, where government regulators still must approve the acquisition. Mr. Sanders said the company will provide a  list of the plants after the European Commission makes a decision on Jan. 22. **********Kimberly-Clark will sell two of its four tissue plants in the United States as part of the agreement reached with the Justice Department. Antitrust regulators required the company to sell Scott's Scotties facial-tissue operations and its baby-wipes businesses. Without the sale, Kimberly-Clark would have controlled more than 60 percent of the United States tissue market. **********On Tuesday, Kimberly-Clark identified four mills it would sell: its two in Neenah, Wis., as well as Scott mills in Marinette, Wis., and Fort Edward, N.Y. In addition it said it would sell Scott's baby wipes plant in Dover, Del. **********Yesterday, Mr. Sanders said that Kimberly-Clark would also close Scott's headquarters in Boca Raton, Fla., by April 30 and the company's offices in Wilmington, Del., by July 31. A technical center in Essington, Pa., will be closed by March 1, he said. **********Another potential obstacle was a lawsuit filed in New York by Shepherd Tissue Inc. accusing Kimberly-Clark of reneging on a pledge not to compete with Shepherd in the making of private-label paper products. Kimberly-Clark now wants to get out of the agreement because Scott Paper makes such products.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/21/busin.main_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Prices for Soybeans Rise Sharply On Signs of Higher Feed Demand
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/21/busin.print_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Prices for Soybeans Rise Sharply On Signs of Higher Feed Demand
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/21/busin.body_text: **********Soybean prices rose sharply at the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday on signs  of surging demand for soybean meal used as livestock feed. **********On other commodity markets, orange juice prices rose and coffee fell. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities rose 0.52 point, to 242.31. **********Prices for corn, which is used in combination with soybean meal to feed cattle and hogs, have surged 22 percent since early August, prompting feedlot operators to use more soybean meal. And with colder weather killing pasture grass, more animals are being fed in the lots. **********The amount of soybeans crushed into meal and soybean oil rose 4.4 percent last week to 26.98 million bushels from 25.84 million bushels a week earlier, according to the National Oilseed Processors Association. **********Soybeans for November delivery rose 8.25 cents, to $6.7225 a bushel, the highest for the contract closest to delivery since June 28, 1994. Soy meal for December delivery rose $4.20, to $208.90 a short ton, the highest since Nov. 19, 1993, for the active contract. **********Orange juice prices rose to a 10-month high on concerns about low inventories. **********Juice processors had 71.6 million gallons in storage as of Oct. 14, the Florida Citrus Processors Association reported on Thursday, down 13 percent from a year ago. Analysts said that a lack of imports from Brazil had forced buyers to dig deeper into storage. **********In addition, months of heavy rains caused in part by a large number of tropical storms have left many groves flooded in South Florida. **********November orange juice gained 1.1 cent, to $1.191 a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange, its highest price since Dec. 20. **********Coffee prices fell on concerns that an agreement by producers to limit exports would dissolve as freshly harvested beans become available. **********An agreement among producers to reduce exports by 20 percent helped prices rally in the summer, but traders increasingly doubt that the pact will hold when the beans now being harvested in Colombia and Central America become available for sale. **********Coffee for December delivery fell 0.5 cent, to $1.2495, a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/08/busin.snippet:
TO what extent is it ethical for a corporation to involve itself with O.J. Simpson? 

     As the Simpson case moves from the courtroom to the marketplace, this question arises with some urgency because a cascade of dubious marketing may be about ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/08/busin.body_text: **********TO what extent is it ethical for a corporation to involve itself with O.J. Simpson? **********As the Simpson case moves from the courtroom to the marketplace, this question arises with some urgency because a cascade of dubious marketing may be about to descend.  Recent press reports indicate that Mr. Simpson's advisers  have plans for a $10 million pay-TV special and hope to receive a multimillion-dollar advance for his next book (in which he will explain "what really happened"). Smaller companies have already experienced a surging demand for O.J. memorabilia: T-shirts, posters, sports equipment and autographs. Alas,  notoriety sells. **********The ethical issue lurking in any entanglement with a suspected murderer will not arise for most corporations because they would probably prefer to use Attila the Hun over O.J. as their spokesperson. Public opinion polls tell them that a majority of the country continues to believe that, his acquittal notwithstanding, Mr. Simpson is guilty of two grisly murders. Indeed, some marketers have already backed away. **********Nonetheless, the ethical issues are not self-policing. Many corporations target products and advertising at very specific and narrow audiences, and Mr. Simpson may prove to be a highly marketable figure in minority communities where he remains an icon. Predictably, a corporation will experiment with O.J. endorsing some minority-targeted product (a brand of liquor or cigarette, perhaps, or a magazine); if successful, others may follow. At its worst, this could become the marketing equivalent of "playing the race card" -- that is, the use of Mr. Simpson as a defiant symbol precisely to capitalize on its inflammatory effect. **********For media companies, the issues are more problematic. The public demand seems obvious. "Court TV" addicts, facing cold-turkey withdrawal from their favorite soap opera, would probably rush to buy a book or consume a TV special that gives Mr. Simpson's "inside" perspective. **********So the ethical issue persists for corporations that may want to exploit that  demand. But what precisely is the ethical issue? **********Wrongly defined, it asks: Can an "ethical" corporation have any involvement with a person whom its managers and owners believe to be guilty of a terrible crime? The problem here lies not in the predictable response that Mr. Simpson was acquitted (a criminal jury, after all, is only empowered to decide that a reasonable doubt exists). Rather, it lies in the public's right to know. **********Business ethics should not be defined in such a way as to encroach upon First Amendment values. Media corporations can thus fairly claim that Mr. Simpson is no different than a variety of other figures -- some convicted, some acquitted -- whose speech would have historical value (Aldrich Ames on the C.I.A., for example, or Michael Milken on Wall Street). **********Indeed, in striking down New York's "Son of Sam" law that required publishers to escrow the profits received by criminals from books describing their crimes,  the Supreme Court ruled that the First Amendment cannot tolerate any law that seeks to target and chill a particular form of lawful speech. Although no corporation is required to publish or promote Mr. Simpson, the traditional idea  that the marketplace promotes the search for truth is a legitimate justification for some corporate involvement with him. **********The real ethical issue involves how any corporation associates itself with Mr. Simpson. Simply put, it is ethically permissible to publish Mr. Simpson's book or defense, but sleazy to use someone that management believes to have "gotten away with murder" to market a corporate product or service, even to a narrow audience that sees him as an idol. A Barbara Walters interviewing O.J. may be in the tradition of Edward R. Murrow investigating Senator McCarthy, but  a smirking Jay Leno interviewing him is not. The classic idea that a free marketplace of ideas promotes the search for truth justifies the first, but not  the second. **********In publishing or presenting Mr. Simpson, business ethics should also require  truth in advertising. Promoting a Simpson book as the "true" story or the "inside story of what actually happened" seems dubious without some affirmative  efforts to verify those facts. A publisher need not believe its author, but it cannot ethically present as true what it has serious reason to believe is false. An ethical publisher should distance itself from those statements it doubts. **********Finally, noncommercial associations between the corporation and a controversial figure who remains under a cloud of suspicion also raise ethical concerns. Many corporations use sports and public figures at internal corporate  events -- as motivational speakers at sales conferences, for instance, or as figureheads at annual golf tournaments.  No simple prophylactic rule can address every such situation, but clearly such a use of Mr. Simpson (unlike the publication of a book or an interview on TV) cannot be justified by the claim that it promotes a search for truth. **********Today, more than 90 percent of the largest United States companies have a corporate code of ethics, many of which address issues like truth in advertising or preservation of the company's reputation for integrity. A growing number of such companies -- around 20 percent -- also have formalized ethics committees or a similar body to evaluate fact-specific ethical issues. **********Unfortunately, the focus of these codes and committees has been narrowly legalistic, with the principal intent being to restrict lower-echelon management from engaging in unlawful conduct, like making bribes, payoffs or political contributions, that may injure the corporation. It is not the junior manager, however, who will endanger the corporation's reputation by using Mr. Simpson as  a corporate representative. **********This observation leads to two policy conclusions: First, senior managers must take seriously the mechanisms they have put in place for others and refer any use of or association with a figure like Mr. Simpson to such an ethics review. Second, any corporate code of ethics must evolve and mature in order to focus as much on the corporation's relationships with, and commitments to, its constituencies as on the need to protect itself from its own employees. **********The minimum obligation on an ethical corporation before it uses a person as questionable as Mr. Simpson as its agent or representative is to articulate a general ethical policy that both justifies that association and places clear limits on it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/02/world.main_headline: Dublin Greets Distant Relative of the Old Sod
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/02/world.print_headline: Dublin Greets Distant Relative of the Old Sod
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/02/world.body_text: **********Tens of thousands of flag-waving Dubliners waited and shivered for three hours today to cheer President Clinton for having the good luck to have Irish roots and for bringing lasting peace closer in Northern Ireland, just 60 miles up the Belfast road. **********On the third day of his trip to Europe, Mr. Clinton made crisp speeches on the acceleration of the Northern Ireland peace effort, defended his decision to  send troops to Bosnia and made repeated references to things Irish: writers and  musicians, the Great Famine that created the Irish diaspora, his ancestors, the  Cassidys. **********The crowds in the street and the Members of Parliament loved it. **********At a rally in downtown Dublin, and in the Parliament, he reminded his audiences -- and they reminded him -- that no American President has ever won the adulation that John F. Kennedy gained here in 1963, when he promised to return. Some Irish said Mr. Clinton had now fulfilled the Kennedy promise. **********"On this beautiful Irish day I feel like a real Dub," he said, using the common abbreviation for Dubliners. "Is that what I'm supposed to say?" **********It was. **********People yelled and waved hundreds of shiny plastic American and Irish flags, many of them provided by the White House and distributed by Irish auxiliary guards at the President's appearance on College Green, a few hundred yards from Trinity College. **********Irish and American spectators both got the distinct impression that the President's campaign for re-election had begun in earnest as television cameras  recorded his terse speeches on Northern Ireland and his plunges into crowds of people to shake hands and smile back at pink-cheeked children. **********"I'm here to celebrate peace," said Julitta Clancy, who brought three of her  seven children from rural County Meath and waited three hours as shadows cooled  the green. **********"I'm so delighted he put his weight into the peace process," she said.  "For  25 years there's been rule up there by terrorist gangs." **********She said Mr. Clinton had persuaded Irish-Americans not to support groups that financed violence in the North, and noted that there has never been significant  support in the Irish Republic for the Irish Republican Army, whose political wing, Sinn Fein, wins only about 1.5 percent of the vote. **********There was no event in the President's day in Dublin to compare with the emotional performance on Thursday in Belfast of Catherine Hamill, an 8-year-old, blond-haired Catholic girl who read a letter to Mr. Clinton about how her father had been killed by the sectarian warfare and how she hoped for peace. **********Mr. Clinton said several times today that he had been moved by the girl's words, and added: "I want more than anything for the young people of Ireland, wherever they live on this island, to be able to grow up and live out their dreams close to their roots in peace and honor and freedom and equality." **********He got several modest laughs during the day with gentle, unhilarious jokes. But he drew a loud burst from the outdoor crowd after he said, "My mother was a  Cassidy and how I wish she were alive to be here with me today. She would have loved the small towns and she would have loved Dublin. Most of all, she would have loved the fact that in Ireland, you have nearly 300 racing days a year. She loved the horses." **********Turning to Bosnia, the President said he was "very gratified" by the announcement by Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, that he supported the sending of American troops as peacekeepers. And he defended his policy against those who argue that the Balkan wars are problem only for Europe. **********"I'd like to ask every American," he said, "how you would have felt when President Bush sent out the call for help in Desert Storm, which was a war, not  a peacekeeping measure, if they [the Europeans] had said: 'You handle that. You  have more money, more soldiers, more interest there. You're concerned about the  oil; you waste more oil than the rest of us do. You guys handle that.' "

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/20/world.main_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;British Tory M.P. Loses Homosexual Libel Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/20/world.print_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;British Tory M.P. Loses Homosexual Libel Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/20/world.body_text: **********A British Member of Parliament lost a libel action today over allegations he  was homosexual, a liar and a hypocrite, bringing to a close one of the most bizarre legal cases heard in an English court for years. **********David Ashby, of the ruling Conservative Party, burst into tears after the verdict was announced and pushed away his estranged wife, Silvana, who had provided much of the evidence in support of allegations made by The Sunday Times. **********Mr. Ashby had sued the newspaper over a story that appeared in January 1994  saying he had shared a bed with a male friend on vacation. The paper also said he was having an affair with a male doctor. Mr. Ashby denied he was homosexual. **********Mr. Ashby, who faces a legal bill estimated at $750,000 to cover the cost of  the four-week trial, admitted to the court he had shared a bed with other male Members of Parliament more than once but had only done so to save money. **********Mr. Ashby said that his wife was obsessed by the idea he might be homosexual. Mrs. Ashby told the court that when she complained she was lonely in her marriage, her husband bought her a dog.

A 12-story building rising in the heart of Washington's central business district is the first major structure built here for the general office market,  rather than a specific tenant, in the last five years. 

     The developer is the Kaempfer C...
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/25/busin.main_headline: Real Estate;Signs of an improving market: a 12-story office building is going up in Washington.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/25/busin.print_headline: Real Estate;Signs of an improving market: a 12-story office building is going up in Washington.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/25/busin.body_text: **********A 12-story building rising in the heart of Washington's central business district is the first major structure built here for the general office market,  rather than a specific tenant, in the last five years. **********The developer is the Kaempfer Company of Washington, in partnership with PVF  Nederland N.V., which administers the assets of three Dutch pension funds. The site is at 19th and K Streets, and the building is known as 1900 K Street. Completion is scheduled for next summer. Lease commitments have been obtained for 80 percent of the 340,000 square feet of space, Kaempfer said. **********Washington will remain one of the most vibrant political and business centers of the world," said Joop J. Hiddink, managing director for PVF Real Estate North America and the investment manager for the pension funds, "and while office space demand will ebb and flow, there will at all times be strong demand for distinctive" office buildings. **********The $120 million development comes at a time of low vacancy rates in office buildings. In the overall office market in Washington, vacancies are placed at a substantial 18 percent in what brokers consider Class C buildings -- older office buildings. The Class B buildings, older buildings but candidates for upgrading in stronger markets, have a vacancy rate of only 7 percent. The inventory defined as Class A office buildings has a vacancy rate of 3.6 percent. **********"The demand is not strong enough to encourage developers to get started," said Stephen B. Goldstein, manager of the Washington office of Julien J. Studley, a national real estate company. "Supply is limited, but demand is also  very limited." **********Demand was strong enough, however, to bring forth commitments that led Kaempfer and its Dutch partner to start construction on 25,600 square feet of land that Kaempfer assembled over several years. Through Studley and the real estate company of Larson, Ball & Gould, leases were signed with McKenna & Cuneo, a law firm, for 110,000 square feet, and with Hunton & Williams, another law firm, for 80,000 square feet. With the leases in hand, the developer broke ground in January. **********The building has been designed by Cesar Pelli of Cesar Pelli & Associates, New Haven, who also designed the World Financial Center in New York City. It will be faced in glass and green stone from Britain, framed in stainless steel.  The corner entrance is a quarter circle flanked by columns. Within the entrance, a balcony will overlook an interior courtyard. **********Kaempfer is one of Washington's largest builders. It renovated the Warner theater, redone as part of an office complex at Pennsylvania Avenue and 12th Street. The company has built more than three million square feet of office space in Washington. **********"The pendulum has swung a little more in favor of the landlord," said Mitchell N. Schear, senior vice president of Kaempfer. "In the past six months tenants have started competing for space in existing buildings." **********As a result, rent concessions from owners have grown more moderate, brokers report, and basic rent levels are "edging up," in the phrase of brokers. **********Another sign of encouragement to brokers is a rehabilitation project in the office building at 2020 K Street, about a block from the Kaempfer project. Quadrangle Development, the owner, renovated the floors while shifting the tenants within, at a time when the building was largely empty. Now the top four  floors have been leased by the AT&T; Corporation. With that lease and expansion of existing tenants, the building is now 75 percent occupied. **********Also, representatives of Gerald Hines, a Houston-based real estate developer, said they would start a 240,000-square-foot building at 600 13th Street early next year. The building has no tenants thus far, however. The architect is Robert A. M. Stern of New York. **********And the John Akridge Company, a development company, is hoping to start construction soon on a 250,000-square-foot building, a twin of the already existing 1225 I Street, which has been in planning for 10 years. **********But in a city where an estimated 50 percent of office leases are said to be expiring within the next three years, the major activity of brokers has been to  seek early renewals on behalf of building owners. **********"Tenants are trying to shake off the last years of high rents by renewing early," said Trip Howell, senior vice president of Grubb & Ellis of Metropolitan Washington.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/15/world.main_headline: At Vatican, Capital Role For Jerusalem
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/15/world.print_headline: At Vatican, Capital Role For Jerusalem
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/15/world.body_text: **********Leah Rabin, widow of the slain Israeli Prime Minister, said today that in a private conversation with Pope John Paul II, he acknowledged Jerusalem to be the capital of Israel as well as the "capital" of three world religions. **********In his remarks, Mrs. Rabin said at a news conference, the Pope insisted that  Jerusalem has a "double role," a reference to the special status that the Vatican has long sought for a city held sacred by Christians, Muslims and Jews.  But it was apparently the first time the Pope accepted Israel's claim to Jerusalem as its capital. **********The Vatican did not officially confirm the Pope's private remarks to Mrs. Rabin, and diplomats here are waiting to see whether they will be published in Vatican documents in coming days. But coinciding with an official visit this weekend to Jerusalem by the Vatican's foreign minister, Archbishop Jean-Louis Tauran, the remarks suggest the Pope's personal interest in resolving one of history's oldest disputes. **********Mrs. Rabin, who is in Italy for commemorations honoring Yitzhak Rabin, said she raised the question of Jerusalem during a 15-minute private audience with the Pope, in which she was accompanied by her children. **********"He said Jerusalem has a double role," she told reporters. "It is the capital of Israel and it's the capital of the three faiths." **********She added: "When it comes to the question of the role of Jerusalem, I heard him say so. I wasn't there alone. I was with my children. And it was clearly said. I understand that the Vatican may have a problem with a statement like this." **********The status of Jerusalem has historically been a sensitive point for the Roman Catholic Church and had at one time held up formal diplomatic relations between  Israel and the Vatican. Relations were established in 1994, but the issue of Jerusalem was left unresolved. **********Most countries, including the United States, do not formally recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel, since the Palestinians also claim Arab East  Jerusalem, annexed by Israel in 1980, to be their capital. **********The Pope has a longstanding invitation to visit Israel, which was repeated today by Mrs. Rabin, and he often says it is his dream to visit the Holy Land, as Pope Paul VI did in 1964. But until recently, a trip by John Paul to Israel would have created problems for its Arab neighbors, with whom the Vatican wants  to keep good relations. **********Recent developments, however, indicate that such a trip may be possible, as the negotiated peace between Israel and the Palestinians takes hold, and Israel  withdraws from some of the occupied territories. **********In the last few weeks, the Vatican formally accredited the first official Palestinian representative to the Holy See, seen as another necessary piece in the puzzle of the church's relations in the Middle East. The Pope's reported comments could be another piece to the same puzzle. **********According to one diplomat here, "It is not far away from the Vatican's eventual position, which is that a country can have the capital of its own choice, as long as it comes with some recognition of its special significance." **********"Their position is flexible," the diplomat said, "but they want something from Israel, something that recognizes that Jerusalem has a special character."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/05/busin.main_headline: Futures Trades Could Explain Daiwa Mystery
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/05/busin.print_headline: Futures Trades Could Explain Daiwa Mystery
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/05/busin.body_text: **********To futures traders at Lehman Brothers, there was something about Toshihide Iguchi -- they called him "Toshi" -- that just didn't make sense. **********At the end of a hectic day, Mr. Iguchi, a bond trader at the New York branch  of Daiwa Bank Ltd., would often execute a complex maneuver used mainly by those  specialized traders who seek to exploit small mathematical discrepancies in the  market. But these moves did not seem to fit with Mr. Iguchi's other trading. Although he certainly made large bets, he was ostensibly a straightforward short-term investor betting on the direction of interest rates. **********Last week, the motive for the strange trades suddenly became clear, when Daiwa announced that Mr. Iguchi had racked up $1.1 billion in losses over the last 11 years. **********"When I saw in the paper what he did, I finally understood what happened," said one trader who had done business with Mr. Iguchi at Lehman. **********The effect of those unusual trades, known as basis trades, was actually to help him hide losses in the futures market, say three traders who worked at Lehman in the late 1980's and early 1990's. **********This is a new twist. In fact, Mr. Iguchi appears to have covered his tracks so well that in its initial statements, Daiwa and the United States Attorney's office, which has brought fraud charges against Mr. Iguchi, said he had only traded United States Treasury bonds and had done no trading in futures or any other financial instruments known as derivatives. **********Derivatives are fast and easy ways to make big bets on financial markets and  have been involved in some of the biggest financial disasters of recent years. Indeed, futures contracts were behind the downfall of Britain's Barings P.L.C. when a trader in Singapore lost $1.3 billion trading futures on the Japanese stock market. **********What's more, according to these traders, who spoke on condition of anonymity, those complex trading maneuvers by Mr. Iguchi could well explain a central mystery: how he was able to tap into the bank's long-term bond holdings, and its holdings of customers' bonds, to cover his mounting losses. **********One key point is that Mr. Iguchi was in charge of both bond trading and some  record-keeping. That dual position -- which was specifically criticized as unsound by the Federal Reserve in 1992 and 1993 -- appears to have allowed him to hide even more of his trading tracks. The basis trades apparently permitted Mr. Iguchi to move the futures losses into bond accounts, which he controlled more directly, these traders said. **********In its fraud charges against Mr. Iguchi, the United States Attorney's office  in Manhattan said he had forged a statement from the Bankers Trust New York Corporation showing $4.5 billion of bonds held in Daiwa's account, when the account contained only $3.4 billion. It is that $1.1 billion gap that is said to represent Mr. Iguchi's trading losses. **********But it is still unclear how much of Daiwa's problem came from any futures trading by Mr. Iguchi. While traders at Lehman said he traded both bonds and futures there, traders at other firms remember him mainly for bond trading. **********Daiwa, based in Osaka, Japan, has already been harshly sanctioned by Federal  and New York State regulators, who have virtually closed down its trading activities in New York. **********And it faces further investigation in Japan. Bloomberg Business News reported today that Japanese financial authorities had begun an on-site investigation of  Daiwa offices. The Bank of Japan, the country's central bank, began searching Daiwa headquarters in Osaka and the Ministry of Finance its Tokyo branch, Keizo  Tsujiyama, manager of corporate communications at Daiwa, was quoted as saying. Bloomberg also said Sumio Abekawa, Daiwa's chairman, had quit as head of the Kansai International Airport Company to focus his energy on the bank's review. **********Representatives of Daiwa, Lehman and the United States Attorney's office declined to comment on any futures trades by Daiwa. **********The root of Daiwa's problem may lie in Japan's rush to get a financial foothold abroad. In the mid-1980's, at the peak of Japan's financial rise, Japanese banks and brokerage firms were eager to establish themselves among the  leading players in New York and London financial markets. Mr. Iguchi was one of  a handful of traders who burst on New York's bond market, buying and selling in  huge quantities. Even at the time, this appeared to be more bravado than skill;  most successful traders are as discreet as possible. **********Still, Mr. Iguchi was one of the most active and profitable customers for Lehman's futures desk, Lehman traders said. "It was a hot, hot account and was handled with kid gloves," one trader said. **********On the phone, another trader said, Mr. Iguchi was arrogant and abrupt, but no more so than many others on Wall Street, generally not considered the most polite of places. Those who met him, though, described a shy, reticent man with  a slight build, who often talked about his personal problems -- like an unpleasant divorce. **********What Mr. Iguchi did not talk about, but what appears to have been eating away at him, was a disastrous record as a trader. **********In a rambling 30-page letter that Mr. Iguchi sent to the president of Daiwa in late July admitting the losses, he described a tale of woe. **********"He must be the worst trader in the world," said someone who has read the letter. "Every time the market moved, he was on the wrong side. He said he saw people making big-time money at other banks and he wanted to trade big as well." **********In the letter, filled with guilt and self-criticism, Mr. Iguchi blames his worry about his trading losses for the end of his marriage, said the person who  read the letter, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "He said he was ready to confess at least four times, but then he didn't," this person said. **********Lehman traders said that they could not tell whether Daiwa was making or losing money over all on its trading, but the that unusual basis trades appeared to be a way to cover up his losses in futures. **********"We would say, 'Is Toshi making or losing money?' " one trader recalled. "If  he was losing money, he would do a basis trade." **********Because of the peculiarities of accounting for basis trades, such a maneuver  could make it look as if he had lost no money on futures. **********In a basis trade, someone sells futures and receives the actual commodity --  in this case bonds -- on which the futures contract is based (hence the name "basis"). The trade could also work in reverse: trading bonds for futures. **********Because they involve a swap of things of theoretically identical value, basis trades do not have to be sent to the brawling floor of the Chicago Board of Trade to be executed at the current market price. Instead, a dealer like Lehman  can merely set the price anywhere between the day's high and low. **********This flexibility appears to have allowed Lehman -- legally -- to get Mr. Iguchi out of some jams. On days when Mr. Iguchi bought futures that subsequently fell in price, he would call Lehman and do a basis trade, selling futures and receiving bonds. And he would ask that the price be set at the day's high. **********That way his futures account would look as if it had broken even or even made a small profit. Of course, these moves did not erase Daiwa's losses; they merely moved the losses from the futures account to the bond account. That is because the cost of creating the appearance of selling futures at a good price was that  Mr. Iguchi had to buy bonds at the same inflated price. **********And this could have helped Mr. Iguchi avoid having his losses detected. In futures trading, traders must cover losing positions every day with cash margin  payments. **********In bond accounts, by contrast, cash moves only when bonds are bought and sold. Moreover, Daiwa said Mr. Iguchi had forged not only account statements but also trade confirmations and other records in the bond account that hid his actions. **********For a dealer like Lehman, swapping bonds and futures is not improper. This tactic is used, say, to move profits to the following year to delay taxes, or to postpone embarrassing losses. **********Traders familiar with Mr. Iguchi's futures activity also suggested that his unusual basis trades could also clear up another mystery: how he was able to tap into the bonds that Daiwa kept at Bankers Trust. **********Under normal circumstances, a custodian like Bankers Trust releases such bonds only when it is notified that cash has been received for them. These payments have to be accounted for on the books of the institution, creating various auditable paper trails. **********But with basis trades, the custodian transfers the bonds to a futures firm and receives a notice that they were part of an exchange for futures. **********Traders who did business with Mr. Iguchi suggest that by using bonds in the custody account to cover losses from futures trading, Mr. Iguchi could well have found an easy way to keep his activity undetected. Other futures-trading experts say that while this is plausible, Mr. Iguchi could have found other ways to tap  into the bonds in the custody account.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/27/world.main_headline: Pacific Islanders Swindled of Unlikely Riches
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/27/world.print_headline: Pacific Islanders Swindled of Unlikely Riches
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/27/world.body_text: **********This is about the people on a tiny Pacific island who make more money than they know what to do with from a source hardly anyone would think of. It is also about some outsiders who, the authorities say, tried to swindle the islanders of $28 million. **********The guilty pleas of three outsiders and the indictments of five others were announced yesterday by Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau, who has seen a lot over the years but perhaps nothing like the lies he described, including a bogus claim of ties to the Rothschild banking family. **********Nauru is an island republic of 7.7 square miles 2,400 miles northeast of Australia. Its people prosper not from oil or fish but from the island's only natural resource: bird droppings, which yield high-grade phosphate for fertilizer -- and enough money to give the people one of the highest per-capita  incomes in the world. Earnings are administered by the Naura Phosphate Royalties Trust, based in Melbourne, Australia. **********Mr. Morgenthau said trust officials were persuaded in 1991 to invest $8.75 million in a letter of credit that was supposed to yield $10 million in a year.  In 1992, trust officials put up $20 million for a "prime bank guarantee" that supposedly would return $25 million in a year. **********The $8.75 million was lost but much of the $20 million was recovered, Mr. Morgenthau said. **********The prosecutor said a key figure in the bogus transactions was Ronald Adrian  Powles, a partner in the London office of the Australian law firm that advised the trust fund. Mr. Morgenthau said Mr. Powles's colleagues eventually became suspicious of his activities. Mr. Powles has not yet been charged but is in prison in Australia, after a suicide attempt, and is under investigation. So are others in Australia and Britain, Mr. Morgenthau said. **********The scheme also became shaky, the prosecutor said, when a British associate of some defendants threatened to tell the police if the swindlers did not pay his London hotel bill. Mr. Morgenthau said that, to get money for the bill, the  swindlers sold a New Jersey businessman a phony certificate of deposit. **********The three who pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court were Frank Decabia, 53, of Scarsdale, N.Y., a former broker with Josephthal Lyons & Ross; Michael McNamara, 48, a broker from Lake Montezuma, Ariz., and Glen Tobias, 45, a Los Angeles broker. All admitted felony fraud charges and have promised to cooperate. **********Under indictment for charges ranging from grand larceny to scheming to defraud are: Leonard Gruber, 56, and Stephen R. Desimone, 35, both of Manhattan; Gary Moody, 43, of Bountiful, Utah; Ralph Scheri, 63, of Naperville, Ill., and Owen Rice, 59, of Tampa, Fla. All pleaded not guilty at arraignment. **********Mr. Gruber, Mr. Rice and Mr. Scheri were officials of a now-defunct Antigua bank. Mr. Moody was a broker and Mr. Desimone was formerly a broker at Paine Webber, according to Mr. Morgenthau.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/17/world.main_headline: Ex-President of South Korea Is Arrested And Apologizes in a HugeBribery Scandal
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/17/world.print_headline: Ex-President of South Korea Is Arrested And Apologizes in a HugeBribery Scandal
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/17/world.body_text: **********Roh Tae Woo, a former general who presided over South Korea's transformation  into a democratic nation, was arrested tonight for accepting hundreds of millions of dollars in bribes while he was President. **********Tired, downcast and humiliated, Mr. Roh (pronounced no) was wedged into the back seat of an unmarked sedan in Seoul as hundreds of camera flashes illuminated his face as if he were under a disco strobe. He was taken to a jail  and placed under 24-hour guard. **********Mr. Roh, who took office with the reputation of a reformer and the image of  an "ordinary man," called South Korea's first elections in 16 years when his appointment as President by military rulers in 1987 triggered riots. He split the opposition vote and won a five-year term despite charges of fraud. He now faces a possible sentence of life in prison. **********An indictment is expected within the next 20 days, and Mr. Roh may go on trial very soon thereafter. There is some talk among politicians that he could be pardoned rather than made to serve a long sentence. **********Mr. Roh is accused of soliciting corporate donations to create a political slush fund and also to build a personal fortune based on a web of real estate and bank accounts held in other people's names. **********He is widely believed to know enough to put half of the people listed in any  Who's Who of South Korea in prison for giving or accepting bribes. A few days ago he suggested that he would reveal what he knows, but tonight he seemed to hint that he would keep his secrets in his jail cell. **********"I am really sorry, and I take full responsibility for this case," Mr. Roh declared to reporters as he prepared to enter the car for the ride to jail. "I am ready to accept any kind of punishment willingly." **********"What pains me the most at this point is that many businessmen have suffered  on my behalf," added Mr. Roh, who is 62 and left the presidency in 1993. "I would like to ask for public understanding so that these businessmen can be given the strength and support they need, so that they do not lose their international competitiveness." **********Mr. Roh was summoned from his home on Wednesday afternoon for a long interrogation, and prosecutors said that shortly after midnight he began to talk about the payoffs. The prosecutors said Mr. Roh, who chided aides shortly after  his election for replacing his Korean-made car with a Cadillac, partly acknowledged the existence of secret Swiss bank accounts, and admitted that he had accepted cash from corporate tycoons. **********Officials of 36 leading South Korean companies have been interrogated about money they are accused of giving Mr. Roh, and the top executives of some major conglomerates could go to jail as well. The South Korean public seems torn between a desire to see the culprits punished and a fear of economic chaos if leading business executives are thrown into jail. **********"The cardinal sin was Roh Tae Woo's," said Lee Seo Hang, a professor of international relations at an institute affiliated with the Foreign Ministry. "The companies were just accomplices." **********Mr. Roh's arrest warrant suggests that he took at least $305 million in bribes, including millions of dollars from the head of Daewoo Corporation in exchange for a contract that Daewoo won to build a submarine base. The chairman  of Daewoo, Kim Woo Choong, is expected to be questioned upon his return from Poland, where he is reportedly discussing the possible construction of a Daewoo  auto plant. **********In the broadest sense, the arrest today is seen as a disgrace not only for Mr. Roh but also for all of South Korea. For several decades "gift-giving" has been an integral part of doing business in South Korea, with payoffs expected by politicians, bureaucrats and journalists. **********"It was the system," an executive of a major South Korean company said today, arguing that tycoons should not be jailed. "It was a cost of doing business." **********Yet while South Koreans have been deeply shamed by the $650 million slush fund that Mr. Roh has reportedly acknowledged he accumulated as President, it is also possible to see the scandal as an outgrowth of the country's unsteady march toward democracy. **********The scandal came to light because of growing pluralism -- in the form of aggressive investigations and questioning by opposition politicians -- and there is little talk of a coup or other actions to shelter Mr. Roh from prosecution. **********"This scandal must serve as a catalyst to destroy corrupt structures throughout the nation," said Seo Sang Mok, a lawmaker in the governing party. **********Mr. Roh has been given some consideration for his former status, in that he was not handcuffed at his arrest and was given sole occupancy of a cell designed for several people at the Seoul Detention House. Also, Mr. Roh will have no limit to visits by his family or lawyers. **********Prosecutors may also arrest aides and family members of Mr. Roh, and the episode has already damaged the credibility of both President Kim Young Sam and  his main rival, Kim Dae Jung, a longtime dissident whose civil rights Mr. Roh had restored before the 1987 election. **********President Kim's party has admitted that it benefited from $100 million given  to it by Mr. Roh, although it is unclear whether some of that money was then used to help elect Kim Young Sam to the presidency. **********Kim Dae Jung, for his part, has admitted accepting about $2.5 million from Mr. Roh for use in his presidential race against Kim Young Sam. Opposition politicians are pressing for an investigation of how Mr. Roh's slush fund was used. **********Mr. Roh reportedly has refused to comment on the political uses of his funds, and he apparently has said that he does not remember exactly how much money he received from each company. **********"Unless it becomes clear how Roh Tae Woo's money was spent, it will be difficult to avoid more arrows of suspicion pointing to the President," said Park Kye Dong, an opposition member of the National Assembly who broke the scandal a month ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/25/world.main_headline: Christmas in Bethlehem: Arafat at Midnight Mass
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/25/world.print_headline: Christmas in Bethlehem: Arafat at Midnight Mass
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/25/world.body_text: **********The night was certainly not silent and it was not always calm as Bethlehem marked its first Christmas under Palestinian control with thunderous fireworks,  choirs, bagpipes, dances and laser lights. **********While the revelry flowed over Manger Square, Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestinian Authority, took his place in the front pew of St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church, part of the larger complex including the Orthodox Church  of the Nativity, for the traditional Midnight Mass in his role as the new leader of Bethlehem and the Palestinians of the West Bank. **********Sitting impassively in his trademark checkered headdress with his wife, Suha, and Bethlehem's mayor of 23 years, Elias Freij, Mr. Arafat listened as the Latin Patriarch, Michel Sabbah, a Palestinian who is the chief Catholic prelate  of the region, praised him and declared that "the beginning of Palestinian freedom is the beginning of reconciliation between Palestinian and Jewish people." **********Following an ancient tradition, the patriarch was escorted from his seat in Jerusalem to Bethlehem by mounted guards. For 28 years, Israelis escorted him the entire way. But this year, the Israeli horsemen accompanied him only as far  as Rachel's Tomb, on the outskirts of Bethlehem, where a group of Palestinian riders in blue uniforms and black-checkered headscarves took over. **********In brief comments of his own, which he made before the services began, Mr. Arafat referred to Jesus in the Muslim tradition as a prophet, and reiterated the themes of peace and harmony that he sounded on Saturday when he made his first triumphant entry into Bethlehem. **********"We pray together and we work together for peace which our prophet Jesus Christ worked and struggled for. And I'm very sure that we will achieve this goal, not only in Bethlehem but also in Jerusalem," he said. "Tonight, Muslims,  Christians and Jews will celebrate in the land of peace." **********Mr. Arafat was originally supposed to have made his first appearance on Christmas Eve, but he moved up his arrival a day, apparently in order not to compete with the Christmas celebrations. **********In any case, it was outside the church, in the Manger Square, that the real celebrations were taking place, and they were as much about the end of Israeli occupation as they were about the birth of Jesus in a cave here in what was then a little town, and is now a city of 55,000. **********The winding, two-lane roads to the square were ablaze with decorations, with  the majority featuring the Palestinian flag and Mr. Arafat's visage, and chock full of cars and pedestrians making their way toward Manger Square. But hundreds of blue-uniformed Palestinian police officers maintained control. **********While German, Fiji, Finnish and many other choirs took turns singing Christmas carols and songs -- including a lively rendition of "Jingle Bells" in  Arabic by a Palestinian choir -- a laser beam traced the words "Release the Prisoners," with the names of Palestinian leaders held in Israeli prisons, on a  large sheet over the square. **********On the square, thick with bottles and debris after three days of almost non-stop celebrations, men linked arms to dance rousing Palestinian steps to a flute or paused at many grills and soda stands. Occasional fireworks would erupt with a deafening bang overhead, sending the crowd into peals of joy. **********"It's good, it's big, and it's a good deal of money," rejoiced a Palestinian  man peddling haroup, a sweet non-alcoholic Arab beverage, from a large backpack  decorated in flowers. "Everything is different from before. There are many more  people, much more celebration." **********Amal Shukri, a Christian Palestinian from Bethlehem, came out with two children, ages 8 and 7. "I told them this is a very special Christmas," she said. "It's wonderful that Arafat is here. We're very happy to have him." **********Though there were far more Palestinians this year and far more revelry, there also seemed to be fewer foreign tourists, presumably because of the uncertainty  over how the transfer of authority from Israel to the Palestinians would go. Christian tourism is the major industry in Bethlehem, and one of the main goals  of Mr. Arafat and Mayor Freij this year was to convince visitors that they could come in safety and comfort. **********"People in Tel Aviv think we were crazy to come here, but we're here, so we might as well live the experience," said Andy Gould, an American who lives and works in Tel Aviv, and who came with a group of Israeli friends. "There was history going on around, and we wanted to see it. We were a bit apprehensive, but people have been very friendly. They've offered us food, they seem very excited. It's like Independence Day." **********The only incident on Christmas Eve occurred at the Israeli checkpoint on the  border of the West Bank, where the police stopped busloads of Israeli nationalists who had wanted to hold a protest against the transfer of authority  to the Palestinians at Rachel's Tomb. **********The protesters held up posters and chanted, "Land of Israel, Land of Israel"  as the police blocked their way to the West Bank. **********"Why can't we go in?" demanded Judy Pearlman, a Jerusalem resident originally from New York. "The Arabs are having their celebration worshiping their God. Why can't we worship ours? All we want to do is light candles at Rachel's Tomb on the last day of Hanukkah. We're second-class citizens in our own country."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/04/busin.main_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;Stocks: The Next Generation
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/04/busin.print_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;Stocks: The Next Generation
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/04/busin.body_text: **********Q. I want to invest in stocks for my grandchildren. Should I do this any differently than if they were for my portfolio? A. You certainly should. While fat dividends in Fortune 500 companies may make sense for you, for your grandchildren you should look for maximum capital appreciation. **********That means nice, solid, growth stocks. If you are very conservative, you may want to mix in some United States Savings Bonds, which can offer tax advantages  when used to pay for higher education. But in the long term -- the term that is  relevant for children -- the action is in stocks. Since 1945, when the Dow Jones industrial average hovered at one-twentieth of today's 4,400 level, stocks have  enjoyed average annual returns of roughly 10 percent. For fixed-rate investments, the returns are just 7.5 percent. **********And to make investing real for children, "why not buy them shares in companies with which they already interact?" suggests Stephen V. Chaplin, an investment counselor with the Radix Organization in New York. Among others, he said, try Kellogg, Sara Lee, Coca-Cola, McDonald's, Toys "R" Us, Apple Computer  and Disney. Disney offers the added appeal of stock certificates adorned with Mickey, Pinocchio, Cinderella -- pretty enough to frame and hang on the nursery  wall. **********Disney, in fact, is one of the few companies that looks at children as future investors, which is what they are. Although some publicly held companies have livened up their annual reports -- Marvel's comic book format, for instance -- most have not. But they should. I still remember the 1973 annual report of Macmillan, the publishing company, which was written in Kid's English. **********However, while buying stocks for your grandchildren is great, maybe the biggest favor you can do is to get them interested in Wall Street. After buying  the shares, sit down with the newspaper stock tables and show them how to locate their investments. Explain how dividends are paid and why it's O.K. to take losses. **********Many books also teach children about investing. Among them are the lavishly illustrated "Money," an oversized book for preadolescents, and "It's My Money: A Kid's Guide to the Green Stuff," by Ann Banks. **********And more books are on the way. This fall Derrick Niederman, a disciple of Peter Lynch, will publish "This Is Not Your Father's Stockpicking Book." Mr. Niederman's message is tailor-made for teen-agers: forget wading through complex financial statements; just watch TV and read the papers and look for trends. **********With college bills threatening to become the "$64,000 Question," your grandchildren need all the help you can afford. But if college costs are a major target of your generosity to your grandchildren, watch out. "There are definitely flies in this ointment," says Kalman A. Chany, author of "The Princeton Review Guide to Paying for College." **********If you put assets in the name of a future college student, he explains, under standard financial-aid rules the school will deem 35 percent of that money as usable for tuition and thereby reduce the student's eligibility for aid. It may  be a better idea to give the money to the parents instead, who will only be tapped for up to 5.65 percent of their savings under the rules. Best to check with your accountant or a financial aid planner. **********Of course, there's another approach. Twenty years ago, parents were thrilled  to get a note from school declaring they had a gifted child. Today, they tremble at what it might cost down the road. I can hear it now as some parents take steps to insure their child prodigy doesn't get into an expensive private college. "Haven't you been spending too much time on homework lately? Mom and I  think you should get out and play more." **********Questions about investing, careers and personal finance can be sent to Minding Your Business, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York 10036. Or E-mail to yourmind@nytimes.com.
