https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/20/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Court Papers Link 2 Daiwa Executives With Errant Trader
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/20/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Court Papers Link 2 Daiwa Executives With Errant Trader
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/20/busin.body_text: **********Federal prosecutors asserted yesterday that at least two senior executives at Daiwa Bank Ltd. conspired with their New York bond trader to conceal $1.1 billion in losses from bank regulators for two months this past summer. **********The allegations, disclosed in court documents unsealed yesterday, were the first indication that the trading scandal at Daiwa went beyond the trader, Toshihide Iguchi, a 44-year-old senior vice president at the bank's New York office. **********The accusation was made as Mr. Iguchi pleaded guilty to a series of charges  in United States District Court in Manhattan. In addition to conspiring with senior management in the cover-up, the charges included bank fraud involving the $1.1 billion, embezzling more than $500,000 for his own personal use, and money  laundering. **********In pleading guilty, Mr. Iguchi also said there had been a cover-up at higher  levels of the bank. **********The supposed cover-up, which Federal prosecutors said occurred between July 23 and Sept. 18, appears to have been a last-ditch attempt at the big Japanese bank to disguise Mr. Iguchi's huge-scale frauds, which date to 1984, but which he apparently revealed to top management in a letter written only in July. In the letter, he explained how he had lost the $1.1 billion in making unauthorized trades and selling customers' bonds to make up for it. **********The court documents said that the senior managers, after learning of Mr. Iguchi's disastrous losses, filed a false report with the Federal Reserve to cover up the $1.1 billion loss and failed to submit a criminal complaint to examiners, as required by law. They also falsified records and books at the New  York branch, the document said. **********The documents also said that Mr. Iguchi and other senior managers made "incomplete and misleading disclosures to the Federal Reserve Board and its examiners" in November 1993 about trading activities. **********The documents did not identify the officials at Daiwa who were said to have conspired with Mr. Iguchi, but said that they included at least one executive of the bank here and one in Japan. **********In a statement released late last night, Daiwa Bank in New York did not address the matter of a cover-up by Mr. Iguchi's superiors. "Mr. Iguchi has accepted responsibility for his crimes," the statement said, adding that "Daiwa  is continuing its own investigation, and is cooperating with the authorities in  their investigations." **********As the scope of the scandal widened, the role of government regulators in policing the bank remained an issue. William J. McDonough, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said through a spokesman yesterday that Mr. Iguchi's name had not come up at an Oct. 4, 1993, meeting at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York with Takeshi Ohta, then vice chairman of Daiwa Bank Ltd. The spokesman, Peter Bakstansky, added that Mr. Ohta had also telephoned the Fed earlier yesterday to say that he did not recall the name coming up at the meeting. **********Yesterday, The New York Times, citing a former senior Federal Reserve official present at the meeting, reported that concerns about Daiwa Bank's New York office, including the supervision of its traders and the name of Toshihide  Iguchi, had come up at that Oct. 4, 1993 meeting. The former Fed official also said that it appeared that the Fed did not work hard enough to uncover what Mr.  Iguchi was doing. **********Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, the Senate Banking Committee chairman, wrote to the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, yesterday, expressing "deep concern over recent events surrounding the activities of Daiwa Bank's New York branch, the lack of cooperation by Japan's Ministry of Finance, and an apparent supervisory lapse by the Federal Reserve and other agencies." **********Mr. Iguchi, who was born in Kobe, Japan, began making unauthorized trades at  Daiwa Bank's New York office in the early 1980's, and suffered big losses. Every time he tried to recoup the losses, he dug himself deeper into debt, he said yesterday. **********To hide the debacle from the bank, he devised a way to pay for the losses with bonds the bank held for its customers. Then he forged statements to hide his sale of the bonds. **********The scheme was only possible, he said, because he oversaw both securities trading and the bond-custody and settlement operations at the New York branch. Those tasks are typically performed by different people to prevent traders from  hiding losses or cheating. At least two other traders were involved in making unauthorized trades, he said. **********In his recounting of a cover-up, Mr. Iguchi said that on July 28 he showed copies of account statements he had falsified to hide the lost bonds to a senior official from Daiwa's headquarters in Japan and a senior manager from the New York branch. **********Instead of immediately reporting the losses to bank regulators, as required by law, the executives, according to Mr. Iguchi, told him to keep up the fraud for a few months, at least until November. "They asked me to continue concealing the losses," Mr. Iguchi said as he stood with head bowed before Judge Michael B. Mukasey. **********Three days later, on July 31, the bank filed a quarterly report to the Federal Reserve, falsely saying that it still held $600 million in Treasury bills, the court documents said. In addition, Mr. Iguchi said his superiors told him to continue selling other securities to raise money for the interest payments due on the phantom bonds that Mr. Iguchi had said the bank held. He also forged two more bank statements. **********Included in the criminal information the United States Attorney's office released yesterday were excerpts from Mr. Iguchi's mid-July letter of confession to Akira Fujita, Daiwa Bank's president. The letter, however, was as much an attempt to cover up as a confession because in it, Mr. Iguchi suggested that Daiwa replace the missing bonds and transfer the loss to a bank outside United States jursidication to elude detection. **********Mr. Iguchi also wrote a second letter to Mr. Fujita on July 21, according to  the court papers, urging him again to buy back the missing bonds and shift the loss to an overseas subsidiary. In that letter, Mr. Iguchi said the bank had fooled the American Federal investigators once and could avoid prosecution if it replaced the bonds. **********"I can clearly say, on the basis of the experience I gained from the Fed inspection the year before last, that there is zero possibility that this case would be found out in the United States if we bought back" the United States Treasury obligations "which is short," Mr. Iguchi wrote, according to the court  document. "Short" is a financial reference to the bonds that Mr. Iguchi had sold to cover his losses. **********During his plea, Mr. Iguchi said the cover-up in July was not the first time  Daiwa officials had misled the Federal Reserve. According to the court documents, regulators first became suspicious of Mr. Iguchi's trading practices  in 1992 and conducted on-site examinations of the bank. **********Just before the examination, Mr. Iguchi said, the bank temporarily transferred securities traders out of Mr. Iguchi's downtown office to the bank's midtown Manhattan office. That ruse was intended to give the appearance that Mr. Iguchi did not oversee the traders, he said, while he was also overseeing the settlements of trades and Daiwa's holdings of customer bonds. **********When the Federal regulators returned in November 1993, a senior Daiwa bank officer assured the examiners in a letter that Mr. Iguchi was no longer supervising the traders. The letter was a lie, Mr. Iguchi said yesterday. **********By the time Mr. Iguchi told his superiors in Japan about the situation earlier this year, he said he had been worn down by his efforts to cover his losses. "Personally, after 11 years of fruitless effort to recoup losses, my life was filled with fear, guilt and deception," he said. "I saw that no one was coming to stop this. There was no end in sight." **********The huge losses at Daiwa Bank, coming so soon after the hidden trading losses of more than $1 billion that caused the collapse in February this year of the venerable British merchant bank Barings, have raised questions about the safety  and soundness of banking systems, and the adequacy of regulation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/30/busin.body_text: **********In a case that has raised fears among foreigners doing business in China, an  Australian man lost his appeal this week to overturn a 16-year prison term for embezzlement and corruption. **********The Higher People's Court in Canton said there was sufficient evidence that James Peng embezzled $180,000 from a textile company he founded in Shenzhen, an  economic development zone abutting Hong Kong. **********Mr. Peng, 36, maintains that the charges were concocted by powerful Chinese  officials who coveted his business. The case has sent shock waves through Hong Kong, where trading with China is considered critical to the economy. **********Neither Mr. Peng, who was born in China and emigrated to Australia, nor his lawyers were allowed to speak at the 30-minute hearing on Tuesday, said Susan Dietz, the Australian consul in Canton.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/19/busin.main_headline: EARNING IT;For This He Needed to Become a Rhodes Scholar?
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/19/busin.print_headline: EARNING IT;For This He Needed to Become a Rhodes Scholar?
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/19/busin.body_text: **********RHODES Scholars. One can find them on the top of the corporate ladder, at the faculty clubs of august universities and in the halls of Congress. These days, there's one in the White House, too. **********Joseph Torsella, a Rhodes Scholar from the University of Pennsylvania, was also moving toward such heady precincts. Shortly after he returned from Oxford, Mr. Torsella was tapped to be the issues director for the Philadelphia mayoral campaign of Edward Rendell, whom he had met when he was a college student. Mr. Rendell won, and Mr. Torsella was asked to stay on the staff. One thing led to another, and at the age of 30 Mr. Torsella was no less than a deputy mayor of the fifth-largest city in America. **********But two years ago Mr. Torsella diverged from the usual path. He did it, however, to pursue many weighty questions: Is there a way to make a map so that  it is less awkward to read in the car? Where are people suppose to file all those ATM slips they gather during a month? And is there an easier way to wash and dry lettuce? **********Through his one-man company, Mr. Torsella has yet to come up with answers to  these stumpers. But he has found answers to similar ones, answers that make money.  Take the Spaghetti Smock. **********"I like to eat pasta, and I'm always splattering myself," he says. "That was  the germ of the idea. I saw a need you could address in a very fun way." **********He sketched an attractive cotton smock that attaches at the neck with Velcro. He conjured up a spaghetti-shaped box as a package. Then came lots of hard work. He hired a company to sew the smocks and went from store to store to hawk  them. And when he got his first order, for 200, the bibs were so stiff that he was up in his apartment at 1 A.M. washing, ironing and refolding them before delivery. **********But at $13 each the bib was the kind of success you might expect from a Rhodes Scholar. QVC sold 1,200 in under three minutes. And Mr. Torsella is putting the finishing touches on a deal under which NOW Designs in San Francisco will produce and distribute the smock. **********Nevertheless, he is humble about his new livelihood. He resists the word inventor; "this isn't penicillin," he says. Nor, he says, does he possess an unusual skill. "I think everybody has great product ideas," he said, "but people think of them and just discard them." **********But the simplicity of his new job doesn't mean the change in direction has been smooth. After the frenzy of making and distributing the smock, Mr. Torsella confines himself to coming up with ideas and licensing them to companies for making and selling. "I now understand," he says, "the headaches that come with manufacturing." **********Thus, Mr. Torsella has a contract with one company, Maco of Hillside, N.J., to come up with a variety of paper and label products. He also finds the company's market savvy a big help in the search for salable ideas. When Maco told him videotape labels had good potential, for instance, he hit upon the notion of designing labels that make a row of tapes look like a shelf of classical books. **********Mr. Torsella, who is single, has also designed for Maco a package of colorful stickers so young children and unartistic adults can decorate Halloween pumpkins. He's adapting the same idea to balloons, and has also designed decorative labels for file folders and other office items. **********And the ideas keep coming. In the mill, but without a company backer yet, is  Face Tea: tea-bag-like packages that can be dropped into hot water for home facials.  With his sister Nicole, Mr. Torsella is also working on a better way to carry store-bought flowers than in those bulky, leaking wrappers. And for everyone who has wondered what is on that unlabeled floppy disk, Mr. Torsella and an associate have designed and licensed a plastic clip that can hold both the disk and a paper copy of its contents. **********All in all, the signs suggest Mr. Torsella's detour may be edging closer to the traditional path of the Rhodes Scholar. He has paid back his original business loan, and he supports himself and an office in a fashionable neighborhood in Philadelphia's Center City.  "I've begun to receive the fruits of my labor," he says. **********And although he emphasizes that his chosen field is hardly profound, in discussing it Mr. Torsella can sound almost philosophical. "It struck me that this was a universal principle," he says. "Things that are utilitarian became decorative."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/29/world.main_headline: Harare Journal;Where Roving Circus Goes, Rare African Species Vanish
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/29/world.print_headline: Harare Journal;Where Roving Circus Goes, Rare African Species Vanish
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/29/world.body_text: **********The official logo of the Akef Egyptian Circus is the face of a large lion. But in Zimbabwe, it was the punched face of a tiny 60-year-old woman that stuck  in the public mind. **********Stella Killick's black eye, plastered all over the daily papers after she and other employees of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals tried to seize three dying pythons, probably did more than anything else to get the Akef  family's circus booted out of Zimbabwe, and to draw attention to one of this continent's oddest, and possibly criminal, business ventures. **********Animal rights activists who have been following the five-year African odyssey of the circus say it is not really a circus at all. Its dog-and-pony acts, contortionists and acrobats, they insist, are just a front for its real business: smuggling endangered species. They believe the circus is a link through which chimpanzees, pythons, falcons, gray parrots and perhaps even lion  cubs make their way from the central African jungle to the private zoos of Saudi Arabia or the laboratories of the United States and Europe. **********No one knows how big the animal trade is. But arrests for smuggling chimpanzees are rare enough to make the Akefs, who have had six seized, seem like players. They deny any involvement with chimpanzees or smuggling, and say their animals were acquired in Egypt in 1990. **********Using a circus is an ingenious way to overcome the inconveniences of traveling with animals. Smugglers who deal in ivory or guns do not have to feed their cargo or worry that it will yelp at a bad moment. **********Trading in endangered species is outlawed under a treaty signed by 126 countries, including the United States and most African nations. But because many obscure frontier posts are manned by untrained or bribable officials, smuggling goes on from Cape Town to Cairo. **********Even for a circus, the Akef caravan is a bit bizarre. Most circuses hustle from town to town to sell as many tickets as possible. But the Akef circus moves desultorily. It arrived in Zimbawe in May, gave sparsely attended performances in July and August, and left in early November. **********"They're obviously not making money as a circus," said Steve Thompson, chairman of the Chimfunshi Wildlife Orphanage Trust, which has a chimpanzee refuge in Zambia. **********The route of the circus took it through Djibouti, Uganda, Tanzania, Zambia and Malawi -- dirt-poor countries where few people can afford circus tickets, but rich in animals and scarce in sophisticated policing techniques. **********According to a Zimbabwean veterinarian who shadowed the long train trip to the border, a Mozambican guard deep in a plate of beans in a bullet-pocked shack waved the circus through without even checking whether its dogs, lions and tigers had up-to-date rabies shots, which they didn't. **********At other borders, officials at least count the animals, or demand inoculation certificates. By following this paper trail, animal-protection groups have compiled a dossier that documents the circus's real sideshow. **********"Mr. Akef arrived in Uganda with five pythons," said Meryl Harrison, director of the Zimbabwe Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. "Then he had two. He arrived in Kenya with seven. He arrived in Zambia with six, then had two. He arrived in Zimbabwe with four.  They're either all dying, or he's flogging them off to buyers." **********The number of lions in the circus has been as high as 10 and as low as six; endangered African gray parrots have gone from nine to zero. The only consistent number on the documents is for the four Siberian tigers. Tigers don't live in Africa. **********The Akef Circus follows a pattern, Mr. Thompson said. On arrival, it approaches local companies seeking sponsorship as a "cultural exchange with Egypt." In Zimbabwe, for example, Lever Brothers, the detergent company, advanced it $7,000.  Until the embarrassed corporation withdrew its backing, Lever Brothers flags were raised over the big top. Then, when the circus inevitably gets in trouble, Mr. Thompson said, the Akefs try lying, then offer bribes, and finally claim diplomatic immunity and demand that the local Egyptian ambassador get the "harassment" stopped. **********Because the smuggling of chimpanzees is such an international scandal -- the  population has dropped from millions in 25 countries to 250,000 in six -- wildlife activists have concentrated on the circus's role in it. **********The poacher who captures one earns about $50, Mr. Thompson said.  By the time it reaches the Middle East or Europe, the market price is $40,000 or more. **********A 150-pound adult can tear a man apart, so poachers take only babies -- by shooting the nursing mother out of the tree. If the baby survives the buckshot and the fall, the whole family group may attack to rescue it, and the poachers will shoot them all.  For every baby captured, the Jane Goodall Institute estimates, 10 adults are killed, devastating chimp populations. Chimps normally breed only every five years. **********The Akef Circus left Egypt in 1990 with two chimpanzees. Six have been seized en route. Early this year, Mrs. Harrison of the Zimbabwe S.P.C.A. confronted Elsayed Hussein Akef, the head of the family, and he naively showed her bills of sale for babies bought from a known Zairean smuggler. **********As the circus was packing up its scraggly encampment in the Harare fairgrounds, Mohammed Akef, Elsayed Hussein's nephew, offered a quick tour of its battered train containers. The lions and tigers -- all named for Egyptian presidents -- appeared well fed, though they were in tiny cages. **********He said the fight in which Miss Killick was punched started when the circus's Muslim women objected on religious grounds to the attention of a local photographer. Miss Killick was hurt in a shoving match between his "snake lady"  and the photographer, he said. (Miss Killick, who is barely five feet tall, says she was attacked by two women, one of whom belted her with a broomstick.) **********Despite the recorded seizures, Mr. Akef denied having any chimps.  "For a long time, it's not allowed to have chimpanzees," he said. **********The circus is now in Maputo, Mozambique. Mr. Akef said it was waiting for a boat to Egypt, but none of the animal groups believe him anymore. Mr. Thompson,  for one, expects him in South Africa soon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge has approved a scaled-back settlement between three makers of silicone breast implants and implant recipients, removing another hurdle for women awaiting money for health-related claims. **********The decision by Federal District Judge Sam C. Pointer, released Friday, clears the way for women to begin receiving forms next month to accept or reject the deal. Payments are expected to begin in 1996. **********The ruling was viewed as little more than a formality because Judge Pointer  participated in talks that resulted in the offer to the women from the three companies: the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, Baxter International Inc. and the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company. **********The agreement provides less money to women and involves far fewer implant recipients than the $4.25 billion settlement it replaced. That compromise collapsed because of the unexpectedly large number of women who sought money. **********About 220,000 women are expected to be eligible for the new settlement. Benefits will range from $10,000 to $250,000. **********Manufacturers deny that breast implants have resulted in injuries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/world.main_headline: French Premier Pledges to Negotiate With Unions to End Unrest
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/world.print_headline: French Premier Pledges to Negotiate With Unions to End Unrest
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/world.body_text: **********Trying to end the worst labor unrest in France in a decade, Prime Minister Alain Juppe today promised "dialogue, consultation and negotiation" with labor unions after nearly a month of confrontations. **********Meeting labor union and business leaders in his office for a "social summit"  that went on into the evening, Mr. Juppe outlined plans to increase economic growth and asked union and business leaders to agree on ways of taking on 250,000 entry-level workers next year to reduce an unemployment rate of 11.5 percent. **********He also said the Government would cut payroll taxes and impose a moratorium  on new tax increases after a new system of paying for the deficit-ridden national health insurance and pension system had been agreed on next year. But he rejected calls from his Cabinet to put off a tax increase set to go into effect on Jan. 1 to work off the $46-billion deficit that the health insurance and pension system had accumulated this decade. **********The Transport Minister, Bernard Pons, backed by some other members of Mr. Juppe's conservative majority in Parliament, said before the meeting that postponing the tax increase was "indispensable" for the economic growth needed to reduce unemployment. **********Mr. Pons is responsible for the national railroad system, which was shut down for 24 days in a wave of strikes by public-sector employees that began in late November after Mr. Juppe announced plans to reduce a Government deficit of $60 billion by cutting generous social security benefits. **********The rail strike forced Mr. Juppe to shelve a plan to cut French budget deficits by eliminating 3,750 miles of rural branch lines and special retirement rules that allow many railroad workers to start collecting pensions at the age of 50. **********Rail service was back to normal today except in Marseilles, where strikes continue. The Paris Metro was functioning normally, but ticket offices will not  begin collecting fares again until Friday. **********Some of the union leaders meeting with Mr. Juppe this afternoon had been demanding the withdrawal of the rest of a plan he announced last month to eliminate the continuing $13 billion annual deficit in the health and pension system, which covers most people in France. **********The talks had got off to a "relatively bad start," said Marc Blondel, the leader of the Workers' Force union, which led the strikes along with the Communist-oriented General Confederation of Labor. **********Mr. Juppe was tight-lipped in advance of the meeting, which included five labor union leaders and representatives of three employers' associations. Jean Gandois, who heads the biggest employers' group, said he would refuse to discuss union demands to reduce the work week to create more jobs. **********Mr. Juppe invited his guests to suggest ways of creating more entry-level jobs for young workers by reducing social insurance premiums on wages and agreeing to flexible working hours. He wants to find ways to reduce the burden the system creates on wages, since it is entirely financed by payroll taxes. Employees pay 6.8 percent of their salaries for health insurance and employers pay 21.7 percent. **********Creating other types of taxes to help finance health care would reduce these  deductions and give workers greater purchasing power, in the Government's view.  Mr. Juppe also hopes that lowering the contributions employers must make on salaries would make them less reluctant to hire new workers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/28/world.main_headline: Galapagos Islands Journal;Homo Sapiens at War on Darwin's Peaceful Isles
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/28/world.print_headline: Galapagos Islands Journal;Homo Sapiens at War on Darwin's Peaceful Isles
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/28/world.body_text: **********The commotion this fall in these far-off islands, where Charles Darwin studied the species and changed human understanding, drew competition for survival in terms sharper than most tourists cared to see. **********Led by a fiery politician, hundreds of fishermen, teachers, bus drivers and laborers shut down an airport, while others converged at the National Park Service, threatening to burn down buildings and take visitors hostage. Radio broadcasts urged looting and arson, while ordinary people vowed to become guerrilla fighters. Visitors fled a vacation paradise turned war theater. **********Nobody was injured during the 15-day strike in the Galapagos in September, and now the protesters dismiss their own threats as saber-rattling to gain the attention of the Ecuadorean Government, which they say cares more about reptiles than people. **********The clash drew battle lines in a conflict that has been simmering for years between a population swollen with migrants from Ecuador's mainland, whose expectations have grown with their numbers, and conservationists, including some residents, who feel business must bow to ecology. **********"Now we see a real polarization among the people here," said Pablo Larrea, the Ecuadorean Government's representative in the Galapagos. "People here believe that if you talk about conservation, you don't want people to have jobs." **********More than 50,000 tourists flock to this desolate smattering of islands each year, on the lookout for such evolutionary wonders as blue-footed boobies, marine iguanas, and the 39 kinds of finches whose highly differentiated beaks inspired Darwin to write "Origin of Species." **********The animals here are still so unaccustomed to humans that they have not learned to fear them. Pelicans and iguanas do not scurry away when a person appears on their path; mockingbirds flit in and out of offices and houses hunting for insect snacks. The islands are cherished by naturalists as a wellspring of endemic species, with 95 percent of the reptiles, 75 percent of the insects, half of the birds and nearly a fifth of the fish appearing nowhere  else. **********But scientists worry that the rapid growth in the human population, from 2,500 15 years ago to 15,000 now, has taxed the delicate ecological balance. With people have come aggressive plant and animal species -- including chickens, rats and goats -- that are multiplying rapidly, along with the overfishing of lobster, shark and sea cucumbers by local fishermen and large industrial fisheries. **********The influx of newcomers, most of them lured by the possibility of living off  nature through tourism or fishing, has also hardened the debate over the future  of these island and marine reserves. **********"Everyone wants a piece of the pie, but they have no idea what went into making the pie," said Jack Nelson, who came here from California some 30 years ago and who owns the Galapagos Hotel. **********Mr. Nelson and others say that those clamoring for change have brought a frontier mentality to the islands that, unchecked, would destroy the place as a  wildlife sanctuary. **********"I think Galapagos is the way it is because the big sharks from around the world didn't find it until very late," said Andre Mauchamp, chief of the plant department at the Charles Darwin Research Station here. "The new people who are  coming don't even realize what Galapagos means to the rest of the world." **********The immediate spark for the uprising in September was a presidential veto of  a special law for the islands. Its 70 articles would have concentrated money and power over the islands in the hands of the people who live here. About 97 percent of the Galapagos is a national park, with 27,000 square miles of the surrounding ocean belonging to a special marine reserve. For now, many decisions that affect the island are made by the Park Service, and the law would have subjected the Park Director to a board weighted with locally elected politicians and representatives of fishermen and tourist-related businesses. **********It would have also created the political framework for the island's growth, giving it the same governmental structures as Ecuador's other provinces, and taxed tour operators. But the law did not address what conservationists and others consider to be the most important point: a limit on immigration. **********Though protesters backed off from their more dire threats, their strike was the second this year. In January, islanders protesting a ban on the fishing of sea cucumbers occupied the research station for two weeks. As word of the disputes spread, said Eduardo Diez, head of the Association of Galapagos Tour Operators, reservations for the Galapagos, which account for 80 percent of Ecuador's tourism, fell 15 percent. **********Ecuadoreans like Fortunato Ayala, 40, and Miguel Andagana, 46, both fishermen, say they came to this scrubby outpost 600 miles off the coast of Ecuador simply to seek a better life. And they are somehow astonished that anybody would have listened to their threats. **********"Nobody here is a warrior," Mr. Ayala said, and laughed. He recalled that one demonstrator suggested burning a car, and instead the group torched a tire. Somebody else took a can of what they said was water, and poured it around the Park Service building as if it were gasoline. "It was only a way to put ourselves into the discussion," Mr. Andagana said. **********Most homes here do not have publicly supplied potable water, and there is no  sewage treatment. There is no hospital to care for the sick, and the school system -- all sides agree -- is a mess. Electricity on the islands shuts off at  11 P.M. **********Tourists pay $80 to visit the park.  The Park Service doubled the fee two ears ago with a pledge the money would go to improve Galapagos municipalities. But the money never left the Park Service, which used it to raise salaries and to finance other national parks. Soon afterward, the two airports on the Galapagos started charging tourists fees for municipal services. But people complain that that money, too, has done nothing to improve living conditions. **********At the time fees were increased, cruise boats began to dominate the market. Low-budget backpacking naturalists, who once filled the hotels and hired boats for day trips, disappeared. Tourists now arrive at the airport, catch buses to their boats, and visit the sights in what tour operators call a model of harmony between conservation and commerce. **********But for disaffected residents, the equation ignores two problems: the tendency of some boats to dump untreated waste and garbage into the ocean, and the residents' own need to earn a living. **********"The island may well be the human heritage of the whole world, but the human  heritage won't feed us when it's all over," said Eduardo Veliz, the congressman  who led the strike. "Most likely, what they really want is for us to pack up and leave."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/20/world.main_headline: COMMUNISTS GAIN IN THE SECOND TIER OF RUSSIA'S VOTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/20/world.print_headline: COMMUNISTS GAIN IN THE SECOND TIER OF RUSSIA'S VOTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/20/world.body_text: **********As if the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin hasn't heard enough grim news this week, the figures from individual parliamentary races started to pour  in today and the results were more of the same, only much worse. **********It now appears certain that Communists will control virtually a third of Russia's new Parliament, far more seats than even they had hoped for. If their close ideological soul mates in the Agrarian Party are included in the calculations, the figure is even higher. **********We are facing a very difficult situation," said Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the leader of Yabloko, the only openly liberal party certain of gaining a place in Parliament. "At this point it is important to unite all forces opposed to attempts to restore a totalitarian system in Russia." **********Almost nobody is talking about returning Russia to totalitarianism, but these days the reform movement does not have much else for building a case. **********When the Russian people elect a Parliament they each get two votes.  One supports an entire party. The other lets voters choose among local candidates in individual races. Although Communists and nationalists were always expected to prevail in the parliamentary vote for the 225 out of 450 seats that is based on  supporting a single party, most experts thought the other half of the seats -- filled in head-to-head races -- would produce far more mainstream victors, as it did in 1993. **********They were wrong. The results so far suggest that the opposition, including Communists, Agrarians and nationalists, will account for nearly 250 of the 450 seats in the new Parliament. The Government party, Our House Is Russia, when combined with its sometime reform rival, Yabloko, will have little more than 100. The rest of the seats will probably be spread proportionally among individuals who have been elected as independents. **********No matter what happens in the end, the Communists are not likely to have enough power to carry their motions over the opposition of reformers, and reformers are unlikely to pass any legislation unless the Communists support it. If only four parties make it into Parliament, as appears likely, then 50 percent of the electorate will have supported parties that did not make it. Despite the  large numbers for Communists, any mandate will be weak. **********"This is going to be a Parliament all about politics and not about government." said Michael McFaul, a senior associate at the Carnegie Moscow Center. "The whole next six months are going to be taken up with the presidential race." **********That means that the Parliament will almost certainly pass a series of bills -- lowering the price of bread, slowing privatization, moving backward on land reform -- that have no chance of Mr. Yeltsin's support. But each failure will be a card that can be dealt during the campaign. **********With 195 of the 225 head-to-head races accounted for, the Communists, with 49 winners, have defeated the Government party, Our House Is Russia, with 10, by five to one. The Communists' Agrarian allies had 19, and the liberal Yabloko had 12. **********When the individual Communists who won are combined with the party list numbers, which are still not final, they will have from 135 to 150 members in the new Parliament. Our House Is Russia is likely to have about 50 to 55 of the  450 seats. The ultranationalist Liberal Democratic Party of Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, which so far has won only a single individual race, will probably have about 50 seats, as will Yabloko in all likelihood. **********None of this is good news for President Yeltsin, but things might get worse.  Most of the results that have already been reported were produced by computer. The rural villages that do not tabulate their vote by computer are not expected  to help turn the tide toward reform. **********Back in seclusion at the hospital where he is recovering from a heart ailment, Mr. Yeltsin met with his Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, today  to talk about the results of the voting. **********Mr. Yeltsin must now decide how to react to a parliamentary vote that has been -- as much as anything else -- a referendum on him. Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist leader, said today that the President would have to make changes in his Government. "How could he possibly look at these results and do nothing about it?" Mr. Zyuganov asked at a news conference. **********Mr. Yeltsin will certainly act, but the script will depend on his own murky intentions. Mr. Chernomyrdin laughed off calls today for wholesale changes in the Government. "Changes, shifts, sackings -- nothing of the sort will happen,"  he said. He said that changes would occur in Government, "as in any living organism." **********"Personnel changes have routinely taken place and will take place in the future," he said, sounding as if he was struggling to believe his own words. "But they have nothing to do with this election." **********That of course depends on the ultimate results, which will not be known for at least two more days. With about 65 percent of the party list vote counted, the Communists have about 21.8 percent of the vote, Mr. Zhirinovsky's ultranationalist party has about 10.6 percent, Our House Is Russia has 9.6, and  Mr. Yavlinsky's Yabloko 7.6. No other party has received the 5 percent necessary to enter Parliament -- although three, the liberal party of Yegor T. Gaidar, the opposition group called Women of Russia, and the very hard-line Communist Labor  Party, are all hovering tantalizingly close to the barrier. **********Mr. Yeltsin has a tricky task ahead. He must sacrifice part of his Government to the results of this election. But if he moves too quickly he will be seen as  caving in. It also is not good politics. Most people expect Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev, perhaps the best-known liberal leftist in the Yeltsin Government, to be the first to go. But Mr. Yeltsin has said he will not decide until February whether he is going to run for president again. And until then, he can gain little by moving his chess pieces more often than necessary. **********Mr. Zyuganov started his chess game today, saying it was time to start planning for the presidential race. He took pains to stress that he would seek a broad coalition in Parliament, that he wanted allies with whom he could work, and that he was not afraid of compromise or disagreement. But he also said he expects the market reforms that have been the hallmark of the post-Communist era here to be eased. And on this, at least, he did not seem willing to compromise. **********"The policy should be corrected," he said. "No matter what they say now it is impossible to continue this policy."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/05/world.main_headline: A Bitter Awakening for West African Nation's Cocoa Farmers
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/05/world.print_headline: A Bitter Awakening for West African Nation's Cocoa Farmers
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/05/world.body_text: **********For three decades, while he pushed the development of agriculture throughout  this country's once thickly forested hinterlands, Ivory Coast's founding father, Felix Houphouet-Boigny, was fond of calling himself the nation's No. 1 peasant. **********The official press never tired of saying that no one could do more than Mr. Houphouet-Boigny to defend the interests of backwoods farmers. No one, it said,  cared more about the welfare of the rural inhabitants on whose backs the country's economy was built. **********Mr. Houphouet-Boigny's vast fortune seemed to belie his claim. But during the boom years from the 1960's through the early 1980's, when Ivory Coast rose to become the world's largest cocoa producer and a major grower of coffee, few seemed to mind this conceit. **********But Ivory Coast's economic luster began to fade in the waning years of his long rule. And in the two years since Mr. Houphouet-Boigny's death farmers have  increasingly come to realize that a system that posed as their defender was actually a huge machine used to fleece them. **********As it did for many other peasants, for Jean Yao, a 32-year-old cocoa farmer and father of three who labors on the outskirts of this market town, this realization came recently when sweeping changes were announced for the state commodities board, called Caistab. In exchange for $150 million in new World Bank loans, the Government said it was ending the board's role as the internal price guarantor for Ivory Coast's export commodities. **********Piecing things together for himself by reading a newly free press and talking with other farmers, Mr. Yao said he had come to see the change as merely the bitter culmination of a long game of deception. Only since Mr. Houphouet-Boigny's death, he said, had peasants come to understand that for years, while cocoa and coffee prices were booming, the Government was salting away huge margins by paying them a fraction of the price it was earning from the export of these crops. And when world commodity prices plummeted in the 1980's the Government, rather than making up the difference to farmers, lowered the guaranteed prices. **********"We grew up in a world where Houphouet decided everything," Mr. Yao said bitterly, taking a break from hacking at weeds with a machete. "Now we have been awakened to discover that we have been deprived of our own fortune, and the Caistab, rather than facing its responsibilities toward farmers, is pulling out  of this business." **********Asked about the country's agricultural situation, a World Bank official here  expressed sympathy for farmers like Mr. Yao. But the official said that in the end, the increased competition in the commodity markets here caused by the Government's withdrawal from its heavy control of export crops would benefit peasants by "creating a system where world prices correspond with the prices paid to local producers." **********But if World Bank officials, who pushed the changes in the export board, think that they will provide new encouragement to cocoa and coffee farmers, they may be disappointed. **********"Among the youngsters who are just starting out in life, people are already looking into anything else they can: rubber, oil palm, pineapple, or just moving to the city," said Toure Vassiriki, an official in Tiassale's cocoa farmers cooperative. "First of all, we have cut down so much forest that there is very little land left for the newcomer. Secondly, a lot of people have been left with a bitter taste in their mouths."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/world.body_text: **********Even before the Bosnia peace agreement is signed in Paris, the United States  and the United Nations have squared off for the next squabble: Who will police the volatile Croatian region of Eastern Slavonia? **********"The problem is that no one seems eager to go there," Argentina's representative on the Security Council, Emilio J. Cardenas, said today, as Madeleine K. Albright, the American representative, accused Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of shying away from a responsibility so as to protect the  image of the United Nations. NATO has already declined the task. **********The Clinton Administration, which campaigned to get the United Nations out of Bosnia, now wants the organization to take on peacekeeping in the Serbian-occupied area of Croatia bordering Serbia. Eastern Slavonia was only recently stabilized by an American-brokered accord that promises a protectorate  for Serbs there in two years. **********In a proposal sent to the Security Council on Tuesday, Mr. Boutros-Ghali said he preferred that the job go to a multinational force, though he did not name NATO. He said the United Nations would have a hard time assembling and sending the necessary force -- 9,300 troops plus 2,000 logistics personnel -- in the time demanded. There are 1,600 Belgian and Russian peacekeepers in Eastern Slavonia now. **********"I also continue to have reservations about the present ability of the United Nations to undertake an enforcement operation of this nature," he said. **********The first version of his report said he would therefore "recommend" a multinational force. Within hours, Ms. Albright telephoned him in Geneva and successfully argued for a change in the text to a "preference" rather than a recommendation. The report was duly rewritten. **********The story might have ended there if the United Nations had not released the original version today, which it had to recall publicly after Ms. Albright's spokesman, James P. Rubin, noticed it. Shortly after, Ms. Albright released her  statement saying it was "misguided and counterproductive" of the Secretary General to argue that the United Nations should avoid this operation "because of the risk of exacerbating a negative image of U.N. activities in the former Yugoslavia."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/23/world.main_headline: Tokyo Journal;In a Land Lush With Cash, the Robbers Cash In
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/23/world.print_headline: Tokyo Journal;In a Land Lush With Cash, the Robbers Cash In
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/23/world.body_text: **********Morimatsu Saito barely knew what hit him. The 63-year-old securities company  employee was walking through Tokyo's financial district carrying a bag containing $400,000 to his company. Just as he reached his building, a man wearing a helmet approached him, sprayed a debilitating gas in his face, and ran off with the money. **********The robbery, which took place in September on a busy street in broad daylight, was one of several recent episodes that have shocked normally safe Japan. But why would someone walk unguarded through the streets with $400,000 anyway? **********The answer is that Japan runs on cash. Personal checks have never caught on  here. Credit cards have recently been spreading rapidly, but even their use is not that well ingrained. **********Instead, people often pay bills amounting to thousands of dollars in cash. Postal service employees visit customers' homes on red bicycles to collect cash  for life insurance premiums or savings account deposits. And on the 10th and 20th of each month, traffic is said to be particularly heavy as businessmen visit suppliers and clients to pay bills or receive payment in cash. **********In Mr. Saito's case, he was bringing the money from a nearby bank because his company, Kyoritsu Securities, needed it to pay customers, who like to receive their proceeds from stock sales in cash, even in amounts up to tens of thousands of dollars. **********A result is that Japanese often carry what, by American standards, are large  amounts of cash, even given the high prices here. This habit has made Japanese tourists tempting targets for pickpockets around the world. But in Japan, where  robberies are rare, it has hardly been a problem. **********Shigeru Nomura, an 80-year-old man who emerged from a securities company near where Mr. Saito was robbed, said he sometimes carried tens of thousands of dollars in a paper bag. "I get a little nervous," he allowed -- but not nervous  enough to have someone accompany him. **********Recently, however, the number of robberies, while still very low by international standards, has been rising. The police have been issuing warnings  to those who transport large amounts of cash not to travel alone and to change routes frequently. **********But so far people "don't feel the danger keenly," said Kiichi Shiraishi of the National Police Agency's community safety planning division. "It is said that Japanese people believe you can get safety and water free of charge," he said. **********So the robberies keep occurring. In late October, Satoshi Murao, 33, an employee of Fuji Bank, visited three customers to pick up cash for deposit. When he emerged from the last customer, a hospital, he was stripped of $130,000 in a  robbery. **********When asked why people do not use checks, Japanese are likely to be puzzled by the question. "In a way, I wonder how Americans can trust personal checks," said Seiichiro Saito, a professor of economics at Rikkyo University. Accepting a check requires verifying or trusting the check writer's identity and financial resources. **********In Japan, people can pay bills by having money automatically deducted from their bank accounts. Or they can deposit money in another party's account using  sophisticated automated teller machines that give exact change. **********Personal checks will also not do for bribery or tax evasion, two popular practices here. In a famous scandal a few years ago, a trucking company executive sent a bribe of about $4 million to a powerful politician. The politician's secretary had to wheel the bills in from the parking lot on a dolly. **********In 1989, passers-by found moldy packets of cash worth $1.7 million in a bamboo thicket in Kawasaki, a Tokyo suburb. A businessman later admitted he had  dumped the money rather than prompt a tax audit by putting it in the bank. **********How hard it will be to break the cash habit might best be seen in the case of Toshio Miyaji, the president of Jonan Denki, a chain of discount electronics stores. "I feel very lonely if I have less than one million yen in my pocket," he said, referring to an amount equal to $10,000. **********Mr. Miyaji's office contains an automatic cash-counting machine, the type normally found in banks, which bundles 10,000-yen notes into packages worth one  million yen and spits them out onto the floor. Every day, Mr. Miyaji's aides insert one of those bundles into his wallet. **********But Mr. Miyaji is most famous for his Louis Vuitton attache case, which can hold up to one million dollars in fresh 10,000-yen bills. He is often seen on television being driven around in a red or sky-blue Rolls-Royce, dispensing bills from his attache case to buy products for his stores. Paying cash, he said, allows him to get bigger discounts. **********One would think this behavior would make Mr. Miyaji a conspicuous target. Sure enough, he has been robbed seven times, losing an amount equal to $390,000  at today's exchange rates. **********In one case, his own driver made off with an amount equal to $65,000 at those rates. "After spending all the money he committed suicide 10 days later," Mr. Miyaji recalled. He added that he blamed himself for tempting the poor driver by leaving his attache case in the car. **********Despite the robberies, the feisty 67-year-old Mr. Miyaji still carries cash around without security. "If I start worrying, it's just like closing down the store," he said. **********He has, however, made a few changes. After he was robbed in his own office last year, he installed some burglar alarms there. And, oh yes, he now takes his attache case with him when he leaves the car.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/11/world.main_headline: World News Briefs;U.S. Spy for East Berlin Gets Suspended Sentence
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/11/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;U.S. Spy for East Berlin Gets Suspended Sentence
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/11/world.body_text: **********A German court gave an American researcher a suspended 18-month jail sentence today for spying for East Berlin. **********The 54-year-old spy, Jeffrey Schevitz, admitted passing secrets to East Germany between 1977 and 1990, helped by his wife, Beatrice Altmann, who was fined $7,000.
