https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/busin.main_headline: Problems at Advanced Micro Add to Selloff in Technology Issues
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/busin.print_headline: Problems at Advanced Micro Add to Selloff in Technology Issues
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/busin.body_text: **********Stung by its inability to produce the latest generation of microprocessors, Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said today that it expected its fourth-quarter earnings to be lower than last quarter, which would put the company's earnings below Wall Street analysts' consensus estimate. **********This morning's announcement by Advanced Micro added to a broad selloff in technology issues and was the latest in a string of bad news for technology companies. Last Friday, Apple Computer said it would report a loss for its current fiscal quarter; the day before, the chip maker Micron Technology announced lower-than-expected profits. **********Advanced Micro said it had encountered unexpected competition from the Intel Corporation in the market for the 486 chip, the previous generation of microprocessor used in most personal computers. Advanced Micro still does not have a chip to match Intel's Pentium, and recently announced plans to merge with tiny Nexgen Inc. to acquire its Pentium equivalent product. Meanwhile, Intel has already announced the Pentium Pro, a higher performance successor to its popular chip . **********Advanced Micro shares dropped $1.125 today to close at $17.125 in New York Stock Exchange trading, a new 52-week low for the stock, and less than half its  52-week high of $39.25. On the Nasdaq market, shares in Intel closed at $57.25,  down $1, while shares in the Cyrix Corporation, another Intel competitor that recently began small shipments of its Pentium equivalent, closed at $24.25, down $2.625. **********"The market has in the last six months made a sharp swing to Pentium, which they don't have out yet," said James C. Poyner, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Company. Advanced Micro has only "486's, which increasingly, the market doesn't  want at any price," he said. **********Advanced Micro said that while it expected fourth-quarter revenues to be up over last quarter, the increase would not be enough to offset higher depreciation and start-up costs from its huge new manufacturing plant in Austin, Tex. The company said sales of communications, programmable logic and memory products remained strong, but that it would ship fewer 486 products than it expected. **********"Intel had appeared to be exiting the 486 market but came back during the fourth quarter," W. J. Sanders 3d, Advanced Micro's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. "The supply of 100-megahertz 486 microprocessors from Intel prevented A.M.D. from achieving our expected unit shipment goal," he  said. **********Advanced Micro said it had begun sending samples of its Pentium-equivalent chip to major computer manufacturers. A spokesman for the company said it would  ship 75-megahertz versions of the chip next quarter, while faster models would be shipped in mid-1996.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/busin.main_headline: Hershey Settles Suit Vs. 2 Pasta Importers
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/busin.print_headline: Hershey Settles Suit Vs. 2 Pasta Importers
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/busin.body_text: **********HERSHEY, Pa., Dec. 21 **********The Hershey Foods Corporation said today that it had agreed to settle a lawsuit it brought against two importers of Turkish pasta, accusing them of selling pasta that did not contain 100 percent durum wheat. **********The dispute arose over Hershey's contention that the lower-priced pasta sold  by the two companies was labeled incorrectly. **********Under the settlement, Vitelli-Elvea Inc. of Harrison, N.J., and the Fentex International Corporation of Rye, N.Y., will remove the words "100 percent durum wheat" from their packaging until they can prove to Hershey's satisfaction that  their products are made from pure durum wheat. **********The settlement also requires the two importers to acknowledge publicly that Hershey, which makes several brands of pasta, had filed the suit in good faith and not to drive the competitors out of business. **********A Vitelli-Elvea spokesman, Roy Taormina, said his company could not afford to continue the legal fight with Hershey. Mr. Taormina said the company had spent more than $500,000 on the case. Vitelli-Elvea had annual sales in 1994 of $10 million. Hershey's annual sales last year were $3.6 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/24/world.main_headline: THE U.N. AT 50: CLINTON AND YELTSIN;Warmth, but Little Substance, at Hyde Park Summit
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/24/world.print_headline: THE U.N. AT 50: CLINTON AND YELTSIN;Warmth, but Little Substance, at Hyde Park Summit
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/24/world.body_text: **********President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin emerged from a meeting today lavishly stressing the stability of the American-Russian relationship. But they  made only limited progress in finding a formula to integrate Russian troops into a peacekeeping force for Bosnia. **********Instead, as they ended more than four hours of talks at the estate of Franklin D. Roosevelt, the two leaders emphasized that they were committed to a  solution and had instructed their military strategists to keep searching for a command structure that both could live with. **********We agreed today that Russian armed forces will participate in these operations," Mr. Yeltsin said just a day after he had repeated in a speech to the United Nations that Russia would not send troops to Bosnia under the command of NATO. "But how they go about doing it is the affair of the military." **********The United States and other members of the alliance have insisted NATO must command any troops sent to enforce peace in Bosnia. **********Mr. Clinton said simply that "we made some progress" in how to structure the  force and that they had instructed Defense Secretary William J. Perry and the Russian Defense Minister, Gen. Pavel S. Grachev, to keep exploring options. **********Still, the very fact that the session was so warm and the two leaders so committed to finding some way to integrate Russia into the Balkan force defied predictions that Moscow and Washington were sliding back toward a cold war-style standoff. **********Instead, the working session began with the Russian President wrapping Mr. Clinton in a bear hug moments after his helicopter touched down in the spectacular autumn foliage of the 33-acre Summer White House used by Roosevelt. **********More than four hours later, the two men emerged from the stone-and-stucco home for a joint appearance that officials had been saying would not take place. And with Mr. Clinton standing at his side in the afternoon sun, Mr. Yeltsin proclaimed that the post-cold-war "partnership" between their two nations "is not calculated for one year or for five years, but for years and years to come,  tens of years, for a century." **********Then he thunderously accused journalists of both countries of promoting discord. "One could see that what you are writing was that today's meeting with  President Bill Clinton was going to be a disaster," Mr. Yeltsin chastised reporters covering the summit meeting. "Now for the first time, I can tell you that you're a disaster." **********"Be sure you get the right attribution there," Mr. Clinton said, his face turning red as he doubled over with laughter and nearly fell into Mr. Yeltsin's  arms. **********On other issues, the leaders said they agreed to push for ratification of the nuclear-weapons nonproliferation treaty, to work toward a comprehensive nuclear  test ban next year and to strengthen close cooperation on safeguarding nuclear materials in Russia. **********Aides to Mr. Clinton said most of the sessions between the two Presidents focused on the Bosnia peace talks, which are to begin on Oct. 31 at a military base near Dayton, Ohio.  The officials said both leaders had given political momentum to the effort to find a way around the Bosnia peacekeeping problem. **********"It's not a political impasse," a senior Administration official said. "It is a military question of how you can resolve the difference here. And you can do that through military technical discussions." **********One American official suggested that the sides were searching for a face-saving way to integrate the Russians with NATO, while letting Moscow insist its troops were not reporting to NATO officers. Mr. Perry has suggested that the Russian troops could serve in a civilian capacity. **********In his quest for a military presence independent of NATO, Mr. Yeltsin has found an ally in France. In recent meetings, French and Russian officials have discussed having 5,000 to 8,000 Russian troops serve under Russian operational command but under the tactical control of the French. **********A senior French official today described the thinking of President Jacques Chirac this way: "We have to take a part of Bosnia, to save its face for public  opinion, and give it to the Russians, under Russian command. The Russians are a  great army. They command their troops. Give them a sector." Washington, mindful  of the tensions when Berlin was divided into four sectors, has opposed such a suggestion. **********Mr. Chirac also said it was impossible to set limits on how long a peace force would be in Bosnia. "We will be there for 20 years," he said. **********Mr. Chirac also reportedly said that unless the United States was willing to  pay one-third of the cost of reconstruction in Bosnia, which French officials say will run $5 billion to $10 billion, "France would not pay at all." **********Administration officials said the related issue of NATO expansion in Europe,  which the Russians have objected to, came up only glancingly during the sessions. **********Both issues have enormous implications, ranging across such vital questions as the American role in Europe, the place of NATO and the Russian relationship with the organization. Complicating matters, both Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Clinton have domestic political considerations that tug them apart. **********Facing a Congress resistant to sending American ground troops to Bosnia, Mr.  Clinton said last week that he would seek Congressional support before he moved  ahead with plans to commit up to 20,000 troops to Bosnia. Congressional leaders  have said they would look skeptically at anything other than a NATO-led operation. **********"It is only NATO in a practical sense which can efficiently and effectively implement a settlement," Anthony Lake, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser,  said on Sunday. **********Mr. Yeltsin, however, is looking toward parliamentary elections in December and has been under fire from nationalists and Communists, who accuse him of being too accommodating to the West. **********On the eve of his United States visit, Mr. Yeltsin made a bow to those critics by threatening to dismiss his longtime Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, the only liberal reformer left in his Cabinet. Mr. Kozyrev, however, did attend today's talks, although he flew to Hyde Park in a separate helicopter. **********As if to underscore the fact that both Presdients were mindful of domestic politics, Mr. Yeltsin presented Mr. Clinton with two ice-hockey shirts of the Moscow Penguins team, reading "Bill Clinton 96" on one side and "Boris Yeltsin 96" on the other. **********The site for today's sessions was chosen to evoke the World War II cooperation between the two countries. In fact, the site seemed to soften the mood of confrontation that had appeared to be almost inevitable on Sunday, when  Mr. Yeltsin used his speech at the 50th anniversary celebration of the United Nations to proclaim that Russia would join a Bosnian peacekeeping force "only under a clear-cut mandate" from the Security Council -- and outside NATO command. **********Today Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin walked, sometimes arm in arm, to the 190-year-old stone home where Roosevelt was born. Mr. Clinton showed the Russian war memorabilia, including the naval hat and cape that Roosevelt wore during meetings with Stalin and Churchill. **********The two men posed briefly for photographers on a veranda, sitting on rustic wooden chairs used during World War II by Roosevelt and Churchill, and gazed at  a resplendent view of the Hudson Valley. **********"It was a very good idea to have our meeting here," Mr. Yeltsin said. "I didn't want to have our meeting in New York in a big place, a formal place like  a hotel. I'm sure that in a place like this, that there are no problems we won't be able to resolve." **********Mr. Yeltsin also thanked the United States today for showing a willingness to compromise on a 1990 treaty calling for reductions in conventional arms within NATO and the former Warsaw Pact by mid-November. **********The idea is to ease limits on weapons on Russia's European borders so it can  deal more easily with secessionist movements. Administration officials said that no formal agreement was struck today, but that the Russians had forwarded their  reply to a NATO compromise proposal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/08/busin.main_headline: Market Place;Who would win in a split-up at Cigna? It depends who is asked.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/08/busin.print_headline: Market Place;Who would win in a split-up at Cigna? It depends who is asked.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/08/busin.body_text: **********A PROPOSAL by the Cigna Corporation to divide its property and liability insurance business into two parts, one stronger and one weaker, might benefit shareholders but is being criticized by policyholders, competing insurers and consumer groups, some of which will testify at a hearing today in Harrisburg, Pa. **********Critics of the plan contend that it could allow the company to avoid paying claims related to asbestos and environmental cleanups. They also complain that the Pennsylvania Insurance Commissioner, on whose approval the plan depends, is  a former Cigna employee who has not excused herself from the case and that she has provided the department's study of the company's proposals to Cigna and its  backers, but not to others. **********The Cigna plan calls for the creation of one group of weaker, inactive subsidiaries that would not sell new property and liability policies but would pay claims as they arose on old policies. The active, stronger company would issue new policies and would benefit, Cigna officials say, because it would have higher financial ratings once it was separated from the inactive unit. **********When Cigna announced its plan in October, its stock was trading at about $105 a share. Since then, it has dipped, before rising again to a high for the year of $112 on Wednesday. It closed yesterday at $110.75, down $1.25. **********Unlike other corporations, whose first loyalty is to their owners, or shareholders, insurance companies have long been regulated under the philosophy  that their primary obligation is to policyholders. **********Many analysts, including Robert Spass, managing partner of the investment group Insurance Partners, predict that Cigna's plan is a prelude to an effort by the company to find a buyer or partner for the property and liability business. **********While Cigna shareholders could benefit if the plan helped the property and liability business return to profitability, the plan's critics worry that policyholders would be left out in the cold if the inactive company ran out of money to pay claims years or even decades from now. **********Cigna officials contend that additional funds they will invest in the inactive company, with some reinsurance of claims against it, provide more protection to policyholders, not less. They also say that the active company will be able to provide additional funds to the inactive company if needed, though it would not be required to do so. **********Maurice R. Greenberg, chairman of the American International Group, a company whose businesses include reinsurance, said that if the inactive company would be that strong, Cigna should back it "with a guarantee from the company" or with full reinsurance. Cigna's unwillingness to do that is evidence, he said, that it wants to limit its liability for future claims. **********John N. Ellison, a partner at the law firm of Anderson Kill Olick & Oshinsky, which represents several Cigna policyholders, said that his clients had not been provided with enough information to evaluate the plan. "If the protection for policyholders is just as strong now as it was before, then why do they want to do it?" he asked. **********Although Pennsylvania's Insurance Commissioner, Linda S. Kaiser, was a Cigna  employee from 1986 to 1992 and is now covered by a Cigna pension plan, the insurance department's lawyers have decided that there is no conflict of interest that would require her to excuse herself. Crystal L. Hull, a spokeswoman for the department, said the existence of the pension plan did not give Ms. Kaiser a stake in the financial performance of Cigna, because the plan  is guaranteed by the Federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/29/busin.main_headline: Stocks Drift Lower in Another Slow Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/29/busin.print_headline: Stocks Drift Lower in Another Slow Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/29/busin.body_text: **********The stock market drifted lower yesterday in slow and somewhat aimless trading. **********"The day was quiescent," said Edwin D. Walczak, chief investment officer of Vontobel U.S.A., describing the inactivity among traders. "You could call it a day of gestation in anticipation of vacation." **********Even the bond market's rally did not have much of an impact on stocks. The yield of the 30-year Treasury bond, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, slipped to 5.98 percent, marking the first time it ended at les than 6 percent since October 1993. **********The Dow Jones industrial average fell 10.12 points, to 5,095.80, for its second consecutive decline. The major blue-chip losers were I.B.M., down 1 7/8,  to 90 1/8; Walt Disney, down 7/8, to 59 3/8; and Philip Morris, down 7/8, to 89  7/8. Among the broader indicators, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index eased 0.41 point to 614.12 and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 5.91 points, to 1,042.22. **********But advancing issues outnumbered declining ones on the New York Stock Exchange by 1,249 to 1,088. Turnover on the Big Board amounted to 288.7 million  shares, up from 252.3 million shares on Wednesday, but sharply below the three-month daily average of around 371 million shares. **********Technology stocks stumbled yesterday, led by Cirrus Logic, which plunged 7, to 19 7/8. On Wednesday, the computer chip maker trimmed its profits forecast for the second time in two months because of reduced demand in the fiscal third  quarter. **********This warning depressed the stock prices of other semiconductor manufacturers  and pulled other technology issues down as well. Intel fell 1 3/4, to 57 1/8; Motorola dropped 1/2, to 56 7/8, and Micron Technology lost 1 1/2, to 40 1/4. **********Airline shares fell after major carriers announced a new round of fare reductions, and that weighed on the Dow Jones transportation average, which slumped 5.98 points to 1,953.49. UAL, the parent of United Airlines, fell 2 5/8, to 174 3/4; Delta lost 5/8, to 72 1/8; AMR, the parent of American Airlines, slipped 3/8, to 73 1/4, and USAir closed down 1/4, at 13 1/8. **********After Michaels Stores said that it expected to report significantly lower profits for the quarter ending on Jan. 31, its shares dropped 5/8, to 14 3/8. Other retailers that ended the day at a lower level were Home Depot, off 1/2, to 47 1/4, and Fingerhut, off 1/4, to 14 3/8. **********In contrast, some utilities advanced and the Dow Jones utilities average gained 0.70 points, to 224.57. American Water Works rose 1 1/8, to 38; Brooklyn  Union added 1/8, to 28 3/4; and Duke Power increased 1/8, to 47 1/2. **********Selected insurance stocks, considered defensive issues that perform well in periods of slow economic growth, also turned higher. Reliastar closed at 41 3/4, up 7/8; Lincoln National closed at 53 1/8, up 5/8; and Horace Mann closed at 30 5/8, up 1/2. **********Wells Fargo, which has made an offer to acquire First Interstate, advanced 2  3/4, to 216 5/8. But Federal National Mortgage, which surged 5 1/4 on Wednesday, gave up 1 1/4, to close at 123 3/4 yesterday on profit-taking.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/16/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Nokia Cuts Its Stake In Dutch Cable Concern
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/16/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Nokia Cuts Its Stake In Dutch Cable Concern
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/16/busin.body_text: **********Nokia is cutting its stake in the Dutch cable company NKF Holding N.V. to 49  percent and selling the company its own cable operations. The news came a day after Nokia announced that it expected lower profits in the final four months of the year and that it planned to reorganize its consumer electronics business. Tonn Van De Laar, an NKF board member, said he did not expect Nokia to sell its  remaining interest in NKF anytime soon. Nokia had held about 56 percent of NKF.      NKF hopes the acquisition of Nokia cable will make the company a more global player. Nokia's cable operations, employing close to 1,100, are expected to have 1995 revenues of 450 million guilders ($280 million).(AP)

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/27/busin.main_headline: Taking In the Sites;A Maui Sunset in Real Time (Modems Not Optional)
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/27/busin.print_headline: Taking In the Sites;A Maui Sunset in Real Time (Modems Not Optional)
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/27/busin.body_text: **********As December nears, it may be of some comfort to know that a Maui sunset is but a few keystrokes away. **********A camcorder at Synchromic Studios, a video production plant in Hawaii, faces  a window toward the Silversword Golf Course and the West Maui mountains. Every 10 minutes, a Silicon Graphics Indy computer automatically uploads a picture to the company's World Wide Web page. **********The Maui Cam has helped the company draw attention to itself. **********"Whether it helps our business is a tremendous intangible," said Jay April, the executive producer, "but it certainly gets us a lot of buzz in our business  and has helped our public relations effort tremendously." **********A surge in on-line cameras shows how worldwide the Web really is. One click puts a live picture of a busy Hong Kong thoroughfare on your computer screen. Another click and it's off to Berlin, with a view of the city's largest train station. Click once more and a smoldering volcano in New Zealand appears. **********The equipment used to feed live images into a computer ranges from high-end video recorders that cost thousands of dollars to the Connectix QuickCam, a black-and-white digital camera that costs about $100. Web pages can be programmed to display the images and refresh them at predetermined intervals. Instructions can be found at the home of the Continuously Refreshing Fish Cam. **********Offered by Netscape Communications, which produces the industry-leading Navigator browser software, the Fish Cam is notably mindless. Several cameras trained on a 90-gallon aquarium show moving pictures of tropical fish. **********Aquatic views abound on the Internet. The Chicago Web-Cam offers surfers a real-time view of the city's lakefront, as seen from the window of a luxury high-rise condominium. The Habitat Company, which manages the property, co-sponsors the page and offers both a button to click for additional information and a telephone number to call for an appointment with a sales representative. **********Introduced in September, the page has increased telephone inquiries regarding the company's 13,000 apartments, said Albert J. Caputo Jr., vice president. Two  weeks ago, he said, the company's brokerage division scored its first sale that  originated from an inquiry from its Web site. **********"The home page has also been particularly beneficial to our relocation group," Mr. Caputo said, citing the broad reach of Internet advertising. **********Web cameras are not strictly for business, however. Pictured above are some frivolous ones: the intersection of Hollywood and Vine, an elementary school in  Oregon, an earthquake recorder in Nevada, and an interactive model railroad in Germany that users can control from afar. **********But wait, it gets even sillier. A page called Steve's Ant Farm is no picnic,  displaying a black-and-white picture that is updated every five minutes. Another camera tracks the goings-on in a dorm room at Swarthmore College in Pennsylvania, and a California camera monitors the lifespan of a Chia pet -- a terra cotta sculpture that, once seeded and watered, covers itself with sprouts  over a one- or two-week period. **********When site-seeing, keep in mind some caveats: many pages require the Netscape  Navigator browser to view images; most sights look better during the day and continuously updated pictures won't continually update themselves unless you have a fast modem, particularly when surfing overseas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/15/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;BAYER PLANS TO BUY A PLASTICS BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/15/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;BAYER PLANS TO BUY A PLASTICS BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/15/busin.body_text: **********Bayer A.G. said yesterday that it would pay about $580 million for a unit of  the Monsanto Company that makes a type of plastics used in car dashboards, computer housings and refrigerator linings. Bayer, which is based in Leverkusen, Germany, already makes such plastics, called styrenics, in Europe, and the acquisition would add them to the line of plastics Bayer makes in the United States. The Monsanto styrenics business, which employs 1,400 people, is expected to have $700 million in sales this year. Monsanto, which is based in St. Louis, is moving away from producing chemicals and plastics and said in June that it was considering selling the styrenics business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/21/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Daiwa Concedes It Told Trader To Keep Dealing
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/21/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Daiwa Concedes It Told Trader To Keep Dealing
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/21/busin.body_text: **********Daiwa Bank Ltd. acknowledged today that it had ordered a bond trader in New York to continue his trading, which had been unauthorized, after he informed executives in July that he lost $1.1 billion. **********The bank's acknowledgment comes a day after Federal prosecutors in New York accused the Daiwa trader, Toshihide Iguchi, and at least two superiors of concealing the losses for nearly two months after Mr. Iguchi first brought them  to their attention. Mr. Iguchi pleaded guilty in Federal District Court on Thursday to concealing trading losses over 11 years. **********With today's announcement, the Daiwa case appears to be unfolding in ways similar to other trading scandals of the 1990's: Blame is first cast on a rogue  trader, but it is later contended that some of those at the top may have played  a significant role, as well. In some cases, this may have been a lack of adequate controls or supervision by senior management; in others, as is contended in the Daiwa case, senior officials may have been more deeply involved. **********But in the Daiwa case, as in the billion-dollar trading loss that led to the  collapse of Barings P.L.C. of Britain, the spotlight has also fallen on government regulators who failed to discover a problem before it became a scandal. **********"Organizations have become so large and complex, it's hardly surprising that  corporate governance is more difficult." said Haig J. Nargesian Jr., senior analyst of financial institutions at Moody's Investors Service in New York. Modern technology also allows individuals unprecedented freedom to move money around, making it easier for a trader to hide what he is doing. **********The court documents that contend there was a cover-up at Daiwa were released  on Thursday as Mr. Iguchi also acknowledged embezzling more than $500,000 from Daiwa. Mr. Iguchi said he had covered his losses by selling bonds held in customer accounts and then making it appear that the bonds were still there, and sold other securities to pay the interest due on the phantom bonds. **********In the statement today from its headquarters in Osaka, Daiwa said it "directed the actions to be continued" because it wanted "to prevent Iguchi from fleeing" and because it had to continue making interest payments on the bonds that Mr. Iguchi sold to conceal his losses. **********But the statement from the deputy general manager of the bank's international division, Kenshi Shiraiwa, contended that the actions did not constitute a cover-up. **********The two senior managers accused by Mr. Iguchi were not identified, but a spokesman for Daiwa denied that one of them was Hiroyuki Yamaji, a senior executive who had once been Mr. Iguchi's superior. Mr. Yamaji was sent to New York to talk to Mr. Iguchi after he told Daiwa of his unauthorized trading in a  July letter to Daiwa's president, Akira Fujita. Mr. Fujita and the bank's chairman, Sumio Abekawa, announced their resignations earlier this month, but it is not clear what, if any, roles they may have had in the debacle. Mr. Fujita was replaced immediately, but Mr. Abekawa will not step down until next March. **********When it first publicized the loss in late September, Daiwa Bank portrayed the scandal as the handiwork of a single trader who duped the bank. That was also the way the case was portrayed at Barings, where Nicholas W. Leeson, who was based in Singapore, bet heavily on the direction of the Japanese stock market and lost $1.4 billion, forcing the old merchant bank to lose its independence. While he was singled out for blame when the scandal erupted early this year, questions have now arisen about top management's possible role. **********This week, a report prepared for the Government of Singapore said two Barings executives tried to play down and conceal information about losses. It concluded that Barings' contention that it did not know what Mr. Leeson was doing "gives rise to a strong inference that key individuals of the Barings Group's management were grossly negligent, or willfully blind and reckless to the truth." **********The Singapore International Monetary Exchange was also criticized in the report, which contended that it accepted explanations of what was occurring from Barings executives. Mr. Leeson is the only banker who has been charged in the case. **********Another case that no longer looks so straightforward is that of Joseph Jett,  who was accused by Kidder, Peabody & Company of singlehandedly creating $350 million in phantom profits while he was head of the government bond trading unit there. An internal investigation of the case found serious problems with Kidder's accounting system and the supervision of Mr. Jett, who has denied any wrongdoing. More than a year after the case broke, no criminal charges have been brought against Mr. Jett. **********In the Daiwa case, Federal prosecutors said Mr. Iguchi and Daiwa executives made "incomplete and misleading disclosures to the Federal Reserve Board and its examiners." Mr. Iguchi himself bragged in a letter to Daiwa that it would be easy to conceal his losses from regulators. **********These comments and other criticism of the Fed's handling of the Daiwa affair  are expected to lead to a review of the regulation of foreign banks. **********Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said in a letter this week to Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, that he was "dismayed by apparent gaps and problems in foreign bank supervision and its implementation." **********In 1991, in response to the scandal at the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, Congress passed the Foreign Bank Supervision Enhancement Act to more strictly control foreign bank branches, with a much bigger role for the Fed. In light of the Daiwa scandal, Mr. D'Amato said, "it is time to re-examine  the structure of foreign-bank supervision." **********Adding to concern about the regulators is the fact that the Japanese Finance  Ministry has acknowledged that it was informed of Daiwa's losses six weeks before the bank notified American authorities on Sept. 18. American regulators have said they should have been notified earlier. **********The Finance Ministry said today that it was looking into allegations that Daiwa's top management might have taken part in a cover-up of the scandal, Kyodo news service reported. **********In a separate development, Moody's today downgraded its rating to Baa3 from Baa2 on long-term deposits of three Japanese financial institutions -- Hokkaido  Takushoku Bank, Nippon Credit Bank and the Chuo Trust and Banking Company. The ratings are the lowest investment-grade level and the lowest Moody's ratings of  Japanese bank deposits. **********In recent weeks, international banks have raised the premiums they charge Japanese banks who borrow funds from them, and Japan's stock market has had occasional jitters from speculation about more troubles among banks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/02/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;ACCUSTAFF HAS AGREED TO PURCHASE GW CONSULTING

Accustaff's stock rose $2.50 a share, to $32.50, in Nasdaq trading yesterday. Accustaff of Jacksonville, Fla., said GW, a provider of temporary personnel in Northern California, had an estimated $43 million in revenues for the 12 months ended Oct. 31. https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/05/world.main_headline: For Victims of Korea's Ugly Years, a Time to Savor
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/05/world.print_headline: For Victims of Korea's Ugly Years, a Time to Savor
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/05/world.body_text: **********He lost an eye when soldiers stomped on his face, and his brother-in-law was  shot dead, and his younger brother was imprisoned, and his parents went insane,  but in some respects Lee Ji Hyun is a remarkably lucky man. He lived. **********Mr. Lee survived a massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators here in the provincial capital, Kwangju, in an incident in 1980 that has haunted South Korea ever since. As he plucked his false eye from its socket, holding it in one hand  and pointing with the other to the scars on his face, Mr. Lee reflected on the prospect of a trial soon of two of the country's former Presidents for ordering  the massacre. **********They should be executed," declared Mr. Lee. "Unless we execute them, how can we put this all behind us?" **********Few people expect the former Presidents, Chun Doo Hwan and Roh Tae Woo, to face the gallows. But both are now in prison, Mr. Chun having just been arrested on Sunday, and they are expected to go on trial next year for staging a coup in  1979 and for ordering the Kwangju massacre in May 1980. By the lowest estimate,  almost 200 people were killed, while other figures range into the thousands. **********For people in Kwangju who have fought for 15 years to investigate the massacre and punish those responsible, this is a moment to savor. Mr. Lee campaigned over the years to honor the victims of the massacre, and twice he was imprisoned -- once for two and a half years -- because of his efforts. Yet now South Korea has been turned upside down, and it is the former Presidents who are wearing prison uniforms and can expect to get used to them. **********The massacre was one of the pivotal moments in modern Korean history, nurturing radicalism and anti-Americanism among a generation of youth. **********An opinion poll at Seoul National University once asked students to identify  the greatest tragedy in Korean history since 1945. The professor who planned the poll assumed that the students would answer the Korean War, but they overwhelmingly cited the Kwangju massacre. **********At Mangwol Dong Cemetery, where 125 of the victims are buried, a light snow fell on the graves today. But an unusually large number of visitors walked among the tombstones, paying tribute to those who died in the massacre. **********"The spirits will be relieved a bit," said Kim Jae Young, a 59-year-old man walking solemnly among the rows of graves. "Their anguish has been soothed." **********Yu Tae Chung, a gravedigger at the cemetery for the last 19 years, knows the  victims he buried as if they were family members. He introduces Choi Mi Ae, who  was then a housewife, eight months pregnant, whose tombstone carries the inscription: "Darling, you were an angel. I'll see you again in Heaven." **********Mr. Yu also showed the grave of a 10-year-old boy, Bang Kwang Bum, who was killed in the massacre. A photo on the tombstone shows a serious child staring solemnly at the camera. **********Like most people in Kwangju, Mr. Yu is angry at Mr. Chun and Mr. Roh and one  moment he says they should be punished to the full extent of the law. The next moment, reminded that they face the death penalty, he steps back. **********"Execution?" he reflected soberly. "I'm not sure I'd go that far. Chun and Roh were fathers of this nation, after all. So I don't really know what punishment they should get. But I suppose if they're not executed, they should get life sentences." **********Mr. Chun set the stage for the Kwangju massacre on May 17, 1980, when he responded to pro-democracy protests by extending martial law across all of South Korea. The next day, demonstrations erupted in Kwangju, and an initial bloody crackdown led to a public uprising against the military Government. Protesters armed themselves with weapons taken from armories, and they briefly ruled the city. **********Ten days after the initial protests, the army invaded Kwangju with tanks and  machine guns. **********The Government has put the civilian death toll at 193, but that figure does not square with the list of 288 dead people whose family members the Government  eventually agreed to compensate as victims of the Kwangju massacre. Neither figure includes 23 soldiers who died, most killed by other troops but some by protesters. **********Dissidents have often argued that the death toll was higher, at least 500 and perhaps 2,000. **********"We still get calls from people who want to report family members who went missing at that time," said Chung Soo Man, whose younger brother was shot dead in the crackdown and who now heads the Kwangju Massacre Bereaved Families Association. Mr. Chung said that the group is happy to see Mr. Chun in prison but that it wants a special prosecutor appointed to get to the bottom of what happened. **********One of the crucial issues that people want to resolve is what role if any the United States played in the massacre. It is an article of faith among many people in Kwangju that the United States military commanders in South Korea stood aside to allow the massacre to take place, and at the cemetery student groups have painted an oversized caricature of President Ronald Reagan, blood dripping from his fingers. **********American officials have denied complicity in the massacre, saying that they had no control over the Korean army units that were used in Kwangju. There is no sign, however, that the United States tried very hard to stop the killing, and the Reagan Administration feted Mr. Chun at the White House less than a year later. **********While delighted at Mr. Chun's arrest, many people in Kwangju seem perturbed that President Kim Young Sam appears to be using the prosecution of the former presidents as a way to bolster his own political standing, distracting attention from a slush fund scandal that had enmeshed him. **********"I don't want to see this used for narrow political purposes," said Kang Yong Bok, a jeweler who was clubbed and bayoneted by soldiers during the massacre. "But it's unbelievable what's happening now."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/busin.main_headline: Fed Drops Rule For U.S. Banks
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/busin.print_headline: Fed Drops Rule For U.S. Banks
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve Board said today that it had eliminated the $25 million limit on the amount healthy United States banks could invest in a foreign company without Fed approval. **********Such investments now will be limited to 5 percent of a bank's Tier 1 capital  (equity and retained earnings), which in virtually all cases is more than the $25 million cap, the Fed said. **********Healthy banks' investments were previously limited to the lesser of $25 million, or 5 percent. The $25 million limit was the "binding constraint in almost all cases," the Fed said. **********The expansion to the board's Regulation K applies only to investments made under general consent authority, for which a bank does not need prior Fed approval. **********The board also gave preliminary approval to a proposal that would require foreign banks operating in the United States to adopt a "home state" by March 31, 1996.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/busin.main_headline: Market Place;For the cautious investor, three candidates for consideration.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/busin.print_headline: Market Place;For the cautious investor, three candidates for consideration.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/busin.body_text: **********DESPITE this year's fabulous rally in stocks, analysts say there are still pockets of value in the market. But finding these opportunities can be difficult for investors. And caution is recommended. **********"Exercising investment discipline is very important after the run-up in stock prices we have enjoyed this year," said Joseph Battipaglia, managing director of Sterling Advisors, a New York money management firm. "Rather than abandon the market, the smart investor should limit stock purchases to only those issues that meet pre-determined standards." **********Mr. Battipaglia uses three general guidelines, looking for companies with: a modest price-to-earnings ratio when based on a company's projected earnings for  the next year; a seasoned management team with a successful track record, and a  well-defined business strategy that offers a map for sustainable growth. **********A company that falls within his parameters is Hooper Holmes Inc., which is hired by life and health insurers to perform medical examinations of new applicants. After acquiring the Olsten Corporation's health services unit this fall, Hooper Holmes became the largest provider of physical exams for insurers in the United States, testing about 250,000 applicants a month. **********The health information service company, based in Basking Ridge, N.J., has been under the same management for the last 15 years. Its per-share earnings for 1995 are projected to come in around 24 cents a share, according to several analysts. Budd Bugatch at Raymond James & Associates projects that per-share earnings will jump to 68 cents in 1996. George F. Shipp of Scott & Stringfellow  projects a range of 50 cents to 70 cents. **********At 68 cents a share, the stock, which closed unchanged on the American Stock  Exchange at $8.125 yesterday, has a price to future earnings ratio of 11.9 a share. That is less than the current P/E of more than 17 for the companies in the Standard & Poor 500-stock index. The reason for caution? Earnings projections are often wrong and the current P/E for Hooper is 33.8. **********Bridgeport Machines Inc., a maker of metal-cutting tools, might also suit the disciplined investor. It commands 40 percent of the market for milling products  in the United States and has seen overseas sales grow to 35 percent of total revenue. According to Chuck Harris, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Company, the Connecticut company's computer-controlled tools hold the top market share position in Britain. And he expects sales outside the United States to represent about half of Bridgeport's total revenue in 1997. **********The company's chairman, Joseph Clancy, has held various senior management positions since 1966, and Bridgeport earned $1.48 a share in the year ended March 31, up from 63 cents the previous year. For fiscal 1996, Mr. Harris sees earnings increasing to $1.70 a share, giving it a price/earnings ratio of 11.6.  Shares closed yesterday at $19.75, down 25 cents, in Nasdaq trading. **********In retailing, Mitch Rubin, an analyst at Smith Barney Inc., says that Trend-Lines Inc., which operates specialty stores and mail-order catalogues in the good-growth sectors of woodworking tools and golf equipment, has been a consistent earnings performer. Though its roots in mail order go back some 40 years, the Revere, Mass., company was created in its current form by the present management in 1981. **********Trend-Lines posted profit of 56 cents a share in the fiscal year 1995, ended  Feb. 28, which was up from 41 cents a year earlier. Mr. Rubin expects the company to earn 65 cents a share in the 1996 fiscal year. Its shares closed at $10.375, up 37.5 cents in Nasdaq trading yesterday, putting the stock's P/E at slightly less than 16. That may make it a little high for the wary investor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/02/busin.main_headline: MEDIA: PUBLISHING;The next big imprint may hail from Hollywood.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/02/busin.print_headline: MEDIA: PUBLISHING;The next big imprint may hail from Hollywood.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/02/busin.body_text: **********HOLLYWOOD has a long tradition of looking to books for good movie ideas. A publisher's colophon, producers figured, gave a seal of approval for a story. Still, making movies seemed more glamorous than making books. So producers stayed in California. **********In recent years, though, producers have been so hungry for good ideas that they have hunted down book proposals in their infancy, grabbing television or film rights sometimes even before a publishing deal has been completed. **********Now, in a sign of how deeply Hollywood has penetrated the publishing industry, several producers are trying to short-circuit the old system entirely  by becoming book publishers themselves, luring writers with lucrative book, movie or book-movie deals that most old-line houses cannot match. **********"Hollywood is so desperate for product they are purloining, or trying to purloin, anything that's not locked in a safe-deposit vault," said David Rosenthal, publisher of Villard Books, a division of Random House, the publishing arm of Advance Publications. **********Spurred in part by the entrepreneurial spirit of Steven Spielberg, Jeffrey Katzenberg and David Geffen, who started their multi-faceted Dreamworks studio last year, film producers like Peter Guber, Sid Sheinberg, Brandon Tartikoff and Bob and Harvey Weinstein have begun publishing ventures. **********One of the first was Mr. Tartikoff, the former president of NBC Entertainment, who last year set up an imprint under his name at the Warner Books unit of Time Warner Inc. to develop novels that he could also sell as feature films. **********His first book, Dean Koontz's "Strange Highways," a collection of suspense tales including novels, novellas and short stories, was published this spring and quickly became a best seller. Mr. Tartikoff's second effort is "Superstitious," an adult thriller written by R. L. Stine, who is known for his  best-selling children's horror tales; it was published last month. Film rights to Mr. Stine's book have already been sold to Miramax; a deal for Mr. Koontz has not been announced. **********Mr. Tartikoff, who still produces television shows for his company, New World Entertainment, gives the Walt Disney Company's Miramax Films a first look at movie rights for whatever he publishes. Mr. Tartikoff's company gets a first look at television rights. **********Harvey and Bob Weinstein, the brothers who sold their Miramax Films to Disney in 1993, have since begun Miramax Books, which publishes novels, screenplays and other works. For example, Miramax, an imprint of Hyperion, Disney's publishing arm, published the screenplay from "The Piano," the 1993 film written by Jane Campion. The book, which was released soon after the movie, has sold more than 60,000 copies. And its publication of the "Pulp Fiction" screenplay by Quentin Tarantino has sold more than 100,000 copies. **********Mr. Sheinberg is planning for his new entertainment company, the Bubble Factory, which is expected to include publishing. **********And Mr. Guber, who once ran the Columbia and Tri-Star studios for the Sony Corporation, threw himself into publishing at the end of the summer with the creation of Mandalay, a multimedia company. **********"That means we can take a creative idea, whether it starts as a book, movie,  TV show, audio book, stage play or CD-ROM, and develop it in any -- and preferably all -- of these areas," said Nanscy Neiman, a former Warner publisher who is now executive vice president of Mandalay and publisher of its books. "We're nothing if not ambitious." **********Arrival of producer-publishers has been germinating for some time. Since the  1970's, the growth of media conglomerates has meant that studios often find themselves in a corporate stable with book publishers. **********Universal Pictures and G. P. Putnam's Sons, for example, became divisions of  MCA Inc., now controlled by the Seagram Company. Paramount and Simon & Schuster  became siblings at Viacom Inc. And HarperCollins and Fox became divisions of the News Corporation. In each case, book and film divisions expected to have an early, if not first, run at each other's projects. **********Still, most remained at arm's length. Then in 1990, Disney took the step of establishing its own publishing division from scratch, setting up Hyperion Books as a general trade book publisher. **********The idea, executives say, was for Hyperion to feed ideas to Disney's film and television divisions, and vice versa, so all groups could benefit from shared publicity and marketing strategies. **********One particularly successful example has been Disney's marketing of the comedian Tim Allen. **********Last year, as a result of Disney's coordinated strategy, Mr. Allen became a leader in three categories. Ratings soared for his Disney-owned television show, "Home Improvement," just as his new book, "Don't Stand Too Close to a Naked Man," ran to the top of best-seller lists for Hyperion, and his first feature film, "The Santa Clause" for Disney, became a box office hit. **********For producers, setting up publishing shops gives them more access to an author's work. Where they once had to await a book's bound galleys before deciding if the story worked as a screenplay, producers can now read book proposals in their infancy. **********Fights over rights are minimized, and marketing opportunities are maximized:  publication and production schedules can be coordinated so that a book comes out just weeks before its film version. **********For authors, the advent of producers as publishers offers a kind of one-stop  shopping. Instead of having to wait for an agent to drum up interest on both East and West Coasts, authors are almost guaranteed a dual book-and-movie sale. **********But they may also forgo the kind of line-editing and guidance they could expect from the traditional, more experienced book publishers. **********Not that most producer-published books will need such tender literary care, said Robert Gottleib, an executive vice president of the William Morris Agency and head of its New York literary department. **********"We are not dealing with Farrar, Straus here," he said. "Remember, this is a  very commercial entertainment business."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/01/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Deion Sanders Signs With Pepsi-Cola
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/01/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Deion Sanders Signs With Pepsi-Cola
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/01/busin.body_text: **********The Pepsi-Cola Company has signed Deion Sanders, the football and baseball player, to a multiyear endorsement contract. The terms of the agreement, announced yesterday, were not disclosed. **********Though "Pepsi has had its eye on Mr. Sanders for a while," said Jon Harris, a spokesman for the Pepsi-Cola unit of Pepsico Inc. in Somers, N.Y., his recent trade from the San Francisco 49ers to the Dallas Cowboys made him more appealing. Pepsi-Cola and Jerry Jones, the owner of the Cowboys, rattled the National Football League by signing a contract although Coca-Cola is the official N.F.L. soft drink; the league is suing Mr. Jones. **********Mr. Sanders joins other athletes like Shaquille O'Neal and Andre Agassi as Pepsi-Cola pitchmen. He will appear in advertisements by the Pepsi-Cola agency,  the BBDO New York unit of the Omnicom Group.
