https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/24/world.main_headline: Safety Fears Fail to Deter Armenians On A-Plant
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/24/world.print_headline: Safety Fears Fail to Deter Armenians On A-Plant
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/24/world.body_text: **********This energy-starved nation, where most homes have electricity just hours a day, plans to restart a nuclear reactor here this week despite Western protests that it is unsafe. **********Armenian officials say the plant meets international standards, and they reject United States claims that the reactor, which was closed in 1989 because of safety concerns, is unfit to withstand the area's serious earthquakes. **********Instead, Armenian officials characterize Western objections as a reflection of East-West competition. **********"This is the struggle for the market," asserted Vanik Nersessian, deputy head of Armenia's Department of Atomic Energy. "This is an issue of the employment of the Western population." **********Armenia's decision to restart the Metzamor plant centers on its dire economic circumstances and its intense nationalism. **********A seven-year, undeclared war with neighboring Azerbaijan has combined with post-Soviet economic chaos to close most Armenian factories. The upheaval has ravaged living standards, prompting an exodus that has reduced Armenia's population of 3.5 million by 20 to 30 percent. **********In turning to the 407-megawatt Metzamor reactor as a savior, Armenia will rely on a Soviet design that Washington considers among the world's most dangerous. There are six such plants in operation; the others are in Bulgaria, Russia and Slovakia. **********Washington has refused economic aid to upgrade Medtzamor, saying it wants to avoid a precedent that might force it to help the others. Rather, the Clinton Administration is pushing permanently to close all six. **********American officials cite the lack of a dome-shaped, concrete containment vessel that is standard on Western reactors. Without this feature, any radiation leak at Metzamor would simply escape into the region of Yerevan, the capital, where 2 million people make their homes. **********"We have expressed our concern about this and other plants like it to various governments, including the Armenian Government," said John Quintus, an American Embassy official in Yerevan. "But it is not within our purview to tell them they must not start it. It is a sovereign decision of the Armenian Government." **********Metzamor sits on a rise overlooking a quiet plain of corn farms and pasture, with snow-topped mountains marking the horizon. It was built on an ancient site that archaeologists have traced back to the Bronze Age, in a village that some local historians say was the birthplace of the Armenian people. **********The Soviet Union installed two reactors at Metzamor that together produced some 30 percent of Armenia's electricity. **********The plant was closed following a 1988 earthquake. There are two major geologic faults near Metzamor as well as many minor ones. **********The 1988 earthquake, measuring 6.7 on the Richter scale, did not seem to damage Metzamor. But the deaths of at least 25,000 people and the destruction of 55 villages spawned a movement that branded Metzamor a threat to the Armenian people. **********Today's reversal of thinking, seen in Armenia's emotional defense of Metzamor, reflects the survival question as much as its shutdown did six years ago. **********The issue is enveloped in Yerevan's support of ethnic Armenians who have captured the tiny Azerbaijan region of Nagorno-Karabakh. **********Azerbaijan has punished Armenia with an economic blockade, severing Yerevan's traditional route for imports of natural gas and fuel oil. Still Armenia, perceiving another crucial test of national will, seems ready to cope rather than compromise. **********In the Armenian view, its only option is to restart Metzamor. **********With Russian assistance, the Government has refitted the plant's valves and miles of water and steam pipes. The Government argues that these steps have upgraded the plant to world standards. **********Gagik Markossian, Metzamor's chief engineer, said one of the plant's new features is an automatic shutdown device that would be activated in case of a serious earthquake. **********"We aren't the kind of people who can set our houses on fire and injure our neighbors," Mr. Markossian said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/20/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;PRAXAIR RAISES OFFER FOR CBI AND SETS A DEADLINE
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;PRAXAIR RAISES OFFER FOR CBI AND SETS A DEADLINE
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/20/busin.body_text: **********Praxair Inc. sweetened its hostile bid for CBI Industries yesterday and pressured CBI to accept it by imposing a deadline of tomorrow. Praxair, based in Danbury, Conn., increased its offer by $1 a share, to $33. If CBI does not accept by 5 P.M. tomorrow, Praxair's bid, valued at about $2.2 billion, plus the assumption of $750 million in CBI debt, will revert to the original $32-a-share  offer that was rejected on Nov. 16. A spokesman for CBI, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill., was unavailable for comment. The acquisition would combine CBI, the world's largest maker of carbon dioxide, with Praxair, one of the world's largest producers of industrial gases. CBI shares were up $1 at $32.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/25/world.main_headline: Khijuri Journal;Science Can't Eclipse a Magic Moment for Millions
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/25/world.print_headline: Khijuri Journal;Science Can't Eclipse a Magic Moment for Millions
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/25/world.body_text: **********Before dawn today, Stephen A. Kolodny positioned himself under a stand of eucalyptus trees here and settled down to wait. By the time the Sun was a red orb on the rim of the north Indian plain, a crowd of villagers had gathered around him, putting his counseling skills in heavy demand. **********Normally, Mr. Kolodny moves between courtrooms in Boston and Los Angeles, following a divorce practice from offices on both coasts. But the villagers who  pressed around the 55-year-old American lawyer in this corner of the semi-desert state of Rajasthan were after his knowledge as an amateur astronomer. **********At a few moments past 8:34 A.M., the Sun was due to disappear behind the Moon in a total eclipse, an event nobody at Khijuri had witnessed -- at least not in its fullest form, when the Earth plunges into eery night -- at any time since the Taj Mahal, 50 miles east of here at Agra, was completed in the 1600's. A total eclipse from any one spot on the Earth is visible only once in 360 years. **********From Iran to Borneo and into the Pacific, millions of people fell into the eclipse's shadow. At mosques south of Teheran, at the ancient Buddhist complex at Angkor in Cambodia, and all along the 10,000-mile path of the eclipse, life stopped briefly. **********Almost everywhere, the event stirred old superstitions, as well as outbursts  of astonishment and joy. **********Among India's 700 million Hindus, many still subscribe to an awful symbolism  in which an eclipse becomes a triumph of evil, represented by the blackness of the Moon's disc, over good, represented by the gold of the Sun. Since anybody exposed to an eclipse risks being tainted, the primeval superstitions lay down elaborate rituals for the event. **********In Khijuri, as in many of India's 500,000 villages, there were special washing rites. Many stayed indoors and lighted candles to the gods. **********Eating, for many, was forbidden for 12 hours before the eclipse and 12 hours  afterward. Pregnant women avoided holding knives or anything sharp for fear their children would be born scarred, or deformed. **********But some of the more intrepid ventured out, to the edge of the harvested wheat field chosen by a group of Americans, who like thousands of other visitors had made the eclipse a centerpiece of their Indian tours. **********There, they found Mr. Kolodny, along with his high-magnification cameras, charts and supply of special sunglasses that allowed direct viewing of the Sun without damage to the eyes. **********For Padam Singh, a grizzled 50-year-old muffled with a blanket against the chill, Mr. Kolodny's explanations of the planetary movements appeared, for a while, to be unconvincing. But after pushing back his turban to take several long looks through the sunglasses at the Moon eating a crescent into the Sun, Mr. Singh conceded. **********"If you say so, it is only nature's way," he said, with a gruffness that conveyed lingering doubt. **********Deeper into the wheat field, other villagers provided a mute audience to a Cape Canaveral-style countdown, aided by an array of computers and satellite links brought in by American scientists. **********"Two minutes to go, the light level is dropping, the shadows are moving in over the trees!" shouted Glenn Schneider, 40, an astronomer from the University  of Arizona in Tucson. As the total eclipse neared, the silence was broken by agitated chattering among egrets and other birds. **********Mr. Schneider resumed: "Thirty seconds! Fifteen seconds! Five seconds!" **********At the instant when the Sun was fully covered, with a only a thin corona of light showing around the Moon's edges, the villagers, told beforehand that they  could look directly at the eclipse without protective glasses during the 52 seconds of total eclipse, erupted into gasps, followed by clapping. **********At that moment, the differences between the Indian villagers and the Americans seemed small. Behind the astronomers, 35 other Americans, mostly from  Chicago and Los Angeles, burst from their canvas seats. Cries of "Oh my God!" and "Just beautiful!" rang across the darkened field. One woman cried. Stockbrokers and physicians and lawyers shook hands. **********Several pledged to meet again at the next total eclipse, along a band of territory that sweeps through Siberia and into Mongolia, on March 9, 1997. In 1999, the hardened enthusiasts will be back in India. **********On the experience with the Khijuri villagers, some, like Mr. Kolodny, said they expected that the level of superstition will have declined, but one story told ahead of the eclipse suggested it might be wise not to overestimate the power of science. **********Usha Mehta, a 76-year-old veteran of India's struggle for independence, recalled being told more than 50 years ago of an incident involving Sir C. V. Raman, an Indian physicist who won a Nobel Prize in 1930 for breakthroughs in the study of light. **********Recounting the story in a weekend interview at her Bombay home, Ms. Mehta said the physicist had rushed home from his Calcutta laboratory to take a ritual bath ahead of a solar eclipse. "The Nobel Prize? That was science," the physicist explained. "A solar eclipse is personal."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/20/world.main_headline: One Mr. Pavon Here, and Another There. Who's Who?
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/20/world.print_headline: One Mr. Pavon Here, and Another There. Who's Who?
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/20/world.body_text: **********Jorge Armando Pavon Reyes's 15 minutes of fame came in 1985, when he was the  police commander who briefly detained a Mexican drug lord who had tortured and murdered an American drug agent. Mr. Pavon then embraced the trafficker and allowed him to board a private jet and fly away. **********Mr. Pavon was later convicted of accepting a $200,000 bribe from the trafficker, and he served 40 months of a four-year prison sentence before his release in 1989. He has since lived with his family in Mexico City, working as a private investigator. **********This week, however, the Italian police arrested a man they identified as Armando Pavon Reyes, and said they were awaiting an extradition request from the United States. **********This international confusion has bordered on the absurd: Italian authorities  insist they have the right man and news agencies report -- incorrectly, according to American officials -- that the Federal Bureau of Investigation has  confirmed through fingerprints that the man is the former police commander. But  a man who appears to be the real Mr. Pavon has turned up in Mexico City, confidently asserting he is who he says he is. **********"There is only one Jorge Armando Pavon Reyes, and I am that person," he said  on Wednesday, waving his arms indignantly during a news conference here. **********At a meeting with reporters on Wednesday evening at a downtown restaurant, he dragged from his wallet documents -- his Mexican driver's license and a tattered 1983 letter certifying him as a federal judicial police officer -- that identified him as Jorge Armando Pavon Reyes. He said he was visiting friends at  a Mexico City police station this week when someone told him his name was once again in the papers. **********The slapstick overtones notwithstanding, the incident has underlined the serious differences that chafe Mexico-United States relations over the extradition process. **********In the United States, Mr. Pavon is a wanted man. A Los Angeles grand jury indicted Mr. Pavon in 1988 in the murder of the drug agent, Enrique Camarena, and a warrant was issued for his arrest. Last year, American authorities put the International Criminal Police Organization (Interpol) on alert for Mr. Pavon, and a bulletin was transmitted to the 176 member nations, an Interpol spokesman  said. The Italian police responded this week with the arrest of the man they identified as Mr. Pavon. **********Mexico is a member of Interpol, but authorities here have made no move against Mr. Pavon, even though his whereabouts have been no secret. A spokesman  for the Attorney General said today that no charges are pending against Mr. Pavon in Mexico. "This is not our affair," the spokesman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/04/world.main_headline: Along Bosnia Dividing Line, Federation Is Only on Paper
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/04/world.print_headline: Along Bosnia Dividing Line, Federation Is Only on Paper
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/04/world.body_text: **********To speak with her daughter and granddaughters in Los Angeles, Adila Glavovic  must use the telephone of a friend who lives 10 minutes away, across a river in  her hometown of Mostar. **********On the other side is also the apartment she once lived in, groceries that are more affordable and the medical care her husband needs. But the west side of Mostar is largely forbidden to Mrs. Glavovic and people who, like her, are refugees in their own city. **********The Croats, who govern the west side of the city, make it almost impossible  for the Muslims, who live in the east, where the Bosnian Government has control, to cross the Neverta River. This divide exists in spite of the fact that Mostar, a 500-year-old city in a narrow mountainous valley, was supposed to be the showcase of the Bosnian-Croatian federation forged by Washington last year. **********But if anything these are two peoples moving apart, not together. Each side has different license plates, currency and passports, and diametrically different views of what Bosnia should be. **********Several days of travel through Croatian-held areas of central and western Bosnia show the federation to be little more than a piece of paper. That piece of paper, drafted to bring an end to fighting between Muslims and Croats, is also central to the American plan for peace in Bosnia, and its importance was underscored this week when negotiators in Ohio announced yet another agreement to strengthen the federation. **********"It doesn't exist," a senior Western diplomat in Zagreb said. "We invented the federation and forced the sides into it." **********Far from seeing the alliance between the Croats and the Bosnian Government as an enduring one, some diplomats and United Nations officials in the region fear  that the alliance of Muslims and Croats might end in conflict between them after a peace agreement is signed. **********Washington's peace proposal divides Bosnia between the Muslim-Croat federation (51 percent) and the Serbs (49 percent). In reality Bosnia's Croats control 20 percent of the territory of Bosnia, and the Muslim-dominated Government in Sarajevo, 30 percent. There are now an estimated 350,000 ethnic Croats in western Bosnia (about half the number before the war) most of them in  the Herzegovina region. **********"If there were a referendum, the people would vote not 90 percent, but 99 percent, not to be part of the federation," said Krunoslav Kordic, a Croat who is mayor of Capljina, 25 miles southwest of Mostar. **********The Bosnian President, Alija Izetbegovic, said in a recent interview that the Croatian people in the region want to be part of Bosnia, but that paramilitary units with aid from Zagreb are stoking the flames of separatism. But Western officials in the Mostar area say that Mayor Kordic's view of public opinion appears to be closer to the truth. **********In front of Mr. Kordic's office, among the evergreens and leafy trees, flies  the red, white and blue flag of the Croatian Republic of Herzog-Bosna. Asked where the Bosnian flag was, he said simply, "We don't recognize it." Bosnia's flag, with gold fleurs-de-lis on a blue background, is seldom seen in Herzegovina, nor are federation policemen. **********The self-declared republic, which has its capital in Mostar, has not been internationally recognized. But it is a reality. It delivers the mail, collects  taxes, generates electricity, educates children, and with its own 50,000-man army defends the territory of Herzegovina (with help from neighboring Croatia).  Police officers wear the same blue uniform as the Croatian police, with an almost imperceptible alteration in the red and white checkerboard shield on their shoulder patches. **********Don't try to buy beer or bananas, gasoline or shaving cream in Herzegovina with the Bosnian dinar. The legal currency in Herzegovina is the Croatian kuna,  or the German mark. **********The Bosnian Croats carry Croatian passports, not Bosnian ones. They vote in Croatia's elections, and in last week's parliamentary elections, they did so overwhelmingly for the Croatian Democratic Party of President Franjo Tudjman. **********Under pressure from Washington and the European Union, President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia has publicly vowed support for the federation. But Western officials say they do not believe that his public stance matches his real feelings. **********"In Zagreb, they don't want it to exist," a Western diplomat there said about Croatia's attitude toward the federation. Mr. Tudjman is under strong American pressure to go along with the federation. **********One of the provisions of the 1994 federation agreement was that all people forced out of their villages during the Muslim-Croat war would be allowed to return home. **********That has not happened. "The federation has brought about no integration of ethnic groups," said Kris Janowski, a spokesman here for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. **********This week's agreement in Ohio aims, in fact, to allow 300 Muslim families and 300 Croatian families to return to homes in areas occupied by the other group. Even if it works, these numbers are tiny in a country with nearly 700,000 internal refugees. **********Mohammed Elezovic was born in the historic Muslim town of Stolac, where his family's roots go back 400 years. He was expelled by Croats in July 1993. Mr. Elezovic, 55, a professor of Slavic languages, has still not been able to go back, not even to pick up his poetry or albums with pictures of his children. **********When Croatian troops recently recaptured the strategic town of Jajce from the Serbs, they moved Croatian civilians back in but did not allow displaced Muslim  residents to return to their homes. **********The grievances are not one-sided, however. **********In Zenica, an industrial city controlled by the Bosnian Government, more than 12,000 of the city's 20,000 Croats have been forced out since the federation agreement was signed, European officials said this week. **********"The federation is rubbish," said a 21-year old Croatian man, who said that he is unable to return to his village near Konjic. **********There are only two ways to make the federation work, said a United Nations official. One is military force, the kind Washington does not want to use. The other is investing "billions" of dollars in Bosnia, so that there is an economy  strong enough to provide jobs for everyone. **********But the lesson of Mostar is that spending money is not enough. **********In the last 15 months, the European Union has spent more than $200 million to rebuild and reunify this city. The reconstruction has been a success -- children are in schools, the hospital has clean sheets and medicines for patients, traffic lights work, water flows. The work has been carried out on both sides of the city. **********What disturbs European Union officials in Mostar is that, because political unification has not been accomplished, the facilities are essentially segregated. **********For example, teenagers from the east cannot attend high school in the west as they did before the war, and special permission is needed for Mrs. Glavovic's husband, who had a heart attack five years ago, to go to the hospital, which is  in the west. **********The failure of political reunification is why Mrs. Glavovic cannot call her daughter without applying for a permit and waiting 10 days for permission to make the 10-minute walk, and why she and her husband cannot return to their three-bedroom west Mostar apartment with balcony views of the valley, even though they can see their former home from where they now live as refugees with  their relatives. **********It is why reconstruction of the 400-year-old mosque in east Mostar is hampered. The quarry with the right quality of stones is on the other side of a  river, explained Hussein Lulic, 71, a stonemason working at the mosque. **********Croatian officials do not deny that they are restricting movement. If they did, they would be "demographically occupied" by the Muslims, said Mile Puljic,  the deputy mayor of west Mostar, with the Muslims from the east coming west. **********With money from Croatian and German business executives, west Mostar is thriving and lively -- like West Berlin was -- with sidewalk cafes where Croatian soldiers in camouflage engage in conversation with chic young women. **********East Mostar, which was poorer before the war, and was more heavily damaged by Croatian shelling during the fighting, has suffered from a lack of significant private foreign investment since the end of the war. Muslims are still struggling to dig out from the rubble, and an old man was seen this week poking  through garbage in search of something of value to him. **********"The people live in a ghetto," Hans Koschnick, a German who is the European Union's administrator for Mostar, said about the Muslims in east Mostar. "I know something of ghettos. I don't like it." **********As for the federation, what the Bosnian Government wants is a country built on the principle of one person one vote, the basis of the American proposal. It  would like at least Herzegovina to be included, and the Serbian territories as well. **********The Bosnian Croats, if they cannot get unification with Croatia, want to be an essentially independent state in a confederation with Bosnia. But the Bosnian Government rejected this two years ago, and it is not part of the American peace plan. **********Mr. Puljic, the deputy mayor of west Mostar, calls the American idea "totally unacceptable." **********"To Mr. Holbrooke, I wish him all the best," he said, referring to Richard C. Holbrooke, the chief American negotiator. "But it is not as simple as he supposes." **********SNAPSHOT Mostar: Two Peoples, Two Cities **********Although the European Community has spent $200 million in Mostar in an effort to rebuild and reunify the city, it remains politically and physically divided into eastern and western portions on either side of the Neretva River; the movement of people between the two is severely restricted. **********WESTERN MOSTAR **********CONTROLLED BY: Self-declared Croatian Republic or Herzog-Bosnia PASSPORTS: Croatian. **********CURRENCIES: Croatian kuna or German mark. **********EASTERN MOSTAR **********CONTROLLED BY: Bosnian Government. **********PASSPORTS: Bosnian Government **********CURRENCIES: Bosnian dinar. **********Photos: Reconstruction in Mostar has been hampered by the separation between the Muslim east and the Croatian west. In the east, workers restore a 300-year-old building gutted by Croats during fighting two years ago. ; In the east Mostar apartment that their families share, Adila Glavovic shows Slavojka Spremo photos of her grandchildren. The Glavovices are not allowed to live in their apartment  in Croatian west Mostar. (pg. 6) (Photographs by Raymond Bonner/The New York Times) **********Map of Bosnia and Herzegovina showing location of Mostar and areas of control. (pg. 6)

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/01/world.main_headline: DOLE BACKS PLAN TO SEND U.S. FORCE ON BOSNIA MISSION
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/01/world.print_headline: DOLE BACKS PLAN TO SEND U.S. FORCE ON BOSNIA MISSION
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/01/world.body_text: **********In a major boost to President Clinton's decision to send American troops to Bosnia, Bob Dole, the Senate Majority leader, today threw his support behind the mission. **********Mr. Dole made his announcement from the Senate floor in tandem with Senator John S. McCain, the Arizona Republican and former prisoner of war in Vietnam who has been one of his party's most bitter critics of any military intervention in  Bosnia. **********Mr. Dole said he was drafting a resolution supporting the President's decision -- with conditions intended to bring the troops home quickly -- and hoped it would pass late next week or early the following week. That would give  Mr. Clinton much needed bipartisan political backing before the scheduled signing of the Bosnian peace agreement in Paris on Dec. 14, which would be immediately followed by deployment of most of the American troops. **********After announcing his support, Mr. Dole, the frontrunner for the Republican Presidential nomination, acknowledged in an interview that American troops would be in Bosnia by the time the Senate voted. But he said that opposing the President after he had made his decision would undermine the soldiers' morale. **********The Administration was swift in praising Mr. Dole. "I welcome Senator Dole's  expression of support," Secretary of State Warren Christopher said in a statement. "His leadership can help build a bipartisanship consensus endorsing the President's decision to deploy troops as part of the NATO-led international force for peace in Bosnia." **********Mr. Dole said of his decision: "It wasn't easy. I knew the easy way out was to go out and trash everything." He added, in an allusion to his Presidential rivals who have opposed the Bosnia mission: "I know I'll get a few whacks out there, but I've been around here long enough to know that at this point we shouldn't be so partisan." **********Mr. Dole added that he was holding meetings with experts on Bosnia to persuade recalcitrant Senators to support him, and that he was also discussing a joint strategy with the House Speaker, Newt Gingrich. **********The Administration is likely to run into much more trouble in the House, whose members are younger and less swayed by Mr. Clinton's argument that failure to take part in the mission would destroy NATO. **********Several hours after Mr. Dole's announcement, White House officials traveling  with Mr. Clinton in Belfast, Northern Ireland, said the President had decided to allow a military spending bill that he needs to help pay for the Bosnian mission to become law without his signature. Although he had said he would veto the $243 billion bill because it contained more money than he had requested, it would also provide the $2 billion needed to pay for the Bosnia operation. **********Late tonight, Mr. Clinton qualified his approval of the bill in a statement issued by the White House that noted his strong concerns about "excessive spending for projects that are not currently needed" for defense. The statement  said Mr. Clinton would send Congress legislation that would eliminate money for  those projects. **********The announcement today by the two key Republicans does not signify a ringing  endorsement of Mr. Clinton, whose Bosnia policy has come under attack from Republicans and Democrats and which -- as both lawmakers pointedly observed today -- is opposed by the vast majority of their constituents. **********Rather, their decision stems more from resignation that Mr. Clinton is going  to send 20,000 troops no matter what, and that it would be unseemly not to line  up behind the Commander in Chief. **********"The bottom line is that the President intends to send these troops to Bosnia one way or another," Mr. Dole said in the Senate. "And so, it seems to me that we in the Congress have a responsibility to try to insure -- to our best ability -- that as this deployment goes forward, that we create the conditions to end it quickly and successfully so that U.S. forces can return to their families. **********"So here we are, and I believe the Congress will do the right thing. We will  end up supporting U.S. forces." **********Mr. Dole has long held the view that a President should be supported once he  decides something as important as committing troops abroad. He argued passionately against the use of American troops to oppose President Saddam Hussein after Iraq invaded Kuwait, but once President Bush decided to do so, Mr. Dole worked hard to win support for him. **********Mr. Dole's decision this time carries with it the long-term political benefit of making him seem above partisanship at a time when most other Republicans seeking the nomination, particularly Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, have been strident opponents of the decision to send 20,000 American troops to Bosnia. **********Mr. Dole, who was severely wounded in World War II, commands respect on military issues. The fact that he spoke together with Mr. McCain, who carries a  lot of weight with younger lawmakers because of his imprisonment in Vietnam, is  expected to blunt Senate opposition to the deployment. **********But neither men made any secret of the fact that they have serious concerns about sending Americans to Bosnia. Mr. Dole listed two major concerns: the possibility of casualties and the potential that Americans will be drawn into a  "quagmire with no way out." **********Throughout the Bosnian war, Mr. Dole was the leading Republican proponent of  arming and training the Bosnians. Today he said that he wished that sending troops could have been avoided and that Mr. Clinton had long ago embraced his policy as an alternative to intervention. **********"If we'd lifted the arms embargo a year ago, we wouldn't be talking about sending American troops now, but that didn't happen," he said. **********In explaining his own support, Mr. McCain was more blunt. "This is not something I want to do," he said in an interview. "I've got calls in my office running 100-to-1 against. But the President has the constitutional authority to  do this and I want to do everything I can to minimize the loss of life and insure a peace agreement is lasting. I've got to do what I think is right. Otherwise, what the hell am I doing here?" **********Senator Joseph Lieberman, the Connecticut Democrat who had cosponsored legislation with Mr. Dole on lifting the arms embargo on Bosnia, praised Mr. Dole for his action. **********"The remarks of the majority leader were more than statesmanlike," Mr. Lieberman said in the Senate. "They were in fact patriotic, in the sense that by taking the position he has, he's put the interests of his country ahead of politics." **********The unpopularity of sending Americans to serve abroad, even in a situation defined as enforcing peace, was underscored earlier in the day in testimony before the House International Affairs Committee by Secretary of State Christopher. **********Asked by Representative Christopher H. Smith, Republican of New Jersey, whether the timing of the American-led peace initiative was motivated by Presidential politics, Mr. Christopher said no. **********"I'm not a political expert," he said. But, he added, "It does not look to me, based upon what the polls are, that the President is taking a position that  is politically popular. Indeed, from what I gather it is a very politically risky position." **********The Senate resolution, which is in rough draft form, will condition support on a commitment by Mr. Clinton that the Bosnian Government will be able to defend itself after the NATO-led force leaves in about one year, Mr. McCain said. **********It also states that the American troops will engage only in military activities, not nation-building activities like the return of refugees or the policing of streets. **********The United States has committed itself to helping the Bosnian Government arm  and train its military, but not as part of the peace enforcement operation of NATO, which opposes the plan. The American military will also not carry out that task. Rather, it will be done with still-undefined American participation in conjunction with other countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/busin.body_text: **********Crowley, Milner & Company, a department store chain, announced yesterday that it was taking over the Steinbach chain in the Northeast. The deal is expected to more than double Crowley's sales to about $215 million a year and add more than  a dozen stores to the 10-store company. Steinbach Inc. is owned by the Schottenstein family of Columbus, Ohio. Under the deal, the family would receive new Crowley stock valued at as much as 45 percent of its current stock. Crowley's stock jumped $1 yesterday, to $5.50, on the American Stock Exchange. Crowley said it would sell 9 or 10 of Steinbach's 24 stores, which operate in Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, New Hampshire and Vermont. The Crowley stores are in southeastern Michigan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/19/busin.main_headline: INVESTING IT;Flying High Even After Bad Trades
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/19/busin.print_headline: INVESTING IT;Flying High Even After Bad Trades
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/19/busin.body_text: **********NOW you can lose all your money in the stock market and still take that trip  to the Bahamas. **********A discount brokerage firm, Bull and Bear Securities, has joined the many airlines, hotels, retailers and car-rental companies that give away frequent-flier miles. Under the program, which began on Nov. 1, a customer gets 500 American Airlines miles for each of his first five trades, then 100 miles for each subsequent trade. The deal applies to trades of all sizes. **********It takes 25,000 miles, or points, to earn a free domestic ticket on American Airlines, and 40,000 for an international flight. So, after buying or selling stocks 380 times, now you can get a free flight to Bolivia. **********A midsize firm based in New York, Bull and Bear is apparently the first discount broker to offer such a perk. The firm pays American for the miles, but  has not raised its own fees, said Mark C. Winmill, Bull and Bear's president. He added that response to the program has been strong. **********But is it worth it? That depends. **********Bull and Bear is neither the cheapest nor the most expensive of discounters,  according to the American Association of Individual Investors, which surveyed the industry earlier this year. To trade 100 shares of a stock with a price of $50, for example, Bull and Bear investors would pay $44 in commissions, a bit more than the industry average of $42.67. But they can sometimes do better: the  firm's minimum commission is $31, somewhat lower than the industry's average minimum of $36.29. **********With the deal, a Bull and Bear investor gets 500 frequent-flier miles for a first trade. On average, a frequent-flier mile is worth 1.5 cents, Randy Petersen, publisher of Inside Flyer magazine, said. That means the 500 miles are worth $7.50; enough, on a $31 trade, to drop the firm's minimum to $23.50. That  is lower than the minimums charged by all but a handful of the nearly 90 discounters tracked by the association. **********The 1.5-cent figure is an average, however. Depending on the actual ticket price of the trip for which the traveler uses the miles, the real value may be lower or higher. And Bull and Bear offers 500 miles just for the first five trades; after that, traders get only 100 miles a trade, worth about $1.50 by Mr. Petersen's reckoning. Add in the many other differences among discounters -- handling fees, interest paid on account balances -- and the importance to the individual investor of the Bull and Bear offer can vary greatly. **********Bull and Bear's promotion is part of an important trend in the discount industry.  "There is really cutthroat competition right now," said Mark D. Coler, publisher of the Discount Brokerage Survey in New York. **********The struggle began last year, with some discounters slashing rates and installing flatter, less complicated commissions. **********But now fees are so low that "prices are a nonfactor" for further competition, said Ronald Kraska, vice president of R. J. Forbes Group, a discounter in Melville, L.I. **********So brokers have turned to nonprice lures instead. Mr. Kraska said his firm considered offering frequent-flier miles last year but decided against it because of accounting difficulties. It is focusing on technology to draw customers, perhaps with software that would let customers trade from home PC's. **********"I'm willing to go to Taiwan and get posters and give them away with every trade," Mr. Kraska said. "It's gotten to that point." **********The higher-priced discounters are offering nonprice lures, too. Hugo Quackenbush, senior vice president at Charles Schwab, criticized the frequent-flier deal. "This is a serious business," Mr. Quackenbush said. He said Schwab offers a Visa card that lets customers collect points toward the purchase of investment-oriented magazines and other items. **********Mr. Winmill said he thought of the frequent-flier angle because he is a frequent flier with American Airlines. "I've chosen my airline because of frequent-flier miles," he said. "The Visa card I have is because of frequent-flier miles. The phone service I use is because of frequent-flier miles." **********Asked why he didn't just reduce Bull and Bear commissions by the value of the frequent-flier miles, Mr. Winmill said, "This is different. It may appeal to people more."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/03/busin.main_headline: Trucker Strike Hurt Car Sales In September
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/03/busin.print_headline: Trucker Strike Hurt Car Sales In September
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/03/busin.body_text: **********An eight-week strike by car haulers has begun to take its toll on United States vehicle sales, causing the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation to report disappointing September sales today. **********The strike, by 5,000 members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters at Ryder System Inc.'s car hauling unit, may sharply hinder October sales if it continues. **********It's beginning to back up, and there's no negotiations going on, so it could affect October in a big way," said David Healy, an analyst with Burnham Securities. **********General Motors reported that its total vehicle sales in the United States during September rose half of 1 percent, to 401,463 units, with car sales up 4.1 percent and truck sales down 5.6 percent. **********But the sales figure for cars, analysts noted, included significant sales to  fleet customers, which are recorded upon production, not actual delivery. **********General Motors is Ryder's largest customer, accounting for roughly 60 percent of the car hauler's business. **********Chrysler reported that its total vehicle sales fell 6.6 percent, to 157,004 units, with car sales off 15.9 percent and truck sales off eight-tenths of 1 percent. **********Nicholas Lobocarro, an analyst with S. G. Warburg, said the Chrysler car sales decline was in part a result of consumer resistance to higher prices on new 1996 models as inventories of discounted 1995 models dwindled. **********"August was a good month for cutting deals," he said. "The consumer is not making these kinds of purchases without being patient and cutting a deal. It makes me think that you'll see pressure for incentives or more fleet sales before long." **********For the entire industry, auto industry sales for September were running 1.1 percent behind sales a year ago. **********Without General Motors' fleet sales, said Michael Luckey, president of the Luckey Consulting Group, the overall September industry sales rate would fall to about 14.7 million units. **********Shares of General Motors fell 25 cents today, to $46.625, on the New York Stock Exchange, while Chrysler shares rose 25 cents, to $53.25. **********The Ford Motor Company is expected to report soft September sales on Wednesday, analysts said. Ford is the least dependent on Ryder of the Big Three auto makers. Ford shares fell 37.5 cents, to $30.75, on the New York Stock Exchange today, while shares of Ryder rose 12.5 cents, to $25.50. **********Among Japanese auto makers, the Honda Motor Company said its total United States vehicle sales rose six-tenths of 1 percent, to 69,182, with car sales up  10.3 percent and sport utility vehicle sales off 17 percent. **********Sales for Subaru of America, a division of Fuji Heavy Industries, totaled 9,772 cars in September, up 6.8 percent from a year ago, with car sales up 22.8  percent. Suzuki Motor Company's sales for the period fell 33.4 percent. **********Volvo A.B.'s United States sales for the month were up 43.7 percent, to 6,836, while Saab Automobile A.B., a venture of General Motors and Investor A.B. , said its sales rose 48.2 percent, to 2,282. **********Other auto makers are expected to report their United States sales on Tuesday and Wednesday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/01/busin.main_headline: INVESTING IT: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;An Options Strategy for Individual Investors
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/01/busin.print_headline: INVESTING IT: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;An Options Strategy for Individual Investors
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/01/busin.body_text: **********Q. My broker suggested that I sell call options against some blue chip stocks I  own. Isn't this a risky type of investment where only the broker ends up winning by making a commission?    T. ESTRA    New York City A. Not necessarily. Let's face it, all investments carry some degree of risk. Nicholas W. Leeson, the rogue trader who last February lost $1.8 billion in Singapore and promptly took down Britain's oldest bank, Barings P.L.C., was trading in that scariest of investments, derivatives. **********But Toshihide Iguchi, the Daiwa trader who allegedly lost $1.1 billion and was arrested last week, was playing with Treasuries, that supersafe bond backed  by Uncle Sam. **********In other words, how you use an investment sharply affects its risk. And what  your broker seems to have in mind -- selling options against shares you already  own -- is one of the few options strategies that make sense for individual investors. **********Known as writing covered calls, this tactic is a conservative way of insuring part of your portfolio against a decline, according to Stephanie L. Ackler, a vice president at Tucker Anthony, a financial services firm. **********Okay, here's how it works. Imagine you own 100 shares of XYZ Technology, and  you are worried its price will fall, either for company-specific reasons or due to a broad market downturn. To soften the impact of such a drop, you sell an option to another investor to buy your stock. **********This "call" option gives the other person the right to buy your shares at a predetermined price, known as the strike price, within a certain period of time. One call covers 100 shares of stock. If XYZ is trading at $44, for example, imagine that you sell one November call at a strike price of $45. You get $300 for selling this right. **********First, the $300 goes into your account and you keep that no matter what. Next, one of two things will take place. If the market falls and XYZ stock closes at, say, $39 at some point before expiration, which occurs the third Friday in November, the option holder will have no interest in buying your stock at $45. The option will expire worthless. And, with the $300 you have pocketed,  you have cut in half the losses on your 100 shares due to the stock's decline. If the stock stays at $44, you have made money on the deal, to the tune of $300. **********But suppose instead that the market rises and XYZ closes at $55 at the option's expiration. The defensive technique of writing covered calls doesn't work well in such a rise. The option holder will naturally elect to buy your 100 shares for $45 apiece.  You do get the $300 from sale of the option, but that isn't nearly enough to make up for the $1,000 you lose in selling stock for $45  a share in a market where it is getting $55. **********Knowing that this can occur, you may want to consider selling calls on only half the number of XYZ shares in your portfolio. This way you won't miss out completely should the stock go up. **********And you should select sleepy stocks -- those equities in your portfolio likely to remain at or around their current levels, said Ms. Ackler.  An example is Lilco,, the Long Island utility, which has been sluggish lately. A contrary example is a volatile stock like Cyrix, a technology company. While you will doubtless get more money for selling options on such a stock, you will also run  a greater risk of missing out on a significant upside move. **********But be aware that selling calls without owning the underlying stock is an entirely different strategy. This is an uncovered position -- and a very risky one, even for the pros. I know, having been a floor options trader on the American Stock Exchange for a few years. A number of my colleagues had to trade  in their yachts for rowboats. **********Still, even writing covered calls requires cautions. One big one: unless you  know exactly what you're doing don't fly solo. Options are complicated, but more than that, they can be very volatile. Should you ever drop into a busy options pit around lunch hour, you'll observe the traders chomping their sandwiches, eyes riveted on the computer screens above them and essentially afraid to leave. Don't go it alone. **********Second, read "Characteristics and Risks of Standardized Options," a booklet your broker should send you when you open an options account. You may also want  to read a book on the subject. Given that most tomes in the investment section of your local superstore are much too complicated -- as if the authors expect George Soros or Warren Buffett to buy one for a brush-up session -- look for something more easily understood. **********I suggest "Getting Started in Options," by Michael Thomsett (John Wiley & Sons, $17.95). Just so you know where I'm coming from, my idea of a beginner's book is Elbert S. Mahoney's "Chapman's Piloting, Seamanship & Small Boat Handling," which begins with the weighty question, "What is a boat?" **********However, if you don't get around to the book (there are only 84 days left for holiday shopping) here are a few guidelines. Always know your potential profit and loss before trading an option. **********Ms. Ackler warns against selling a call for under a half point ($50) since it won't be worth the commission cost. And don't get carried away; most professional portfolio managers only sell call options on 5 to 10 percent of their entire holdings. **********If you follow these rules and if you have the stomach for it, by all means listen to your broker and let him play the options game. After all, when Charles F. Kettering, a top executive at General Motors years ago, said we should all be concerned about the future because we will have to spend the rest of our lives there, he might just as well have been talking about options trading. **********But if you are the type to get upset if you make a bad options trade, heed the advice of Sam Goldwyn, the malapropist filmmaker of yore: never make any predictions, especially about the future. **********Questions about investing, careers and personal finance can be sent to Minding Your Business, in care of Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York 10036. Or by E-mail to yourmind@nytimes.com. Questions can be answered only in the column, not by mail, E-mail or telephone.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/09/world.main_headline: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: YOUTHS;From Young Israelis, an Outpouring of Emotion
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/09/world.print_headline: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: YOUTHS;From Young Israelis, an Outpouring of Emotion
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/09/world.body_text: **********Perhaps it came at the moment when Yitzhak Rabin's teen-age granddaughter broke down and sobbed at his funeral. **********Perhaps it was a phenomenon that was building all along in the peace songs and the rallies that preceded his assassination. **********Whatever its origin, something close to a spiritual fervor touched off by adulation, idealism and grief has been inspired in many young Israelis that many of their elders regard as extraordinary. **********If there are defining images of the nation's grief, they lie in the visions of young people lighting candles at makeshift memorials in central Tel Aviv and  in the catch in the voice of Mr. Rabin's granddaughter, Noa Ben-Artzi Philosof,  18, at the burial Monday when she spoke of the slain Israeli leader as "the pillar of fire before the camp." **********"I felt that she said things that many of us thought were right," said Noam Bacharach, a 14-year-old high-school student who went to deliver a letter of condolence to the Rabins' high-rise apartment in a rainy Tel Aviv suburb today.  "When he was shot, we felt we lost a part of ourselves, that we lost a grandfather, too." **********For some, the torrent of emotion represents a benchmark change. "When he fell as a victim," said Mr. Rabin's widow, Leah, the spectacle of "all those children and all those youth coming up to speak for him and what he was doing" showed that something had shifted. **********"We are living in something that was not true two days ago," she said. **********Some people, however, say such sentiments are restricted to young secular people, and have occurred simply because emotion is the prime currency of adolescence. **********There may be another reason for the popularity of the slain Prime Minister among the young. From the age of 18, every Israeli must serve three years in the army. The peace that Mr. Rabin promised represented the offer of a new life without the danger and disruption of military service -- an offer that is perceived by many as now being cast into doubt. **********"If there is going to be peace, the next generation is the one that is going  to make the changes," said Saev Sagir, an 18-year-old student who is to start military service in two weeks and does not relish the idea. "People are really scared of going into the military," he said. "You are going to fight for your life every day." **********Tom Segev, an author and columnist, wrote today in the newspaper Haaretz: "The most surprising thing this week was the readiness of young people to adopt  Rabin as their hero. Maybe, who knows, the children thought that Rabin was giving them a new world without basic training in Gaza," he wrote. **********At the spot in downtown Tel Aviv where Mr. Rabin was shot on Saturday night by another young Israeli -- 25-year-old Yigal Amir -- a 23-year-old El Al airline steward, Roten Albelda, fumbled as he tried to light a candle. "It's like there's a big hole in me," he said, "or a big ball of confusion and fear."  He added: "I really trusted him. I trusted the way he was leading us." **********Thousands of candles burned today at the site of Mr. Rabin's shooting -- the  former Kings of Israel Square that has been renamed Yitzhak Rabin Square -- until rain sweeping in from the Mediterranean quenched many of them. **********Then, as the rain gave way to winter sunshine, people came to light the candles anew. **********"The young people wanted to believe that they wouldn't have to go to war," said Ronit Zohar, a 25-year-old who wept openly as she maneuvered the stroller carrying her 8-month-old daughter through the candles. "They wanted to believe they won't fight, they won't die anymore. When I heard about the shooting, I looked at my daughter and thought: What kind of world will you inherit?" **********Amos Ben Shalom, a 63-year-old laboratory technician said: "The young people  are lonely. They are more afraid. They looked to Rabin as a father, as a big father." **********The impact of such emotions on Israeli politics is still far from clear. Nearly half of Israel's 5.2 million people are under the age of 24 and many of those are under the voting age of 18. Moreover, young people, like the rest of Israeli society, are deeply divided over the peace effort. **********In both Tel Aviv and at Mr. Rabin's grave in Jerusalem today, there was little indication that ultra-Orthodox Jews -- young or old -- were taking part in the mourning, any more than were Mr. Rabin's adversaries on the right. **********Some political analysts suggested that the young people who took part in public mourning were the same people who had attended peace rallies, meaning that their tears would not create a shift in the political center of gravity. **********"Maybe they were the ones who were idealistic enough to hope that something was going to come of all this," said Gadi Wolfsfeld, of Hebrew University in Jerusalem. "Maybe they really believed we were entering a new world, that their  lives would be different than ours had been." **********Noa Schein, a 13-year-old high school student, said: "He wanted us to grow up in peace. It means we don't have to be afraid any more."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/27/busin.body_text: **********The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation will build a new transmission and engine assembly plant in the Philippines for 20 billion yen, or about $200 million, a company spokesman said today. Construction of the plant is scheduled to begin in early 1996 and is expected to be completed by mid-1997. The plant will replace an existing Philippine plant that has a production capacity of 156,000 units. The new factory's projected output is 234,000 units, the spokesman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/28/busin.main_headline: Pasta Makers of the World, Unite
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/28/busin.print_headline: Pasta Makers of the World, Unite
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/28/busin.body_text: **********Oktay Piyale chewed, swallowed, furrowed his brow, and then smiled broadly. "Ah, al dente!" he said -- just the right firmness. "In Turkey we cook it too long," said Mr. Piyale, the chairman of Maktas, Turkey's largest pasta maker, as he sampled a first course of fusilli with vegetable ragu. **********The occasion was the opening luncheon on Thursday of the First World Pasta Congress, and the presence of Turks -- along with noodle merchants, manufacturers and experts from China and India, Burkina Faso and Saudi Arabia, along with the Americans and Italians -- was testimony to the global reach of the huge pasta industry. **********The delegates say pasta has become worthy of such a gathering. The world's prodigious appetite, for instance, has contributed to a shortage of durum wheat, said James Streeter, a trader for the big grain company Italgrani S.p.A. Prices  have climbed to about $7.50 a bushel in the United States, from $4.50 a few years ago. And increasingly competitive pasta makers have brought trade disputes to international forums. **********Still, for Giuseppe Menconi, the big decision at the start of the two-day conference was what sort of pasta to serve to Mr. Piyale and the 500 or so other delegates. Fusilli was no haphazard selection. **********"When you're cooking for so many people, you have to choose a short format, with considerable thickness," said Mr. Menconi, president of the Union of Italian Industrial Pasta Manufacturers, indicating the ideal length with a thumb and forefinger. **********And how was it kept al dente? "I always say, pasta must swim like a fish in water, so you need one liter for every hundred grams," he said. "The pasta must  be alive, like serpents. Pasta is a living thing, it is not a shoe, or a button, and you must remove it from the water at the right moment, onto a hot serving dish." **********Across the dining room of Rome's elegant Excelsior Hotel, where the delegates clinked glasses and slurped their fusilli -- a short, wavy variety that goes well with heavier sauces -- Ding Xiaolin deftly twisted an unaccustomed fork. Professor Ding, a specialist in food science from Jiangsu, China, had led a team of Chinese experts to Rome. **********"Most of the time, we have Chinese noodles, but I like pasta," said Professor Ding, who got to know the Western variety during the two years he spent at Kansas State University. "Because our population is so big, if the Chinese eat pasta one night a week, that's a lot of pasta." **********Calculations like that warm the heart of Mr. Menconi, whose group organized the conference, the first of its kind, to gather delegates from over 40 countries, including manufacturers of pasta and pasta-making machinery, grain growers and traders, nutrition and food policy experts. **********After the fusilli, which was followed by veal, they broke up into working groups. In one, a Swiss engineer from Buhler A.G., the world's largest manufacturer of pasta-making machines, projected slides showing magnified cross-sections of penne to illustrate new techniques for producing extrusion dies. Elsewhere, Giorgio Duchi, an Italian pasta expert, discussed the "granulometric characteristics of semolina," the durum wheat flour that is pasta's principal ingredient. **********"In Italy, we say the spaghetti is eaten first with the eyes, then with the mouth," he said. "So color is fundamental." **********"The idea is to exchange ideas," said Leonard DeFrancisci, the president of Demaco Food Processing Systems, in Ridgewood, Queens, which makes pasta machines. **********"We're discussing everything from the promotion of pasta, to awareness of pasta's value, to manufacturing methods," said Mr. DeFrancisci, whose huge computer-controlled machines, selling for $3 million to $4 million apiece, can turn out 100,000 pounds of pasta a day. **********The conference's diverse attendance bore witness to pasta's international appeal, he said. "It has no fat," he said, "it's got complex carbohydrates, and  it's an efficient way to produce nutrition. It takes 8 or 9 pounds of grain to make a pound of beef. Why not just eat pasta?" **********With prices for things like raw materials rising, the struggle is fierce for  shares in leading markets. Indeed, the fly in the sauce at this week's meeting was the decision earlier this month by the United States Commerce Department to  tentatively impose tariffs on Italian and Turkish pasta, in response to a complaint by some of America's largest manufacturers. As imports have grown in recent years, the American industry argues that Italian and Turkish producers use government subsidies at home to sell pasta below cost in the United States.  The American companies asked for the tariffs to offset the European advantage. **********But Mr. Streeter said a pall of silence hung over the topic. "No one has talked about it much," he said, adding, "Everybody wants free trade, as long as  it's not my product." **********The consensus appeared to be that the world's hunger for pasta was large enough to satisfy everyone. "These are episodes, this will not be the rule," said Mr. Menconi of the American action, waving his hand as if to whisk the problem from the table. "The only ones who will earn money on this in the end will be the lawyers." **********"Peace, harmony, harmony," urged C. Mickey Skinner, the president of the Hershey Pasta Group, which sells Ronzoni pasta and is one of the American companies that filed the suit. Hershey Pasta is a unit of the Hershey Foods Corporation. **********Though pasta may be a universal commodity, George P. Morris, the president of Borden Inc.'s North American Pasta Company, which sells Prince pasta, noted how  attitudes toward it vary in the United States. **********"I think pasta has two basic personalities," he mused, turning the idea as if twisting vermicelli on a fork. "In some markets, it can be a piece of Americana; in other markets it has to be Italian ethnic." **********"New York, which I believe is the world's largest pasta market," he said, "is one of those latter markets." **********Thus, some American brands, like Ronzoni, have Italian-sounding names, while  others, like Prince, do not. Borden's contender in the great New York pasta race, he noted glumly, is called Creamette, though its Classico brand has now entered the running against Italian imports like De Cecco and Barilla. **********If the Italian and American pasta makers made efforts to disguise mutual disdain, competitors from further afield showed greater equanimity. **********"Pasta is part of Indian folklore," said Ramana Rao Arkal, whose company, Jaya Food Industries Ltd., in Bangalore, India, manufactures Bambino pasta. "We  eat it as a breakfast food, or as a dessert called kheer, in sweetened milk." **********In recent years, said Mr. Arkal, whose company produces about 2,400 tons a month of various pasta types, including vermicelli, penne and spaghetti, Indians have developed a taste for foreign foods, most notably Chinese cuisine. **********"We are thinking of starting an Italian food revolution," he said, by teaching Indians, who already enjoy Italian dishes like pizza, to consume pasta  with sauces the Italian way. **********Pasta, he said, could provide India with a nutritional alternative. "We don't worry about obesity," he said, "but it is splendid for diabetics, of which there are many in India, and for cardiovascular problems, for its protein content." **********"One of our legends has it that the Hindu god Krishna, as a baby, was fond of sweets, curds and butter," he said. "And one of his favorite sweets was kheer."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/13/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Turner Said to Defend Milken's Advisory Fee
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/13/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Turner Said to Defend Milken's Advisory Fee
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/13/busin.body_text: **********Ted Turner, the chairman of Turner Broadcasting System, acknowledged at an investment conference on Wednesday that huge sums would be at stake for himself  and others in the planned acquisition of his company by Time Warner Inc. But he  defended the tens of millions of dollars that are to be paid to his friend, Michael R. Milken, for advising on the takeover, people who attended the conference said yesterday. **********By contrast, Mr. Turner offered to cut his pay package, which has been reported at more than $100 million, if it would smooth the path for the $7.4 billion deal, these people said. **********Mr. Turner was the lunchtime keynote speaker at the conference in New York,  which was organized by Goldman, Sachs & Company for its clients in the communications and entertainment industry. The firm has been trying to expand its investment banking business in that area. **********In his remarks, Mr. Turner said Mr. Milken, the former junk-bond financier, waatN tx be paid tens of millions of dollars more than the $50 million fee that  has been widely reported as his compensation for advising Mr. Turner and his company, according to people at the conference. **********"The whole part of his discussion that concerned Milken was extremely light," said a person who heard Mr. Turner's remarks. A spokesman for Turner Broadcasting declined to comment on Mr. Turner's statements. A spokesman for Goldman, Sachs also declined to comment on the meeting. **********The large sums that are to be paid to Mr. Turner and to Mr. Milken have upset many investors and others associated with the takeover. Some have contended that Mr. Turner has been looking after his own interests in the deal while neglecting those of his executives. Mr. Turner's pay package is reportedly more  than $100 million over five years. **********And Mr. Turner's adviser, Mr. Milken, is a particularly controversial figure. A brilliant financier who pioneered the development of the junk-bond market, Mr. Milken pleaded guilty in 1990 to securities fraud, served two years in prison and paid fines of close to $1 billion. Mr. Milken was also banned from the securities industry for life, and regulators in Washington have been pondering whether to take a closer look at his new business activities to determine if he  has infringed that ban. **********A spokesman for Time Warner said that "nothing has been confirmed on any of those numbers" for Mr. Turner's compensation or Mr. Milken's fee. The totals will be in the proxy statement, this spokesman said, adding that "whatever is printed in the newspapers is just speculation."
