https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/08/world.main_headline: Armenia Runs Show in Disputed Enclave
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/08/world.print_headline: Armenia Runs Show in Disputed Enclave
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/08/world.body_text: **********On a recent autumn day in this town linking Muslim Azerbaijan to Christian Armenia, young soldiers, their heads newly shaved, boasted of "defending our homeland." **********The men, pulling on cigarettes, would not have been unusual except that they  were Armenian Army regulars. Their presence on this side of the border reflected how, since a cease-fire in May 1994, this disputed region of Azerbaijan has become an effective part of Armenia. **********After a seven-year war in which Azerbaijan has lost a fifth of its territory, the shift makes the ethnic Armenian-majority region of Nagorno-Karabakh another example of how nationalist ambitions have redrawn borders since the cold war. **********"Whether or not this is a kind of federation, maybe to some extent we would like it to happen," Robert Kocharian, 41, the president of Nagorno-Karabakh, said in an interview in the enclave's capital, Stepanakert. **********Already, leaders of Nagorno-Karabakh travel on Armenian diplomatic passports, and the economy runs on Armenian currency. With financing from the Armenian population in the United States, a highway is being paved through this gorge to  connect Armenia with Nagorno-Karabakh. **********Mr. Kocharian demands that any peace accord give Armenia the right to intervene militarily in response to Azerbaijani hostilities against ethnic Armenians in Nagorno-Karabakh. **********The conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh, a region of 1,700 square miles whose prewar population was 200,000, is rooted in Stalin's decision in 1923 to attach the enclave to Azerbaijan. In 1988, war began when ethnic Armenians there declared a desire to unite with Armenia. For Armenia, the current situation embraces a nationalist goal of rebuilding historic Armenia. **********In negotiations that are to resume between the two former Soviet republics on Saturday in Moscow, Azerbaijan has demanded control over Nagorno-Karabakh as an  autonomous region, or at least that its territorial status be decided later. **********For now, a fragile measure of normality has returned to Nagorno-Karabakh. South of Stepanakert, Yuri Vedian, 58, seeded a wheatfield on a 1,000-acre collective farm, steering a tractor through dark, rich earth. With the region's  first full growing season in years, Mr. Vedian said, all but 50 acres were being sowed. **********"If it had depended on me, there never would have been a war at all," he said. "Of course we are part of Armenia. But the main thing is that our children should not die."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/17/world.body_text: **********Stating that there was no assurance that it would succeed, former Senator George J. Mitchell has begun the work of the new international panel that is to  deal with the dispute over disarmament of the Irish Republican Army in Northern  Ireland. **********Mr. Mitchell, head of the International Body on disarmament, said on Friday in Belfast, the Ulster capital, "we understand that the success of our efforts is far from assured but we believe that the process of peace and reconciliation  now underway in Northern Ireland is historic." **********The panel marks a change in British policy: for decades London had rejected  the idea of a foreign diplomatic involvement in achieving a political settlement in Northern Ireland, saying it was an internal British problem. But the internationalization of the Northern Ireland situation had long been a goal of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A. **********The panel is to try to work out a compromise between Sinn Fein and the British Government and Protestant political leaders in Northern Ireland. The British insist that the I.R.A. make a start on disarming before Sinn Fein is allowed to take part in negotiations to reach a political settlement of the strife that has killed more than 3,100 people since 1969. **********Sinn Fein holds that this is an unacceptable condition and that the I.R.A. has proved its committment to peace in the unilateral cease-fire it has kept since September 1994. **********British officials have said that the panel might find a way, aside from actual disarmament, that would settle the dispute by obtaining from Sinn Fein other assurances for the Protestant majority that the I.R.A. has abandoned forever its "armed struggle" to end British control of Northern Ireland. **********But Gerry Adams, the leader of Sinn Fein, said Friday that he doubted the panel would succeed unless Britain dropped its demand for a start of disarmament before full peace talks could begin. **********The panel met with Sir Patrick Mayhew, the British Northern Ireland Secretary on Friday. Today, it heard from Ulster political officials before taveling to Dublin for two days for meetings with Sinn Fein and Irish Government officials. **********The panel is to make a recommendation by mid-January. Its other members are Harri Holkeri, a former Prime Minister of Finland, and Gen. John de Chastelain,  chief of staff of Canadian defense forces.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/03/busin.main_headline: International Briefs;Sega Plans to Move Production From Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/03/busin.print_headline: International Briefs;Sega Plans to Move Production From Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/03/busin.body_text: **********Sega Enterprises Ltd., the computer game maker, is planning to move production of all of its home computer game systems overseas from Japan. The company, which already makes 59 percent of its home game machines outside Japan, will contract with factories in other Asian countries and plans to move production there by the end of next year, a Sega spokeswoman, Misao Hibi, said on Thursday. **********She said the Japanese yen's rise of about 15 percent against many other currencies this year had made production in Japan more expensive relative to other countries. Last month, Sega introduced its newest machine, the Saturn, in  the United States. Sega, Japan's largest maker of arcade games and its second-largest home computer game maker behind the Nintendo Company, said it also planned to try to move production of arcade games overseas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/08/world.main_headline: A Fuel Tanker Explodes in Iraq, Killing 10, With 2 From U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/08/world.print_headline: A Fuel Tanker Explodes in Iraq, Killing 10, With 2 From U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/08/world.body_text: **********At least 10 people, including two United Nations guards, were killed and 30 were injured today when a fuel tanker exploded in northern Iraq, a United Nations spokesman said. **********The two dead guards were a Pole and a Filipino. A third guard, from Nepal, was also injured but his life was not in danger, according to the spokesman of the United Nations Department of Humanitarian Affairs. **********The first investigation reveals that the vehicles of the guards were passing or crossing at the moment a fuel tanker exploded," she said. **********"Two guards died. At least eight local people were also killed and over 30 people were injured." **********The names of the guards were not released. **********It was not clear from a brief report from United Nations officials in Iraq whether the explosion was caused by a bomb, but the Geneva spokeswoman said she  thought it was not. **********The blast occured at Shaqlawa, some 35 miles north of Erbil, the main city of three Kurdish-ruled provinces in northern Iraq. **********Some 150 United Nations guards are deployed to patrol northern Iraq to guard  aid supplies and other United Nations convoys. Northern Iraq has been under the control of Kurdish groups since shortly after the end of the 1991 Gulf War. **********Earlier, an official in London of the Iraqi National Congress, an Iraqi opposition group, said 13 people had died in the blast. **********"Witnesses reported that a tanker used to bring petrol from Baghdad to the U.N. gasoline station exploded in a large fireball," the group said in a statement later faxed to Ankara. **********A bomb explosion at the group's security office in the northern Iraqi town of Salahuddin in October killed at least 28 people. Opposition groups have blamed President Saddam Hussein of Iraq for that attack.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/11/world.main_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;3 U.N. Troops Wounded By Israelis in Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/11/world.print_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;3 U.N. Troops Wounded By Israelis in Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/11/world.body_text: **********Three United Nations peacekeepers were wounded early today when an Israeli tank opened fire on their night patrol in the Israeli occupation zone in southern Lebanon. **********The Israelis apparently mistook the peacekeepers for Muslim guerrillas who are battling to oust the occupying army from the nine-mile wide zone. Israel quickly expressed regret for the incident. **********The three peacekeepers, all Norwegian soldiers, were in stable condition tonight after undergoing surgery for wounds caused by Israeli anti-personnel shells, a United Nations spokesman said. **********The spokesman, Michael Lindvall, said that the Israeli force had fired at the patrol despite having been told only half an hour earlier that the United Nations personnel were operating in the area. The incident came at a time of mounting tensions between Israeli forces and Party of God guerrillas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/20/world.main_headline: Echoing the Cold War, Yeltsin Rails Against the West
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/20/world.print_headline: Echoing the Cold War, Yeltsin Rails Against the West
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/20/world.body_text: **********Pumping up the volume before his summit meeting with President Clinton next week, President Boris N. Yeltsin sounded off today against NATO and the United States and said he would dismiss his Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, who is often criticized here as too accommodating to the West. **********Mr. Yeltsin's performance at an interview with Russian and western reporters  today carried a touch of the cold war bravado displayed by Nikita S. Khrushchev  at the United Nations in 1960 -- including table-pounding (though with his fist, not his shoe). **********As Western allies seek to work out a Russian role in policing a peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Mr. Yeltsin gave no outward signs of compromise. "We will not fight under NATO command," he said. **********Mr. Yeltsin's plans to dismiss Mr. Kozyrev emerged off-handedly, in response  to a question. **********He had publicly criticized Mr. Kozyrev before, but today's remarks, on the eve of a major overseas visit, were far harsher. **********"My dissatisfaction remains," he said. "I see no improvement of his work." **********Mr. Kozyrev, who has served in Mr. Yeltsin's Cabinet longer than any other minister and is the only liberal left, had always publicly defended Mr. Yeltsin's frequent foreign-policy mood swings. **********Accusing the Foreign Minister of not getting along with other Cabinet ministers, Mr. Yeltsin said he had been forced to coordinate foreign policy himself. **********President Yeltsin said it would take time to find a suitable replacement for  Mr. Kozyrev, and said he would keep him in his job until then. **********"For now, since he is trying, let's not squash him," he said. "Let him work.  But my decision remains." **********Mr. Yeltsin made several startling statements about the December parliamentary elections and the 1996 presidential race in Russia. He backed away from the centrist political bloc he helped create, Our House Russia, saying he would treat all nonextremist parties equally and describing this reversal as "a  slight turn." **********Mr. Yeltsin also suggested for the first time that his military invasion of Chechnya in December might have been misguided. **********"It might have been possible to manage the situation more subtly and with more foresight," he said somberly. He described the huge loss of life there as "the greatest disappointment of my presidency." **********Mr. Yeltsin, who is under intense pressure from nationalist and Communist opposition, said his country would fight NATO expansion in Europe, blamed Western-style capitalism for corruption in Russia and mocked American pressure to reverse Russia's plans to sell nuclear reactors to Iran. He said he had made  certain that the reactors could not be converted by Iran for military use, then  added that Washington's campaign was secretly aimed at thwarting Russian arm sales. **********"Our weapons are powerful and in many respects better than American ones," he said with a smirk. "They don't want us to move gradually ahead and conquer the world market for arms and military hardware." **********Mr. Yeltsin, who not along ago was hospitalized for a severe heart problem, appeared robust and even frisky as he arrived in a gilded reception room in the  Kremlin. Heedless of television cameras recording the scene, he playfully tweaked two secretaries in the back as he walked to his seat. **********He was quite in earnest, however, when he paddled away from the pro-Government Our House Russia, recently organized by Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin. The party, mostly made up of governors and legislators, has fared poorly in recent regional elections. Mr. Yeltsin said today that he did not want to be associated with only one party, but would support all factions except the Communists and extreme-nationalist Liberal-Democratic party. **********"I made a slight turn, but I am in no way rejecting Our House Russia," Mr. Yeltsin said. "I am at the same time demonstratively supporting other movements. I must be even with everybody, you see?" **********Asked whether he could work with a Communist-dominated Parliament if one was  elected in December, he said his main goal was to prevent such a thing. **********"If the Communists come up with any calls to overthrow the existing regime, well, in such cases, we may go so far as to cancel the registration of such candidates," he said. "I mean, we must conduct propaganda against the Communists." But he added that he did not think the Communists had as much support as suggested by public opinion polls. **********Mr. Yeltsin did not seem overjoyed by another candidate doing well in opinion polls, Aleksandr I. Lebed, a nationalist and anti-establishment general who is running in the December elections in the hope of becoming a presidential candidate in 1996. **********"I am neutral toward them," he said referring to General Lebed and the leader of his party, Yuri V. Skokov. "They have some positive ideas, but there are some strong-armed intentions that Russia does not need." **********Mr. Yeltsin said he had not decided whether he would seek another term but did not rule it out, saying he would decide after the parliamentary elections. **********Asked about his pledge to curb corruption in Russia, Mr. Yeltsin bristled and replied that corruption was far worse in the United States and Europe. Echoing the kind of views favored by Communist leaders, he called Russia's current problems "the son and grandson" of corruption in the West. **********"All this is connected with free-market economy, which creates the corruption, the mafia and so on," he said. "It has become easy to trade, cheat and behave like hooligans." **********Toward the end of the interview, however, Mr. Yeltsin appeared to want to soften his words, and said free-market reforms were the greatest achievement of  his presidency. **********But he was adamant in his refusal to allow Russian peacekeeping troops to be  stationed in Bosnia under NATO command. He said that even if another international peacekeeping arrangement could be found, Moscow could not afford the cost of sending a division. He said that he would consider reinforcing the Russian troops already stationed in former Yugoslavia. **********Mr. Yeltsin also stated that Russia would take "protective measures" against  any attempt by Western allies to expand membership in NATO, but he did not spell out what those measures would be. **********Despite his criticism of NATO, Mr. Yeltsin spoke kindly of President Clinton, whom he said he respected and got along with "very well."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/26/busin.body_text: **********Stocks rose again here today, trading at the highest levels of the year. The unit has since been disbanded. **********Mr. Brown was one of eight soldiers to face charges in connection with the Somalia mission, mostly relating to the torture and beating death of Shidane Arone, a 16-year-old Somali who slipped into the Canadian compound. https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/10/world.main_headline: Russia's Fall Grain Harvest Will Be Its Worst in 30 Years
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/10/world.print_headline: Russia's Fall Grain Harvest Will Be Its Worst in 30 Years
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/10/world.body_text: **********Scorched by a summer-long drought and plagued by years of bad farm management, Russia's fall grain harvest will be its worst in 30 years, senior Government officials said today. **********Russia has suffered seriously this year, but we will remain self-sufficient  in grain until the 1996 harvest," Deputy Prime Minister Aleksandr K. Zaveryukha  told the Interfax News Agency upon returning from Canada this afternoon. "We will provide for our own citizens." **********That will be possible, specialists here say, mostly because the Russian people have begun to providing for themselves. More than a third of all meat and nearly half the vegetables in the country are now produced privately in back yards or in communal garden plots. For that reason, the predicted harvest of about 66 million tons of grain -- down from last year's anemic 80 million-ton figure -- will not lead to hunger, bread lines or the large-scale personal strife that often follows Russia's poorest harvests. **********But the economic effects, particularly on farmers, will be severe. And the political consequences -- a parliamentary election is scheduled for mid-December just when price increases on meat and milk should hit consumers -- are not expected to be comforting to President Boris N. Yeltsin's administration. **********"I think the biggest effect of this really grim harvest will be known in December," said Viktor F. Lischchenko, director of agricultural studies at the Academy of the National Economy of Russia and a former Government adviser. "Nobody can do anything about a drought. But the policies of this Government have for some time made a bad situation worse. Now they will be forced to let prices rise or to support them when they shouldn't for political reasons before  the election." **********Price increases are never good for the party in power. But price supports might be more harmful in the long run, because they could fuel inflation. **********Each problem in the farm system quickly touches upon others. Because the harvest was poor last year, few farmers could afford new machinery this year. That meant that the grain that was ready for market often failed to get there quickly enough. **********More than half of Russia's agricultural land suffered from drought this year. The poor crop will most seriously affect the quality and price of meat. Less grain means more expensive cattle feed. That will drive many farmers out of the  market, because they cannot afford the cost of keeping their animals alive. For  a while it will become a buyers' market, because farmers will be forced to sell  at low prices to get rid of their cattle. Then, once the animals are slaughtered, prices will rise sharply because supplies will drop. **********Mr. Zaveryukha, the country's most senior agricultural official, has said over the past several weeks that Russia is prepared to import grain if necessary. But nobody wants that. Grain imports are an important emotional issue here: They suggest that the country, which is still largely rural, cannot feed itself without outside help. **********Russia's problems are deepened by the fact that the other two major regional  grain suppliers -- Kazakhstan and Ukraine -- have also had problems this year. In Kazakhstan, the harvest is expected to fall to 12 million tons from 19 million last year. Ukraine is hoping to stay even with its harvest of 1994, but  last year's harvest of 35 million tons was far lower than the figure for 1993. It is unlikely that Ukraine will be able to help Russia with exports this year. **********There are many reasons for the poor harvest beyond the weather. Although the  collective farming system set up under Communism has officially been dismantled, nothing coherent has taken its place. Independent farms have no real distribution systems or bank credit and their equipment is inadequate and aging. When crops do well and are harvested rapidly they have to sit so long before they can be transported to market that as much as 40 percent of raw grain rots in the fields. **********Most important, perhaps, the property laws in Russia remain murky, discouraging people who do have money from buying a farm for fear they will not  really own it. Finally, because the Government is the biggest buyer of grain, it can keep prices low, meaning that many farmers cannot even recoup their investment. **********"What has happened now will take years to set right," said Viktor I. Pashinin, vice chairman of the Association of Peasant Farms and Agricultural Cooperatives of Russia. "We have combined stupidity with bad luck and now we are in a big hole."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;For the first time since '86, the holidays seem free of print ads that sing, pop up or mimic snow globes.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;For the first time since '86, the holidays seem free of print ads that sing, pop up or mimic snow globes.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/busin.body_text: **********ELABORATE, expensive print advertisements with holiday themes, intended to help sales messages stand out when consumers are busiest and most besieged by marketing blitzes, might well be going the way of an appreciation for fruitcake. **********The trend had begun in 1987, when Absolut vodka ran an ad embedded with a microchip that played Christmas carols. Since then, consumers have been enjoying (or, depending on their tolerance for whimsical kitsch, wincing at) pitches that have sung, talked, moved, popped up and mimicked the snow globes and Advent calendars of childhood memory. Another popular gimmick has been to enclose gifts, ranging from gloves and stickers to hosiery and handkerchiefs. **********Most of these ads, known as spectaculars, have peddled premium-priced products, particularly liquor. Several of them have carried premium price tags,  too, costing advertisers as much as $1 million in production and media costs. **********Those factors, and the genesis of spectaculars in the status-conscious 1980's, have fed a perception that they have been fading in relevance and effectiveness. **********Indeed, it appears that this holiday season will be the first in eight years  without a single spectacular. Even Absolut, which had run one every year since 1987, chose a decidedly low-key alternative for 1995: a four-line ad in tiny type on the bottom of the front page of The New York Times. That ad, which ran yesterday, announced that Absolut would donate $250,000 to the anti-hunger organization Share Our Strength. **********"I'm not saying that spectaculars are gone forever," said Arthur Shapiro, executive vice president for marketing at the House of Seagram in New York, a unit of the Seagram Company that is responsible for hawking brands like Absolut  and Chivas Regal Scotch whisky. **********"But everyone expects us to do a Christmas blockbuster," he added, "and that's a little more reason to zig while you're thinking we'll zag." **********It was that loss of the element of surprise and "a need to do something different," Mr. Shapiro said, that rang down the curtain for now on holiday spectaculars, rather than any belief that, as he put it, "they're so 80's." **********Richard Lewis, executive vice president of TBWA Chiat/Day in New York, the longtime Absolut agency that is owned by the Omnicom Group, agreed. **********"We're certainly not walking away from spectaculars," he said. "Just because  an idea was born in the 80's doesn't mean it had to die in the 80's." **********"What we decided this year was to simply take a break, a sabbatical," he added. **********One theory about why spectaculars are diminishing in appeal is that they are  being supplanted by interactive media projects that offer more consumer involvement -- and cost far less to create and produce -- than ads inviting someone to listen to a tinny tune or open a die-cut door. **********For instance, Carillon Importers Ltd., a unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. that markets Stolichnaya vodka, has redesigned its site on the World Wide Web for the holidays. The site (http://www.stoli.com) permits computer users to send electronic greeting cards called Stoli Notes; for each cybernaut who logs on and sends a greeting, Carillon will donate a dollar to the Literacy Volunteers of America. **********"We didn't feel it necessary to do something spectacular," said Robert Manni, group account director at Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners in New York, the Stolichnaya agency. **********However, he added, the Internet project "isn't being done in place of a spectacular; we're doing it in conjunction with what works on our Web site, which is interactivity, fun and entertainment." **********Margeotes/Fertitta is also running colorful, full-page magazine ads for Stolichnaya, featuring works by Yuri Gorbachev, a Russian artist. Those are meant to "create a warm, folksy feel for the brand," Mr. Manni said, as a kind of holiday card in print; many of the graphic elements on the Web site are borrowed from the print ads, he added. **********Among those likely to be most despondent about the missing spectaculars are the advertising sales executives at the magazines where they have most frequently appeared. But at least one publisher maintained that she and her staff were "definitely not throwing ourselves out the window." **********"Spectaculars make a statement and make advertisers stand apart," said Amy R. Churgin, the publisher of New York magazine, which is owned by the K-III Communications Corporation. "They're units that have what we call 'the wow factor.' **********"But companies are probably rethinking them because they like to try something new," she added. **********Several marketers, in categories like distilled spirits, financial services and retailing, are working on "smarter, more interactive" types of spectaculars for 1996, Ms. Churgin said. And, in another change, she added, they probably will eschew the holiday season and choose times of the year when spectaculars were less expected.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/23/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Caspian Caviar Crisis: Killing Too ManyFish; Free Markets, Fewer Sturgeon
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/23/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Caspian Caviar Crisis: Killing Too ManyFish; Free Markets, Fewer Sturgeon
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/23/busin.body_text: **********The 10 little jars of glistening black sturgeon eggs in Tofiq's refrigerator  reflect the bleak future of the world's caviar industry. **********Twenty miles east of here is the Caspian Sea, where the sturgeon live and 95  percent of the black caviar that adorns appetizer plates around the world is produced. Until the 1991 Soviet breakup, Bank was Azerbaijan's caviar center, where sturgeon fishing was carefully regulated, and eggs were canned under state inspection in the local factory. **********Today, however, with the collapse of state control, illegal fishing has ravaged the Caspian sturgeon population, and traders like Tofiq have come to dominate the caviar trade. **********Post-Soviet upheaval led to chaos in the Caspian region's caviar industry, the most important after oil. Despite the industry's dominance in the world market, experts say it is fading and are urging emergency measures to save it. **********In just the last five years, the sturgeon population has plunged from 200 million to fewer than 60 million, according to a Russian Government estimate. **********Before the collapse of the Soviet Union, it and Iran were the sole nations on the sea, and they obeyed strict quotas. Sturgeon fishing was banned on the sea itself; to catch the mighty schools of sturgeon, fishermen fixed nets across Russia's Volga, Azerbaijan's Kura and Kazakhstan's Ural rivers, and caught them as they swam to spawn. **********These days, the affable Tofiq, 26, buys caviar straight from the boat, adds salt, scoops it into red jars indistinguishable from official containers and resells it to black-market exporters. From there, the jars ultimately reach speciality shops in the United States, Europe and Russia. **********"If someone wants 100 jars, I can make them; all I need is an order," Tofiq said, removing a 3.6-ounce sample from his home refrigerator. "Pasteurization is not necessary. **********"Sometimes, if I have a large order of 100 or 200 jars, I take my caviar to the factory. They process it in about five minutes," said Tofiq, who asked that  his last name not be used. "But that is the only time the factory is working." **********Azerbaijan alone exported an average of 15 tons of caviar a year, mostly from Bank, which abuts the Kura; 1926 was the bumper year, with 550 tons exported, according to state figures. The Bank factory sent two-pound caviar salamis wrapped in white cloth to Stalin, state officials said, and exported 110-pound barrels of the black eggs to London retailers. **********The breakup four years ago, however, produced five Caspian states -- Azerbaijan, Iran, Kazakhstan, Russia and Turkmenistan -- which have failed to enforce the restrictions. **********Today, almost all fishing is done indiscriminately on the sea, before the sturgeon spawn. Specialists say this practice, along with pollution from petrochemical plants, oil and raw sewage, have been the key reasons for the sturgeon's decline. Another culprit has been a natural rise in the level of the  Caspian, where the sturgeon live 12 to 18 years before they spawn. **********The sea has risen 3 feet in the last decade, enough that the Kura River no longer descends rapidly into the Caspian. Some experts predict another 10-foot rise within a decade. **********Already, the water has submerged two sturgeon hatcheries near here that had released 10 million fish a year into the sea. Silt now almost blocks the Kura from meeting the sea, and sturgeon from reaching their traditional spawning grounds. **********Exacerbated by the construction of hydroelectric dams, some breeding grounds  have also been lost on the Russian Volga, Europe's longest river and the source of most Caspian caviar. **********"Every day the supply of sturgeon declines, and declines fast," Tariel Mamedli, Azerbaijan's deputy fisheries minister, said in the Azerbaijan capital  of Baku. "It can't go on long. We have to take fast measures or lose it. We'll lose everything in five years." **********Local fishermen and wholesalers themselves continue to inflict much damage. No one regulates how they produce or process caviar, and Western specialists say one result has been a decline in the freshness and general quality of some exports. **********By custom, fishermen here bonk their catch on the head, cut the fish open alive and scoop the caviar out. The fish is set aside for the market, and the caviar washed, weighed and sorted. **********In past years, the caviar was then sent to the local factory. There, it was put into jars, sealed with official steel caps and pasteurized by immersion in a 140-degree water bath for two and a half hours. Finally, it was refrigerated at  35 degrees, and sent to Russia for export. **********Rafael Jalelov, a manager at the old state caviar factory, said this process  yielded an eight-month shelf life. **********Today, Bank's busy, unregulated caviar market retains only the intrigue of the old Soviet Union, with sellers using a comical, surreptitious ritual, as though in the drug trade. **********Shifty-looking men sidle up behind buyers in muddy corner lots, where people  sell squirming fish and headless ducks. "Do you want caviar?" they whisper. **********In one such lot, a man pulled out from under his overcoat a pint-size jar wrapped in newspaper. It contained a slimy substance, caviar, but evidently not  extracted from a live sturgeon. He asked for the equivalent of $30. **********Such men make up the low end of Bank's caviar market. The high end -- those who control exports abroad -- is represented by a tough, officially tolerated mafia, local traders said. **********Traders like Tofiq represent the main, middle range, people who sell caviar from their backyards, often to mafia figures. **********At today's rates, Tofiq buys caviar from local fishermen for $20 a pound, and a local maker provides the jars and lids. Tofiq then charges $8 for a 3.6-ounce  jar -- a 78 percent markup. **********In Moscow, such jars go for $60; in New York, the retail price can be $75. **********Tofiq reckoned that he and his neighbors sell about a ton of caviar a month,  or enough for about 8,000 standard 4-ounce jars -- a credible figure, considering Soviet-era production. But the local take is relatively small, so traders like Tofiq do not think much about the impact of overfishing. **********"All my neighbors do it," he said, tossing a two-by-four at two dogs sniffing around a gutted sturgeon that a fisherman has brought by motorcycle. "You have to make a living."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/02/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Brazil's President Prevailing Despite Disruptive Oil Strike
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/02/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Brazil's President Prevailing Despite Disruptive Oil Strike
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/02/busin.body_text: **********At dawn, drivers start lining up here for scarce gasoline. In shantytowns, residents boil coffee over backyard cooking fires. At the gleaming new international airport, travelers pack into planes as airlines cut flights to cope with fuel shortages. **********Brazil's longest oil strike in history is strangling South America's largest  city, so why is Brazil's new President smiling? **********For one thing, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso has faced his first major strike, and won. The strike is not officially over, but it is crumbling. Oil workers straggled back to work today without a contract, and production at state oil refineries stood at 63 percent and rising. **********In a test of wills, the oil workers had threatened to derail the nation's anti-inflation program. Had they won pay increases above the inflation rate, other unions would have demanded equal treatment. **********Instead, the failed strike proved to be a fiasco for the left. In May, two calls for general strikes went unheeded. The left, in particular the Workers Party, which is aligned with a confederation of public-employee unions, gambled  that Mr. Cardoso, a sociologist and former exile, would buckle under pressure. Instead, he sent troops last week to occupy four refineries, helping restore production. **********Mr. Cardoso is also smiling because the strikers played neatly into his plans to push a package through Congress of market-oriented constitutional amendments. **********As the shadow lengthened from the monthlong strike by employees of Petrobras, the state oil company, the Chamber of Deputies, Brazil's lower house of Parliament, approved amendments that abolished the state telephone monopoly, erased discrimination against foreign companies, allowed private companies to sell piped natural gas, and opened the 5,000-mile Atlantic coastline to foreign  cruise ships and freighters. **********"The strike increased political support for breaking the monopolies," said Walder de Goes, a political scientist in Brasilia and president of the Brazilian Institute of Political Studies. "It showed the public how risky it is to have a  state monopoly in something so essential as oil." **********Mr. de Goes, who surveys Congressional attitudes, believes that when the lower house votes on Wednesday, it will approve the most controversial item of the free-market package -- allowing foreign companies to drill for oil in Brazil. The Senate, more tightly controlled by the governing coalition, is expected to ratify all measures the deputies approve by July. **********Breaking the phone monopoly is expected to pave the way for as much as $10 billion in foreign telecommunications investment by the end of the decade. Ending discrimination against foreign investors, such as the prohibition of majority ownership in mining operations, is expected to open the door to privatization next year of the huge state mining company, a sale expected to fetch about $15 billion. **********The rapid-fire series of congressional votes is making Brazil's left sound notes of desperation. Leonel Brizola, who spent 15 years in exile after a coup in 1964, said last week, "If there is not a popular civilian reaction, there will inevitably be a military action, because the military are traditionally nationalists." **********Orestes Quercia, a former governor of Sao Paulo state, said here on Sunday, "This Government is promoting the breaking of monopolies in an irresponsible way, with the goal of selling the nation's patrimony for small change." **********Sensing that a 50-year tradition of state companies is quickly slipping away, union leaders have assailed Mr. Cardoso, and there has been some violence. Last  week, in a northeastern city, protesters stoned the President's bus, smashing three windows and slightly injuring two aides. **********But, with public opinion polls backing the President, his free-market drive continues unabated. Inaugurating a public service concessions law, the Government in May privatized a highway, a major bridge and a hydroelectric dam project. In the second half of the year, 17 companies are to be sold, largely electricity and petrochemical concerns. **********Bolstering Mr. Cardoso's standing, Brazil's inflation for the first six months of the year is expected to be 10 percent -- the lowest rate for a six-month period in more than 20 years. Despite a trade deficit and an overvalued currency, foreign confidence is returning to Brazil for the first time since the outbreak of the Mexican financial crisis. **********In April, stock markets recorded the first inflow of foreign investment since November. Last week, the Government sold $916 million of securities denominated  in yen. **********Economic growth is expected to be 6 percent this year, down from 10.5 percent in the first three months alone. With most economists predicting continued growth through the rest of the decade, a series of companies announced investments here last month. Procter & Gamble is to build a $100 million factory near here; Cargill is to invest $300 million, and Brazil's newly privatized steel industry plans $6 billion in investments through 1999. **********John Mein, vice president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Sao Paulo, said investors seemed to be waiting for the constitutional amendments to take effect. "Then," he said, "we will see a major increase in investments in Brazil, especially in areas previously not open to international investors."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/04/busin.main_headline: Home-Grown Capitalism Delivers the Wide World of Sports to RussianFans
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/04/busin.print_headline: Home-Grown Capitalism Delivers the Wide World of Sports to RussianFans
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/04/busin.body_text: **********In 1990, Vladimir Titorenko was a leading writer for the national sports daily in Russia, Sovetskii Sport. But as he began to write positive reports about the National Basketball Association, he faced increasing disapproval from  hard-line editors, who were more interested in pushing coverage of the Olympic sports favored by the state: track and field, weight lifting and archery. **********The deputy director of Sovetskii Sport, Vladimir Kuchmi, had been experiencing similar frustration. So that spring he raised the idea of starting  a politically independent sports daily and invited Mr. Titorenko to join him. **********In July 1991, a few weeks before the inept hard-line coup that marked the beginning of the end of the old Soviet Union, 12 of Sovetskii Sport's most popular writers left en masse to start the new paper. They were taking a huge personal and professional risk. Sovetskii Sport was not just the most popular sports daily, it was the country's only sports daily. **********To distinguish the new paper from Sovetskii Sport, its founders promised to emphasize sports with the largest audiences -- soccer, hockey and basketball --  and relegate the more obscure sports to occasional articles. The quest seemed hopeless. But today their paper, Sport Ekspress, is one of the most successful dailies in Russia, with a circulation well above 800,000. **********While the editors are reluctant to discuss financial details, they say that most issues sell out and that the daily rate for a full-page advertisement is $24,000 -- though, like their Western counterparts, they offer discounts to good customers. **********"Our reasons for quitting were not simply political but professional," said Mr. Kuchmi, 46, who is editor in chief of Sport Ekspress. "Sovetskii Sport was a small newspaper, only four pages. One page was official party news, another physical culture. A third was articles pirated from the foreign press. There was only one page of sports news for fans: one page for journalists to work in a normal professional manner." **********Sport Ekspress began publishing three days before the August coup. Mr. Kuchmi had used personal sources to get a low-interest six-month loan of three million  rubles ($160,000) from the Commercial-Industrial Bank of the Russian Republic. The founders bought computers, telephones and newsprint and started to work in one another's kitchens. **********Their goal was to deliver accurate and timely information about popular sports from a broadly international perspective, but the lack of wire services,  coupled with the Soviet Union's inadequate telephone system, made acquiring any  information, domestic or foreign, an arduous business. **********No one received wages for the first six months. "We were fortunate each of us had friends who were able to help us," said the deputy editor, Vladimir Geskin,  42, who like Mr. Kuchmi spent more than 20 years at Sovetskii Sport. **********Yelena Vaitsekhovskaya, the assistant editor and a former Olympic diving champion, recalled the first days. "We knew only how to write articles, but nothing about production, advertising or distribution," she said.Still, the founders were able to publish 20,000 copies of a four-page paper five times a week. It was delivered from the trunk of Mr. Kuchmi's car to whatever newsstands would take it. **********They immediately found an audience, and circulation increased rapidly. Mr. Kuchmi said he paid back the bank loan in three months. **********Advertising took longer to expand. As Soviet mores disappeared, ads for bookies and phone sex began to appear in Sport Ekspress. But eventually they gave way to lucrative displays for large Western and Russian companies selling everything from cigarettes and coffee to athletic shoes and computers. **********Still, Vsevolod Kukushkin, the paper's business director, had to reorient a certain Russian literalness concerning advertising. "Not everyone understood what it meant to advertise in a paper like Sport Ekspress," he said. "Someone would say, 'We sell computers, but you are not a computer newspaper.' Well, we are not a computer newspaper, but aren't people who buy computers also interested in soccer and hockey?" **********It didn't hurt to be lucky. "We'd published for three days when the coup began," Mr. Kuchmi said. "All newspapers were closed down, but I was so obsessed I forgot the danger. Our printing plant was surrounded by troops, but I begged a soldier to let me pass with our layouts. He could have shot me, but he waved me  by." **********In the post-Soviet era, circulation and advertising expanded rapidly. The paper grew to eight pages, and the staff grew to more than 200. Permanent headquarters were secured in a small apartment in downtown Moscow. But by late 1994, Mr. Kuchmi said, "We had exhausted the technical possibilities available to us." **********"We were 8 pages, but we knew we could grow to 16," he continued. "We needed  more phones, wire services, correspondents and computers." **********So they formed a privately held company and sold 51 percent of its newly created stock to the French sports daily L'Equipe for an undisclosed sum. The founding editors retained 49 percent of the shares. **********Sport Ekspress used the new capital to build a modern office in an otherwise  dingy building not far from Tverskaya Street, one of Moscow's main thoroughfares. **********Using a combination of sophisticated (computers for the production process) and primitive (typewriters and pencils for the writing and editing) technology,  the paper is published five days a week. Advertising occupies one-fourth to one-third of the available space. **********After four years, Sport Ekspress has begun to generate solid profits, its editors say. Journalistically, however, it has yet to find its own voice. Many of its practices are overreactions to the perversities of Soviet journalism, which featured a lack of up-to-date information and a preference for opinion over news. Afraid of putting words in their subjects' mouths, the editors structure virtually every article -- whether a game report or an analysis -- as  an interview. **********Nonetheless, Sport Ekspress has clearly found an audience, though its editors realize that the paper's independence is a byproduct of its financial success. **********"We understand we are a capitalist enterprise," Mr. Kukushkin said. "Our future is tied to the future of Russia's business sector."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/04/busin.main_headline: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;Answer to This Problem Is Not in a Textbook
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/04/busin.print_headline: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;Answer to This Problem Is Not in a Textbook
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/04/busin.body_text: **********THE 12-by-16-inch wooden slab that constituted my desk this spring was dwarfed in both size and significance by the international banks I was studying. Once a week after work I joined hundreds of New York bank employees at the American Institute of Banking, where we would slip into the humble furniture of  adult education to learn the rules of the financial system. This term we had firsthand experience of an institutional tolerance for cheating. **********Ten minutes into our midterm in international banking operations, a young woman sitting in the front row pulled out her textbook and began flipping through it. The teacher had not stayed to monitor us, and thus, he did not see the incident that would eventually riddle the class with anger, distrust, self-pity, xenophobia, complicity and cynicism. **********The moment the student began searching through her textbook, the 20 other scribblers looked up, eyebrows shot up -- and, most shockingly, the hands of two students shot down into bookbags to pull out their textbooks. Then the tense silence was broken by the click of the door. In walked the teacher. **********He strolled in front of the blackboard a while before his eyes fell on the open textbook. "Close that book," he said quietly. He evinced no sign of the outrage I was feeling. The student closed it. He left the room. Not five minutes went by before she reopened the book. **********Because I once was a teacher, I allied myself with authority and spoke up: "Is this an open-book exam?" The students regarded me, then hid deeper into their work. "Does anybody think this is an open-book exam?" I asked more forcefully, staring hard at the young woman. She turned to me, and I said, "Excuse me, but that offends me." **********"Why?" she shrugged. "I forgot some answers." Her benign expression said I was the misguided one. **********"It's called cheating!" grumbled a gruff voice from the back. Then a another  woman spoke to her in their native tongue, clearly to reprimand her. She closed  the text. **********All this occurred in about 15 minutes, but the debate that followed still rumbles among the students and possibly in the administration of the American Institute of Banking, which is the educational arm of the American Bankers Association. I spoke to the teacher as I left the classroom the evening of the midterm, and he appeared concerned but noncommittal about any course of action.  I also called the school to ask about its policy on cheating, only to be told that it depended on the individual teacher. To which one can only respond: "Does bank robbery depend upon the individual bank?" **********When we reconvened the following week, a few students expressed frustration that their complaints to the teacher and the school were met with mild surprise and marked indifference. I was surprised by the apparent quandary of the teacher as he spoke to us at the beginning of that class. He addressed us as a group of malefactors; the woman who had cheated sat in the first row as unflappable as ever. **********He expressed three concerns: that we could not be trusted when he was out of  the room; that we ought to consider how we would feel if our own children cheated, and that the test was a standardized one, which the school had designed to be fair. **********Although he was addressing a classroom of working adults, ages roughly 30 to  50, he used a patronizing tone. His whole approach gave rise to a new outrage -- namely, that we were all lumped together with this witless cheater. **********There seemed to be no contemplation of punishment, just a lot of finger-wagging. I was not the only one annoyed, and a group of us gathered outside after class arguing about it. The initial fury at the cheater was soon directed at the teacher -- and at that large target, The System. **********Several students felt the exam had been unfair and that we had not been properly prepared. Though this view is arguable, there was a comprehensive textbook, so the teacher really couldn't be blamed. **********The text, maintained one student, was written in a dense style and was far too complex for the foreign students to whom English is a second language. But the school is called the "American" Institute of Banking, so it could reasonably be expected to teach and test in English. **********The teacher's English, his second language, was horrendous and could hardly be understood, said several students. True, but I never heard these students asking him if he really meant "the Fed" when he said "the bed." And the test was not based on the lectures but on the book. I think ignorance of English is a shoddy excuse for cheating and reinforces dangerous prejudices. We don't really  think the ethics of the developing nations look like their balances of payments, do we? **********Another student whined about banks that reimburse tuition on the basis of grades: an A earned 100 percent reimbursement, a B only 80 percent, etc. Combined with the low pay at the foreign banks, the economic imperative for cheating gained a few fans. So is it O.K. to take money from the till at the end of the day because your pay is too low? **********What bothered me most, however, was my fellow students' gradual consensus that cheating is indeed part and parcel of banking, if not schooling. While several were initially outraged at the idea of cheating on a test, mention of Wall Street's more notorious cheats allowed us to settle into cynicism. Why should the institute be less tolerant of cheating than the institutions it's training us for? **********Thus the cheater was slowly exonerated by specious but steady rationalization. **********By the time we took our places for the final exam, I feared most students were prepared to cheat their way through it. Perhaps the teacher also thought so; he took his place in front of the class and bent an eagle eye upon us. But the young woman didn't show up for the final. Without her, we had no scapegoat for bad behavior. The exam stretched through two intense and muffled hours. I doubt that anybody had an opportunity to cheat, and since that was what had obsessed us, it was easy to feel cheated in the end.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/busin.body_text: **********The Quaker State Corporation said today that it had agreed to pay $4.4 million to settle a lawsuit that it was part of an oil industry price-fixing conspiracy. **********Quaker State, a producer of motor oil and lubricants based in Irving, said it was one of three companies that were the targets of a 1994 class-action suit brought by producers of Penn Grade crude, an oil that yields products ranging from engine lubricants to food additives. **********The producers, most of whom operate in Pennsylvania and neighboring states,  contended that Quaker State, the Pennzoil Company and the Witco Corporation had  violated Federal antitrust laws by conspiring for 14 years to fix prices at several dollars less than what producers say they need to be profitable.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/world.main_headline: Clinton Gets Wary Backing From His Rival, Dole
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/world.print_headline: BALKAN ACCORD: THE DEBATECAPITOL SKETCHBOOK; Clinton Gets Wary Backing From His Rival, Dole
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/world.body_text: **********Only hours before President Clinton departed for the signing of the Bosnian peace agreement in Paris, Senator Bob Dole sought to ease his mission. He reached back 25 years in history and recalled the furious Senate debates over the Vietnam War and the issue of supporting American troops and their Commander  in Chief. **********The Kansas Republican and Senate majority leader presented one of the more arresting moments in the inevitable overlap of foreign policy and domestic politics: Mr. Dole, the scarred war hero, considered the front-runner to challenge Mr. Clinton in 1996, offering wary backing to a President regularly dogged for not serving in Vietnam. **********Long debates, rancorous debates, heated debates," Mr. Dole said today, recalling Vietnam on a spirited day of dispute over Bosnia. Crafting clauses, sizing up votes, the Senator was intent on delivering a qualified Senate blessing to the President's Bosnian initiative. At the same time, he was holding off a significant bloc of members who were as vocal as the critics in the old Vietnam days in wanting no part of putting 20,000 American troops at risk as peacekeepers in Bosnia. **********"We had one debate that lasted seven weeks," he told a chamber that had little more than 12 hours to come to terms with the President's action on Bosnia. "And I was the leader of the effort not to cut off funds because we had  people like John McCain in prison," Senator Dole said of the Vietnam war hero and Senator from Arizona. The nation's military, he cautioned in retrospect, should never bear the brunt of unpopular political decisions. **********"It was wrong during Vietnam, and it's wrong now," Mr. Dole insisted, nudging the Senate toward approval of the Dole-McCain resolution, which would support the President's Bosnian effort but try to reshape it in the name of better protecting the troops and insuring peace by fully arming the Bosnian faction. **********The conflict of proposals for and against going to Bosnia presented as much a test of Mr. Dole's leadership as the President's. Only weeks from the formal start of campaigning for 1996, the rivals were, briefly at least, on oddly parallel tracks in a debate that reflected the full range of the public's doubt  about the mission. **********"This is a goofy proposal to send American troops to stand in between warring factions that have been at war for 500 years and never honored a peace agreement," warned Senator Hank Brown, a Colorado Republican who cited American  troops' experiences in Vietnam, Lebanon and Somalia. "C'mon now, does anybody believe the cause of interfering in civil war is important enough that they should lose their lives?" **********Far to the contrary, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, New York Democrat, rose as a former representative to the United Nations to hail the Bosnian mission as  a "rousing statement of the centrality of law" and the upholding of treaty commitments by the Government. "We are responding today to what we have learned  from the past," he said, reviewing history from the ideals of the founding fathers to the darkest lessons of two world wars. **********Standing somewhere between was William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, who criticized Congress for yielding its constitutional responsibility for war powers to the White House across the years of ethnic atrocity in Bosnia. Looking ahead to the coming political year, he warned that the President's failure to seek stronger Congressional support sooner could prove crucial when casualties occur and the resolve to continue the mission flags. "Unless you have Congress on record in support," he said, "when the public turns, the Congress will be in  full pursuit." **********Many speakers sought to support American troops yet criticize the President.  But Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Connecticut Democrat, warned, "We cannot support the troops and oppose the mission." **********Senator James M. Inhofe, Oklahoma Republican, said, "I don't think we can tell the good guys from the bad guys," and argued that the troops would be wide  open to terrorist attacks. Mark O. Hatfield, Oregon Republican, scoffed at Administration assurances about avoiding battle. "We are going into Bosnia with  an army," he said, "And we are going to force the peace." **********If nothing else, the debate laid bare the multi-edged domestic politics of the Bosnian issue. Mr. Dole carefully drew distinctions with Mr. Clinton, saying his Senate resolution insures not just the arms for Bosnia that he had long sought over the President's opposition, but also a more "timely and safe withdrawal" of the troops than Mr. Clinton planned. **********"Let's be clear: a date is not an exit strategy," Mr. Dole declared, even as  his primary Republican rival, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, was setting his sights on Mr. Dole. **********"I am concerned about the Dole amendment," Mr. Gramm said, arguing that arming the Bosnians would shred American neutrality. **********Mr. Dole paid no heed. "This is not about politics," he told the Senate, adding that "this is about a lot of frightened young Americans" arriving in Bosnia and asking one question of their homeland: "Did we have the support of those who represent us?"

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/06/busin.body_text: **********Soybean prices surged on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as concern grew that a lack of rain was harming Brazil's crop, the world's second largest. **********Wheat prices also rose strongly on concerns over low rainfall. The Commodity  Research Bureau index of 21 commodities gained 1.03 points, to 244.09. **********Soybeans for January delivery soared 9.75 cents, to $7.0275 a bushel at the  Chicago Board of Trade, the highest since June 17, 1994. **********"It's all weather here," Victor Lespinasse, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds in Chicago, said. "That's what pushed us up." **********Dry conditions in the Brazilian states of Rio Grande do Sul, the largest soybean growing region, and Parana have slowed planting this year and threatened to halt germination of seeds already in the ground. As of Nov. 23, only 54 percent of the crop was planted, down from 64 percent a year ago, the Safras & Mercado agricultural newsletter said. **********Little relief is on the horizon. A high-pressure ridge is building over Brazil's southern regions, locking out rainfall and lifting temperatures as high as 100 degrees Fahrenheit. **********Brazil is expected to produce 835.9 million bushels of soybeans in 1996, down 10.4 percent from 1995, according to the newsletter. **********A smaller crop in Brazil would compound the losses this year in the United States, where the harvest was down 13 percent from last year. **********Wheat prices rose on concern that low rainfall in Kansas, Texas and Oklahoma  was stunting development of the winter wheat crop. Only 49 percent of American winter wheat fields were in good to excellent condition last week, the Agriculture Department said Monday, down from 52 percent a week earlier. **********March wheat rose 10.25 cents, to $4.98 a bushel at the Chicago Board of Trade.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/05/busin.print_headline: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;Getting Paid for Living Vicariously
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/05/busin.body_text: **********Q. Can you suggest a simple business that my husband and I, both retired, and in our 60's, can start from home?    Gale Osgood    St. Louis **********A. A 1973 syndicated newspaper cartoon says it all: A husband, surrounded by suitcases on the doorstep, is about to put the key in the lock when he turns to  his wife and says, "The most exciting part of our vacation is coming home and discovering which part of the house has been flooded, collapsed or burglarized." **********A desire to prevent that kind of "excitement" must have given rise to the house-sitting service, which has become a pay-as-you-go business ideally suited  for senior citizens interested in supplementing their retirement incomes. **********Jane Poston, who at 72 is a Mother Superior of the nascent senior home-sitting business, says, "Today's new homeowner may have no family living nearby and often won't know the neighbors well enough to impose on them." **********Nor can one always depend on neighborhood teen-agers for hire. "Reliability is critical," Ms. Poston explains, "and retirees tend to be very reliable." **********For many who swear by it, house-sitting can represent a chance to live vicariously, occasionally on some wealthy person's estate or ranch. Some even look on these assignments as "paid vacations." **********Senior citizens are ideal in that there is little "heavy lifting." Previous experience in household management, though, is taken for granted. "At the very least, home sitters should know how to reactivate a circuit breaker, replace a fuse, reset a thermostat and open the electric garage door," says Paul Sauer, 57, a former biochemist who 22 years ago founded Denver's Homewatch Corporation  (800 777-9770). Subsequently, he branched out into other areas (the company is now in 27 cities in 6 states), offered franchises ($18,500 a territory) and added ancillary services, like home pet care, handyman work and nonmedical companion care. **********Ms. Poston, a former high school English teacher and Peace Corps volunteer, ran the Tucson, Ariz.-based House Sitter Security Service for 20 years before retiring herself and selling her business. Her 41-page soup-to-nuts manual, "How to Run a House-Sitting Business" ($38 by mail from 1708 East 9th Street, Tucson, Ariz., 85719, or by calling 520 884-8530), is now in its third printing and has  been ordered in bulk from as far away as Saudi Arabia, "where one homeowner required the sitter to take care of a hooded falcon and an Arabian steed." **********Most house-sitting is done by individuals, most of whom carry no liability insurance, are not bonded and rely on referrals rather than advertising, maybe to escape the attention of the tax collector. Tax officials are often aware of who is doing what in the nation's underground economy, but may choose to overlook a few senior citizens working part time to make ends meet. **********House-sitting is not necessarily a penny-ante profession. One Long Island house sitter describes her post-retirement work as "extremely lucrative." Last year, she cleared an untaxed $48,000, most of it from jobs paying $25 an hour." **********Nor does "house-sitting" necessarily mean actually moving into someone else's home, though many homeowners do request 24-hour service. More often than not, users are satisfied with either a "drive by" (to make sure that no windows or locks are broken and that the mail hasn't piled up on the stoop) or "drop in" (to inspect the interiors and water the plants). A number of customers order overnight service, requiring sleep-ins. Most of the established outfits offer a  Chinese menu of basic house-sitting services, insist on contracts, ask for partial payment in advance (vacationers have been known to return broke) and charge per service for extras like pool cleaning, lawn mowing and pet care. **********Costs vary considerably, depending on what kind of service is requested, where one lives and what has to be watched. One of Mr. Sauer's Virginia franchises has gone from house-sitting to boat-sitting, and charges accordingly. Even among the entrepreneurs, there are daily and hourly rates, bulk discounts, and mileage allowances for car travel. **********Who makes the best house-sitters? "What we're selling," Mr. Sauer of Homewatch says, "are men and women with the experience, maturity, sense of responsibility, most of whom have gone through disasters and know instinctively  what to do in case of an emergency." Not surprisingly, Ms. Poston thinks women over 50 do. "They know more about taking care of houses than anyone else. They are comfortable to stay at home, and they instinctively ask the right questions  before settling in." Like the name and number of the plumber, electrician and all the other service people. **********A busy house-sitter will often farm out jobs to others. Because each home is  unique, as are its owners, putting together the right sitter for the right clients can make house-sitting similar to running a dating service, Ms. Poston adds. "You need to make sure that the petite, 100-pound sitter isn't suddenly confronted with having to walk a 200-pound St. Bernard," which is precisely what happened to her in the early days. A house sitter with as much experience as Ms. Poston will also deftly handle the occasional odd job, like spoonfeeding a high-strung Afghan hound chocolate chip ice cream -- the only thing that would calm him during a week of terrifying thunderstorms. **********Questions about investing, careers and personal finance can be sent to Minding Your Business, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York 10036. Or they can be sent by E-mail to yourmind@nytimes.com. Questions can be answered only in the column, not by mail, E-mail or telephone.
