https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/25/busin.print_headline: Deal Planned to Sell Maker of Newsprint
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/25/busin.body_text: **********Donohue Inc. said over the weekend that it had agreed to buy the Quno Corporation, a newsprint maker, for $1.1 billion (Canadian), or $809.9 million (United States) in cash and stock. **********The acquisition by Donohue, which produces newsprint, lumber and pulp, would  create the third-biggest newsprint maker in North America, with about $1.37 billion (Canadian) in sales, based on 1994 revenue. **********Quno, based in St. Catherines, Ontario, was put up for sale in September, when the Tribune Company, the Chicago-based media company, said it wanted to sell its 53 percent stake. **********Donohue, based in Quebec, will pay $30.50 (Canadian) a share in cash, notes and shares of Donohue for each of Quno's 36.17 million shares, the companies said. **********Tribune, which owns 34 percent of Quno's common stock plus debt that can be converted into stock, agreed to sell its stake. Tribune's after-tax proceeds from the sale will be about $330 million (United States), the company said. Tribune also will own 6 percent of Donohue after the deal is completed in the first quarter. **********Quno, formerly the Quebec and Ontario Paper Company, was a wholly owned unit  of Tribune before an initial public offering in 1993.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/03/world.main_headline: Clinton Seeks to Shore Up Muslim-Croat Federation
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/03/world.print_headline: Clinton Seeks to Shore Up Muslim-Croat Federation
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/03/world.body_text: **********On the second day of Balkan peace talks here, the outlines of the Clinton Administration's strategy are already clear: strengthen the Muslim-Croat federation and seek to oust the separatist Bosnian Serb leadership as a means to cement the fragile unity of the single Bosnian state envisaged in any peace agreement. **********A statement issued today by the State Department said the Bosnian President,  Alija Izetbegovic, and the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, had agreed on steps to shore up the tenous federation brokered last year by the United States. **********The federation, whose creation stopped the 1993 war between Muslims and Croats, recently came under acute pressure when a Muslim-Croat offensive in western Bosnia last September turned into a race for territory between the two armies that twice degenerated into fighting between them. **********Under the accord, about 300 Muslim families are to return to two towns, Jajce and Stolac, that are controlled by the Croats. At the same time, 300 Croat families are to return to two central Bosnian towns, Travnik and Bugojno, controlled by the Muslim-led Government. Up to now, mutual suspicions have prevented such returns of refugee families. **********The federation is viewed as critical by United States officials because, without it, Bosnia would disintegrate altogether. The Croats control about 22 percent of Bosnia and their strong inclination is to govern this territory directly from Zagreb rather than work with the Sarajevo Government. **********The overall peace plan presented here today to the Presidents of Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia calls for the establishment of several centralized institutions, including a presidency and a parliament, and for what Secretary of State Warren Christopher on Wednesday called a Bosnian state "with a single international personality." **********But at the same time it envisages splitting the country roughly in half between a Muslim-Croat federation and a republic of Serbs. **********The Serbs, who have fought since 1992 to establish their own state in Bosnia  and now control about 48 percent of the country, have told American officials that they want the central Bosnian institutions to amount to no more than "a paper roof." **********It is this tension -- between the centralized unitary state sought by the Bosnian Government of President Izetbegovic and the very loose union that might  open the way to eventual secession sought by the Serbs -- that lies at the heart of the peace talks. It is by no means clear that the diplomatic acrobatics of the chief American mediator, Richard C. Holbrooke, can resolve it. **********Mr. Christopher made clear in a television interview broadcast today that the United States expects Radovan Karadzic and Gen. Ratko Mladic, the political and  military leaders of the Bosnian Serbs who have been indicted by an international tribual in The Hague as war criminals, to be ousted in the very near future. **********This statement amounted to by far the boldest demand yet made by the Clinton  Administration for the removal of two men who would certainly work determinedly  to insure that Bosnia is irrevocably split in two. **********"We can't really expect that forces of NATO would be there at the same time as these individuals are in positions of power," Mr. Christopher said. **********Because a NATO force, including at least 20,000 American soldiers, is expected to go to Bosnia almost immediately after any peace agreement, this statement suggested that the Clinton Administration now wants the two men removed within weeks. This demand appeared to reflect the impact on the Administration of recent Serbian massacres of Muslims in Srebrenica and northwestern Bosnia. **********Up to now, however, President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia has only offered to work for the removal of Dr. Karadzic through elections that would take place within the next year, Western officials said. **********Thus considerable new pressure is being applied to Mr. Milosevic and it appears by no means clear that his response will be positive. The Serbian President heads a delegation that includes three senior Bosnian Serb officials. **********The aim of the American policy seems clear: open the way for Bosnia to be knitted together again by removing the men most identified with its division. But the risks are considerable, for the two men have solid bands of highly armed supporters with little to lose. **********Nicholas Burns, a State Department spokesman, said the three delegations were today handed four draft documents of an eventual peace. He said the papers included what he called "the general peace agreement" -- covering the overall terms of an accord -- and separate papers on the organization of elections, constitutional issues, and the separation of military and paramilitary forces. **********The documents were mainly drafted by the State Department and the team working with Mr. Holbrooke. But they were reviewed by delegations from Russia and the European Union. Other documents, on issues like economic reconstruction, are still under review. **********Apart from the highly contentious issue of territory, and particularly the status of Sarajevo, the question of elections is also a highly charged one, officials said. **********Apart from their objections to any role for Mr. Karadzic and General Mladic,  the Bosnian delegation wants the central parliament to be elected by direct, popular vote. The Serbs want its members to be appointed by the respective parliaments of the Muslim-Croat federation and the Serb republic in order to insure that ethnic balance of its members is roughly even. **********In an indication that the meeting will last at least another week, the United States Ambassador to Croatia, Peter Galbraith, and a European mediator, Thorvald Stoltenberg, were sent today to eastern Slavonia, the one remaining Serb-held area of Croatia. They are to return to Dayton in about a week. **********Mr. Tudjman and Mr. Milosevic agreed on Wednesday to work "toward full normalization of relations" between Croatia and Serbia, but no accord was reached on the fate of eastern Slavonia. Mr. Tudjman, who is to leave Dayton today and return next week, said recently that Croatia would take the area by force or negotiation by the end of the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/04/world.main_headline: For American Press in Canada, a Simpson Free-For-All It's Not
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/04/world.print_headline: For American Press in Canada, a Simpson Free-For-All It's Not
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/04/world.body_text: **********The judge presiding over a sensational murder trial in Toronto recently warned American journalists here that they could not only be barred from his court but that they could be charged with an offense under Canada's Criminal Code if they reported prohibited testimony. **********In an American court, as millions know who watch the sparring in the murder trial of O. J. Simpson daily from Los Angeles, little that goes on in open court is withheld from the public. **********But the restrictions imposed here by Judge Patrick LeSage in a sexual torture case that has dominated the news here the past couple of weeks places the differences in the two legal systems into sharp relief. The American emphasis on press freedom sometimes clashes with the Canadian view of restrictions required to insure a fair trial. **********Judge LeSage had been angered by a report by a Buffalo television station of  the defense counsel's call for a mistrial, made while the jury was out. **********The press can report on developments here only when the jury is present. The  panel, it is argued, might otherwise be infuenced by press interpretations of what happened in its absence. For similar reasons, the courts routinely ban news media coverage of preliminary hearings. **********The Canadian courts take these steps "to insure the jury is not polluted," said Kent Roach, a professor of criminal law at the University of Toronto. "The  inherent power to order bans is a deeply ingrained mechanism in Canada." **********Lisa Flynn, the court reporter for WKBW, the Buffalo television station covering the trial, said she was aware of the ban by Judge LeSage. She has been  commuting from Buffalo and was in Buffalo when she reported the mistrial request. **********"The position of our management is that when we're in the U.S. we don't have  to obey the Canadian laws," she said in an interview. Judge LeSage did not agree. **********"If you have any difficulty in abiding by our rules, then simply do not come  into the courtroom," he said. "Or else you will be subject to charge if you violate Canadian laws." **********Many of the grotesque details of the deaths of two teen-agers allegedly slain by Paul Bernardo that are now being described -- and even seen on videotape -- in Judge LeSage's court, were the subject of an earlier publication ban, during  the trial of Mr. Bernardo's former wife, Karla Homulka, two years ago. **********The prosecution contends that Leslie Mahaffy, 14, and Kristen French, 15, were held captive in the Bernardo house in St. Catharines, Ontario, and tortured sexually before being strangled with an electrical cord. **********Several American publications ignored another Canadian judge's publication ban in the Homulka case, and a black market developed in smuggled copies of the  illicit articles. The Canadian authorities accused the American media then of failure to respect Canadian traditions, but took no punitive action against American reporters in Canada. **********Unhappy at being muzzled, the Canadian press fought the ban, but did not succeed. **********Press freedom was not written into the Constitution here until the 1982 Charter of Rights and Freedoms, two centuries after the American First Amendment. **********The situation is summed up by another Canadian reporter covering the Bernardo trial, Barry Brown, who writes for The Buffalo News: "In the States, we sequester the jury; in Canada we sequester the public."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/06/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;GOODYEAR CHOOSES A NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;GOODYEAR CHOOSES A NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/06/busin.body_text: **********The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that Samir F. Gibara, its president and chief operating officer, would become chief executive, effective on Jan. 1. Mr. Gibara, 55, will take over from Stanley C. Gault, who is also chairman of the Akron-based tire company. Mr. Gault, 69, will remain chairman until June 30. The company's board said it intended to name Mr. Gibara chairman  next June. Mr. Gibara was named president and chief operating officer April 10. Mr. Gibara, a Harvard M.B.A. born in Cairo and fluent in several languages,  is a 30-year Goodyear veteran whose experience includes executive posts with Goodyear in Canada and Europe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/20/busin.print_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS: FUNDS WATCH; A Squeeze In Junk Bonds
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/20/busin.body_text: **********JUNK bonds are generally not attractive, with the exception of emerging-market debt, Susan Belden wrote recently in the No-Load Fund Analyst, a newsletter published in Orinda, Calif. **********The yield for unrated -- hence, junk -- bonds has been running three to four percentage points above that for 10-year Treasury notes, to account for their greater risk. Junk-bond yields now average about 10 percent, and 10-year Treasury yields are about 6.5 percent. **********But that spread is not particularly big by standards of the last decade. It is greater than in the early 1980's, before the leveraged-buyout boom, but lower than in the subsequent crash in the junk-bond market, when spreads exceeded nine percentage points. Given the risk of a recession or at least some slowdown in economic growth, junk bonds are not very appealing now, Ms. Belden concluded. **********But bonds of emerging markets -- also in the junk category -- have yields of more than 14 percent. Latin American issues could be very volatile in the short term, Ms. Belden said, but there is considerable potential for attractive long-term returns. **********For long-term investors who can ride out declines in the market, she recommends the Scudder Emerging Markets Income Fund. Too Little, Too Late? **********A majority of employed Americans believe that they will be forced to continue working after they reach retirement age, according to findings of a recent poll by Roper Starch Worldwide for Kemper Financial Services. The main reasons cited: They are not saving enough, and Social Security will not make up for the shortfall.  The poll, of 2,086 Americans, offered hints for younger workers. When asked to give advice to younger generations about saving for retirement, many retirees suggested that they start saving early and take advantage of company retirement plans.  Among all respondents, the preferred retirement saving choices were 401(k) plans, 52 percent; savings accounts, 44 percent; mutual funds, 40 percent; life insurance, 39 percent, and Keogh plans or individual retirement accounts, 39 percent. Respondents could list more than one choice.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/08/world.main_headline: World News Briefs; U.S. Moving to Extradite Man Wanted by Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/08/world.print_headline: World News Briefs; U.S. Moving to Extradite Man Wanted by Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/08/world.body_text: **********The United States plans to begin extradition proceedings this morning against a man identified as a top leader of the militant Palestinian group Hamas who is being detained in New York City, a defense lawyer said last night. **********Israeli asked the United States last week to arrest and extradite the man, Mousa Mohamed Abu Marzook, a 45-year-old Palestinian businessman, on charges he helped organize terrorist attacks in Israel. **********Mr. Abu Marzook's lawyer, Stanley L. Cohen, said the Justice Department informed him last night that the United States intends to comply with Israel's request. Today's hearing is the start of what is likely to be a lengthy legal battle. **********The United States Attorney's office in Manhattan would not comment on the hearing. Carole Florman, a spokeswoman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Washington, confirmed that the hearing "is related to a request for extradition."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/09/busin.main_headline: Worker Productivity Up, Costs Down, U.S. Reports
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/09/busin.print_headline: Worker Productivity Up, Costs Down, U.S. Reports
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/09/busin.body_text: **********Growth in worker productivity accelerated during the second quarter as more goods were produced with fewer workers, the Labor Department said today. **********Labor costs moderated, helping keep inflation under control. And the average number of hours worked fell by the largest amount in 15 years as businesses shed jobs. **********"Computers have replaced people in a lot of jobs," from switchboard operators to assembly line workers, Astrid Adolfson, an economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York, said. "Plus people who have jobs are working harder." **********Productivity, which measures the time, effort and cost of providing goods and services, increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3 percent in the second quarter, faster than the revised pace of 2.5 percent in the first quarter. The gain in the first quarter was initially reported as 2.7 percent. The productivity data do not include the farm sector. **********Increases in productivity gains are essential for businesses to hold down prices and stay competitive. As labor costs remain in check, companies are able to absorb higher material and production costs without passing them on to their customers by investing in technology. **********The Labor Department report showed that unit labor costs, which account for about two-thirds of overall business costs, rose six-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter after increasing 1.6 percent in the first quarter. Hourly wages adjusted for inflation rose two-tenths of 1 percent after increasing 1 percent in the previous three months. **********Worker output increased at a pace of six-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, well below a gain of 4.5 percent in the first quarter. The number of hours worked decreased 2.4 percent, the largest drop since the second quarter of 1980, as companies dismissed or furloughed employees. In the first quarter, hours worked rose 2 percent. **********On the inflation front, the implicit price deflator, a measure of price increases tied to the productivity report, rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter after climbing 1.3 percent in the first quarter. **********"The labor market isn't really adding to inflation; in fact, it's just the opposite," said Dan Friel, a senior economist at Nationsbanc Capital Markets Inc. in Charlotte, N.C. **********Still, the Labor Department said unit nonlabor payments, which include such items as taxes and rental payments, climbed 1.3 percent in the second quarter after increasing seven-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter. **********In a separate report today, figures released by the Commerce Department showed that unsold goods continued to pile up at wholesalers' warehouses during June, suggesting manufacturers must further reduce production. The biggest buildups were in big-ticket goods like automobiles and furniture, where demand has been sluggish.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/10/busin.print_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS: FUNDS WATCH; Fidelity Tinkers With Charity Fund
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/10/busin.body_text: **********LAST year was disappointing for investors, and the Charitable Gift Fund from Fidelity Investments did not escape the fallout. The fund, which invests in Fidelity mutual funds, is an alternative to establishing a private foundation. Its investments in the equity-income and interest-income categories fell behind the mutual fund averages for their categories, while the portfolio's growth investments came out only slightly ahead. **********Robert A. Beckwitt, who runs Fidelity Asset Manager and is a member of the gift fund's investment review committee, suggested some changes when he described performance to the fund trustees last winter. **********On his suggestion, Fidelity Blue Chip Growth was replaced with Mid-Cap Stock, reducing the technology exposure and adding more midsize companies. Mr. Beckwitt also dumped Short-Term World Income in favor of Intermediate Bond to minimize interest-rate bets that had turned sour. And out went Global Balanced, hurt by emerging-markets plays; it was replaced by a combination of International Growth and Income and Dividend Growth. **********The result: a slightly better performance this year than would have been achieved with the old mix of funds. The Charitable Gift Fund has granted more than $75 million to more than 10,000 charitable organizations on behalf of its donors since its 1991 inception. A $10,000 minimum is needed to open an account. Waiving Fees On Money Funds **********Five money market funds waived all their fees in the second quarter of 1995, down from 11 in the first quarter, according to IBC/Donoghue's Quarterly Report on Money Fund Performance in Ashland, Mass. Three were funds open to individual investors: Benham Florida Municipal Money Market, Olde Premium Plus Money Market Series and Strong Money Market, which was the top-performing general-purpose fund for the quarter. **********By waiving or absorbing certain fees, funds can at least temporarily increase returns for investors and gain an edge over their competitors. The decline in waivers can probably be traced to the big rally in the bond market earlier in the year, a rally that made money fund yields more attractive without the waivers, said Walter Franke, chief economist of IBC/Donoghue Inc. **********Still, absorbing at least some expenses for a competitive edge is a thriving practice among money funds, where tiny increases in yields go a long way toward luring investors. Among taxable money funds, 57 percent waived at least part of their expenses in the second quarter, up from 55.3 percent in the corresponding period a year earlier. Among the 386 tax-free money funds, 61.7 percent waived part of their expenses, up from 60.1 percent a year earlier.  How Much to Pay A Fund Director? **********Fund directors and trustees are usually paid a flat fee each year, with an additional amount for each meeting they attend. Only a few funds base directors' compensation on the amount of assets overseen. Templeton Global Opportunities Trust and the Navellier Series Fund are two that do so, according to Jeffrey C. Keil, an editor with Lipper Analytical Services, in Denver. **********The median total compensation for mutual fund directors was $41,000 in 1994, an 11 percent increase from 1993, according to the 1995 Survey of Mutual Fund Directors Compensation conducted by Fund Directions, a trade newsletter in New York, and Management Practice Inc., a management consulting firm, also in New York. The groups surveyed 413 independent directors representing 56 boards and 1,588 funds. Unsolved Mysteries Of Arbitration **********If you have an arbitration bugbear, it's time to speak up. Consumer advocates and others frequently cite problems with how arbitration is used to resolve disputes between investors and their brokers. A common complaint is that arbitrators are apt to have worked in the industry and, therefore, have a brokerage bias. **********Now, the National Association of Securities Dealers, the self-regulating body for the securities industry, is soliciting information from investors through a 24-hour toll-free number, (800) 925-0278. If you are fighting with your broker and the case has gone to arbitration, the N.A.S.D. wants to hear your thoughts on the system's strengths and weaknesses. Suggestions for improving the process are welcome. **********Perhaps your ideas will go to the N.A.S.D.'s arbitration policy task force, which expects to submit a final report in November. Mergers **********Paine Webber Growth and Income has picked up the assets of the Paine Webber Global Energy and Mitchell Hutchins/Kidder, Peabody Equity Income funds. **********Smith Barney Utilities Fund will merge with the Smith Barney Utilities Portfolio in November, subject to shareholder approval. **********In conjunction with the New England Investment Companies' acquisition of Harris Associates, the Oakmark fund will reduce its management fee slightly, to 0.95 percent for assets over $2.5 billion. Electronic Tools **********Working Assets has opened a Home Page on the World Wide Web (http://www.efund.com) to let investors review the performance of its Citizens Index of 300 "socially responsible" companies and how it stacks up against the Standard & Poor's 500 index. Investors can also scan profiles of 60 of the companies in the Citizens Index. **********Mutual Funds magazine has set up a free service called Mutual Funds Online on the World Wide Web (http://www.mfmag.com/ abf). **********Users can get the magazine's articles, a fund performance calculator, performance rankings, fund charts (updated daily), shareholder reports and prospectuses, among other information. In Brief **********Fidelity Advisor New York Tax-Free, a new fund, will invest primarily in New York investment-grade municipal debt and maintain an average maturity of 10 years or more. **********Prudential GNMA Fund will expand its holdings by investing in mortgage securities issued by agencies other than the Government National Mortgage Association and by private companies, if shareholders approve the change. **********The Big Six accounting firms audit 95.8 percent of all mutual funds, with Price Waterhouse leading the pack, according to figures compiled by Lipper Analytical Services. Price Waterhouse accounts for 31.4 percent of the market, representing $700 billion in fund assets. **********Four funds from Working Assets, which specializes in "socially responsible" investing, have dropped sales charges ranging from 2 percent to 4 percent. They are Citizens Income, Emerging Growth, Global Equity and Muir California Tax-Free Income. **********Franklin Natural Resources is a new fund that invests in companies around the world that own, produce, refine, process and market timber, minerals and other natural resources or that provide support for such companies. The sales charge is 4.5 percent. **********Before the Piedmont Management Company merges with the Chartwell Re Corporation, it will spin off the Lexington Management Corporation, its asset management subsidiary. Lexington manages $3.4 billion, including $1.5 billion in mutual funds. **********The Dreyfus Guide to Investing for College is available free by calling (800) 896-2645, ext. 4248. **********Fidelity Investments has a new guide called Sector Fund Investing, available free by calling (800) 544-8888.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/03/busin.main_headline: OUTLOOK 1995: THE ECONOMY Industry Groups Cope With Cost-Cutting and Consolidation; Consumer Stocks Could Gain Luster
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/03/busin.print_headline: OUTLOOK 1995: THE ECONOMY Industry Groups Cope With Cost-Cutting and Consolidation; Consumer Stocks Could Gain Luster
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/03/busin.body_text: **********Although they have had their moments in 1994, consumer-products companies have not exactly set the world on fire, or more specifically, inflamed investors with passion for consumer stocks. But if the economy slows in 1995, an increasing number of investors may be looking to consumer-products companies with strong growth prospects. **********The reason? They are a useful alternative to the companies whose products are linked to the ups and downs of the economy. **********In the meantime, the mantra for managers of consumer-products companies in 1995 will be the same as it was in 1994: shed major management distractions to focus on core businesses, pay down debt to improve earnings, buy shares to increase the stock price and hammer out a strategy to maximize the impact of key brands. **********This is a surprisingly hard regimen to follow, and no major consumer-products company did it more successfully in 1994 than the Scott Paper Company, the Philadelphia giant that is the world's largest producer of tissue products. A year ago, the company had ballooning debt, a high cost structure and a stock price that had nose-dived along with its earnings. **********Last April, into the comfortable, patrician offices of Scott strode Albert J. Dunlap, the first chief executive hired from outside the company. **********Mr. Dunlap, who is by now tired of the sobriquet Chainsaw, which he won through the years for his cost-cutting ways, immediately lived up to his nickname. He accelerated the company's restructuring plan by dismissing 11,200 workers. **********After this agony, the company's stunned survivors witnessed a series of rapid Dunlap moves: he cut corporate perquisites, sold one of the company's jets and put for-sale signs on the 55-acre world headquarters and office park. He also sold $2 billion in assets not related to the core tissue business. **********After all that, Scott was able to announce in December that it would repurchase $300 million of stock and reduce the corporate debt by $1.3 billion. **********By the end of the year, Scott stock, which had languished at $37.75 when Mr. Dunlap took over, was at around $69. **********"With other consumer products companies, the problems haven't been so extreme, and so they didn't need to take such extreme measures," said Kathryn McAuley, a paper-products analyst for Brown Brothers Harriman & Company. "This is remarkable progress in six months. It's a very quick turnaround, but it's solid." **********Mr. Dunlap, who is not given to false modesty, said in an interview last month that "Scott has come out of the dark ages." GLENN COLLINS

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/19/busin.snippet: Automotive pollution-control devices are about to get complicated -- so complicated that it will take a computer to fix them -- and independent shops have waged a long battle to keep car dealers from monopolizing this high-tech repair business. A ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/19/busin.main_headline: Independent Mechanics Win Access to Car-Repair Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/19/busin.print_headline: Independent Mechanics Win Access to Car-Repair Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/19/busin.body_text: **********Automotive pollution-control devices are about to get complicated -- so complicated that it will take a computer to fix them -- and independent shops have waged a long battle to keep car dealers from monopolizing this high-tech repair business. A recent Federal decision has given the independents a partial victory, granting them the right to those computer programs but setting no price for that access. **********Federal rules require that all 1996 models, some of which are now on sale, have computerized systems to detect failures in pollution control equipment. Indeed, some cars already have such systems, which include computer chips that would be used to repair any such failures at the push of a button, simply by making alterations to the computer program that controls the pollution equipment, or by reprogramming it. **********Car makers wanted to keep the software proprietary, giving dealerships a monopoly on repairs. But independent shops, which do 80 percent of all repairs, argued that the Federal Clean Air Act entitled them to the information, too. That, they argued, would create far more places for consumers to obtain the service, increasing competition and lowering the cost to consumers. **********In a recent ruling, the Environmental Protection Agency agreed that independents should have access to the information and that the car makers must provide it to them. **********The law required that consumers "have a choice in where their vehicle is serviced," said Cheryl Adelman, a senior policy adviser at the E.P.A.'s motor vehicle emissions laboratory in Ann Arbor, Mich. Independent technicians, the agency said, should have access to emissions-related service and repair information because they do most car repairs. **********The agency's decision puts independent shops on "even ground" with dealers, said Aaron Lowe, director of legislative and regulatory affairs for the Automotive Parts and Accessories Association, a trade group in Bethesda, Md. Now "we will be able to stay in this race," he said. A lot is at stake: Car repairs cost Americans $170 billion -- $75 billion for service, the rest for parts -- and that market is expected to grow even larger as systems become more sophisticated, detecting more emissions problems sooner. Further, it will be more difficult for the average do-it-yourselfer to repair these systems. **********Car makers and dealers -- who had opposed providing the information to independents, citing concerns that it would allow them to increase engine performance in a way that would violate clean-air rules -- played down the E.P.A. decision. **********"We really don't believe they will need to do much reprogramming," John Trajnowski, an engineer with the Ford Motor Company, said of the independent shops, since much will be done by the dealers under warranty. **********Douglas Greenhaus, director of environment, health and safety for the National Automobile Dealers Association in McLean, Va., said, "We're a bit concerned" about making reprogramming equipment available to independent shops, but will "do whatever we can" to safeguard against tampering, he added. Still, Mr. Greenhaus said the E.P.A. had "split the baby" and sided with manufacturers and dealers in deciding not to set the price of the information, saying merely that they should charge a "reasonable cost" for providing it. **********Further, the E.P.A. did not feel it was necessary for independent parts makers to gain information from manufacturers on how to design parts compatible with the new computerized systems. This part of the rule signals a potential setback for the small shops. "We wanted software information on how they make their parts," said Tyler Wilson, director of government relations for the Automotive Service Industry Association, based in Elk Grove Village, Ill. **********This would particularly pertain to a part like the oxygen sensor or catalytic converter. The agency's refusal to require the transfer of this information to independent parts makers could affect their ability to manufacture effective parts and could give dealers a monopoly, raising consumer costs, Mr. Wilson said. **********But Gregory Dana, vice president and technical director of the Association of International Automobile Manufacturers in Arlington, Va., said the independent parts makers would be able to compete, provided they started spending the money necessary to produce the sophisticated parts, something auto manufacturers have been doing all along. **********Mr. Lowe hopes independent manufacturers can still build reliable parts without assistance from the auto manufacturers. No one knows for sure, he said, since these computerized environmental emissions systems are just beginning to appear on cars and parts manufacturers have not yet begun to design them. **********As of now, neither parts makers nor auto makers plan to challenge the rule, with both sides saying the E.P.A. had found a middle ground. "Everyone can claim they've lost equally," Mr. Greenhaus said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/09/world.main_headline: Burundi Strike Averted, Easing Ethnic Tension
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/09/world.print_headline: Burundi Strike Averted, Easing Ethnic Tension
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/09/world.body_text: **********A citywide strike that many feared could set off widespread ethnic violence was averted today when Burundi's powerful Tutsi-dominated opposition party said it had won its battle to oust the Prime Minister. **********Government officials said there had been no such agreement, only a decision by President Silvester Ntibantunganya to eventually consider a new candidate chosen by all the opposition parties to replace Prime Minister Anatole Kanyenkiko. **********Even after the strike was called off, the capital, Bujumbura, remained tense with sporadic gunfights. On Tuesday evening, several grenades exploded, and gunfire was reported in the center of the city. **********Western diplomats said it was unclear who was responsible. No activity by the military or bandits was visible during a ride through Bujumbura tonight after curfew began. **********Burundi, with an ethnic mix similar to Rwanda, its troubled neighbor, has been teetering on the edge of a civil war since the assassination of its first democratically elected President, a Hutu, in October 1993. **********Since then, Burundi's ruling coalition has been hobbled by a tense and at times antagonistic relationship between the Hutu in the Government and the Tutsi-dominated army. **********Although the central African country has a Hutu majority, it has been dominated in many ways by the Tutsi minority since it won independence in the 1960's. **********The Tutsi-dominated opposition party, the Union for National Progress, or Uprona, reported it had won an agreement on replacing the Prime Minister on Tuesday. **********Late last week, the party had threatened to overthrow the Government if Prime Minister Kanyenkiko was not replaced. If the party's prediction today is borne out and he is ousted, it would mean the establishment of Burundi's fourth government in a year and a half. **********Under a agreement brokered in September with United Nations help, the Prime Minister of Burundi must be a member of Uprona. **********Prime Minister Kanyenkiko, a Tutsi and until January a member of Uprona, was said to have been ejected for not following directives. **********The potential for ethnic violence remains a top concern. The killing of Melchior Ndadaye, Burundi's first Hutu leader, in a failed military coup in 1993 set off months of bloodshed, claiming 100,000 lives.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/21/busin.main_headline: UNOCAL TO SIGN PACT WITH TURKMENISTAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/21/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; UNOCAL TO SIGN PACT WITH TURKMENISTAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/21/busin.body_text: **********The Unocal Corporation said yesterday that it would sign an agreement with the former Soviet republic of Turkmenistan as a first step in an $18 billion project to transport natural gas and oil across Afghanistan to Pakistan. The company, which is also involved in an $8 billion oil development in nearby Azerbaijan, said the project would unlock huge gas reserves in Turkmenistan that the republic developed and has not sold. Unocal and its partner, Delta Oil Company of Saudi Arabia, will spend $10 million during the next year on engineering and marketing studies to determine where a pipeline could be built and who would buy the gas. An agreement on that will be signed with the Government today in New York. But analysts noted that the project faced many risks. There is no agreement with Afghanistan, and the country's mountainous territory would make building a pipeline difficult.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/30/busin.main_headline: SBC COMMUNICATIONS TO TAKE CHARGE AGAINST EARNINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/30/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; SBC COMMUNICATIONS TO TAKE CHARGE AGAINST EARNINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/30/busin.body_text: **********SBC Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would take a non-cash charge of $2.8 billion in the third quarter to accelerate the depreciation of its plant and equipment. The company said the after-tax charge would amount to $4.67 a share, and analysts said it would result in a loss for the year. The charge adjusts the book value of the company's plant and equipment by increasing depreciation at the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company, the local phone unit of SBC. SBC is the last of the seven Baby Bells to change its accounting rules to reflect a changing regulatory environment and increased competition in the $90 billion local phone market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/03/busin.main_headline: OUTLOOK 1995: THE ECONOMY Industry Groups Cope With Cost-Cutting and Consolidation; Military Industry Looks to Revamp
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/03/busin.print_headline: OUTLOOK 1995: THE ECONOMY Industry Groups Cope With Cost-Cutting and Consolidation; Military Industry Looks to Revamp
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/03/busin.body_text: **********The megamergers between Grumman and Northrop, and Martin Marietta and Lockheed grabbed the headlines last year. But the greatest strides in shrinking the military industry will come not from a bigger-is-better approach but from combining the overlapping operations of competitors. **********The acquisition by GM Hughes Electronics of General Dynamics' missile business is perhaps the most vivid illustration of the virtues of such a practice. It demonstrates how eliminating duplication and shuttering plants can shave costs, increase efficiency and bring in new business, at an increased profit. **********Others in the defense industry have gone through painful consolidation, but the results have not been as visible as those at Hughes," said John Harbison, who heads the aerospace group at Booz, Allen & Hamilton Inc., the management consulting firm. "Hughes for so many years was run like a nonprofit enterprise, putting technology first at any cost. Its turnaround is dramatic." **********One of the biggest rewards of the turnaround came in late September, when Hughes, in a winner-takes-all contest, beat out McDonnell Douglas for the Tomahawk missile contract, which could be worth almost $2 billion over seven years. **********Now, analysts say, Hughes is the most likely of a handful of missile makers to survive as a dwindling number of contracts forces further consolidations. With the loss of the Tomahawk, McDonnell Douglas may be vulnerable and Hughes may be ready to strike. "If there is an opportunity, we'll look," said Michael T. Smith, vice president of GM Hughes Electronics.  SALLIE HOFMEISTER

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/31/busin.body_text: **********COMMUNITY BANKSHARES INC., Concord, N.H., a savings and loan holding company, plans to acquire Centerpoint Bank, Bedford, N.H., a state-chartered commercial bank, for $10.5 million, or $17.70 a share, in a stock-swap transaction. https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/13/busin.main_headline: Technology Issues Lead Market to Another Mark
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/13/busin.print_headline: Technology Issues Lead Market to Another Mark
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/13/busin.body_text: **********Stocks went into orbit yesterday, not only reaching record levels but also triggering the so-called circuit breaker designed to stabilize the market. **********The New York Stock Exchange imposed its downtick rule at 3:11 P.M. to curb program trading, or stock-index arbitrage, which goes into effect when the Dow Jones industrial average rises more than 50 points. It was the eighth time this year that the limits went into effect, the last occurring on May 31. **********Institutions placed five rounds of buy programs over a period of more than an hour, according to Birinyi Associates. "A lot of it was fueled by positive corporate earnings," Greg Schoenleber, a Birinyi analyst, said. **********At the close, the Dow was up 46.69 points, to 4,727.29, a new high. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index hit a record 560.89, up 6.11, and the Nasdaq composite index, closing at a record 988.63, enjoyed a 18.41-point advance -- its biggest this year and its third largest in history. Since Jan. 1, the three indicators have climbed between 22 percent and 32 percent. **********"Institutional buying was concentrated in the same issues that it has concentrated on throughout the year," Louis Ehrenkrantz, president of Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum, said. "It was an extremely wild day when everybody tried to get into the same door at the same time." **********Traders generally expect the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates soon, as it did last week, and thereby help the economy pick up steam this year and next. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond moved down to 6.54 percent yesterday from 6.58 percent on Tuesday. **********Advancing issues on the Big Board surpassed decliners by 1,493 to 827. Volume on the New York exchange rose to 413.6 million shares, from 376.8 million shares on Tuesday. **********Technology stocks once again spearheaded the rally and -- as has been the case for most of the year -- familiar names led the way. Intel was up 3 3/8, to 72 1/4; Motorola, 5 1/8, to 75 5/8; Microsoft, 3 3/8, to 99 7/8, and Hewlett-Packard, 2, to 81 3/8. **********Some less recognizable companies in the technology sector also surged after announcing better-than-expected profits. Alliance Semiconductor, which declared a 3-for-2 stock split, climbed 4 3/4, to 60 1/2. And Seagate Technology, which was recommended by a number of analysts, soared 3 1/2, to 45. **********Bank stocks were helped by the announcement that First Chicago intended to merge with NBD Bancorp. First Chicago closed at 61 1/2, up 7/8, while NBD ended at 34 3/8, up 1 7/8. Republic New York rose 1 1/8, to 57; First Interstate, 1 5/8, to 83, and Bank of Boston, 3/4, to 38 5/8. **********Other groups also performed well yesterday. Some money managers who had hesitated to buy fertilizer issues decided to wait no longer. Potash gained 2 1/2, to 58 1/2; IMC Global, 2 3/4, to 59 1/8, and Terra Industries, 1/2, to 14 1/8. **********Cable stocks, many of which are selling well below their highs and considered capable of achieving further advances, showed gains, too. Comcast was up 7/8, to 20 1/2; Tele-Comunications, 5/8, to 24 3/8, and Cablevision, 1/4, to 68 1/8. **********One issue that wound up lower yesterday was Revco D.S., which was affected by reports that a few securities firms either lowered or planned to lower their earnings projections. The stock declined 3, to 20 3/8.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/08/world.main_headline: U.S. Scrambles to Block Oil Rigs From Reaching Serbia
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/08/world.print_headline: U.S. Scrambles to Block Oil Rigs From Reaching Serbia
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/08/world.body_text: **********In a secret transaction involving four countries, several companies and altered documents, two oil rigs have been shipped from Iran en route to Serbia in violation of the United Nations sanctions against Belgrade, Western officials say. **********The shipment was discovered by the Central Intelligence Agency after it left Iran, officials said, and now the United States is trying to prevent the contraband from reaching its destination. **********Apparently in an attempt to disguise the identity of the intended recipient in Serbia, which would use the equipment for its war machine, the original documents for the transaction described the contents in the ship's hold as oil-drilling equipment destined for Bulgaria, then Russia. The oil rigs had belonged to a Canadian company owned by a Serbian immigrant. **********The documents were later altered to say the rigs were hydrological research equipment, destined for Macedonia, according to officials from several countries, who have seen the documents and are tracking the equipment. Western officials said similar shipments were planned if this one was successful. **********"It is a particularly egregious example of a broader problem," said a Western diplomat who follows sanctions closely. **********The broader problem, officials said, is that the sanctions have developed a huge leak in the southern Balkans, and traders and the Serbs are using so many false fronts that governments are finding it hard to stem the flow. Not since engines for fighter planes were smuggled into Serbia a few years ago has a single shipment in violation of the United Nations embargo so alarmed Washington, officials say. And now the high-stakes espionage drama continues. **********Investigators are trying to keep track of the equipment, which is more than 100 trucks' worth and already in at least three countries -- and block it from reaching the Serbs, who have oilfields in the north and in a Serbian-controlled area of eastern Croatia. **********"This is big stuff," a Western diplomat said. "The most important thing you can deny to Yugoslavia is oil." **********With the United States having declined to send troops into the war zones of Bosnia and Croatia, sanctions against Yugoslavia are the centerpiece of Washington's Balkan policy. They are the means by which the United States hopes to persuade President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, the most powerful politician in Yugoslavia, to negotiate, end his support for the Bosnian Serbs and recognize the independence and boundaries of Croatia, Bosnia and Macedonia, all of which broke away from the old Yugoslavia. **********The case of the oil-drilling equipment is highly delicate, and officials who answered questions did so only on the condition that they, and in some cases even their countries, not be identified. **********The issue is delicate in part because about 700 tons of the equipment has already slipped through Greece and Bulgaria, and neither American nor European diplomats want to embarrass those countries' governments. In addition, Western intelligence agencies do not want the Iranians and the Serbs to learn how they found out about the shipment. **********Slobodan Popovich, who works in the foreign press section of the Yugoslav Information Ministry, said he knew nothing about the shipment. "I doubt if anyone would," he said. He said that it would be a violation of the United Nations sanctions for anyone to sell such equipment to Yugoslavia, but that he did not think it would violate any law for Yugoslavia to try to buy it. **********The Iranian Embassy here declined to comment, saying it knew nothing about the matter, and the Foreign Ministry's press office in Teheran declined to answer questions. **********One of the most perplexing questions for investigators is why Iran would sell something of such military and strategic value as oil-drilling equipment to Yugoslavia, since Iran openly supports the Muslim-led Bosnian Government in its war with the Serbs. **********One Western official speculated that Iran did it simply for the money. But some Western officials have not ruled out the possibility that even Iran did not know the ultimate destination of the equipment and that it might have been diverted after leaving that country, though they said this seemed unlikely given the control the Iranian Government exercises. **********The shipping documents list the shipper of the equipment as Canadian Triton International, which is based in Calgary, Alberta. It is owned by Vladimir Katic, who Western officials said is a Serb who immigrated to Canada from Yugoslavia in 1966. **********Canadian Triton is a small oil-drilling company whose only operations are in Iran, George Duchesne, a company official, said in a telephone interview from Calgary. Mr. Duchesne, who declined to give his position in the company, confirmed that Mr. Katic was the owner and said he did not know about his background. **********Mr. Duchesne said he did not know why Canadian Triton's name was on the shipping documents. He said the company had leased the two rigs from a Yugoslav company in 1992 and had used them in Iran for one year. At the end of that time, Mr. Duchesne said, they belonged to Yugoslavia again. **********"It's theirs," Mr. Duchesne said. "Is there a problem with their bringing their own stuff home?" **********Based on interviews with American, Western European and Balkan officials in seven countries, it is possible to piece together this outline of events: **********An Iranian ship, the Ershad, left Iran about Feb. 1, loaded with two rigs. It landed at the Greek port of Salonika about Feb. 20. The equipment, valued at $4.9 million, was consigned to a Bulgarian company. **********When the United States, through its intelligence sources, determined that the equipment was headed for Yugoslavia, it approached all governments in the region. **********One of the Security Council's sanctions resolutions -- No. 820, which was passed in April 1993 -- requires countries to detain all vessels and cargoes "suspected" of having been involved in violating sanctions. **********When the American intelligence was first relayed to the Greeks, they were slow to react, European and American officials said. **********A Greek Foreign ministry official who insisted on anonymity said Greece had not initially interfered with the shipment because under Greek law the Government has no right to stop a shipment in transit to a legitimate country, in this case Bulgaria, according to the shipping documents. **********Later, under constant pressure from the United States and the European Union's sanctions monitoring office in Brussels, Greece put a hold on the rest of the equipment. **********Before Greece acted, Western officials said, about 1,200 tons had already been hauled by trucks to Bulgaria. They crossed the border at Kulata, consigned to a company called Baypass, several officials said, including one who read from the shipping documents. Officials said they had not been able to locate the company. **********It was after the shipment reached Bulgaria that the documents were altered, declaring that the cargo was hydrological research equipment, Western officials said. **********American officials asked the Bulgarian Government not to allow the cargo to continue. But the Bulgarians said they could not interfere with the shipment since it was intended for Macedonia, a country against which there is no embargo. **********The Bulgarian Foreign Ministry said no one was available to answer questions about the case. The President's office said he was on a trip to North Korea and Mongolia with his spokesman and foreign affairs adviser. **********Bulgaria notified the United Nations sanctions committee this week that 60 truckloads of the equipment passed through Bulgaria into Macedonia. **********Some of it was loaded onto rail cars and was about to go to Serbia when American officials stepped in. The fully loaded rail cars sit on the tracks. **********If the United States succeeds in persuading Greece and Macedonia not to release the equipment now in their custody -- and Western officials say it is by no means certain Washington will -- the deal will have fallen through for the Serbs, because the parts that have been held up are needed for the rigs to work.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/21/busin.main_headline: The Costly Marriage to NCR Becomes a Vision That Failed
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/21/busin.print_headline: THE SECOND BREAKUP OF AT&T: THE COMPUTER BUSINESS; The Costly Marriage to NCR Becomes a Vision That Failed
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/21/busin.body_text: **********When AT&T finally overcame the resistance of the NCR Corporation in 1991 and paid $7.4 billion for what was the nation's fifth-largest computer company, AT&T's chairman, Robert E. Allen, proclaimed a new era in which AT&T would make "global computer networks as easy to use and accessible as the telephone network is today." **********That vision of a convergence of computers and telecommunications is held even more widely today, as businesses and consumers move to the Internet in search of the next generation of business technology. **********But AT&T's stewardship of NCR, which it renamed AT&T Global Information Solutions, had done little, if anything, to advance that revolution, and AT&T is now quitting that particular struggle. **********After years of losses, the new management of the division has decided its only hope of survival is to abandon the personal computer business, narrow its focus and return to its roots, providing hardware and software to retailers, financial services and communications companies. **********Yesterday, AT&T said the troubled unit would again become an independent entity, one of three to be formed by the breakup of AT&T. And to begin realigning the company, AT&T said 8,500 of its 304,500 workers would be terminated, including 1,000 at its Dayton, Ohio, headquarters. **********"AT&T thought they could throw their muscle around to make NCR what it wasn't," said Jon Oltsik, an analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. "They tried to diversify into everything, but they didn't have a plan." **********AT&T will take a $1.5 billion charge against earnings in the current quarter to account for the revamping. Not including NCR's $7.4 billion purchase price, the write-down makes a total of more than $2 billion in NCR-related charges since 1991. The division lost $332 million in the first half of this year. **********Lars Nyberg, the executive who arrived in June to turn around the troubled computer unit, said the cuts would allow the division to break even in 1996, just before it is expected to be spun off in early 1997. **********"This company has not done what other companies have done in this industry," he said yesterday. "It has not reduced expenses as gross margins have declined." **********Strong medicine is not new to NCR, which began life in 1882 as the National Cash Register Company in Dayton, Ohio, where it is still based. In the early 1970's, the company almost went under when its managers failed to recognize the growing importance of computers. After three-quarters of its workers were laid off, the company fought its way back to profitability and became a leader in automatic teller machines and high-end computers. **********After cutting expenses, Mr. Nyberg said, he plans to increase revenue by focusing on the unit's strengths, rather than making PC's, where the competition from lower-cost manufacturers was too formidable. **********He pointed to opportunities in the banking industry, where the pace of technical change is gathering momentum. He said that he also planned to exploit the company's lead in the area called data warehousing, in which retailers and other companies plumb huge data bases containing information about their customers to tailor marketing campaigns. **********Because of the expense of the powerful systems needed for such jobs, data warehousing has been available only to large players like Wal-Mart. But next week, Mr. Nyberg said, he would introduce a line of machines to make the practice affordable for medium-sized and even small companies. **********"It was a niche business, but it won't be a niche business anymore," he said. **********The computer operation would enter the world as the smallest and weakest of the three new AT&T companies. It had $8.4 billion in revenue last year, and after the revamping it would be smaller, Mr. Nyberg acknowledged. **********Most analysts believe that it will face an uphill fight. "Outside of their traditional banking and retail areas, they have lots of things going but none of them are leaders in their areas," said David Moschella, an analyst at International Data Group in Boston. "They still can't make up their mind whether they are a product company or a service company. That's a tough position to be in."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/22/world.main_headline: Aides to Clinton Say He Will Defy Beijing and Issue Visa to Taiwan's President
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/22/world.print_headline: Aides to Clinton Say He Will Defy Beijing and Issue Visa to Taiwan's President
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/22/world.body_text: **********President Clinton has decided to grant a visa to the President of Taiwan, senior Administration officials said today. The action would break a 16-year-old policy and risk retaliation by China, which vehemently opposes the move on the ground that the United States has no official relations with Taiwan. **********The officials said President Clinton had decided to risk a run-in with China by admitting President Lee Teng-hui because of intense pressure from the Republican-dominated Congress. **********Earlier this month, the Senate voted 97 to 1 and the House 396 to 0 to urge Mr. Clinton to reverse the longstanding policy and allow Mr. Lee to attend Cornell University's alumni reunion next month in Ithaca, N.Y. **********With this move and the decision to impose trade sanctions on Japanese cars, President Clinton will in one week have angered the two most powerful Asian Governments, China and Japan, at a time when many experts on Asia say American relations with the world's most dynamic continent are already strained. **********No President of Taiwan has been allowed to visit the United States since 1979, when the United States adopted a policy that recognizes Beijing as the sole Government of China. Until then, Washington had recognized the Chinese Nationalists, who fled mainland China for Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war with the Communists, as the legitimate Chinese Government. **********Under intense pressure from China, the United States now maintains only unofficial ties with Taiwan, which the Government in Beijing views as a breakaway province. **********A senior Administration official said that when Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, and Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff met China's Ambassador to the United States, Li Daoyu, on Saturday to inform him of the decision, Mr. Li said his Government was "very unhappy." Another official said the Ambassador responded that his country would have "a sharp reaction." **********A spokesman for China's Foreign Ministry in Beijing, asked about the decision to allow Lee Teng-hui to visit the United States, said that the ministry would not have any immediate comment. **********Shortly after Congress adopted its resolution urging that President Lee be granted a visa, China's Foreign Ministry said that admitting him for either an offical or a private visit would have "serious consequences." **********American diplomats acknowledged today that they feared that China might somehow retaliate, but they added that they had sought to assuage the Chinese by saying Congressional pressure was making such a decision inevitable. **********"We expect China to be unhappy about this, but we'll have to wait and see exactly how they react," said a senior State Department official, who said the visa did not signal a change in the Administration's policy toward China or Taiwan. **********In discussing the decision, which is expected to be announced on Monday, members of the Administration sought to minimize the likelihood of an angry Chinese response by noting that President's Lee trip would be a short, private visit in which he would not meet any American officials. **********Mr. Lee, who received a doctorate in agricultural economics from Cornell in 1968, has been invited to be the main speaker at the university's alumni weekend, from June 8 to 10. **********China is expected to accuse the United States of violating a commitment by admitting Mr. Lee because last September, after a long policy review, the Administration assured China's Government that President Lee would not be allowed into the country except for a transit stop for safety, comfort or convenience. Last May, his plane was allowed to stop in Hawaii to refuel, but the Administration barred him from staying overnight and meeting friends. **********Even though they excluded Mr. Lee in the past, State Department officials said they liked him, and they praised him for solidifying democracy in Taiwan. **********Republicans in Congress welcomed the decision. "The White House had to address the realities in Congress," said Senator Frank Murkowski, the Alaska Republican who sponsored the resolution on Taiwan in the Senate. "When we look at the significance of President Lee in the development of Taiwan -- they'll have free elections this year -- keeping him out was a situation that had to end, and I'm glad to see President Clinton move on it." **********One senior official acknowledged that the nonbinding resolution approved by Congress had forced the Administration's hand, since continuing to bar Mr. Lee would give the impression that Mr. Clinton was bowing to Chinese pressure. **********The President has sought to shake that image since last May, when he extended China's preferential trade status even though its human rights performance fell far short of what he had demanded. **********When Mr. Lake and Mr. Tarnoff met with Ambassador Li, they told the Chinese diplomat that if Mr. Clinton did not soon grant a visa to Taiwan's President, Congress might overwhelmingly adopt a binding resolution that would not only require him to do so, but would also upgrade the American relationship with Taiwan -- something that China bitterly opposes. **********"The Taiwan issue is very important symbolically for China and we have to manage it very carefully," a senior State Department official said. "There was a desire by this Administration to pre-empt new binding legislation that could hurt our relations with China." **********Administration officials said they had no idea whether or how China might retaliate. After President Bush announced plans in 1992 to sell F-16's to Taiwan, China protested and, many Asia experts say, retaliated by ignoring American pleas not to sell missile technology to Pakistan and nuclear technology to Iran. **********"The Chinese aren't going to like this one bit," said Harry Harding, an expert on China who is dean of the Elliott School of International Affairs at George Washington University. "It's possible, even likely, that they will take some retaliatory action. It's difficult to know what they will do, but I think when they find an issue that is more important to us than to them, they will decide not to be cooperative." **********Administration officials say Secretary of State Warren Christopher overruled some low-level officials when he recommended to the President last week that Mr. Lee be admitted. Several Asia experts in the State Department opposed granting Mr. Lee a visa, fearing that it would do too much damage to relations with China when Mr. Christopher's diplomatic vision is to try to maintain strong relations with the world's major powers. **********But some other advisers were recommending a visa for Mr. Lee to avoid a high-stakes showdown with Congress that the White House was likely to lose. Their fear was that Congress would adopt a binding resolution to admit Mr. Lee with enough of a majority to withstand a Presidential veto. **********"We will be quite delighted if President Lee is able to attend the alumni reunion weekend," said Henrik Dullea, Cornell's vice president for university relations. "It will be the capstone of the weekend." **********Cornell's President, Frank H. T. Rhodes, had urged the Administration to admit Mr. Lee, as had a petition from students, faculty and alumni. **********One factor that weighed in the decision, Administration officials said, was that China was slowly increasing economic ties and unofficial diplomatic exchanges with Taiwan even as it pressed the United States and dozens of other countries to keep contacts with Taiwan to a minimum.
