https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/04/world.main_headline: Opened Road in Croatia: Path to Peace?
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/04/world.print_headline: Opened Road in Croatia: Path to Peace?
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/04/world.body_text: **********On a map, this is a town like any other in Croatia. But it lies on a tense though unrecognized border between Government-controlled Croatia and the one-third of the country that has been occupied by rebel Serbs for more than three years. **********It is one of the most volatile borders in Europe, so the recent reopening of a major highway through this town is being watched with a mixture of hope and apprehension. **********Along the roadside, the ruins of villages from which the Serbs chased Croatian families three years ago are stark reminders of the brutality of the "ethnic cleansing" that was practiced here. A gas station near Nova Gradiska, at the other end of the Serbian-controlled portion of the road, is a twisted wreck of steel and concrete. Road signs are peppered with bullet holes. **********No one knows when the Croatian Government, which has grown increasingly frustrated by the long occupation, will launch an offensive to try to retake the Serbian-controlled region. **********Such an offensive, which could reignite the 1991 war of independence fought by Croatia against the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Federation, seemed imminent as recently as November, when the Croatian Army canceled leaves and moved elite units toward the border. Diplomats in Zagreb, the Croatian capital, say that only intense behind-the-scenes pressure from Washington led Croatian leaders to abandon their plans for an offensive. **********Until recently, negotiations between the Croatian Government and the Serbs brought virtually no progress. The Serbs, backed by their brethren in Bosnia and in Serbia itself, have proclaimed the territory they hold to be an independent country, which they call the Republic of Serbian Krajina, and they vow never to submit to Croatian rule again. **********But after the Americans twisted Croatia's arm, and to the surprise of many people throughout the Balkans, leaders of the Croatian Government and the breakaway Krajina region reached an accord that could help normalize lives on both sides of their disputed border. **********Under the accord, water and electricity lines that have been cut since 1991 are to be restored and work is to begin on repairing an oil pipeline that runs from the Croatian port of Rijeka through the Krajina region and on toward Hungary, the Ukraine and Russia. In addition, the accord provided for reopening what was once Yugoslavia's most important road, the one connecting what were its two largest cities, Zagreb and Belgrade. **********The road used to be called the Brotherhood and Unity Highway, but in recent years it has come to represent the gulf of hatred that divides Serbs and Croats. There was heavy fighting along the road during the 1991 Serb revolt, and each day that it remained closed made the prospect of peace seem dimmer. **********When the road reopened on Dec. 23, only a few carloads of journalists and a handful of trucks carrying worried refugees ventured to test the good will of the Serbs who continue to guard it. But traffic has grown steadily, and now more than 2,000 vehicles are using it each day. **********A ride along the 16-mile stretch that runs through Krajina is still very unlike a ride on a normal road. Signs at Novska and Nova Gradiska, the towns on either end of the stretch, still proclaim "Republic of Serbian Krajina," and Serbian flags adorn checkpoints along the way. White armored personnel carriers carrying United Nations peacekeepers look down from bridges and guard exits to make sure that travelers do not leave the road and venture into other parts of Krajina that are still strictly off limits to outsiders. **********Many of the Serbs who patrol the road are evidently unhappy to see it open. **********"We have asked them repeatedly to take their flags down," said Capt. Kamal Pokhrel, a Nepalese officer who is among the United Nations soldiers assigned to watch the road. "They say, 'Why should we? This is our land.' " **********The question of whose land this really is remains to be settled. Croatians consider it theirs, and most of the outside world agrees. But Serbs vow never to return it. **********An agreement to resolve this conflict, if it can be reached at all, is months or years away. In the meantime, diplomats say the accord that reopened the road is the most important step taken so far to defuse the conflict. **********The significance of the agreement was underlined a few days ago when President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia drove through. "The opening of this highway is just a first step toward the liberation of the entire region," Mr. Tudjman promised a throng of supporters in Slavonski Brod. **********When a representative of Croatian refugees who lost their homes in Krajina suggested that opening the highway seemed to imply recognition of Serbian authority in the region, Mr. Tudjman replied, "A peaceful solution should give you more chance of returning to your homes than a new war." **********Many leading Croatian politicians and military officers, however, remain impatient with the Serbian presence, and warn that they will not wait indefinitely for a negotiated solution. **********"If Serbian forces from the so-called Krajina shoot or kill any Croatian citizen on this highway, don't expect us to complain to Boutros-Ghali," the Croatian Chief of Staff, Gen. Janko Bobetko, asserted Friday, referring to the United Nations Secretary General. **********"We will consider it an act of war and we will strike immediately, without warning. We have enough strength to recover this part of Croatia by military means if that becomes necessary. This highway will never be closed again."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/06/busin.main_headline: Treasuries Surge And Rates Fall On Jobs Report
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/06/busin.print_headline: Treasuries Surge And Rates Fall On Jobs Report
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/06/busin.body_text: **********Treasury prices rallied sharply yesterday, sending long-term interest rates down for a second day to their lowest level in more than a year after an employment report showed unexpected weakness. **********The report is the clearest sign yet that the economy has slowed to a point where inflation, which erodes bonds' value, is muzzled. The bond rally helped the dollar against the German mark and the Japanese yen in currency trading.  [ Page 34 ] . Stock traders, however, worried that such a slowdown could hurt corporate earnings, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 16.26 points.  [ Page 39. ] **********Bond prices surged after the Labor Department reported that the nation's unemployment rate jumped three-tenths of a point, to 5.8 percent, in April and that the number of new jobs fell for the first time in more than two years. The data followed a string of reports, including the Commerce Department's index of leading indicators on Wednesday, all pointing to the slowdown sought by bond investors and generating the biggest weekly rally in the market since June 1989. **********"Each new piece of data causes bond investors who have been holding out on the sidelines to one by one throw in the waiting towel and buy bonds for fear of missing an opportunity," said Kevin McClintock, manager of fixed-income portfolios at Aeltus Investment Management. **********The price of the 30-year bond jumped 126/32 , to a 10717/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 7.02 percent, from 7.16 percent on Thursday. The 7.02 percent was the lowest since March 28, 1994, when the yield was 6.97 percent. **********It was the sharpest drop in the long bond's yield since Feb. 3, when it fell to 7.61 percent from 7.76 percent two days after the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates for the seventh time in 12 months, according to CS First Boston. **********For the week, the yield fell 32 basis points, reflecting the biggest bond market rally since June 1989, when the yield dropped 33 basis points, to 8.15 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********While the employment report and other economic data have clearly pointed to a slowdown, there have been concerns that the economy may slip into a recession and the Federal Reserve will have to reverse its course on interest rates. But a continued drop in interest rates could help stabilize a slowing economy, providing easier credit for businesses and home buyers. **********Still, there are a number of traders and analysts who saw yesterday's gains as an overreaction. The market's bubble, they said, could easily burst next week when traders face a new supply of notes and data on consumer and producer prices. **********And the significance of the employment report may have been overstated, they said. **********"The economy is not slowing as rapidly as this report implies," said Donald Fine, the chief market analyst for Chase Securities. "When all is said and done, the economy is clearly slowing, but the degree of slowing is still uncertain, particularly when looking ahead to the second half of the year. **********"You can't tell anything from this report; the only hard evidence that can be gathered from this report is that the manufacturing sector was weak in April. All other aspects of the report are open to interpretation." **********Christopher A. Low, senior economist for the HSBC Group, said a number of factors made the data uncertain -- in particular, a shorter duration between Labor Department surveys. **********"But I think the report was so much weaker than expected, that it does look like a slowdown going into the second quarter," Mr. Low said, "and that is what I believe the market is rallying to." **********Mr. McClintock of Aeltus Investment Management and other market participants said they thought the market was getting ahead of itself, particularly in short-term Treasury securities. With two-year Treasury notes yielding 6.12 percent, compared with a Federal funds rate of 6 percent, the market has priced in a cut in interest rates by the Fed, Mr. McClintock said. **********"Quite frankly, I don't see that easing happening," he said. "A more neutral spread between the two-year and funds rate would be about 80 to 120 basis points. If you polled the market today, most will tell you that they do not expect the Fed to raise interest rates at its next meeting on May 23." **********In the short term, he said, the market should continue to rally, provided that new economic data show weakness. **********Jay Goldinger of Capital Insight in Beverly Hills, Calif., said that despite the employment data, the economy was still growing. **********"Everyone feared inflation, but none have seen it," Mr. Goldinger said. "The so-called get-me-in people are buying bonds like it is some sort of commodity that is in short supply. Next week there will be plenty, but my fear is that the market will rally right into that supply and then roll over. But on the other side of the coin, momentum right now is so great, it's hard to believe we won't see prices go even higher." **********In when-issued trading late in the day, in advance of next week's auctions, three-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.29 percent while 10-year notes were at a price to yield 6.69 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/09/world.main_headline: Allies and Former Enemies Gather to Pledge Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/09/world.print_headline: V-E DAY PLUS 50: BERLIN; Allies and Former Enemies Gather to Pledge Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/09/world.body_text: **********Gathering in the vibrant capital that has risen from the ruins of the city where Hitler planned his war of aggression, leaders of France, Britain, Russia, the United States and Germany pledged today to prevent a repetition of the European cataclysm that ended on this date 50 years ago. **********"I believe that for our countries here, it was the last time we will ever fight against each other," said Prime Minister John Major of Britain. "I cannot believe that we will ever revert to the old way of doing things." **********Mr. Major and the other leaders gathered at dusk in the 19th-century Schauspielhaus, Berlin's most elegant concert hall, which lies in the former East Berlin only a few hundred yards from the underground bunker in which Hitler committed suicide as Soviet troops fought their way toward him. The 1,400 guests, among them senior government officials and foreign ambassadors, filed up the marble stairs on a specially laid red carpet and took their places beneath glittering chandeliers. **********Stirring works by Beethoven, the "Coriolanus Overture" and the "Choral Fantasy," bracketed the speeches. **********It was the third ceremony marking the end of World War II that the five leaders had attended in slightly more than 24 hours. They began their tour Sunday in London and were in Paris this morning. The series of commemorations was to conclude with a parade of war veterans in Moscow on Tuesday. **********Most Berliners went quietly about their normal business today, their interest in 50th anniversary commemorations evidently sated by the dozens that have been held across the country in the last few months. **********Some 4,000 police officers were posted around the Schauspielhaus to guard against protesters, but none appeared. **********The reflective public mood was reinforced by arson attack on a Lubeck synagogue Saturday night and the desecration of a Berlin cemetery for Nazi victims a few hours later.  As foreign dignitaries arrived here today, city officials were at a groundbreaking ceremony for a new museum on the site of the former Gestapo headquarters. **********"We cannot be permitted to suppress and forget the horrors of the Nazis, the nadir of German history," Mayor Eberhard Diepgen said at the ceremony. "All Germans, even those born after the war, share responsibility." **********It is this burden, deeply felt by many Germans, that made today a somber occasion rather than a time to rejoice at what President Francois Mitterrand of France called "the spirit of peace" that Germany and its former enemies now share. **********The approach of today's anniversary has led many older Germans to recall their generation's suffering. In speeches and articles, they have been reminding the country that the end of the war led to the expulsion of more than 10 million ethnic Germans from their homes in Poland, Czechoslovakia and other parts of Central Europe. **********According to a poll published today in the magazine Der Spiegel, 40 percent of Germans over the age of 65 believe that the expulsions were as serious a crime against humanity as the Holocaust, in which six million Jews were killed. But when public figures compare the two events, they face sharp rebuke, as Chancellor Helmut Kohl did over the weekend. **********In a statement Saturday, Mr. Kohl expressed compassion for three groups of World War II victims: concentration camp survivors, combat veterans and Germans who were expelled from their homelands. His remarks sparked immediate protest in Germany and abroad. Sir Teddy Taylor, a member of the British Parliament, called them "insensitive and likely to cause outrage." **********"There is a world of difference," he said, "between people suffering because they have initiated a war and people suffering because of a mad and evil philosophy of ethnic cleansing." **********Although such debates still strike delicate nerves among older Europeans, many of their children find them less meaningful. Younger Germans often say they have difficulty connecting their lives to the evil that was crushed 50 years ago today. **********"I can understand the Middle Ages better than I can understand what led my parents' generation to welcome Hitler with those ridiculous salutes and then be so cowardly as to avert their eyes from Nazi crimes," said Antje Vollmer, a leader of the Green Party who was born in 1943. **********All the visiting foreign leaders made clear that they hold no grudge against the country whose dictatorship inflicted so much suffering on their peoples between 1933 and 1945. **********Mr. Mitterrand, in an unusually personal speech on the eve of his departure from office, called the 50 years of peace among Europe's powers "the triumph of life" and "a victory of Europe over itself." **********Vice President Al Gore praised the "profoundly new relationship between victor and vanquished" that now binds Germany to its neighbors, and said the United States hopes to see "an ever-expanding circle of democracy" in Europe and beyond.  Mr. Gore represented the United States at ceremonies in London, Paris and Berlin; President Clinton is to assume that role in Moscow on Tuesday. **********Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, the Russian Prime Minister, asserted that his country joins the other World War II combatants in accepting "a special responsibility to prevent this horrible past from ever recurring." He also warned against the erection of "new barriers" in Europe and urged "the construction of a genuine pan-European system of security and stability on a bloc-free basis," evidently a reference to Russian opposition to the planned eastward expansion of NATO. **********"None of us have found it easy to shed the memory of the 'Iron Curtain' and the Berlin wall and to begin trusting each other," Mr. Chernomyrdin said. "We are all taking our first steps in this new direction, and we need to be extremely circumspect and careful not to upset the structure upon which the current peace in Europe is based." **********President Roman Herzog of Germany, however, described Western Europe as "an island of peace, freedom and prosperity," and said: "The island must be made larger.  No one should feel threatened by such a policy." **********Mr. Herzog also expressed Germany's "sense of collective shame" for the crimes of the Nazis. "The Germans today know full well, perhaps more clearly than 50 years ago, that it was their Government of that time and many of their fathers who were responsible for the Holocaust and who brought ruin down upon Europe," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/02/world.main_headline: Christopher and Chinese Official Fail to Settle Differences
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/02/world.print_headline: Christopher and Chinese Official Fail to Settle Differences
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/02/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State Warren Christopher and his Chinese counterpart met here tonight in an effort to repair the biggest breach in relations since China's violent suppression of the democracy movement six years ago. **********Despite an exchange that both sides agreed to characterize as "frank and useful," they made no progress on the two major issues dividing Washington and Beijing. **********After a 90-minute session, the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, emerged clearly dissatisfied that the United States refused to guarantee that it would never again issue a visa to a top official of the Taiwan Government, as it did in June for Lee Teng-hui, Taiwan's President. **********And Mr. Qian said the fate of Harry Wu, an American citizen being held on charges of stealing state secrets, was in the hands of the Chinese judicial authorities. He suggested that the Foreign Ministry could not intervene to release Mr. Wu, a step that Washington has made clear is a prerequisite to improving relations. **********Nonetheless, Mr. Christopher's aides insisted that the tone and body language of the meeting suggested that relations with China were finally emerging from what one senior Administration official termed "the deep freeze." **********They noted that Mr. Christopher and Mr. Qian had agreed to instruct their deputies to continue talks in coming weeks, a step the Chinese had refused to take until today. And they said the two men had even talked, in vague terms, about the goal of arranging a summit meeting in October between President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin. **********Mr. Christopher was clearly eager tonight not to rile China further but fearful of fueling Congressional criticism that the Administration is coddling China's leadership at a time of continued human rights violations and suspected sales of missile technology to Iran and Pakistan. **********In a stark illustration of Mr. Christopher's balancing act, he stopped short of telling Mr. Qian directly what he said to reporters on Monday: that it would be "difficult to imagine" a summit meeting while Mr. Wu was still incarcerated. **********Administration officials who described the private exchange on the issue suggested that the Secretary was simply choosing his words diplomatically, and that that message was implicit in Mr. Christopher's statement to Mr. Qian that a "more constructive environment" was needed before any summit meeting could take place. **********"The Chinese know where we are on this," one official said. "They read the newspapers. We have to give it some time to sink in." **********Mr. Qian, while smiling and at one point joking with Mr. Christopher in front of the cameras, made clear in public and private that Beijing was intently focused on one issue: its fear that the Administration's decision to let Mr. Lee into the country indicated a change in policy toward Taiwan, despite Mr. Christopher's repeated statements to the contrary. **********Mr. Qian also made clear that he considered the issuing of the visa to be a violation of past assurances about Washington's adherence to the policy of recognizing "one China," with Beijing as the sole legitimate Government. **********"As an old Chinese saying goes," Mr. Qian told reporters in Mr. Christopher's presence, "Words must count and deeds must yield results. Words have value only when they are honored in deeds." Mr. Qian, officials said, repeated that statement almost verbatim when the private meeting began. **********"Some of the things he was saying were pretty tough," one official said. **********But Mr. Qian apparently spoke without any trace of the rancor that has characterized the public exchanges between Washington and Beijing for two months. That has led many American experts to speculate that both sides are fearful of overstepping the bounds. **********Mr. Qian repeatedly referred to a speech Mr. Christopher had given in Washington on Friday that offered detailed assurances that America's position toward China -- and its view of Taiwan -- had not changed, and describing China's economic and political importance to the United States. **********The question remaining after today's meeting is whether domestic politics in the two countries will stop driving them further apart. **********Congress seems eager to embrace Taiwan's emerging democracy and to embarrass the Administration, as it did last week when the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, invited Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek, the widow of the leader who established the Government on Taiwan after being driven from the Chinese mainland, to a Capitol Hill reception. **********At the same time, China's leadership rarely turns down a chance these days to voice suspicion that Washington is out to contain Chinese power. **********At one point in the talks tonight, held after an all-day session of foreign ministers from Southeast Asia and their major trading and security partners, Mr. Christopher seemed to acknowledge to Mr. Qian that the Administration was not fully in control of China policy -- and that Congress could not be ignored. Mr. Clinton was forced to issue the visa to Mr. Lee, a step the Administration opposed, after a nearly unanimous vote in Congress. **********The White House feared that failing to act might only tempt Congress to tinker with the Taiwan Relations Act, which limits Washington's interaction with Taiwan to "unofficial" contacts. **********Mr. Christopher also directly addressed China's fundamental fears about America's intentions. "He said we want to engage you and not contain or isolate you," one Administration official said. **********But Mr. Christopher also made it clear to Mr. Qian that political conditions could force the issuing of further visas, and that some influential Americans outside the Administration clearly believed that containment would be a better policy. **********"They were clearly not satisfied that the U.S. could not give a better answer," one Administration official said of the Chinese. **********Two planned trips to China by American Cabinet members, one by Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman, the other by Commerce Secretary Ron Brown, were not discussed, though presumably those trade missions are possible tools to rebuild relations in coming months. **********Nor was there discussion, officials said, of whether Hillary Rodham Clinton would attend a conference in Beijing next month on the status of women. That decision will be made by the White House, State Department officials said. Clearly, though, they are hoping that the lure of having the First Lady visit will give China an additional incentive to release Mr. Wu, who has repeatedly documented the conditions in China's prisons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/26/busin.main_headline: Borders Shares Off to Good Start
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/26/busin.print_headline: Borders Shares Off to Good Start
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/26/busin.body_text: **********Shares of Borders Group Inc., a book retailer, rose 5.2 percent higher than their initial public offering price yesterday, as the Kmart Corporation gave up control of the company. **********Shares of Borders, which is based in Ann Arbor Mich., and operates the Borders and Walden chains of book stores, closed at $15.25 in its first day of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. About 10.3 million shares of the stock traded hands, making it the session's second-most-active issue. **********The underwriters priced the offering of 35.9 million shares at $14.50 a share yesterday. The first trade took place at $15.25. **********Still, Kmart, the discount retailer based in Troy, Mich., said it would record a pretax charge of $185 million against its second-quarter earnings because of the sale. It said the charge, about 40 cents a share, reflected the difference between what it paid for and invested in the Borders chains and what it was getting for them now. **********The initial public offering of Borders is the third-largest this year, trailing those of the Nabisco Holdings Corporation, at $1.1 billion, and the PMI Group Inc., at $731 million. **********Kmart had planned to sell 87 percent of the company, a move that would raise $493 million. But it said it would sell 100 percent of Borders if the offering was oversubscribed, in which case it would receive $567 million, after underwriting fees. **********The sale of Borders marks the latest step in the effort by Kmart to slim down and focus on its discount-store chain. Last fall, it sold majority stakes in the Sports Authority Inc., which operates a chain of sporting-goods stores, and Office Max Inc., which sells office supplies. Kmart still owns Builders Square, a home-improvement retailer, which it also plans to spin off.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/13/world.main_headline: U.N. Juggles Funds to Stay Afloat, Expert Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/13/world.print_headline: U.N. Juggles Funds to Stay Afloat, Expert Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/13/world.body_text: **********The United Nations has run out of money to pay its regular operating expenses and is being forced to borrow from peacekeeping funds, which are also strained, an American accounting expert in charge of financial management here told a General Assembly committee today. **********The regular budget ran out of cash in mid-August and $98 million has been borrowed from the peacekeeping budget since then, Joseph E. Connor, Under Secretary General for Administration and Management and a former chief executive officer at Price Waterhouse, told an oversight committee. If nations in arrears do not pay their debts, the diversion of funds from peacekeeping will rise to $200 million by the end of October and to $300 million in November, he said. **********Mr. Connor said United Nations members are now about $3.7 billion in arrears in paying both regular and peacekeeping assessments, up from $2.8 billion at the end of May. He said the United States owes the largest amount, $1.18 billion. Estimates of the shortfall differ because of varying projections and methodology. **********The United Nations has no capital fund and cannot borrow from banks, so meeting expenditures is almost always an exercise in robbing Peter to pay Paul, officials say. But unexpected new expenditures, like the establishment of war crimes tribunals for Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia; the loss of money in currency exchanges because of the depressed value of the dollar, and fears that Washington will delay payments even more than usual this year have exacerbated the crisis. **********"This year the situation is different because the amounts involved are unprecedented," Mr. Connor told the committee, elaborating on a state-of-the-organization report released by Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali on Monday. **********The United Nations already owes more than $900 million to nations that provide peacekeeping troops, Mr. Connor said, and at the current rate the amount owed is projected to reach more than $1.2 billion by the end of the year. **********Mr. Connor, who was appointed to his position at the urging of the United States, said the Secretary General has ordered a freeze on recruitment, limits on staff overtime and travel, delays in payments to vendors and the issuing of monthly instead of semimonthly salary checks. More drastic measures are planned.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/04/world.main_headline: Brazil's Horizons Widening With New Common Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/04/world.print_headline: Brazil's Horizons Widening With New Common Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/04/world.body_text: **********Brazil, South America's industrial giant, has just won more legroom with the start of the Southern Common Market, a customs union that expands by 50 percent the duty-free area open to Brazilian manufacturers. **********On New Year's Day, tariffs were ended on 95 percent of goods traded among Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay. At the same time, the four neighbors adopted common tariffs -- averaging 12 percent -- for goods imported from outside their borders. **********"Brazil has just discovered its Canada," a Brazilian ambassador exulted. "Argentina is Brazil's natural extension south, in the same way that Canada is the United States' natural extension north." **********Brazilian exporters and investors have been quick to follow the diplomats. In the four years since the Southern Common Market treaty was signed and a gradual reduction in tariffs began, regional trade has more than tripled, reaching $12 billion in 1994. **********Once a hostile rival of Argentina, Brazil has become its largest trading partner, displacing the United States; Argentina is now the leading recipient of Brazilian foreign investment. **********"Three years ago, it was almost unimaginable that this could happen," Brazil's new President, Fernando Enrique Cardozo, said here Monday. "Yet, today, we are in a full customs union." **********With flights now shuttling hourly between Buenos Aires and Sao Paulo, manufacturers calculate their economies of scale according to the size of the new, expanded market -- 190 million people and $800 billion in economic activity. Largely forgotten is the skeptical talk that once lampooned the Southern Common Market as "a club of the poor." **********"There are now over 300 joint business ventures between Brazil and Argentina," said Jose Artur Denot Medeiros, Brazil's negotiator for the common market, known in Portuguese as Mercosul, a contraction for Southern Common Market.  "Five years ago, there were only 5 or 10 Brazilian companies in Buenos Aires." **********Brazil's South American trade and investment drive seems destined to accelerate after the inauguration on Sunday of Mr. Cardozo, a former Foreign Minister and the first Brazilian President in modern times to speak Spanish. **********"It will make South America one of the most dynamic, growing areas of the world," Mr. Medeiros said of an expanding network of free-trade agreements that is to be called the South American Free Trade Area. Last month in Miami, hemispheric leaders agreed to negotiate during the next decade the formation of a free-trade area that would stretch from Alaska to Argentina. **********As President-elect, Mr. Cardozo visited the capitals of Brazil's three Mercosul partners in November. On Monday, his first day on the job, he was host at a meeting of the four Presidents of the southern market countries along with the Presidents of Chile and Bolivia, two neighbors that have promised to sign free-trade treaties with the Southern Common Market by June. **********"Let's forget a little about the 19th century and start looking at the 21st century," Bolivia's President, Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, said, referring to national barriers that split South America after independence from Spain and Portugal in the early 1800's. "There is a lot of enthusiasm for moving toward a united region, not separated by borders." **********By the end of this year, free-trade treaties are to link the southern market with the four remaining Spanish-speaking nations of the continent -- Peru, Ecuador, Colombia and Venezuela. **********"Peru's economy is already getting ready to join Mercosul in two or three years," Peru's President, Alberto K. Fujimori, said after meeting with President Cardozo here on Monday. **********Betting on the duty-free zone, Bolivia is promoting a plan to supply natural gas to the region. Under this plan, pipelines are to built over the next five years from Bolivia to Brazil, to Paraguay and to northern Chile. A gas line already links Bolivia and Argentina.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/12/busin.main_headline: Argentina, a Victim of Mexico's Fall, Tries to Recover
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/12/busin.print_headline: Argentina, a Victim of Mexico's Fall, Tries to Recover
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/12/busin.body_text: **********ARGENTINA isn't Mexico. But Domingo Cavallo, Argentina's finance minister, has had a hard time trying to convince investors and creditors that his nation is really different. **********Since Mexico surprised the financial markets in December by devaluing the peso, the ripple effect has been felt throughout Latin America -- and nowhere more so than in Argentina. The country's once-vibrant economy is threatened by recession as credit dries up, foreign investors take flight and Argentines pull their money out of banks. **********Until a rebound on Friday, fueled largely by the announcement of Mexico's austerity plan, Argentine stocks dropped roughly 38 percent since the Mexican devaluation on Dec. 20. Additionally, an estimated $3 billion of deposits has been withdrawn from Argentine banks. Recently, four banks were forced to close for lack of funds, and the Government has cobbled together emergency support for other endangered banks, hoping to prevent a collapse. **********Mr. Cavallo said last week that his Government would seek another $2 billion from the International Monetary Fund. The new request comes just a week after Argentina said it needed $420 million from the I.M.F. to supply funds to its strapped banks. After Mexico, it does seem as though the next currency ripe for devaluation is Argentina's peso. **********On numerous trips to the United States and Europe this year, Mr. Cavallo has tried to assure investors and bankers with two messages: Argentina is on more solid economic footing than Mexico, and there is more discipline in his country's exchange-rate system, which should blunt speculation. **********In the last four years, Argentina's growth rate -- roughly 7 percent annually -- has been far higher than Mexico's. Argentina's current-account deficit, though rising, is proportionately far less than that of Mexico, which reached 7.6 percent of gross domestic product last year. And inflation in Argentina, once a textbook case of hyperinflation, has dropped to less than 5 percent. **********Much of the improvement here dates from April 1991, when the Argentine Congress passed the "Convertibility Act," which pegs the peso tightly to the dollar at a one-to-one ratio. Under the convertibility plan, every Argentine peso in circulation is backed by a dollar reserve in the central bank. Mexico had no such fixed system. **********In a recent interview with Telem, a local news agency, Mr. Cavallo blamed speculators for growing hysteria and pressure on Argentina to devalue. He insisted that no Argentine economy indicator justified the steady losses on the stock market. **********"The economic signs are very positive, and I hope market operators in Argentina as well as abroad will see this and will reverse the climate of panic or terror that is being installed here," Mr. Cavallo said. **********The first signs of a squeeze on Argentina's economy appeared early last year when interest rates in the United States and Europe began rising. That made Western investors more likely to keep money in their home markets, slowing the inflow of foreign capital to Argentina and other developing nations. But Argentina was hit hard when the Mexican financial crisis prompted many foreign fund managers and investors to pull out of Latin America. The decline in foreign investment is expected to stunt economic growth in Argentina and reduce tax revenue, raising questions about whether the country can meet its debt payments. **********In an interview last week, Mr. Cavallo insisted that Argentina's debt payments of $5.2 billion would be made on time this year and that the funds had already been allocated. "Any statements saying that we are not going to meet payments are false," Mr. Cavallo said. **********Asked if a recession might arise from the lack of liquidity, Mr. Cavallo said that there would be "a decrease in production" in 1995 but "not a strong recession." **********Economists now predict that with the loss of foreign investment and the credit crunch, Argentina will post no growth this year and may even shrink slightly, compared with earlier forecasts of as much as 6 percent growth. **********The real threat in Argentina, economists say, is less of capital flight in the traditional sense than an old-fashioned run on the banks. Argentina's convertibility system is intended to make conventional currency speculation pointless. **********But bank withdrawals are running so high because depositors -- both Argentines and some foreigners -- are afraid that the banking system could collapse. Local bankers here report that many Argentines are withdrawing dollars from their savings accounts and placing them in safety deposit boxes or under mattresses at home. **********In the past, Argentina relied on foreign investments to balance its trade accounts, paying for its imports and other obligations from abroad. Yet with foreign investment declining, Argentina has been forced to adopt an austerity package to avoid what Mr. Cavallo has called "the unthinkable -- devaluation." **********The Finance Minister announced the austerity program two weeks ago. The main elements are $1 billion in budget cuts and a drive to generate another $2.5 billion in revenue by eliminating tax deductions and cracking down on tax evaders. The measures are intended to help close a projected budget deficit of $4.5 billion this year. **********Most economists and financial analysts here believe that Mr. Cavallo will stand by his word and not devalue the peso, despite the growing pressure on the currency. Were Mr. Cavallo forced to reconsider, a devaluation would require approval of Argentina's Congress. Any devaluation, analysts say, would certainly not occur before the Presidential elections in May. **********Most economists and analysts believe that the inherent strength of Argentina's economy should make it possible for Mr. Cavallo to avoid a devaluation. But the skittishness of depositors and investors, both at home and abroad, after the Mexican collapse could make it all the harder to stay on course. And the jump of nearly 13 percent in the Argentine stock market on Friday shows, for better or worse, how much investors still link Argentina's fortunes to those of Mexico. **********"It's been a long, difficult haul trying to persuade people that things are stable and Argentina is different from Mexico," said Christopher Eccelstone, an analyst for Interacciones, a brokerage firm here. "What's happening is that everybody got it wrong on Mexico and they are trying to make sure that they don't get it wrong again on Argentina."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/18/world.main_headline: U.S. Utilities Helping Czechs to Curb Greenhouse Gases and Air Pollutants
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/18/world.print_headline: U.S. Utilities Helping Czechs to Curb Greenhouse Gases and Air Pollutants
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/18/world.body_text: **********Here in the heart of one of Europe's most polluted regions, three American utility companies are embarking on a project that environmentalists hope will show the world a new way to reduce the greenhouses gases that are believed to be altering the world's climate. **********The utilities are to break ground on Monday for a gas-fired power plant to replace a coal-burning plant that has been spewing heat-trapping gases and poisons into the air since it was built in 1980. **********The plant, which will supply heat and hot water to apartments housing about 4,000 people and contribute a small amount of electricity to the local grid, is minuscule by world standards. But scattered across Central and Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union are about 80,000 dirty power plants like the one here, and if this experiment is successful, it is likely to be copied. **********"This is the first project of its kind in the world," the United States Energy Secretary, Hazel O'Leary, said at a news conference in Prague. "It's the model. You need one or two successes, and then others will come." **********The project is one of the first concrete results of decisions made at the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro and a follow-up meeting in Berlin this year. **********At the Berlin meeting, most of the world's countries accepted a new concept called "joint implementation," under which governments and companies can receive credit toward their domestic pollution reduction targets by sponsoring projects abroad. **********"Greenhouse gases don't respect political boundaries," said Roger Dower of the World Resources Institute, an environmental group that will serve as an independent monitor to try to insure that projected reductions in pollution here are achieved. "We're moving into a new era where we not only understand the importance of this issue, but we're also coming up with some creative and promising solutions." **********The announcement of the project came after mounting evidence that global warming is continuing and that pollution is part of the reason. **********Under the accord signed in Rio, industrial nations are seeking to lower their levels of greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels by 2000. **********American officials have concluded that the United States will fall short of that goal, but they have embraced the idea of "joint implementation" as a strategy that could have even greater effect. **********The United States has not yet enacted a law allowing utilities to count their pollution reductions abroad against reductions they would otherwise be expected to achieve at home. But many utility executives predict that such a law may be enacted in the years ahead, and are seeking experience in ways to cut emissions abroad. **********And American utilities are actively seeking markets in the developing world, from which almost all of the future increase in demand for electric power is likely to come. **********The utilities behind the Decin project -- Wisconsin Electric Power Company, a unit of the Wisconsin Energy Corporation; Nipsco Industries of Indiana, and Commonwealth Edison of Illinois, a unit of the Unicom Corporation -- are hoping that their work here will position them for future contracts in the Czech Republic and elsewhere if emissions of pollutants and of gases like carbon dioxide are restricted. **********Decin, a town of 55,000 in northern Bohemia, is in the heart of the "black triangle," a highly polluted region that includes corners of Poland and the former East Germany as well as the Czech Republic. The incidence of respiratory ailments and malignant tumors in Decin is more than 50 percent higher than in the rest of the Czech Republic, and diseases during pregnancy are four times as frequent. **********"These levels would have to qualify us as an environmental disaster area," said Milan Kunc, 29, the Mayor of Decin, who has been a driving force behind the project. "We now see the possibility of confronting this problem, and at the same time contributing to the global environment." **********The new 10.6-megawatt plant in Decin is to cost $7 million to build. The Czech Government is paying most of the cost, with the American utilities putting up $600,000 and the Danish Government contributing a similar sum. **********Gas will come from Russia, through a 10-mile spur that will be built off a pipeline that runs nearby. When it comes on line next September, the new plant will emit 31 percent less greenhouse gas than the old one, Secretary O'Leary said. She said there would also be a 90 percent drop in sulfur dioxide emissions and complete elimination of particulate and coal ash emissions. **********At the old plant, which is still running, mountains of soft lignite coal are piled outside. The coal is carried by a conveyer belt into a blazing furnace. Outside, the air is pungent and faintly nauseating. **********This is one of four such plants in Decin, all of which are to be replaced by gas-fired plants by 2000. **********"Conditions here have gotten a little better since 1990, but we still don't have any healthy children here," said Josef Charouzd, the plant manager. **********"Before 1990, parents didn't allow their children to play outside at all between November and March, because the air was so bad," Mr. Charouzd said. "Both of my own kids have serious asthma. They cough and have seizures. But with the new plant being built, I think we can hope that their children will live in a much cleaner environment. **********"There's only one bad aspect of this project. The new plant will take only 5 people to operate, not 35 like this one. I'm hoping I'll be one of the five."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/09/busin.main_headline: Chiron and Ciba-Geigy in Collaboration With N.Y.U.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/09/busin.print_headline: Chiron and Ciba-Geigy in Collaboration With N.Y.U.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/09/busin.body_text: **********The Chiron Corporation and Ciba-Geigy Ltd. said yesterday that they would collaborate with New York University on the development of a new approach for the optical mapping and sequencing of genes. **********Mapping is the process of locating specific genes on the human genome; sequencing is the spelling out of each gene's makeup. With more than 4,000 human genetic diseases and many more in which genetic predisposition plays a role, acquiring genetic information has enormous potential for developing new diagnostic tests and drugs. **********Under the agreement, Chiron has obtained an exclusive worldwide license to the technology, with the right to sublicense and commercialize resulting products, in exchange for an initial payment of $5 million and potential royalty and milestone payments to the university. **********Ciba is making an initial payment of an undisclosed size and has been granted a sublicense by Chiron to use the technology for research purposes. **********Coming a week after Ciba said it would invest up to $60 million in Myriad Genetics Inc. of Salt Lake City, this agreement is further indication that the Swiss company intends to take a leading role in genomics, the effort to find and spell out every human gene, with the purpose of identifying new targets for medical treatment. **********Optical mapping involves selective cutting of DNA and gene sequences into defined lengths to create a pattern that helps characterize genomes and identify individual genes. The technology, invented by David Schwartz, a professor of chemistry at New York University, makes it possible to construct gene maps quickly and to discover new genetic sequences for use as targets in developing novel drugs, vaccines and diagnostic products. **********Chiron shares closed yesterday at $52.25, up 50 cents, in Nasdaq trading. In November, Ciba acquired a 49.9 percent stake in Chiron, a leading biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif. Analysts said the agreement with New York University should be regarded as a long-term investment that could provide new leads for Chiron's diagnostics business within a few years. **********The N.Y.U. technology "is really fabulous stuff," said Paul Boni, an analyst with Mehta & Isaly. The direct method of mapping genes is potentially much faster than the indirect methods now used, he said, and "if the technology can be extended to sequencing, then you would have something really revolutionary. But there are several tough steps in between." **********Mickey Urdea, Chiron's vice president of research and development, said the technology would speed the company's discovery of new drugs and diagnostic targets. In addition, Chiron will sell the instruments and reagents needed for the process to others. "We see this as a means to screen a series of interesting molecules simultaneously," he said. **********Genome mapping is currently done by pouring large quantities of DNA onto gels that are then exposed to an electromagnetic field. The process is slow, costly and hard to automate. Professor Schwartz's technique can be applied to single DNA molecules, without gels, using readily available enzymes and dies to delineate particular gene sequences. Because of its lower cost and higher speed, the process should facilitate mapping of whole individual genomes for large segments of the population. **********Professor Schwartz said he expected to begin mapping individual genomes within a year. "Optical-mapping technology is a powerful platform for ultrarapid, high-resolution, whole-genome analysis that will find application in virtually every branch of biological science," he said. "This is actually very complementary to any of the efforts to sequence human genes."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/21/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Yankees, Phone Home!; GTE Role in Venezuela Is Warning on Privatization
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/21/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Yankees, Phone Home!; GTE Role in Venezuela Is Warning on Privatization
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/21/busin.body_text: **********In the three years since Venezuela's creaky state telephone company was privatized, the new American managers have increased the number of lines by 50 percent, doubled international circuits and quadrupled the number of working pay phones. **********So, Venezuelans have been heaping praise and honor on the country's largest single foreign investment, right? **********Not exactly. In the same three years, Bruce E. Haddad, president of a consortium led by the GTE Corporation of the United States that runs Venezuela's Cantv phone company, has been arrested once, called to testify before congressional committees 23 times and has faced marches by union workers chanting "Gringos out of Cantv." Last year, Government bureaucrats suddenly refused to allow his company to buy dollars, forcing it to default on millions of dollars in overseas loans. **********Through it all, Mr. Haddad -- who is also president of Cantv -- has remained upbeat. "You have to take a long-term view, you have to expect ups and downs," said the 41-year-old Florida native and longtime executive of GTE's telephone company in the Dominican Republic. **********Venezuela has one of Latin America's rockiest economic environments, but GTE's experience here serves as a warning to American business about the hazards of operating in a region that is starting to open politically sensitive public utilities to foreign investment. **********From Mexico to Brazil to Argentina, Latin American countries are seeking foreign investors to run former government monopolies like power generation and telecommunications. As American companies take up the task, they are sometimes encountering echoes of the nationalist passions that led to widespread seizures of foreign-owned utilities in the 1960's and 1970's. **********And with Venezuela's economy heading for the worst performance in Latin America for the second year running, Yankee capitalists have become a convenient scapegoat for a left-wing Government that is widely blamed for economic mismanagement. **********At the very least, as GTE has discovered, running a public utility with 2.3 million subscribers can be vastly more complicated, and certainly more politically sensitive, than building cars or selling soap. **********Venworld, the GTE-led consortium, paid $1.9 billion for a 35-year-controlling concession of Venezuela's telephone company in 1991. The president at the time, Carlos Andres Perez, was a free-market advocate who welcomed the foreign involvement. **********Since then, Venezuela has gone through two coup attempts, four changes of government and seven communications ministers. Rafael Caldera, Venezuela's current president, often follows policies at odds with those of Mr. Perez, his lifelong political rival. **********"There are still people in Congress debating whether Cantv should have been privatized to begin with," said Joseph A. Mann, editor of Political Impact, a newsletter here. "The Government should go out of its way to help Cantv. But I think that Caldera firmly believes that the company should be in the hands of the Government." **********Last year, without a political godfather, Cantv repeatedly became embroiled in conflicts with Mr. Caldera's new administration. After the Government imposed exchange controls one year ago, the company found itself far down a long list of businesses seeking to buy dollars. **********"While 98 percent of our revenues were in local currency, 95 percent of our debt payments were dollar-denominated," Mr. Haddad recalled. **********With leftists initially controlling the Government currency board, which must approve foreign-exchange transactions, the American-controlled telephone company was promptly cut off from access to dollars. **********"I granted two hours of my time to listen to the petition of the president and vice president of the company," Ivan Pulido Mora, then board coordinator, petulantly told reporters last August in response to questions about Cantv's foreign-exchange requests. **********Although telecommunications has been a rare growth sector of Venezuela's troubled economy, the foreign-exchange problem took almost a year to resolve. In May, the company renegotiated its debt to 40 foreign banks, winning a Government guarantee of near-automatic access to dollars to service the debt. **********The disruptions -- and Venezuela's general economic slump -- caused Cantv to slash its capital investment plan by 40 percent, to $408 million this year. Even with this reduction, Cantv investments will total $2.4 billion for the first four years of private operation, 10 times the $239 million invested during the last three years of public ownership. In addition to GTE, Cantv's controlling consortium of private investors includes AT&T, Telefonica de Espana, Banco Mercantil and Electricidad de Caracas. **********Relations with the Government took another nasty turn last August when Cantv briefly cut off 80 percent of Government ministry telephone lines for nonpayment of Government telephone bills totaling $100 million. Since then, the unpaid debt has stopped growing, partly because officials allowed Cantv to install pay phones in Government buildings for public employees to make personal calls, cutting down on the monthly bills. **********"We now have people in Government that we can deal with," Mr. Haddad said, noting that the Government now routinely approves requests for dollars and for rate increases based on inflation. "This is not some financial play -- this is a long-term commitment." **********In addition to sometimes hostile politicians, the American managers have had to cope with a xenophobic labor unions. From the outset, union leaders opposed privatization, to the extent of trying to disrupt the ceremony granting the foreign investors the telephone concession in 1991. Led by the Radical Cause Party, the unions have also tried to block GTE's merit-based management system, preferring the political criteria that prevailed in the old state-company days. **********"The Cantv multinationals raise rates and oppress workers," read one union poster showing a malevolent Uncle Sam figure pointing a pistol at passersby. **********Despite the union problems, Cantv managed to negotiate a favorable deal. Two weeks ago, after seven months of negotiations, the company signed a new general contract giving it greater flexibility in setting hours and shifts and in defining the duties of the company's 12,000 unionized employees. **********Last week, Venworld announced that Gustavo Roosen, a Venezuelan businessman with close links to the Caldera administration, would become Cantv's chairman. At the end of June, Mr. Haddad is to move to Irving, Tex., to work as international vice president for GTE Telephone Operations, the GTE subsidiary that oversees the Venezuela operation. He will continue as president of Cantv. **********While Venezuela's Government and unions often have treated the American company managers roughly, Venezuela's public is increasingly pleased with the service they provide. With the average wait for a dial tone down to three seconds, customer satisfaction has hit about 80 percent, up from around 30 percent before privatization, Cantv surveys show. **********Beyond political issues, Cantv's management has had to cope with Venezuela's roller-coaster economy. **********After booming in the early 1990's, Venezuela recorded South America's worst economic performance in 1994. In a repeat this year, Venezuela is expected to record the continent's highest inflation -- about 70 percent -- and its only shrinking economy, a contraction of roughly 2 percent. **********In last year's economic chaos, half of the banking sector collapsed. This year, the cash-short Government has fallen into arrears on its foreign debt payments and is expected to take over three failing insurance companies. **********At Cantv, though, it is a different story: Its results are expected to swing back into the black from a 1994 loss of $220 million. **********"We firmly believe that the long- term prospects for Cantv are excellent," a recent Salomon Brothers report read. "Venezuela's current economic problems will not last forever." **********With oil revenues expected to be 20 percent lower than last year, the Government's budget deficit is heading toward 10 percent of the country's gross domestic product. And with foreign interest fading, the nation's privatization program has virtually stopped. **********Although the Government planned to raise $1.5 billion this year by selling most of its remaining shares in Cantv, sales have been indefinitely suspended because of lack of investor interest. Although large mining companies are scheduled for sale, some foreign investors say they are staying away, citing Venezuela's exchange and price controls and the Government's rough treatment of Cantv. **********"I just don't understand it," one American mining executive here said, shaking his head. "The Government should have given Cantv special treatment as an example for other companies interested in privatizations."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/02/busin.main_headline: AMSTRONG WORLD PLANS THE MERGER OF TILE CONCERNS
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/02/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; AMSTRONG WORLD PLANS THE MERGER OF TILE CONCERNS
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/02/busin.body_text: **********Armstrong World Industries said yesterday that it intended to merge the American Olean Tile Company, its wholly owned subsidiary, with Dal-Tile International Inc. After the merger, Dal-Tile, a Dallas-based maker of ceramic tiles, will be the surviving entity, with Armstrong holding a "significant minority" stake. Terms were not disclosed. Armstrong said it would have the opportunity to increase its holdings in the future. Dal-Tile's controlling shareholder will remain AEA Investors Inc., the company's management and shareholder group. Dal-Tile manufactures ceramic tiles at seven sites in North America. American Olean of Lansdale, Pa., has ceramic tile factories in five United States locations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/30/busin.main_headline: International Briefs; Midsize Car From Fiat
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/30/busin.print_headline: International Briefs; Midsize Car From Fiat
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/30/busin.body_text: **********Fiat, the Italian auto maker, introduced a midsize car yesterday that it hopes will break the European dominance of Volkswagen, General Motors and Ford Motor. The introduction of the new car line, which is being marketed under the names Bravo and Brava, is being marked by 10 days of events in Turin, Italy, Fiat's home. Bravo is a two-door sporty sedan aimed at young professionals, while the five-door Brava hatchback is being marketed to the family travel segment. The company hopes to sell 350,000 of the two models a year, split equally between Italy and abroad. (AP)

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/07/busin.main_headline: OWENS-CORNING TO GET CASH FOR ASBESTOS CLAIMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/07/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; OWENS-CORNING TO GET CASH FOR ASBESTOS CLAIMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/07/busin.body_text: **********The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation said yesterday that it had confirmed access to $330 million of insurance coverage to pay asbestos claims related to its former insulation contracting business. The building products company, based in Toledo, Ohio, said the settlement with an unidentified insurer would provide enough cash to cover 80 percent of its liability through 1999. The deal would also allow Owens-Corning to buy more insurance through 2007. Nonproducts insurance covers asbestos-exposure claims made by former installers, unlike product-hazard insurance coverage. Owens-Corning shares rose $3.75, or 9 percent, to $43.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/12/world.main_headline: Yeltsin Taken To Hospital Suffering Heart Pain
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/12/world.print_headline: Yeltsin Taken To Hospital Suffering Heart Pain
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/12/world.body_text: **********President Boris N. Yeltsin, whose visibly declining health has long provoked speculation here, was rushed to the hospital today with what his press service described as "acute" heart pains. **********Within hours the Kremlin began issuing statements saying that the 64-year-old President was "fully in control," that he would continue with his work while in the hospital, and that his pains had subsided. **********Doctors said Mr. Yeltsin had had an attack of ischemia, which means that the heart is not getting all the oxygenated blood it needs. Caused by an accumulation of plaque blocking a coronary artery, it can be a relatively minor affliction or it can be the first step in a severe heart attack. A large number of Americans suffer from coronary blockage but may not have symptoms, and a smaller number experience pain from ischemia resulting from the blockage. **********"Judging by the first data from Boris Yeltsin's examination, nothing serious has happened to him," said the presidential spokesman, Sergei K. Medvedev, who did not make the data public. "He continues to fulfill his constitutional duties." **********In a statement released in Moscow tonight, Mr. Medvedev said: "The patient is active. He gets up from his bed. There have been no recurrences of pain in recent hours." **********The feverishness with which the Presidential Press Service put out the word that Mr. Yeltsin suffered no serious damage was highly unusual. Normally -- and this has been particularly true with Mr. Yeltsin's health problems over the years -- the public is told little about the illnesses of Russian leaders. **********Many politicians -- including Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, who would carry out Mr. Yeltsin's duties if the need arose, and Ivan P. Rybkin, the Speaker of Parliament -- emphasized the minor nature of Mr. Yeltsin's ailment today. And there was no reason to doubt them. The President signed official documents during the day, according to his press spokesman, and he has no plans to cancel a scheduled trip to the Russian Far North and to Norway next week. **********But at 64, there can be few more obvious candidates for a heart attack than Mr. Yeltsin. He has already lived five years longer than the average Russian man, he has high blood pressure and is overweight, and his job is among the most stressful in the world. Although he tries to play tennis as often as possible, he rarely plays for long, and his face shows the wear of the years during which he has led the country. **********Mr. Yeltsin has been seen stumbling frequently in the last year, and many published reports refer to his heavy drinking. Unlike many Russians, however, he does not smoke. **********"He has all the classic signs that would point to heart disease," said Dr. George Goy, an American doctor based here at the clinic recently opened by Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. "It's going to slow him down. And if he doesn't slow down, he could be in for trouble." **********Mr. Yeltsin's health problems are inevitably linked to his political leadership of the nation. He is by far the most important politician in Russia, but he has never been less popular. The bitter war for Chechnya has largely been attributed to him, a recent no-confidence vote in Parliament was essentially seen as a message to the President, and he now rarely appears in public or on television. **********When the war began in December, Mr. Yeltsin was hospitalized for an undisclosed problem with his nose. He appeared in public only once during the first few weeks after he sent 40,000 troops into the secessionist republic. Any serious physical setback for Mr. Yeltsin now would have a significant impact on Russian politics and the reform program. Mr. Chernomyrdin -- a solemn ex-Soviet industrialist -- has become far more popular than his boss, in part because he has been seen as the biggest force behind negotiations for peace in Chechnya.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/22/busin.body_text: **********The Enron Corporation plans to build a $545 million natural gas-burning power plant in Marmara, Turkey. Enron will run the project and own half the plant, which should be completed by 1997, the company's chairman and chief executive, Kenneth L. Lay, said. Enron said Midlands Electricity P.L.C. of England will own 31 percent of the plant, while Gama, a Turkish company, will own 10 percent and the Wing Group of Aspen, Colo., will hold 9 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/19/busin.main_headline: International Briefs; Pearson Profit Falls; Special Charges Cited
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/19/busin.print_headline: International Briefs; Pearson Profit Falls; Special Charges Cited
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/19/busin.body_text: **********The British media company Pearson P.L.C. posted a 27 percent decline in pretax profit yesterday for the first six months of the year, partly the result of one-time reorganization expenses. Pearson reported some weakness in advertising for its main publication, The Financial Times newspaper. Also, textbook sales in the United States were slow, as were British sales of its Penguin line of books. **********The company reported pretax profit of $:50.5 million, about $78 million, compared with $:69.3 million in the first half of 1994. Pearson reported a charge of $:10.4 million from a revamping of printing operations, and said the 1994 period had included a one-time gain of $:8.5 million. Without one-time items, Pearson said its profit would have grown 6 percent, to $:71.4 million. Revenues rose 20 percent, to $:781 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/04/busin.main_headline: Europe-U.S. Team Bids on Rocket Designs
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/04/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Europe-U.S. Team Bids on Rocket Designs
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/04/busin.body_text: **********Taking advantage of the United States Government's new willingness to allow greater foreign participation in building its rockets, the European consortium Arianespace is bidding with an American partner on a $2 billion contract to design a new family of rockets. **********The launching vehicles, which will be constructed for the United States Air Force, are designed to lift spy satellites and other payloads into orbit for the Government. **********Arianespace, which has dominated the commercial space-launching business in recent years, made its move as a member of a team led by Alliant Techsystems, an aerospace and technology company based in Minneapolis. Two weeks ago, the team bid for the Air Force contract to design launchers that would be the core of the nation's unmanned rocket fleet starting early in the next century. **********The Air Force program is the first big effort to develop a family of launching vehicles to replace the current fleet of Atlas, Titan and Delta rockets, whose design was largely based on 1950's technology. The program comes as once-nationalistic space programs, with jealously guarded technological secrets, give way to international consortiums engaged in global technology transfers. **********The bid is a big development in the highly competitive and strategically important rocket launching business, and it gives Arianespace a shot at a market that is currently dominated by its archrival, the Lockheed Martin Corporation. **********The United States has maintained a strict policy of launching military and other Government payloads on American rockets only, shutting out Arianespace as well as Russian and Chinese launchers. But with the new program, Washington has effectively opened the door to more extensive foreign participation, allowing a group like Arianespace to contribute a significant amount of the rocket's components. **********Before this development, Lockheed Martin, which makes the Atlas and Titan rockets, was given the bulk of United States Government business. That steady stream of work helped Lockheed Martin remain competitive as the European consortium grew to dominate the commercial-launching business, primarily handling telecommunications satellites. **********Evan McCollum, a spokesman for Lockheed Martin Astronautics, declined to comment beyond saying that the company was also bidding on the new project. **********But in a sign of the breakdown of the industry's once-inviolate national bent, Lockheed Martin is likely to have incorporated foreign technology into its proposals in the form of engines or other hardware from Russia, industry executives said. Lockheed sells Russia's powerful Proton rocket to commercial users in the West and has close ties to that nation's launching industry. **********Further underscoring the rapid changes in the industry, a top Russian aerospace executive said in Moscow on Friday that the United States was close to dropping the quota it had placed on Russian launchings of commercial satellites containing American technology. Anatoly Kiselyov, the general director of the Krunichev rocket factory, told reporters after a visit to the plant by Vice President Al Gore that the move would allow the venture between Lockheed and Proton's Russian manufacturers to book additional launchings beyond the eight up to 1999 that the United States had previously agreed to permit. **********The new American program, known as the Evolved Expendable Launch Vehicle, is intended to upgrade the current fleet of Atlas, Titan and McDonnell Douglas Delta rockets, all of which were originally built to carry nuclear warheads. **********A number of other aerospace companies are believed to have made proposals, although the Air Force declined to say how many it has received or to identify any bidders. Initial development contracts are scheduled to be awarded to as many as three or four bidders in August, with the final selection of a single winner still several years away. **********The Pentagon is not formally changing its buy-American policy, and in becoming a key subcontractor to Alliant, Arianespace is effectively giving up on cracking the United States Government market on its own. **********But Alliant and the European consortium are taking advantage of a greater willingness on the part of the Pentagon to allow its rocket makers to seek foreign technology and partners if doing so will result in lower costs and greater reliability. **********Richard Schwartz, Alliant's chief executive, said Arianespace would provide the program with its liquid-fueled, or cryogenic, stage -- the main booster, providing most of the power on rockets capable of carrying the largest spy satellites and other heavy payloads into orbit. **********The Arianespace cryogenic stage is now in the final stages of development and is the core of the new Ariane V launcher, scheduled to fly for the first time later this year. Under Alliant's proposal, the European Vulcain engine would be used in conjunction with upgraded solid-rocket boosters built for the Air Force's Titan program by Alliant's Aerospace Systems group, which encompasses the former Hercules Aerospace, an engine maker acquired by Alliant earlier this year. For small and medium-sized payloads, the Alliant proposal would use all solid boosters. **********"The Europeans have already developed this vehicle and spent a lot of money on it," Mr. Schwartz said. Combined with Alliant's recently upgraded solid motors, "you can form a system with low nonrecurring costs and significantly lower the cost per launch," he said. **********If its bid was eventually accepted, the Alliant team would most likely obtain a license for the European technology. The engine would then be built in the United States. The European engine and its associated hardware are built primarily by two French companies, Aerospatiale and Societe Europeene de Propulsion. **********Although the new program's primary aim is to upgrade the American military's launching capabilities, it also has the goal of promoting the development of a more competitive American commercial launching industry by improving reliability and driving down production and launching costs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/13/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; F.C.C. Backs Digital Satellite Radio
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/13/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Communications Commission allocated a portion of the airwaves today for satellite radio broadcasting, a new class of services that would use satellites to beam programs directly to listeners' radios nationwide and compete with local AM and FM stations. **********But the arrival of "digital audio radio service" -- or D.A.R.S. -- is still several years away, in part because some commission officials worry about undermining conventional broadcasters and must still define the rules under which the satellite services are allowed to operate. **********Four companies have applied for licenses to offer satellite radio broadcasting and hope to begin in 1998. As envisioned, the satellites would beam dozens of channels of radio programming in digital form that matches the clarity of compact disks, well exceeding that of FM and especially AM stations. **********But conventional broadcasters have lobbied intensively against such services for years, arguing that satellite broadcasting would destroy "localism" by undermining the business of local stations that serve individual communities. That argument has been successful: though the F.C.C. first began discussing satellite radio four years ago, it has moved with glacial slowness. **********Even today, several commissioners expressed concern about harming conventional radio broadcasters and said they wanted to draft service rules to keep that from happening. **********Commissioner Andrew C. Barrett said that the agency had "an obligation to carefully evaluate the risk of economic harm that D.A.R.S. may present to existing terrestrial radio, and ultimately to local radio service." **********The four satellite radio companies hoping to start services praised today's action. "This is the big one, the decision to create a service called satellite CD radio and to zone the land for it," said David Margolies, chairman of CD Radio Inc., a start-up company in Washington that first asked the F.C.C. to approve the service four years ago. Mr. Margolies said his company could begin offering service about three years after it received a license. **********The other three companies that have applied for satellite radio licenses are American Mobile Radio Inc., a company owned in large part by Hughes Aircraft, a unit of the General Motors Corporation; Primosphere Inc., a start-up company based in New York, and the Digital Satellite Broadcasting Corporation, a start-up based in Seattle. **********Conventional radio broadcasters feel threatened by the new services in part because it is hard for them to switch to the clearer digital transmission technology. Several companies are working on technologies that might allow broadcasters to transmit both digital and the current analog systems in the FM radio band, but the industry has yet to agree on a technical standard. **********Local stations also fear the nationwide reach of satellite radio, which could capture both listeners and a share of their advertising. **********The National Association of Broadcasters, a trade group, denounced today's action and said it would try to block satellite radio broadcasting from reaching the marketplace.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/09/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; SEACOR HOLDINGS IN DEAL WITH JOHN E. GRAHAM
