https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/22/world.main_headline: Outcry Mounts In Philippines Over Hanging
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/22/world.print_headline: Outcry Mounts In Philippines Over Hanging
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/22/world.body_text: **********President Fidel V. Ramos appealed to the nation today for "sanity and sobriety" as outraged Filipinos stepped up protests across the country over the execution last week of a Filipino maid in Singapore. **********The protests have alarmed the Singapore Government, which today issued a formal protest over the burning of its flags here. Singapore has also urged its citizens to avoid travel to the Philippines. **********The execution of Flor Contemplacion, who was convicted in Singapore of the murder of another Filipino maid and a 4-year-old Singaporean child, has made Mrs. Contemplacion into a martyr to the cause of migrant workers' rights. Nearly 75,000 Filipinos work in Singapore, most as household maids or in other menial jobs. **********Mrs. Contemplacion was hanged despite appeals from President Ramos, who asked for a delay in the execution in light of new testimony suggesting that she was framed. **********The testimony came from another Filipino maid who said that the Singaporean boy died in an accidental drowning and that the maid was murdered by the boy's vengeful father, who blamed her in the drowning. Singapore prosecutors said that the new testimony was untrue, and that Mrs. Contemplacion's conviction was based on her confession. **********Leading politicians and labor organizations in the Philippines announced a new round of protests over the execution today and urged Filipinos to boycott Singaporean products. To protect the Manila offices of Singapore Airlines from attack, the landlord today posted a sign saying, "This building is owned by Filipinos." **********While Mr. Ramos had earlier declared Mrs. Contemplacion a national heroine whose death "will not be in vain," he warned at a meeting with reporters here today in Manila that "the tragic death of Flor Contemplacion" has been "used by some people to promote their political interests." **********"I hope that sanity and sobriety will be restored in due time, and the sooner, the better, because the country has to move forward." said Mr. Ramos, whose administration has been criticized for doing too little to help Mrs. Contemplacion and the more than 2 million other Filipinos who work abroad. **********Protest organizers have vowed to organize a series of demonstrations throughout the country, culminating with the largest on Sunday, when Mrs. Contemplacion's body is to be buried in her hometown of San Pablo, south of Manila. **********There were protests in several cities and provinces today. The mayor of Davao, a city of a million people on the southern island of Mindanao, led about 1,000 city employees Monday in burning a Singaporean flag. The mayor, Rodrigo Duterte, urged Filipinos in Davao not to accept Singaporean investments and called for a boycott of Singaporean goods.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/21/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; An unusual hybrid agency seeks to cross-pollinate campaigns on each side of the Atlantic.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/21/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; An unusual hybrid agency seeks to cross-pollinate campaigns on each side of the Atlantic.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/21/busin.body_text: **********A LEADING British creative team and a small American agency are joining forces for an unusual, potentially innovative venture: forming allied agencies based in London and New York to work both sides of the Atlantic. **********Steve Grounds, a copywriter, and Rob Morris, an art director, who have spent 10 years together creating award-winning campaigns for advertisers like Citroen, Tambrands and the Wilson Sporting Goods Company, are teaming with Martin H. Landey, chairman and chief executive of Cox Landey & Partners, a New York agency with $35 million in billings from accounts like the Eastman Kodak Company, Hartmarx and the Hearst Corporation. **********In New York, Cox Landey will be renamed Landey & Partners, Grounds Morris; in London, a new agency will be opened as Grounds Morris, Landey & Partners. The three executives will be partners and hold equity stakes in both shops, which will work in tandem using $50,000 to $80,000 in high-tech gadgets like linked computers, videoconference equipment and a dedicated line for a service known as I.S.D.N., or integrated services digital network, which carries voice or data signals. And of course, when clients insist upon more personal contact, there are always airplanes. **********"American advertising is stuck in a rut," said Mr. Landey, who takes the title of strategic planning partner at both agencies. "There's a world of talent and ideas." **********The concept of a partnership between trans-Atlantic agencies is not without its risks. There's the danger that the hybrid shops will serve only to reinforce George Bernard Shaw's observation that America and Britain are divided by a common language. Potential clients might worry that the logistical challenges faced by agencies divided by an ocean will leave them at sea. And Mr. Landey is restless in creative relationships, having worked with three creative executives in the last nine years. **********"You never know," Mr. Landey acknowledged. "A lot of it is chemistry; you have to get in bed together and see how it works." **********Mr. Grounds echoed his new partner. "You have to kiss a lot of frogs," he said, laughing. **********Still, the venture is emblematic of efforts by the agency industry to seek new paradigms to serve clients more effectively. Others include spinoffs of large agencies, affiliations between big and small shops and other two-continent initiatives like the plans of Leagas Delaney, a creatively focused London agency, to establish its first overseas office in the United States. **********"Ideally, what we'll do is bring some of what works in the U.K. to bear in the American market and learn from the American market as well," said Mr. Morris, 43. He and Mr. Grounds, 41, will be creative partners of both shops; for the last 13 months, since they resigned as joint creative directors of the London office of Euro RSCG, they have been freelancing in Norway, South Africa and Sweden. **********Mr. Morris said the difference between American and British advertising stemmed from "British creative people tending to bring a strong sense of humor to a central idea" and American creative talent tending "to be very, very direct to get to the point incredibly quickly." **********"That's great," he added of the American approach, but all too often "it's more of a hammer over the head." He can still recall the commercials that so startled him when he started visiting New York nearly 20 years ago -- the hard-sell spots for the JGE appliance retailer, featuring a shouting shill asking, "What's the story, Jerry?" **********Mr. Morris asserted, "There's a whole generation of Americans who don't want to be hit over the head." Mr. Landey agreed that American advertising was "too direct," and praised the "wonderfully humorous storytelling" abilities of his new partners "to persuade from a different point of view." **********The three executives were introduced by a British executive recruiter who knew the Britons were "thinking of relocating to America," Mr. Grounds said, because "we've always wanted to work there." They decided against that, he added, but "in the end we worked out a way" to work in the United States and continue living in Britain. **********Mr. Landey, who answers to 58, said he hoped Mr. Grounds and Mr. Morris would halt the turnover in creative executives with whom he has worked since a long-term relationship with Arnie Arlow ended more than a decade ago; Mr. Arlow is now the creative director on the Carillon Importers account at Margeotes Fertitta Donaher & Weiss in New York. **********"Can they deliver?" Mr. Landey asked of Mr. Grounds and Mr. Morris. "I have no question they can. The question is, can we make this work here? Can we in New York market this new capability effectively?" **********If not, he added, displaying what the British call taking it on the chin, "that will be our failure."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/06/busin.snippet:

Raymond Loewe, president of College Money in Marlton, N.J., suggested looking at ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/06/busin.main_headline:
SPENDING IT;
How to Be Ready for Those Giant Tuition Bills
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/06/busin.print_headline:
SPENDING IT;
How to Be Ready for Those Giant Tuition Bills
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/06/busin.body_text: **********FOR the average family, the thought of putting away hundreds, perhaps even thousands, of dollars every month until their children reach college age is overwhelming. **********Raymond Loewe, president of College Money in Marlton, N.J., suggested looking at the prospect another way. "Paying for college is like buying a house," he said. "No one pays for a house in cash." The larger the down payment, of course, the smaller the debt burden, which may carry well into retirement years. So it still is best to save as much as possible now. **********For those who feel they absolutely cannot spare much of their income for college savings, Mr. Loewe begins by taking out $25 a month, then keeps doubling up until the family can't bear any more. "It's amazing what people can save if they don't see the money," he said. **********But saving is only the beginning. The next important decision is whose name to put the money in. Since the "kiddie" tax was put into place in 1987, there has been little reason to put large amounts of money into accounts in your child's name. For a child under 14, the first $650 of income is tax free. The next $650 is taxed at 15 percent, but anything above that amount is taxed at the parents' rate. Furthermore, money saved in the child's name can disqualify the child for financial aid. Schools consider about a third of the child's assets to be available each year for college, but only about six percent of parents' assets, excluding retirement accounts and home equity, are considered available. **********And financial aid is not only for the impoverished. A family with one child in an expensive private college could receive financial aid even if its income is $100,000. So unless you are wealthy, it is best not to assume there will be no aid, at least until your child is 14. At that point you can do a financial aid test and determine whether you are better off leaving investments in your name or gradually giving them to your child, who, after age 14, will be taxed at his own income rate. **********Carol C. Pankros of CCP Inc., a financial adviser in Palatine, Ill., suggested putting no more than $10,000 in a child's name, not just because of financial aid, but also in case the child does not go to college. **********Grandparents should also think twice about giving money to their grandchildren. Better to make the gifts in the parents' names. Otherwise, the parents may end up shelling out money that might have come from financial aid. **********The next step is to decide how to invest college savings. For a young child, most experts agree that a majority of savings should go into equities where growth potential far outstrips that of fixed-income instruments. Jennifer Saslaw, a financial planner in Chicago, suggested 80 percent in equities until the child is 8 years old. At that point, one should trim stocks to 70 percent. Once the child is 14, it is important to slowly move assets into less volatile, fixed-income instruments to assure your capital is there at college time. Move it in tranches, the experts advise. Your child will be spending the money over at least four years. If you are seeking financial aid, remember that selling stock the year before your child goes to college will show up on your income statement as a capital gain. Since up to 47 percent of a parent's adjusted income is considered available for college, that gain will decrease the amount of aid you receive. **********Next, parents need to determine how to invest the money. Most advisers suggest mutual funds. While many parents and grandparents choose zero coupon bonds for college, these investments don't have the same growth potential of stocks. "The advantage is that you know how much you will have at the end of the time," Ms. Pankros said. But that security may cost you a lot in returns over 18 years of investing for college. The same goes for savings bonds. **********Another possibility is life insurance. Variable universal life insurance policies offer the ability to manage your savings in mutual funds. They also have the potential for huge tax savings, since the cash builds up in the policy while taxes are deferred. And you can borrow against the policy to pay for college without incurring taxes, as long as you never allow the policy to lapse. But you are borrowing against your future death benefit, so if you allow the policy to lapse before you die, you may be hit with an enormous tax bill when you least expect it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/03/busin.main_headline: Body Shop Reports Weak Sales in U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/03/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS; Body Shop Reports Weak Sales in U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/03/busin.body_text: **********Body Shop International P.L.C. disclosed yesterday that its sales in the United States had been torpid, and it predicted little profit growth this year. The company's chairman, T. Gordon Roddick, said the company, a British maker of natural beauty products, would slow the pace of United States store openings and increase spending on new products and advertising. **********Body Shop said pretax profit in the fiscal year rose 13 percent, to $:33.5 million ($53.5 million). But Body Shop said sales at American stores open at least a year fell 3 percent in the year ended Feb. 25. Since then, same-store sales across the United States have fallen 8 percent. The United States is the home of a fifth of Body Shop's 1,210 stores.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/15/busin.body_text: **********The Adelphia Communications Corporation has agreed, along with its Olympus Communications joint venture, to acquire several cable television systems for a total of about $124 million in cash. **********Olympus, a venture between Adelphia and FPL Group Inc., plans to buy Leadership Cable, a company that serves the West Palm Beach, Fla., area. In addition, Adelphia plans to buy the cable systems of the Eastern Telecom Corporation, which serves the Pittsburgh area, and First Carolina Cable TV L.P., which serves New England. **********Adelphia, a cable operator, is based in Coudersport. **********The systems to be bought serve a total of 108,000 subscribers. In addition to the $124 million in cash, the price includes $53.7 million in seller financing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/11/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Borland's Stock Surges After Ruling
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/11/busin.body_text: **********Shares of Borland International Inc. surged today after a ruling late Thursday that the company had not infringed copyrighted material in the Lotus Development Corporation's 1-2-3 spreadsheet program. **********Borland shares closed at $9.75, up $1.25, in heavy Nasdaq trading. Lotus shares also rose, although by a smaller percentage, to close at $44.50, up $2.50. The movement in Lotus shares reflected the minimal impact that the ruling, by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit in Boston, is expected to have on the company's operations. Although Lotus had said it expected to receive more than $100 million in damages in the suit, Borland had less than half that amount in cash, and few analysts expected the outcome to be material to Lotus. **********The clear winner in yesterday's decision was Borland, a company that has had little good news for a long time. As long as the suit and the threat of huge damages hung over its head, the company's very survival was in question, and some customers might have deferred buying its products for that reason. Borland's newest product, Delphi, a software development tool used to create custom applications, was introduced to rave reviews last month. That product now has a better chance of success. **********The resolution of the suit, barring any appeal Lotus may file, also raises anew the possibility that Borland will be acquired. Although the company has been mired in losses for many quarters, there is still a strong franchise for its core products, like the dBase and Paradox data base management programs, and various software languages and development tools used by professional programmers. Borland recently completed a major revamping to focus on these products. **********Borland officials said the ruling cleared the way for them to pursue their new strategy. "This decision removes a huge cloud of uncertainty from Borland and allows us to move forward with our business plans to develop and market world-class software development tools," said Gary Wetsel, who was named president of Borland in January after the company's founder, Phillipe Kahn, stepped down. Mr. Kahn remains chairman. **********Lotus executives, who said they were considering their options, would not say whether they planned to appeal the decision. **********But in many ways, the issue is moot in terms of the company's place in the market today. In August 1993, Borland removed a feature in its Quattro Pro spreadsheet that a lower court had found to infringe Lotus copyrights. Last March, the company sold the product altogether to Novell Inc. **********In the meantime, Lotus 1-2-3 has lost its place as the leading spreadsheet program to the Microsoft Corporation's Excel, and Lotus now says it expects its Notes program for workgroup computing to generate growth. **********"Was it Borland that damaged 1-2-3? Not likely -- it was Lotus itself," said Stewart Alsop, editor of Infoworld, a trade publication.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/11/busin.main_headline: International Briefs; Sabena to Buy New Aircraft
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/11/busin.print_headline: International Briefs; Sabena to Buy New Aircraft
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/11/busin.body_text: **********Sabena, the Belgian national airline, said yesterday that it would purchase between 15 and 20 aircraft next month in response to a surge in European passenger traffic. The airline, which has a fleet of 66 planes, said it would like to buy 70- to 80-seat airplanes to fly between European capitals. It said it was considering Dutch Fokker-70 planes and Avro RJ-85 planes, made by British Aerospace. **********The total investment would be between $300 million and $450 million, depending on the number of aircraft Sabena decided to buy, analysts said. The purchase would be the first since Sabena agreed to an alliance with Swissair in May, and signals the determination of the two airlines to increase their share of the European market. (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/18/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Good earnings and a stock buyback please Kodak investors.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/18/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Good earnings and a stock buyback please Kodak investors.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/18/busin.body_text: **********FINALLY, some good news from Rochester. The Eastman Kodak Company, long a disappointing performer, delivered earnings near the high end of expectations yesterday and said it would spend $1 billion to buy back 2.5 percent of its stock in the next six to nine months. **********Earnings for the quarter were $338 million, up 33 percent from operating earnings a year earlier. Investors responded positively to the report, sending the price of Kodak's shares on the New York Stock Exchange up $2.50, to $59.625, a gain of nearly 4.4 percent. **********The news was all the more welcome because it was somewhat surprising. With consumer-products companies like Polaroid and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing warning that third-quarter earnings would not meet expectations, there were fears that Kodak, too, would post numbers below the 94-cent-a-share consensus of analysts. **********But the company reported net earnings of 99 cents a share for the period, just two pennies less than the most optimistic forecast. "The street was worried that it was going to be ugly," said B. Alex Henderson, an analyst with Prudential Securities Research. "We had heard about losses in copiers and retail sales over all were down." **********Instead, Mr. Henderson said, Kodak's sales of consumer photographic products surged, fueling earnings. "Film sales were well above the trend line, growing 7 percent compared to a trend of 3 to 4 percent," he said. "That is good news, but it may not be sustainable." **********Harry L. Kavetas, Kodak's chief financial officer, disputed those doubts. He said the consumer imaging business -- film in yellow boxes, photofinishing, photographic paper and accessories -- could be counted on to expand. "We are finding that the consumer imaging business is larger and growing more rapidly than the conventional wisdom would allow," he said. **********Mr. Kavetas is one of the outside executives brought to Kodak by George M. C. Fisher, who decided to drop drugs and other chemical products shortly after he became the company's chairman in December, instead preferring to concentrate only on the imaging business. **********Mr. Kavetas said Kodak's electronic imaging operations, Mr. Fisher's product line of the future, was still unprofitable, but on track to become profitable in 1997. "It is our fastest-growing business," he said. **********Analysts said Kodak had promised to begin a program to return cash to shareholders by the end of this year, so yesterday's $1 billion stock repurchase announcement came three months before the self-imposed deadline. They said it was made possible by Mr. Fisher's asset- sales program, which allowed the company to pay off most of its debt. **********"This is the first quarter in years where cash exceeded debt," said Jack L. Kelly, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs. "They have $1.3 billion in cash and marketable securities and $1.06 billion in debt. The balance sheet is a success story." **********Analysts generally praised the buyback program, though some questioned its size and duration. "This will all be over by the middle of next year," said Nicholas P. Heymann of NatWest Securities "What happens next? **********"They could have announced a three- or a five-year program," he added. "By doing this, you have to suspect there is something else pending, like an acquisition." Mr. Heymann said Kodak's future cash-flow prospects could have supported a larger stock purchase plan. "They are keeping an awful lot of powder dry there," he said. **********Kodak executives and analysts agreed that despite the strong earnings and the stock purchase plan, the company has more to do to convince investors that it can trim administrative costs that are widely seen as excessive. In his statement, Mr. Fisher pledged to "continue to work very hard to reduce our cost base." **********Kodak executives, Mr. Kelly said, "know they have to reduce costs in areas like distribution. It is just that cutting costs is taking longer than cleaning up the balance sheet."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/18/busin.main_headline: CLINICOM AND HBO HEALTH CARE SOFTWARE TO MERGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/18/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; CLINICOM AND HBO HEALTH CARE SOFTWARE TO MERGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/18/busin.body_text: **********Shares of the software provider Clinicom Inc. surged 23 percent yesterday on news that it is to be acquired by its marketing partner, HBO & Company, for stock valued about $188 million. The companies, both of which are based in Boulder, Colo., supply software and services to health care organizations and have been marketing partners since the mid-1980's. Clinicom had 1994 revenues of $35.4 million. HBO had 1994 revenues of $327.2 million. Under the pact, Clinicom shareholders would receive four-tenths of an HBO & Company share for each Clinicom share. Clinicom shares were up $4 yesterday, at $21, in Nasdaq trading. HBO shares dropped $4.25, to $54.25.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/16/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Jones industrial average, the most closely watched but often difficult to interpret of stock market gauges, came tantalizingly close to 4,000 yesterday. **********By 1:30 P.M., the Dow, the index of blue-chip stocks, had come within 2.05 points of touching 4,000, and surged four more times past 3,995 before falling back. The Dow closed at a record high of 3,986.17, up 27.92. **********After three sessions in which many traders stayed on the sidelines, the volume on the New York Stock Exchange surged to an unusually heavy total of 378.9 million shares, more than 14 percent higher than the daily average this year. **********Almost twice as many stocks rose as fell on the Big Board, with 1,475 advancing and 765 declining. Ninety-five stocks hit new highs and 50 hit new lows. **********The stock market rallied because Government reports on consumer prices, factory use and industrial production suggested for the most part that the economy was continuing to grow, but at a slower pace and with only modest inflation. **********The data suggested to many traders that the Federal Reserve might ease its policy of raising interest rates to fight inflation, thereby lowering corporate borrowing costs, raising profits and lifting share prices. **********Traders said the Dow was certain to break 4,000 soon, if not today then probably tomorrow, when there will be a quarterly expiration of stock options, which usually leads to a spurt in stock buying. **********"From my perspective," said Todd Clark, managing director of equity trading at Mabon Securities, "it's just as important that we had a record high as it is passing a psychological barrier at 4,000 that is really no big deal." **********The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose as well, on Tuesday inching past its previous record of 482 set on Feb. 2, 1994, and finishing yesterday at 484.54, up 1.99 points. **********The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 5.01 points, to 795.63, still 9 points shy of its peak of 803.93 last March 18. **********But some analysts cautioned that the stock market would not be stable above a Dow of 4,000, because fixed-income instruments like bonds and certificates of deposit would continue to lock up cash that could go into stocks. **********"There are some record highs in the Dow that energize the broader market," said Christine Callies, equity strategist at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company. "This is probably not one of them." **********She noted that the cash inflows into stock mutual funds had slowed slightly in 1994, but the inflows had surged sharply for money-market mutual funds, which offer higher yields than stocks. **********"For the broader market to become energized will require an enormous quantity of new money," Ms. Callies said, "and what will attract new money is a rapid and prolonged decline in interest rates." Money-market funds and other fixed-income instruments become less attractive to investors when rates fall. **********In a speech in Honolulu yesterday, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, seemed to suggest that he would continue to fight inflation with high interest rates. Mr. Greenspan said he questioned reports that the economy was slowing and said he saw "reasons for some concern" that prices later in the year would rise faster than in 1994. **********Stock and bond prices fell after excerpts from the speech were quoted on news services. **********Some traders also fear that too vigorous a rally in the stock market might itself prompt the Fed to raise interest rates. And the fine print in yesterday's economic data, like an unexpectedly high "core" rate of inflation of four-tenths of 1 percent, seemed worrisome to some analysts. **********Joseph Liro, an analyst at S. G. Warburg, said in a report to clients that the data held "the first glimmer of evidence" that prices were "beginning to rise at a moderately faster pace." **********Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 21 stocks rose, led by Walt Disney, which rose 1 1/4, to 53 5/8. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 297 rose, led by General Electric, which rose 1, to 53 5/8. **********Conseco Inc. fell 4, to 40 1/8, after the insurance holding company reported that its fourth-quarter operating profit dropped 35 percent, in part because of a restructuring charge in advance of a failed attempt to buy the Kemper Corporation. **********The American depository receipts of Daiei, a supermarket chain in Japan, fell 3, to 20, after the company reported that 11 of its stores could not be repaired because of the earthquake in Kobe. **********Intuit dropped 3, to 65 1/2, because the antitrust settlement with Microsoft that was rejected by a Federal judge called into question Microsoft's planned acquisition of Intuit, a software company. **********The most active stock, with 10.4 million shares traded, was Hanson P.L.C., the British conglomerate. The American depository receipts of Hanson fell 1/4, to 18 3/4, after the company reported on Tuesday that its first-quarter pretax profit rose 58 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/18/world.main_headline: Nationalist Fever Helps Heat Up Another Latin Border
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/18/world.print_headline: Nationalist Fever Helps Heat Up Another Latin Border
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/18/world.body_text: **********In another outbreak of Latin America's new nationalist fever, Venezuelan soldiers swept through a border area this week, rounded up about 1,000 illegal Colombian immigrants, burned some of their houses and crops and deported them to Colombia. **********The expulsions were a reprisal for a cross-border raid three weeks ago by Colombian guerrillas that left eight Venezuelan Navy marines dead and four wounded. **********With relations between the Andean neighbors at their lowest point in almost a decade, Venezuela's President, Rafael Caldera, declared the 1,378-mile border to be "a theater of operations" on Wednesday and airlifted 5,000 troops into the four Venezuelan states bordering Colombia. On Saturday he is to tour the area, visiting the navy post destroyed in the guerrilla attack. **********Today Colombia's President, Ernesto Samper, visited Colombia's side of the border. Stung by Venezuelan criticism that it has lost control of its border to the guerrillas, Colombia increased its military presence there this week to 6,200 soldiers. **********Long called "sister republics," Venezuela and Colombia hope to avoid direct confrontation. Pioneers in Latin America's economic integration, the two countries have watched trade between them double since a free trade pact went into effect in 1992. **********Yet the two countries are seized by Latin America's new vogue, the sort of flag-waving nationalism exemplified by the month-long border war between Peru and Ecuador that ended in early March. The mood is captured by graffiti freshly sprayed on walls of this modern capital: "Venezuela weeps for her soldiers," "Colombians, killers!" and "Colombians go home!" **********Last week, Mr. Caldera won his only standing ovation from Venezuela's Congress during his state of the union speech when he declared in, "If cases like what happened repeat themselves, a right to legitimate defense will have to be recognized that cannot be stopped by a border line." **********Angered by years of unpunished attacks and kidnappings by guerrillas, Venezuela now demands from Colombia the right of "hot pursuit" -- for Venezuelan soldiers to cross the border when they are chasing guerrillas. **********"Venezuela is the subject of constant incursions -- by drug traffickers, common criminals and guerrillas," Venezuela's Minister for Border Affairs, Pompeyo Marquez, said in an interview today. "We can't keep on supporting all this aggression in a passive way." **********Last week, results of a public opinion poll in Colombia showed that 96 percent of respondents opposed allowing Venezuelan soldiers to enter Colombia. **********Some Colombians argue that Venezuela is using old problems -- 1.5 million undocumented Colombian immigrants here and cross-border attacks by Colombian guerrillas -- to divert attention from Venezuela's shaky economy and soaring crime rate. With unemployment spreading, Venezuela's homicide rate jumped by 65 percent last year, hitting 4,909 murders for 1994. During pre-Lenten Carnival celebrations here, 58 people were slain. **********In January, well before the border attack, Venezuela's Government started a campaign to raise the country's spirits. The Government printed two million small paper flags and started airing patriotic commercials with slogans like "Venezuela is mine" on television. **********"Someone started playing Venezuelan music on the radio station, someone put a Venezuelan flag on his car -- and all of his sudden it took off," said a Government spokesman, Guillermo Alvarez Bajares, whose Information Office printed up the two million flags. **********Venezuelans have genuine grievances against Colombia, the Venezuelan Government spokesman added. **********He noted that over the last decade, Colombian guerrillas have attacked Venezuelan military installations about 50 times, killing 30 Venezuelan soldiers. During the last half of 1994, about 3,600 cars stolen from Venezuelans were taken to Colombia. Virtually all of the three tons of cocaine confiscated in Venezuela last year came from Colombia. **********In recent weeks, Colombian guerrillas started to send extortion letters to Venezuelan oil companies, threatening to dynamite their installations near the border if they did not pay up. **********"There is no serious Colombian effort to watch their side of the border," the spokesman continued. "Because of the kidnappings, our side is almost depopulated." **********Last week, Colombia's Defense Minister, Fernando Botero Zia, promised to spend $200 million on building and staffing four military posts in the border area. **********The Perija mountain range of Zulia State, where most of the expulsions this week took place, has recently become a haven for Colombian guerrillas. A milk- and beef-producing region that was once one of Venezuela's most productive, it reported 25 kidnappings last year at ranches in the shadow of the mountain range. **********"There is a third state in the region," Hugo Chavez Frias, a retired armed officer and leftist politician, said today. "The Colombian and Venezuelan governments must extend the presence of their states to the border." **********But human rights workers fear that by turning the border region into a "theater of operations" the Government will turn a blind eye to military abuses against rural peasants. Last week Venezuela's leading human rights group, Provea, charged that Venezuelan soldiers detained 23 local peasants after the guerrilla attack on the marines' navy post, beating and torturing them with electric shocks and hot iron rods.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/20/busin.main_headline: HITACHI AND FONAR SETTLE PATENT DISPUTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; HITACHI AND FONAR SETTLE PATENT DISPUTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/20/busin.body_text: **********Hitachi Ltd. and the Fonar Corporation settled a patent dispute involving magnetic-resonance imaging technology yesterday, after opening arguments in a Federal jury trial in Hauppauge, L.I. Fonar, a maker of M.R.I. machines, sued Hitachi and the General Electric Company in 1992 over four Fonar patents related to M.R.I. technology, which is used to produce detailed pictures of the human body. Fonar was seeking $62 million from Hitachi and a subsidiary, Hitachi Medical, and about $300 million from G.E. After the settlement was disclosed, Federal District Judge Leonard Wexler granted a motion by G.E. for a mistrial, a court official said. Lawyers for G.E. argued that reports of the Hitachi settlement would bias the jury against G.E. Fonar, based in Melville, L.I., did not release details of the agreement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/17/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Loblaw Selling Its U.S. Stores
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/17/busin.body_text: **********Shedding the last piece of its United States food operation, the Loblaw Companies agreed today to sell its National Tea Company supermarkets in St. Louis and New Orleans to Schnuck Markets Inc., which will resell some of the units to Schwegmann Giant Super Markets Inc. **********The price was not disclosed. Analysts estimated that Loblaw received about $354 million for the 89 National Tea supermarkets, which operate under the names National Supermarkets, Garden Markets and National Markets. **********Proceeds will be used to pay off more than $680 million in debt, said Donald Reid, Loblaw's senior vice president of finance. **********Loblaw's United States sale "takes a hefty bite out of debt, and it's positive in the sense that there's no significant earnings impact," James McLeod, an analyst at Richardson Greenshields, said. **********Loblaw operates 415 supermarkets in Canada, mostly in Ontario. National Tea generated sales of about $1.5 billion in 1994, with operating profit of about $30 million, or about 12 percent of Loblaw's total $258 million in operating profit, analysts said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/01/busin.main_headline: International Briefs; Westpac of Australia Bids for Challenge Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/01/busin.print_headline: International Briefs; Westpac of Australia Bids for Challenge Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/01/busin.body_text: **********The Westpac Banking Corporation offered $689 million (Australian), or $507.6 million (United States), for Challenge Bank Ltd. yesterday. The bid is the second in a week for Challenge, a regional bank in Perth, Australia. On Thursday, St. George Bank Ltd. offered $581 million (Australian) for Challenge. St. George, which owns nearly 11 percent of Challenge, said yesterday that it did not plan to match Westpac's offer. Both Westpac and St. George are based in Sydney. **********Westpac has an 8.5 percent stake in Challenge. Under Westpac's bid, Challenge's shareholders will have the option of receiving cash or a combination of cash and stock. Challenge said its board would review Westpac's offer. (Dow Jones)

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/08/world.main_headline: World News Briefs; Gonzalez Escapes Inquiry On Spain's Death Squads
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/08/world.print_headline: World News Briefs; Gonzalez Escapes Inquiry On Spain's Death Squads
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/08/world.body_text: **********The Supreme Court said today that there was not enough evidence to warrant investigating the Socialist Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, in connection with death squads that killed 27 suspected Basque separatists in southern France in the early 1980's. **********The announcement came on the same day that fresh accusations arose indicating that Spain's military intelligence service outlined a master plan for a "dirty war" against the separatists. **********A Supreme Court spokesman said the decision was based on a report by the Board of State Prosecutors, which said the earlier accusations were "vague, incorrect, and based on mere suppositions without proof." **********But the report recommended a subpoena for former Interior Minister Jose Barrionuevo, a Socialist member of Parliament. **********Mr. Gonzalez who is traveling in Moscow as European Union President, told reporters today, "What I said two months ago continues to be valid: The accusations are all false."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/11/busin.main_headline: WALBRO IN FINAL PACT TO GET DYNO'S FUEL-TANK BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/11/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; WALBRO IN FINAL PACT TO GET DYNO'S FUEL-TANK BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/11/busin.body_text: **********The Walbro Automotive Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a final agreement to acquire the fuel-tank unit of Dyno Industrier A. S. for about $124 million. A preliminary agreement between the two companies was announced in January. Walbro Automotive, a unit of the Walbro Corporation, a fuel-systems maker, said the Dyno subsidiary supplied plastic fuel tanks to most European vehicle makers. Walbro is based in Cass City, Mich. Dyno, which makes chemicals, explosives and plastics, has its headquarters in Oslo.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/16/busin.main_headline: In Trade Talks, a Duel of Statistics
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/16/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; In Trade Talks, a Duel of Statistics
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/16/busin.body_text: **********Anyone who wonders why Washington and Tokyo can't reach an agreement on automobile trade should try to complete these three statement: **********1. The number of car models sold by American auto makers in Japan with the steering wheel on the right side, which is the custom in Japan, is **********(a) 59 **********(b) 2. **********2. America's trade deficit with Japan in autos and auto parts is **********(a) getting bigger **********(b) getting smaller. **********3. Imported cars account for **********(a) only 4 percent of the Japanese market, far less than the imported share in other industrialized nations **********(b) 8-12 percent of the Japanese market, about the same as in other industrialized nations. **********The correct answers are a or b, depending on whether one believes the United States Government or the Japanese Government. In other words, the sides are worlds apart, giving new meaning to the old saw about "lies, damn lies and statistics." **********In an effort to influence world opinion, both Governments have been issuing a blizzard of statistical fact sheets and counter-fact sheets in a duel that has no doubt kept lower-level bureaucrats on both sides of the Pacific toiling over spreadsheets until the wee hours of their respective mornings. **********Needless to say, each side presents the figures in a way that best suits its case. **********Take right-hand drive cars. Japan argues that one reason so few American cars are sold here is that Detroit simply does not make cars for the Japanese market. It argues that there are just two American cars sold in Japan with the steering wheel on the right side -- the Chrysler Jeep Cherokee and the Ford Probe. **********No way, cries Washington. The Government says there are 59 right-hand drive models offered in Japan by Detroit's Big Three, and it has published a list of them. (In fact, the list contains 60 models, but who's counting?) **********The discrepancy is that Japan counts only cars made by the Big Three in the United States. But Washington includes cars made by the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company in Europe as well as those made by Mazda Motors in Japan that are sold here by Ford. It does not matter where the cars are made, Washington says, as long as the models with right-side drive are for sale in Japan. **********But Washington's view of what constitutes a car "model" is considerably more liberal than Japan's. Consider the Telstar sold by Ford and made by Mazda. **********Washington lists 16 versions of the small car and counts each one as a right-hand drive model. There's the Ford Telstar II (18i-Ef) and the Telstar II (18i-E) and the Telstar II (18i-X), for example, not to mention the popular Telstar II (20i-X), which also comes in a four-wheel-drive version. There are also two models of the Telstar TX 5, two versions of the Telstar Sedan and seven varieties of the Telstar Wagon. **********What is the difference, say, between the Telstar II (18i-Ef) and the (18i-E)? According to a Ford dealer, the E has an audio system and electrically retractable side-view mirrors, while the Ef does not. In other words, not much of a difference if all one cares about is which side the steering wheel is on. **********Then there is the question of just how many new cars are sold by foreign auto makers in Japan. Washington argues that imported cars make up only 4 percent of the Japanese market; Japan says foreign auto makers captured more than 8 percent of the market last year. **********In calculating import market share, the United States calculates imports as a share of all vehicles sold in Japan. Japan, though, counts only passenger cars, excluding commercial vehicles and mini-cars, an extremely small vehicle for urban use, arguing that foreign auto makers do not really compete in those segments. **********Whatever the figure, how does this compare with other countries? Imports account for between 33 percent of the market in the United States and 55 percent in Italy. Given the paltry 4 percent share held by imports in Japan, that proves that Japan's market is effectively closed, Americans say. **********Japan begs to differ. The share held by imports in other big car markets around the world ranges from only 5 to 16 percent, Japan says, not 33 to 55 percent. **********As for the other nations, Japan excludes imports into the United States from Canada and Mexico and imports into one European country from another, arguing that these occur within free-trade areas. That knocks down the share of the market held by imported cars in France, say, from the 38 percent calculated by Washington to only 5 percent. **********What about the big picture? Can the two sides agree on that? **********The question of whether the United States deficit in auto-related trade with Japan is getting bigger or smaller simply depends on which currency is used to measure it. **********In dollar terms, the difference between imports and exports of automobiles and parts rose to $36.7 billion last year from $30.8 billion in 1990. But in Japanese yen, the deficit shrank 13.4 percent in that period, mainly because Japan has been exporting fewer cars to the United States. But because the yen has substantially risen in value against the dollar, the deficit measured in dollars has climbed substantially. **********As for the huge imbalance in auto parts pouring into the United States and the trickle of American parts flowing to Japan, Washington argues that something must be amiss in Japan because the United States has a surplus in auto-parts trade with the rest of the world. **********Well, not quite, says Japan. Tokyo contends that the United States imports more parts than it exports with most countries, including Mexico, Germany and France. The overall surplus the United States touts is mainly with Canada, Japan says, where the Big Three have several assembly plants that they supply with parts from the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/20/busin.body_text: **********TO understand the fall and rise of the European car in America, consider the case of Volvo and the cup holder. **********The year was 1990. With its American sales plunging, Volvo, the Swedish auto maker, was developing a new, make-or-break model, the 850. It asked eight dealers in the United States to confect a "no apologies car," with all the equipment their customers would want. The dealers demanded a sleeker look and splashier colors inside and out, and, they declared, they simply had to have cup holders. **********Old World habits, though, die hard. The Swedish engineers said no way; they would not contribute to reckless behavior like drinking hot coffee while driving. **********But the North American sales operations insisted on the inclusion of that uniquely North American auto fetish, and, ultimately, the engineers "were beaten into submission," in the words of William J. Hoover, executive vice president of Volvo Cars of North America. The cup holders, optional when the 850 was introduced in the fall of 1992, have since been made standard, and the car has spearheaded Volvo's comeback in the United States. **********These days, in a stunning reversal of fortune, it seems that a European auto company can't miss in the United States. As the overall American market stalled out in the first seven months of this year, slipping 2.3 percent, Volvo sales were up 8.1 percent. And Volkswagen, BMW, Saab, Jaguar, Land Rover and Audi posted percentage gains in the double digits. Only one major European contender saw its sales decline, and that was Alfa Romeo, which is abandoning the United States. **********Chased from commuter parking lots in the late 80's by sturdier and less expensive high-line Japanese cars, the Europeans have dueled their way back in much the same way that the Japanese conquered the American market -- by cutting costs, restraining prices and finally pausing to ask customers why they started snubbing the cars in the first place. **********It turns out that drivers in the United States never lost their hankering for the snarl of a BMW engine, the craggy profile of a Volvo or the down-and-dirty ignition of a Saab. **********It's just that, strangely, they also prefer electrical systems that don't short out and sunroofs that don't leak. They like chipper colors and capacious glove boxes. They enjoy advertising that treats them like adults, or darn close to it. They don't like to pay too much for that muffler, or for anything else. **********"It's not so much magic," said Dr. Jens Neumann, the member of Volkswagen A.G.'s board of management who overseas operations in North America. "You just have to go out from the ivory tower to where the real life is taking place." **********Dr. Neumann, who graduated from high school in Baltimore, could not resist serving up a little crow. "I told you we'd double the sales," he said, recalling a promise made in 1994. "No one really believed it." (In point of fact, V.W.'s sales in the United States last year rose only 95.9 percent.) **********In part, the European companies are benefiting from their recent obscurity in this country. **********Erin Spencer, a 38-year-old management consultant in Atlanta, said her old Nissan Altima "was a great car." But when it came time to trade up, she said, "I wanted one that everybody and his brother didn't have, versus the Lexus and Infiniti, which everybody has. Saab was just a little bit different." **********At the same time, the Europeans are aggressively promoting their cars by jabbing at perceived weaknesses of the Japanese wares: unexciting handling and vanilla styling. **********"That's a big downfall of the Japanese -- they're not stylish cars," said R. Michael Smith, an executive search consultant in Roswell, Ga., who recently replaced his 1992 Infiniti Q45 with a glacier-white Jaguar XJ6 sedan. "The Jaguar's a very stylish car. People look when I drive by, and I like it." **********Mr. Smith knew all the old jokes about the quality of Jaguars ("You have to buy two, since one will always be in the shop"), but he had heard that the cars had improved since the Ford Motor Company bought Jaguar Cars Ltd. in 1989. "The bottom line was, I wanted a Jag since I was a kid, and now the quality was in it," he said. **********Despite their recent gains, most European car makers remain below their record levels of the 1970's and 80's, and they represent tiny fractions of the American market. For example, in the most marked resurgence, Land Rover more than doubled its sales last year after introducing a new sport utility model, the Discovery. It cost just less than $30,000 -- compared with more than $50,000 for Rover's other four-door model, the Range Rover -- and had some features oddly novel in Rover's lineup, like a glove box. **********While its sales jumped more than doubled, Land Rover nonetheless sold only 12,045 vehicles in the United States all last year. By contrast, Ford sells about 30,000 of its Explorer sport utility alone -- each month. Even the biggest of the European brands in this country, Volkswagen, sold only 97,043 vehicles in 1994. **********Over all, however, the Europeans are steadily gaining share, to 3.1 percent of the total car and light truck market at the end of July, compared with 2.7 percent a year ago; the Big Three auto companies in the same period slipped from 73.7 percent of the market to 73.6, while Japanese companies declined from 22.7 percent to 22.3. **********The European companies generally sell at the upper, and smaller, end of the market, where customers are more demanding but profit margins are fatter. And within that segment, their gains are bigger. **********Through July, they controlled 27.5 percent of the luxury market, up from 23.8 percent for all of 1994, according to an analysis by Susan Jacobs, the president of Jacobs & Associates, an automotive consulting firm based in New Jersey. **********To cement and extend their gains, the Europeans are preparing to deliver a slew of new models, from convertible roadsters to sport utilities. They are also moving down-market with less expensive but jazzier vehicles, in a bid to win younger buyers by broadening the appeal of staid brands like Mercedes. And, as the Japanese did years ago, they are building plants in this country to dig themselves securely into the American market. **********At a new plant in South Carolina, BMW A.G. has already started making sedans and roadsters. In Georgia, Mercedes plans to start producing a new, so-called all-activity vehicle by 1997. Peugeot is weighing building a plant and selling again in the United States; Volvo says it will almost surely build a new plant in North America by the end of the decade. **********THE Euro rash has spread even to Detroit. The General Motors Corporation, desperate for a luxury car to excite youngish buyers, is turning to its German subsidiary, Opel, for an import it will sell as the Catera in the fall of 1996. **********It is also crossing the Atlantic for the basis of its next mini-van and a new model of its Saturn cars. And Ford's so-called world cars, the Ford Contour and Mercury Mystique, started their life as the European Mondeo. **********As recently as a decade ago, the Europeans could sell anything they offered in the United States because they had a part of the market mostly to themselves: luxury performance vehicles with a whiff of romance. Although competitive threats were stirring, the auto makers were complacent. **********"I don't think any of the manufacturers thought the consumer would accept the Japanese as premium cars," said Jim Crumlish, president and chief executive officer of of Saab Cars U.S.A. Inc. **********But the Japanese offered better quality at a lower price, and quickly lured customers away. At the same time, Detroit's auto makers began improving their own quality and styling, presenting another threat. **********With sales tumbling, the Europeans finally woke up in the early 1990's. As the Big Three had, they began studying Japanese manufacturing and marketing methods, rethinking their organizations, their brands and their products. **********The results were some shocking changes -- shocking mostly because they had not been made years before. Mercedes-Benz, for example, began disciplining its product developers for the first time to hit price targets for new cars, to insure that the new models could go head to head with Japanese cars and attract suddenly price-conscious luxury buyers. **********Such a change might seem elementary, but Mercedes-Benz "did business a hundred years with great success, and there's a certain inertia to walking away from what you've been doing successfully," said Mike J. Jackson, executive vice president for marketing, service and sales at Mercedes-Benz of North America. "While everyone knew change had to come, no one understood how dramatic or fast or urgent the change needed to be." **********TO cut costs, Mercedes turned to outside suppliers to make more parts for its cars, since they could do so more efficiently. It also began shrinking its work force in Germany through early-retirement programs. **********The aggressive efforts by Mercedes to control prices came just as Japanese cars, because of the rising yen, were losing their bargain status. When Lexus introduced its ES300 in the fall of 1991, it cost $26,620, well below the bottom-line Mercedes, which then cost $30,200. **********But two years later, when Mercedes brought out its new entry level model, it priced the car only $125 above the model it replaced. Meanwhile, the price of the Lexus had shot past the Mercedes, rising 17 percent, to $31,080. Since then, reflecting the tougher competition, the prices of both models have risen only 4 percent, leaving Mercedes with the advantage. **********Sales have surged for Mercedes since the debut of that new entry-level model, the C-class, and it is now poised to bring out several new cars to reposition the company here. A new E-class sedan is due this fall, to be followed by a convertible roadster, the all-activity vehicle and an all-new entry-level vehicle, which will cost less than the C-class. Mr. Jackson is hoping the cars will update the Mercedes image to draw in more, and younger, buyers. **********"An icon up on a pedestal is not where we want to be in the 90's," he said. Mercedes, he said, needs to become "more approachable, relevant, friendlier." **********Mercedes had deep-enough pockets to weather the market shakeout. Not so some of the other European auto companies, which lost their independence to big auto makers demanding immediate changes. While Ford bought Jaguar, BMW bought Rover. **********For its part, G.M. bought a 50 percent stake in Saab for $600 million in 1990, and installed new executives to salvage the collapsing company. Over the next four years, Saab chopped its work force in half, in the process lowering its break-even point -- the number of sales at which it becomes profitable -- from 130,000 to 80,000. **********Saab also went to work on a replacement for its 900 model, with new attention to Japanese manufacturing techniques and American tastes. **********The North American sales operation asked for a six-cylinder engine. Saab almost surely could not have afforded to develop one on its own, but G.M. simply sent one it already made in England. **********Saab's product planners also demanded a convertible, brighter colors, unusual wheel designs and a better sound system. Oh, and they asked for one more thing. "It was a tough thing to convince the Swedes of, why you need a cup holder," Mr. Crumlish recalled. **********Closer attention to quality in the new cars is also paying off. At Volvo, for example, to produce the side of the 850, workers now stamp only one piece of metal, rather than welding together several small pieces, as they had on previous models. **********The result is a stiffer side less prone to rattles, as well as greater efficiency in the factory. Volvo's scores in J. D. Power & Associates' Initial Quality Survey, an industry yardstick, climbed from worse than average in 1992 to 10th best of 33 ranked brands this year. **********MERCEDES and BMW have also moved into the top 10. Indeed, while they still lag behind the Japanese, the European auto companies as a group have improved their J. D. Power scores by 39 percent since 1992, compared with an 18 percent improvement for the industry as a whole, said Jacques DaCosta, a project director at Power. **********Dealers and auto analysts say that, in good measure, the European recovery is a result of basic price competition. With aggressive pricing, particularly through lease deals, the Europeans have been able to equal or undercut the Japanese companies. **********"I don't think the average buyer is tired of buying Japanese," said Kyle Brooks, Volkswagen sales manager at Bay Ridge Car World Ltd. in Brooklyn. "What's happening is because of the competitive pricing the American buyer is looking into the European car. Once they get here, they're finding this is a nice car for the money." **********Some buyers say that, beyond price, European cars have an advantage in personality and performance. **********"The European cars are different," said Mark Gordanier, an accountant in Green Oak Township, Mich., who recently replaced a Toyota 4-Runner sport utility vehicle with a Volvo 850 sedan. "They're tight. The steering's tight. The ride's tight." **********That is certainly the image most European companies are promoting. Toyota's marketing program for its Avalon sedan, which pictures a car floating among clouds, is the antithesis of the Europeans' message. **********"I am scrubbed of pollen, free of dust, void of pollution," a young woman cheerfully announces in a new V.W. ad. "So," she asks, her voice climbing to an echoing yell, "Why can't I breathe!" To a burst of vigorous music, the advertisement cuts to a shot of a V.W. convertible Cabrio, amid dazzling reds, golds and blues, twisting, top down, through country roads at high speeds. **********"It invigorates, never isolates," declares the ad, and a female narrator avers, "On the road of life, there are passengers, and there are drivers." **********DR. NEUMANN explained that V.W. was looking to attract "active drivers." **********"It's the young people -- up to 40 or 45 -- and those who stayed young that have the feel for it, and that we need to focus on," he said. To that end, V.W. is planning to introduce a futuristic version of its beloved Beetle, designed in Simi Valley, Calif., for sale in the United States. The company is coy about the introduction date, the price and other details. **********While Dr. Neumann said Asia presented the auto makers with the most room to grow, he called the United States a "relative growth market" for a company like V.W. that is positioned to gain market share. **********Selling in the United States, he argued, can contribute more than profits. The market here strengthens auto companies because it is so "transparent," he said, thanks to strict emissions and safety standards and independent watchdog groups like Power. **********"This competition," he said, "teaches you something."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/03/world.main_headline: In Cairo, Israel and Arabs Back Peace Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/03/world.print_headline: In Cairo, Israel and Arabs Back Peace Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/03/world.body_text: **********The leaders of Egypt, Jordan, the Palestine Liberation Organization and Israel, in their first regional summit meeting, agreed tonight to conduct talks in the coming days aimed at overcoming the obstacles to peace in the region. **********In the past, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin has met individually with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat, chairman of the P.L.O., but until Mr. Mubarak invited the group to Egypt, Mr. Rabin had never sat down with all three of the Arab leaders who have formally made peace with Israel. **********The leaders, who met for five and a half hours, did not adhere to their schedule and speak with reporters after the talks, which underscored the lack of progress. **********But Egypt's Foreign Minister, Amr Moussa, read a joint communique condemning political violence, calling for the preservation of the P.L.O.-Israeli agreements, appealing for more international financial support for the Palestinian Authority and seeking the establishment of a regional development bank. **********"The four parties condemned all the outbreaks of bloodshed, terror and violence in the region and reaffirmed their intention to stand staunchly against, and put an end to, all such acts," the statement read. **********Mr. Moussa said the meeting had helped save the Middle East peace effort and brought it "back on track." It also brought Mr. Mubarak back to the center of Middle East issues. And the presence of Mr. Rabin was a milestone for Israel. **********But the meeting yielded no solutions to the growing attacks by Islamic militants against Israelis, which have eroded support in Israel for the 1993 peace accord with the Palestinians. **********Mr. Moussa said, "There will be a meeting in Cairo on Monday on elections. On Thursday there will be a meeting between the Prime Minister and the Chairman at Eretz to discuss all the pending bilateral issues.  There will be a meeting between the four foreign ministers in Washington on the 12th of this month. And there will be a meeting in Amman for the four countries, Jordan, Egypt, Israel and the Palestinian Authority, to discuss the question of expanding settlements." **********The four men also promised to meet again "when necessary." **********Mr. Moussa played down the failure by the leaders to make any concrete commitments to accelerate the peace agreement, which calls for most of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip to be handed over to the Palestinians. **********A senior Palestinian official, who asked to remain unidentified, said after the talks, "There was no agreement between us and Israel on most issues." **********Palestinian officials said they had been unable to secure a commitment by Israel to release some 6,000 Palestinian prisoners or redeploy Israeli troops in the West Bank before elections are held. **********Marwan Kanafani, Mr. Arafat's chief spokesman, said Mr. Rabin reiterated his call for tough action against Islamic militants, and that Mr. Arafat responded by pinning much of the blame for the violence on Israeli occupation, the building of Israeli settlements and delays in widening the Palestinian self-rule agreement. **********Mr. Moussa said the leaders had not convinced Israel to end its closure of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip after the Jan. 22 bomb attack that killed 21 Israelis. The attack led Israel to suspend talks with the Palestinians on the implementation of the peace agreement. **********The three Arab leaders were also unable to get Israel to curb the expansion of Jewish settlements, despite the fact that Mr. Moussa said the settlement issue was "the subject of a long discussion." **********"If you expect that after two or three hours we are going to deal with all problems, you are mistaken," Mr. Moussa said, "but at least we opened the door to discuss the problems." **********Syria and Lebanon, which have not signed peace treaties with Israel, did not participate in the talks. **********The Syrian President, Hafez al-Assad, blames Israel for the deadlock in the negotiations and has repeatedly turned down calls from Prime Minister Rabin for a meeting. **********President Assad says he will not negotiate until Israel returns the Golan Heights, a strategic plateau that was captured by Israel in the 1967 war. Lebanon, which is closely allied with Damascus, has always followed Syria's lead with regard to the peace talks. There was no indication that any progress was made towards bridging the gaps between Israel and the Syrians and Lebanese. **********The leaders were invited to the summit meeting by President Mubarak. It was held at Ittahadiay Palace in northern Cairo after iftar, the meal eaten at sunset when Muslims break the daylong fast they observe during the holy month of Ramadan. **********Each of the leaders met President Mubarak separately before the summit meeting, but no information about those discussions was released. **********The peace efforts, which began three years ago in Madrid, have led to agreements between Israel and the P.L.O. and between Israel and Jordan. (Egypt signed a peace treaty in 1979 with Israel.) **********Israeli troops have withdrawn from the Gaza Strip and the West Bank town of Jericho and allowed Mr. Arafat to establish self-rule enclaves. **********But in recent weeks violence by Islamic militants has stymied further steps and eroded support for the agreement. Mr. Rabin and Mr. Arafat are facing mounting criticism and waning enthusiasm among their backers. King Hussein has also been criticized in Jordan for signing a treaty with Israel before Syria did. **********And President Mubarak, battling a wave of attacks by Islamic militants, hopes to win favor with Western backers by helping to push the peace effort forward. **********Before leaving for the summit meeting, Mr. Rabin told members of his Labor Party that Mr. Arafat's and his colleagues must "make sure the territory they rule -- Gaza and Jericho -- is not used as a shelter or as a place to prepare, incite and execute attacks." **********Their ability to meet this commitment "will decide more than anything both the speed and possibility of progress in implementing the solution of the Palestinian-Israeli conflict," he said. **********But radical groups that operate out of the West Bank and Gaza Strip vowed today to continue to kill Israelis. Islamic Holy War, which has carried out several suicide bombings against Israeli targets, denounced the summit meeting as a public relations effort to salvage the image of Prime Minister Rabin. **********In Cairo, Mr. Moussa said Egypt and Israel were also no closer to solving their dispute over the treaty against the spread of nuclear weapons. Egypt says it will refuse to sign the treaty, which is up for renewal in April, unless Israel signs as well. **********But Israel, which is said by Western officials to have as many as 200 nuclear warheads, refuses to sign until there is "comprehensive peace" in the region. **********Egyptian officials have mounted a campaign to persuade other Arab states to withdraw support for the treaty until Israel opens up its own nuclear program for inspection. **********The Foreign Minister said Egypt's position toward the treaty and toward Israel remained unchanged.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/29/world.main_headline: Scientists Say Raw Sewage Killed 40,000 Birds
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/29/world.print_headline: Scientists Say Raw Sewage Killed 40,000 Birds
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/29/world.body_text: **********In a surprising conclusion to an investigation into the deaths last winter of some 40,000 migratory birds at an irrigation reservoir in central Mexico, scientists have identified raw human sewage, not industrial pollutants, as the main killer. **********The scientists said rivers of sewage flowing into the Silva Reservoir, 195 miles northwest of Mexico City, created a vast incubator for botulism bacteria, which poisoned the food eaten by the ducks, coots and other birds landing in the fetid waters after migrating from the United States and Canada. **********A nine-member panel of scientists from Canada, Mexico and the United States urged that the reservoir be kept drained and, to prevent a mass new bird infection from microbes still active in the soil, that environmental workers be deployed in coming weeks to scare away birds arriving in this fall's migration. Over the long term, the authorities should spend $50 million to build water treatment plants for the city of Leon, which lies upstream, the scientists said. **********The panel was formed under the environmental tenets of the North American Free Trade Agreement, and its investigation -- the first of its kind -- was an important test of the three nations' ability to cooperate on environmental matters. **********The Mexican authorities concluded last summer that industrial pollutants had killed the birds. But the Nafta panel's report said that although exposure to heavy metals, discharged without treatment by 1,000 leather tanneries upstream from the Silva reservoir, may have been a factor, botulism was the main killer. **********"The overriding cause of mortality in waterbirds at the Presa de Silva was botulism; however, a small percentage of birds may have died of other causes," the report said. **********The panel's identification of untreated sewage as an environmental killer underlines what health experts have long called one of Mexico's most sweeping health problems: the lack of water treatment facilities. Julia Carabias Lillo, Mexico's environment minister, said this month that there are only 660 water treatment plants for all of the country's 92 million people, and many of them are not functioning. **********From November through January, when most of the birds died, the waters of the Silva reservoir were likely 100 percent raw sewage, the Nafta panel's report said. **********Noting that thousands of birds began perishing six weeks before Mexican authorities reacted, the Nafta scientists urged Mexico to form an agency to monitor the health of its beleaguered wildlife and respond to outbreaks of wildlife diseases. **********Mary A. Minette, a staff lawyer for the National Audobon Society, which along with two Mexican environmental groups requested the investigation, warned that although the reservoir has been drained, local farmers depend on it for irrigation. **********"Unless they provide a clean place for birds to land nearby, this is just going to happen all over again," Ms. Minette said.
