https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/30/busin.snippet:
THIS last week marked the fifth anniversary of the passage of the Americans with Disabilities Act, yet the legislation's extraordinary impact on the American workplace is still not appreciated.

A.D.A. complaints of discrimination are pouring into...
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/30/busin.main_headline:
VOICES: VIEWPOINT;
A Level Playing Field or a Quagmire?
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/30/busin.print_headline:
VOICES: VIEWPOINT;
A Level Playing Field or a Quagmire?
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/30/busin.body_text: **********THIS last week marked the fifth anniversary of the passage of the Americans with Disabilities Act, yet the legislation's extraordinary impact on the American workplace is still not appreciated. **********A.D.A. complaints of discrimination are pouring into the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the agency charged with enforcing the law, at the rate of 1,500 a month.  But the fact that the measure is creating fertile ground for lawyers only tells part of the story. It is also having a profound impact because of its hallmark requirement to provide "reasonable accommodation" for disabled people. **********Although the term is not defined by the law, "reasonable accommodation," in practice, requires that employers affirmatively help a wide range of employees in a variety of ways and with a flexibility that is counterintuitive to the way most businesses operate. **********The requirements are far different than the precept of equal treatment mandated under other equal employment laws. The reasonable-accommodation requirement is imposed on employers so that disabled employees have a means of overcoming barriers that prevent or restrict employment opportunities.  Since every job, employer and disability is unique, providing reasonable accommodation can entail diverse actions like restructuring a job, buying special devices for a worker, providing an interpreter or granting leave or flexible hours. **********The frightening aspect of this process for employers is that the final arbiter of what is reasonable may be a jury that has the authority to hand out a staggering award, including back pay, legal fees and punitive damages. **********The concept of reasonable accommodation challenges many of the fundamental assumptions employers have held with respect to job qualifications. For example, if physical or mental standards screen out individuals with disabilities, an employer must demonstrate that the standard is job-related and consistent with business necessity. In one recent case, a Federal court in Kansas City, Mo., held that a blanket prohibition on licensing one-armed security guards constituted discrimination under the A.D.A.. The court reasoned that it was improper to assume that an individual with one hand could not perform the same physical tasks as someone with two hands. Courts that have addressed these issues have not concerned themselves with employer discretion as to how the job is done but only with insuring that the job is done. **********The law's employment provisions are only a few pages long, but their brevity belies a panoply of complicated legal issues. It has taken the E.E.O.C. 47 pages of regulations to explain what constitutes lawful disability-related inquiries under the law, and those regulations raise just as many issues as they resolve. **********The E.E.O.C. says you can ask a job applicant how many days leave she took last year but not how many days she was ill. Because alcoholism is considered a disability under the A.D.A., you can't ask someone if he is an alcoholic, but you can ask if he drinks alcohol. These subtleties are beyond the grasp of most lawyers, let alone the small-business owner who meets the law's threshold coverage of 15 employees. **********Even defining the term "disability" has proved mercurial, requiring 60 more pages of explanatory regulations. Individuals are protected under the law if they possess a "physical or mental impairment which substantially limits one or more major life activities." That latitude often makes determining coverage under the law ambiguous. **********Let's say, for example, an employee is impatient with her co-workers and her boss, often loses her temper and publicly questions her superior's directions. If this conduct is a result of manic depression -- rather than merely a personality trait of impatience or arrogance -- this person receives all of the law's protections. **********Employers can hardly be sanguine about the law's seemingly endless scope. Falling within its broad protective sweep are recovered drug addicts; people suffering from panic attacks, depression or other mental illness; the learning disabled; the mentally retarded; alcoholics; the obese; individuals with facial disfigurements, and persons who are impaired in their ability to procreate.  In addition, the law protects those employees who are not actually disabled but are perceived to be so. For the employee who wants to sue, the A.D.A. has, as my wife likes to say, a lid for every pot. **********The law's outer boundaries are not yet known, but we are living, after all, in a renaissance age when it comes to legal ingenuity. The computer programmer fired for tardiness who claimed that he suffered from a neurotic compulsion for lateness did not succeed in his lawsuit.  Nor did the bus driver who suffered from uncontrolled diabetes, which could make him lose consciousness.  And the waitress with panic attack disorder, who had a "meltdown" in a packed restaurant on New Year's Eve, was denied her demand that she have an assistant when the restaurant was crowded. **********Nonetheless, companies are fairly concerned that the law has become a weapon for any disgruntled employee who wants to bring a discrimination claim. **********Advocates for the disabled seem reluctant to acknowledge that the law imposes requirements on business that give disabled employees special treatment. They equate the measure with other equal employment laws, but employers will be wise to recognize that the mantra of equal treatment just doesn't cut it under the A.D.A. With input of the disabled employee, employers must provide assistance on an individual basis. After that, employers can only hope that a jury playing Monday morning quarterback will be convinced that the company acted in a "reasonable" manner. **********Readers may submit articles to Viewpoint or From the Desk Of, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York 10036, or send E-mail in care of viewpts@nytimes.com or fromdesk@nytimes.com. All submissions become the property of The Times. They may be edited and may be republished in any medium. If manuscrpits are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/09/busin.main_headline: Pond's gives its campaign a face lift and vaults into the top ranks of skin-care products.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/09/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Pond's gives its campaign a face lift and vaults into the top ranks of skin-care products.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/09/busin.body_text: **********IN the world of women's cosmetics, the caste system used to be as strict as that of India. In the upper castes dwelt the Estee Lauders and Chanels at Saks Fifth Avenue and Bergdorf Goodman, while in the lower castes the faux-designer perfumes and other pretenders sat in the murk of suburban strip malls. **********The marketing, for the most part, was as caste-ridden as the products. The Brahmins lavished millions on artfully sculptured bottles and skin-care jars, and even more artful magazine advertising. The outcastes skimped on packaging and advertised scarcely at all, and then only to rail at the $30 to $100 price tags of the prestige brands. **********Somewhere in between was Pond's, which has nonetheless managed to leap from No. 5 in its market to No. 2 in the last three years with a canny and largely successful attempt to erase those caste lines. Its latest attempt to further erase those barriers, backed by $45 million in advertising and marketing spending, begins this week. **********Pond's, a 149-year-old brand name, has until recently languished as a product line redolent of grandmother's cold cream. Pond's products are aimed at women aged 25 to 55 and its famous cream, derived from witch hazel, was invented in Utica, N.Y., by Theron T. Pond with the help of an Oneida Indian medicine man. **********Not surprisingly, modern women seemed wary of such a vintage legacy. "Women always said Pond's was for someone else, someone older, even if they were 55," said David Cohen, category director for Chesebrough-Pond's U.S.A. in Greenwich, Conn., a unit of London-based Unilever. **********By giving its mass-market product as many earmarks as possible of a prestige brand, however, Chesebrough-Pond's U.S.A. has sharply increased its market share. It has done so with new products, like Age Defying Complex, as well as with the Pond's Institute advertising campaign designed by Pond's ad agency since 1992, Ogilvy & Mather, which is owned by WPP Group. **********But the clincher may have been acid-etched glass. In a canny bit of legerdemain, Chesebrough-Pond's redesigned its bottles and other packaging to mimic the sculptured romanticism of the prestige brands. It now uses much the same heavy glass as in the $100 perfume bottles. **********But Pond's has retained mass-market prices. Pond's cold cream, the original product, sells for as little as $3.99 a jar and the product line tops out at $14.99 for Prevent & Correct, a new anti-aging product, which uses the popular alpha-hydroxy acid to help remove old skin. **********This week, in the print stage of its new campaign, Pond's is introducing an approach that mimics the glamour of fashion magazines while attempting to hold on to current customers who harbor a mild suspicion of glamour. The ads are beginning this week in People, McCall's and Ladies' Home Journal. **********For its new campaign, Pond's hired Herb Ritts, the fashion photographer known for his photos of models like Cindy Crawford and Naomi Campbell. **********"What we didn't need to do was warm up the Pond's brand; it was very respected," said Victoria V. Corcoran, a senior partner at Ogilvy & Mather. "But we did need to connect somehow with what women were feeling today." **********The Ritts photographs are framed like magazine covers. But the photos are not typical glamour shots -- a younger woman holds her face in her hands in a faintly comic gesture of stress, and in another a gray-haired woman in her 50's seems to be auditioning for the chief executive position at a company. **********"What Herb is terrific at is capturing moments instead of poses," said Glen Jacobs, an Ogilvy & Mather partner who oversaw the campaign. What the agency was seeking were portraits of practical women who seek dependability, value for money, but also effective skin care. **********"The campaign says, 'Look, we know you don't want to look 12 years old,' " Mr. Cohen of Chesebrough-Pond's said. "What you want is to look great for your age." **********The previous campaign centered on the Pond's Institute, a consumer-research center in Trumbull, Conn., that in television commercials somehow came to resemble the Mayo Clinic, with white-jacketed researchers tipping their horn-rimmed glasses as they peered at clipboards. The campaign effectively gave Pond's a scientific image that helped erase the grandmother image of old. **********The earlier campaign led to a lift in market share. In 1992, Pond's was an also-ran with a 7.8 percent share of a $655 million market in face-care products for the mass market, according to data from the A. C. Nielsen Company. Pond's trailed Neutrogena, now owned by Johnson & Johnson; L'Oreal's Plenitude; Procter & Gamble's Noxzema, and the market leader, P.& G.'s Oil of Olay. **********As of July 8, Pond's had a 13.5 percent share of an $810 million market and was No. 2, after Oil of Olay, which has a 20 percent share. **********"We knew that what women wanted was a little luxury for less," Mr. Cohen said. "This advertising will try to address that, too, but remain practical."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/11/busin.main_headline: Jefferson-Pilot Agrees to Buy Household's Life Insurance Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/11/busin.print_headline: Jefferson-Pilot Agrees to Buy Household's Life Insurance Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/11/busin.body_text: **********The Jefferson-Pilot Corporation said today that it had reached an agreement to buy Household International Inc.'s insurance unit for $575 million. **********The purchase of the unit, the Alexander Hamilton Life Insurance Company, based in Farmington Hills, Mich., would nearly double Jefferson-Pilot's assets, to about $14 billion. In addition to its insurance business, Jefferson-Pilot operates radio and television stations. **********"It really moves Jefferson-Pilot to a new plateau in the life industry," said John Hall, an analyst at Northington Partners Inc. "In a fairly mature industry which is not growing, scale is going to be increasingly important." **********Jefferson-Pilot, based in Greensboro, N.C., said the combined company would have about $631 million in annual revenue from life insurance premiums, up 89 percent from Jefferson-Pilot's current level. The combined company's annuity revenue would be more than three times that of Jefferson-Pilot's alone. **********Jefferson-Pilot, which is strongest in the Southeast, said it would be helped by Alexander Hamilton's strength in the Midwest and West. **********Household, which makes home-equity loans and issues credit cards, said it wanted to focus on its core business. The company, based in Prospect Heights, Ill., said it would use the sale proceeds to finance its lending operations and strengthen its capital base. **********"There's been a general trend for noninsurance companies who own insurance to get out of insurance," Mr. Hall said. In the past year, Deere & Company, Harcourt General Inc., and the Quaker State Corporation have sold all or part of their insurance operations, and Sears, Roebuck & Company spun off its majority stake in the Allstate Corporation. **********Alexander Hamilton contributed $42 million in operating income to Household last year. Household said it did not expect the sale to have a significant impact on per-share earnings this year. **********"While Alexander Hamilton is an excellent company, its business focus and customer base are much different from our core lending businesses, thereby detracting from our business focus," Household's chief executive, William F. Aldinger, said in a statement. **********Jefferson-Pilot shares rose $1.625 to close at $57.375 in trading of 287,500 shares, more than twice its daily average of 90,600 in the last three months. Household shares climbed 37.5 cents to close at $52.125 in trading of 114,700 shares, compared with a three-month daily average of 252,200.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/21/world.main_headline: Mexican Talks With Rebels Are Delayed
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/21/world.print_headline: Mexican Talks With Rebels Are Delayed
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/21/world.body_text: **********More than a year after a first round of peace talks failed to end an armed uprising in the southern Mexican state of Chiapas, Government representatives delayed resuming the talks today until their safety was guaranteed by the rebels. **********Surrounded by hundreds of sympathizers of the Zapatista rebels, representatives of both sides were scheduled to meet in a hastily erected building on top of the town's concrete basketball court to discuss, among other things, proposals for a permanent truce to ease tensions and end the 16-month-old rebellion. **********But in an indication of how complicated a task it will be, the Government delegates refused to enter the building because of the rebel sympathizers, some of whom wore traditional ribboned hats and carried signs saying, "We are all Zapatistas." The Government said their presence violated the neutrality of the talks, and it refused to allow its delegates to enter San Andres until their safe passage could be guaranteed. **********Rosario Ibarra de Piedra, an opposition member of Congress who had come to witness the talks, ridiculed the Government's position. "What did they expect," she said. "If the talks had been held in New York City, there would have been sympathizers." **********The standoff is the latest frustration to arise from the uprising, which began with 12 days of armed skirmishes in January 1994 that left more than 145 dead. Since then, there has been practically no violence, but the threat that the two sides might again clash has hung heavily over the state, damaging investor confidence in Mexico and raising political tensions that affected last year's presidential election. **********The situation has changed drastically since February, when the Government arrested several people it accused of being rebel leaders, identified the masked spokesman who had been known only as Subcommander Marcos as a radical college professor, and sent a huge force of federal troops into the rebels' highland forest stronghold. The rebels, who are mostly Mayan Indians, have been surrounded since then, while attempts were made to reopen formal peace talks. **********Masked representatives of the Zapatista National Liberation Army arrived here to cheers Wednesday night with what their leaders said was a specific proposal for a permanent truce. Government negotiators also said they had come with a plan for lowering tensions and eliminating the lingering military threat. **********But Government officials said they were seeking more than a resolution of the military aspect of the rebellion. **********"In terms of military force, the Zapatistas no longer have any," said a Government official close to the negotiations. "What we need to do here is resolve the deeper issues in a way that does not leave behind any resentment that can become another problem in the future." **********Although they are surrounded by Mexican troops, the Zapatistas still represent a formidable public relations threat with support throughout Mexico. The Government, beset by economic and political problems, feels it must take the rebels seriously, and many Government officials fear that an outburst of violence or a terrorist attack would severely set back Mexico's attempts at recovering from the economic crisis caused by the devaluation of the peso in December. **********The current Government plan is for the negotiating sessions with the rebels to continue for several months, perhaps till the end of this year. Each round of talks will deal with specific themes. In later sessions, the Government will take up rebel demands concerning land rights and the brutal poverty in which the Indians of Chiapas live. **********This threadbare community, about 15 miles northwest of San Cristobal de las Casas, is a Zapatista stronghold that mirrors the conditions the rebels have said forced them to take up arms. Nearly all the 15,000 residents of the area speak a variety of Indian languages; more than half have never attended school; less than 15 percent of the houses have plumbing, and only 25 percent have electricity. **********Government officials have made it clear that they will not expand the talks to include national issues, like democratic reform, that the rebels have tried to place on the agenda. Nor, officials said, will the Government succumb to pressures from conservative parts of society that want to see a quick end to the rebel movement. **********"The policy of the Government is not based on pressures but on meeting the goals and objectives of the people of Chiapas," said another Government official close to the talks. **********Today's planned talks follow a preliminary session on April 9 between rebels and the Government that was meant to beat a deadline imposed by the Mexican Congress. Arrest orders against rebel leaders had been suspended for a month by a special amnesty law but would have become effective again on April 10 if the rebels had not taken steps to begin the long-stalled process of negotiation. As long as the talks continue, the Government has pledged to keep the arrest orders suspended. **********Both the Government and rebel leaders are declaring their openness to discuss all issues and to work for a solution to the conflict that has dragged on for 16 months at great cost to Chiapas and to Mexico. **********It is clear that part of the Government's strategy is to differentiate these talks from those that failed in February 1994. Then, the Government was represented by an independent peace commissioner, Manuel Camacho Solis, who personally attracted nearly as much attention as the rebel leader Subcommander Marcos, who has become a national hero. **********Those talks were held under wide publicity in the cathedral of San Cristobal de las Casas. After several days, delegates emerged with a 32-point preliminary settlement, which eventually was rejected by the rebels. **********This time, the Government is represented by officials of the Interior Ministry and a bipartisan Congressional commission. The rebel contingent is not led not by Subcommander Marcos, who did not show up, but by Commander Tacho and other Maya Indians who speak only halting Spanish. **********This round of talks is expected to last for two days.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/25/busin.snippet: WHAT'S in a name? In the case of the "Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995," conumers will find a world-class misnomer. Now before the Senate, the bill is more accurately described as securities litigation repeal. For millions of middl...
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/25/busin.main_headline:
VOICES: VIEWPOINT;
Securities Litigation Bill Is Reform in Name Only
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/25/busin.print_headline:
VOICES: VIEWPOINT;
Securities Litigation Bill Is Reform in Name Only
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/25/busin.body_text: **********WHAT'S in a name? In the case of the "Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995," conumers will find a world-class misnomer. Now before the Senate, the bill is more accurately described as securities litigation repeal. For millions of middle-class American investors, the fate of this bill -- and the even more radical version passed by the House of Representatives in March -- could spell the difference between recovering or losing billions of dollars from securities fraud. **********Securities litigation reform began with the intent of putting some weights around the ankles of a few fleet-footed lawyers; but the measure now dangerously close to Senate passage would wind up being a noose around the neck of defrauded investors. While everyone agrees on the need for reasonable reform, numerous public-minded groups are strongly opposed to radical steps in the Senate bill, S.240, that would snuff out key investor rights. **********If securities litigation reform was the real goal here, the widespread support that exists for reasonable steps to curb lawsuit abuses would have insured easy passage. But the bill now before the Senate would rein in frivolous lawsuits only by making it virtually impossible for consumers to pursue rightful claims. Here we see the financial world's equivalent of the notorious Vietnam "hamlet strategy": we must destroy this village in order to save it. **********The reality is that the main intent of this legislation, despite what its proponents say, is to provide a shield for all but the most extreme cases of fraud. Have the members of the Senate already forgotten the financial scandals of the 1980's that cost investors and taxpayers billions of dollars? Is it really good public policy to erect protective barriers around future wrongdoers who will be emboldened to emulate Lincoln Savings and Loan and Prudential Securities? **********At the heart of consumer concerns over this legislation are two key problems. **********Under current rules, public companies are prevented from deceiving investors by reasonable restrictions on statements concerning future corporate performance, known as "forward-looking statements." The original S.240 created a limited "safe harbor" for such statements, but the harbor was changed to an ocean. So now the Senate is considering a measure that protects any reckless or irresponsible statement by a company about its future as long as the statement is represented as forward-looking and notes that actual results may differ. **********The Senate bill narrowly defines as fraudulent only those statements "knowingly made with the expectation, purpose and actual intent of misleading investors." As if this was not a loose enough standard, the bill requires that each of the three conditions be proven separately in court. **********Consequently, S.240 is a dagger aimed at the heart of what makes possible strong public confidence in the markets: full, fair disclosure mandated under Federal securities law. Arthur Levitt Jr., the Securities and Exchange Commission chairman, has noted: "I cannot embrace proposals which allow willful fraud to receive the benefit of safe harbor protection." **********Perhaps the clearest sign, however, that the bill's proponents have sold middle-class investors down the river is their refusal to lengthen the time in which consumers can bring cases to court. The current rule derives from a 1991 Supreme Court decision that created a statute of limitations for Federal securities law cases of one year from discovery of a misdeed or three years from the commission of the act in question. This represented a serious reduction in the time available for such lawsuits, since Federal courts previously had relied on state standards for statutes of limitation. **********Currently, 31 states permit longer than the "1 and 3" standard for the filing of state securities cases. What possible case can the backers of this bill make for keeping the time limit as short as possible so that future swindlers who cover their tracks carefuly will get off the hook for good? **********Fortunately, efforts are under way to pull the measure back toward the interests of small investors. Among the amendments expected to be deliberated on the Senate floor this week are measures that would: replace the expansive safe harbor for forward-looking statements with a directive to the S.E.C. to continue its rulemaking efforts in this area; lengthen the statute of limitations for private securities fraud actions; fully restore aiding and abetting liability under the securities laws, an established concept that, before it was recently removed by a Supreme Court decision, made it possible to sue even indirect participants in a fraud, and lift the severe limitations the bill imposes on joint and several liability, allowing investors to continue recovering from all participants in the fraud. **********The difference between reform and repeal of securities litigation is an enormous one for middle-class investors in America. Based on current payments to securities class-action claimants, it should be expected that shutting the doors of America's courthouses over the next five years to securities fraud victims will result in 1.79 million investors losing the right to recover approximately $2.87 billion. Even these numbers may underestimate matters. **********By loosening the Federal laws that now empower citizens to go to court to restrain misconduct in our financial marketplace, Congress has the potential to unleash a new, painful era of financial fraud.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/10/world.body_text: **********"Emerging viruses" is the medical world's understated phrase for the several strange and often deadly pathogens, little explored in Western textbooks, that have appeared out of the blue or expanded well beyond their range in recent years. **********While doctors still debate whether the new agents are homegrown ones that have acquired a special virulence or exotic agents unleashed on the world as civilization invades their forest refuges, writers and film makers have rushed in to chronicle the horrors of mystery viruses. **********The Ebola virus is the villain of the "The Hot Zone" by Richard Preston, published last year and still on the best-seller lists after 30 weeks. The book focuses on an outbreak of Ebola virus in 1989 among monkeys in a holding facility in Reston, Va., and gives a hair-raising account of an outbreak of the disease among humans in Zaire in 1976, where it killed 18 of 21 people infected by a single individual. **********The Ebola virus and other emergent pathogens, like those of Legionnaires' disease, AIDS and Hantavirus, are described in "A Dancing Matrix: Voyages Along the Viral Frontier" by Robin Marantz Henig and "The Coming Plague: Newly Emerging Diseases in a World Out of Balance" by Laurie Garrett. Both books emphasize the incompleteness of medical knowledge and the need for surveillance systems to detect the new pathogens at an early moment. **********A fictional work on the same theme is the 1987 thriller "Outbreak" by Robin Cook, made into a current hit movie of the same name as well as a television movie called "Robin Cook's 'Virus'," which was broadcast Monday on NBC. **********"The Hot Zone" was also destined for Hollywood, under the title "Crisis in the Hot Zone" but was dropped when "Outbreak" seemed to have won the virulence race.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/28/world.main_headline: Tangshan Journal; After Eating Bitterness, 100 Flowers Blossom
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/28/world.print_headline: Tangshan Journal; After Eating Bitterness, 100 Flowers Blossom
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/28/world.body_text: **********Here at the site of the deadliest earthquake in the last two and a half centuries, He Shuyun, a 46-year-old Communist Party member, expresses nothing but sympathy for the quake victims of Kobe, Japan. **********But more than concern, Mr. He and others in this industrial city 105 miles southeast of Beijing exude resilience. Since a quake struck Tangshan nearly 19 years ago, they have shown through enterprise and determination that life goes on even in the face of devastation and death 50 times greater than the disaster that hit the industrial city in western Japan last week. **********"We know what it's like," Mr. He said, standing in the preserved ruins of a library on the campus of the Tangshan Institute of Technology. The building is one of seven memorials to the destructive power of the vast quake, which killed 242,000 people and injured 160,000 when it struck at 3:42 A.M. on July 28, 1976. **********China has borne the brunt of some of the worst earthquakes on record, at a cost of 550,000 lives in this century alone. The Tangshan quake is believed to be the world's third-most destructive in 2,000 years. Nearly a generation later, many older city residents still cannot bear to talk about it. **********The quake measured 7.8 on the Richter scale. For 20 seconds the landscape heaved repeatedly, pummeling the city of just over a million residents with earth-splitting jolts and causing all but a handful of buildings to collapse on sleeping residents. **********All communications were cut off. People crawled from the rubble dazed and in darkness. A light drizzle was falling. Nearly one-fourth of Tangshan's residents were dead. **********"Seven thousand families were completely exterminated," said Lu Shushan, a city official who in 1976 was a Chinese teacher at the No. 13 Middle School. He was buried when his house collapsed but managed to struggle out of the rubble by himself. **********"It was very silent for a few seconds, and then you began to hear the shouts and cries," said Liu Chuanzhen, a member of the city planning commission who also pulled herself out of her collapsed house that day. **********It took 12 hours for the central authorities in Beijing to discover that Tangshan, at the quake's epicenter, had been completely leveled. **********Mao lay dying, and his potential successors were engaged in a fierce power struggle. They learned of the scale of the disaster only because a Tangshan coal miner, Li Yulin, drove a red ambulance for six hours along dirt roads to reach Beijing. His face muddied and clothes tattered, he rolled right up to the imposing gates of Zhongnanhai, the high-walled compound where China's leaders live, to give his report. **********It took days to mobilize the army and start relief operations. The Tangshan residents dug with their hands, stacking tens of thousands of bodies along the alleyways and roads so choked by debris that the trucks could not always get through to remove the dead. **********Airplanes flew over the city spewing disinfectant to stop the spread of disease. **********China's leaders forbade foreigners from traveling to the area and rejected offers of aid from international relief agencies. Instead, they organized a lean recovery operation whose name reflected the politics of the time: "Resist the Earthquake and Rescue Ourselves." **********It was a time of eating bitterness, as the Chinese like to say. With no water and only bags of biscuits dropped from airplanes in the first days, the people of this city had little time to mourn the dead, whose bodies were dumped in mass graves. **********"No one cried," recalled Mr. Lu. "It was so big and so many people died that the streets and alleys were all piled up with corpses. People didn't even think to cry." **********It took China more than a decade to rebuild the city. Some residents did not get new housing until 1988. The central Government called on China's provinces to send planners and engineers to Tangshan. The city of Shanghai took responsibility for one neighborhood, and Sichuan, Hubei and Shanxi provinces took responsibility for others. **********"Basically, a whole new city was planned on top of the ruins," said Zhao Shuzhen, the municipal secretary. The Chinese Communist Party apparatus mobilized volunteer construction brigades, and factories contributed construction materials. Tangshan residents did the rest. **********Tangshan's rebirth has coincided with China's opening to the outside world, after the death of Mao only weeks after the earthquake and the rise of Deng Xiaoping a year later as China's paramount leader. **********In Chinese history, disasters are said to foretell the end of dynasties or the deaths of great leaders. Many Chinese saw the Tangshan earthquake as an omen of Mao's passing, just as some Chinese today say the Kobe quake may presage the death of Mr. Deng, who is 90 and in declining health. **********Today, Tangshan is again a prosperous industrial city. The population has grown to 1.55 million, and economic output has increased sixfold since 1976. The city now ranks 23d among China's 460 urban centers in the total value of its industrial and agricultural production. **********Foreign companies have signed contracts to invest more than $1 billion in the city's 550 joint ventures. Though Tangshan preserves its earthquake memorials, municipal leaders now prefer, as they do throughout China, to steer any conversation to foreign investment and how to attract more of it. **********Yet the scars remain, some less visible than others. A mental hospital still shelters those who broke under the strain. A hospital for paraplegics cares for people who were maimed or crushed. **********On a recent sunny afternoon at the Institute of Technology, an elderly man with a snowy white beard shuffled along the walkway. He was asked if he remembered the events of that day. **********"Oh, I remember," he said. Asked to share his recollections, he just smiled, then shuffled away silently.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/17/busin.main_headline: Sorry, Orville, but Redenbacher's new look emphasizes youth.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/17/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Sorry, Orville, but Redenbacher's new look emphasizes youth.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/17/busin.body_text: **********ORVILLE REDENBACHER is inexorably being Betty Crockered. **********For the first time, the avuncular Mr. Redenbacher is absent from advertising for a popcorn product bearing his name, just as Ms. Crocker, the mythical homemaker, is no longer visible in campaigns for the food and baking items named after her. **********A television commercial that begins running this week, introducing two additional varieties of the Redenbudders line of flavored microwave popcorns, omits Mr. Redenbacher but for a fleeting glimpse on the package logos. In a second spot, for a line of popcorn cakes in test markets, he makes only a cameo appearance at the end. **********The case of the missing popcorn pitcher isn't difficult to solve. The reason is age: not Mr. Redenbacher's -- he turned 88 yesterday -- but rather consumer demographics. The face of the brand, No. 1 by a wide margin in the microwave popcorn market, is being reshaped by Ketchum Advertising San Francisco, its agency since 1975, to appeal to snackers aged 25 to 34. They prefer potato chips or pretzels to popcorn because the gratification found inside a microwave oven isn't instant enough. **********"He's 88, but he's a very vibrant man still out there spreading the word," said David Rohdy, marketing director for the Orville Redenbacher's brand at the Hunt-Wesson division of Conagra Inc. in Fullerton, Calif. **********"Microwaving, in general, tends to skew to consumers over age 35," he added. "We see an opportunity to bring in a younger group." So in the Redenbudders commercial, a couple of 20-somethings are the sole stars, unchaperoned by Mr. Redenbacher. And in the spot for Orville Redenbacher's 100 Percent Popcorn Cakes, the plot centers on office workers who hide the snack from their officious boss. **********The remaking of the Orville Redenbacher's image speaks to a larger point about the care and feeding of powerful brand icons: the only constant is change. **********For instance, General Mills has had to update the look of the make-believe Betty Crocker six times after the first portrait of the character was commissioned in 1936, most recently in 1986. But perhaps because a single painting cannot convey the diversity of contemporary cooks -- including many Benny Crockers -- a red spoon with the Betty Crocker signature always appears now in place of the portrait. **********As the irascible Frank Perdue began turning over the operations of Perdue Farms to his son, Jim, advertising by Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, featured both men for several months last year before switching to solo son spots. **********And the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company unit of RJR Nabisco Holdings has shifted to multiple camels in campaigns for Camel cigarettes: Old Joe, the venerable original mascot; Joe Camel, the cartoon version peddling Camel Filters and Camel Lights, and updated versions of Old Joe for store signs and promotional programs like a series of "Classic Camel Collector's Packs," featuring vintage advertisements, going on sale next month. **********The issue is "holding onto the characteristics of the brand," said Tom Freyer, a senior vice president and creative director at Ketchum San Francisco, owned by Ketchum Communications. **********"Orville will always be a strong presence," Mr. Freyer added, "because he built the company, he built the brand. We've done a lot of research and to consumers he is popcorn. **********"At the same time, you want the brand to have its own identity to some degree." **********Mr. Rohdy concurred. "Consumers want to know it's from Orville and has his quality standards," he said. But particularly with newer products like Redenbudders and the popcorn cakes, "we found the name is definitely enough to communicate that," he added. **********The Redenbudders commercial will appear through the fall on local and national broadcast and cable stations and networks. Though Mr. Rodhy declined to discuss the budget, he said the brand typically spends $5 million to $7 million on introductions. **********The popcorn cakes spot has been running since February in two test-market regions; one is Albany, Buffalo, Rochester and Syracuse, and the other is Denver, Phoenix and Salt Lake City. A third region -- Cleveland, Detroit, Pittsburgh and Grand Rapids, Mich. -- is being added this month. Sales results so far "are very, very positive," Mr. Rohdy said, but no decision has been made about introducing the line nationally, where it would compete with the dominant Quaker, Mother's and Chico-San brands marketed by the Quaker Oats Company. **********For some misguided snack eaters, Mr. Redenbacher has been completely Crockered. **********"There are people out there who think Orville Redenbacher's not a real person," Mr. Rohdy said, laughing. "He likes to say if he were an actor, there'd be a much better actor up there."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/06/busin.main_headline: GILBERT ASSOCIATES TO PAY $30 MILLION FOR XEL STOCK
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; GILBERT ASSOCIATES TO PAY $30 MILLION FOR XEL STOCK
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/06/busin.body_text: **********Gilbert Associates Inc. of Reading, Pa., said yesterday that it had agreed to buy all of the XEL Corporation's common stock for $30 million in cash. Gilbert, which owns the GAI-Tronics Corporation, a supplier of industrial communications equipment, would pay XEL shareholders more if XEL, which makes computer network products, meets earnings targets in the fourth quarters of 1996, 1997 and 1998, and meets revenue targets from 1996 until 1998. Gilbert Associates said it would use the proceeds from its recent sale of its Gilbert/Commonwealth unit to the Parsons Corporation for the purchase of XEL, a closely held company based in Aurora, Colo.
