BBA Group of Britain had acquired Muhlebach in June as part of a takeover of the German company Holvis A.G. (Dow Jones)

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/06/busin.body_text: **********After 15 months of robust growth, the American economy is beginning to slow. But no one can know yet from the scant emerging evidence whether the slowdown will turn out to be only a lull -- followed by another stretch of strong growth -- or the beginning of a slide toward much slower economic growth, if not recession. **********Auto sales and home construction, the two pillars of growth, remain mostly intact. But once built, the new homes now sell less quickly. Many retailers find they must offer bigger discounts to keep people buying. Manufacturers say that while they are still very busy, new orders are not as numerous. And last month, for the first time since 1992, the unemployment rate rose. **********"I am hearing in the past two months comments that I had not heard before, comments that new orders are flat or slowing," said Ralph Kaufman of the National Association of Purchasing Managers, which conducts a monthly survey of its members, who are all in manufacturing. "Some of the managers feel that the higher interest rates are starting to take hold." **********Yet the hard data is far from conclusive. "It is mostly straws in the wind, a sense things are not going as well as they had been," said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office. **********No straw seems more noticeable than the stockpiles of merchandise and materials piling up at stores and warehouses. Virtually every forecaster expects stockpiling to be less robust this year than last, helping to slow the economy. The slowdown could turn into a recession in the unlikely event merchants decided, more or less simultaneously, that they had stockpiled much more than they could sell. After all, their inventories in the last quarter reached three times standard levels -- and a reluctance to order more goods would have a ripple effect. **********Factories would be forced to cut back, layoffs would rise, consumer confidence would falter and the economy would slow sharply. That sequence has been a major cause of recessions in the past. **********"The most important ingredient for a slowdown is in place," said Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist. **********But right now, the nation's merchants are not talking cutback. "Our inventories are right where we expect them to be," said Harold Ruttenberg, chairman of Just for Feet, a chain of 15 sporting goods stores based in Birmingham, Ala. **********Still, some store owners are clearly concerned. "We had a very strong Christmas season, but my inventory is higher than I want," said Craig Cooper, owner of Bikes to You, a bicycle shop in Grinnell, Iowa. "My suppliers are eager to extend credit to me to get their goods into the store. Ultimately, as the retailer, I have the final say, but they are offering discounts and deals on credit that I just cannot refuse." **********Economic recoveries in the United States typically alternate between strong growth and lulls. That was the pattern during the recovery that lasted through most of the 1980's. A lull now would be the second in the current recovery, which began in March 1991, with the end of the last recession. The first came in the winter and spring of 1993. **********The Federal Reserve, of course, has been encouraging the onset of a lull by raising interest rates steadily since last February, and most recently last week, when it raised the lending rates it controls by half of a percentage point -- hoping to slow the economy by damping demand for housing, cars and other goods and services purchased on credit. Less growth, in turn, would keep inflation from rising. **********So far 15 months of strong economic growth have produced neither rising inflation nor rising wage levels, the principal source of inflation. But Fed officials and many economists say that absent a lull, in which economic growth would decline to an annual rate of 2.5 percent from the current 4 percent, both phenomena are just around the corner. **********In their view, the economy is too much like it was in 1988 and 1989. In those years, labor costs and the inflation rate rose after a period of low unemployment and weak inflation very much like today. Although the unemployment rate rose by three-tenths of 1 percent in January, to 5.7 percent, many economists consider that rate still low enough to produce labor shortages and wage pressures. **********"Economists are no better than the readers of history," Professor Gordon said, "and the big historical caution is that in 1988 and 1989, inflation did accelerate." **********The antidote, rising interest rates, is beginning to have an effect and, if precedent holds, the effect will be even greater in 1995. Home sales, for example, have fallen since October, partly in response to a 30-year mortgage rate that averages 9.1 percent today, more than two percentage points higher than late 1993. And rising rates might help to account for a phenomenon that manufacturers are just beginning to report. **********Manufacturing has played an important role in the robust growth. Factories have operated at full capacity, and while wage levels have not risen, overtime pay and bonuses have put spending money in the pockets of tens of thousands of people. But now orders for production several months ahead are no longer growing at their old rate, according to the National Association of Purchasing Managers. **********The Mexican crisis might also be a factor. Exports have been an important source of new orders and sales, but that market might shrink this year, partly as a result of the Mexican crisis, with its ripple effect. Latin America accounts for more than 20 percent of this nation's overseas sales. **********Still, American consumers have been at the heart of the strong economic growth, and the rising interest rates have cut only slightly into their buying habits, says Richard T. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center. **********Mr. Curtin cites several reasons. What with overtime and more people holding jobs today than a year ago, the total income available for spending has risen, even though individual wages have not. Then, too, Mr. Curtin's surveys show that most consumers do not expect a recession, despite the rising interest rates, and for this reason, their fear of layoffs has diminished. **********"There is some point when consumers will judge that current Fed policies have crossed some threshold and the rising rates will cause a recession," Mr. Curtin said. "That threshold has not been crossed yet." **********Most important, consumers have adjusted. While in the past, they would have cut spending abruptly if their wages failed to rise faster than the inflation rate, today they keep spending as long as their wages manage to keep up with inflation. **********"There was a sense in the 1970's that if you were not gaining ground on inflation, you must be losing ground; you could not stand still," Mr. Curtin said. "That attitude is no longer true. There is greater acceptance now of slowly improving living standards."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/20/busin.main_headline: GILLETTE AGREES TO BUY A MAKER OF EAR THERMOMETERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; GILLETTE AGREES TO BUY A MAKER OF EAR THERMOMETERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/20/busin.body_text: **********The Gillette Company agreed to buy Thermoscan Inc., a maker of infrared ear thermometers, for $105 million in cash, Thermoscan said yesterday. Thermoscan, based in San Diego, makes thermometers that measure body temperature by measuring the light energy generated by the eardrum and surrounding tissues. As part of the transaction, Gillette will assume an unspecified amount of debt. Gillette, which is based in Boston, will merge Thermoscan with a subsidiary.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/17/world.main_headline: Gulf Nations Balk at Proposal for Mideast Development Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/17/world.print_headline: Gulf Nations Balk at Proposal for Mideast Development Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/17/world.body_text: **********A proposal championed by the Clinton Administration and Israel to create a regional Middle East Development Bank appears to have been dealt a major blow by Arab countries, with officials saying they will neither finance such a bank nor take part in it. **********The unusually forceful position from the diplomatically timid Persian Gulf countries appears to be part of an Arab retreat from further normalization with Israel. **********The bank proposal was a key part of the American approach to the Middle East peace effort, intended to integrate Israel into regional Arab economies through joint developmental projects. **********The idea was resisted for months by several Arab countries that had been expected to be donors to the bank, mostly the members of the Gulf Cooperation Council, which is led by Saudi Arabia and whose members are Kuwait, Qatar, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates and Oman. **********It was supported by others, mostly Egypt, Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization, along with Israel, all of which expected the bank to be a source of additional financing for their economies. **********Now, officials and columnists in the gulf countries are going further in their resistance, arguing in statements and editorial commentary that wider economic cooperation with Israel will have to wait until full peace has been established. **********In a weekend news conference timed to coincide with a visit by the American Secretary of Commerce, Ronald H. Brown, to the United Arab Emirates, Ahmad bin Humayd al-Tayir, the United Arab Emirates Minister of State for Financial and Industrial Affairs, said, "The Arab world is not in need of an institution or a development bank in which Israel participates." **********Mr. Tayir added, "Before talking or thinking of establishing a common Middle East market, some balance in security and economic interests between the Arabs and Israel must be established, and the Arab world's interests must be assured in political, social and economic areas against plans to dominate us and impose facts upon us." **********On Monday, a Saudi official who spoke on condition of anonymity, said in a telephone interview, "Our position has been stated repeatedly in the meetings of the Gulf Cooperation Council, which is that any talk of regional cooperation with Israel is premature until Israeli troops leave Arab lands in the West Bank, Gaza, Syria and Lebanon." **********Writing in the Saudi daily Asharq Al Awsat on Monday, Abdelrahman al-Rashid, an influential Saudi political columnist, argued that Arab gulf countries feel the bank project "is another financial tax imposed upon them which they cannot accept, and even if they accepted it, they will not be able to fulfill it because of their difficult financial circumstances." **********Similar objections were raised during a major Middle East economic conference in October in Casablanca, Morocco, where the idea of the bank first surfaced, along with other projects for regional economic cooperation that would involve Arab countries, Israel and Turkey. **********The development reflects palpable cooling of an earlier enthusiasm after Israel signed peace treaties with the P.L.O. and Jordan last year. Then several Arab gulf countries, including Oman, Qatar, Bahrain, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, lifted an economic boycott against companies doing business with Israel and allowed officials to meet with their Israeli counterparts in several Arab and world capitals. **********But on Saturday, Hamad bin Jasim bin Jabir al-Thani, the Foreign Minister of Qatar, which was one of the first gulf countries to hold public talks with Israel on economic and political cooperation, told Qatar television that his country would not "rush to establish ties to Israel." He denied there were plans to export natural gas to Israel. **********Israeli officials had said several months ago that they were in the final stages of negotiating a deal to import natural gas from Qatar. **********The Qatari Foreign Minister also denied in an interview that there were plans to open representational offices in Israel. "Such a step can only be taken at the appropriate time," he said. **********After the Morocco meeting, the United States said it was scaling down the project, which was first proposed with a initial capital of $10 billion. But Washington insisted that the idea continued to enjoy support among several Arab countries, including those in the Gulf region, and that it would be pursued.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/29/world.main_headline: NATO Presents Plan to Expand Alliance
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/29/world.print_headline: NATO Presents Plan to Expand Alliance
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/29/world.body_text: **********NATO today set out its vision of expansion for Central European and other countries eager to join the alliance, but was apparently unable to reassure Russia that expansion would not recreate the East-West divisions of the cold war. **********"What we have seen so far is not enough for us to change our minds about the prospects of NATO enlargement," Vitaly I. Churkin, the Russian Ambassador to Belgium, said after receiving copies of a 28-page study and hearing a two-hour presentation at NATO headquarters. **********"Feelings are very strong about this in Russia," Mr. Churkin said. "We are still against it. The matter has not been thought through in the context of European security." **********Western diplomats here said the Russian reaction came as no surprise, since Russia was aware that Central European countries like Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic want to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as a guarantee against the threat of renewed Russian expansion. **********NATO's Secretary General, Willy Claes, said it would probably take time before the Russians lost their fears, just as it would take time before the allies were ready to take in the first new member, a process that would require approval by the United States Senate and the parliaments of NATO's 15 other members. **********"A larger NATO will threaten no one," Mr. Claes insisted as Mr. Churkin listened impassively. After the initial Russian reaction, the NATO chief reiterated, "We cannot imagine a strong, credible security architecture in Europe without Russia." **********The enlargement study that NATO handed out today did not indicate which countries might eventually join the alliance, or when. But the study made it clear that before admitting new members, the United States and other allies would have to be fully prepared to come to the assistance of the new members, even with nuclear weapons, if they came under attack. **********It also made clear that expansion would cost money, perhaps a lot of money, not only from new members but from existing ones, and it took pains to reassure Russia that any eastward expansion would go hand in hand with the intensification of NATO's relationship with Moscow. **********"NATO-Russia cooperation can help to overcome any lingering distrust from the cold-war period, and help insure that Europe is never again divided into opposing camps," the document asserted, adding that relations between the alliance and Russia should be developed parallel to NATO's eventual enlargement. **********But it made clear the question was not whether the allies would invite new members to join, but when, since most prospective applicants were likely to join the 15-country European Union in the next decade. **********Some Russian positions were dismissed summarily. **********"NATO decisions cannot be subject to any veto or droit de regard  [ right to be consulted ]  by a nonmember state, nor can the alliance be subordinated to another European security institution," it said. Moscow has often said that NATO should be subordinated to the Vienna-based Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, a 54-member group that grew out of the cold war and that includes the United States, Russia and nearly all European states. **********"Ultimately, allies will decide by consensus whether to invite each new member to join, according to their judgment of whether doing so will contribute to security and stability in the North Atlantic area at the time such a decision is to be made," the study said. **********New members would face "substantial financial obligations," the study said, since they would be expected to make their equipment, headquarters and operating procedures compatible with NATO's and help pay for joint military programs and peacekeeping operations. **********"There is no a priori requirement for the stationing of nuclear weapons on the territory of new members," it said in an attempt to reassure Russia that expanding the alliance would not mean advancing NATO's nuclear arsenal to Moscow's western doorstep. **********"In light of both the current international environment and the potential threats facing the alliance, NATO's current nuclear posture will, for the foreseeable future, continue to meet the requirements of an enlarged alliance," the study continued, though it added that this could change. **********"For new members, the peacetime stationing of other allies' forces on their territory should neither be a condition of membership nor foreclosed as an option," it continued, adding that NATO currently had no intention of moving troops eastward. **********"All allies must of course be prepared in times of crisis or war to allow other allies' forces to enter and operate on their territory," it said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/19/busin.main_headline: BellSouth, Seeking Savings, Is Planning More Job Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/19/busin.print_headline: BellSouth, Seeking Savings, Is Planning More Job Cuts
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/19/busin.body_text: **********Conceding that an earlier program of job cuts had not reduced costs enough, the BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that it would reduce its work force by another 9,000 to 11,000 employees by the middle of 1997. **********BellSouth announced its first big cutback, of 10,200 employees, in late 1993. The company, based in Atlanta, said yesterday that only 5,200 workers, or about half the projected number, had retired or been laid off so far. That means BellSouth must remove 14,000 to 16,000 more workers from its payroll in the next two years. **********"We still are not at the cost levels we need to be competitive in this marketplace," said Jere A. Drummond, president and chief executive of BellSouth Telecommunications, the company's core subsidiary, which offers local phone service to more than 14 million customers in nine states throughout the South. **********Mr. Drummond added that 70 percent of the reductions would affect blue-collar workers and 30 percent would affect white-collar employees. **********The job cuts will not end with this reduction, either. Mr. Drummond informed employees of BellSouth yesterday that the company would initiate another round of cuts in the fall, though that reduction would be far smaller. Mr. Drummond said that by 1997, BellSouth will have slashed its labor force by 30 percent, to roughly 58,000. The company began trimming in 1991. **********Shares of BellSouth fell $1.375, to $60.625, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. **********All seven regional Bell companies have struggled to rein in costs as their once-protected markets have opened to new competition from long-distance carriers and cable television companies. For many of them, that has meant huge job cuts. **********Mr. Drummond said BellSouth had worked assiduously to reduce its costs by replacing aging equipment and shutting or consolidating service centers. But the company still ranks as the second-costliest operator among the Bells. According to Furman Selz, an investment firm, only the Nynex Corporation has higher costs. **********Elaine Altman, a telecommunications analyst at Furman Selz, said BellSouth had an added incentive to streamline, because the company recently won regulatory relief in two states, Georgia and North Carolina. The BellSouth rates in those states had previously been set to generate a predetermined rate of return. **********Now, however, BellSouth will be able to retain the extra cash it generates through cost savings. "There's some head room and incentive to cut costs under these new regulations," Mrs. Altman said. **********Mr. Drummond said the new reductions could result in a charge against the company's earnings. But he said BellSouth had not made a final judgment because new, generally accepted accounting principles required companies to describe very specifically the financial impact of a work-force reduction. BellSouth would not be able to establish the cost of its cuts until sometime this summer, he said. **********BellSouth took a charge of $1.2 billion to $1.3 billion to cover its last cutback. That charge, though, included a write-down of aging equipment and plant consolidations. If BellSouth takes a charge this time, Mr. Drummond said, it will be in the range of $300 million to $400 million. **********Until now, analysts considered BellSouth something of a laggard among the Bells in preparing for new competition. To a certain extent, the company has not had to worry that much: Its mostly rural markets have attracted fewer new rivals than the more urban markets served by Nynex or the Pacific Telesis Group. **********Pacific Telesis said on Monday that it was reducing its projected earnings for 1995 by 10 percent, in part because of fierce competition from the AT&T Corporation and the MCI Communications Corporation in the short-haul long-distance market. Long-distance carriers are not allowed into that market in most states in the BellSouth region. **********But Mr. Drummond said BellSouth was starting to feel the pressure from its new rivals, particularly in the lucrative access market, in which calls are handed off from long-distance to the local phone network. **********Mr. Drummond said BellSouth had reduced the access fee it charged to long-distance carriers by 18 percent since 1989, in response to the inroads made by so-called competitive access providers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/22/busin.main_headline: Dismissal of Security Expert Adds Fuel to Internet Debate
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/22/busin.print_headline: Dismissal of Security Expert Adds Fuel to Internet Debate
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/22/busin.body_text: **********Depending on your attitude toward Satan, a skilled computer security expert named Dan Farmer is either a genius or a menace. **********Satan is a sophisticated software program, intended to find the security flaws in any computer system linked to the global Internet. Mr. Farmer helped create Satan and plans to begin distributing it free over the Internet early next month. He sees its dissemination as a public service to computer administrators who want to identify the chinks in their security armor so they can fix them. **********But his employer, Silicon Graphics Inc., sharing the worries of many in cyberspace, fears that Mr. Farmer is about to put a powerful jimmy into the hands of hackers everywhere.  So, on Monday, Silicon Graphics dismissed him. **********The sacking of Mr. Farmer, who helped develop Satan on his own time, adds fuel to a controversy that has swirled around him in recent weeks as he has ignored the threat of lawsuits and various other forms of pressure to keep Satan on a short leash. **********In the Internet community, Mr. Farmer's case is seen as symbolizing the conflict between a time-honored ideal -- the free flow of information in cyberspace -- and the harsh new reality that corporations and government agencies must protect their computer systems against intruders and vandals armed with increasingly sophisticated break-in software. **********"This is the classic double-edged sword," said Peter Neumann, a computer scientist at SRI International, a research and consulting organization in Menlo Park, Calif. **********"You have to get the information about how bad things are to people in order to fix the problems," Mr. Neumann said. "On the other hand, you run the risk of this information falling into the hands of sinister elements. So you lose either way because the systems aren't secure." **********Mr. Farmer has his defenders, including some managers at Sun Microsystems Inc., the computer company where he worked as network security manager before taking a comparable job at Silicon Graphics in December. **********Some executives at Sun Microsystems still think highly enough of Mr. Farmer that they would welcome him back. But Sun's lawyers see Mr. Farmer as a walking liability suit and are urging management to steer clear for the time being. They fear reprisals from government agencies, universities or corporations that may end up having their networks burglarized by Satan-wielding break-in artists. **********"This lawyer's liability consciousness is exactly what the problem is," said John Gage, the director of the science office at Sun Microsystems. "The spirit of Dan Farmer's software is what we need to make complex computer systems secure." **********Silicon Graphics, which has offered Mr. Farmer a severance package, said it had tried to be even-handed with him. **********"We've been discussing this issue with Dan and we've agreed mutually that parting company at this time is appropriate," said William Kelly, the vice president of business development at Silicon Graphics. "It's fair to say that we at SGI did not agree with the distribution plan he has for that product." **********Mr. Farmer said he understood, but disagreed with, Silicon Graphics. **********"They're a corporation and they have to do what they have to do," he said. **********But Mr. Farmer says he, too, must do what he has to do. "In a way, it's a freedom of speech issue," he said. "I want to teach people and have them learn about computer security." **********Mr. Farmer said he had been developing Satan with a Dutch friend and colleague, Wietse Venema, and had intended all along to distribute it far, wide and free. It is scheduled to be released on April 5, Mr. Farmer's birthday. **********The issue of whether little-known computer security flaws should be widely publicized has long been discussed among the computer experts who care for and maintain the computer hardware and software that make up the Internet. **********One camp argues that the community of systems administrators who maintain computers is inherently lazy and will not make needed security changes unless forced to do so. **********But other, more conservative, computer security workers are aghast at the prospect of an automated software tool like Satan being made available to anyone who wants to look for holes in computer network defenses. Freely distributing Satan, they contend, is like handing a loaded gun to every punk computer vandal in the world. **********Whether he rejoins Sun Microsystems or is hired by another computer shop, Mr. Farmer could find the Satan controversy to be a career asset in the world of computer security. **********"I've had people at a number of companies say they would love to hire me," he said. "But they said they weren't interested until April 6."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/03/busin.main_headline: OUTLOOK 1995: Global Economic Prospects Are Brighter for Most; Mexico Heads Back To the Drawing Board
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/03/busin.print_headline: OUTLOOK 1995: Global Economic Prospects Are Brighter for Most; Mexico Heads Back To the Drawing Board
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/03/busin.body_text: **********Economic prospects around the world look better this year than last. The decision by several large countries to sell off Government-controlled industries is one big engine of growth. Yet deficits, inflation and joblessness keep hampering the pace of recovery in many countries. **********For many nations, 1994 was a turnaround year as they began pulling out of recession. Some of the hottest economies, and targets of foreign investment, emerged in once-overlooked markets of Southeast Asia and Latin America. **********China, a favored destination for foreign investment, slowed down its unrelenting growth last year to 11 percent, a still-formidable rate that strained the capacity of aging industries and power grids. Japan, no longer the growth model for Asia, tried to climb out of its prolonged slump, with growth of barely 1 percent in 1994. **********Political developments rattled countries like Mexico, where the peso plummeted after being freed to float against the dollar. Eastern Europe continued to slough off old Communist habits. But in Russia, the best economic news may have been that growth dropped off only 8 percent in 1994, compared with double-digit declines in the previous two years. **********Trade liberalization became an international byword, notably with the North American Free Trade Association, now a year old. But frontier barriers were also lowered within Europe and Latin America, even as Washington's trade frictions with Japan and China festered. The European Union expanded to 15 countries. And the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade transformed itself into a sleeker new World Trade Organization. **********For Mexico, 1994 should have been a year to remember. Instead, almost everyone would just as soon forget it. Expectations were dashed from the very first when, instead of entering triumphantly into the North American Free Trade Agreement and the club of developed nations that membership had come to represent, Mexico looked down the barrel of a rebel's gun in the southern state of Chiapas. **********The disappointments continued throughout the year and hit bottom the week before Christmas with a clumsy forced devaluation of the peso that cost investors in the United States and Mexico billions of dollars overnight. **********The expected economic lift that was to have come from the trade pact never really materialized, and the Mexican stock exchange ended the year well below the 3,000 level that optimistic financial analysts had predicted. Mexican exports to the United States increased over the year, but so did imports from north of the border. Mergers and acquisitions of Mexican businesses by bigger companies in the United States and elsewhere meant that many Mexicans, from executives to line workers, lost their jobs. **********The new President, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, is a Yale-trained economist whose beliefs in the open market will be tested as he tries to rebuild Mexico's collapsed economic strategy. He closed the year by bringing another economist educated at Stanford, Guillermo Ortiz Martinez, as his new Finance Minister after the old one, Jaime Serra Puche, resigned following his erratic performance during the peso's slide. **********The official Government targets for 1995 are a tidy 4 percent growth and 4 percent inflation, with a balanced budget and increased social spending. But after the devaluation, the Government had to go back to the drawing board and start over. Even officials ended the year without any clear idea of what would happen in 1995. **********The nightmare of 1994 has not ended, especially after the devaluation. The Zapatista uprising in Chiapas is still unresolved, unemployment is still high and uncertainty remains a constant. The hopes for Mexico's getting an investment-grade rating any time soon have all but disappeared. The Standard & Poor's rating service, which some analysts had thought would promote Mexico to investment grade in 1994, ended the year by putting Mexican foreign debt on a credit watch. **********The other political shocks last year -- two assassinations, post-election unrest, kidnappings and infighting within the ruling Party of Revolutionary Institutions -- also took their toll as did interest rate increases in the United States that drained investor money from Mexico. **********But many investors stuck with Mexico anyway, realizing that the ability of the country to continue even after such shocks was a sign that its financial institutions functioned well, even if its political institutions did not. **********The first order of business in 1995 will be to regain their confidence. ANTHONY DePALMA

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/14/busin.body_text: **********American personal computer companies made strong gains in Japan in 1994 and now account for about a third of PC sales here, according to a market research report released today. **********But the NEC Corporation, which has long dominated the Japanese market, saw its lead decline, as the computers compatible with the worldwide I.B.M. standard made inroads against NEC's machines, which have a unique design. **********The International Data Corporation, a market research company in Framingham, Mass., said NEC's share dropped to 43.2 percent in 1994 from 49 percent in 1993, because the company's sales growth of 19.4 percent was slower than that of the market as a whole. **********Apple Computer Inc., the second-largest vendor, registered a gain in sales of 55.8 percent to reach a market share of 15.4 percent. The International Business Machines Corporation, in third place, saw sales more than double, and its market share rose to 10.1 percent from 6.8 percent a year earlier. Compaq and the Digital Equipment Corporation each saw their sales in Japan roughly triple from a year earlier and achieved market shares of 3.9 percent and 1.5 percent, respectively, International Data said. **********Five of the top 10 vendors in Japan are now American companies, according to International Data. Over all, the PC market in Japan expanded 35.5 percent, to 3.4 million units, it said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/30/world.main_headline: Police Link Algerian Militant Group to Paris Train Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/30/world.print_headline: Police Link Algerian Militant Group to Paris Train Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/30/world.body_text: **********The police said today that there were signs that a group linked to the violent conflict in Algeria was responsible for the bombing of a commuter train in Paris on Tuesday that killed 7 people and injured more than 80. **********Although they did not make a formal statement, police officials told reporters that they have a number of indications that the so-called Armed Islamic Group may be to blame. **********This group is the most militant of several armed opposition movements trying to overthrow the military-backed Algerian Government.  A publication that generally represents the group's views, El Ansar, said in an issue distributed in Sweden on Friday that the rush-hour explosion on the train at the St.-Michel station on the Left Bank was one of the recent actions of "Islamic fighters." It did not explicitly cite the Armed Islamic Group. **********The police said they are now certain that the explosives were placed in a thick metal gas canister of a kind commonly used by campers. Such gas canister bombs have been used previously by the Armed Islamic Group, officials said. The police said that technicians were still comparing bomb fragments with other materials recently confiscated from suspected collaborators of Algerian militants in France. **********In another lead, an auxiliary police officer who had been on the train shortly before the explosion said that he had seen two youths carrying a bag and that as he was getting off at the Chatelet station, the two youths pushed past him and also got off but without the bag. **********From the beginning of the investigation, officials have believed a foreign group was responsible. **********Human rights groups said they feared that the bombing would add to the rising antiforeigner sentiments in this country, newly evident in the surge of support for the far-right National Front in municipal elections last month. **********European diplomats here suggested that terrorist actions on French soil and the perceived need for stricter security might further postpone France's plans to join some other countries of the European Union in dropping border checks within the union. **********Since the blast, the police working on the case have arrested 195 people for a variety of suspected crimes as well as 57 foreigners whose papers were not in order. **********The Armed Islamic Group has claimed responsibility for killing foreigners, including French citizens, in Algeria. Last December, it hijacked an Air France plane in Algiers and forced the pilot to land in Marseilles. There French commandos stormed the plane, killing all four hijackers. The following day the guerrilla group vowed to take revenge. **********According to the police, French security officials were tipped off this spring that Algerian guerrillas were preparing to strike in France. The information prompted raids and the arrest of suspected sympathizers. **********The police said today that they were taking seriously a warning of impending actions against France that had appeared in the Algerian newspaper La Tribune. Earlier this month La Tribune reported that the Armed Islamic Group had threatened "bomb attacks in Paris to punish the Paris Government." **********Complicating the work of investigators here is the fact that the Armed Islamic Group has a number of factions. Investigators said it is not always clear which faction is speaking in the group's name. **********Bombs scares resulting from false threats continued to keep Paris and other French cities on edge today. Thousands of people were ordered to evacuate the Louvre and a department store in the center of Paris.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/13/busin.main_headline: International Briefs; Pirelli Reports A Profit for 1994
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/13/busin.print_headline: International Briefs; Pirelli Reports A Profit for 1994
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/13/busin.body_text: **********Pirelli S.p.A. of Italy said yesterday that it returned to profitability in 1994, for the first time since 1990, as both its tire and cable operations made money again. The company said it would not pay a dividend, because its parent company lost money. That is because the profits in 1994 from the tire and cable companies will not be passed on to the parent, which would make the payout, until this year. Pirelli said the results from the first few months of 1995 indicated that the profit would rise again this year. Consolidated net profit was 110 billion lire, or $65 million, in 1994, in contrast to a loss of 62 billion lire in 1993. Pirelli lost almost 229 billion lire from 1991 to 1993. (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/19/busin.main_headline: LAIDLAW TO BUY CARELINE AMBULANCE SERVICES
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/19/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; LAIDLAW TO BUY CARELINE AMBULANCE SERVICES
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/19/busin.body_text: **********Laidlaw Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Careline Inc., a provider of ambulance services, by exchanging 1.1 of its nonvoting shares for each Careline share. Based on yesterday's close of Laidlaw's B shares -- which fell 50 cents, to $9.625, on the New York Stock Exchange -- the transaction was valued at about $350 million, which includes the assumption of $175 million in debt. Shares of Careline, which is based in Santa Ana, Calif., jumped $1.625, to $9.875, on Nasdaq yesterday. Careline -- which had revenue of $148.2 million in 1994 and said yesterday that it would report second-quarter revenue of about $56 million -- is one of the country's largest ambulance-service companies. Laidlaw, a provider of transportation and waste-management services, said it would merge Careline with its Med Trans unit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/20/busin.main_headline: From Mac Users, Fury at Microsoft
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/20/busin.print_headline: From Mac Users, Fury at Microsoft
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/20/busin.body_text: **********Can great big software companies write truly great computer programs? **********The question is being raised by users of Apple Macintosh computers, who are widely reviling and rejecting the newest version by the Microsoft Corporation of its word processing program, Word, for use on the Macintosh. Microsoft, the world's largest software publisher, dominates the market for Macintosh software, including a 65 percent share of Macintosh word processing programs. **********But the Word controversy is threatening Microsoft's control of that niche, as a growing number of Macintosh customers have begun switching to word processing programs from several smaller companies. Macintosh users complain that the new version of the Microsoft program, Word 6.0, is too slow and unwieldy and has too many bugs. **********They also contend that the program, released last fall, has not been adequately fine-tuned to the requirements of the Apple Macintosh, and that it is merely a rough translation of the version of Word 6.0 that Microsoft sells for the world's far larger number of I.B.M.-compatible personal computers. **********Like many other software companies, Microsoft has at times rankled users by introducing a version of a product that failed to meet their expectations or contained a seemingly unreasonable number of bugs. Microsoft officials say that there is nothing unusual or alarming about the Word 6.0 uproar, and that the company is rushing to address the concerns. **********But many Macintosh users see the problem as an early sign that Microsoft may be growing so big and diverse that it cannot focus on important details of a specific product -- or so powerful that it doesn't care to sweat the small stuff. **********"Pass the Cranberry Sauce, This One's a Turkey," read the headline of a review of Word 6.0 in the current issue of the quarterly journal of the Berkeley Macintosh Users Group. **********"Word is Microsoft's flagship product," said Bob Thyken, executive director of the Berkeley group, one of the country's largest organizations of corporate and individual Macintosh users. "It makes people think twice about the company." **********Another review, in Macweek magazine, said that the task of counting words took almost 11 times longer with Word 6.0, compared with the previous version of the software. **********Seeking to quell the complaints, Microsoft has announced a free maintenance version of the program, due by the end of March, to fix bugs. And the company, based in Redmond, Wash., has scheduled a meeting to discuss the problem with analysts and reporters on Jan. 30 in Cupertino, Calif., the city where Apple is based. **********"We think we understand the issues and are addressing them," said Pete Higgins, Microsoft's senior vice president of desktop applications. **********To be sure, Microsoft still rules the software world and remains enormously profitable. Two days ago, the company reported an earnings increase of 29 percent for its second quarter -- to $373 million -- on the strength of better-than-expected sales of its products, which cover a range of business, home-office and consumer software. Such profits can help finance the company's ambitious expansion plans into fields like home banking and on-line services, and providing access to the Internet global computer network. **********But some analysts see signs that Microsoft may be spreading itself too thin. They see symptoms of a company where the nimbleness necessary for top-flight computer programming is in danger of being overwhelmed by a bureaucratic software development organization. **********The uproar over the new Macintosh Word program, which was six months late when it reached the market, comes as the company is encountering continued delays in introducing the next version of its Windows operating system. And a new program called Bob, scheduled to be released in March and intended to be consumer friendly, has been criticized as condescending and inefficient by some industry reviewers. **********In recent years, Microsoft has assumed the industry role formerly occupied by the International Business Machines Corporation, influencing the direction of the computer business by defining standards and controlling markets for software. But in the late 1980's, I.B.M. lost contact with new technology trends and with customers, and saw its influence wane. Now a favorite topic of industry conversation is whether Microsoft will be able to avoid that fate. **********"They feel they're in control of the marketplace," said Stewart Alsop, editor of Infoworld, a weekly computer industry newspaper, "But things may be getting out of control." **********Apple Computer Inc. produces the operating system software that controls the basic workings of a Macintosh computer. But Microsoft is the leading provider of application software for the Macintosh, with programs like Word and the Excel spreadsheet. **********Over all, Macintosh programs are a $400 million business for Microsoft, but that constitutes less than 8 percent of the company's revenue. And many Macintosh users contend that Word 6.0 is evidence that Microsoft is paying too little attention to their needs. **********"It's simple," said Steven Levy, a columnist for Macworld magazine. "Microsoft's message to Macintosh users is, 'Drop dead!' " **********Reviewers in Macworld and other trade magazines have found that the program takes about three times as long to start up, and runs at about half the speed, as Microsoft's previous version, Word 5.1. **********The Macworld review, for example, reported that on a Macintosh Centris 610 model, the Word program took more than 7 minutes to start. And counting the words in a long document took 5 minutes and 48 seconds, compared with 33 seconds in Word 5.1, according to a review in Macweek. **********The performance decline, computer experts said, is a result of Microsoft's using common underlying software for both the Intel-compatible PC and Macintosh versions of Word 6.0, but refining it first and more successfully for the PC program. The PC version, released in the second half of 1993, has generated no performance-related complaints. **********Some critics say Word 6.0 also suffers from "feature creep" -- the tendency to add dozens of new features to each new version of a program, creating a slower program that requires many times as much memory and disk storage space. Fully installed, Word 6.0 requires 25 million bytes of disk space. Word 5.1 needed only 6 million. **********Such weaknesses have opened a large hole for smaller competitors like Novell Inc.'s Wordperfect unit and tiny Nisus Software Inc.'s Nisus Writer. Both have recently enjoyed significant increases in word processing sales for the Macintosh market. **********Because Microsoft's Windows operating system competes directly with Apple's Macintosh software, some Macintosh users are always looking for signs of sabotage by Microsoft. But even some of the company's harshest critics see maladroitness, rather than malevolence, in Microsoft's handling of Word 6.0. **********"The conspiracy theories are saying that this is Microsoft's attempt to undermine the Mac," said Jim Heid, an author who wrote the negative review in Macworld. "But I'm in the camp that believes that even big companies can blow it." **********Microsoft executives said the disappointing performance of Word 6.0 for the Macintosh was a one-time foul-up. Using common underlying software code for its Macintosh and Windows-based applications is a new approach for Microsoft, the executives said, and the Word 6.0 problems are a result of a rough transition that is now behind the company. **********That explanation has done little to mollify some of Microsoft's largest corporate Macintosh users, who have told the software publisher that they are not willing to install Word 6.0 because they find it unusable. **********One California-based company whose work force uses more than 2,000 Macintoshes agreed in late 1993 to buy rights to use Word 6.0, based on demonstrations of a prototype version. The attractive new features included an electronic-bookmark feature that lets users quickly navigate through a long document. **********But 15 months later, the company has still not begun to use the program. "As soon as we got it, we installed it on our server, but two weeks later the president of our company ordered us to take it off," said one of the company's computer managers, who spoke on the condition that neither he nor his company be identified. The software was simply too slow, he said. **********Customer dissatisfaction is evident at the retail level, as well. Computerware, the largest Macintosh dealer in Northern California, said it sold an equal number of copies of Wordperfect 3.0 and Macintosh Word 6.0 in December. With the earlier version, Word 5.1, Microsoft typically had a substantially larger share of the chain's sales. **********"The problem you have when you get really big and really dominant is you lose touch a little bit," said Ken Krich, president of Computerware. "It's a challenge to keep listening to your customers."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/02/world.main_headline: A Deficit Reins In Sweden's Welfare State
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/02/world.print_headline: A Deficit Reins In Sweden's Welfare State
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/02/world.body_text: **********In the last six decades, Sweden has built one of the world's most generous and successful social welfare systems, providing its citizens with a lifelong array of benefits that help them maintain a high standard of living through good times and bad. **********But now, unable to afford the bill, the country is being forced to pare social welfare spending. Although the cuts have so far hardly been Draconian, there is widespread anxiety that the system, long seen as the model for combining socialist welfare policies with vibrant capitalism, could collapse under its own economic weight. **********The strains are already beginning to show. Despite Sweden's commitment to universally available child care, local authorities in some areas have had to reduce spending on subsidized day-care centers. **********In the last few years, reductions have been made in unemployment insurance and in payments to workers injured on the job. Among a number of proposals likely to be enacted in coming months is a $17 reduction in the $100 monthly payment provided to every family for each child regardless of need. **********Nearly every industrialized country is seeking to overhaul its social welfare system. As in the United States, the issue is moving to the political forefront across Western Europe, where the high costs of maintaining generous benefits are increasingly seen as a drag on the economy. **********But no major Western nation faces financial pressure as intense as that of Sweden, where citizens remain downright coddled by American standards. Still, it is particularly unsettling to many Swedes that the most recently proposed cuts, the deepest so far, are being carried out under the party that built the system, the leftist Social Democrats. **********The party, the dominant political force since the 1930's, regained power in elections last fall after three years in opposition, in part because voters felt that the conservative Government had gone too far in dismantling Sweden's liberal system. **********"We are just nine million people, and we should be able to take care of each other," said Annelie Drevstam, an assistant at a Stockholm photo agency. "It's a new problem for Sweden that we have people living on the streets, and if I have to pay more in taxes or get less child allowance to help, I'm willing to do it." **********Yet Sweden already imposes one of the world's heaviest tax burdens to pay for its social largess, with total Government receipts in 1993 amounting to 58.3 percent of gross domestic product, compared with 31.1 percent in the United States. **********As a result some Swedes, including Ms. Drevstam's husband, Mika Laitanen, say their commitment to social welfare has its limits. **********Since the family is hoping to buy a house, Mr. Laitanen would like to see the Government do more to bring interest rates down, maybe even at the expense of cutting welfare, and he supports the tax-cutting philosophy of the conservatives. **********"I would rather decide what I do with my money," said Mr. Laitanen, an electrician for the Swedish military. **********The Swedish system provides, among other benefits, a guarantee of close to a full income indefinitely in cases of sickness and unemployment. It covers medical care and subsidizes educational costs, sets minimum retirement income and provides paid leaves of absence for new parents. **********But faced with one of the developed world's worst budget deficits and plagued by a stubbornly high unemployment rate of 13 percent, Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson has had little choice but to push for spending cuts. **********In January the Government proposed a four-year, $15 billion program of spending cuts and tax increases, by far the biggest austerity package in the country's history, in an effort to stop the growth in the deficit and to bring down punishingly high interest rates. **********The deficit surged from 7.4 percent of gross domestic product in 1992 to 13.5 percent in 1993. Although it dropped slightly by some measures last year, it remains more than three times as high as the average ratio of 3.8 percent for the world's largest industrial countries. **********Mr. Carlsson said he was confident of getting his package through Parliament, despite complaints from the left that the cuts were too deep and from the right that he was relying too much on tax increases. By 1997, he said, the deficit should be down to around 7 percent of gross domestic product. **********Mr. Carlsson said his plan would bring financial stability to Sweden without forcing any wholesale changes in a system that extends far beyond providing a safety net for people who need help to recover from misfortune. **********Under Mr. Carlsson's plan, for example, Swedish women would continue to be encouraged to take a year off from work after the birth of a child, but they would be paid 75 percent of their former salary for the year, down from 80 percent. **********"We're trimming the system, not dismantling it," Mr. Carlsson said in an interview. "It's very clear to me as a Social Democrat that if we want a social welfare system, we have to have the income to pay for it. The condition for this is to strengthen the Swedish economy, and that's exactly what we are doing now." **********The slimming of the welfare state began under the previous, conservative Government, led by Carl Bildt. In three stormy years as Prime Minister, he sought to impose a Thatcherite revolution on Sweden by cutting taxes, introducing free-market economic policies and asserting the need for more individual responsibility. **********But Mr. Bildt's tenure coincided with the worst recession in Sweden since the 1930's. The jobless rate went from almost nothing in 1991 to 13 percent last year. **********With the economy foundering and unemployment benefits and other welfare payments surging, Mr. Bildt's tax cuts led to a rising deficit. The problem was compounded when he was unable to find consensus in his coalition Government for large-scale spending cuts. **********Mr. Carlsson's budget strategy has set off protests from some of those affected, including several thousand students who marched in Stockholm in January to protest cuts in their grants. **********Many business executives and economists contend that the Government has been too timid in its cuts, though. **********"In our view the proposed measures will not be sufficient, either in scope or direction, to achieve the necessary correction in state finances or the growth for which the Government is striving," the chairmen of eight of Sweden's largest companies -- including Volvo, Electrolux and the technology giant Ericsson -- said in a letter to Mr. Carlsson. **********Some analysts say that rather than snip around the edges of the benefit programs, the Government needs to engage in a wholesale reassessment of Sweden's priorities. **********"Inevitably, the debt burden will force Swedes to make large-scale modifications to their public benefit programs and accept slower growth in their standard of living," said a report from Moody's Investors Service, which analyzes the financial condition of countries and companies. **********The need for a shift in public policy, Moody's said, "has not yet been accepted widely by the full population." **********Sitting around their kitchen table in Skarpnack, a Stockholm suburb, Barry Andersson and his wife, Majvor Hansson, said the change that would be most widely felt -- the $17-a-month reduction in child benefit payments -- would not dent their comfortable middle-class life, even though they had two children. **********"It's only because we've had such good times in Sweden that these small problems sometimes seem very big," Ms. Hansson said. **********Mr. Andersson, a chimney sweep, and Ms. Hansson, who works in a psychiatric clinic, said they were confident that the Social Democrats would try to keep the social welfare system intact. They expressed a vague unease that Sweden might be lurching toward much bigger changes, but they made clear that they still expected a lot from their Government. **********Mr. Andersson said he wished the Government would do more to reduce unemployment. Ms. Hansson said she wished the Government would come up with a program so that someone who was unemployed could take her job and she could take a year or two off -- with pay.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/27/busin.main_headline: SEMI-TECH TO BUY STAKE IN JAPANESE ELECTRONICS MAKER
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/27/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; SEMI-TECH TO BUY STAKE IN JAPANESE ELECTRONICS MAKER
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/27/busin.body_text: **********The Semi-Tech (Global) Company said yesterday that it would buy 55 percent of a financially troubled Japanese electronics manufacturer in an effort to expand its worldwide business. Semi-Tech, which is based in Bermuda but whose shares trade in Hong Kong, will pay about $172 million for the stake in the Akai Electric Company of Tokyo. Semi-Tech is a unit of International Semi-Tech Microelectronics Inc., which also controls the Singer Company, the world's largest sewing machine company. The purchase is intended to take advantage of Singer's worldwide distribution network and Semi-Tech's existing stakes in other electronics companies. Akai makes videocassette recorders and other consumer electronics.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/17/busin.main_headline: Big Board Account Put Up for Review
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/17/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Big Board Account Put Up for Review
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/17/busin.body_text: **********The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had placed in review its account, which has been at Wells Rich Greene BDDP in New York for the last five years. Though the billings were not disclosed, trade publications estimated them at $8 million to $10 million. **********"We've experienced unparalleled growth in the last five years, and our goals and objectives have broadened," said Andrew Yemma, a spokesman for the exchange, in confirming reports of the review this week in Adweek and The Delaney Report, a newsletter. "We wanted to explore other advertising partners." Mr. Yemma declined to identify the agencies involved or to discuss whether Wells Rich, a unit of BDDP Worldwide, would participate. A decision is expected in a few months, he said.
