https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/07/busin.body_text: **********Capital Cities/ABC Inc. may have had the most publicized stock increase last week. But the biggest percentage gainer was the stock of another media player, the Learning Company, a producer of educational software, which agreed to a $440 million acquisition by the Broderbund Software Company. **********Meanwhile, CBS Inc., which the Westinghouse Electric Corporation agreed to buy for $5.4 billion, had three prime-time programs -- all reruns -- among the top 10 for the first time all summer. Some weeks, CBS hasn't even made the list.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/04/world.main_headline: Almost Anything Goes in Birth Science in Italy
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/04/world.print_headline: Almost Anything Goes in Birth Science in Italy
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/04/world.body_text: **********First there were the "granny moms," a series of women who had babies in their 50's, even in their 60's. Then there was the case in January of baby Elisabetta, who was supposedly conceived from an egg taken from a woman who had died two years before and carried to term by her father's sister. **********With these and other tales of artificial fertilization making headlines, the next announcement was not as amazing as it might seem. **********"A pregnant man? It could be," a newspaper said, citing a professor who had discussed the theoretical possibility of male pregnancy at a seminar here in Rome. **********It took a day or so for the story to be knocked down by other experts, who pointed out that science -- like the male body -- does have its limits. But the larger point struck home: Italy is virtually the only country in Europe that still has no law, no controls, not even any minimum regulations governing more than 100 private clinics that perform various fertilization procedures. **********This legal vacuum has led to charges that Italy has become the Wild West in a rapidly shifting field of biomedicine that carries profound ethical as well as social and health implications. Politicians say Italy has become a mecca for foreign women who come here for "procreative tourism." **********"We have no law, which means everything imaginable is legal," said Francesco D'Agostino, president of the Committee on Bioethics, whose proposal for a set of regulations on fertility centers is still sitting in Parliament. "There is widespread acceptance of fertility assistance. The case of Elisabetta, for instance, was viewed by the public as a great curiosity, not as a scandal. Public opinion did not say, 'No.' Most people said, 'Why not?' " **********It is no small paradox that all this goes on next door to the Vatican, which has taken a harsh stand against any fertilization procedure that substitutes for the sexual act. Since it regards embryos as human beings, the Roman Catholic Church is particularly opposed to 'in vitro' fertilization, in which embryos are often destroyed -- a point reiterated in Pope John Paul II's encyclical last week. **********"The Catholic Church is against any progress in this field," said Dr. Emanuele Lauricella, president of Cecos, a French organization operating 20 private fertility centers in Italy. "Since the church holds to the principle that the sexual act must serve procreation, they say 'no' to birth control, 'no' to artificial procreation." **********In the years when Italy's old Christian Democratic Party was in power, no laws on artificial fertilization were passed. In 1985, the Health Minister -- a Christian Democrat -- issued an administrative circular to all public hospitals advising them not to undertake fertilization procedures unless they involved the sperm and the egg of married couples. **********The result has been a sprouting of private clinics. In late 1992, the Italian Register for Medically Assisted Procreation listed 57 clinics; today, the number is 120. **********But the registry has no control over the clinics, none of which are licensed, and registration is voluntary. **********By Dr. Lauricella's estimate, 2,000 artificial fertilization procedures are done each year in Italy, 500 of them at Cecos clinics. Without a monitoring system, it is difficult to know the true number, but the fact is that in this predominantly Catholic country, the church's strictures are clearly ignored by many couples. **********Fertility doctors say many of their patients are devout Catholics who in a number of cases are referred by priests looking to help childless couples. **********But the legal loophole is upsetting to many doctors, who want to see some controls. Cecos, for instance, refuses women over 45 and single mothers, with some rare exceptions. **********Dr. Severino Antinori, a pioneer in fertility treatments for post-menopausal women, rejects the idea of such categorical refusals. "The limit is not age; the limit is physical," he said. "What I want to see is a law that controls the centers, and not the wishes of the people." **********Of the 300 post-menopausal women who have come to him for treatment to get pregnant, he said, he agreed to treat only 70, all successfully. **********Most countries in Europe long ago adopted licensing procedures, which control the quality of centers, monitor donated sperm and eggs and limit the time embryos can be kept frozen. In the United States, a Federal law has been passed to require fertility clinics to register, report success rates and certify laboratories. **********The push for legislation in Italy has gathered steam in recent months. The Italian Medical Association last weekend leapt into the fray with its own rules, barring doctors from using artificial fertilization treatment on women over 50, single women and lesbians. **********The association's rules are being contested by some doctors, including Dr. Antinori, who has called them "dangerous and illegitimate." **********But Mr. D'Agostino says the quandary of Italian politicians is that they are not quite sure which way to go. "Politicians are not sure what the public opinion is, and they have a fear of losing consensus," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/14/busin.main_headline: Companies pursue electronic ways to insure that sports advertisers get the best sites in the house.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/14/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Companies pursue electronic ways to insure that sports advertisers get the best sites in the house.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/14/busin.body_text: **********TELEVISION sports viewers who have just gotten used to rotating billboards behind home plate and at basketball scorers' tables might soon have to make another visual adjustment: ads inserted electronically during the action that appear to be part of the actual background. **********Before the year is out, a television network that has not been identified plans to offer its advertisers the option of having their ads appear in places where no ads have gone before or to have them superimposed over existing ones. The network will be able to do that through a digitalized system that maps landmarks, or optimal spots for ads, on the playing field. The system is being developed by Princeton Electronic Billboard, which is based in Princeton, N.J. **********With electronic signs, the same ad space could be sold again and again. For example, the prime space on the fence behind the tennis star Pete Sampras that bears the name of an American company could be bought by any number of companies in other countries whose television stations were simultaneously running the telecast and had the capability to accept electronic advertising. **********In test footage of a tennis match currently shown by Scidel Technologies Ltd., an Israeli company that is Princeton Electronic's main competitor, stationary ads depicting corporate logos are inserted during action in the service courts, doubles alleys and backcourts. **********"This has all sorts of possibilities," said Mark Bingham, vice president of marketing for the New York Mets baseball team. "Signs can be changed thousands of times. You can probably put ads on someone's helmet." **********But Steve Schanwald, vice president of marketing for the Chicago Bulls basketball team, said he was unimpressed with electronic signs. "There's a prohibition against it in the N.B.A.," he said. "It holds no interest for me. Even if it were allowed, I wouldn't want my ads covered over, and I wouldn't want to do it to anybody else's signs." **********As long as sports events have been televised, there have been signs on fences and in arenas. In recent years, teams have used rotating billboards that show a new message every few minutes and can be sold to as many as 30 advertisers per game. The billboards are there for TV viewers -- the backdrop to 7-foot-tall men running back and forth on a basketball court or behind the baseball batter. **********Dorna U.S.A., the American subsidiary of Dorna Promocion del Deporte S.A., a sports marketing company based in Madrid, dominates the market for rotating signs. Its Adtime systems are in 15 major league baseball stadiums, 16 National Basketball Association arenas and 5 National Hockey League arenas. Full-season contracts can cost $200,000. **********But companies like Princeton Electronic and Scidel are counting on electronic advertising to generate far more revenue than its mechanical counterpart. In recent months Princeton Electronic has tested its system during baseball games of the major-league Florida Marlins and the minor-league Trenton Thunder, and at an international broadcast of the Parmalat Cup, a soccer tournament, at Giant Stadium in New Jersey. **********With the Princeton Electronic system, ads can be inserted into live action -- that is, foul balls pass over the ads, as do swinging bats. Princeton Electronic focuses on up to 16 landmarks. "You need that many, because some get covered up during a game," said Sam McCleery, the company's vice president of marketing. "You always need four or five visible." A digital map of the landmarks is saved, and during a game ads are inserted into them. **********Scidel, whose main investor is Scitex, the Israeli maker of imaging equipment that is a subsidiary of the IDB Holding Corporation, has been showing tapes of its system to networks and advertisers but acknowledges that it is behind Princeton Electronic in development. Right now, Scidel cannot insert ads into live action. **********Princeton Electronic and Scidel are carving different niches in the emerging market. Princeton Electronic wants to be in the existing billboard segment. Scidel wants to insert signs and logos onto the floors of stadiums and arenas, where corporate logos often appear during college bowl games. **********"I know we won't be doing the Super Bowl," said Kobi Bendel, executive director of Scidel, "but there are many other small events in thousands of cities that need this extra money." **********For the moment, these are among the commercial possibilities of electronic advertising: ***********If, for example, the Yankees were playing the Tigers in Detroit in a game shown in New York on the MSG Network, signs at home plate that now show Motown-based advertisers could be electronically covered with those of local advertisers. ***********During a nationally broadcast game, General Motors might want to regionalize its messages by putting a Pontiac sign in the Northeast market, a Cadillac sign in the West and an Oldsmobile sign in the Midwest. ***********On a soccer telecast beamed to 50 countries, a global company might want to pitch itself in dozens of languages or to plug the divisions it owned in those nations. **********Because electronic signs have yet to be introduced, it is unclear whether the sports leagues will allow them or whether advertisers will go for them. **********Mr. Bingham of the Mets envisions problems ahead. "While Toyota and Sharp love being seen around the country," he said, "I can see them saying, 'You've taken away half our value' if they were covered up electronically." **********He said electronic billboard signs could work only if agreements were reached between teams that would allow them without a legal war. But he is not ready for such signs on the actual playing fields. "I wouldn't want to see a running back, on third down and one, to have to cross a Modell sign for a touchdown," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/21/world.main_headline: Fortunes of Bosnian War Ease U.S. Military Tasks
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/21/world.print_headline: Fortunes of Bosnian War Ease U.S. Military Tasks
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/21/world.body_text: **********Despite Western setbacks and miscalculations, the United States suddenly finds its risks in Bosnia greatly reduced. **********The dangers of the Balkans remain high, as the deaths on Saturday of three American diplomats on a rain-soaked mountain road near Sarajevo remind. But Pentagon planners say that the extrication of 24,000 United Nations forces from Bosnia would require far fewer troops for only a portion of the time previously estimated. Similarly, the size and risks of any peacekeeping operation could be smaller than had been thought. **********This all could have significant political consequences for 1996, since Administration officials say they will probably send American troops to Bosnia in the next year either to help withdraw the United Nations troops or to enforce a peace plan. **********A smaller operation with more manageable risks would probably pose less of a political liability for President Clinton during his re-election campaign, when his handling of the lingering crisis in Bosnia is likely to be an issue. **********Events of the last month, including the West's concession of two Muslim enclaves in Bosnia to Bosnian Serb rebels and a successful Croatian offensive that defied Pentagon predictions, have unexpectedly opened new diplomatic opportunities and foreclosed some difficult military missions. **********"While losing the enclaves has been unfortunate for Bosnia, it's been great for us," said a senior Administration official. **********At the same time, any lessening of the military risks could undermine one of the Administration's central arguments for not flouting the arms embargo against the Bosnian Government. Defense Secretary William J. Perry has said that breaking the embargo would set off the withdrawal of United Nations peacekeepers, commit thousands of American troops to help them leave, and be "risky, costly and shameful." **********With a resurgent Bosnian Army joined by its Croatian ally now standing up to rebel Serbian forces and pushing them back in some areas, and fewer United States troops needed to withdraw less vulnerable peacekeepers, Mr. Perry's warning may not be so dire. **********Administration officials say there are now three likely scenarios the Balkans crisis could follow: ***********The latest American peace plan fails, but the United Nations peacekeeping force, dominated by Britain and France, stays for another winter. ***********The negotiations fail and the United Nations pulls out. Without a firm peace plan, there is concern in Washington that Britain and France will decide by mid-September to leave. ***********The warring parties accept an American-brokered peace plan, and a NATO force roughly the size of the withdrawal force moves in to police the plan. **********President Clinton has promised to send as many as 25,000 American soldiers for a 70,000-member NATO force to extricate the United Nations peacekeepers spread out over Bosnia. The Pentagon said the operation could take 22 months to complete. As many as 10,000 of those United States troops could actually go into Bosnia itself, with the rest handling logistics in Croatia or remaining in reserve. **********But events of the last month have radically altered the Balkans map, and with it the risks and responsibilities for United States forces. **********Two precarious Muslim enclaves in eastern Bosnian -- Srebrenica and Zepa -- have been overrun by Bosnian Serb troops. The Croatian Army's offensive earlier this month relieved the siege of another enclave, Bihac. **********On Friday, the United Nations said it would withdraw its last remaining ground troops in Gorazde, a fourth enclave, and rely on air power alone to protect the civilians there. **********"It's fair to say that the number of troops that might need to be evacuated from potentially hostile areas has been reduced by at least two-thirds," said a senior Administration official. **********The current evacuation plan assumes the worst: cramped sea ports, snow, fighting and poor roads. But with the changes on the ground, a spirited debate has broken out in the Administration over how large a withdrawal force would be needed. **********Defense Secretary William J. Perry and Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, are arguing to keep as robust a force as possible to deal with all possible contingencies with the lowest casualties. But other State Department and White House officials are trying to pare the force down to make it more palatable to a Congress wary of sending ground troops to Bosnia, even to help extract America's allies. **********But most peacekeepers could probably now drive themselves out of well-defended central Bosnia through Croatia. At worst, peacekeepers could be helicoptered out after they disabled their equipment. Military officials say this could require a much smaller NATO force, and perhaps only a few thousand American troops, and take weeks, not months. **********Adm. Leighton W. Smith, the commander of NATO forces in southern Europe, has told his senior planners to submit revised draft withdrawal plan by this week. Admiral Smith is also expected to meet this week with senior American commanders from the various branches of the armed services who would take part in a withdrawal or peacekeeping plan. **********Since the negotiations over the American-brokered peace plan are still in a relatively early stage, it is hard to tell how many and what kind of military forces would be required. To be sure, any peacekeeping or peace enforcement mission would be risky, with possible American casualties. **********"The hooker on this is we don't know what we're going to face," said a senior Pentagon official. "Just three weeks ago, people talked about the Serbs winning it all. Now they're on the run. That makes planning extremely difficult."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/18/busin.main_headline: International Briefs; France Plans to Sell More State-Held Assets
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/18/busin.print_headline: International Briefs; France Plans to Sell More State-Held Assets
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/18/busin.body_text: **********The French Government will sell the aluminum maker Pechiney S.A., the shipping company Compagnie Generale Maritime and a further stake in the car maker Renault in the next wave of state asset sales, the Finance Ministry said yesterday. Renault and Pechiney will be sold in public offerings, and Generale Maritime will be sold in a private transaction. No sale dates were set. **********The sale of France's remaining 51 percent stake in Renault would bring in about 20 billion francs ($4.1 billion) at its current share price. The 56 percent stake in Pechiney could fetch 7 billion to 8 billion francs. (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/16/busin.main_headline: Treasury Issues Advance Despite Loss Earlier in Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/16/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasury Issues Advance Despite Loss Earlier in Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/16/busin.body_text: **********The bond market yesterday showed the resiliency that it has displayed many times this year, recovering from early losses to end with modest gains. **********Bond prices fell early in the day following comments by Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, which indicated that the Fed was unlikely to cut interest rates anytime soon without evidence that the economy is slowing. **********But as the price of the 30-year bond fell and its yield approached 7 percent, buyers began to emerge, traders said. **********The rebound was helped by a report on industrial production and capacity utilization, which was weaker than expected. **********The price of the 30-year bond settled up 24/32 of a percentage point, to 99 26/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, slipped to 6.89 percent, from 6.95 percent on Monday. **********The Federal Reserve said yesterday that industrial production rose one-tenth of 1 percent in July after a revised one-tenth of 1 percent drop in June. Industrial production was unchanged in May. Capacity utilization fell to 83.4 percent, the sixth consecutive monthly decline. While capacity use was a little higher than the 83.1 percent forecast, that was largely a result of increased use of electric power during the heat wave in July. **********"Indeed, were it not for the heat wave, industrial production would have dropped in July," noted Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities. Manufacturing output dipped two-tenths of 1 percent, with motor vehicles the weakest sector and computer and office equipment the strongest. **********Bond prices opened lower after Mr. Blinder, in an interview Monday night, indicated that economy would have to weaken from current levels before the Fed would again push interest rates lower. **********Eric Hamilton, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said Mr. Blinder's comments "spooked traders who were still factoring in the chance for another easing at next week's Federal Open Market Committee meeting." The committee sets Fed interest rate policy. **********But bonds soon recovered, rising in the late afternoon after the release of a Johnson Redbook report showing lackluster store sales in the first two weeks of August. **********Bonds were also bolstered by a surge in the dollar. The currency rose to its highest level in six months after the Fed and the Japanese and German central banks bought dollars on foreign exchange markets. **********Mr. Hamilton of Technical Data said the stronger dollar prompted those who were selling short, or betting that bond prices would fall, to cover their positions, pushing the market higher. **********"Looking ahead, the stronger dollar intervention seen today should continue to have a positive impact on the market," he said. "Those central banks now holding a fresh supply of dollars typically look to put these funds back into the Treasury market." This, he added, should be enough to keep the downside of the market protected over the next couple of trading sessions. **********Mr. Fine of Chase Securities, however, noted that the market could soon have other concerns. "Lurking in the minds of bonds market participants is tomorrow's announcement of two-year and five-year Treasury notes," he said. "Both issues are expected to be increased in size, and will temporarily add to the market's supply distribution woes." . **********In the municipal bond market, where states, cities and their agencies sold $1.089 billion in new securities through negotiated and competitive sale, Los Angeles priced one of the larger issues. **********The city sold $229 million in general obligation bonds through competitive bidding won by BA Securities. The serial bonds are insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company and are rated triple-A by the rating agencies. **********Underwriters said the serial bonds were priced to yield from 3.75 percent for a bond due in 1996 to 6.30 percent for those due in 2015.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/18/busin.body_text: **********Motorola Inc. stunned Wall Street today by disclosing that sales of its cellular phones would be well below analysts' projections in the first quarter. **********The company's shares plunged $6.375, or 9.9 percent, to close at $57.875 in extremely heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Motorola said that it recently discovered that it had shipped to its domestic distributors "several weeks" more inventory than they had been able to sell during the fourth quarter of 1994. **********The semiconductor and telecommunications giant, which is based just west of here in Schaumburg, Ill., said that it would curb production of the phones for the rest of the current quarter and possibly into the next quarter to bring the inventories back down to normal levels. **********"This is strictly a domestic problem," said Edward Gams, Motorola's vice president in charge of investor relations, adding that the company continued to experience strong worldwide growth in the cellular business. He said Motorola did not expect the inventory bulge to put more pressure on cellular phone prices, which have been falling. **********The company said the oversupply was a contrast to the situation in the final quarters of 1992 and 1993 when Motorola and other manufacturers had not shipped enough phones to meet demand. It said the rate of growth in demand was less predictable as the phones became more popular with general consumers. **********Shares of L. M. Ericsson of Sweden, Motorola's main cellular equipment rival, also fell today on general nervousness about cellular industry growth rates. The company's American depository receipts dropped $1.50, to $56.875, in Nasdaq trading. **********Sales of cellular phones accounted for more than $8 billion of Motorola's $22.2 billion in revenues last year, with more than half of the sales coming from outside the United States. The cellular business has been one of Motorola's most rapidly growing operations for several years and the company today reiterated previous projections that worldwide sales would continue to grow at a rate of 50 percent or more for the next couple of years at least. **********Analysts said today's sharp selloff in Motorola's stock reflected profit taking (the shares had been trading at their 52-week high), the tendency of some investors to bolt at the first whiff of weakness in rapidly growing businesses and perhaps surprise at a stumble by a company that so frequently had delivered news that was better than expected. **********Most analysts shaved their first-quarter earnings estimates -- some as much as 10 percent -- but the prevailing view was that the news was not nearly bad enough to justify today's drop in the stock price. "I had it as a buy -- it's more so now," said John M. Geraghty, who follows the company for CS First Boston. **********Motorola may have contributed to investor nervousness by repeating warnings made last month about other problem areas, notably the slow rate of orders for its radio communications systems from start-up companies like Nextel Communications that have had trouble arranging financing to build the networks that they expect will compete with cellular phones. **********Motorola also reminded Wall Street to anticipate start-up inefficiencies with the company's new semiconductor plants expected to come on line this year. **********Mr. Gams said today that the company did not anticipate any write-offs against its earnings from any of the problems.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/30/world.main_headline: Argentine President Discourages New Revelations on 'Dirty War'
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/30/world.print_headline: Argentine President Discourages New Revelations on 'Dirty War'
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/30/world.body_text: **********In a radio interview President, Carlos Saul Menem has called on former military torturers and murderers to confess to priests and not to "rub salt in old wounds" by publicly recounting their deeds. "Publicly coming forward to give testimony is a way of returning to a horrible past that we are trying to forget," he said. **********Mr. Menem, who is running for re-election in May, accused "some of the media" of playing up recent revelations by a former navy captain, Adolfo Scilingo, who said the military disposed of hundreds of political prisoners by throwing them, alive but unconscious, into the ocean from aircraft. **********In an interview on Tuesday with Radio 9.90, which broadcasts to the capital, Mr. Menem said the Argentine people are tired of hearing about the military's "dirty war" of repression during the 1970's, and he blamed the news media and former military officers for keeping "this horrible memory" alive. **********Mr. Scilingo's disclosure has prompted other military men to come forward in recent weeks. A former navy conscript, Raul Alberto Guaru, said that during the 1970's he overheard his superior officers discussing instances when they "threw live people into the ocean." And a retired army captain, Hector Pedro Verges, said both military and civilians should tell all that they know about the dirty war "for the good of national reconciliation." **********Human rights groups and the families of victims said they were shocked and disappointed by Mr. Menem's statements, which they said may have been politically motivated. **********A national commission has determined that 4,000 people were killed under the military Government and that 9,000 people disappeared. Mr. Menem's Government announced last week that it has compiled a list of 1,000 additional people who disappeared during the dirty war. Mr. Menem said the Government planned to release the first 530 names within the next few days.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/28/busin.main_headline: Good News But No Good Explanation
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/28/busin.print_headline: Good News But No Good Explanation
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/28/busin.body_text: **********AT 12:58 last Tuesday afternoon, an auspicious event occurred in the corporate life of Presstek Inc.: the printing press technology company surpassed a total market value of $10 million -- per employee, that is. **********Now, this tiny New Hampshire company -- which is followed by no major Wall Street analysts, has little in the way of profits, and employs only 86 people -- is worth more than $800 million. **********Indeed, it was nothing short of an amazing week for Presstek. On Monday, the company's shares split on a two-for-one basis and began trading at slightly more than $46. By the following day, the share price had jumped as much as $16.25, to $62.50 a share. It closed out the week down from its highs, at $56.875 in over-the-counter trading. **********What accounts for all the excitement? Certainly not the company's disclosed financial performance. In the first quarter, Presstek announced earnings of 2 cents a share -- or $160,000 -- down 50 percent from the 4 cents it earned in the first quarter of 1994. Presstek shares are now trading at some 500 times earnings, the kind of lofty heights that should give most any investor a nosebleed. **********In public statements, Presstek has said that it has no idea why the stock price is moving in such a galloping way. But some short sellers -- that Wall Street breed that sells borrowed shares in a bet that the stock price will collapse -- have their own opinion: somebody out there is manipulating the price of Presstek shares. **********There are already some signs that there might be something to that.  Since November, the Securities and Exchange Commission has been conducting an investigation into the possible manipulation of Presstek stock. No charges have been filed, nor has any evidence from the inquiry been made public. **********In fact, the last time there was this much controversy about a rapid rise in a stock price was 1993. Then, the stock that was defying the laws of gravity was Future Communications, a Dallas-based cable television company with only three dozen employees. In little more than two months, shares in Future Communications surged from $6.50 to almost $30. Sound familiar? **********Short sellers argued it was a manipulation and sued. Future Communications later settled civil charges with the S.E.C. and went bankrupt. The lofty share price collapsed, and now the stock trades sporadically at around 25 cents a share. The investors in Future Communications seemed to scatter in the wind. **********What's odd is that a number of those same investors -- both institutions and individuals -- have been ponying up cash for Presstek shares. So, what does this mean for the potential of Presstek? Maybe nothing. Maybe it's all just one big, eerie coincidence. But one bit of advice: given the lack of public announcements from Presstek to account for its astronomical price rise, investors should probably pay close attention to future communications.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/29/busin.main_headline: Dollar Is Pushed Down Sharply As Fed Declines to Raise Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/29/busin.print_headline: CURRENCY MARKETS; Dollar Is Pushed Down Sharply As Fed Declines to Raise Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/29/busin.body_text: **********The dollar fell sharply against the German mark and the Japanese yen yesterday as the Federal Reserve left interest rate unchanged. **********The dollar fell throughout the day amid expectations that the Fed would not raise short-term interest rates. When the Fed announced yesterday afternoon that it was not taking any action, the dollar stayed at its depressed levels. **********Rising interest rates often help a currency by making bank deposits denominated in it more attractive. The prospect of steady rates prompted many traders to sell dollars. **********"The Fed didn't do anything," said Frank Conte, deputy chief currency dealer at Royal Bank of Canada. "That was expected, and the expectations triggered dollar selling." **********The dollar fell as low as 1.3857 marks, its lowest since March 20. In New York trading yesterday, it settled at 1.3882 marks, down from 1.4050 marks on Monday. The dollar fell to 88.90 yen from 89.40 yen. **********Growing expectations that the Bundesbank -- the German central bank -- will not lower interest rates at its policy meeting tomorrow also weighed on the dollar, dealers and analysts said. **********The Bundesbank's dominant concern is to control inflation. Strong economic growth and recent labor settlements that included annual wage increases of more than 4 percent will probably keep the central bank from lowering rates, analysts said. The Bundesbank has left rates unchanged since July 27. **********"Interest rate differentials will probably move against the dollar," as strong German economic growth pushes German interest rates higher, said Bruce English, manager of currency sales for ABN-Amro Bank in Chicago. **********Three-month dollar deposits in Europe yielded 6.25 percent yesterday, compared with 5 percent for three-month Euromark deposits. **********The dollar fared better against the yen than against the mark because of expectations of an interest rate cut in Japan, market participants said. **********Those expectations arose on Monday after Finance Minister Masayoshi Takemura, using a phrase that has become a code word for interest rate cuts, said Japan would follow a "flexible monetary policy" to cope with the strong yen. **********In other trading, the dollar fell to 1.1465 Swiss franc, from 1.1740 francs on Monday. The British pound rose to $1.6150 from $1.5975.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/28/world.main_headline: Hidden Change in Foreign Aid Bill Sets G.O.P. Against G.O.P.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/28/world.print_headline: Hidden Change in Foreign Aid Bill Sets G.O.P. Against G.O.P.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/28/world.body_text: **********A disagreement has broken out among Senate Republicans over an amendment quietly stuck into the foreign aid bill that would withdraw most-favored-nation trading status to any country that does not back sanctions against the Burmese military Government. **********While floor managers of bills often insert amendments that have unanimous support, several lawmakers criticized Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican who managed the foreign aid bill, for inserting an amendment, without unanimous backing, that could have huge repercussions. **********Several lawmakers said the bill could, for instance, cut off China's most-favored trade status because Beijing does not honor sanctions against Myanmar, formerly Burma. **********As the flap heated up, Senator McConnell said he would withdraw the amendment. **********After the Senate approved the bill last Thursday, John McCain of Arizona, a Republican leader on foreign policy, took to the Senate floor to attack the way the amendment on Myanmar was inserted. **********"I was quite upset about it and thought it was highly inappropriate to do it," Mr. McCain said in an interview. "I have a special concern about Burma -- 60 percent of the heroin coming to the United States comes through Burma -- and if there was an amendment on the issue, I wanted to be involved in the debate." **********Joining this unusual intraparty feud, Senator William Roth, the Delaware Republican who is chairman of the Finance Committee, wrote a letter to Mr. McConnell expressing great disappointment with the amendment. He complained not only that the provision involved matters that were the jurisdiction of his committee, but also that its call for withdrawing most-favored-nation trade status would violate treaties. **********In an interview today, Mr. McConnell said he inserted the amendment without a vote to apply some quick pressure on the Burmese military dictatorship. The foreign aid bill, approved 91 to 9, would cut overseas assistance by 10 percent. **********Mr. McConnell's amendment also calls for banning travel to Myanmar, barring Burmese imports and withholding money to the International Monetary Fund if it provides aid to Myanmar. **********"I do think there is some urgency about this," Mr. McConnell said. "The situation there is quite terrible. I thought it would be helpful to the situation in Burma to have some language in the bill." **********He called Senator McCain late today to say he would move to delete the amendment when House and Senate lawmakers meet to rework the bill in conference. Nonetheless, Mr. McConnell vowed to continue trying to pressure Myanmar and "fight this another day and soon." **********Several Republican Senate aides said they had been reassured by Robin Cleveland, a top aide to Mr. McConnell, that no Myanmar amendment would be put into the foreign aid bill. Several Republican aides said they were stunned to learn that a Myanmar amendment had been inserted into the overall bill, especially since several senators had expressed reservations about a bill on Myanmar that Mr. McConnell had been floating for several months. **********Mr. McConnell defended his decision to insert the amendment. Speaking about Senator McCain, he said, "What was unusual was that John wanted to clear every amendment we handled," he said. "That's just not possible. You can't manage a bill that way." **********But a senior Republican aide said, "It violates all Senate rules of tradition and comity to surreptitiously insert an important amendment that does not have unanimous consent."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/27/world.main_headline: The Clintons Back Parley On Women
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/27/world.print_headline: The Clintons Back Parley On Women
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/27/world.body_text: **********Celebrating women's suffrage in the first place in the world to grant it, President Clinton today denounced efforts to portray the United Nations Fourth World Conference on Women as a radical, anti-family event, and he and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, defended her decision to lead the American delegation as an attempt to improve the lot of women worldwide. **********In their most extensive remarks on Mrs. Clinton's participation in the conference in Beijing next month, the President and First Lady went out of their way to emphasize the diverse, bipartisan makeup of the official American delegation. And without citing China by name, Mr. Clinton made it clear that many nations still have a long way to go in assuring basic rights for women. **********Many Republicans in Congress have opposed American participation in the conference and Mrs. Clinton's attendance in particular, because of China's violations of human rights and because of the conference's expected stand on such issues as abortion. But Mr. Clinton dismissed such arguments as demagogic and beside the point. **********"One of the most troubling things to me about our politics today in America is that everything gets turned into just another version of the same old political fight," Mr. Clinton told a rally organized by the Wyoming League of Women Voters and other groups to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the ratification of the 19th Amendment, which gave all American women the right to vote 51 years after Wyoming had already done so as a territory. **********"All these issues seem to be torn like Silly Putty into extremes, so now there is this huge effort in America to try to convince the American people that this conference is somehow anti-family, and that we're sending some sort of radical delegation there," he said. **********"Why? Not because it's true, but because it furthers the almost addictive, almost narcotic drive among some elements in our society to take every single issue and use it as a cause for division among our people when we need to be united." **********Instead, Mr. and Mrs. Clinton said, the conference is about the most basic issues of concern to women and families everywhere: adequate health care, economic opportunity and political rights. Mrs. Clinton listed much of the delegation, which includes former Gov. Thomas Kean, the New Jersey Republican, and Susan Weld, the wife of Gov. William Weld, Republican of Massachusetts, in an effort to show it was not some liberal cabal. **********"And however anyone might try to paint this conference," Mr. Clinton said, "the truth is it is true blue to families -- to supporting them, to conserving them, to valuing them." **********He said that the United States could learn lessons from other countries, and that he would establish an interagency task force to carry out any "good ideas" that might come out the conference. **********The White House announced on Friday that Mrs. Clinton would serve as honorary chairwoman of the American delegation, one day after China expelled the American human rights advocate Harry Wu on espionage charges. Today's event had been long planned, and officials said Mrs. Clinton was glad to have the announcement of her role in the conference out of the way so she could elaborate on her reasons for going. **********The trip will be one of the First Lady's most high-profile appearances in months, but she left the political infighting to the President today and was much more circumspect in her comments, repeatedly emphasizing the nonthreatening motherhood themes of the meeting. **********The conference, she said, will raise awareness about the challenges and burdens women face and advance their interests. **********Women voters are an important constituency for Mr. Clinton, and one whose support his fledgling campaign is working hard to retain next year. Since 1964, women have outnumbered men among the American electorate, and they constituted 54 percent of the vote in 1992. **********But, Mrs. Clinton noted, only 45 percent of eligible women voted in the 1994 election, and the Administration is hoping to boost that turnout next year. Today's appearance, featuring a rousing performance by the Cow Patsys, a singing, fiddling trio of women, had all the feel of a campaign rally, with the Teton mountain range a perfect backdrop against a cloudless sky. **********Mr. Clinton recited his history as the son and grandson of working women in the 1940's, and both Clintons recited Wyoming's pioneering history. While some other American states and cities allowed women to vote in school board and some other local elections earlier, Wyoming is regarded as the first jurisdiction in the world to grant women a general right to vote, in 1869, and Jackson became the first municipality in the world with an all-female government, in 1920. **********The state's legacy is commemorated in its motto, "The Equality State" and in its official seal, which features the image of a woman with broken chains on her wrists, holding a banner. **********But the territorial legislators' decision to grant women the vote was born partly of old-fashioned expediency. At the time, men outnumbered women here by about 7 to 1, and the legislators saw women's suffrage as a way to attract more women and families as settlers. **********In his weekly radio address today, Mr. Clinton made another pitch for protecting the nation's natural wonders from Congressional budget cuts or unwise private development. He once again criticized the 1873 Mining Law that he said allows claims to be staked and mined on Federal land "while giving virtually nothing back to the American people who make it possible." **********The President acknowledged that some Federal environmental regulations needed streamlining or simplifying. "Do we need reforms? Yes," he said. "Should we reverse course? Not on your life."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/15/world.main_headline: With New African Flavor, Pope Starts Tour in Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/15/world.print_headline: With New African Flavor, Pope Starts Tour in Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/15/world.body_text: **********On Pope John Paul II's 11th visit to this continent, beginning in Cameroon today, each stop of his four-country tour will include African touches for church ceremonies that even five years ago would have seemed strongly out of place for a Roman Catholic event of this magnitude. **********Responding to the wishes of African bishops for a church that is more accessible to the continent's worshipers, the Vatican has worked hard in recent years to put more African flavor into the church's rites offered here, tolerating a growing number of local influences so long as they are not seen to violate any of Roman Catholicism's central tenets. **********Many of these changes were on display here in this former French colony last week, as the church celebrated the introduction of Catholicism 100 years ago, when the first missionaries settled in the Ivory Coast. The festivities included priestly processions to the beat of African drums in which men dressed in hand-woven gowns waved fly whiskers, much in the manner of many traditional African ceremonies. **********"Africa must find Jesus within its own culture," said Paul Cardinal Poupard, the Pope's special envoy to this country's centenary. "In Zaire, for example, their rites are totally different from the Roman Mass. The accessories used are typically traditional, people are asked how they are faring before the service, and the offerings consist of local products, like yams and plantains. In short, the Gospel is integrated into the cultural patrimony of each African country." **********But if opening up the church to some of Africa's colorful pageantry and other tastes has proved relatively easy, in many other ways the challenge before this Pope of making the Vatican's teachings more relevant to the world's poorest continent has become more difficult than ever. **********When John Paul II last visited Africa, in 1993, the breakup of the Soviet Union was still an event whose consequences were fresh on people's minds everywhere, and one of his central messages as he traveled the continent was for people to be wary of ideology and to place their faith in the teachings of the church. **********Still, if Africa, with its more than 90 million Catholics, is one of the most fertile recruiting grounds for new believers, it is also a place where many of the Vatican's teachings collide with deeply ingrained cultural obstacles or face harsh economic, demographic or health realities that to many seem to argue against them. **********During a stopover in Benin on his last African tour, for instance, the Pope suggested that abstinence was the only acceptable means for combating the spread of AIDS, which has hit this continent harder than any other. **********John Paul's comments flew in the face of campaigns under way in Benin and many other African countries to encourage the use of condoms as the most cost-effective way of containing the disease and at the same time helping control the continent's galloping population growth. **********Perhaps nowhere can the challenge facing the church's teachings in Africa be more readily seen than in the question of polygamy, a practice that is considered sinful by the Vatican, but which forms a central part of the traditional social structure of millions of Africans in every region of this continent. **********African Catholics often reconcile their faith with this ancestral practice with discretion or outright denial, performing an urban church ceremony in one marriage, and an often quieter, rural and traditional ceremony -- often nothing more than the pouring of libations or the exchange of vows before witnesses -- in subsequent weddings with second and third wives. **********As in many African countries, in the Ivory Coast the most powerful example of this pattern was given from above by President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, a practicing Catholic who nonetheless took more than one spouse, a fact which although never officially announced, was widely known. **********Mr. Houphouet-Boigny built the world's second largest basilica, after St. Peter's in the Vatican, and this Pope came to bless it. **********For many on this continent, extramarital liaisons are as much a reflection of hard economic facts of life as they are of adherence to custom. **********"It is one thing to be a Christian, and it is another thing to survive," said Martine Abetoh, a single, 29-year-old Catholic woman here who says she has a longstanding relationship with a married Catholic man. "The economic environment in our countries does not always permit us to live the word of God. He takes care of me and of my child, and I don't have a job or any other means. Should I live in misery?" **********For Cardinal Poupard, there is no question of the church's endorsing practices like these, but at the same time, there is a growing sense of patience before a task that, admittedly, will not be accomplished overnight. **********"A polygamist is not a Christian, because a Christian follows the word of God, and the Bible does not permit a man to have two wives," he said. "In this case, a person should not take communion, because he is not worthy of the kingdom. But can the church prevent man from doing what he wants to do?"

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/05/busin.main_headline: A New Tune: Freedom Not to Pay Taxes
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/05/busin.print_headline: A New Tune: Freedom Not to Pay Taxes
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/05/busin.body_text: **********Twenty-six years ago, Richie Havens opened the Woodstock music festival with his signature anthem, "Freedom," a hoarsely passionate cry of the heart that expressed the rage and defiance of a youthful America against a seemingly monolithic, authoritarian Federal Government. **********Some things change; it is now the right that is generally associated with decrying the centralized power in Washington. But some things don't; Mr. Havens still does not like the Government. And he often expresses this in his live performances by telling audiences -- "reminding them," is how he put it in a recent telephone interview -- that paying Federal taxes is voluntary. **********"I'm more or less not a protester," Mr. Havens said, taking pains to point out that he does, in fact, pay all his taxes, "so much as I am trying to get the actuality out about what the people don't know: that tax, especially income tax, is voluntary." **********Mr. Havens contended that this was explicitly written in the Constitution. He could not make a precise citation, though he referred to the Government's needing the people's permission to exercise its power, an apparent reference to the 10th Amendment, which delegates "to the states, respectively, or to the people" all powers not specifically delegated to the Federal Government. **********At the age of 54, Mr. Havens is still spreading the gospel musically. He tours almost every week of the year, he said; he's working on a new recording for Rhino Records. And, in a rather delicious culture clash, he will be performing at Rainbow and Stars, the elegant cabaret adjacent to the Rainbow Room atop Rockefeller Center, for two weeks at the end of July. He said he did not know how much money he made last year, but that it was not a lot and that most of it went to paying his bills. **********Mr. Havens is happy to pay state and local taxes, he said, because it is money that a citizen can see is being put to use. But Washington is another story, dominated by party politics and, as he sees it, serving the special interests of the legislators, not those of all Americans. **********"The point is there's no such thing as far right, or liberalism; there's only Americans," he said. "All of us are Americans first." **********He added that "we should pay for what we get, not for what we don't get." What we don't get, he said, is "just about everything." **********"How about a real Congress?" he asked. "And not people who have been there for 100 years, promoting their agenda. That's called pork barreling." **********Mr. Havens said these were his reasons for not voting. He does pay taxes, he said, because "I'm much more effective in my own life and my own conscience, to be free of the legal hassles that those guys can give you."

The 2,015-megawatt plant being built 120 miles south of Bombay would be the nation's biggest power plant. **********Opposition leaders who won elections in March in Maharashtra state set up the committee to review the terms of the $2.5 billion deal.
