https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/23/busin.main_headline: Dreamworks and Microsoft in Multimedia Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/23/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Dreamworks and Microsoft in Multimedia Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/23/busin.body_text: **********Dreamworks SKG and the Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that they would form a software company to produce interactive and multimedia entertainment products. **********Separately, William H. Gates, chairman of Microsoft, said his company would become a minority investor in Dreamworks; he did not disclose the amount of the investment. On Sunday, Paul G. Allen, a co-founder of Microsoft, agreed to make an equity investment of $500 million in Dreamworks, which is raising a total of $900 million from outside investors. **********At a news conference yesterday at Microsoft's headquarters in Redmond, Wash., executives from the two companies said they would invest $30 million to start the software venture, which would be based in Los Angeles and Redmond. **********The venture will focus initially on interactive CD-ROM disks, with up to two dozen titles a year based on original adventure games, licensed properties, and movies and television series produced by the DreamWorks studio, the new entertainment company controlled by David Geffen, Jeffrey Katzenberg and Steven Spielberg. **********The company's first titles will be original and should be out by Christmas 1996. The venture also plans to license consumer products. **********The company expects to begin with 75 employees, who will come from the software, animation and film industries. A search is currently under way for a chief executive, the companies said. Mr. Katzenberg said most of the start-up budget would go toward hiring people. **********Although Dreamworks is investing far less in the multimedia venture than in its other businesses, Mr. Katzenberg said his company saw the venture as an important part of its future. **********Mr. Geffen, who has been involved in both the record and film businesses, said it was too early to judge the impact of multimedia technology on the music industry. "As it becomes more clear, we will figure out how to address it," he said. **********Independent of the Dreamworks venture, Microsoft will continue to develop interactive information and entertainment software products under its Microsoft Home brand, which includes the Microsoft Encarta multimedia encyclopedia. **********Microsoft, which has a reputation for seeking to control its own future, has never before been involved in a joint venture of this nature. When the executives were asked how effectively they thought the venture could work, Mr. Katzenberg replied that the sides had come to respect one another during the last several months, adding that he believed the new entity would have a large degree of control over its own destiny.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/18/busin.main_headline: CIBA-GEIGY AND MEDAREX TO DEVELOP NEW CANCER DRUG
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/18/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; CIBA-GEIGY AND MEDAREX TO DEVELOP NEW CANCER DRUG
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/18/busin.body_text: **********The Swiss drug maker Ciba-Geigy A.G. and Medarex Inc. said yesterday that they had formed a partnership to develop and market Medarex's treatment for certain cancerous tumors. Medarex's product, MDX-210 Bispecific, is being tested as a potential treatment for breast, ovarian, prostate and other cancers. Under the agreement, Ciba-Geigy will spend $8 million to acquire common shares of Medarex, a biopharmaceutical company based in Annandale, N.J. In addition, Ciba-Geigy will provide as much as $31 million for research and development and pay all costs relating to clinical trials, regulatory approval and the introduction of MDX-210. Shares of Medarex rose 87.5 cents, to $4.25, in Nasdaq trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/14/busin.body_text: **********The Sprint Cellular Company said today that it had agreed to acquire the Southeastern Cellular Company of Greenville, N.C. Terms were not disclosed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/17/busin.body_text: **********The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company raised many of its prices as much as 5 percent yesterday and analysts predicted demand for tires would continue to surge. As a result, tire stocks rallied. **********Goodyear, based in Akron, Ohio, announced price increases of 3 to 5 percent in the cost of replacement tires effective Feb. 15. It said higher prices were necessary to offset higher costs of raw material. Commercial truck and farm tire prices are set to rise 3 percent to 5 percent while auto and light-truck tires will increase 3 percent across the board. **********Goodyear, North America's largest tire maker, said market prices for some grades of rubber had more than doubled since early 1994, with much of the increase coming in the last 60 days. Synthetic rubber and carbon black prices have also jumped by more than 10 percent over the last year. **********Yesterday's announcement followed price increases of 2 percent to 10 percent for off-road tires in January, 3 percent to 4 percent for tread rubber and retread products in December and 2 percent to 4.5 percent for all replacement tires in October. **********On the stock market, Goodyear shares rose 87.5 cents, to $38.25. Cooper Tire & Rubber gained $1.625, to $27.50, and Bandag Inc., a maker of retread rubber, added 12.5 cents, to $61.50. **********Also yesterday, Wendy Beale Needham, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, raised her investment opinion on both Goodyear and Cooper Tire to "outperform" from "market performer." Both companies are seeing "continuing good underlying demand for tires," she said in a research report, and are financially strong enough to increase their dividends this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/09/busin.main_headline: Ketchum Inc. Has Plan To Close Later This Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/09/busin.print_headline: Ketchum Inc. Has Plan To Close Later This Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/09/busin.body_text: **********Ketchum Inc., for many years the nation's largest fund-raising counseling company, has begun to wind down operations and will close later this year, Robert Carter, its president, said last night. **********"While we are fully booked with fund-raising commitments throughout the country, the firm's inability to make a reasonable profit in the foreseeable future made this difficult decision a prudent business move," Mr. Carter said. Word of the company's plan began circulating in fund-raising circles yesterday after it started notifying clients that it would fulfill its contracts but would not extend them. **********Ketchum Communications, the worldwide advertising and public relations group that was spun off from the fund-raising operation years ago, will not be affected by Ketchum Inc.'s closing. A related partnership, Ketchum Canada Inc., will also be unaffected, Mr. Carter said. **********Mr. Carter said the company, which is privately held and based in Pittsburgh, fell victim to a failed expansion into Britain, too much debt resulting from a 1986 purchase of a Pittsburgh office building and a slowdown in fund-raising drives by nonprofit hospitals unsure about the future of health-care financing. **********He said the company was also hurt by its emphasis on full-time employees, instead of consultants paid by the project. Ketchum Inc. has 70 employees, down from 200 employees five years ago, in Pittsburgh, Boston, Charlotte, N.C., and other cities. **********The decision to close Ketchum Inc. comes at a time of intense competition for charitable dollars. Data gathered by the National Center for Charitable Statistics indicate total giving, adjusted for inflation, has been declining since 1989. **********In campaigns for major gifts "the market has matured and many, many colleges and hospitals and other institutions that in the early days hired a firm like Ketchum and paid them a healthy retainer to have a manager on-site for a year or two years now have their own staff to run their campaigns," said Russ Reid, president of Russ Reid, Inc., a prominent fund-raising firm for direct mail and television campaigns, based in Pasadena, Calif. **********"The old-line firms are going to have to adapt to a new market if they want to survive," Mr. Reid said. **********Since its founding in 1919, Ketchum Inc. has raised billions of dollars for hospitals, youth and social services organizations and religious charities. Mr. Carter said that in the past decade it raised more than $1 billion just for higher education, including campaigns for St. John's University, Georgetown University and Northeastern University. **********"This is very sad because they were for years the biggest and one of the best," said Jack Schwartz, the retired president of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel Inc., a trade association. "This shows that the field of professional fund raising is much more difficult today, with much greater competition for the philanthropic dollar and with many organizations relying on their own staff and using professional firms primarily as consultants, which makes it very hard to make a profit." **********Carlton G. Ketchum, one of the company's founders, helped start the trade association in 1935 to raise standards among professional fund-raisers. Mr. Ketchum, who died in 1984 at age 92, served as the association's first president.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/11/busin.main_headline: INITIAL OFFERING PROPOSED FOR AMERICAN LIFE GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/11/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; INITIAL OFFERING PROPOSED FOR AMERICAN LIFE GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/11/busin.body_text: **********Conseco Inc. of Carmel, Ind., filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday for an initial public offering of 15 million shares of the American Life Group, an insurance company that is based in Des Moines. At the $17-a-share price proposed in the filing, the sale would total $255 million and produce a profit of nearly $100 million for Conseco Capital Partners II, the investor group that acquired American Life's predecessor company in September 1994. About 5.9 million shares are to be sold by American Life and 9.1 million by American Life's owners.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/24/busin.main_headline: Securities Firms Post A Profitable Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/24/busin.print_headline: Securities Firms Post A Profitable Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/24/busin.body_text: **********Wall Street securities firms were generally profitable in the second quarter, rebounding from a loss in the corresponding period last year, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday. **********The 309 member firms of the exchange that do business with the public had net earnings of $899 million on revenue of $22.3 billion in the quarter that ended on June 30, the Big Board said. In the corresponding period a year ago, the firms had a loss of $404 million on revenue of $16.4 billion. **********Commission revenue for the firms rose to nearly $4 billion in the latest quarter from $3.2 billion in the second quarter of 1994. Last year's loss was caused by a slump in financial markets, which hampered trading and underwriting activities. **********The exchange said 253 firms were profitable in the latest quarter, compared with 200 in the corresponding period last year. Only 56 firms were unprofitable in this year's quarter, much lower than the 102 a year earlier. **********Big Board specialist firms, which do not do business with the public but manage trading in individual stocks between securities firms, reported a quarterly profit of $39 million on revenue of $173 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/03/busin.main_headline: Mexican Report Details Brush With Insolvency
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/03/busin.print_headline: Mexican Report Details Brush With Insolvency
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/03/busin.body_text: **********Haunted by lingering investor uncertainty, Mexican financial markets lost ground today as a central bank report showed how close the nation had come to insolvency before a new international assistance package was announced in Washington earlier this week. **********The peso, after gaining strength for the last two days, weakened slightly to 5.455 to the dollar, down from 5.375 on Wednesday. The Mexican stock market, unable to sustain a rally, slumped a further 2.7 percent today to close just under 1,944 -- 56 points below the 2,000 level many investors consider an important indicator of market health. **********The Mexican central bank reported late Wednesday night that its foreign currency reserves had dwindled during January to $3.48 billion, a drop of more than 43 percent since the end of December, when reserves totaled nearly $6.15 billion. **********The Government had previously denied a report in The International Herald Tribune on Monday that the reserves had fallen to $2 billion. **********However, financial analysts here and in New York say that the $3.48 billion figure does not truly represent the central bank's current assets because some of the money may be tied up in accounts with restrictive terms. Furthermore, the bank reported that last month it had to draw down $2.1 billion from the lines of credit made available by the United States, Canada and other nations on Jan. 3. **********The report made clear that Mexico had come close to going broke before President Clinton announced the new rescue package on Tuesday. Economists said the $3.48 billion in remaining reserves would have been enough to cover only two and a half to three weeks of imports. In addition, the Government knew that it was obligated to pay off more than $1 billion worth of short-term bonds this week. The bonds, called tesobonos, are indexed to the value of the dollar. **********Alluding to Mexican economic officials, Jorge O. Mariscal, vice president of the Latin American equity group at Goldman, Sachs, said: "They were very close to having to really come up with something else. This week they may have solved half of the problem, which is the financing of tesobonos. But the other half is the lack of credibility of Mexican institutions." **********By Monday, Mexico will have available the first installments of more than $50 billion in assistance brokered by President Clinton. This money is expected to come from the first part of a $17.8 billion line of credit approved by the International Monetary Fund late Wednesday. **********[ European financial officials were quoted in Frankfurt as saying Thursday that five leading European nations had abstained from the approval vote as a sign of displeasure at being given only an hour's notice of the new rescue plan by the United States. ] **********Investors will be watching next Tuesday's regularly scheduled auction of Government bonds to see whether the new assistance helps Mexico's credit standing. The Government canceled this week's auction after President Clinton declared that he was abandoning his efforts to get a Mexico rescue package through Congress, but before he announced his alternative. **********Interest rates for the bonds had reportedly risen above 30 percent on Tuesday morning, persuading officials to cancel the sale. **********The auction next Tuesday will be seen as a test of investors' confidence, both in terms of how many bonds are sold and the kind of inter est rates that investors demand. The current interest rate for the 91-day bond is 24.98 percent. **********While the markets calmed down this week, financial analysts said they were unsure about the willingness of Mexico to tighten its budget and monetary policies, and uneasy that the Government had not yet announced a new policy for setting the peso's exchange rate. **********American depository receipts of Telefonos de Mexico, a bellwether for the Mexican equity market, closed today at $33.50 a share, down 75 cents, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The continuing uneasiness was apparent in a move Wednesday by Standard & Poor's to lower its ratings one notch on Mexico's long-term foreign-currency debt, to BB, Mexico's peso-denominated debt was similarly lowered, to single-A. **********However, S.& P. also removed Mexican debt from the credit watch it had imposed on Dec. 23, three days after the Government set off the current crisis by devaluing the peso. "The removal of all ratings from credit and the stable foreign currency outlook are based on the stabilizing effect of the $51 billion multilateral financial support agreement," the rating agency said in a statement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/15/busin.main_headline: Intuit Signs 19 Deals for Home-Banking Software
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/15/busin.print_headline: Intuit Signs 19 Deals for Home-Banking Software
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/15/busin.body_text: **********Intuit Inc. announced yesterday that 19 financial institutions, including many of the nation's largest banks, credit card companies and brokerage firms, would use its popular Quicken software for home banking services beginning this fall. **********The move signals the company's intent to compete aggressively with the Microsoft Corporation after the collapse in May of plans for the two companies to merge. **********Yet while the alliances are expected to enhance Intuit's lead over Microsoft in the fast-growing home banking market, many of the banking companies that have signed on with Intuit -- including Chemical Banking and Sanwa Bank California -- also have relationships with Microsoft. Officials of those banks say they will allow customers to choose which service to use. **********"I think we can expect a pier-six brawl between Microsoft and Intuit this fall," said Adam Schoenfeld, vice president of Jupiter Communications Inc., a market research firm in New York that specializes in on-line services. **********With a new version of Quicken, customers of American Express, Chase Manhattan Bank, Smith Barney and other institutions will be able to transfer money between accounts, pay bills and retrieve data from their accounts directly into financial files on their personal computers. All electronic transactions will be processed through the Intuit Services Corporation, a unit of the company that acts as a data clearinghouse between the customer and the bank. **********The customer will probably pay a monthly fee to the institution for the electronic banking services, though in some cases, said Scott Cook, the chairman and founder of Intuit, the service might be free. Intuit will collect fees from the institutions. **********Shares of Intuit rose $2.75 yesterday, to $85.75, in Nasdaq trading. The stock jumped $4.75, or 6 percent, on Thursday in anticipation of yesterday's announcement. Shares of Microsoft also rose yesterday, closing at $103.675, up $3.50, in Nasdaq trading. **********The new service could accelerate consumer participation in the long-nascent market for electronic banking services. Only about a quarter of home computer users regularly use a financial software program, but that number is growing quickly. And Quicken has between 60 and 70 percent of the personal finance software market, with about eight million users. Mr. Cook of Intuit called the endorsement of Quicken by the 19 financial institutions " a giant leap forward" in the way both home computer users and small-business owners manage their books. **********For banks, home banking will lead to lower costs as they cut back on labor and branch costs, much the same way automated teller machines have led to lower bank staff costs. Small and midsize banks are eager to offer home banking to give them an edge over larger institutions. "It levels the playing field for smaller banks without the branch reach," said Keith H. Karpe, vice president of Sanwa Bank California, which has 110 branches. **********Intuit's announcement comes at a time of rapid change in the electronic banking industry. Two months ago, Microsoft withdrew its $2 billion bid to acquire Intuit amid an antitrust investigation by the Justice Department. **********In addition, the No. 3 company in financial software, Meca Software of Fairfield, Conn., a unit of H & R Block, announced in May that it was being acquired by a union of the BankAmerica Corporation of San Francisco and the Nationsbank Corporation of Charlotte, N.C. The two banking companies plan to offer electronic banking services over their own private networks, with Meca's Managing Your Money software installed on customers' personal computers. **********After the merger of Intuit and Microsoft collapsed, there was some question in the software industry as to whether Intuit would have enough influence on its own to woo large financial institutions. **********Mr. Cook of Intuit said negotiations with many of the institutions announced yesterday were begun during the merger negotiations, but that the collapse of the merger had no impact on their decisions. "We lost no financial institution partners that were with us at the time of the merger," he said. **********The other institutions that will work with Intuit are Bank of Boston, Centura Bank, Compass Bank, Corestates Bank, First National Bank of Chicago, First Interstate Bank, Home Savings of America, M&T Bank, Marquette Banks, Michigan National Bank, Texas Commerce Bank, Union Bank, U.S. Bancorp and Wells Fargo Bank.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/05/busin.main_headline: KETCHUM SELLS SOME ASSETS TO RESOURCE SERVICES
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/05/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; KETCHUM SELLS SOME ASSETS TO RESOURCE SERVICES
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/05/busin.body_text: **********Ketchum Inc., which announced on Feb. 8 that it was going out of business after decades as the nation's leading fund-raising company, has sold its research files and remaining business to Resource Services Inc., a privately held Christian fund-raising company. Resource Services, owned by the Dallas businessmen Ben Gill and William Wilson, said it expected to raise $400 million for clients this year. Mr. Gill and Mr. Wilson will operate Ketchum, based in Pittsburgh, and Resource Services in tandem. But the companies' combined activities make them the nation's largest fund-raising concern, Carl Hefton, executive vice president of Resource Services, said. Mr. Hefton said the acquisition would allow Resource Services to develop secular markets and expertise in large gifts usually connected with estate planning.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/10/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Literary factors may be driving Berkshire Hathaway's surge.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/10/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Literary factors may be driving Berkshire Hathaway's surge.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/10/busin.body_text: **********CAN a best-selling book send a stock zooming? Apparently, the answer is yes. The stock of Berkshire Hathaway Inc. has leaped 20 percent so far in 1995, rising despite reports of some insider selling late last year and in the face of mediocre performance from many of the stocks that Berkshire Hathaway owns. **********Berkshire Hathaway, as every owner of the stock knows, is run by Warren E. Buffett, who does not believe in stock splits. That fact, plus the excellent record Mr. Buffett has compiled, explains why Berkshire Hathaway trades at levels never seen before in this country. The stock closed at $24,550 a share, down $275, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. When Mr. Buffett took over the company 30 years ago, the price was less than $20. **********Mr. Buffett is the subject of a current best seller, "The Warren Buffett Way," by Robert C. Hagstrom Jr. In its subtitle, the book calls Mr. Buffett "the world's greatest investor." If anything, the book is more laudatory than that would indicate. **********Peter A. Russ, an analyst with Shelby Cullom Davis and a longtime fan of Berkshire Hathaway, said he assumed that the readers of the book had felt they had to own a share or two of Berkshire Hathaway. **********"I think this is the first time the stock does not have a dollar-for-dollar intrinsic value underlying it," Mr. Russ said. But he quickly added that he thought the stock was likely not to fall sharply but to mark time for a period, as values caught up with the stock price. **********One holder who evidently was taken by surprise by the latest run-up was Charles T. Munger, vice chairman of Berkshire Hathaway. He took in about $8 million in November and December, selling 400 shares at prices ranging from $19,600 to $20,700, far below the current level. He did not return a telephone call seeking comment yesterday. Mr. Buffett also did not return calls. **********As the shares have advanced this year, trading as high as $25,200 last week, there has been more turnover than normal, with the volume in January at 6,130 shares traded, the highest monthly volume in more than three years and more than double the usual level. So far this month, the volume has come to 2,120 shares. The assumption is that the activity was caused by the book publicity; certainly no one is thinking about a takeover. **********Berkshire Hathaway's annual report should be out in early March, and only then will investors learn how the company's various businesses performed. They range from the World Book encyclopedia and The Buffalo News to See's Candies, Dexter Shoes and the Nebraska Furniture Mart. The operating results of Berkshire Hathaway's insurance companies are also important. **********But if there are a lot of unknowns in those businesses, it is clear how some of Berkshire Hathaway's largest stock investments are performing. Their performance cannot explain Berkshire Hathaway's surge. The company's portfolio of big holdings, now valued at almost $14 billion, includes holdings of $1 billion or more in Coca-Cola, Capital Cities/ABC, Geico, Gillette and Wells Fargo. Other sizable holdings are in the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, General Dynamics, the Washington Post Company and Guinness. **********Since the beginning of the year, those common stock holdings have risen 3 percent, while Berkshire Hathaway's stock has gained 20 percent. From July 1 of last year the comparisons are just as striking, with the stock portfolio up about 12 percent and Berkshire Hathaway's stock up 49 percent. **********Berkshire Hathaway also has large convertible preferred holdings in Salomon Inc. and USAir. Because the preferreds do not trade, neither is included in the calculations. If estimates of them were included, the performance for the portfolio would be a bit worse. **********Mr. Hagstrom's book does a fine job of describing Mr. Buffett's investment style, which often features the purchase of stocks that are out of favor with investors. At $24.95, the book now is probably a better buy than the stock.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/10/busin.main_headline: Added Worry Facing CBS: Gaping Holes In Fall Lineup
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/10/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Added Worry Facing CBS: Gaping Holes In Fall Lineup
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/10/busin.body_text: **********After a collapse in prime-time ratings that has seen the network lose ground every night of the week, CBS is likely to find itself with an extraordinary number of holes to fill in its program schedule next fall -- more new programming, a senior CBS executive conceded, than any network can realistically introduce at once. **********The network's fortunes, in sharp decline since September, have fallen further and faster in recent weeks as a batch of new programs introduced last month have fared even worse than the programs they replaced. **********The overall prime-time rating for CBS this season is a still respectable 11.2, compared with a 12.1 rating for the leader, ABC, which is owned by Capital Cities/ ABC/ Inc. (Each rating point represents 954,000 homes.) **********But in the last three weeks, CBS has been in a midweek ratings desert: From Tuesday through Friday, not a single CBS program has reached a double-digit rating in prime time. **********"CBS's position is kind of scary," Steve Sternberg, a senior partner with BJK & E Media, said. Compared with last season, he added, "the network is down 10 to 20 percent across the board." **********CBS executives freely acknowledge that they find themselves in the position of a sports team that is so far behind in a game it adopts a strategy of "clearing the bench." **********"We're just kind of sending in the scrubs to see what they can do," David F. Poltrack, senior vice president of research for CBS, said. "We knew we wouldn't be competitive." **********CBS has already confronted the difficult problem of falling so far short of the guarantees it made to advertisers that it was forced to give away large numbers of commercials to advertisers -- what are known as make-good ads. With the network's recent performance declining even more, the make-good problems have worsened, Mr. Poltrack said. **********Some CBS executives have started to resort to gallows humor. "We joke that it's deliberate," a senior CBS executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said. "We're doing this bad now so no matter what we put on next season, it'll look like we've improved enormously." **********Mr. Poltrack replied: "That's how a cynic sees it. That may be how you set a low benchmark for next season. If you survive until next year it's a good strategy. The problem is how to survive until next year." **********One way CBS is surviving is by holding back on costs as much as possible. The network has not filled some positions that have become vacant, including the head of its program practices division (better known as the chief censor), who left last month. "We probably won't be filling that job," the senior CBS executive said. **********But Mr. Poltrack emphasized that the network's focus had shifted. He said CBS wrote off this season after the end of the last ratings sweep period in February. "Since then we've been in development for next season," he said. **********CBS has tried to load the next sweep month, in May, with as many specials -- mini-series and the like -- as it can. Otherwise the network has concentrated on finding new shows for next season, which begins in September. **********But given the midweek collapse it has been suffering, CBS may be required to add more new fall programs than ever, the senior executive said. **********Last month, Peter Tortorici, president of CBS Entertainment, presented a preview for advertisers of the programs CBS had in development. Most in the audience were impressed. At the time, Mr. Tortorici said he expected to replace "about five and a half hours of shows on the low end" and "seven hours on the high end" in the fall. **********As the season draws to a close in the next two weeks, though, CBS has 8 to 10 hours on the weekly schedule that are regularly below the network's ratings average. **********"At the research department we would advise against going up toward 10 hours of new programs," Mr. Poltrack said. "Beyond six hours, it's almost inevitable that the replacement show won't equal the show it's replacing." **********The reason, he said, is that in program planning, the best new show is considered to have replaced the worst old show. As the network moves down its list of new shows it begins to move up the list of shows it intends to replace, and the line that defines which show is truly better begins to get blurred. **********"We have a lot of tough decisions to make," Mr. Poltrack said. He cited a group of shows the network introduced this year that, while not hits, have not really been rejected by viewers, including "Due South," "Under Suspicion" and "Touched by an Angel." Depending on how many new shows with potential that CBS thinks it has, some in that group may return next season, despite tepid ratings. **********Most prominent in that category, Mr. Poltrack said, is "Under Suspicion," a show about a female detective. He said CBS believed the lead actress, Karen Sillas, has an opportunity to become a star; several viewers' groups have organized campaigns to save the series. **********"For reasons we can't really explain, that show has been the lowest-sampled show on television," Mr. Poltrack said. "The viewers who have seen it tell us they like it." **********Another risk CBS faces in ordering wholesale cancellations is that the network will have nothing but repeats of lame-duck shows to offer during the summer. **********CBS also does not want to further damage its most valuable property, "The Late Show With David Letterman." That show still dominates the late-night competition but has seen its audiences erode along with CBS's midweek evening ratings. **********"The prime-time lead-in for Letterman is about 40 percent less than it is for Jay Leno on the 'Tonight' show," Mr. Poltrack said. Mr. Leno, on NBC, which is owned by the General Electric Company, is Mr. Letterman's main entertainment competition. But, Mr. Poltrack added, "I think the summer won't be as bad for Letterman because college kids are home and he's especially popular with them, and Leno won't get the huge lead-in he's getting now."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/17/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Interactive Focus For Two Alliances
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/17/busin.body_text: **********Two developments in interactive marketing were announced yesterday. **********Three market research companies -- Nielsen Media Research, a unit of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation; Yankelovich Partners, and ASI Market Research -- have formed a strategic partnership to develop research services for measuring the use of on-line computer services and the Internet. The alliance is being called ANYwhere Online, for the first letters of the names of the three partners; it will focus initially on the World Wide Web. **********ASI is also a partner in the Interactive Information Index, a research service to compile data for interactive media. ASI is forming the service with the Arbitron New Media unit of the Ceridian Corporation and Next Century Media. Asked if ASI would continue its involvement in both projects, Bill Moult, president and chief executive of ASI in Stamford, Conn., said: "That's a very good question. We have made commitments to certain clients and things have to be sorted out over the next couple of months." **********And two agencies specializing in interactive marketing said yesterday that they had teamed up to develop and manage interactive programs for selected clients. The terms were not disclosed. The shops are the Interactive Media Works in Overland Park, Kan., and Interactive Marketing in Hermosa Beach, Calif., which will continue to operate as independent agencies. The two will join forces to work for clients that have not been identified.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/12/busin.main_headline: CHAIN EXPECTS 2D-QUARTER EARNINGS TO DECLINE OVER 50%
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/12/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; CHAIN EXPECTS 2D-QUARTER EARNINGS TO DECLINE OVER 50%
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/12/busin.body_text: **********The Kmart Corporation's second-quarter earnings are expected to decline by more than 50 percent as it struggles to improve operations while being buffeted by stronger, more efficient rivals. The nation's No. 2 discount retailer on Monday is expected to report earnings of 11 cents a share, down from 20 cents in the quarter a year earlier, according to 16 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. And estimates have been falling: The three most recent estimates were for 8 cents a share. The retailer, based in Troy, Mich., has had nine straight quarters of disappointing results -- including a loss in the fiscal first quarter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/15/world.main_headline: Brazil's Chief Due in U.S. Riding Boom
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/15/world.print_headline: Brazil's Chief Due in U.S. Riding Boom
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/15/world.body_text: **********With exports and investment surging into Brazil from the United States, this nation's new President plans to open a campaign next week to shift Americans' attention from Mexico to his country. **********"We have sustained a 5 percent economic growth rate for the last three years," said President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who arrives in New York on Monday on a five-day visit to the United States. "Mexico never had this." **********The country's first English-speaking President in memory, Mr. Cardoso, 63, is fashioning a role as national salesman with the goal of attracting more investment and expanding Brazil's political influence. **********In a speech on Tuesday at the United Nations, he is expected to argue that Brazil, with a population of 155 million, should win a permanent seat on an expanded Security Council. **********In speeches to American business executives in New York, he is expected to outline expanding investment opportunities in Brazil, which has a market economy that is larger than Russia's. To encourage more Americans to come here, he plans to sign new legislation lengthening the visas issued to Americans from 90 days to five years. **********United States exports to Brazil jumped by 35 percent last year, and Brazil has recently been the only major country to post monthly trade deficits with the United States. On the investor side, corporate interest in Latin America's largest economy has risen steadily, as reflected in rising membership in the American Chamber of Commerce in Sao Paulo. **********"We have a flourishing economy," the President, a former sociology professor and politician from Sao Paulo, said in an interview last week in Brasilia, the capital. "Inflation has fallen to 1.5 percent a month." **********This year Brazilian diplomats expect to wrap up negotiations for a South American free-trade zone intended largely to provide new markets for Sao Paulo's booming industries. **********Brazil is also quietly expanding its role in regional politics, brokering cease-fires in the border fighting between Peru and Ecuador earlier this year, for example. **********Next month it sends 1,100 peacekeeping troops to Angola, in its largest overseas military mission since Brazilians fought alongside Americans in Italy in World War II. **********Although Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown visits the country regularly, the Clinton Administration's envoys to Brazil are generally low-level. By contrast, 10 British ministers have come here over the last year. **********But several longstanding irritants in relations with the United States have eased in recent years. Brazil dismantled its secret nuclear bomb program in the early 1990's, and it renegotiated its huge debt to private foreign banks last year. **********After 10 years of civilian government, tensions with the United States over military rule in Brazil have become a distant memory. On the first state visit accorded a Brazilian leader in decades, Mr. Cardoso will visit Washington as the leader of one of the world's largest democracies. **********But the President, who has served as a Foreign Minister and Finance Minister, will need strong support at home to make good on some of his business pledges. While he is hoping to amend Brazil's Constitution to open the economy to foreign oil, telephone and mining companies, for instance, resistance in Congress is high. **********Mr. Cardoso's five-party coalition technically constitutes a congressional majority, but he routinely loses vote after vote in Congress. Since he took office, lawmakers have voted a 12 percent cap on interest rates, approved a $3 billion bailout for large farmers and buried a bill intended to restructure Brazil's largely bankrupt social security system. **********Mindful of Mexico's recent economic collapse, some economists fear that lack of congressional support could endanger Mr. Cardoso's anti-inflation plan. **********Still, Mr. Cardoso takes comfort in recent public opinion polls, which give him approval ratings ranging from 40 percent to 64 percent. **********"Brazil is going to change, and the minority that I defeated at the polling booths is not going to block the change," he told a crowd of peasants in a speech last month. **********Known as a patient man who values the art of negotiation, Brazil's President seems unfazed by complaints of a slow start to his four-year term, which began on Jan. 1. **********"You have to set a goal, and then build your road to get there," he said. "You lose today. You win tomorrow. You have to have perseverance."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/02/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Silicon Graphics Account in Review
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/02/busin.body_text: **********Silicon Graphics Inc., the computer work station marketer, has placed its account in review after almost nine years at Poppe Tyson in Mountain View, Calif. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $12 million to $20 million. **********Harry Pforzheimer, a spokesman for Silicon Graphics in Mountain View, confirmed a report of the review this week in Adweek. He said the review was narrowed from 25 agencies to 7, which he identified as Poppe Tyson; Austin Associates and CKS Partners, both of San Jose, Calif.; Cole & Weber in Seattle, and three shops in San Francisco: Foote, Cone & Belding; Hal Riney & Partners, and Woolward & Partners. A decision is expected in mid-February.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/19/world.main_headline: U.S. Pressing Iraq to Release Two Americans
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/19/world.print_headline: U.S. Pressing Iraq to Release Two Americans
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/19/world.body_text: **********Relying mainly on foreign intermediaries to negotiate with Baghdad, American officials continued their efforts today to win the release of two Americans being held in Iraq. **********Secretary of Defense William J. Perry, who is in the Middle East on a weeklong diplomatic mission, said the two men were working for the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, which has a contract to maintain Kuwaiti aircraft. **********The Administration has asked the United Nations and Poland, which handles American interests in Iraq, to press President Saddam Hussein to release the Americans, who were seized Monday night just north of the Kuwait border. Washington has not had direct diplomatic relations since Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990. **********Some American officials say they fear that gaining the men's release could prove difficult because relations are so strained, especially after Washington persuaded the United Nations this week to maintain economic sanctions against Iraq. **********"We're still hoping for an expeditious resolution of this," said Sondra F. McCarty, a spokeswoman for the State Department. **********Mr. Perry, who was on his way to Saudi Arabia, said the Americans had been taken to Baghdad. "The report we get is that they are in good condition," he said. "I mean, they are not in any danger." **********[ In Baghdad, in the first official Iraqi comment on the two Americans, Vice President Taha Yassin Ramadan acknowledged their capture and said, "Nothing much will happen to them," The Associated Press reported. ] **********Kathy Daliberti, of Jacksonville, Fla., told The Florida Times-Union on Friday that her husband, David Daliberti, 41, is one of the captives. In an interview today, she identified the other as Bill Barloon, of Iowa. **********Talking about her husband, Mrs. Daliberti said, "It's just a terrible, terrible thing, and I am just about at my wit's end not knowing if he's all right and how they're treating him." **********Mrs. Daliberti said her husband was employed by Kay Industries of Chicago, an airline maintenance company. American officials said Kay apparently is a subcontractor of McDonnell Douglas. The Administration has emphasized that the men are not Government employees and were not working on a Government contract. **********Administration officials raised the question again today of how the men could have mistakenly entered Iraq, especially after Kuwait built a 16-foot-wide, 10-foot-deep trench last year along the 130-mile border. **********American officials said the Americans had been driving a white Jeep similar to United Nations vehicles in the area, which apparently made it easier for them to pass through an Iraqi border checkpoint. **********"As near as we can tell, it was a mistake, a blunder on their part," Secretary Perry said. "And the reason they got past the checkpoints was apparently they were mistaken for a U.N. vehicle. By the time they had realized their mistake they were in Iraq, and by that time the Iraqis realized they were not U.N. and arrested them."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/28/busin.main_headline: Lazard Freres Units Form New Partnership
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/28/busin.print_headline: Lazard Freres Units Form New Partnership
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/28/busin.body_text: **********The three Lazard Freres partnerships have banded together to form a new partnership, Lazard Capital Markets, to enhance their financing and trading operations in Europe and in emerging markets. **********Damon Mezzacappa, a senior partner and head of capital markets for Lazard Freres & Company in New York, has been named executive chairman of the new partnership. Jeremy Sillem, a general partner in the New York firm and managing director of Lazard Brothers & Company in London, will be responsible for its day-to-day operations as chief executive. **********The partnership will unite the capital markets efforts of the London and Paris firms: Lazard Brothers & Company and Lazard Freres & Cie. **********In a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Mezzacappa offered several reasons for creating the new partnership, including clients' increasing need to tap into a variety of capital sources and the globalization of the financial services business. **********"We've had very, very strong banking and advisory relationships in all three markets we serve," he said, "and while we've developed a financing and trading capability in New York, we haven't done enough of that in Europe." **********He also acknowledged a certain degree of opportunism. "Given the disruption in the industry, it is a good time to hire talented people, and we've begun that process," he said. **********Lazard Capital Markets has already hired Moray Wright from J. P. Morgan in London to become its senior trader.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/04/busin.main_headline: INGERSOLL-RAND BEGINS HOSTILE TENDER OFFER FOR CLARK
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/04/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; INGERSOLL-RAND BEGINS HOSTILE TENDER OFFER FOR CLARK
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/04/busin.body_text: **********After having its merger offer rebuffed, the Ingersoll-Rand began a hostile $1.34 billion tender offer for the Clark Equipment Company, a maker of construction machinery. The cash offer of $77 a share came less than a week after Ingersoll-Rand disclosed that Clark had rejected its bid of $75 to $77 a share. Clark said the company was not for sale and filed an antitrust suit to block the bid. Clark stock was unchanged yesterday at $82.50 in New York Stock Exchange trading. Clark said Ingersoll-Rand was offering less than its true worth.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/22/busin.main_headline: U.S. Is Resisting Any Pressures For a Quick Fix To Aid Dollar
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/22/busin.print_headline: U.S. Is Resisting Any Pressures For a Quick Fix To Aid Dollar
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/22/busin.body_text: **********The Clinton Administration and the Federal Reserve seem determined to resist any pressure that might come next week from other major industrial powers to move promptly to shore up the dollar, arguing that a quick rescue effort could be self-defeating. **********"There is nervousness and great concern about the declining dollar, but there is a sense that nothing can be done right now," an Administration official said. "It would not be fair to say the Administration does not care; it would be fair to say we do not have any great ideas." **********Top finance officials from around the world are already starting to gather in Washington for next week's semiannual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Central bankers and finance ministers from the Group of Seven industrial powers will also meet to discuss the international economic situation. **********Although the dollar has dropped 20 percent against the Japanese yen and 12 percent against the German mark since the beginning of the year, the American stock and bond markets have held up well. And there has been no major fallout in markets abroad. This absence of a crisis atmosphere relieves some of the pressure on the Administration to act quickly. **********The main tool for a quick fix is higher interest rates, a tool the Federal Reserve controls. At a time when people are hurrying to exchange hundreds of billions of dollars for yen and marks, higher interest rates in the United States might halt the dollar selloff. The higher rates would make American bonds and other interest-earning securities more profitable to own, encouraging people to buy them with their dollars rather than exchanging the dollars for yen or marks. But with the economy slowing, any rise in interest rates now could make a recession more likely. Fed officials have said that preserving the economy's health is a higher priority than strengthening the dollar. **********"At the present time, the policy is benign neglect, with one constraint: you don't want to allow the situation to accelerate," a senior Administration official said. He was referring to the risk that the falling dollar might result in plunges in stock and bond prices. **********In that case, the Federal Reserve would indeed be expected to raise interest rates, Administration officials said. The Fed in effect would step into a market crisis much as it did on the day after the 1987 stock market crash, when interest rates were pushed down sharply to make credit more available in a critical moment. **********This week the dollar showed signs of a modest recovery. It rose on Wednesday and Thursday, and fell slightly yesterday, to 82.71 yen and 1.3680 marks. Experts in foreign exchange markets said traders were holding back to await the outcome of the meeting of finance ministers and central bank presidents from the United States, Germany, Japan, France, Britain, Italy and Canada. **********Although a quick fix has been ruled out, Administration officials, who declined to be quoted by name out of concern that their remarks about dollar policy might roil the markets, speak of the possibility of a rate increase later this year. That might happen if the economy begins to revive again. The weakened dollar may itself be a source of stimulus, by making American exports less expensive and thus more sought after in Europe and Japan. **********Imports, however, would become more expensive, raising the danger of a higher inflation rate, after several years of mild inflation in the United States. "At some point, rising import prices bring a rise in the nation's general inflation rate," said Peter L. Bernstein, an economic consultant. "I don't know when that point comes, but it will." **********Rising inflation would undoubtedly prompt the Federal Reserve to raise rates, helping the dollar in the process. **********The dollar's value has been declining gradually against the mark and the yen since the early 1970's, when the Nixon Administration decided that the dollar would no longer have a fixed value and would float against other currencies. Even in the early 1980's, when the dollar was becoming stronger, making American exports less competitive, it never returned to its levels in the mid-70's. **********Various administrations have welcomed the decline as inevitable and healthy, since it reflected the rising output and growing economic strength of other nations and America's declining share of the world market. Only twice has an Administration struggled against a sharply falling dollar. The first time was in the late 70's when Jimmy Carter was President and the dollar lost 40 percent of its value against the yen in only two years. The second time is now. **********The late 1970's, however, offered a set of circumstances that made reversing the dollar's slide easier than it might be today. Inflation had become a severe problem and that gave the Federal Reserve an opportunity to push up rates far more than might be possible today. In the process, the interest rates on American bonds became much higher than the returns from owning German and Japanese securities. **********What's more, foreigners, particularly the Japanese, were far more willing to hold dollars and invest them in the United States than they are today. **********Because the dollar has become less attractive to foreigners, an increase in interest rates now, even a substantial one, seems less likely than in the 1970's to reverse the slide in the dollar. Largely for this reason, Administration officials are pushing longer-term policies for strengthening the dollar. They speak, for example, as they have for months, of Commerce Department promotions for American exports, to lower the trade deficit and thus reduce the flow of dollars abroad. **********And they talk particularly of the Administration's latest effort -- an effort that has been made for years -- to get the Japanese to spend more of their hoard of accumulated dollars on the purchase of American cars and auto parts, the biggest item in the huge United States trade deficit with Japan. **********"Prying open the auto market might not result in an immediate change in the deficit, but it would have a great psychological effect that would help the dollar," an Administration official said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/13/busin.main_headline: Amoco and McDonald's to Develop Sites
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/13/busin.print_headline: Amoco and McDonald's to Develop Sites
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/13/busin.body_text: **********After more than a year of experimenting, the McDonald's Corporation and the Amoco Corporation have concluded that consumers like one-stop fill-ups for their gas tanks and stomachs. **********The two companies today announced plans to develop retail sites that combine Amoco gas stations and convenience stores with McDonald's restaurants throughout most of the central, Mid-Atlantic and Southeastern United States. **********The alliance, which is similar to one McDonald's announced in August with the Chevron Corporation for the Pacific and Southwest states, leaves the Northeast as the only big region in which the fast-food giant has not chosen an oil company partner. **********Amoco, of Chicago, and McDonald's, of Oak Brook, Ill., plan to open up to 75 dual-service sites in the next year, in addition to the 12 now operating, and to add hundreds more in the years to come, according to Kathleen Latham, the Amoco executive managing the oil company's relations with McDonald's. **********Some sites will have the full McDonald's menu and others will have more limited offerings, but all are expected to have inside seating and drive-through service, the companies said. **********Opening outlets in service stations is part of the fast-food industry's race into nontraditional sites including schools, hospitals, stores like Wal-Mart and even airplanes. In addition to Amoco and Chevron, McDonald's has run test programs with Mobil, British Petroleum, Texaco and Shell.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/13/busin.main_headline: Patents; Entrepreneurs Find Pitfalls When Naming Their Products. The Name May Be Spoken For
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/13/busin.print_headline: Patents; Entrepreneurs Find Pitfalls When Naming Their Products. The Name May Be Spoken For
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/13/busin.body_text: **********ENTREPRENEURS who have flourished by developing multimedia technologies are finding new uses for copyright material. But some of them who have created computer games, personal software and CD-ROM's for markets that did not exist 10 years ago are also encountering pitfalls in dealing with electronic rights for books, photos, music and titles. And at least one independent CD-ROM developer is learning the hard way that having an original idea and sewing up the content rights is not enough; you still have to be careful what you call it. **********Irving Green runs Scanrom Publications from his house in Cedarhurst, L.I. The company is tiny, consisting of Mr. Green, his wife and his son, who wrote the programming for their CD-ROM of Judaica reference materials. But it has managed to attract the attention of a much larger software company: Microsoft. **********The Greens spent two years and $150,000 compiling Jewish history, religion and folklore texts, biographies and a cookbook. They hoped their disk would supplement rows of Judaica books in homes and libraries, so they called it "The First Electronic Jewish Bookshelf." **********The Greens were thrilled when they were invited to join a Microsoft-produced marketing brochure. But the second message from the huge software developer was troubling. **********"We have come across the enclosed catalogue listing for 'The First Electronic Jewish Bookshelf,' " said a letter from a Microsoft lawyer, William O. Ferron Jr. "We believe this use is likely to cause confusion with Microsoft's "Bookshelf" and "Bookshelf Series" trademarks, and so is an infringement of Microsoft's rights." **********Thus the Greens discovered that in the context of CD-ROM products, Microsoft has owned "bookshelf" since 1991, when it trademarked the term to cover its CD-ROM collection of reference books, Microsoft Bookshelf. Mr. Green says he did not bother to do a trademark search because it never occurred to him that anyone could own such a generic term. "There are certain words that belong to the people," he argued. **********But as tax authorities are fond of saying, ignorance of the law is no excuse. Thousands of generic words are trademarked. The Patent and Trademark Office grants marks for specific goods or services -- Microsoft, for example, owns the term "bookshelf" as applied to CD-ROM products. But a scuba diving company that wanted to call snorkel and fins "bookshelf" would probably not infringe the Microsoft mark. **********Unfortunately for Mr. Green, he is not in the diving business. And he says he does not have the money to change his disk's programming, packaging, inserts and advertising. **********Both Mr. Green and a Microsoft spokesman, Erin Carney, said last week that they hoped to settle the dispute amicably.  Extending The Trombone **********At some point in the 15th century, musicians discovered that a trumpet could be modified with sliding tubing to produce deeper musical tones, and the trombone was born. All brass instruments produce music by manipulating the air blown through their tubes, mostly with valves. The trombone was different, however, because it controlled air flow with a slide that elongated its tubing. **********About 400 years later, Brian Phillip Leonard took up the instrument in high school. Playing jazz with friends in Melbourne, Australia, he quickly discovered the trombone missed certain low notes. It needed longer tubing to hit those lower notes, and the slide was already as long as a musician's reach. **********"To create lower notes, you'd have to push the slide out so far it would just fall off the end," said Mr. Leonard, now a professor of mechanical engineering at the University of Akron. Using his knowledge of air flow dynamics and acoustics, he designed a trombone with tubing and valves added near the instrument's bell and won three patents for his inventions. **********"The trombone was a hobby, and I tried to combine it with my knowledge of fluid mechanics," Professor Leonard said. "The whole thing has to be worked out mathematically in terms of the length of the windpipe. That may have inhibited others, because most musicians don't have a knowledge of the theory of acoustics." **********When a trombone is in its closed position -- with the slide completely compacted -- it produces high notes. As the tube is lengthened by extending the slide, the air has to travel farther and so the notes become progressively lower. That is, until they run into the limits of a musician's reach. **********To fill a musical gap between the tenor range and pedal tones -- those low notes reminiscent of an organ -- without requiring difficult slide movements, the inventor added brass tubing to the trombone's bell section. The tubing is controlled by thumb- and finger-activated valves. **********In a standard B-flat tenor trombone, the tubing is 108 inches long, with a slide that extends about 22 inches. Professor Leonard's attachments add 138 1/2 inches, without lengthening the slide. Instead, when a musician wants to blow air through the attachments, he opens a valve with his thumb or middle finger. **********Professor Leonard's most recent invention, an attachment 20.4 inches long, puts notes the trombone already achieves in more convenient places along the slide. His first invention, a 63.7-inch attachment with two valves, lets the trombone hit a low B. A second invention, a 54.3-inch tube, fills the "tenor gap" by allowing a B-flat trombone to hit E flat, D, D flat, C and B. **********The rights to the patents belong to the University of Akron. Professor Leonard received patents 5,365,823 and 5,375,499. His third patent is to be issued this summer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/10/busin.body_text: **********The Mazda Motor Corporation said today that it would shut down four car-assembly lines next month and lay off 5,500 workers for as many as five days because of poor sales in Japan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/31/busin.main_headline: Stocks Post Modest Increases, but Dow Still Declines by 3.87
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/31/busin.print_headline: Stocks Post Modest Increases, but Dow Still Declines by 3.87
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/31/busin.body_text: **********Stocks posted modest gains yesterday after Time Warner Inc. offered to buy Turner Broadcasting System for $8.5 billion, touching off a rally in media shares. **********"It bodes well for stocks that even though the market is up 20 percent, companies are still willing to buy companies for stock," said Alan Bond, chief investment officer at Bond Procope Capital Management. "It says maybe media shares are still undervalued by the market." **********Still, losses in the shares of Alcoa, the Aluminum Company of America; the International Business Machines Corporation, and the International Paper Commpany caused the Dow Jones industrial average to slip 3.87, to 4,604.57. **********The broader Standard & Poor's 500 Index, meanwhile, climbed 0.92, to 560.92, as technology shares rebounded, and long-distance and drug stocks advanced, tempering losses in retail, oil and gold issues. **********Gains by many technology issues helped the Nasdaq Composite Index end a four-day losing streak, rising 8.97, to 1,012.61. **********The Russell 2000 Index of small companies recouped almost all yesterday's losses, gaining 1.76 to reach 303.26. The American Stock Exchange Market Value Index jumped 5.82, to a record 534.01, fueled largely by gains in Turner Broadcasting. **********Some 1,254 shares rose and 977 declined on the New York Stock Exchange. **********About 329.9 million shares changed hands, the heaviest trading since July 17, when 354.17 million shares traded. **********Time Warner's $35-a-share offer for Turner Broadcasting adds to a string of big merger agreements, including a move by the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Chemical Banking Corporation this week to create the largest United States bank and Walt Disney Company's purchase of Capital Cities/ABC Inc. at the end of last month. **********Time Warner's stock slipped 7/8, to 41 3/8. Turner Broadcasting class A shares surged 6 7/8, to 30 1/2 and the company's class B shares added 6 1/2 to reach 30 1/2. **********The proposed combination fueled speculation among analysts that consolidation within the media industry would continue. Liberty Media, a Tele-Communications Inc. spinoff, was up 2 1/8, to 26 7/8. Tele-Communications owns 21 percent of Turner stock. The Comcast Corporation jumped 11/16 , to 21 7/8 and the E. W. Scripps Company was up 5/8, at 33 3/8. **********And early today, the Chicago-based Tribune Company agreed to buy the television station KTTY-TV in San Diego from Citibank for $70.5 million. Tribune's shares were up 1/4, at 66 7/8. **********Shares of savings and loans also added to the advance after a Federal appeals court handed savings and loans what may be a multibillion-dollar victory against the United States Government. The court said savings institutions that acquired failing savings and loans during much of the 1980's were entitled to damages because Congress and Federal regulators withdrew a promised regulatory break after passing the 1989 S.&L.-bailout bill. **********Shares of Glendale Federal Bank, which filed one of the legal claims against the Government, rose 1 7/8, to 16 5/8. The Golden West Financial Corporation jumped 1 1/4, to 46 7/8; Washington Mutual Inc. rallied 1 1/8, to 25 1/2, and Coast Savings Financial added 3 1/4 to reach 27. **********Many technology stocks reversed losing streaks that began four days ago amid concern the Microsoft Corporation's new computer operating system, Windows 95, would disappoint investors. **********The group began to recoup losses late yesterday after Microsoft reported that it sold one million copies of Windows 95 in North America alone the first four days it was on sale. Microsoft's stock rose 1 3/8, to 93 1/4. The shares have fallen 14.4 percent from their high of 109 on July 17. The Intel Corporation shares gained 1 1/2 to reach 60 3/8, and Texas Instruments Inc. climbed 2, to 74. **********Shares of Adobe Systems Inc. defied the advance. Analysts said the software maker may not meet earnings forecasts for its fiscal third quarter. The stock tumbled 8.8 percent, to 49 1/2, bringing its five-day decline to 20.5 percent. **********The AT&T Corporation rose 1 3/8, to 56 5/8, a day after it announced it had won a $10 million contract from the American Red Cross.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/24/busin.main_headline: Relief for Now at Times Mirror Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/24/busin.print_headline: Relief for Now at Times Mirror Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/24/busin.body_text: **********A sigh of relief spread through Times Mirror Magazines last week with the announcement that the parent company's drastic cost-cutting program would not include selling the magazine division. The Times Mirror Company closed New York Newsday on July 16 as part of a plan to cut 1,750 jobs at its newspapers, including 150 at The Los Angeles Times. **********But it is unclear if the magazines have really been spared or if Mark H. Willes, Times Mirror's new chief executive, will eventually decide to sell them as a group or individually. **********Times Mirror Magazines, with 10 publications, is one of the largest publishers of outdoor leisure magazines. They range from the 100-year-old Field & Stream, which has a circulation of 2 million, and Outdoor Life, with 1.5 million, to smaller niche magazines like Yachting, with 133,000, and the newest acquisition, Transworld Snowboarding, with 92,000. A new magazine, Snowboard Life, is planned for October. **********Francis P. Pandolfi, president and chief executive of the magazine group, said the division was profitable, but declined to give figures. **********Last week Times Mirror Magazines introduced a strict profit improvement program. An ambitious but costly multimedia group was eliminated and its projects taken over by individual publications. Popular Science, for instance, is planning a series of CD-ROM's called Popular Science for Kids and Skiing magazine hopes to go on line by Labor Day. **********"We've got to do better" in terms of profitability, Mr. Pandolfi said. "We do have a goal, but I just can't discuss numbers with you." **********Many of the publications are referred to as mature, in the sense that they may have reached their circulation peaks. They are known in the industry as "hook and bullet" magazines for serious sportsmen, as opposed to the more "life style" sporting magazines that appeal to younger readers. Still, circulations are generally stable and revenues are up. **********And the outdoor category is expected to grow. "I would think the market for buyers is pretty good" if the magazines go on sale, said Leo E. Scullin, a media consultant. "Mature doesn't mean over the hill. And frankly some of these magazines can be considered annuities -- just cashing in your chips year after year." **********Mr. Pandolfi said subscriptions and newsstand prices would probably be raised next year. And some publications may move from Lower Park Avenue in Manhattan to less expensive locations in other states. **********The magazines belong to the company's consumer media group, which also includes Harry N. Abrams, the book publisher, and the just-closed multimedia division. In 1994 the consumer media group reported a 6.9 percent increase in revenue, to $289.9 million, but its operating loss deepened to $4.9 million from $3.8 million in 1993. This year, revenue through June was $142 million, compared with $132 million last year, and the group's operating loss has reached $12 million, up from $4.6 million in the comparable period last year. **********Mr. Pandolfi said he was not about to change his overall vision of the company as a force for environmental change. Since 1991, when he started the Partnership for Environmental Education, 175 advertisers have included an environmental message of 15 words or more in their ads and Times Mirror has donated 2.5 percent of the revenue from these ads to environmental causes. Mr. Pandolfi said the total contribution was almost $400,000. **********The company also sponsored the Smithsonian's Ocean Planet exhibit, which will go on tour next year. And last October volunteers were invited to sites in Nevada, Kentucky and California where, under the direction of the Bureau of Land Management, they made trails, constructed wildlife viewing areas for handicapped people and built information kiosks. **********"I was at the site at Cache Creek in Northern California, where it was 104 degrees, and at the end of the day the manager told me that she had had 10 years of work done in that one day," Mr. Pandolfi said. **********This connection to the environment attracts many readers. But the magazines still suffer from the perception that they are staid publications for older readers. **********"Part of their problem is that they are not perceived as hot and it would take good P.R. to overcome it," Martin S. Walker, a magazine consultant said. "Hunting and fishing books do not fly with 25-year-old media buyers in New York."
