https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/07/busin.main_headline: SEAGRAM WILL BUY 80% OF BIG STUDIO FROM MATSUSHITA
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/07/busin.print_headline: SEAGRAM HEADS FOR HOLLYWOOD; SEAGRAM WILL BUY 80% OF BIG STUDIO FROM MATSUSHITA
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/07/busin.body_text: **********Seagram has agreed to pay $7 billion to buy 80 percent of the movie and entertainment company MCA Inc. from the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, people close to the deal said yesterday. **********Matsushita acquired MCA in 1990, during the heady days of Japanese investment in the United States, but has agreed to cede control after failing to master the vagaries of Hollywood and a disgruntled American management team. **********The money for the acquisition will come from the sale by Seagram of nearly all its 25 percent stake in Du Pont for $8.8 billion in cash and securities. That transaction was announced last night.  [ Page D3. ] **********Whether Seagram can get better results than Matsushita from MCA remains an open question, because the acquisition will mark such a radical departure from Seagram's core spirit and beverage business. **********The president of Seagram, Edgar Bronfman Jr., declined to comment last night, apparently because the deal had not been signed. But top executives of MCA, who are widely expected to leave the company, had already been told that the company was changing hands. **********"I feel sad because I have been around here for 59 years," said Lew Wasserman, the 82-year-old chairman of MCA, who has run the company for decades. "But life goes on." **********The change of owners and managers for MCA could have broad ramifications in Hollywood. The company is best known for blockbuster movies by Steven Spielberg like "E.T.," "Jurassic Park" and "Schindler's List" and music produced on the Geffen Records label. **********But lately MCA has lost momentum and now has only tenuous ties to Mr. Spielberg and the record executive David Geffen, which are based primarily on their personal relationships with Mr. Wasserman and the president of MCA, Sidney J. Sheinberg. **********For Matsushita, which paid $6.6 billion for MCA, scaling back to only a minority stake in MCA could suggest a model for retrenchment to another Japanese giant, the Sony Corporation. Sony has lost billions of dollars on Columbia Pictures Industries, the Hollywood studio it acquired in 1989, and has been considering ways to reduce that investment. **********But if Sony stays the course, Matsushita could be embarrassed, some financial analysts in Japan said. "It's an admission of defeat," said Joseph A. Osha, technology analyst at Smith New Court (Japan) Ltd. "But I think it's smart to admit defeat because there's no way they are ever going to be able to integrate this business." **********Though Seagram has no experience in running an entertainment company, doing so has been a dream long nurtured by the Bronfmans, the Canadian family that founded Seagram more than 70 years ago and still controls it. **********The chairman of Seagram, Edgar M. Bronfman, who is 65, was a big shareholder and chairman of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in the late 1960's, before selling his stake to the investor Kirk Kerkorian. **********And the current thrust into entertainment has been championed by the younger Mr. Bronfman, the president of Seagram, who is 39. He spent several years as a screenplay reader and in 1993 was responsible for the acquisition by Seagram of 15 percent of Time Warner Inc. **********Some analysts said yesterday that Seagram was paying too high a price for its stake in MCA, given the recent performance of MCA. But they said the bigger issue was who would run the entertainment company, which includes the Universal Pictures studio, the Universal Television programming unit, record labels, theme parks and a book company. **********Asked yesterday if there was a chance that he would stay at MCA, Mr. Wasserman, the chairman, said: "I have no idea. It's free enterprise. If they buy it and pay for it, they can do what they want to." **********Mr. Wasserman said the elder Mr. Bronfman telephoned him late Wednesday night to tell him about the deal. Mr. Bronfman, he said, explained that he had not called sooner because he was not free to do so, apparently alluding to the secret nature of the talks with Matsushita, which were conducted over several weeks and appeared to be winding down yesterday in Manhattan. **********Mr. Sheinberg, who is 60, indicated that he, too, was uncertain about his future. The news of the MCA sale is "one of those things that is anti-climactic," he said yesterday, referring to the reports of the negotiations that began appearing last week. **********The talks between Matsushita and Seagram intensified last weekend, and since then involved round-the-clock discussions -- including telephone conversations between the younger Mr. Bronfman and the president of Matsushita, Yoichi Morishita, in Osaka, Japan, according to people familiar with the talks. **********It is unclear what type of role Mr. Bronfman sees for himself at MCA. Other men who have bought control of studios -- including Sumner M. Redstone of Viacom, who acquired Paramount, and Rupert Murdoch of the News Corporation, who bought 20th Century Fox -- have taken active roles in the companies. **********Those who know Mr. Bronfman say he may bring in the powerful Hollywood agent Michael Ovitz to run the studio. Mr. Ovitz, who was the broker in the acquisition of MCA by Matsushita in 1990, is thought to have had no formal role in the Seagram-MCA deal. But he is a close friend of Mr. Bronfman's and, informally, his business adviser. **********If Mr. Ovitz joins MCA, the move is likely to raise questions about whether the company will have a relationship with Dreamworks SKG, the new entertainment company formed by Mr. Spielberg, Mr. Geffen and the former Disney executive, Jeffrey Katzenberg. Though Dreamworks had been expected to distribute its movies through MCA under Mr. Wasserman and Mr. Sheinberg, such an arrangement with Mr. Ovitz could be another matter. **********Even though Mr. Ovitz has long been Mr. Spielberg's agent, industry executives said yesterday that it might be difficult for any of the Dreamworks team to suddenly begin reporting to Mr. Ovitz, a man who they have long considered to be their professional equal. And Mr. Geffen and Mr. Ovitz reportedly have a chilly professional relationship. **********No matter who manages MCA, Seagram will be in control of one of Hollywood's legendary film companies. Founded in 1923 as the Music Corporation of America by the band leader Jules Stein, the company's initial business was booking engagements for bands. By the time Mr. Wasserman joined the company in 1936, at age 22, it was already expanding into a talent agency. And soon after Mr. Wasserman became president in 1946, he led the company into television production. **********The Justice Department forced MCA out of the talent agency business in 1962, because its roles as both a producer of television programs and an agent for actors were seen as too strong a consolidation of power.  But by then Mr. Wasserman had already begun to lead MCA into the movie business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/08/busin.main_headline: Benefits Given Coors Workers' Gay Partners
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/08/busin.print_headline: Benefits Given Coors Workers' Gay Partners
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/08/busin.body_text: **********The Coors Brewing Company, considered by many a bedrock of conservative views, has decided to offer full benefits to employees' unmarried domestic partners, including homosexual companions. **********The proposal to extend such benefits was made by a group of Coors employees known as the Lesbian and Gay Resource Group, or Lager. The company's board approved the change, by unanimous vote, on May 11. The change was disclosed to Coors employees on June 21. **********The change was the latest in a series at Coors, which in the past had been boycotted by minorities over its employee relations and support of conservative causes through foundations created with the Coors fortune. **********Coors joins dozens of other companies nationwide that offer full benefits to unmarried partners, including Apple Computer, the Xerox Corporation and Levi-Strauss. **********In addition to recognizing the lesbian and gay employee association, Coors offers sensitivity training on minority issues and has a nondiscrimination clause to protect gay employees. **********The company's new policy allows unmarried, live-in partners of company employees to be added to health and life insurance policies, pensions and other benefits. **********The Coors move was hailed by gay-rights advocates. **********"We absolutely applaud the victory Lager has won, and think it is a great step forward for Coors Brewery employees," said Kerry Lobel, deputy director of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force in Washington. "We hope other employers will follow suit." **********"However, we are still concerned about the relationship between the Coors Brewing Company the Coors Family Foundation and members of the Coors family who fund social policies that are not in the interests of gays and lesbians in this country." **********Among other organizations the Coors Foundation and Coors family members have contributed to, Ms. Lobel said, is the Heritage Foundation, the conservative Washington organization she contends is an advocate of anti-gay policies. **********Joe Fuentes, a Coors spokesman, said there was no connection between the company's social policies and those supported by the Coors Foundation or by members of the Coors family.

Best now rates Prudential as "A", the third highest of 15 letter grades, down from A+, the second-highest rating. The Standard & Poor's Corporation, another rating firm, cut the rating of Prudential twice last year, to AA- from AA+, and retains a negative outlook for the company. **********Despite the cuts, A. M. Best and Standard & Poor's note that Prudential remains a strong company with $9.5 billion of capital. Analysts warn, though, that the company's sales agents may have a harder time competing with other insurers with higher ratings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/31/busin.main_headline: Growth Revised Upward, but It Was Still Weak
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/31/busin.print_headline: Growth Revised Upward, but It Was Still Weak
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/31/busin.body_text: **********The economy grew at a somewhat faster clip in the second quarter than originally estimated, the Government said yesterday, but the rate of expansion was still the weakest in nearly four years. **********For the April-June period, the Commerce Department said gross domestic product, which measures all goods and services, grew at an annual rate of 1.1 percent on an inflation-adjusted basis, more than double the rate of a half of 1 percent reported a month ago, when a preliminary estimate of second quarter growth was released. **********The slightly faster rate of growth was largely a result of upward revisions in consumer spending and a rise in farm inventory investment. But the change did little to alter opinions among private analysts about the economy's prospects for the balance of the year. **********"The entire revision was in two categories, consumption and farm inventories, which alone was responsible for about 40 percent of the overall increase in gross domestic product," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities Inc. "But being on a trading floor in New York, I can't get excited about farm inventories." **********After slowing sharply during the first six months from an unsustainably rapid pace in the second half of 1994, most analysts still expect the economy to rebound to the rate of growth of 2 to 2.5 percent that is favored by the Federal Reserve. In the first three months of the year, the economy grew at a 2.7 percent annual rate, down from the more than 4 percent average rate of growth recorded for the last six months of 1994. **********"On the margin, the economy wasn't as weak as we thought in the second quarter, and this bodes better for the second half," said Paul Mastroddi, a managing director at J. P. Morgan Inc. **********The revised report contained "more good news than bad news," said Donald Ratajczak, director of the economic forecasting project at Georgia State University. "Capital spending is still strong, exports are still good and there are no inflationary concerns." **********Worries about inflation were the primary force behind the seven increases in short-term interest rates engineered by the Federal Reserve over a 12-month period beginning Feb. 4, 1994. **********The absence of inflationary pressures was prominently mentioned when the Fed reversed its previous course in early July, pushing short-term rates down by a quarter of a percentage point. **********Yesterday's report provides further evidence that inflation remains in check. **********"The economy looks like it is headed to a 2 percent to 3 percent growth path," said Allen Sinai, chief global economist at Lehman Brothers, "and that is exactly where the Fed wants it." **********As measured by the gross domestic product deflator, the prices of goods and services rose 1.6 percent during the second quarter, slightly higher than the 1.3 percent rate reported in July, but less than the 2.2 percent rate recorded in the first quarter. **********The fixed-weight price index for domestic purchases, which in contrast to the deflator does not reflect the changing composition of output, rose at a 2.8 percent rate, up slightly from the 2.7 percent rate of increase that was originally reported. **********The Commerce Department will make its final revision to its second-quarter G.D.P. report at the end of September. **********The department also said that using a new method of calculating growth that it is phasing in this year, G.D.P. expanded five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, and did not decline by two-tenths of 1 percent, as first reported. The new method will formally replace the older system at the end of 1995 and is designed to measure price changes more accurately. **********Analysts cited improving home sale numbers, which should lead to increased sales of consumer durable items, strong capital spending and a likely improvement in the nation's trade accounts as reasons they expect growth to pick up. **********Mr. Ratajczak, who projected that the economy was growing at a 2 percent annual rate in the third quarter, said that despite sluggish auto and back-to-school sales, consumers almost certainly are spending more money this quarter than they did in the previous three months. **********"We know they are spending more, if not on autos, then on utilities, because of the heat, which affects anyone from the Mississippi Valley to the East," he said. **********Increased spending on utilities could well cut further into the personal savings rate, which fell significantly in the second quarter from the first. **********Yesterday, the Commerce Department said the personal savings rate in the second quarter was 4 percent, not 4.1 percent, as originally reported. In the first quarter, the savings rate was 5.1 percent. **********"The heat will boost service consumption in July and August," Mr. Fine said, "but I don't know if consumer spending will remain strong. We do know the third and fourth quarters will be better than the second. Growth in the second half should be characterized as moderate, not strong. And it will not engender increased inflationary pressures."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/10/busin.main_headline: Making It Harder For Investors to Sue
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/10/busin.print_headline: INVESTING IT; Making It Harder For Investors to Sue
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/10/busin.body_text: **********NOW that Congress is back at work after the summer recess, it faces the task of crafting, out of rival House and Senate proposals, a single bill that would change the rules governing how and when American investors can sue companies for securities fraud. **********The competing proposals, sponsored by the Republicans who control Congress, both aim to protect companies from ill-founded investor lawsuits. And, despite differences in the fine print, both would make it significantly harder for investors to sue. **********Not surprisingly, the bills are supported by business leaders, accountants and underwriters. And they are opposed equally vehemently by consumer groups and Federal and state securities regulators. **********So far, the debate on the issue has been dominated by caricature. Congressional critics have vilified lawyers who file securities class-action cases as fee-hungry extortionists who do nothing to help investors. Corporate executives dismiss the plaintiffs in those suits as cynical opportunists who buy stock only to gain suing rights. Class-action lawyers condemn their corporate critics as greedy hucksters seeking a license to steal. **********But beyond these strident stereotypes are executives, plaintiffs and lawyers who agreed to discuss their experiences in the trenches of securities-fraud law. **********There are executives like John G. Adler of Milpitas, Calif., whose consistently profitable company was sued when one quarter's revenues fell just 15 percent below Wall Street forecasts. There are plaintiffs like Kenwood and Helena Perkins of San Marcos, Calif., securities-fraud victims who recovered some desperately needed money through a class-action suit. And there are class-action lawyers like Howard B. Sirota of Manhattan, who condemns those who file frivolous suits but fears that pending proposals will prevent him from fighting even worthy battles. **********Together, they provide a far richer and less distorted picture of the securities-fraud terrain and of the potential consequences of the efforts to reform it. And they suggest that while change is needed to rein in unfair and costly abuses, the bills may unintentionally leave many wronged investors without hope of justice. **********"I've been frivolously sued, too," said Anthony C. Lami, a pizza parlor owner in Sandy, Utah, who joined a class-action suit after he lost more than $400,000 of his investment in Media Vision, whose stock collapsed after the company retracted past financial statements. "I can see that for a company like Apple, say, whose stock has gone from $70 a share to $20 a share several times in its life, it may be cheaper to pay a settlement than to fight a lawsuit -- and that's wrong to me. But if the new legislation prevents lawyers from taking on a case like mine, that's wrong the other way." **********Though the Senate proposal is considered somewhat more moderate, both would raise the burden of proof for plaintiffs, protect companies from lawsuits based on "forward looking" earnings statements and encourage judges to force the losing party to pay the winner's legal bills if the judge believes the loser's case was not justified. **********Both would also limit a guilty defendant's financial liability to some "proportionate share" of the blame, repealing the current "joint and several liability" doctrine under which any guilty defendant may be assessed for the full damage award if other guilty parties cannot pay. **********And to the dismay of consumer advocates, neither bill addresses Federal regulators' request that Congress remedy gaps in current securities laws caused by Supreme Court decisions curtailing the statute of limitations on fraud claims and restricting claims made against "aiders and abettors" of fraud. **********Before any bill can be sent to the White House, a congressional conference committee must resolve differences between the two bills in ways that have sufficient support in both chambers to overcome a possible Presidential veto. Though President Clinton has not publicly stated his position on the bills, officials in the Administration have indicated that, unless the loser-pays provisions are removed by the conference committee, he could well decide to veto the final bill.  The Perkinses A Nest Egg Recovered **********Before becoming the victims of a securities fraud in the mid-1980's, Kenwood and Helena Perkins were living in the upscale San Diego community of Rancho Bernardo and looking forward to a comfortably secure retirement. **********But like hundreds of other Californians -- doctors, dentists, professional athletes -- Mr. Perkins had entrusted his finances to a persuasive entrepreneur named Harry Stern, the founder of a public conglomerate called Technical Equities Corporation. Mr. Perkins had worked briefly as a senior executive of Mr. Stern's company in the late 1960's, and years later turned to him for guidance. **********"I was traveling a lot overseas for my job and I really didn't have the time to look after my finances," Mr. Perkins recalled. "So I made the serious mistake of letting an individual manage my money." **********At the time, Technical Equities was a favored client of Security Pacific Bank, whose advertisements once boasted of its role in financing the company's robust growth. **********The corporate audits were done by a major accounting firm and its investment bankers were well-known brokerage firms. **********But in February 1986, Technical Equities collapsed in what some commentators called the largest financial scandal in California's history. In July 1988, Mr. Stern agreed to plead guilty to criminal fraud charges stemming from the maze of Ponzi-like transactions he conducted through the company. **********The Perkinses were devastated. "We seriously considered personal bankruptcy," Mrs. Perkins said. "I had fears of going on welfare." **********Instead, Mr. Perkins -- despite health problems he blames on the stress of their situation -- went back to work at age 65. The couple sold their home and moved to a trailer park in San Marcos, Calif. **********And they joined a class-action lawsuit being directed by Alan R. Plutzik, now with the firm of Farrow, Bramson, Baskin & Plutzik, in Walnut Creek, Calif. **********"I'm not about to defend the entire legal fraternity," Mr. Perkins said softly. "But in this case, they were a real bright light in a very dark situation." **********The lawsuit by Mr. Plutzik's team, one of dozens filed in the scandal, claimed damages of $12.5 million plus interest and ultimately was able to recover $13 million, the lawyer said. After legal fees, Mr. Perkins recovered about 60 percent of his losses. **********That recovery would have been unlikely if lawyers had not been able to seek full damages from the company's bankers, auditors and investment bankers, Mr. Plutzik said. **********"Joint and several liability was critical here," he explained. "If that had not in place, the potential recovery in the case would have been drastically reduced." **********And if the current "loser pays" proposals had been in effect, he added, "I would have had to caution the Perkinses that they might have ended up having to pay a share of the defendants' legal fees, which were utterly huge." Mr. Perkins, now 76, said he certainly would not have taken on that risk. **********As it turned out, the money from the lawsuit is what has enabled the couple to live in reasonable comfort. "We're still living in the mobile home park," Mr. Perkins said, "but our future is reasonably secure, and it would not have been without that extra money." Anthony C. Lami  Anxious, Then Angry **********Tony Lami, who is 39, calls himself a careful investor. Before he bought stock in Media Vision, which made multimedia computer products, he made sure to study the growing multimedia market and monitored Media Vision's sales by reading annual reports and Wall Street research. **********Impressed by the company's red-hot sales, he accumulated 12,000 shares by early spring 1994, at prices ranging from $31 to $46 a share. His outlay was approximately $450,000 -- a substantial sum for a man who, after managing restaurants for others, was setting up his own pizza parlor. **********"Not for one minute did it occur to me that those sales numbers were not real," he said. **********But in late March 1994, Media Vision announced it expected a large loss in the first quarter of the year; then, in April, it said it had actually incurred a large loss in 1993, not a profit. As the company's stock sank, Mr. Lami was sick with worry. **********"It takes a lot to admit that this is really happening to you -- that it is not a dream," he said. "This is not an easy business we're in. My wife and I work seven days a week, evenings, weekends. And this was all our money, everything we had worked for through seven restaurants." **********New fears surfaced as the stock fell below $20 a share. The couple was adopting a baby daughter, but the adoption was not yet final, and he was afraid his deteriorating finances would derail the process. **********By the time the stock had reached $11 a share, he said, his anxiety was so severe that he found himself "running around the block in my suit. It seemed that if I was running, it would be O.K., but if I stopped, I felt I would explode." **********Finally, with the stock at $9.75, he sold his entire stake in April to raise money to pay his taxes. "It was a godsend, in a way," he recalled. "The stock ultimately went to zero." **********In July 1994, Media Vision filed for bankruptcy. To settle its debts and emerge from court protection, it awarded new stock to its creditors, thus rendering its prior shares worthless. **********"I felt I'd been lied to," Mr. Lami said. On his own, he found a class-action lawyer, George S. Trevor at the firm of Gold Bennett & Cera in San Francisco, and joined one of the dozens of lawsuits filed against Media Vision, its accountants and its underwriters. **********Mr. Lami understands that the accountants and underwriters resent being seen as "the deep pockets" in the case. **********"But I counted on them to go in and check on this company, and if they didn't do their job properly, that is their responsibility," he explained. "After all, if somebody slips and falls in my restaurant because I haven't cleaned my floor carefully, that is my responsibility, isn't it?" **********As the legal fight creeps forward, a Federal judge has dismissed as too vague the allegations against one accounting firm and the company's underwriters, giving the plaintiffs 90 days to file more specific charges. The case still stands against the company's founder, several senior officers, and another accounting firm. All defendants deny they played any role in Media Vision's collapse. **********"It is not unusual for plaintiffs' counsel to cast around for deep pockets in a case like this," said Jared Kopel, a partner in the firm of Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati in Palo Alto, Calif. **********He is the lawyer for the underwriters Montgomery Securities and Cowan & Company. "But there is no evidence that the underwriters knew of, or should have known of, of any evidence that the company was in trouble." **********Mr. Trevor said the plaintiffs' cases would not be worth pursuing if proposed limits on "joint and several liability" were enacted. "You could go through three or four years of litigation, prove all your points, get a successful verdict against people who were found to be liable for damages -- and still not get any of your damages back," he said. John Adler  Insult Added To Injury **********John G. Adler came to the United States from his native Hungary in 1956, a nearly penniless 19-year-old "running from the Russians." With a scholarship, he earned an engineering degree in 1960. After 20 years with I.B.M. in upstate New York, he gravitated to Silicon Valley. In 1985, he became president of Adaptec, a young computer parts manufacturer in Milpitas, Calif. **********By late 1990, Mr. Adler had added the titles of chairman and chief executive and Adaptec's revenues exceeded $100 million. After lean earnings in 1989, both Mr. Adler and Wall Street analysts expected a strong rebound. **********Then, in mid-November of that year, Mr. Adler learned that various sales glitches would cause fourth-quarter revenues to be about 15 percent lower than Wall Street expected. It seemed minor -- the quarter and the year would still be solidly profitable -- but Mr. Adler decided to hold a conference call to alert the handful of analysts who followed his company. **********After the stock market closed on Monday, Dec. 10, 1990, Mr. Adler and two senior executives made the conference call. When the stock market opened on Tuesday morning, Dec. 11, Adaptec's stock fell more than 30 percent in response to the revised forecasts. By Friday, the first of seven lawsuits against Adaptec had been filed in Federal court in San Jose. **********"Up to this point, I'd paid zero attention to these frivolous suits," Mr. Adler said. **********Company lawyers tried but failed to get the case dismissed. For six months, photocopiers were wheeled from department to department as employees gathered documents sought by plaintiffs' lawyers. Legal expenses grew. **********Added to the injury of lost time and money was the insult. "The suit alleged we were a badly managed company on the verge of collapse," Mr. Adler fumed. "Yet we had a balance sheet with almost no debt and lots of cash, and we were profitable." **********The maneuvers cost the company $2 million in fees and ultimately led to settlement talks. "I was not at all inclined to settle," Mr. Adler said. "I was still on my soapbox." But he was advised that a trial could cost the company's shareholders far more than the $4.3 million settlement the lawyers had negotiated. **********So he settled -- protesting that "this was legalized extortion" and refusing to shake the opposing lawyer's hand when the talks ended. He also refused to sign any settlement agreement that declared the suit had been justified or that barred him from discussing the settlement, he said. **********William S. Lerach, whose San Diego law firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, led the the plaintiffs' case against Adaptec, remains critical of Mr. Adler for only notifying a few analysts of the revenue shortfall instead of making a public announcement to all investors. "The case was absolutely justified," Mr. Lerach said. "I don't have any question about it." **********Mr. Adler, no longer Adaptec's chief executive but still its chairman, is a vocal supporter of the Senate bill, which he sees as "much more moderate" than the House bill. But he said he has no interest in shifting legal fees onto the losers, and he suspects that provisions putting the biggest investors in charge of lawsuits would mean that some valid cases would not be pursued. **********"No bill is perfect," he said. "The system is out of control, and whenever you think you're going to fix it, you may have broken something in the process. But that doesn't argue for preserving the status quo." **********Besides, he added, if these proposals push the pendulum too far, "there will be a backlash and another tweak will come to bring us back to the middle." **********But if Mr. Adler is uncertain of what will happen if some version of the two pending bills becomes law, he is certain of what will happen if nothing changes. "I just know that somewhere along the way, we're going to miss the numbers again. It's inevitable," he said. "And I'm going to get sued and go through the same thing again." Corporate Defendants  Fighting Can Pay Off **********Securities class-action lawyers joke that every company they sue condemns the action as frivolous -- even when Federal prosecutors are at the door. And the corporate habit of settling cases instead of fighting them before a judge or jury can make even specious fraud claims look valid. **********But there are cases in which courts have found class-action cases to be wanting. **********For example, in June 1994, after four years of preparation and 21 days of trial, Information Resources of Chicago was cleared of class-action fraud charges filed after the company fell far short of its 1989 profit forecasts. **********A month ago, on Aug. 16, an appellate court upheld the jury's findings that the company's forecasts were based on reasonable assumptions, and that no fraud was involved in its accounting practices. **********When the verdict was reached, James G. Andress, the company's chief executive, said he hoped it would "encourage others to fight these actions." **********But his company was sued again just months before the courtroom victory -- and later quietly settled out of court for $12.5 million. The company would not comment on either case. **********T. J. Rodgers, the chief executive of Cypress Semiconductor Corporation in San Jose, Calif., fought for more than three years against a class-action case accusing his company of making deliberately misleading earnings projections in late 1991 and early 1992. **********In June, a Federal judge granted the company's motion for summary judgment, ruling that "no reasonable jury could find that any of Cypress's statements were false or misleading." Howard Sirota  Is It Time To Change Sides? **********Since 1987, Howard Sirota, has specialized in filing securities class-action lawsuits. But do not ask him to defend those who file quick-draw cases whenever corporate earnings miss their mark. He is furious at the impact that such suits have had on his business. **********"My so-called colleagues have accused thousands of innocent executives of securities fraud and it's created this terrible backlash," he complained. "We are having a harder and harder time convincing judges that a case is an actual fraud because too many people have cried 'fraud' for every earnings disappointment." **********Unlike the image of class-action lawyers drawn in Congressional debate, Mr. Sirota, who is 46, does not commute between a palatial estate and an office where paralegals churn out boilerplate fraud claims at the push of a computer button. **********He and his wife, Rachell, work together in a four-person firm -- Sirota & Sirota -- in a modest office in midtown Manhattan. The couple, their daughters, his in-laws, and several pets all live in the same house in a beachfront community in Queens. **********Mr. Sirota's class-action credentials include successful cases against the Crazy Eddie retail chain and the Sahlen & Associates security-guard empire, both subsequently the targets of Federal criminal fraud convictions. He boasts of recovering more than $100 million for plaintiffs over the years. **********But now, Mr. Sirota is turning down cases he might once have accepted, he said, because the public vilification of class-action lawyers has made judges more hostile toward such cases. **********"I'm raising my standards," he explained. "In the two recent cases I turned down, I was convinced there was securities fraud, but I'm going to leave them to lawyers more aggressive than I am." **********"I'm filing cases where I'm convinced there is actual fraud and then I'm trying to figure out how to collect," he said. "But the trend is definitely negative. The proposals being considered now are designed to get at these frivolous suits, but they have the effect of making it riskier and possibly disastrous for me to try to bring my fraud cases." **********The limited liability of accountants and underwriters under the current bills is worrisome, he said, because truly fraudulent companies are the most likely to have collapsed before any damages can be collected. But he is most concerned about proposals encouraging judges to charge the losers for the winner's legal costs. **********"If they adopt 'loser pays,' I quit," he said. "I'll go back to representing the corporate defendants." **********And if other class-action lawyers follow suit and refuse to handle valid investor complaints? "Look, this is not 'Wall Street Legal Services' I'm running here," Mr. Sirota said. **********"Society used to encourage these lawsuits as a way of policing the system. Now society is saying that filing a securities class action is akin to molesting a child. Fine -- if the Congress is saying 'the public be damned,' I'll represent the crooks."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/30/busin.main_headline: L'Oreal to Pay $1.4 Million in Boycott
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/30/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; L'Oreal to Pay $1.4 Million in Boycott
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/30/busin.body_text: **********L'Oreal S.A., the world's largest beauty and fragrance company, agreed today to pay $1.4 million to settle a long-running investigation into charges that it violated American laws against cooperating with the Arab economic boycott of Israel. **********The settlement is the second largest in the 17-year history of the American anti-boycott law, said John Despres, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Export Enforcement. "The size of this, the magnitude of the violations, is reflected by the size of the payments being made," Mr. Despres said at a news conference. **********Stanley J. Marcuss, L'Oreal's outside lawyer, said the company denied any wrongdoing but was settling the case anyway. "L'Oreal does not want to obscure the fundamental fact that it is opposed to the boycott and is a major participant in the Israel economy," he said. **********It is against the law for companies in the United States to supply information that will help Arab countries enforce the boycott. **********Paris-based L'Oreal, best known for its Lancome creams and perfumes, asked a newly acquired American subsidiary, Helena Rubenstein Inc., to supply information in 1989 about its contracts and royalties from a licensee selling its cosmetics in Israel, Mr. Marcuss said. Helena Rubenstein had been on an Arab blacklist of companies that did business with Israel, and L'Oreal was blacklisted when it acquired Helena Rubenstein. **********L'Oreal sent information to Arab officials in Damascus, Syria, the same year about Helena Rubenstein's operations in Israel, and L'Oreal was removed from the Arab blacklist in July 1989. But Mr. Marcuss said it was not clear whether the information provided by Helena Rubenstein in the United States was the same as that passed on to Arab officials, and he argued that the Commerce Department was wrong to interpret the information being sent to Paris as a violation of the boycott law. **********"This was simply a communication between a subsidiary and a parent company," the lawyer said, adding that L'Oreal has bigger cosmetics operations in Israel than any other company. **********Mr. Despres noted that L'Oreal's activities in Paris were outside the jurisdiction of American officials and the American boycott law. **********But Lindsay Owen-Jones, the chairman of L'Oreal, nonetheless sent a letter today to the Anti-Defamation League apologizing for the company's correspondence with the Arab officials. **********"As chairman of L'Oreal, I personally would like to say that I am sorry such correspondence was ever sent," he wrote. "I also want to inform you that I have taken measures to assure that such action will not happen again." **********Abraham H. Foxman, the league's national director, said he strongly believed that L'Oreal had cooperated with the Arab boycott, although he said there was some room for discussion whether American laws had been broken. But he accepted Mr. Owens-Jones's apology and praised L'Oreal for having expanded its operations in Israel in recent years. "The question is not punishment or vengeance; the question is what happens from now," he said. **********L'Oreal has been a target of criticism since 1991, when it was reported that the chairman of its American marketing arm, Jacques Correze, served in 1940-41 as Paris region director of the pro-Nazi Revolutionary Social Movement. The movement worked with the Gestapo in raiding homes and businesses of Jews, although Mr. Correze denied before his death that he took part in anti-Semitic attacks or persecution. **********In the summer of 1991, the Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations began an investigation whether to bar Mr. Correze from the United States. A week after the investigation was announced, Mr. Correze, who served five years in a French prison after World War II, stepped down as head of the marketing arm, Cosmair Inc., and died a few hours later of pancreatic cancer. **********Helena Rubenstein has been merged since 1989 with another American subsidiary of L'Oreal, Parbel of Florida Inc., which agreed today to pay $1,387,000. Cosmair agreed to pay $9,000. Parbel and Cosmair are both wholly owned subsidiaries of L'Oreal. **********Bruce L. Mishkin, who was the vice president, general counsel and corporate secretary of Helena Rubenstein in 1989, and is now associate general counsel of Cosmair, agreed today to pay $50,400. **********The largest penalty for violations of the anti-boycott law was imposed two years ago on Baxter International, which agreed to pay $6 million for violating provisions of the law prohibiting it from giving Arab nations details of its business and charitable contributions in Israel. **********Today's announcement came after the close of trading in Paris, where L'Oreal's shares rose 15 francs to close at 1,275 francs. **********Mr. Despres said that while he planned to continue enforcing the boycott law, Arab countries appeared to be showing less interest in enforcing the boycott. The number of complaints received by the Commerce Department's anti-boycott office dropped 27 percent in the first half of this year from the preceding six months, while the number of complaints from Persian Gulf countries, which had rigorously enforced the boycott, dropped 61 percent in the same period, he said. **********Arab hostility toward Israel has been diminishing in recent years, as Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization reached agreements with the Israelis, and Syria has held negotiations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/11/world.main_headline: Politics Aside, Many in China Are Expanding Business With Taiwan
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/11/world.print_headline: Politics Aside, Many in China Are Expanding Business With Taiwan
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/11/world.body_text: **********As relations between the United States and China worsen, barely a day goes by without a Chinese leader spewing invective about Taiwan and how Washington treats it. **********But away from China's diplomatic huffing and puffing, senior and mid-level officials who grapple with how to modernize China's economy are steadily expanding business ties with Taiwan, the island nation that is increasingly seen by mainlanders as a model for how to do business more efficiently and profitably. **********Shao Chun, president of one of China's largest securities firms, China Securities Company, is a good example of the business-minded officials in their 40's and 50's who now make up the bulk of China's power structure. **********Although Mr. Shao does not object to China's formal view that Taiwan is an "inalienable part of the motherland," he is more interested in imitating its economic success. **********"I'm going there next month," Mr. Shao said the other day. "We have a lot to learn from them." **********As he discussed similarities between the securities markets in China today and in Taiwan a decade ago, Mr. Shao said that China's current problems, like insufficent regulation and uncontrolled speculation, are exactly what Taiwan experienced. **********For decades, China's Communist Party has warned about how the evils of capitalist Taiwan could corrupt the mainland. Until the mid-1980's, visitors who crossed the Taiwan Strait from either direction were regarded as spies to be interrogated and jailed. The only exception was defectors. Taiwan, for example, rewarded each defecting Chinese Air Force pilot with instant celebrity and $1 million. **********But now that the business of China, more and more, is business, Taiwan's combination of identical language, cultural backround and fast-growing economy offers a special role as teacher to the mainland. **********"This has nothing to do with ideology," said Mr. Shao. "This is about making money." **********Although Taiwan investment in mainland China is difficult to measure accurately -- direct investment is still officially banned -- David O'Rear of the Economist Intelligence Unit in Hong Kong estimates that it reached about $6 billion in 1994, compared with $2.5 billion from the United States. **********Taiwan business people started coming to China in the mid-1980's as economic and political policy relaxed on each side, and Taiwan estimates that its residents conducted seven million visits to the mainland last year. Taiwan business people can now be found in every major mainland city, both as private investors and as resident representatives for multinational companies. **********"It makes a lot of sense if you think about it," said a Taiwan businessman who is general manager for an American company in Shanghai. His insistence on not being identified reflects a lingering sensitivity to the issue. "We have a much greater intuitive ability to work with people here than other outsiders do." **********Growing ties are not limited to individuals. Last fall, even the People's Construction Bank of Shanghai formalized ties to a venture capital company owned partly by Taiwan and partly by the United States. The company, the China Development Corporation, formed a $250 million fund aimed at a variety of Asian investment projects. **********There is another side to Taiwan business activity in the mainland, too. Chinese officials complain that a large percentage of sour deals and business fraud is conducted by Taiwan business people, and point to the pirating of American and Chinese music copyrights as an area dominated by business people from Taiwan. For years, Taiwan has been a leading violator of publishing and recording copyrights. **********On the other hand, Taiwan business people have cooled their enthusiasm for direct investment in the mainland during the last year because of frustration caused by China's lack of adequate legal protection when a dispute arises with a Chinese partner. **********Ever sensitive to the issue of sovereignty, China's concern centers on the question of whether the United States views the mainland and the island off its southeastern coast as "one China" or as "one China and one Taiwan." **********The current troubles were touched off by something as seemingly innocuous as the United States decision to allow President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan to attend a reunion at Cornell University last month. **********American officials have been at pains to point out that Mr. Lee's visit to Cornell did not alter their position recognizing only one China. Indeed, to American diplomats, the idea of one China seems to be sacrosant, at least in part because any change would make their own work more difficult.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/26/world.main_headline: Mourners of Fire Victims in India Protest Hospital as Inadequate
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/26/world.print_headline: Mourners of Fire Victims in India Protest Hospital as Inadequate
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/26/world.body_text: **********A crowd of some 5,000 mourners for people killed in a fire at a school ceremony here blocked the police today from hauling away bodies for cremation. **********The crowd threatened to tear down a wall of Mandi Dabwali's Civil Hospital, which they said was not equipped well enough, and to burn the bodies where they lay inside. **********The death toll in the fire continued to grow. Authorities said today the confirmed death toll was 538. **********The fire on Saturday spread swiftly through the 30-by-30-foot, tent-like structure made of plywood and polyester, which had a corrugated metal roof and was surrounded by a 10-foot-high brick wall. **********There were only two openings in the wall. One was locked and the other was too small to accommodate the fleeing crowds. **********Many of the dead were mothers and their children, killed by smoke, flames or  a stampede as the frightened audience tried to escape. **********The police were holding Kewal Kishan Dhamija, the owner of the structure, on  suspicion of criminal negligence. Improper wiring at the hall may have caused the blaze, an initial police investigation concluded. **********The Calcutta-based Statesman newspaper said that Mr. Dhamija, whose wife, niece and nephew died in the fire, admitted the shelter was built without proper permits. **********At the protest today, the police kept the crowd under control, and the protesters dispersed after about five hours without carrying out their threats. **********"Is this a way to run a hospital?" said one protester, Suresh Singh. He said  the hospital had only 10 beds for the town's 50,000 people. **********The protesters blocked the police from taking away 18 bodies, and threatened  to burn the car of a state minister, Jagdish Nehra, who reportedly had said such accidents were common in India. **********"I didn't say such a thing," Nehra said later. **********There was no immediate response from the hospital. **********About 250 people were injured in the fire on Saturday. Doctors at the Dabwali hospital sent all but a handful of burn cases to nearby towns. **********The death toll could rise to as high as 600 if the most seriously injured survivors die. In addition, the police said some people took their dead or dying relatives home and some of those deaths have not been tallied. **********Chief Minister Bhajan Lal, the top official of Haryana state, declared three  days of mourning and announced an investigation. Mandi Dabwali is in Haryana, 125 miles northwest of New Delhi. **********Devi Lal, a resident of the town, said today that some people escaped the blaze after a farmer rammed his tractor through the wall. **********Sukhdev Dutt Sharma, 76, said his 9-year-old grandson had the role of a parrot in the program and had just said "Happy New Year" when the fire broke out. The boy and eight other members of Mr. Sharma's family were killed. **********"Just about every family has lost someone," The police chief, Hari Shankar, said. "This town has been devastated. Everyone is in mourning." **********Funeral pyres were smoldering today in a farm field on the edge of town. The  authorities said families were burning hundreds of bodies there after the tragedy overwhelmed the town crematory, which can handle just 20 bodies a day. **********Nearly all the victims were Sikhs or Hindus, whose religious traditions require cremation. The authorities said the few Muslims who died were buried in  local cemeteries. **********The state Government announced it would pay families of the dead the equivalent of about $2,500 each, and survivors would get about $1,500.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/01/busin.main_headline: Broken Hill Of Australia Agrees to Buy Magma Copper
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/01/busin.print_headline: Broken Hill Of Australia Agrees to Buy Magma Copper
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/01/busin.body_text: **********The Broken Hill Proprietary Company of Australia, one of the world's largest  natural resources and industrial companies, said late yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Magma Copper Company of Tucson, Ariz., for $1.8 billion plus the assumption of about $600 million in debt. **********The acquisition would make Broken Hill the largest publicly traded producer of copper in the world, second only to Codelco, the state-owned copper producer in Chile. After buying Magma, Broken Hill would produce roughly 10 percent of the world's copper. **********By Tuesday, Broken Hill plans to begin a cash tender offer of $28 a share for all of Magma's outstanding common shares, a 31 percent premium to yesterday's closing price of $21.325. The shares rose $1.25 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, before the deal was announced. The agreement does not  require the approval of Broken Hill's shareholders, and Magma's largest shareholder, the Warburg Pincus Capital Company, which owns 26 percent of Magma  on a fully diluted basis, has agreed to tender its shares. **********Graeme W. McGregor, executive general manager of Broken Hill, which is based  in Melbourne, said in an interview last night that the deal had several advantages for his company. **********Most importantly, it would give Broken Hill a fully integrated copper operation, because Magma has a state-of-the-art smelter that the BHP Copper Group, the subsidiary to be created to meld Broken Hill's and Magma's copper operations, can use to transform mined copper into metal. Broken Hill, which does not have a smelter, now hands over the copper it mines to outsiders to process into metal. **********It would also give Broken Hill immediate access to the American copper market, essentially giving it a global reach. Most of its copper products are now sold in Asian and European countries. **********"The key focus of this acquisition is growth," Mr. McGregor said. "The asset  base complements our existing asset base in a way that will create great synergies." **********Broken Hill said that in addition to the $28-a-share offer for Magma's common shares, it would also tender for outstanding shares of Magma's Series D and E convertible preferred stock at a price that equals its offer for the common stock. **********Broken Hill plans to finance the acquisition with internal cash resources and existing lines of credit. Mr. McGregor said that the company's debt would rise somewhat initially. **********He said the acquisition was expected to save the combined company $30 million to $40 million a year over time as redundancies in operations like exploration and administration are thinned. **********Magma's stock has risen sharply in the last two weeks, after Dan Dorfman, the CNBC television financial correspondent, quoted analysts as saying the stock could hit $29 in 18 months. He did not, however, predict an acquisition. **********Mr. McGregor hinted that Broken Hill might have had some competition for Magma, saying, "The deal has the support of both boards, but that, of course, doesn't mean others may not have an interest. But it would be hard for anyone else to extract the value we get from this, because our operations are so complementary." **********CS First Boston, the investment banking unit of CS Holding, advised Broken Hill on the acquisition, and Goldman, Sachs & Company advised Magma. **********The BHP Copper Group will be based in San Francisco, along with Utah Mining,  which Broken Hill acquired from the General Electric Company last year. BHP Copper is expected to produce about 900,000 tons of copper in 1996. **********Magma earned $51.9 million, or $1.02 a share, on sales of $392.6 million in the third quarter of this year. In the fiscal year that ended in May, Broken Hill posted a profit of about $907 million on revenue of roughly $13.2 billion.  All the figures are in United States dollars.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/28/busin.main_headline: Atlanta Fed Chooses No. 2 To Be Its Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/28/busin.print_headline: Atlanta Fed Chooses No. 2 To Be Its Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/28/busin.body_text: **********The Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank today named Jack Guynn, its vice president and chief operating officer, to be its president and chief executive. The appointment ends a months-long search after the current president, Robert P. Forrestal, announced his retirement. **********At a news conference where his appointment was announced, Mr. Guynn, 52, said the Fed's top priority must be fighting inflation. He added that while inflation had slowed during the last 15 years, it should be slowed further. **********Mr. Forrestal will step down on Jan. 1 some 10 months before he turns 65, the mandatory retirement age for Fed presidents. Mr. Forrestal is capping a 12-year career as one of the nation's regional Fed presidents. **********Mr. Guynn had been a leading candidate for the Atlanta Fed post, although Sheila Tschinkel, a senior vice president and director of research at the Fed branch, had been cited as a strong contender by some. **********While Mr. Guynn expressed satisfaction with the 2.9 percent yearly inflation  rate during the first 10 months of this year -- the same pace as the two earlier years -- he said he would like to see even smaller price increases. **********"My main emphasis is on price stability," Mr. Guynn said. "Price stability is that point when price issues don't get in the way of basic business development." **********Mr. Guynn said there was little chance of a rising wage-price spiral because  scattered labor shortages earlier this year had dwindled. **********Also, inflation may be even slower than it appears, he said. **********The Atlanta branch is headquarters for the Federal Reserve Bank's sixth district covering Florida, Georgia, Alabama, Tennessee, Mississippi and Louisiana.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/30/world.main_headline: San Carlos de Bariloche Journal;In Nazi's Hiding Place, the Stain Won't Wash Away
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/30/world.print_headline: San Carlos de Bariloche Journal;In Nazi's Hiding Place, the Stain Won't Wash Away
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/30/world.body_text: **********Nestled in Argentina's snow-capped Andes, overlooking a vast pristine lake, this picturesque ski town has long been a favorite of Latin American jet-setters. No wonder it was chosen as the site for the recent annual meeting of presidents from Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking countries. **********But despite Bariloche's many gingerbread houses, chocolate and fondue shops,  pine forests and jagged peaks, which have led many visitors to compare it to Bavaria, the town's reputation has been undermined by an 82-year-old former Nazi who has become its most infamous resident. **********Erich Priebke, a former SS captain who has lived in Bariloche for 50 years and has admitted taking part in the killings of 335 Italian civilians at the Ardeatine Caves outside Rome in 1944, is under house arrest here as the Argentine Supreme Court decides whether he will be extradited to Italy. **********For decades Argentines have quietly referred to Bariloche as a haven for Nazis who fled Germany after World War II. But it was not until two years ago, when Mr. Priebke was uncovered by a team from ABC News television, that the world began to associate this town with Nazis. **********"You'd have to be either crazy or blind and deaf to think that Bariloche does not have its share of Nazis," said Rosario Zaballa, 48, a store clerk who has lived here all her life. "They don't bother anybody, but they are here." **********Swastikas are regularly scrawled on walls and even appear in some public artwork. Throughout the town, people tell tales of Germans who still hold secret celebrations of Hitler's birthday on April 20. **********Many residents openly support Mr. Priebke. He declined to be interviewed but  has said he is innocent of any crime because he was obeying Hitler's orders. **********The Italian massacre, which included 71 Jewish victims, was ordered by the SS in reprisal for an attack by Italian underground fighters that killed 33 German  soldiers. **********In August, an appeals court overturned a lower court judgment ordering the extradition of Mr. Priebke to Italy. His lawyer, Pedro Bianchi, told reporters here that the decision was based on Argentina's 15-year statute of limitations for murder. **********A group of Mr. Priebke's supporters held a Mass to celebrate the court's ruling, and a local newspaper, Bariloche Hoy, said in a front-page article that  Mr. Priebke was "an ideologically responsible person" and not guilty of the Nazi atrocities. **********To many Jews, the appeals court's decision is another example of how Argentina continues to provide refuge for Nazis. **********"We have his signed confession that he participated in these acts, and I can't understand why the court would refuse to extradite him," said Rabbi Marvin Hier, dean of the Los Angeles-based Simon Wiesenthal Center, which is devoted to bringing Nazis to justice. **********"There is a great support in Argentina for fascism and people who love the old days under Peron when people like Priebke were heroes," Rabbi Hier said. "What the Argentine Government really wants is a biological solution to the problem. That Priebke will die before they have to extradite him." **********President Carlos Saul Menem's Government has said it is committed to bringing former Nazis living in Argentina to justice, including quick extraditions. **********Tourism and municipal government officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said people who believe that Bariloche is a Nazi refuge are judging the city unfairly, based solely on the past actions of a small fraction of its residents. **********The officials said Bariloche, about 850 miles southwest of Buenos Aires, was  one of the few cities in Argentina that had passed a resolution repudiating Nazism and noted that the city's three other papers had called for Mr. Priebke's extradition. **********Bariloche, a town of more than 100,000 people that was founded 100 years ago  by Germans from Chile, today has a German population of several hundred. **********Daniel Reisfeld, a retailer who is president of Bariloche's small Jewish population of 35 families, said that while he had not encountered any anti-Semitism in the 15 years he has lived in Bariloche, he believed there were  anti-Semites and Nazis living here. **********"There is the same quantity, percentage-wise, of Nazis living in Bariloche as there is in any other city with a strong German population and history," Mr. Reisfeld said. "The only difference is that Bariloche is the only city with a Nazi who is waiting to be extradited and who has caught people's attention."
