https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;BIC IS ABSORBED BY ITS PARENT AND ENDS U.S. TRADING
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/busin.body_text: **********The Bic Corporation said yesterday that its shareholders had approved the deal for Societe Bic S.A. of France to spend $40.50 a share, or $219 million, to buy the 22 percent of the Bic Corporation's common shares not owned by Societe Bic and the Bich family. A Bic Corporation spokeswoman said in May that its closely held French parent company was making the offer in part because the French franc was much stronger than the dollar. Bic, of Milford, Conn., expects to continue its United States operations as before. The company, which traded on the New York Stock Exchange, said that it had ceased being a public company at the close of business yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/10/world.main_headline: Pope Renews Vatican Stand Backing Religious Freedom
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/10/world.print_headline: Pope Renews Vatican Stand Backing Religious Freedom
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/10/world.body_text: **********Government measures to insure the separation of church and state should not be viewed as barring religion and religious convictions from any role in public  life, Pope John Paul II said last week in a statement that also reaffirmed the Roman Catholic Church's commitment to religious freedom. **********The statement, synthesizing a number of the Pope's favorite themes, was issued on Thursday to mark the 30th anniversary of "Dignitatis Humanae," the Second Vatican Council's declaration on religious freedom. **********The Pope hailed that declaration, which renounced the church's longstanding  insistence on a privileged relationship with governments, as "one of the Council's most innovative texts," which had "resulted in the release of enormous moral and religious energies" and "had a real bearing on the social and political transformations of recent years." **********Noting that millions of believers had fallen victim to political ideologies or religious or ethnic hatreds during the last century, the Pope stressed "the individual's right to be free from coercion in matters religious." **********But the Pope also addressed what he described as a limitation on religious freedom "more subtle than overt persecution" -- the claim that, in democratic and pluralistic societies, religious beliefs should be relegated to the realm of private opinion and have no role in public life. **********Moral questions were at the core of great public issues, he said, and democracy and pluralism required that citizens whose morality was informed by religious convictions should feel welcome to express them. **********"Religious believers," he added, "must be deeply committed to the method of dialogue and persuasion." **********The statement, sent to an International Congress on Secularism and Religious  Freedom that met on Dec. 5-7 in Rome, closed with a declaration of "profound repentance" for times in history when the church had fostered intolerance or approved of "the use of violence in the service of truth."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/busin.main_headline: Dow Passes 5,000 Level, but Drops Back
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/busin.print_headline: Dow Passes 5,000 Level, but Drops Back
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Jones industrial average twice surpassed the 5,000-point level yesterday, but the market could not keep up the momentum and the Dow wound up closing lower. **********When the Dow first crossed the 5,000 mark in the morning, a chorus of cheers  erupted on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. But by the end of the session, this widely watched indicator retreated 6.86 points, to 4,983.09. **********The broader indexes fell as well. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 3.22 points, to 596.85, and the Nasdaq composite index, heavy with technology issues, dropped 15.56 points, to 1,029.47. **********Declining issues exceeded advancers on the Big Board by 1,274 to 1,047. Volume amounted to 335.5 million shares, well off from Friday's 429.4 million shares; Friday's activity was stimulated by options-related buying. **********"It was just a so-so day in a typical holiday week," Robert Freedman, chief investment officer of the John Hancock Funds in Boston, said of yesterday's trading. "And we've been seeing a change of leadership in the market." **********Yesterday's early rally was sparked by the temporary resolution over the weekend of the Federal budget crisis. Since a compromise between the Clinton Administration and Congress had been previously factored into the market, though, stock prices fell back toward the end of the day. **********"Don't get too aggressive in buying, since a positive budget outcome is already built into the market," said Larry J. Wipf of the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "Federal Reserve and private-sector reports reveal a sputtering manufacturing sector, easing home sales and rising credit-quality concerns." **********High-technology stocks slumped for the second consecutive session in reaction to the Hewlett-Packard Company's announcement on Friday that a greater percentage of its fourth-quarter profit came from products with lower profit margins. Hewlett-Packard tumbled 4 1/2, to 84; Micron Technology dropped 5 1/4,  to 49 7/8; Texas Instruments declined 3 1/4, to 56 1/2, and Sun Microsystems fell 5 7/8, to 81 5/8. Shares in so-called Internet stocks were an exception to  the technology selloff and finished significantly higher. **********However, money managers rotated into big-name consumer-oriented companies with consistent earnings. Among those showing gains were Eastman Kodak, up 1 3/8, to 70 1/4; Walt Disney, up 1, to 60 1/4, and Texaco, up 1 to 72. Caterpillar rose 1/8, to 55 5/8, amid signs that a 17-month strike by its unionized workers might soon end. **********A number of retail issues were higher. Gucci gained 3 1/8, to 33 7/8; Sears,  Roebuck advanced 3/8, to 39 3/4, and Federated Department Stores increased 1/4,  to 29 1/8, **********Automobile stocks, which had been underperforming the overall market, showed  some strength yesterday. General Motors closed at 47 5/8, up 3/4, and Ford Motor ended at 29, up 3/8. Chrysler was unchanged at 50. **********American Home Products, which received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to sell a new drug, gained 1, to 90 1/8. Iomega, which won awards from two computer magazines at a trade show last week, soared 61/64 , to 409/64  . C-Cube, which announced a 2-for-1 stock split, jumped 3, to 83. **********In contrast, Eckerd, the drugstore chain, declined 2 1/2, to 41 1/8, after saying that it plans to sell 2.5 million shares to the public. Exide Electronics dropped 3, to 16 1/2, after Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette downgraded the stock. And Haemonetics slipped 1 7/8, to 17 1/2, after being downgraded by Alex. Brown  & Sons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/08/busin.body_text: **********PARKING Delivered, Presumably, Dent-Free In a test run in Augsburg, Germany, an automatic rotating disc brought three cars to their parking slots. The promised waiting time at this fancy new garage: 2.5 minutes **********PUBLISHING Those Business Week Papers Let's see. First Procter & Gamble sued Bankers Trust, saying it had been led down a too-risky investment path. A mass of papers quickly piled up -- lawyers tend to be good at that -- and a judge decided some of them weren't quite ready  for public consumption. Then Business Week got hold of the sealed papers and smelled a scoop, a judge said no, and all sorts of First Amendment hell broke loose. Last week some smoke cleared, as the judge unsealed the documents, which  seemed to bolster P.&G.'s case by disclosing losses at other companies from derivatives sold by Bankers Trust. But the free-speech issue was left smoldering, for the judge also insisted he had the right to stop publication. Now it's in the lap of the appeals courts. **********CHARITY Throwing Big Money at Cancer It's all too familiar these days: a takeover, a merger, a little board-room back-scratching, and some executive walks away with a sum that would boggle the  mind even if it lost a couple of zeroes. But last week came a stunning variation: the mind-numbing sum was going not to an executive but to science. Jon Huntsman, who made about $1 billion in chemicals, lost both parents to cancer and battled it twice himself. That was enough to prod him to say he'd give $100 million to a cancer research center at the University of Utah. That may be walking-around money to Ted Turner, but it's the largest individual gift  ever to medical research. "It's been 26 years since a man walked on the moon," Mr. Huntsman said, and we're still battling cancer. He wants to win this one. **********AUTOS Speaking Out at Chrysler The seat belts are off at Chrysler. Last week the chairman, Robert Eaton, lashed out at those he said wanted to "trash" the company -- mainly Kirk Kerkorian and  Jerome York. He said Mr. Kerkorian, who now owns nearly 15 percent of Chrysler,  "has no real knowledge" about what's happening and is merely out for "personal gain." He said Mr. Kerkorian and Mr. York -- the former Chrysler executive who's now in Mr. Kerkorian's camp -- are merely harming other shareholders by trying to gain control. **********REAL ESTATE Japanese for 'Low Rent' Japanese real estate prices are so high they're almost an international joke (so long as someone else is paying them). So when you hear that they've plummeted -- by two-thirds or more -- in recent years, does that mean they're out of the stratosphere? Not exactly. You'll still spend $6,000 or so (every month!) to rent a modest suburban house, perhaps $4,000 for a one-bedroom Tokyo apartment;  this is Japanese for "plummet." And it may not even last. Last week the I.M.F. forecast a recovery for the battered Japanese economy in 1996, though it did lower its estimate for the nation's growth this year. Rent 'em while you can. **********CAREERS The Mailroom Gambit It is, so it's said, the American way: if you're near the top of your field, you make a good living. So you'd think that Jay Bonin, who's in the top 200 or so Americans in his chosen field, would be riding high. If he'd been a lawyer, he might have been one of the hundreds of that profession at the Simpson defense table; if he played baseball, he'd be out there spitting with the richest of them. But Mr. Bonin's great talent is chess. Yes, there's $1 million in prize money in the world championship match that was speeding toward a conclusion last week atop the World Trade Center, but in chess, if you're not at that pinnacle,  you'd better have a day job. Mr. Bonin, brilliant at chess, makes a few thousand a year at it; by day, he's a mailroom clerk. **********INNOVATIONS Making Cats Easier to Love There are, those tireless statisticians tell us, 63 million cats in this country. There'd be a lot fewer if it weren't for one Edward Lowe. Cats, you see, smell. Built for the desert, they use water with enviable efficiency, but the downside is that their urine . . . well, you know. To fight the odor, people tried sawdust, sand, wood shavings, but they weren't much help. Then one day in  1947 -- a watershed day in feline history -- Mr. Lowe had a neighbor try a dried, granulated clay used to sop up grease spills in factories. And, yes, Kitty Litter was born -- along with what is now a $600 million annual industry.  And Mr. Lowe? In 1990 he sold his business for $200 million. And last week he died at age 75. **********OPPORTUNITIES Gulps of Premium Juice Who has the most impact on this marvelous capitalist machine we inhabit? Well, one week it might be Bill Gates, the next week Newt Gingrich, and the next, Steven Spielberg. Last week, of course, it was 12 faceless jurors in a Los Angeles courtroom. They spoke, and this mighty economy -- which prides itself on packing every second chock full -- ground to a halt for long, long minutes. You  could have heard a stock drop, if any had been trading; you could have heard the phone ring, if anyone had called. The jurors spoke, and whole conglomerates were born -- reported $1 million sales of photos of the reunion of the defendant (what was his name?) and his children, tales of $50 million pay-per-view blowout interviews, other interview deals, book deals, and then probably books about the book deals. And, yes, talk of a television drama series based on the lives of two DNA experts. And it's only just begun. **********HEALTH CARE Medicare Plan Under Fire Medicare may well need patching up, but the Republicans' notions about how to do it took a lot of flak last week. First came the American Medical Association, which has kept silent for much of the recent debate but now voiced concern that  limits on payments would scare too many doctors away. "It would be a major blow," said an A.M.A. spokesman. Then the A.A.R.P. joined the fray, saying Congress was cutting "too much, too fast" from projected spending. Newt Gingrich has been trying to get the elderly on his side, but he doesn't seem to have succeeded. And in a final attack, the head of the American College of Physicians said bluntly, "We are not on board."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/29/world.main_headline: World News Briefs;Turkish Jet Crashes In Aegean Encounter
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/29/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;Turkish Jet Crashes In Aegean Encounter
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/29/world.body_text: **********A Turkish F-4 jet fighter crashed in the Aegean Sea today after Greek warplanes intercepted it near the island of Mitilini. **********The Turkish plane's systems operator was rescued, but the pilot was missing.  A search was under way by Greek and Turkish military aircraft and ships. **********The Greek Defense Ministry said the two crewmen ejected over the sea as the  plane went down 5 miles west of Mitilini, inside Greek territorial waters just off Turkey's coast. **********Both Greece and Turkey blamed mechanical failure for the crash. **********Jet fighters from the two antagonistic NATO neighbors often have mock dogfights over the Aegean Sea in an effort to intimidate each other, and planes  from both countries have crashed in the past. **********The Greek Defense Minister, Gerasimos Arsenis, said two armed Turkish F-4 fighters had violated Greek airspace over the island of Chios. **********The Greek F-16's engaged the Turkish planes to try to force them back to their own airspace, he said, and one of the planes crashed as it tried to maneuver away.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/04/busin.main_headline: Computer Theory as Social Science;Innovative N.Y.U. Program Stresses Content and Use in the Real World
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/04/busin.print_headline: Computer Theory as Social Science;Innovative N.Y.U. Program Stresses Content and Use in the Real World
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/04/busin.body_text: **********Wedged into a tiny control room at New York University, hair flying and arms  waving above their heads, a group of graduate students danced wildly in the glow of television monitors and to the cacophonous sounds of canned music, scratchy broadcast conversations, touch-tone phone beeps and the screech of feedback. **********"You got it!" Prof. Nick West shouted into a microphone. "Experimental television, and we're putting the 'mental' in it!" **********On screens behind him and in homes across Manhattan, images of tiny robotic  figures jerked to the same ear-splitting music. The dancing of these computer-generated mannequins was manipulated by a few television viewers punching buttons on their touch-tone telephones after dialing in to the university's late-night interactive TV program. One minute, viewers could see the real dancers; the next, the robotic mannequins -- all keeping time to the same music. **********Experimental shows like this are irreverent, funky, hip -- a digital mix of music, video and bright graphics. Graduate students in the Interactive Telecommunications Program call the shows the future of television. **********The technical elite who style themselves the digerati might find that, energy aside, the scenes were generations behind the computer images in the Disney film "Toy Story." But the students, who made the movie a topic on their show, are indifferent to such comparisons. They say they want to extend multimedia to the  technological have-nots of the information age, the people with television sets  but no computers, phones but no modems. **********In a world that celebrates the ever more complex, New York University has created a graduate program built around the notion that technology is truly useful only if it enhances creativity for all. In the Interactive Telecommunications Program, technology is a liberal art. **********In practice, this means that the 200 students take one course in programming, but none in electrical engineering or physics, in contrast with the requirements of computer-science programs at schools like M.I.T. While most students here know such technical arcana as which digital-compression standard works with what kind of computer file, their curriculum has the same free-form, random-access feel as the digital world they work in. **********"We're more interested in content than in hardware," said Red Burns, a New York University professor and head of the Interactive Telecommunications Program since 1983. "To me, the computer is just another tool. It's like a pen. You have to have a pen, and to know penmanship, but neither will write the book for you." **********Thus, in contrast with many technically oriented graduate programs, her students get formal training in multimedia with an emphasis on what they can do  for technology, not the other way around. **********"I think new technology represents a cataclysmic change -- in the way we look at the world, in the way we communicate," Professor Burns said. "But since we're in the middle of it, we don't know what it is." **********The program has no required texts or theories. "What they know of the field they came from is what they will use in technology," she said. "They bring ideas, play with ideas, examine ideas and look for the appropriate technology. We try to train people to learn how to learn, to go out and work in a technology world that is changing all the time." **********The N.Y.U. program predates the current hyperbole about the convergence of computers with entertainment and information. It has existed since 1979, its founders believing that a multimedia revolution was already under way. **********"At that time, it was cable and video," Professor Burns said. Originally a documentary film maker, in the mid-1970's she helped create two-way television programs to inform the elderly about community social services. She and her colleagues put video cameras in retirement homes, hospitals and housing agencies, and linked them through a cable system. They used technology in untried ways to answer questions and spread information about facilities for the elderly. **********As Professor Burns said recently, "We didn't go in and say 'here's the technology, let's find a way to use it.' We said 'here's a need.' " **********With N.Y.U. colleagues two decades ago, she cobbled together the space at the university, found money for the program, and took on about 20 graduate students, dubbing the effort the Interactive Telecommunications Program. "I had a very hard time trying to explain to people what it was," Professor Burns recalled. "Nobody understood. It wasn't mass media? Then what was it?" **********Today, about 200 students are enrolled for two years to study multimedia forms, ethics of the digital domain, and, as Professor Burns puts it, "enough about technology to be able to use it." **********Many work in familiar areas like interactive video, computer graphics and electronic publishing. But some classes range further afield, adopting the attitudes, and prose style, of modern social science theorists. In a course titled E/Merging Media, students are taught "how to control the dynamics of merging and interactivity so as not to abandon the content." **********"How does the formal tension among the media create new possibilities for meta-media?" the course description asked. "Are we, in effect, moving toward the widespread adoption of what has been called hypermedia? What are the ethical dilemmas?" **********"The courses are there for people to get a handle on what the questions are," Professor Burns said. "But the problems are solved in the halls, at the computers. There's a lot of collaboration that goes on here in the middle of the night." **********Her department fills the fourth floor of N.Y.U.'s Tisch School of the Arts. A hall with wide pine floorboards ends in her office, where a long farm table serves as a desk and a computer is tucked unobtrusively into a corner, leaving the impression that it is not the center of attention. The decor in other rooms  is techno-modern, with doors of glass and tables full of computers, video monitors and editing machines. **********On a recent day, students in a class on Design for the Screen gathered for a  lecture on how information can best be presented on computers so that people feel comfortable. "It's important to understand, appreciate and respect the technology side," said Miles Kronby, a second-year student. "But my interest is  in the content side of it. Basically, what kind of stories might best be told in these media and how to tell them? What kinds of stories and information are more engaging because of interactivity?" **********Professor Burns said that her students, with their diverse backgrounds and their degrees from the program, go to work "everywhere, because these technologies have permeated everywhere." In the last five years, graduates have  taken jobs at Apple Computer, Nynex, Viacom, MTV, HBO and the Macmillan publishing house. Many others have begun their own businesses. **********One destination is the Starwave Corporation outside Seattle, a multimedia producer of CD-ROM's and World Wide Web sites. "So far, I.T.P. is the only place to go to find people who cross disciplines," said Erling Aspelund, a Starwave producer and a graduate of the Interactive Telecommunications Program. Until he  arrived, the company, started by Microsoft's co-founder, Paul Allen, had never heard of the program. **********"We are a publishing company first and foremost," Mr. Aspelund said. "This is the only school you can go to find associate producers, graphic artists, designers -- the kinds of people coming up with concepts, with new ideas for on-line services." **********At Microsoft, Pierre de Vries, lead program manager of its Consumer Systems Prototyping Group, worked last summer with interns from N.Y.U. and recently hired a program graduate. **********"Microsoft has no shortage of the best technical thinkers," Mr. de Vries said, "and we need to find and attract people who are the best at traditional creative thinking. The insights that people who are artists have are crucial if  we're going to make a breakthrough in the way we think about the uses of technology and if we are going to make things that are compelling." **********Which is not to say that he or other employers could do without the electrical-engineering or computer-science majors who are expert in intricate programming. But the I.T.P. students' ability to resort to low-tech legerdemain  when there are no easy high-tech solutions fits the needs of both new multimedia companies and older software businesses. **********In the hopes of fitting into such a business, Sigi Moeslinger, an industrial  designer from San Francisco, enrolled in I.T.P., rather than a more technical program. For a department exhibition, she created a "virtual flower." A flower pot sat on a shelf below a monitor embedded in a wall. A synthetic stem from the pot reached toward the monitor, disappeared and then re-emerged on the screen, with an animated flower blooming at its head. When lamps in the room were moved, the on-screen flower pivoted toward the light. When water was poured into the pot, the flower on the monitor perked up. **********"There's this thing that's half real and half virtual," she said. "You can interact with it in the real world, and use some of your natural experiences. People feel more engaged when there's a physical relationship."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/24/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Leeson Is Formally Charged in Singapore
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/24/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Leeson Is Formally Charged in Singapore
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/24/busin.body_text: **********Singapore formally charged the extradited former Barings P.L.C. trader Nicholas W. Leeson today with fraud and forgery linked to some $1.4 billion in losses that broke the venerable bank. **********The 11 charges were read in court by an official of Singapore's financial police, the Commercial Affairs Department. It was a lengthy process rather than  the five-minute remand hearing that Singapore legal experts had predicted. **********Most of the charges were long and packed with technical details, including those of individual trades in the derivatives market in which Mr. Leeson thrived before fleeing Singapore in February as word of his losses began to leak out. **********Lawrence Ang, chief of the Commercial Affairs Department, said his officers needed time to question Mr. Leeson, who was extradited on Thursday from Germany, where he was arrested in early March after a six-day global manhunt. **********Mr. Ang said it was not necessary for an immediate response to the charges from Mr. Leeson, the 28-year-old former whiz-kid greatly admired by colleagues in the days when he did millions of dollars' worth of deals each day. **********"As the accused has just been brought back to Singapore and C.A.D. officers have not had sufficient opportunity to interview him, I'm applying that his plea not be taken at this stage," Mr. Ang said. **********Mr. Leeson was expected to be ordered held in custody pending his trial. **********No date has been set, but Mr. Leeson's Singapore lawyer, John Koh, told reporters aboard the plane that flew Mr. Leeson and his wife, Lisa, to Singapore that he expected the trial to start before the end of the year. **********After his detention in Frankfurt on March 2, Mr. Leeson fought to be extradited to Britain for trial in London, Barings' headquarters. **********He opposed extradition to Singapore, originally saying he feared a show trial in a country that has a tough criminal code and various punishments including caning for certain offenses. It also hangs convicted killers and drug traffickers. **********None of those punishments would apply to Mr. Leeson, who faces a maximum 14 years in prison, and last month he abruptly dropped an appeal against extradition to Singapore. **********His lawyers have denied that the change of heart indicated a deal with the Singapore authorities. **********Nevertheless, Singapore legal experts said that if he cooperated with the authorities and pleaded guilty, Mr. Leeson could expect a jail term of between six months and two years. **********Mr. Leeson has said nothing publicly since he left a suburban Frankfurt jail  on Wednesday for a 13-hour overnight flight to Singapore. Airline cabin crew protected him from the dozen journalists who also caught the plane.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/busin.main_headline: Sales of Existing Homes Fall For 2d Consecutive Month
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/busin.print_headline: Sales of Existing Homes Fall For 2d Consecutive Month
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/busin.body_text: **********Sales of existing homes fell for a second consecutive month in November, an industry group said today, as a slowing economy reduced confidence about future  job security. **********The group, the National Association of Realtors, said resales of single-family homes dropped 1.7 percent in November, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.04 million units, despite lower mortgage rates. **********Sales of previously owned homes declined a revised 1 percent in October, to  an annual rate of 4.11 million; previously, October sales were reported to have  fallen a steeper 1.9 percent. That followed five consecutive months of rising sales from May through September. **********Analysts said that even after two months of declines, sales remained at a relatively healthy pace, in part because lower interest rates have made it easier for first-time homeowners to qualify for loans. **********The realtors' group said the average interest rate for a 30-year mortgage loan in November was 7.38 percent. That was down from 7.48 percent in October and was well below the rate of 9.16 percent in November 1994. **********November sales of existing homes were 9.5 percent above those in the corresponding month a year earlier, when they were running at an annual rate of  3.69 million. **********But some buoyancy has clearly left the housing market, a development that was reflected in a separate survey yesterday by the Conference Board, a business research group based in New York. **********The group said its consumer confidence index fell to 98.7 in December from a  revised 101.6 in November. The index, based on a sample from 5,000 households, is calculated on a base of 100. **********Edgar Fiedler, vice president and economic counselor at the Conference Board, noted that the index had hovered around the 100 mark throughout the year. **********"The traditionally warm spirits of the holiday season, however, have not lifted the economic expectations of consumers above this moderately favorable level," he added. **********After a strong third quarter in which the gross domestic product rose at a vigorous 4.2 percent annual rate, the economy has been on a slowing trend that is forecast to continue into 1996. **********That is casting a shadow over future prospects, as shown in lackluster Christmas sales. The most recent figures for retail sales, published today by Mitsubishi Bank-Schroder Wertheim, showed a modest surge of 1.4 percent in sales at chain stores in the week that ended Dec. 23. **********Although no official measure of fourth-quarter G.D.P. is available because of the continuing Government shutdown, most analysts anticipate an expansion of only about 2 percent. **********"The crux of the matter at this point really is job insecurity," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist for the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "Consumers are not sure about their job prospects in 1996 and consequently they're not really willing to spend a lot of money." **********Art Godi, president of the realtors' group, said, "The closing of the Federal Government, coupled with the onset of the holiday spending season, may have caused some reluctance among consumers to get into the housing market last month." **********Separately, the Labor Department said it would be forced to delay reports on  December prices and employment that were originally scheduled for release in early January. **********"At this point those things have been delayed," said Bill Barron, deputy commissioner at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, citing the partial shutdown of the Government because of the budget impasse. **********Although the data for the December economic reports were collected before the shutdown, the furlough of Government workers has led to delays in the processing of the information, Labor Department officials have said. **********The December employment and unemployment data were originally scheduled for release on Jan. 5. The report on the Producer Price Index was to be released on  Jan. 11 and the Consumer Price Index report was scheduled for Jan. 12.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/17/world.main_headline: European Union Offers Timetable for Talks With Applicants
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/17/world.print_headline: European Union Offers Timetable for Talks With Applicants
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/17/world.body_text: **********Leaders of the European Union offered new hope today to countries in Eastern  Europe that their admission to the union and its single market would come sooner rather than later. **********Ending a two-day summit meeting here, the 15 leaders agreed to begin formal negotiations with 10 Eastern European countries, as well as Malta and Cyprus, by the end of 1997. **********It was the first time in the three years that former Communist countries have been pushing to enter the European Union that they have had such a solid timetable. **********Still, it is far from clear how long it will take for the first former Communist country to become a full member or to what extent European Union leaders will require prospective members to liberalize their economies and institute further democratic reforms. **********"We can't tumble into this like lemmings over a cliff," said Prime Minister John Major of Britain. "We have to have realism over the enlargement of the community." **********Still, European Union officials said they expected that once the negotiations began, it would be two and a half to five years before the first countries were  permitted to join. **********Eastern European leaders had asked for a commitment on timing so that they could go back and tell their constitutents that the austerity measures many had  instituted had not been in vain, and that the result would be membership in the  giant European market and a free flow of their goods westward. **********So far, Poland, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Slovakia, Bulgaria, Romania, Slovenia, Estonia, Lithuania and Latvia have said they want to join. All but Slovenia and the Czech Republic have formally applied. **********Many Eastern European countries hoped that the European Union would consider  their applications jointly and admit them together in a kind of giant political  marriage. But union leaders made it clear that there was no hope of that happening. **********Going into the two-day meeting, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said he favored the quick admission of Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary, whose economies are far more modernized and integrated into Western European markets than the others. In addition, this would extend the European community's borders eastward toward Russia. **********"It is obviously of great political interest to Germany that the eastern border of Europe is not the Polish border," said one German official here. "We simply want the border as far from us as possible." **********Many predicted today that these three countries would be the first to join. But many officials warned that creating an elite first group among the former Soviet-bloc countries could leave the region divided and possibly unstable. **********While fixing a time for negotiations was only a step toward expanding the European Union, it capped one of the most decisive summit meetings by the group's leaders in years. **********On Friday, the union made a symbolic decision to give the name euro to the common, unifying currency it hopes to create in Europe by 2002. It also signed an agreement with leaders of four South American countries -- Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay -- to work toward a free trade pact early in the next century. **********But any decision on enlargement will be fraught with problems, if only because of money. The union now spends almost $47 billion to subsidize its farmers and calculates that similar subsidies for Eastern Europe would cost another $13 billion. And other economic assistance for residents in poorer regions of the European Union, now almost $40 billion, would have to rise to more than $90 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/04/world.main_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Powerful Quakes Rock Islands North of Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/04/world.print_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Powerful Quakes Rock Islands North of Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/04/world.body_text: **********A strong earthquake hit the Kurile Islands in the Russian Far East early today, but no injuries or damage were immediately reported. **********The quake measured 7.2 on the Richter scale and was centered about 31 miles  undersea off the island of Iturup, Japan's Central Meteorological Agency said. It followed a quake on Sunday that measured 6.9 and was centered 60 miles east of Iturup. Five other quakes hit the region last week, but there were no reports of injuries or damages from the sparcely populated area.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/31/world.main_headline: Judge Urges World to Heed Rwanda Crisis
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/31/world.print_headline: Judge Urges World to Heed Rwanda Crisis
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/31/world.body_text: **********A South African judge who signed the first indictments for genocide issued by an international panel investigating massacres in Rwanda in 1994 says that a lack of cooperation from African nations is hampering efforts to bring the accused to justice. **********"I feel a sense of urgency in Rwanda," said Navanethem Pillay, a defense lawyer and the first black woman to be appointed to the South African Supreme Court. Ms. Pillay is one of six members of the panel on Rwanda, part of the International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague. **********As Ms. Pillay spoke in interviews on Thursday and today, there were reports  from Zaire of the arrests of 8 to 10 Rwandans near the Goma refugee camps on charges of intimidating Rwandan refugees who want to return home. Among those detained was Francois Karera, a former mayor of Kigali, the Rwandan capital, whom human rights groups consider a central figure in genocidal attacks on Tutsi and moderate Hutu in the spring of 1994. After the slaughter erupted, Tutsi rebels drove out the Hutu-dominated Government. **********Mr. Karera is not among the eight Rwandans indicted this fall by the war crimes tribunal, which focused its first cases on killings around the western town of Kibuye. But as a refugee living in luxury apart from fellow Rwandans in  Zaire, Mr. Karera, a Hutu, had made no attempt to hide his contempt for Tutsi people. Although he was vague about what he was doing when massacres took place  in Kigali, he is considered a candidate for an indictment on genocide charges. **********In August 1994, Mr. Karera told a reporter: "The Tutsi are originally bad. If the reasons are just, the massacres are justified." **********Mr. Karera, formally accused of genocide by the new Tutsi-led Rwanda Government, appears to have irritated the Zairians not for activities in Rwanda  but for efforts as a member of a Hutu party, the Rally for a Return to Democracy in Rwanda, to organize resistance to the return of Rwandan refugees from Zaire.  The others arrested by Zaire were apparently also party members. **********Zaire would like to empty the camps of about a million remaining refugees, many of them Hutu fearful of Tutsi reprisals, a terror played on by leaders like Mr. Karera. Last fall, the Zairian Army made attempts to evict them by force before being assured by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees that an orderly return would be organized as soon as possible. **********Justice Pillay welcomed the reports of arrests in Zaire today, but said that  the Zairians have not been willing to discuss the tribunal's cases with international prosecutors or with Justice Richard Goldstone, the South African who heads the Rwanda panel and a similar one on former Yugoslavia from his base  in The Hague. Resistance has also been demonstrated by other African countries,  including Kenya, where President Daniel Arap Moi threatened to arrest prosecutors. Other Kenyan officials have since intervened to temper those comments. **********Ms. Pillay, 54, a lawyer from Natal province, said that her experience in supporting the creation of a commission in South Africa to investigate political crimes during apartheid convinced her that Rwanda must have the same opportunity. Without the healing that comes from seeing justice done, she said,  Rwandans cannot build a new society or resist demands for revenge. **********"Judges must raise their voices," she said, dropping the cloak of anonymity usually worn by panel members. Ms. Pillay said she appealed to African governments and the Security Council, which created the tribunal, for help in moving faster on genocide charges in Rwanda. The Rwanda panel, based in Tanzania, will be ready to try cases in February. The five other judges on the Rwanda tribunal -- which will sit as two three-member panels -- are from Bangladesh, Russia, Senegal, Sweden and Tanzania. **********But the exact whereabouts of the Rwandans identified in the first eight indictments are unknown and without the help of officials in countries where they may be living, they cannot be brought to trial. While the tribunal is seeking help from governments to find them, the names of the accused have not been made public to make it harder for them to evade arrest. **********Even so, at least one of those thought by human rights groups to be among the indicted was recently reported to have drowned in a boating accident along the Zaire-Rwanda border. Alison DesForges of Human Rights Watch/Africa, said in an interview today that there seems to be a rash of "disappearances" and "deaths" in the region that she said may be efforts to cover suspects' tracks. **********"Show me the bodies," Ms. DesForges said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/12/busin.main_headline: Manzi Departure Unlikely To Derail I.B.M.'s Plans
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/12/busin.print_headline: Manzi Departure Unlikely To Derail I.B.M.'s Plans
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/12/busin.body_text: **********For I.B.M., the abrupt departure of Jim P. Manzi is less a strategic blow than a sobering reminder of how quickly the human assets of a software company can take flight. **********It was less than four months ago that Mr. Manzi, the 43-year-old chief executive of the Lotus Development Corporation, agreed to sell Lotus to I.B.M. for $3.5 billion and join the executive ranks of I.B.M. **********Most analysts expect other Lotus executives to leave the International Business Machines Corporation in the wake of Mr. Manzi's move. But they say a trickle of departures should have scant effect on I.B.M.'s strategy for making Lotus software -- especially its Notes program -- a vehicle for growth during the next several years. **********The real danger, analysts say, would be if there were a wholesale exodus of key Lotus people from I.B.M., like the team of developers behind Notes, which enables computer-linked employees to work in far-flung teams. The head of the Notes team is Ray Ozzie, whom William H. Gates of Microsoft once called "one of  the top five programmers in the universe." **********"Manzi's departure is not any kind of derailing of I.B.M.'s strategy for Lotus," said Stuart Woodring, an analyst at Forrester Research Inc. in Cambridge, Mass. "But if Ozzie and a few others left, that would be a real problem." **********I.B.M. paid cash for Lotus, which means that people like Mr. Ozzie instantly  became multimillionaires thanks to their Lotus shares. And despite reports that  Mr. Ozzie has a contract to complete two more upgrades of Notes, which could keep him at I.B.M. for another 18 months or so, one executive close to Lotus said there was no contract holding Mr. Ozzie. Mr. Ozzie could not be reached for comment yesterday. **********Keeping the key Lotus developers and managers within the I.B.M. fold, and keeping them motivated and productive, is vital if I.B.M. is going to make a success of its software business in the future. **********Today, I.B.M.'s sizable software business is largely dependent on the company's mainframe and mini-computer lines, and is growing very little, according to Stephen K. Smith, an analyst for Paine Webber Inc. **********Since 1988, I.B.M.'s software revenues have increased by just $1 billion, to  $11 billion last year, Mr. Smith estimated. During the same period, he said, the total computer software market has grown to $75 billion from $30 billion. **********"I.B.M. desperately needs to get growth from the software business, and that's what the Lotus acquisition was about," Mr. Smith said. **********Armed with Lotus Notes, I.B.M. hopes to retain its corporate customers and to finally beat the Microsoft Corporation in an important product category. Despite spending heavily, I.B.M. has been unable to make its OS/2 desktop operating program any kind of a rival to Microsoft's Windows. **********Major corporations increasingly want their employees to share documents, reports and financial information across time zones and borders. Lotus Notes is  the leading program that enables this kind of teamwork -- a software category called groupware. **********Recently, Notes has become a hot product among large industrial companies, banks and high-tech concerns. Installations are expected to double this year to  roughly 2.6 million. And significantly for I.B.M., Microsoft has been an uncharacteristic laggard in groupware. **********Yet so far, most analysts said, the early signs from the I.B.M.-Lotus merger  look encouraging, despite Mr. Manzi's surprise departure. Last July, for example, I.B.M. executives announced that Lotus products like cc:mail, Lotus Organizer and Lotus Approach would be the standard desktop offerings from I.B.M. **********"To date, the integration of the two companies is ahead of schedule," said John B. Jones Jr., an analyst for Salomon Brothers Inc. **********Investors apparently agreed, shrugging off news of Mr. Manzi's resignation. I.B.M. shares closed yesterday at $92.50, up $1.75. **********"The direction of change at I.B.M. is still upward," said Dan Mandresh, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/22/world.main_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;British Woman Convicted Of 3 Mass Murder Counts
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/22/world.print_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;British Woman Convicted Of 3 Mass Murder Counts
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/22/world.body_text: **********As one of Britain's most infamous mass murder trials drew to a close, a 41-year-old woman was found guilty today of the brutal murder of three girls, including her 16-year-old daughter and eight-year-old stepdaughter. **********The woman, Rosemary West, remained stone-faced as the foreman of the 11-member jury in Winchester read the verdicts. The jury will resume deliberations Wednesday on seven other murder charges against Mrs. West, who faces life in prison. **********The case has gripped Britain since February 1994, when the police, investigating the 1987 disappearance of Mrs. West's daughter, Heather, found instruments of sexual torture, dismembered bodies and human bones buried in the  house and garden Mrs. West shared with her husband and their eight children. **********The bodies belonged to a series of teen-age girls and young women, many of them runaways, whom Mrs. West and her husband, Frederick, had befriended. **********Mr. West confessed to the murders and told the police he was the lone killer. But he hanged himself in prison in January, leaving his wife to face the charges alone. Mrs. West said she had no knowledge that her husband had murdered anyone.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/busin.body_text: **********Theratech Inc. said yesterday that it had asked the Food and Drug Administration to approve its estrogen skin patch and that it planned to make similar applications in Europe early next year. Theratech, based in Salt Lake City, made the announcement with the Procter & Gamble Company of Cincinnati, which has exclusive marketing rights to the patch everywhere but in Asia. The patches deliver Estradiol, the main female estrogenic hormone, through the skin, generally for post-menopausal women with osteoporosis.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/01/busin.main_headline: Breach of Agreement Is Charged In Big California Health Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/01/busin.print_headline: Breach of Agreement Is Charged In Big California Health Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/01/busin.body_text: **********Health Systems International said yesterday that Wellpoint Health Networks and Blue Cross of California were in breach of the terms of an agreement to acquire Health Systems for $1.89 billion in stock. **********The move followed an announcement on Monday that Dr. Malik Hasan, chairman and chief executive of Health Systems, and five other big shareholders in that company had withdrawn their support for the deal. **********Both sides maneuvered to avoid blame for breaking the deal, which could mean a $50 million penalty. Yesterday, a Health Systems board committee proposed submitting the dispute to mediation by a former California Attorney General, John Van de Kamp. Mr. Van de Kamp is a lawyer for the California Wellness Foundation, which is a major holder of nonvoting Health Systems stock. **********Health Systems said Wellpoint and Blue Cross had failed to address concerns raised by its board. In a letter, it demanded that the two companies correct the reported breaches within 10 business days. **********Health Systems said it objected to the nomination of individuals with close personal or business ties to Wellpoint's chairman, Leonard Schaeffer, to the board of the combined company and attempts to limit Dr. Hasan's responsibilities. **********The company further said Wellpoint had failed to report that its California Care Health Plan business could be denied accreditation. **********Wellpoint, which is 80 percent owned by California Blue Cross, agreed in April to buy Health Systems. That would be followed by a recapitalization that would pay $1.2 billion to Wellpoint stockholders, including Blue Cross. **********Dr. Hasan and the five other shareholders who withdrew their support of the acquisition plan together control about 25 percent of Health Systems' shares. **********In a five-page letter filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Dr.  Hasan accused Wellpoint and Blue Cross of fraud. He accused Mr. Schaeffer of fraudulently misrepresenting key facts regarding the proposed merger, including  an agreement to share responsibility for acquisitions, and of inflating Wellpoint's membership. **********Earlier yesterday, Wellpoint and Blue Cross rejected the accusations, calling them untrue and "a smokescreen for renegotiating the deal." John Cygul, a Wellpoint spokesman, accused Health Systems International of engaging in a "reckless and irresponsible campaign to renegotiate the definitive agreement signed by all parties." Neither side has disclosed the text of the agreement.
