https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/world.main_headline: U.S. Responds Calmly to Communist Gains in Russian Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/world.print_headline: U.S. Responds Calmly to Communist Gains in Russian Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/world.body_text: **********The Clinton Administration responded with equanimity today to the preliminary outcome of parliamentary elections in Russia, despite the revival at the polls of the once-moribund Communist Party. **********"I think there's a sense of calm and perspective about this election," said Nicholas Burns, the State Department spokesman. **********Mr. Burns said the outcome, which was largely expected, was inconclusive in  the fractured political environment of 43 parties, even though the Communists have gained more than 20 percent of the votes reported when today's round of counting ended. **********The results so far indicate that the Communists are replacing the nationalist party of Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky as the leading anti-reform element in the lower house of Parliament. But Administration officials said they did not see any need to adjust Washington's policy toward Russia and the Government of Boris N. Yeltsin. **********Even the apparent plurality achieved by the Communists leaves them well short of a working majority, said Administration officials, who concluded that more than three in four Russian voters did not support a return to the past. They noted that the Communist surge was offset by a decline in support for Mr. Zhirinovsky's nationalists, which meant that the coalition of forces opposing President Yeltsin's liberalization policies had not really increased. **********"At this point, I think it seems likely that the new Duma that was elected yesterday will not be strikingly different than the Duma that has been in session for the last few years," Mr. Burns said today, referring to the lower house of the Parliament. In essence, he said, the results mean that one-third of the legislators would oppose economic reform, another third would support it and the rest would be in the middle. **********The votes reported so far apply to seats allocated to political parties, which account for only half of the 450 seats in the lower house. The results for remaining seats will not be known for some days. Those seats are elected from among individual candidates who represent themselves and are expected to hew more closely to the center because they will be elected foremost on the basis of local issues. **********Because the lower house of Parliament is constitutionally much weaker than the presidency, Administration officials are also treating yesterday's elections as a kind of rehearsal for the presidential elections next June that will determine Mr. Yeltsin's political survival. **********It also seems likely that the Administration has been looking beyond President Yeltsin, who is not only politically unpopular at home but also suffered a heart attack recently, to identify younger, more vigorous Russian politicians who support economic reform. **********Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, said, "What remains clear after the election is that the political culture of Russia is still multi-faceted and quite dynamic, with a lot of different participants, a lot of  different factions, a lot of different points of view of what Russia's political future should hold." **********While conceding that the Communists had made a strong showing, Mr. McCurry said, "We also believe that there is a strong presence in the newly elected Duma of reformers and those committed to democracy and market economics." **********Even so, Administration officials acknowledge some discomfort with the new prominence of the Communists, whose leader, Gennadi Zyuganov, has spoken of reconstituting the Soviet Union. **********"It certainly doesn't hearten those of us who believe in democracy and reform," Mr. Burns said at today's State Department briefing. **********But another senior Administration official observed that it would be hard to  put the Soviet Union back together because Russia, like the West, recognizes the sovereignty of the other former Soviet republics. **********"Russians are looking to the future, not looking to turn back the clock, but  they have very different ideas of what the future should be," he said. **********The official observed that foreign policy issues had not figured in the recent political campaign, which focused far more on the debate over Russia's troubled transition to a market economy. **********The final composition of the lower house, and its variance with President Yeltsin, will not become clear until it is known how many political parties garner 5 percent or more of the total vote, which is the threshhold for inclusion in the legislature. **********Dr. Harvey D. Balzer, director of the Center for Eurasian, Russian and East European Studies at Georgetown University, agreed that the outcome so far did not pose a threat to the Administration's relationship with Moscow. "Overall, it probably deserves a sigh of relief," he said. **********Mr. Burns, who previously served as a Russian affairs specialist in the National Security Council, offered another reason for the relative calm with which the Administration accepted the election news. When the nationalists under Mr. Zhirinovsky made gains in the first parliamentary elections in 1993, Mr. Burns recalled, "there was pretty much shock" inside the White House. This time  around, he said, it was expected that perhaps a third of the Russians would not  be reconciled to change.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/busin.main_headline: Southwest Air to Cut Flights in February
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/busin.print_headline: Southwest Air to Cut Flights in February
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/busin.body_text: **********The Southwest Airlines Company said today that it would cut 16 flights from its schedule in February because the strike at the Boeing Company had delayed the delivery of new jets. **********Two Boeing 737-300's scheduled for delivery in November have not arrived, and Southwest said it expected delays of at least some of the nine planes scheduled  for delivery in the first quarter of 1996. Southwest is scheduled to receive three 737's a month in the first quarter, half of the 18 jets it is scheduled to get next year. **********The canceled flights amount to eight round trips and are distributed throughout the carrier's schedule. **********Southwest will cut two round trips between Chicago and Detroit and one each from Chicago to St. Louis and Columbus, Ohio. Round trips from Oakland, Calif, to Phoenix and Spokane, Wash., will be eliminated, as will a round trip from St. Louis to Houston. Southwest will also drop a round trip from Phoenix to San Diego. The changes take effect on Feb. 27. **********The airline said it had no plans to delay its expansion into Florida, which is scheduled to begin in late January. **********Boeing and the machinists' union agreed on Tuesday to resume talks aimed at ending the 61-day strike at the plant near Seattle. The talks are the first since Nov. 22, when the 32,500 union members, about one-third of Boeing's work force, rejected a three-year contract proposal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/24/world.main_headline: THE U.N. AT 50: GENERAL ASSEMBLY;Money on Their Minds, Leaders Tell U.N. to Trim Down
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/24/world.print_headline: THE U.N. AT 50: GENERAL ASSEMBLY;Money on Their Minds, Leaders Tell U.N. to Trim Down
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/24/world.body_text: **********Beset by economic uncertainties at home and preoccupied by the shadow of bankruptcy looming over the United Nations, world leaders speaking here today could not avoid the subject of money. **********The financial predicament has added urgency to calls for reform of the United Nations and may make it easier for the United States and other industrial nations to curtail their support sharply and possibly to force the United Nations to close about half a dozen agencies. This would be the most extensive shrinking and restructuring of the organization in its half-century of existence. **********Today Prime Minister John Major of Britain used the toughest language heard  so far in calling for a smaller, more efficient organization. **********"Is the U.N. spread too wide?" he asked. "I believe it is." **********"Is too much time and energy spent on ritual verbal battles, brilliantly interpreted into six languages and printed on the world's highest paper mountain?" he said. "Of course it is." **********Officials traveling with Mr. Major say that he has a number of United Nations agencies in mind for reduction or elimination. The list is the same one from which the Clinton Administration is working as it tries to negotiate with Congress over a reform plan. **********Until the Administration can make some concessions to Congress on foreign spending issues, money to pay more than $1.2 billion in overdue American assessments to the United Nations will not be forthcoming. Today both Britain and France joined a host of other nations in publicly deploring deadbeats. **********American officials acknowledge that the agencies now under the most severe scrutiny are the United Nations Industrial Development Organization, which the Administration says has been made redundant by other agencies, and the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, whose functions may be overtaken by the new World Trade Organization. **********In addition, United States officials say, a plan to rejoin Unesco, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, from which the United States withdrew in 1984, has all but been abandoned for the foreseeable future,  and there are serious doubts about continued support for the Food and Agricultural Organization and the International Labor Organization. **********The agencies and organizations have also been criticized by Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and by other Republican leaders. The Clinton Administration appears ready to sacrifice American membership or support for the agencies if doing so will unlock money, votes on treaties and the confirmation of diplomats, all of which are being held up by the Republicans. **********Today Mr. Major and President Jacques Chirac of France -- each saying his country had contributed the largest number of peacekeeping troops to the United  Nations -- both spoke more concretely about reforming the United Nations than President Clinton did in his speech to more than 140 world leaders on Sunday. **********Mr. Chirac proposed the appointment of a new Under Secretary General to oversee all development work and to be the "strong-arm executor" coordinating various agencies. **********Fears that development assistance may fall off played a part in the drafting  of a strong set of speeches from African leaders -- delivered by chance on the same day. **********Presidents Nelson Mandela of South Africa, Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, Brig. Gen. Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo of Equatorial Guinea, and Foreign Minister Destin Tsaty-Boungou of the Republic of the Congo were among those who asked that the world not turn away from poor nations, especially in Africa, which is falling further and further behind other developing regions in standards of living. Several African leaders blamed the heritage of colonialism for continuing poverty and social stress. **********President Jerry Rawlings of Ghana, saying with some passion that "we feel the hunger in the midst of plenty," added that for his continent, "the next 50 years will be even more crucial than the past 50 years." **********He added, "We cannot help being struck by the fact that the international community is willing to spend $5 million a day on U.N. peacekeeping operations in Bosnia-Herzegovina, and we would not begrudge those noble people such international solidarity. **********"But when we have asked for a sum that represents 10 to 15 days of that bill  to help those of us in Africa making every possible effort to assist ourselves with our meager resources, there is deafening silence." **********Behind the scenes today, more than 70 private meetings took place between leaders in dozens of instant conference rooms created by temporarily partitioning areas of the first and second floors of the United Nations headquarters. More conversations took place at lunches or over coffee in the basement Viennese coffee shop. **********Although they do not get the attention of a Clinton-Yeltsin summit, the large number of usually unpublicized, off-camera meetings between other leaders is evidence of the extensive use of the United Nations as a one-stop diplomatic hub. Visiting leaders not only met each other but also lobbied heads of United Nations agencies. **********Foreign Minister Amr Moussa of Egypt, on his way to meet King Hussein of Jordan after sessions with the Prime Minister of Morocco and the President of Azerbaijan, said that he had been trying to activate some Islamic opinion on Bosnia as he went from meeting to meeting within the building. **********"That saves time and effort," he said. "You don't even have to cross the street."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/26/world.main_headline: World News Briefs;Results Are Announced For Russian Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/26/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;Results Are Announced For Russian Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/26/world.body_text: **********Results of last week's parliamentary election were announced by Russia's Central Electoral Commission today, indicating that the Communist Party will control 158 of 450 seats in the lower house of Parliament. **********Half the seats in that body are elected by single-seat constituencies. The other 225 are elected according to party lists with a minimum five percent of the vote needed to win seats. The exact allocation of party list seats will be announced later.  According to the estimates released today, the Communists would have 158 seats, including 58 elected in single-seat constituencies, in the lower house, or Duma. Ultra-nationalists in the Liberal Democratic Party would have 51 seats, with only one from a single-seat vote. **********Our House is Russia, the Government-supported party led by Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, would have 54 seats, with 10 of those from single-seat constituencies. The liberal Yabloko Party would have 45, with 14 from single-seat elections.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/busin.main_headline: Market Place;Hot Internet Stocks Soar: Stampede or A Squeeze?
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/busin.print_headline: Market Place;Hot Internet Stocks Soar: Stampede or A Squeeze?
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/busin.body_text: **********Internet stocks -- already among the market leaders -- shot higher yesterday  and have soared 20 percent or more in just the last few trading days. To some, it looks like the greatest bull stampede ever. To others, it appears that short-sellers are being squeezed like never before. **********"The Internet stocks remind me of the riverboat gambling stocks of a few years ago," said Emanuel Geduld, the president of Herzog Heine Geduld, a major market maker in the Nasdaq market. "The public loves these stocks." **********But there may be more to it than that. Recent trading patterns -- many Internet stocks have doubled over the last month -- make it look like short-sellers have been forced to buy to stem losses. A short-seller, who bets that stocks are overvalued and will decline, sells borrowed shares and, eventually, must buy shares to repay the loan. **********Wall Street rumors say that some market makers -- brokers who stand ready to  buy and sell stocks to meet public demand -- found sellers scarce and ended up going short whether or not they intended to do so. Whether that is true cannot be confirmed, but even the speculation can help to bring out buyers hoping to drive up the price and force short-sellers to buy shares in an effort to avoid even bigger losses. **********Mr. Geduld said his firm had resisted the temptation to short any of the stocks. "Intellectually, they all appear like great shorts," he said. "But when  they are on a feeding frenzy like this, it is best to step aside." **********Yesterday's spurt came despite the fact most stock averages dipped, including the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell 6.86 points, to 4,983.09, after briefly trading over 5,000. [Page D8.] **********And the Internet boom is coming at a time when many technology stocks have weakened. For example, the Philadelphia semiconductor index, which fell 11.41 points yesterday, to 217.78, is now down 28 percent from the peak it reached in  September. Microsoft, the pre-eminent computer software company, fell $1.375 yesterday, to $86, and was off 22 percent from its peak. **********It may be, however, that the Internet frenzy peaked, at least for now, during yesterday's trading. After 2 P.M., many of the stocks gave up a good part of the gains they had recorded earlier in the day, although they all ended with substantial gains. Spyglass, for example, traded as high as $112 before ending the day at $104.75, a gain of $4.25 during the day. Netscape closed at $116.25,  up $5.75 from Friday, but down $8.50 from the peak. **********The market argument for the Internet stocks is that they are going to benefit from the next great change in the computer marketplace, in which communications  are so cheap that it makes sense to do everything effectively on the Internet rather than have a lot of computing power at your home or office. Instead, you can use so-called dumb terminals that cost much less, hooked into both memory and software away from your site. **********That may work out. But it is likely to be awhile, and it is clear that the high value now being put on Internet stocks by the market is wildly out of line  with insider expectations only a few months ago. **********Netscape, for example, the premier company making software to let computer owners get onto the Internet, went public in August at $28 a share. That in itself was a dramatic increase from the $12 price the company was willing to take, with insiders selling some of their own shares. At yesterday's peak, the price was 10 times that. **********Or consider Spyglass, which also provides Internet access and has software to let companies offer products and services on the Worldwide Web. It went public in June at $17, although it and its insiders had been willing to sell for as little as $11. It too hit 10 times that figure in yesterday's trading. **********Uunet -- pronounced "you-you-net" is another provider of Internet access. It  went public at $14 a share, although its insiders were willing to take as little as $10. At its peak yesterday of $98.75, it was worth just less than 10 times that price, making it the laggard in the group. It closed yesterday at $93.25. **********Another way of looking at those hot three is that at their public offering prices, the companies were worth a total of $1.5 billion. A month ago, they were worth $6.1 billion. Now they are valued at $7.5 billion. **********There are many other stocks -- some of them with only marginal connection to  the Internet -- that have profited in the boom. But the latest initial public offering to do so was that of Secure Computing, which went public last week at $16 a share, although insiders had been willing to take as little as $13. It offers an "Internet firewall" product that is supposed to protect computers hooked up to the net from unauthorized entry by hackers. **********On its first day of trading Friday, the share price leaped to $48.25. Yesterday, it traded as high as $59.50 before ending the day at $55.50. **********Secure, unlike some other hot initial public offerings, has an operating history and has shown a profit. But that profit and history were based on its old business of government contracting. Its new business, of selling computer safety systems to commercial customers, is barely a year old, with the product announced last November and first shipped in March. Through Sept. 30, it had sold 42 units and had orders for 13 more. **********Including management options -- managers get to buy shares for as little as 59 cents each -- the market is now valuing Secure Computing at $373 million. With total revenues for the last 12 months of nearly $19 million, that works into a price-to-revenues ratio of 20. Clearly, great things are expected. **********When an initial public offering is hot, it is all but impossible for most investors to get an allocation, and many of the buyers who get in on the offering are professionals who want to make money rapidly and get out. Each of the stocks mentioned above saw first-day Nasdaq volume of more than the number of shares that had been sold in the offering, indicating a lot of flipping. **********Those who got in the first day of public trading paid up for their shares, but all have since had a chance to sell at good profits. Just how long those profits will last depends in part on how great the public enthusiasm gets to be, and in part on how many short-sellers there still are with big losses and hopes  that the prices will come down.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/25/world.main_headline: Bosnian Serb Leader Signals Acceptance of Peace Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/25/world.print_headline: Bosnian Serb Leader Signals Acceptance of Peace Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/25/world.body_text: **********In his first public statement since a peace agreement was reached, Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader, said this evening that his government had accepted the agreement and the fact that the military struggle that began nearly four years ago is over. **********"We accept the peace," Dr. Karadzic said in a televised interview this evening. Although the Bosnian Serbs are not happy with many of the provisions of the Washington-brokered agreement, Dr. Karadzic said, "the time has come to switch to political ways to achieve our goals." **********Dr. Karadzic, who appeared subdued if not defeated in the one-hour interview from his headquarters in Pale, in Bosnia and Herzegovina, sought to put the current reality in the best light for the Bosnian Serbs. **********A few months ago, he noted, the Bosnian Serbs controlled 64 percent of the territory of Bosnia, and under the accords negotiated in Dayton, Ohio, they will get only 49 percent. Still, he said, "We have achieved our objectives. We have half of Bosnia; we have more than 40 cities; we also got some good land." **********And even though the self-declared Bosnian Serb republic, of which he is considered president, has not been recognized as an independent state, it has been recognized as an entity within Bosnia, he noted. The other entity is the Croat-Muslim federation. **********Dr. Karadzic said nothing about his own political future, which has been a matter of great speculation. Under the terms of the Dayton agreement, Dr. Karadzic will be barred from politics because he has been indicted by the international war crimes tribunal. **********The Bosnian peace agreement was initialed on Tuesday in Dayton by the Presidents of Serbia, Croatia and Bosnia, but the Bosnian Serb representatives refused to initial it and did not acquiesce until Thursday, after intense pressure from the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic. **********Dr. Karadzic's public acknowledgment that he accepted the peace agreement would seem to move the Clinton Administration a step closer to deploying the 20,000 troops it has promised as part of a 60,000-member NATO force to enforce the peace. Without sounding bellicose, Dr. Karadzic made it clear that the peacekeepers will not be out of harm's way and may face a greater task than expected. **********Likening Sarajevo to Jerusalem, he said the peacekeepers would have to protect the Serbs in the city. **********"The Muslims will regret that they opted for this solution," Dr. Karadzic said about the unification of Sarajevo. The Bosnian Serbs had wanted the city divided between Serbs and Muslims. Dr. Karadzic said the Serbs would resist Muslim-Croat control and will want to have their own police and their own schools. **********According to the Bosnian Serbs, there are 120,000 Serbs in the Sarajevo suburbs that will now come under Bosnian control. The United Nations puts the number at closer to 50,000. **********"The international community will have to protect the Serbs in Sarajevo," he  said. "We will demand protection for five years, at least." **********Not all Bosnian Serb leaders were as conciliatory as Dr. Karadzic. Ratko Adzic, mayor of the Serbian-controlled Sarajevo suburb of Ilijas, said, "We will use all forces to fight for our city and our property," according to a Belgrade  television report. Mr. Adzic and other leaders from the Serbian suburbs had been summoned to Pale to meet with Dr. Karadzic. **********And though Dr. Karadzic did not criticize Mr. Milosevic, his political rival, other Bosnian Serb leaders have accused the Serbian President of having betrayed the Bosnian Serbs in Dayton. **********On a television program in Belgrade this evening, Biljana Plavsic, a vice president of the unofficial Bosnian Serb republic, accused Mr. Milosevic of having given away more territory than he had been authorized to. **********The Bosnian Serbs are angry that Mr. Milosevic gave up land in a corridor in  the northeast of the country and in a corridor that links Sarajevo with the Muslim enclave at Gorazde. **********During the television interview, Dr. Karadzic used maps to show the territorial divisions the Serbs had wanted. **********Mr. Milosevic also overruled the Bosnian Serbs on the deployment of NATO troops, said Momcilo Krajisnik, speaker of the Bosnian Serbs' self-declared parliament. **********"We did not want NATO troops on Serbian-held territory," said Mr. Krajisnik,  who appeared on Bosnian Serb television with Mr. Milosevic. "Milosevic outvoted  us." **********And the Americans virtually ignored the Bosnian Serbs, he said. Dr. Karadzic  criticized Washington for siding with the Muslims. "Since the beginning of the war, they have kept them from total defeat," he said, and in Dayton the American negotiators drew a map that favored the Muslims, he said. **********Other developments in Bosnia today underscored the politically complex and militarily precarious terrain the new peace force will enter. **********In the early morning hours, some 200 troops of the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government raided a United Nations camp, firing machine guns over the heads of Bangladeshi peacekeepers and stealing nine armored vehicles, United Nations officials in Sarajevo said. There were no reported casualties. **********And the United Nations in Sarajevo also reported that soldiers of the Bosnian Croat army were burning and looting homes in an area of northwestern Bosnia that is to be returned to Serbian control. The Bosnian Croat army, though nominally part of the federation, has operated largely independently of the Bosnian Government, though the troops are supposed to be unified under the Dayton agreement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/22/world.main_headline: Japanese Premier Vows to Renew Leases on U.S. Bases in Okinawa
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/22/world.print_headline: Japanese Premier Vows to Renew Leases on U.S. Bases in Okinawa
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/22/world.body_text: **********Easing a sore point with the United States, Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama  declared today that he would force Japanese landowners to renew leases for property that is used for American bases. **********The first of the leases expires next March. If Mr. Murayama does not intervene then part of the land on an American base will revert to its Japanese  owner. **********While Mr. Murayama's decision clears the way for continued operation of American bases, it also underscores the growing sensitivity of the American military presence, particularly on the southern Japanese island of Okinawa. The  leases involved are on Okinawa, where the American bases are concentrated. **********The decision was particularly painful for Mr. Murayama, the head of the Socialist Party and a lifelong opponent of American bases in Japan. But he has had to abandon most of his Socialist positions since being installed as Prime Minister by a conservative-dominated coalition. **********"Time is running out," Mr. Murayama told reporters later, and indeed time may already have run out. The legal procedure for Mr. Murayama to force an extension of the leases is so cumbersome that it is not clear that it can be completed by  March. **********Normally, it is the Governor of Okinawa who would sign the documents to force owners to lease their land for bases or other public uses. But the Governor, an American-trained scholar named Masahide Ota, has refused to sign and has demanded that American troops be gradually withdrawn from Okinawa. **********Mr. Ota's stance against the American bases is enormously popular. A recent poll found that 89 percent of Okinawans supported his stand, along with 78 percent of Japanese nationwide. **********Antagonism toward the American military presence, always evident in Okinawa,  has grown sharply since the rape in September of a 12-year-old girl, in which three American servicemen have been charged. The men have pleaded guilty and are now on trial. **********The next step is for Prime Minister Murayama to advise Mr. Ota to sign the documents forcing the extension of the leases. Then, when Mr. Ota rejects the advice, Mr. Murayama can order Mr. Ota to sign. **********When Mr. Ota refuses to obey the order, as he is expected to, Mr. Murayama can go to court to compel him to do so. Finally, if Mr. Ota still refuses, Mr. Murayama can sign the necessary documents himself. **********The dispute over the land-use rights has cast a shadow over attempts by American and Japanese officials to reaffirm the importance of the American military presence in Japan. Before it was put off because of the budget impasse  in Washington, President Clinton had been planning a state visit to Japan to underscore the importance of the security relationship. Security issues are still expected to be the centerpiece of Mr. Clinton's visit when it is rescheduled for some time early next year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/23/world.main_headline: 3 Lawyers Plan to Aid Servicemen In Okinawa
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/23/world.print_headline: 3 Lawyers Plan to Aid Servicemen In Okinawa
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/23/world.body_text: **********Three American lawyers plan to help defend three American servicemen now on trial for the abduction and rape of a 12-year-old Okinawa girl by challenging the Japanese investigation that, they contend, may have resulted in coerced confessions. **********The three lawyers -- Eric V. Ross of Atlanta, Michael J. Griffith of Southampton, L.I., and Charles Beach of Clinton, Tenn. -- have never met their clients, who come from small towns in Georgia and Texas. Their only direct information from the servicemen comes from letters and telephone calls to relatives in which one complained about "coaching" by Japanese investigators. **********The servicemen pleaded guilty earlier this month to conspiracy to abduct and rape a Okinawa schoolgirl in September, an incident that has prompted demonstrations and criticism of the United States military presence in Okinawa.  Their trial will continue on Dec. 4, and at least one of the American lawyers plans to attend the next session to monitor the proceedings. **********The American lawyers say the servicemen were pressured into admitting their guilt when they entered a plea at the beginning of the trial earlier this month. "An independent investigation needs to be done into the veracity of their statements," Mr. Ross said. **********The lawyers cite letters home from Seaman Marcus D. Gill that were written in September when United States military officials were transporting the men daily  to the Japanese police office in Okinawa for hours of questioning. **********In a letter to his wife, Mr. Gill described sitting in a room with a Japanese investigator for eight hours a day. In another note to his father, he said the Japanese would not allow a lawyer present while they were being questioned. **********"I've been 'coached' (forced by Japanese police) into making statements the way the victims describe," Seaman Gill wrote. "At the time the victim was raped, I was in my quarters, but they do not want to hear that." **********Japanese officials maintain that the lawyers are raising irrelevant issues because all three servicemen openly pleaded guilty in court to a rape conspiracy charge. **********"They admitted their guilt, although the two servicemen denied actual sexual  intercourse," said Tatsuya Sakuma, first secretary at the Japanese Embassy in Washington. "Still, they admitted their guilt to abducting the child. So why are these allegations of coerced confessions being raised in connection with the case?" **********But lawyers on the newly formed legal team said they have doubts about whether the current Japanese lawyers, whose fees are being paid by the United States military, are acting agressively enough to represent the servicemen. **********"They may be under a lot of pressure to do the right thing," said Mr. Griffith, who is a partner in a law firm that specializes in representing Americans arrested overseas. He represented William Hayes Jr., an American whose imprisonment on drug charges in a Turkish jail was the basis of the book and movie "Midnight Express. **********Unable to talk to the servicemen by telephone, Mr. Griffith is preparing to fly to Japan to interview them and attend the next trial session. The American lawyers are also seeking to hire Japanese investigators to assist in their defense. **********The American authorities were originally led to the suspects by a fourth serviceman who had been with them earlier the same evening and said he heard them discuss plans for abducting a girl. **********The three men are accused of abducting the sixth-grade girl from the street and raping her in the back seat of their rented car. Prosecutors contend that the servicemen planned the attack, purchasing condoms and adhesive tape to cover the victims's eyes and mouth and to bind her feet and hands. If convicted, they  face sentences of three years to life. **********The money for the new legal effort is being raised by the families of the servicemen, who come from Woodville, Tex., and Griffin and Waycross, Ga., through local fund-raising dinners and church collections.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/world.main_headline: World News Briefs;French Set Last A-Test For February, Not May
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;French Set Last A-Test For February, Not May
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/world.body_text: **********France will conduct its last nuclear test in February, months earlier than planned, Defense Minister Charles Millon said today. **********France has conducted four tests at a remote South Pacific atoll since September, when it broke a three-year moratorium. It has pledged to sign a nuclear test ban treaty as soon as six to eight tests are completed. **********The last French nuclear test should be before the end of February 1996, well before the date initially announced, May 31, 1996," Mr. Millon said. France insists the tests are necessary to develop computer simulation technology to make further tests unnecessary.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/25/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;HAMBURGER HAMLET IS CLOSING A THIRD OF ITS STORES
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/25/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;HAMBURGER HAMLET IS CLOSING A THIRD OF ITS STORES
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/25/busin.body_text: **********Hamburger Hamlet Restaurants Inc. said yesterday that it was closing a third  of its stores and would file for Chapter 11 reorganization in a move to return to profitability. The restaurant chain also said it had reached a tentative agreement with its bank to finance "certain near-term working capital needs." It did not provide details. On Nov. 9, the company reported a widening loss and said it could not draw on the remaining $1.8 million of a bank credit line because it had violated part of its loan agreement. The restaurant chain said it was closing 12 restaurants, effective yesterday, leaving it with 19.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/11/busin.main_headline: Europeans Buy Home PC's At Record Pace
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/11/busin.print_headline: Europeans Buy Home PC's At Record Pace
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/11/busin.body_text: **********An avid keyboard player, Mario Tronco paid $2,100 six months ago for a personal computer that he hooks up to a 48-track digital recording system to produce mesmerizing music for his band, Avion Travel. When Mr. Tronco is not composing, his wife uses the computer, a simple I.B.M. clone, for her translation business. **********Growing up two decades ago in Caserta, a workaday town outside Naples, the 32-year-old musician attended schools with no computers. **********Computers?" The idea made him laugh. "They didn't have central heating," he recalled. But his cousin's 5-year-old son, Nicola, growing up in Caserta today,  "turns the family computer on and off, perfectly at ease," Mr. Tronco said. **********The bets of Europe's computer industry are riding on the likes of Nicola. With improvement in European economies in the last year or two, sales of personal computers have boomed, growing at rates of 25 percent to 30 percent in  each of the first three quarters of this year, after years of erratic growth. **********Feeding the boom is a fierce price war, as personal computer makers from Europe, Japan and the United States flood the market with fancier and cheaper machines intended to woo computer-shy Europeans. **********The European divisions of American companies are getting their share of the action. Compaq and the International Business Machines Corporation are the No. 1 and No. 2 suppliers, respectively, and Apple Computer, Hewlett-Packard and Dell  rank in the top 10. **********Europe's manufacturers are struggling hard against the American assault. Siemens Nixdorf and Escom A.G., in which the German industrial giant Siemens A.G. holds a 10 percent stake, have had to cut prices steeply to increase their  share of the market. Olivetti of Italy lost $162 million on personal computers last year, and though it is fighting back with a new home computer system called Envision, some industry experts fear it may be the European computer war's first fatality. **********What fuels the hopes of PC companies is that far fewer Europeans than Americans own home computers. Nearly 4 in 10 American households have a computer, but Europe is another story. In technology-minded Germany, slightly less than 20 percent of households have a computer, about the same percentage as in Britain. In France, postal authorities gave out small home terminals, called  Minitels, virtually free of charge in the 1980's to turn Frenchmen into computer enthusiasts. Yet today, only 15 percent of French households have upgraded to a  personal computer. **********As the rate of increase in the sale of home computers begins to slow in the United States, the companies that make them are spending millions to convince Europeans that their future, and their children's, should have a computer in it. **********They have learned that with computers, as with most other consumer products,  the cost of having one is greater in Europe than in the United States. Fewer Europeans than Americans are exposed to computers in schools, and fewer use them at work. More Americans work at home or bring work home from the office than do  Europeans, who more passionately defend the line between home and the workplace, according to a recent survey by Inteco, a market-research firm near London. **********Europeans, the computer makers have learned, have less access than Americans  to the global Internet, and when they do, government telephone monopolies make them pay more for them. And while the market for CD-ROM's is growing apace, Europe's fragmentation into relatively small language groups makes the cost of producing them greater than in the United States. **********Over the last two years, I.B.M. has spent millions of dollars overhauling its personal computer division, the C.P. Company, and used television and print ads  to get Europeans to try computers. The ads typically show fathers, mothers and children working or entertaining themselves at a home computer screen. **********And big manufacturers like I.B.M. and Compaq are banking on brand recognition, hoping that parents who use their products at work will buy the same brand for their children to do their homework. The companies, accustomed to providing big corporations with computer systems, are tailoring new models to home use. **********"We used to sell only Ferraris," said Aldo Meneghelli, chief of Compaq's Italian unit in Milan, which is pushing Compaq's Impresario multimedia system. "But you don't sell a Ferrari to someone who's satisfied with a Fiat." **********The manufacturers are getting a run for their money. Recently, aggressive competitors like Escom, Hewlett-Packard and Dell have cut prices as much as 20 percent to gain market share. In the third quarter Escom catapulted into third place, from seventh, by acquiring a chain of 200 retail stores in Britain, outside its home German market, then undercutting competitors' prices by about one-third. So many producers are rushing in that some analysts fear a glut in the market. **********"These are still quite high-ticket items for every household to have one," said Charles Smulders, who follows the personal computer market for Dataquest in London. "Yes, penetration of the market is higher in the United States, so the opportunity is here in Europe." But, he added, there may always be a gap between the American enthusiasm for computers and that of Europeans. **********Apartments in Europe are generally smaller than American homes, with less space available for computers and peripheral equipment. And with computers somewhat more expensive here, their purchase is more heavily tilted toward the wealthy than in the United States. American consumers now spend $1,500 to $3,000 for a typical personal computer system, while prices in Europe generally begin around $2,000 -- a bigger chunk of usually lower salaries than in America. **********Moreover, with fewer high-volume discount outlets, Europeans often buy their  computer equipment in small retail stores, where operating costs and rent are higher per unit than at the big American discounters. The value-added tax, a kind of sales tax at each stage of production and distribution, adds as much as  20 percent to the cost of a computer. **********"It's not just computers, but hi-fi's and television sets, too," said Miles Thistlethwaite, a computer analyst at Inteco. "You simply pay more in Europe." **********Cost plays a role in other ways, too. Many CD-ROM's for education or entertainment -- films, encyclopedias or children's educational aids -- are American items produced in English, and the cost of having them translated and sold in relatively small European markets is high. These costs, passed along to  the consumer, discourage Europeans from buying them in sufficient quantities to make their production profitable. **********Beyond all that, the high cost of telephone calls and on-line services often  stifles purchases of computers and modems. The European Commission has proposed  directives that demand full market deregulation by Jan. 1, 1998, but with many telephone systems still run by state monopolies for now, service in Europe is costlier than in the United States. **********Heiko Schmidt, a 20-year-old economics major at the University of Bonn, logs  onto the Internet free of charge through the university's access system. Were he to use the German post office's BTX access ports, he would pay a $15 monthly fee, plus the cost of the call. "Their system is very slow, so you wait hours,"  he said. **********In most countries, on-line access is only available in big cities, requiring  those elsewhere to make expensive long-distance calls for access. Mr. Schmitt, for instance, is discouraged from joining Compuserve because the nearest access  ports are in Frankfurt and Dusseldorf, 50 to 100 miles away. **********Despite the improvement in computer sales, the tempo of market growth slowed  in the second and third quarters of this year. But manufacturers hope that the Christmas season will revive home PC sales. **********Elio Franci, who operates 15 Arcipelago Sparta computer stores throughout northern Italy, part of Sparta S.p.A., said that the two months of November and  December generally accounted for 40 percent of sales. But echoing store owners elsewhere in Europe, he noted signs of a new European economic slowdown -- something that would not bode well for products like home computers. **********Others, paradoxically, believe that even a slowdown might provide a sales stimulus, as parents seek to equip their children for an increasingly tight job  market. **********"Parents think kids need one," Mr. Thistlethwaite of Inteco said. "It makes them more attractive for getting a job. They need skills."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/busin.body_text: **********Seven executives of the AT&T Corporation, including its chairman, Robert E. Allen, exercised options for shares worth about $17.6 million in October and November, as they cashed in on investor optimism about the company's planned three-way split. **********Mr. Allen made about $600,000 when he exercised 16,539 shares on Oct. 30, taking cash instead of shares, said Dick Gray, an AT&T spokesman. Mr. Allen's options were due to expire in January. **********The executives had the right to exercise their options for more shares or to take cash instead of shares. In total, the officials exercised options for 281,403 shares. The executives then sold or were paid cash for 244,440 shares, according to CDA/Investnet, a service that tracks insider stock purchases and sales. **********The sales are important because AT&T insiders usually hold the majority of their stake in the company in the form of options. **********The sales represent the first big block of shares sold by the executives since the company said on Sept. 20 that it would split into three companies: a telecommunications concern, a communications equipment manufacturer and a maker  of mainframe computers and automated teller machines. **********Shares of AT&T fell $1.50 yesterday, to $65.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/busin.main_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Long-Bond Yield at 6%, A 2-Year Low
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Long-Bond Yield at 6%, A 2-Year Low
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/busin.body_text: **********The yield on the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond dipped briefly below 6 percent yesterday, then closed at an even 6 percent, its lowest in more than two years, as the market rallied for a fourth consecutive day on favorable economic  data and investor optimism that a Federal budget agreement was attainable. **********Some market participants have said that as long as President Clinton and Republican leaders are still talking, there is a chance that the deadlock will be resolved in the near term. The market's price rise was limited, however, by bouts of profit taking. **********The 30-year bond rose 15/32 , to a price of 112. The yield of 6 percent was  down from 6.03 percent on Tuesday and was the lowest since Oct. 29, 1993, when it was 5.97 percent. **********Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, said that he thought a budget agreement was coming but that he did not expect a breakthrough from the scheduled talks on Friday. **********"The process has been ugly, but we remain confident that a deal is coming and will put the Government on a fundamentally more conservative fiscal path," he said. "That will be -- despite all the concern and questions -- good news for the debt and equity markets, good news for the dollar and good news for the economy." **********Few economic statistics have been available from Washington since the start of the partial Government shutdown, but the market rose yesterday after a report from a private source. The National Association of Realtors said yesterday that existing-home sales fell for the second consecutive month in November, suggesting that declining mortgage rates have not been enough to overcome the concerns of potential buyers about the slowing economy. **********Thomas E. Donne, vice president and a senior portfolio manager at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said that while recent economic news had been relatively positive for the bond market, he would not read too much into the gains yesterday, given the thin volume. **********"Most everyone, including the fund managers running sizable amounts of money  through the market, set their positions for the rest of the year almost a week ago," Mr. Donne said. "As a result, there was very little trading in the long maturities, with some buying and selling in the intermediate and shorter maturities. **********"Getting below the 6 percent yield on the long bond is not something I think  is sustainable," he added. "But I think that there is a sense in the market that the additional information it is looking for will not be long in coming. And the sooner the Government statisticians are back to work, the sooner we will get that information." **********For now, Mr. Donne said, his trading position is "on the long side of neutral," meaning that he could make a modest commitment to invest in more government securities, depending on market conditions. **********Bill Gamba, senior vice president in charge of the government trading desk at Cowen & Company, predicted that yields would fall further once there was a budget agreement. "The market is dying to do better, with the direction of interest rates headed down," he said. **********"What we need now is a credible budget deal to bring about a comfort level to entice fresh buying," he added, "and that will give the market the ability to maintain levels under 6 percent in the long end." **********In futures trading, the March Treasury bond contract hit 12031/32 , matching  its Dec. 8 high, Mr. Gamba noted. The low was 12010/32 , but that was in overnight trading. At the close, the contract was 12023/32 , up 13/32 on the day. **********"I think any decline in the market can now be used as a buying opportunity,"  he said. **********Stewart Taylor, a fixed-income market analyst at Thomson Research of Boston,  said last week's bond rally brought prices back to levels of early December. "I  suspect that the rally is a retest of those early December highs, but I do not expect any significant activity until after the new year," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/01/busin.main_headline: RJR Nabisco Refuses to Spin Off Food Unit Immediately
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/01/busin.print_headline: RJR Nabisco Refuses to Spin Off Food Unit Immediately
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/01/busin.body_text: **********The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation firmly rebuffed yesterday demands by the financiers Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn for an immediate spinoff of its food business from its tobacco operations, calling their proposal "imprudent" and "irresponsible." **********"The board will accomplish a spinoff just as soon as it is able to determine  that the spinoff is in the best interests of all the shareholders and consistent with the corporation's commitments," Charles M. Harper, chairman and  chief executive of RJR Nabisco, wrote in a letter addressed to Mr. LeBow. **********Mr. Harper was responding to a letter sent to him by Mr. LeBow on Monday. Mr. LeBow, with his partner, Mr. Icahn, had announced that the company he heads, Brooke Group Ltd., would solicit nonbinding consent from RJR Nabisco stockholders for an immediate, complete spinoff of the Nabisco Holdings Corporation. **********In a stock offering in January, RJR Nabisco sold 19.5 percent of its food business to the public. The board subsequently voted that no decision about a complete spinoff could be made before 1997. **********Some analysts believe that RJR Nabisco's stock price has been depressed by the potential legal and legislative liabilities of the company's tobacco operations and that a spinoff would unlock that value. **********Although the board "continues to be fully committed to a spinoff," Mr. Harper said, three conditions must be met for such a move: "It must be tax-free; it must be accomplished in a manner that avoids long litigation delays and the resulting uncertainty that would erode shareholder value, and it must preserve the financial integrity of both the food and tobacco businesses." **********There is "absolutely no need for a shareholder referendum," Mr. Harper's letter said. "Based on discussions with shareholders, we know that a majority are in favor of a spinoff just as soon as it can be reasonably accomplished." **********Mr. LeBow, in a statement from a spokeswoman, Anna Cordasco, responded, "After months of denying that there is any shareholder interest in a spinoff of  the Nabisco food unit, RJR now belatedly acknowledges that in fact there is overwhelming shareholder support for such action." **********Gary Black, a tobacco industry analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, took a similar position. "I don't know which shareholders Mr. Harper was talking to, but the shareholders I speak with don't want to wait until 1997 to get the Nabisco dividend," from the spinoff, he said. **********In his letter, Mr. Harper said Mr. LeBow's consent solicitation could "jeopardize the possibility of ever completing a spinoff," since it focuses attention on "nonbusiness-related" aspects. **********A spokeswoman for RJR Nabisco, Carol Makovich, said the transaction's tax-free status could be jeopardized if the spinoff was done purely to push up the stock price and not for business-related reasons. **********On Monday, Mr. LeBow and Mr. Icahn said they held a 4.8 percent stake in RJR  Nabisco, adding that they would also ask shareholders to change bylaws adopted in August that forbid shareholders to call special meetings. **********Yesterday, Mr. LeBow said, "We strongly disagree with chairman Harper's contention that only the RJR Nabisco board is qualified to decide to do the spinoff." **********On Monday, Mr. LeBow and Mr. Icahn said they would propose a new slate of directors at RJR Nabisco's annual meeting in April who favor an immediate, complete spinoff. Unless RJR Nabisco agrees to an immediate spinoff, the slate will be offered before Nov. 20, the deadline for proposing new board members. **********"You are, of course, free to solicit proxies to elect a new board of directors at the annual meeting," Mr. Harper wrote. "We do not believe the shareholders will support you and turn over to you control of their $9 billion investment."    RJR Nabisco released its response to Mr. LeBow after the stock market closed. RJR Nabisco shares ended up 12.5 cents, at $30.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/03/busin.main_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn Prices Thrive in the Rain; Cotton and Natural Gas Decline
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/03/busin.print_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn Prices Thrive in the Rain; Cotton and Natural Gas Decline
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/03/busin.body_text: **********Corn prices rose sharply yesterday as rain and cold weather add further delays to an already late planting schedule. **********On other markets, natural gas and cotton prices fell. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities dropped 0.64 point, to 233.96. **********Heavy rains in the southern Corn Belt this spring have drenched Illinois, Missouri and parts of Iowa, drowning out chances for a repeat of last year's record 10.1 billion bushel crop. More rain and cooler temperatures are expected  for much of the region through June 10, according to the National Weather Service. **********"We're not going to see the size of a corn crop everybody has been expecting," said Larry Acker of 3F Forecasts in Polo, Ill., an agricultural research and weather forecasting firm. "They haven't been able to get corn in the ground." **********As of Sunday, only 71 percent of the corn crop had been planted, below the normal 89 percent for this time of year, according to the Agriculture Department. **********Corn for July delivery at the Chicago Board of Trade rose 3 cents, to $2.7225 a bushel, the highest since last June 20. This year's crop could be only 6.6 billion bushels, Mr. Acker said, below the Agriculture Department's forecast for 8.6 billions bushels, as farmers stop planting corn and switch to other crops. **********Wheat prices also gained, reaching a five-month high, on concern that cold,  damp weather would delay the winter wheat harvest in the Southwest and encourage disease in younger plants in the Midwest. **********Teams hired to harvest the winter wheat crop, planted last fall, in northern Texas and the Oklahoma panhandle are waiting for fields to dry. **********At the Kansas City Board of Trade, July hard red winter wheat gained 6 cents, to $3.9775 a bushel. **********Natural gas prices tumbled as mild temperatures so far this summer weaken demand, leaving unused gas to accumulate in storage facilities. **********July natural gas on the New York Mercantile Exchange fell 4.7 cents, to $1.688 for 1,000 cubic feet, the lowest in three weeks. **********Cotton prices declined amid forecasts for further rain in Texas, easing the  dry conditions that threatened the crop. **********Cotton for July delivery fell 1.6 cents, to $1.1075 a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/world.main_headline: Gore Finds Rainbow at End of African Trip
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/world.print_headline: Gore Finds Rainbow at End of African Trip
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/world.body_text: **********Vice President Al Gore got a blast of the Rainbow Nation today, finding himself surrounded by dancing bricklayers, electricians and carpenters in orange, blue, green, yellow and red overalls. **********His visit to an American-sponsored trade school in this black and Indian suburb of Johannesburg had slipped from sober testimonials about the school into a hearty chorus of "Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrika" ("God Bless Africa') the national anthem, and then into a singing, chanting African hoedown with the Vice President in the middle playing maypole with a big grin on his face. **********Mr. Gore didn't actually join in dancing a toyi-toyi, as President Nelson Mandela would have done. But he did look about as relaxed as he gets in public. **********In fact, everything about the Vice President's visit was "on Africa time" --  he was half an hour late, and his Secret Service escort had even left their sunglasses home. He gave everyone he met the three-step African handshake and used the words "ubuntu" and "masakhane" a lot, words in the Bantu languages that roughly translate as "humanity" and "togetherness." He also took a bricklaying lesson, at which he wasn't half bad, though he laid the mortar on a bit thick. **********Since, in a very high-tech American touch, he was wearing a portable microphone hooked into the public address system, everyone could hear only what  he said during the lesson, which was mostly: "Got it. O.K. Got it." **********Upon graduation, he was presented with his own congratulatory trowel. **********The visit to Union Buildings Trade Project -- a joint project of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., bricklayers' unions and South African construction companies -- began Mr. Gore's last day in Africa. He made a quick stop in Botswana and then flew to Cape Town before heading home. **********The important work of his three-day visit was done on Tuesday, when he signed agreements with Deputy President Thabo Mbeki allowing the Peace Corps into South Africa and creating a number of Cabinet-level binational discussion groups on business, the environment, science, energy, education and agriculture. **********One Russian journalist's question brought a laugh from the crowd when he pointed out that America's newest binational commissions are with South Africa and Russia and asked whether a new strategic alliance was forming. **********Mr. Gore, chuckling, said this was no scheme for world domination, but an American effort to applaud both Russia and South Africa as emerging democracies  that could serve as examples of the value of free elections and ethnic tolerance. **********Mr. Gore also met with President Mandela and Deputy Vice President F. W. de Klerk, and he toured the trade school with Tokyo Sexwale, premier of Gauteng province.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/25/busin.main_headline: Mattel Plans to Sell Its Own Brand of Software
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/25/busin.print_headline: Mattel Plans to Sell Its Own Brand of Software
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/25/busin.body_text: **********Even as tiny tots look for lost Barbie shoes and misplaced pieces to the new  Hot Wheels sets from Santa, Mattel Inc. is already hard at work on electronic versions of these toys for next Christmas. **********Mattel, the world's largest toy company, has formed a Mattel Media division to develop and sell multimedia products and software based on its toy brands, which include Barbie, Hot Wheels, Cabbage Patch Dolls and Polly Pocket miniature collectibles. Among the products planned for the new line will be a software program to let kids make clothes for their Barbies. **********Mattel, based in El Segundo, Calif., is reluctant to discuss its plans before a big announcement planned for Jan. 30 at the American International Toy  Fair in New York. But in an an interview last week in the trade paper Computer Retail Week, Doug Glen, president of Mattel Media, said the first of the products would be in stores in the fall of 1996. **********In developing software line on best-selling toy brands, Mattel is following a brand-marketing strategy that has proven successful for entertainment companies. Disney Software, has had success with programs based on its movies, including "Lion King" and "Aladdin." **********Whether a toymaker with no software experience will find the going smooth, or shelf space available in different stores than those it usually deals with, remains to be seen. But Barbie is the best-selling toy of all time, and that might provide the necessary muscle. **********Mattel's software line comes just as the company's Fisher-Price division, in  league with the Compaq Computer Corporation, is set to introduce a line of computer products for very young children. The companies plan to display the first of their products at the Winter Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Nev., in early January. But while these projects may mark Mattel's first official foray into personal computing, Barbie already has a following among computer users who browse the Internet's World Wide Web. Barbie collectors have started dozens of home pages devoted to sharing information, buying and selling dolls and generally reveling  in Barbie facts and history. **********One Web site so polished that it looks like it might have been produced by the toy maker itself is Jennifer Warf's Internet Barbie Collection, which the home page says is "designed for collectors looking for Barbies" (http://silver.ucs.indiana.edu/jwarf/barbie.html). The categories, illustrated by photos, include "Holiday Limited Editions" and "1996 New Barbies!" **********Ms. Warf, a student at Indiana University who will soon be looking for a job, is apparently aware (and even hopes) that she might be mistaken for a Mattel marketer. So she includes this disclaimer: **********"All copyrights on this page belong to the Mattel corporation. I am in NO way affiliated with the Mattel company, nor do I design, create or own any copyrights on the doll. Not saying that I wouldn't like to. So, Mattel, if you are looking . . . please take a look at MY ONLINE RESUME, and HIRE ME!!!" **********There are some sites Mattel would probably rather give a wide berth, like the Hacker Barbe Dream Basement (http://www.catalog.com/ mrm/barbe/barbe.html). This iconoclastic, feminist site, which gets some 12,000 visits a month, is maintained by Marianne Mueller, a systems programmer at Sun Microsystems. Ms. Mueller misspells "Barbie" to avoid copyright problems with Mattel. **********Dream Basement takes an irreverent approach, such as an image of a defiant, topless Barbie outside the "No Tell Motel." Like Ms. Warf, Ms. Mueller offers a  disclaimer: **********"Some of the images on these pages poke fun at some ideas that some people have about women and sexuality. Please don't follow any links from this page if  yu think they will be seen by children or by people who are easily offended."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/09/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;M. A. HANNA TO BUY CIMCO'S SHARES AND SELL SOME UNITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/09/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;M. A. HANNA TO BUY CIMCO'S SHARES AND SELL SOME UNITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/09/busin.body_text: **********The M. A. Hanna Company said yesterday that it would acquire all outstanding  shares of Cimco Inc. for $10.50 a share, or about $31 million. Shares of Cimco,  based in Costa Mesa, Calif., were up $1.25 yesterday, to $9.625, in Nasdaq trading. Hanna, a specialty chemicals company in Cleveland, said that after the  acquisition, it would sell Cimco's plastics and molded components businesses and retain its plastics compounding operations. Hanna said that Russell T. Gilbert, Cimco's chief executive, has offered to purchase the molded components  business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/30/world.main_headline: Subway Fire Kills 300 in Caucasus Capital
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/30/world.print_headline: Subway Fire Kills 300 in Caucasus Capital
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/30/world.body_text: **********Rescue workers recovered about 300 bodies today from the wreckage of a subway train that caught fire Saturday in Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan, officials said. **********At least 200 more people were injured. Unable to escape from the packed cars, most of the victims were killed by carbon monoxide poisoning from burning toxic  materials in the train carriages, officials said. **********The fire started when the train was between the Ulduz and Narimanov subway stations in central Baku on Saturday afternoon because of a malfunction of the train's electrical system, officials said. **********Survivors described sparks flying from high-voltage cables just after the train left the busy Ulduz station. **********"As soon as the train entered the tunnel, I saw a flash," said Tabil Guseinov, 45, a passenger. "Then the flames enveloped the train car, there was a sound of breaking glass, and the lights went out. People started breaking windows to get out. We were starting to suffocate." **********Morgue officials said they had counted at least 303 bodies, and the independent Azerbaijani news agency Turan quoted medical officials as putting the death toll at 337. **********Azerbaijan's Health Minister, Ali Insanov, said 269 people had been injured.  Of the injured, 62 remained hospitalized today, most of them in serious condition. **********It was not known how many people were on the train, officials said. **********The President of this Caucasus nation, Heydar Aliyev, set up a commission to  investigate. Its chairman, Deputy Prime Minister Abbas Abbasov, promptly blamed  Baku's "outdated Soviet" subways, which needed urgent repairs, the Turan news agency reported. **********Last year, about 20 people were killed in two terrorist attacks on the Baku subway. Officials said today that there was no indication of terrorism in the fire.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Murdoch and 3 OthersSet Latin Satellite-TV Effort
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Murdoch and 3 OthersSet Latin Satellite-TV Effort
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/busin.body_text: **********Seeking to dominate the satellite television market in Latin America, the News Corporation said yesterday that it would form a direct-broadcast satellite  service with three powerful partners: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator; Globo, the leading media company in Brazil, and Grupo Televisa, the giant Mexican broadcaster. **********Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation, said at a news conference in New York that the partners planned an initial total investment of  $500 million in the service, which is to begin operations in May. It will transmit 150 channels of entertainment, news and sports programming to homes equipped with satellite dishes and digital receivers. **********Although the service will have just one million subscribers when it starts,  Mr. Murdoch said it had a potential audience of more than 400 million viewers throughout Central and South America. **********"I believe our joint announcement today concerns the most exciting and far-reaching development yet in the brave new world of global television," he said. **********Certainly, the partnership brings together a potent array of resources: the News Corporation owns two satellite services -- B Sky B in England and Star TV in Asia -- as well as the Fox television network. Tele-Communications, based in  Englewood, Colo., has interests in cable systems in Latin America, Europe and Asia with a total of 2.4 million subscribers, in addition to having 14 million cable subscribers in the United States. **********Globo has extensive interests in broadcasting, and magazine and newspaper publishing in Brazil, while Grupo Televisa is the world's largest producer of Spanish-language programming. **********"This is the best possible alignment of partners I could imagine," said Fred  Vierra, the vice chairman of Tele-Communications and chairman of its international operations. Mr. Vierra said the service could eventually attract 10 percent of the viewers in Latin America, or 40 million people. **********Mr. Murdoch said the News Corporation, Globo and Televisa would each own 30 percent of the venture; Tele-Communications would own the remaining 10 percent.  The initial $500 million investment and the profits from the venture will be divided accordingly. **********The four companies face competition in the Latin American satellite market. Hughes Communications, a part of the Hughes division of General Motors, is starting a Latin American satellite-broadcast service in partnership with three  smaller Latin American media companies. Hughes already operates DirecTV, a satellite-broadcast service in the United States. **********But several media industry analysts said yesterday that the programming resources of Televisa and Globo -- combined with the distribution power of the News Corporation and Tele-Communications -- gave their venture an enormous competitive advantage. **********Also yesterday, Mr. Murdoch confirmed a recent published report that he had considered making a takeover bid for Time Warner Inc. two months ago, shortly after Time Warner announced plans to acquire the Turner Broadcasting System. But Mr. Murdoch played down the seriousness of the effort, which was disclosed in a  lengthy profile of him in The New Yorker. **********"It was a bit of a joke," Mr. Murdoch said. He said the idea was proposed to  him by other media executives. Previously published reports had said the idea came from the president of Tele-Communications, John C. Malone. Mr. Murdoch said yesterday that he had "a few young M.B.A.'s run the numbers for half a day" before deciding not to proceed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/busin.body_text: **********The Nationsbank Corporation and a Boston-based housing group announced today  that they would provide $500 million in unusually flexible and inexpensive mortgages for homes in low-income urban areas. **********The agreement between the nation's fourth-largest bank and the the National Assistance Corporation of America is believed to be the largest commitment yet for such mortgages. The loans feature no down payments, no closing costs, no application fees and "liberal underwriting at a market rate." **********This is the best mortgage product in the country that meets the needs of working people," said Bruce Marks, executive director of the housing group, known as NACA. **********Other banks have made larger commitments for community lending, such as an $18 billion initiative the Chemical Banking Corporation and the Chase Manhattan  Corporation announced after they disclosed merger plans. But the Nationsbank and NACA agreement is significant because its unusually flexible terms are designed  for the working poor, said John Taylor, executive director of the National Community Reinvestment Coalition.
