https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/02/world.main_headline: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: SARAJEVO;On All Saints', the Quick Recall the Dead
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/02/world.print_headline: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: SARAJEVO;On All Saints', the Quick Recall the Dead
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/02/world.body_text: **********Sarajevans honored the city's dead at grave sites across the capital today, remembering their loved ones and praying for peace on All Saints' Day. **********"This is a day for all of us, Serb, Croat or Muslim, a day for all of the dead," Vesna Komarica, a 56-year-old Croat, said as she walked along a rocky path to the grave of her husband, a Muslim who was killed in the street by a Serbian sniper this year. **********Referring to the peace talks in Ohio Mrs. Komraica added: "I expect this day to be special in Dayton, too. I expect them to sign the document for all of these people who now lie here." **********She bent down and kissed her husband's small wooden headstone, brushing her face along its border, at the Lion Cemetery **********"They are all so young," she said. **********To hold the more than 10,000 people killed in Sarajevo in three and a half years of war, cemeteries have sprouted across the capital's bombed-out landscape, between vegetable gardens, near the front lines, in small rows between sidewalks and parking lots. **********For many, this annual day of visits to the grave sites, as well as commemorations on All Soul's Day on Thursday, underscored the idea of a multi-ethnic Bosnia. **********"I am Croat and my wife is Serb, and we also have Muslims in our family," Marko Duspara, 62, said as his sister put flowers on his wife's grave. "The Bosnian Serbs should stand here and see this. This is what we are fighting for.  If we live through this war, this is what we want." **********Since last month, when the Bosnian Serbs, the Bosnian Croats and the Bosnian  Government agreed to a cease-fire and to hold peace talks, Sarajevans have watched their city come alive with street lights and the zoom of traffic. Markets have sprung from places of carnage, and civilian convoys have crossed Bosnian Serb territory to Government-controlled areas. **********For workers at the Lion Cemetery, they have not only experienced a respite from being targets of snipers and artillery and but also from the many burial plots they had to dig. **********"There were many days of 40 or 50 holes," said Husein Salispahic, 47, a gravedigger. "And there have been many more deaths at the graveside. When the Serbs saw a lot of people here, they liked to shoot. I hope now I will only have to bury the old, not the young people I have grown used to burying. And I am fairly confident about this happening." **********Yet for others, memories of many broken cease-fires and failed talks have tempered any optimism they hold for the negotiations in Ohio. **********Referring to the Bosnian Serbs, Amir Began, a 38-year-old soldier said: "They understand Tomahawk missiles and NATO planes. And if they don't settle, they will understand our tanks on the Drina River. Then we can be assured of peace."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/29/world.main_headline: Rape Trial In Okinawa Is Suspended
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/29/world.print_headline: Rape Trial In Okinawa Is Suspended
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/29/world.body_text: **********The trial of three American servicemen charged with raping a 12-year-old Japanese schoolgirl was suspended today after the mothers of the two Marine Corps defendants asked to have the trial moved out of Okinawa. **********The rape of the girl, on the southern island of Okinawa on Sept. 4, has provoked deep outrage throughout Japan, and increased tensions in the military relationship between Japan and the United States. **********The trial, which had been expected to end today, will now be suspended until a higher court rules on the request by the mother of Pfc. Kendrick Ledet, 20, of Waycross, Ga. The judge rejected the motion from the mother of Pfc. Rodrico Harp, 21, of Griffin, Ga., because her son did not support the request. **********Privates Harp and Ledet have denied raping the girl, but have both admitted to kidnapping her. In testimony earlier this week, the two marines said they had cooperated only because they were intimidated by the third defendant, Marcus Gill, a 22-year-old Navy seaman. Seaman Gill, of Woodville, Tex., has admitted to kidnapping the girl and raping her. **********But Seaman Gill, who testified on Wednesday, emphasized that all three men had staged the abduction and planned the rape together. He said that Private Harp spotted the girl as she was walking into a stationery story and that Private Ledet had suggested ambushing her. **********The schoolgirl, whose name has not been made public, was bound with tape and  raped in a rented car on a remote road near a farm, according to the prosecutors. She is not expected to appear in court, although her family did submit a statement by her in which she mentions the rape. **********Masanori Higa, the lawyer for Seaman Gill, said that the girl seemed not to remember clearly but that she believed she was raped twice. **********The two mothers, Daisey Harp and Barbara Cannon, were allowed to make the request as legal assistants to their sons. The two women argued that the emotionally charged atmosphere in Okinawa made it virtually impossible for their sons to receive a fair trial. **********Many Okinawans complain about crimes, accidents and noise that they say are the result of the American military presence. Soon after the rape, at least 50,000 Okinawans staged a protest against the bases. **********Underscoring the political repercussions of the rape case -- and the wide presumption among Okinawans that the three servicemen are guilty -- opponents of the American military bases purchased an advertisement in The New York Times on  Nov. 15 calling for their reduction and stating that three Americans had raped a schoolgirl. The advertisement invited readers to make contact or inquiries with the Okinawa Governor's office. **********"If three Okinawans committed rape in New York and Governor Pataki put an ad  in the paper, do you know how fast the trial would be moved?" said Michael J. Griffith, a partner at the International Legal Defense Counsel, who is informally advising the defendants. "These guys have been made a spectacle. Rape is a horrible thing, but these guys deserve the semblance of a fair trial." **********A change of venue is provided for in Japanese law but is very unusual, in part because cases are decided not by juries but by judges who are presumed to be less emotional than members of the public. In Japan, judges determine guilt or innocence as well as the sentence, and in this case a three-judge panel of Okinawa judges is hearing the case. The Japanese lawyers for the three servicemen say it is unlikely that the request will be granted. **********"We know from past rulings that the possibility of this claim is very low and that it is just a waste of time," said Yutaka Arakawa, the Japanese lawyer who is representing Private Ledet. Mr. Arakawa added that the delay in the trial could prolong the detention of Private Ledet, and he made it clear that he did not agree with the tactic. **********Japanese prosecutors have an overwhelmingly high conviction rate, partly because they prosecute only cases that have very strong evidence, including confessions. Thus, Japanese defense lawyers often focus not on winning acquittal but on trying to get leniency for clients by apologizing and demonstrating contrition. **********All three American servicemen, including some family members, have made apologies, and each serviceman has also offered to pay $5,000 to the girl as compensation. **********If convicted, the three men could be sentenced to prison terms ranging from three years to life. Sentencing had been expected on Jan. 19, but the request for change of venue may delay that.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/07/busin.main_headline: Family Business (Extended);In Italy, New Generation of Leaders Looks Abroad
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/07/busin.print_headline: Family Business (Extended);In Italy, New Generation of Leaders Looks Abroad
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/07/busin.body_text: **********Paolo Barilla was born an heir to Europe's biggest pasta empire. But from his childhood Soap Box Derby days, his passion was always racing cars, not ravioli. **********So, though his grandfather founded Barilla S.p.A. in 1877 and Paolo's brothers were lured into the $2 billion company by their father, Paolo built a career driving at tracks like Le Mans in France and Monza in Italy, and for the  Toyota Motor Corporation in Japan. **********Then, one day in 1990, he decided it was time to go home. "I felt an attraction for the family business," said Paolo, who is now 34. "I was curious about it. My father always believed that whatever comes naturally and is not forced puts down the deepest roots." Three years later, his father died, and he  and his brothers Guido and Luca took over. **********Paolo's return to the family fold is part of a much larger generational changing of the guard in Italian business, which, more than industry in almost any other European country, is dominated by families. Except for the huge but inefficient state sector, virtually all Italian companies, even giants like the  Fiat auto group, the Pirelli rubber company and the Olivetti computer maker, are controlled and run by families. **********Fiat, Pirelli and Olivetti were all founded during Italy's 19th-century industrialization. And some economic historians trace the strong family tradition in Italian business to the great banking and commercial families of the Renaissance, like the Chigis of Genoa and the Medicis of Florence. But most  of the 3,500 private-sector companies active today were created during the rebuilding of Italy's economy after World War II. With the founders now aging, analysts estimate that one-third of them will have to find successors within the next five years. **********The search for new leadership comes at a crucial time for Italian businesses. Like companies elsewhere, they are having to come to grips with the globalization of markets and increased competition from abroad. **********It isn't that leaders in the older generation were global slouches. They hawked shoes and clothing, machine tools and packaging equipment in foreign markets from Stuttgart to Singapore. But they did so in broken English or sign language and rarely dreamed of building factories outside Italy. The sons and daughters have been trained abroad, speak fluent English and maybe one or two other foreign languages, and think readily about manufacturing in other countries. **********So pronounced is the generational shift that Bocconi University, Italy's leading business school, started a special program in 1991 to train the sons and daughters of graying business owners. **********The courses, which enroll about 30 students, focus on practical problems, like defusing family tensions. The students are required to write an essay on their family's business after interviewing their parents and other company officers. **********"If a father is successful, that usually means he's a strong personality with a very elevated ego," said Guido Corbetta, who teaches corporate strategy and helped design the three-week program. "That causes psychological problems." **********Members of the younger generation at big Italian companies often go outside Italy for their business degrees and then get hands-on training at high-profile  positions within the business before taking over. Consider the worldly experience of one rising star of the Italian business world, Alessandro Benetton, next in line to run the Benetton S.p.A. clothing empire. After getting a management degree from Boston University, he spent two years in London as a financial analyst for the American investment firm Goldman, Sachs & Company. Though he spent much of the time "doing photocopies and making coffee," he said, the experience gave him the breadth he needed to finish a degree at the Harvard  Business School, where he wrote his thesis on -- what else? -- Benetton. **********In his final training stint before moving to Benetton, the 31-year-old Alessandro has been put in charge of a family investment and consulting company  that caters to small businesses in the Veneto region of northeastern Italy. **********The young Mr. Benetton recounts how his father, Luciano, 60, two uncles and an aunt pioneered the use of computer-assisted design and distribution to build  their knit-goods company in Veneto into a worldwide clothing and sports-equipment giant. In addition to selling apparel, Benetton partly or wholly owns companies that make sports brands like Rollerblades, Nordica ski boots, Kastle skis and Prince tennis racquets. **********But while Alessandro was steeped from childhood in the family business, he said, "I always felt free to do whatever I chose." **********To be sure, there are big and small problems that result from corporate inbreeding and in some cases from a dearth of international-minded professional  management. GFT S.p.A. of Turin, for instance, the apparel maker that brought the craze for Italian designer fashions to the United States in the 1980's, had  to be bailed out in the 1990's by banks after the Rivetti family proved incapable of managing the complex multinational operations. Non-family members in upper management sometimes clash with the owner clan. Before Carlo de Benedetti took over Olivetti, he worked briefly for Fiat, but quit after locking horns with the Agnelli family, which controls the auto maker. **********Dissension within the family ranks can also make a company vulnerable to corporate raiders. Children sometimes refuse to join the business, or fight over the inheritance. Some of the major foreign acquisitions in Italy -- including the 1993 takeover of the Gucci fashion-goods company by Investcorp of Bahrain -- resulted from such quarrels. **********And there is always the danger that a family will anoint a weak successor. In the early 1990's, when Fiat was struggling through the recession, its banks and  other investors begged Gianni Agnelli, the chairman and family patriarch, not to cede his position to his younger brother, Umberto, who was considered less capable. Gianni Agnelli agreed to delay the passing of the torch, and this year  the family bypassed Umberto and designated his 31-year old son, Giovanni Alberto Agnelli, to inherit his uncle's mantle. **********As such internecine scheming suggests, family-controlled companies in Italy can sometimes be tripped up by their secretiveness. Umberto Bertele, a management professor at Milan Polytechnic University, said Italian business was  rife with "Chinese boxes, cross shareholdings and other financial constructs that in America would be prohibited." **********The habits of doing business around the dining room table and withholding information from the public have spawned a recent wave of scandals and criminal  prosecutions. Numerous companies have been charged with paying off tax officials in exchange for favorable audits. The number of arrests among government inspectors suggests that the practice was widespread. **********One of the defendants is Silvio Berlusconi, the chairman of the Fininvest media company. He has responded by accusing prosecutors of manufacturing the case against him last year when he was Prime Minister of Italy. And Piersilvio,  his son, rejects the charges against his father as "absolutely ridiculous." **********Piersilvio, 26, cut short his university studies to join Fininvest in 1993. After a stint in advertising, he switched to a job creating new programs for a channel aimed at teen-agers. **********Piersilvio said he had been learning the family business since, as a child, he listened in on discussions over heaping plates of pasta around the dining room table at the family home at Arcore, outside Milan. "I attended all the meetings about television when I was 16, 17, 18," he said. **********For all his familiarity with the business, though, he said he had asked himself many times whether he really wanted to work for his father. When faced with tough decisions, he said, he likes to go scuba diving, because the sport helps him relax. "I must say I did a lot of diving," he said. **********Far from crimping Italian companies, analysts said, the family connection generally works to their advantage. "They often specialize in custom-made products," said Enrico Valdani, chairman of the marketing department at Bocconi  University, which is in Milan, Italy's financial capital. And, because control is concentrated, he added, "they have the ability to adapt quickly." **********The internationalization of markets poses a new challenge to Italy's family-run companies. To compete, they have to grow, and to grow they will have  to raise fresh capital. That will mean bringing in more outside investors, diluting the family's stake. **********With the revolution in the media industry, for example, the senior Mr. Berlusconi sold stakes in Fininvest's television unit to the Saudi investor Prince Walid bin Talal and the German media magnate Leo Kirch, while retaining management control. **********Beyond capital, the other big requirement of family companies is management expertise. "They always produced in Italy and exported, and so we have to ask whether they will be capable of defending international markets," said Bocconi's Professor Valdani. "They will have to be pocket multinationals, perform and behave like the big guys, developing strategies of penetration, joint ventures,  overseas investments." **********The Barilla clan never hesitated to seek outside help. In the 1970's, when terrorism and economic uncertainty clouded Italy's business climate, it sold the company to the American businessman J. Peter Grace, then the chairman of W. R. Grace & Company, only to buy it back several years later with the help of Swiss  investors. **********Now, Paolo Barilla and his brothers are again seeking outside expertise, and  this year they hired the former chief of Procter & Gamble, Edwin L. Artzt, to join their board. **********Paolo Barilla paints a glowing future for the pasta company. It will be "much faster, closer to the consumer, a flexible company," he said. And, he added, "It will be much more international." **********Clearly, his father's attentions paid off. Paolo Barilla said his father was  a patient teacher who never forced anything on his three sons. "He wanted us to  develop a kind of affection for it," he said. "His fear was that if he pushed us and pushed us, in the end we'd reject it."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/08/busin.main_headline: MARKET WATCH;A Rough Week for A Top Rookie
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/08/busin.print_headline: MARKET WATCH;A Rough Week for A Top Rookie
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/08/busin.body_text: **********Has any Wall Street rookie ever had a season like Marc A. Kaufman is having? **********Mr. Kaufman was 25 when he took over Fidelity's Select Electronics Fund at the end of March. It was his first stab at managing money, and he hasn't done badly. His fund gained 61.5 percent in his first six months, more than any other fund. **********Mr. Kaufman did that by leaping into semiconductor stocks with both feet. In a technology-crazed market, that was the right thing to do, and he did it with more gusto than anyone else. **********Mr. Kaufman, now 26, joined Fidelity as an analyst in 1992 after getting a master's degree. He dropped out of the Ph.D. program in electrical engineering at M.I.T. "It was very intellectually challenging," he said of academia, "but on a day-to-day basis, it is not as exciting as what we do in this business. Engineering is a science. There is an art to investing." **********This has been an exciting year to be investing in technology stocks, especially for Mr. Kaufman. The cash has poured into his fund, pushing assets from $152 million at the end of 1994 to $1.25 billion now. **********Such heavy cash flows can create a wonderful merry-go-round. As the money comes in, a fund buys more of the stocks it likes, which drives up the price of  those stocks and improves the fund's performance. That brings in more money, and away we go. **********There is a theory on Wall Street that it is young money managers who are best positioned to take advantage of wild bull markets, such as the current tech boom. No matter how much history they have read, they are untroubled by recollections of being caught owning collapsing stocks. When things are good, that gives them the courage to throw caution to the winds. **********Mr. Kaufman knows there are people who see the current boom in technology stocks as a classic bubble, but he doesn't sound worried. He isn't buying a market, he said. He's buying stocks. "There have always been plenty of good ideas to buy, and that is still true today." **********Enthusiastic investors sometimes have a way of engaging in what might be called "ruler forecasting," placing a ruler on a trend line and assuming it will continue indefinitely. Mr. Kaufman may in fact be guilty of that now. He said demand for semiconductors has been rising at a year-over-year rate of 30 percent for several years and he sees no reason for that to change. **********In that way, he said, "this period is very different from 1983," when semiconductor stocks soared, only to tumble. "That was much more of an inventory build for demand that was never there in semiconductors," he said. "The demand here is much more sustainable." He talked with scorn of the "panic" that has driven down the price of one semiconductor maker, Integrated Silicon Solutions,  from a July high of $73 to about $30 now, largely out of fears that prices of its chips will fall, and says the stock is a good buy. **********Integrated Silicon Solutions is, in fact, a fine example of how amazing this  year has been. The company went public in February with insiders selling stock at $13. It is a rare year when someone can look at a stock eight months after it had gone public, see it selling at more than twice the original price, and pronounce that a sign of panic. **********Last week was bad for tech stocks and for investors in Mr. Kaufman's fund, which fell 5.5 percent. Have such stocks peaked? We don't know. But some day, perhaps soon, we will see if Mr. Kaufman and other technology bulls are as nimble in a falling market as they have been in a soaring one.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/06/world.main_headline: Intruder Startles Wife of Canada's Premier
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/06/world.print_headline: Intruder Startles Wife of Canada's Premier
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/06/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Jean Chretien's wife, Aline, came face-to-face with an intruder who was standing at their bedroom door with an open jackknife early today. **********Mr. Chretien said he and his wife locked themselves in their room until the Royal Canadian Mounted Police arrived minutes later and arrested the man. **********Neither was injured. **********Mr. Chretien told reporters that his wife woke up at about 2:45 A.M. when she heard a noise. The police said the man broke into the Prime Minister's official  residence by smashing a window with a rock. **********"She got up and she saw a person in front of her, and she closed back the door very rapidly, came back to the room and locked the other door," Mr. Chretien said. **********He spoke at the airport before leaving for Israel to attend the funeral of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin. **********A police inspector, Jean St-Cyr, said the motive for the break-in was unclear. Another, unidentified police spokesman said a 34-year-old man from the  Montreal area was arrested. **********No other details were released.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/01/world.main_headline: Chilean Vows to Avoid Prison in Letelier Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/01/world.print_headline: Chilean Vows to Avoid Prison in Letelier Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/01/world.body_text: **********The former chief of the Chilean military's secret police, convicted of the assassination of the opposition leader Orlando Letelier in 1976, vowed today not to go to jail despite a Supreme Court ruling on Tuesday that upheld a seven-year prison sentence imposed by a lower court. **********The general, Manuel Contreras Sepulveda, the head of the secret police during the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, said in a television interview this morning, "I'm not going to any jail as long as there is no real justice." **********Speaking from his ranch in southern Chile, where he has been secluded for weeks, General Contreras said he did not receive due process because "the judges were scared by Marxists." **********"My constitutional rights were not respected," the 65-year-old general said. **********Although it is unclear whether General Contreras plans to resist arrest or if he was simply expressing dissatisfaction with the high court's ruling, his remarks have raised the specter here of a confrontation between the civilian police and military loyalists who are serving as bodyguards for the general at his ranch. **********In an interview with reporters this afternoon, the retired general said that  he had the backing of the entire Chilean military and that he had not yet decided if he would resist arrest. **********"At the moment they come for me, I will decide what is necessary at that moment," the general said. "As a general I am not going to run away because I am going to face the battle. I am a winner and do not want to lose." **********Andres Allamand, president of the center-right National Renovation Party, criticized General Contreras, saying, "In a nation of rights, no one can avoid the law, and Contreras is no exception." **********The military has declined to comment on the Supreme Court's decision. But Santiago Sinclair, a retired deputy army commander and confidant of General Pinochet, said: "The army is deeply wounded by this ruling. We are returning to  confrontational situations, which could be extremely delicate for the country's  fate." **********The Supreme Court upheld a lower court's conviction of General Contreras and  his deputy, Brig. Gen. Pedro Espinoza, in the car bombing that killed Mr. Letelier, a former Chilean Ambassador to the United States and foe of Pinochet,  and a colleague, Ronni Moffitt, in Washington. General Espinoza was sentenced to six years in prison. **********The Justice Ministry declined to say when the two officers would be taken into custody, but lawyers said the process should require only a week. **********Human rights groups, politicians and the Letelier family openly praised the court's decision. **********Congressman Juan Pablo Letelier, Mr. Letelier's son, called the verdict "a rebirth of democracy in Chile." In a nationally televised speech, President Eduardo Frei urged all Chileans to respect the ruling, saying it "cannot and should not be used to criticize the military."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/01/busin.main_headline: 2 Big Banks In Merger Set Aid for Poor
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/01/busin.print_headline: 2 Big Banks In Merger Set Aid for Poor
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/01/busin.body_text: **********In an effort to smooth the way toward the biggest bank merger in history, the Chemical Banking Corporation and the Chase Manhattan Corporation are expected to announce today a multiyear package of loans and grants worth billions of dollars to low-income communities nationwide. **********The banks are trying take the initiative away from community groups that are  likely to oppose the merger in what has become a banking industry ritual. The 1977 Community Reinvestment Act allows the Government to block mergers by banks  that do not have good records of lending money where they do business. Thus, a protest filing is perhaps the best way an activist on a street corner can get attention of the bankers high in the executive suite. **********In many larger mergers, groups have filed protests complaining about the banks' records only to withdraw the challenges when the bank agreed to increase  its loans and grants to the community. But in other cases, protesters have delayed approval. The proposed merger between the Fleet Financial Group and the  Shawmut National Corporation announced in February has still not been approved by the Federal Reserve, largely because a storm of protest about Fleet's past lending record. **********The process has been described as blackmail by bankers and as the only way to get a bank's attention by community activists. **********Chemical and Chase accept the fact that to get their deal done they will have to substantially increase the $1 billion a year that the two banks already invest in low-income programs. While most of the money is in new home mortgage loans, there are important grants to local groups that in some cases help them survive. **********But in their own twist on the process, the banks are not waiting for the protests. Instead the banks took the unusual step of sending questionnaires to 375 community groups asking what they needed in preparation for today's announcement. **********"We don't want to submit to what has been seen in the past as C.R.A. blackmail." Carol Parry, Chemical's top community reinvestment officer said. "There will be some unhappy people who don't get what they want. But we don't want to be in a position where we have one group that holds us hostage while 350 groups sign on." **********Matthew Lee, the director of Inner City Press/Community on the Move, a Bronx  organization that has challenged several bank mergers, criticized Chemical for what he called a move to buy silence from community groups. **********"Groups are not supposed to take $5,000 grants and then not protest," he said. **********But many other community activists known that this is the time to put pressure on and they see nothing wrong with what they get. "I find it disingenuous when people in the banking industry put out terms like blackmail or extortion," said Brad Lander, executive director of the Fifth Avenue Committee, a Brooklyn housing group. "Since the merger will affect the city in negative ways --job losses and branch closings -- it seems appropriate that at this moment they are especially accountable." **********Of the Fifth Avenue Committee's $550,000 budget, 20 percent comes from banks, the largest source after government subsidies and property management fees. Chemical and Chase have given the group $9,000 so far this year. **********Francine Justa, director of Neighborhood Housing Services of New York, which  develops low-income housing, said: "So what if a few groups try to get some computers from a $400 billion corporation. People are trying to survive." **********One irony of this process is that Chemical is largely regarded as having one  of the best community lending records in New York, with a top grade from Federal regulators. When it merged with Manufacturers Hanover in 1992, Chemical committed $750 million to community development programs over five years. After  four years, the total loans and grants is actually $1.9 billion. **********Last year's share of this investment totaled $502 million in community investment loans and 2,021 nonprofit and community groups got $6.1 million in grants. More than half of the lending total is $282 million for home mortgages.  Another $174 million was lent to small businesses in low-income areas, to nonprofit organizations and through the Small Business Administration loan program. **********But Chemical's record has not been enough to keep the protesters at bay. **********"We want to make sure that their commitment level after the merger goes up not down," said said John Taylor, the executive director of the National Community Reinvestment Coalition, a Washington clearinghouse for local groups. **********Moreover, some groups say Chase's record is worse than Chemical's, largely because it has appeared to be shunning lower-income customers. **********Banking lawyers said that Chemical's approach seemed to be designed to shift  the spotlight to housing development programs, an area in which the bank would like to make large investments. That will distract attention for Mr. Lee's demand that Chemical increase its routine deposit and lending services through branches in low-income areas. **********"Chemical is very smart to attempt a pre-emptive strike," said Warren Traiger, a New York banking lawyer who specializes in the Community Reinvestment Act. "They can divide and conquer. The groups that benefit under the proposal will take Chemical's side." **********Despite the large amounts, these commitments are hardly a huge sacrifice for  the new bank, which will be run largely by Chemical management under the tonier  Chase name. Chemical's community development area makes a small profit, in fact, because the high returns from lending to big housing projects subsidizes the operating costs of making small business loans and mortgages to first time home  buyers. Bad debts are no more common in these loans than those to more affluent  customers. **********"What the C.R.A. has done is bring people to the table," Mr. Taylor said. "In the past, mergers were largely adversarial. Banks did not sit down and talk abut community needs. Now we and the banks realize we're all in this together." **********Banking lawyers say it is highly unlikely that regulators will block Chemical's merger or any of the other large deals. But the regulators do try to  orchestrate these battles between the banks and the community groups as a way to keep the pressure on the banks. **********"There is a lot of shaping that goes on in a subtle way as a result of the fact that banks have to file applications, with public scrutiny, pressure from community groups and sometimes questions asked by regulators," said one senior Federal official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. **********Indeed, the Federal Reserve and the New York State Banking Department have just called for a rare public hearing on Nov. 16 to look at the Chemical-Chase merger, which will largely focus on community concerns. **********Chemical, of course, has been preparing to defend its record. It devoted 192  of the 270 pages in its Government merger application to its community-lending record. By contrast only 15 pages are devoted to antitrust issues and 9 pages to the financial and managerial resources of the new company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/29/busin.main_headline: F.C.C. Rules on Foreign Stakes in U.S. Set
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/29/busin.print_headline: F.C.C. Rules on Foreign Stakes in U.S. Set
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/29/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Communications Commission adopted guidelines today to approve or  reject investment by foreign telecommunications companies in the United States. **********Currently, the F.C.C. reviews such deals on a case-by-case basis. Officials hope a more predictable approach will encourage overseas companies to invest greater sums in United States companies. **********Adoption of the rules is expected to pave the way for the F.C.C. to act next month on the $4 billion investment by France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom in the Sprint Corporation, the long-distance phone carrier. **********The new rules make it more likely that the F.C.C. will approve large foreign  investment stakes in United States telecommunications companies if an overseas company's home market is open to competition -- or is in the process of opening  up. **********By contrast, the agency can block overseas investments by foreign companies if it determines that the home countries of those companies are barring competition. **********Under the new rules, an investment stake of more than 25 percent by a foreign phone company would cause an automatic F.C.C. review of that company's home market. **********But even a smaller stake could be reviewed. For example, those involving a large dollar amount or those that raise concerns over competition could bring formal scrutiny.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/16/busin.main_headline: Patents;In the struggle to alleviate the pain of rheumatoid arthritis, a doctor says he  has taken a step forward.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/16/busin.print_headline: Patents;In the struggle to alleviate the pain of rheumatoid arthritis, a doctor says he  has taken a step forward.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/16/busin.body_text: **********A NUMBER of drug companies are pressing to develop an inflammation-blocking drug that will alleviate, without side effects, the symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis, a chronic disease that afflicts two million Americans. Such a drug could be worth hundreds of millions of dollars annually and might be prescribed  to treat other autoimmune diseases like multiple sclerosis. **********The aim is to suppress the activities of a protein known as tumor necrosis factor, or T.N.F., which normally helps jump-start the immune system but sometimes goes haywire. In the case of rheumatoid arthritis, T.N.F. starts a series of events that can result in irreversible damage to the body's joints. **********In 1985 Dr. Bruce A. Beutler, now an investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute and an associate professor of internal medicine at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas, was one of the first  scientists to isolate and clone T.N.F. Dr. Beutler has now received a patent covering what he contends is the most effective way to thwart the wayward protein. **********There are several possible ways to block T.N.F. One is to administer monoclonal antibodies, large Y-shaped proteins that originate from the immune cells of mice. These antibodies bind to the T.N.F. and neutralize it. Centocor Inc. is taking this approach, as are other companies. **********The problem with this method, Dr. Beutler contends, is that even when these antibodies have been "humanized," the body will recognize them as being foreign  in origin and eventually will produce its own antibodies that will nullify any therapeutic effect. "Rheumatoid arthritis is a lifelong illness, so you need a drug that will work for years and years," Dr. Beutler said. **********Dr. Beutler's approach is to splice two genes together to produce a new gene  that codes for a Y-shaped molecule that is essentially an artificial monoclonal  antibody. The two arms of the Y are T.N.F. receptors; the stem of the Y is a fragment of a normal human antibody. **********"It's a thousand times more potent in neutralizing T.N.F. than a typical monoclonal antibody would be," Dr. Beutler said. "Another important advantage is that it is made of pieces of two molecules that already exist in the human body, so it is invisible to the immune system. It's very probable that this could be given indefinitely, just as human insulin is given to diabetics." **********Hoffmann-LaRoche, a unit of Roche Holding Ltd., and the Immunex Corporation are testing a similar concept clinically; patent attorneys at both companies said they were not aware of Dr. Beutler's patent. **********"We actually own the molecule -- or at least we think we do," Dr. Beutler said. **********Ray Wheatley, director of technology transfer at the Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas, said the university had not spoken yet with any companies about the patent. "We haven't tried to market it yet, but our patent could be seen as being very powerful," he said. **********Dr. Beutler, Karsten Peppel and David F. Crawford received patent 5,447,851,  which was assigned to the University of Texas. **********An Alternative To Swaddling **********Though seemingly immobile, small babies can wiggle out of their clothing with disconcerting ease. Khoi Nguyen-Senderowicz, a mother of four with a fifth on the way, recently patented two ways to keep infants covered up. **********Her first patent is for a "zipperless, snapless, laceless infant sac with car safety seating capability." The sac, which has sleeves that end in mitts, is elegantly simple. The front features two overlapping panels. The inside panel wraps across the front of the baby and attaches to a Velcro tab inside the sac at one edge. The outside panel wraps across to the opposite edge, where it also  attaches to a Velcro tab. **********Ms. Nguyen-Senderowicz said her invention was a snug alternative to swaddling. "When you think you've got the swaddling all neat and nice, everything falls apart and baby's legs start sticking out," she said. "With this, you just plop baby in and she stays there." **********The second patent covers an elastic brace designed to keep socks or booties in place. The brace resembles a figure-eight, with the top loop wrapping around  the ankle and the bottom one around the arch of the foot. **********Ms. Nguyen-Senderowicz recently formed a company, Appealing Apparel in Berkeley, Calif., to manufacture and market the two inventions. She received patent 5,418,979 for the sac and patent 5,445,598 for the brace. **********A Disposable Liner For the Shower **********James Williams, an inventor in Burlington, Mass., has patented a disposable plastic liner for showers that he said will simplify bathroom cleaning. **********The liner is about 3 millimeters thick and attaches to the top of the shower  walls with rubber-based adhesive tape. At the bottom of the liner is a semi-rigid foil frame, which is crimped into the edge formed between the bathtub and the shower wall. **********"If you make a couple of incisions the plastic will stretch and slide over the bathroom fixtures," Mr. Williams said. **********The liner, which can be made of recycled plastic and is meant to be replaced  every few months, takes about 15 minutes to install, he said. "But we've removed it in as little as 46 seconds," he added. "It sure beats washing the goop off your walls with some kind of caustic soup." **********Mr. Williams said the liner could prove a valuable advertising medium. "You would have the undivided attention of your naked consumer for 5 to 10 minutes every day," he said. **********Mr. Williams, who hopes to license the liner, received patent 5,435,021.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/06/busin.main_headline: First Bank Confirms a Large-Scale Buyback of Its Stock
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/06/busin.print_headline: First Bank Confirms a Large-Scale Buyback of Its Stock
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/06/busin.body_text: **********First Bank System Inc. confirmed yesterday that it had begun buying back its  stock in large amounts immediately after announcing an agreement early in November to buy First Interstate Bancorp for about $10 billion in stock. **********Wells Fargo & Company, which is waging a hostile bid for First Interstate, raised the issue of the buybacks in recent weeks, contending that First Bank, which is based in Minneapolis, had "artificially inflated" its stock price. **********First Bank at first declined to comment, but said yesterday that it had bought 3.1 million of its shares in the fourth quarter, the vast majority of which were purchased in the four weeks after its Nov. 4 agreement with First Interstate. First Bank justified the purchases by noting that it had a longstanding program to reduce excess capital through buybacks and that it bought four million shares in the third quarter of this year. **********Because various rules prohibited the bank from buying back its stock in October, while it was negotiating the deal, and in December, when another deal is scheduled to be submitted to shareholders, First Bank said it needed to concentrate its stock purchases in November. **********"We had been out of the market for much of the quarter, and we had a big pent-up demand for shares," said Lee Mitau, general counsel for First Bank. **********Some, however, have raised concerns about the timing of the buybacks. "The investment community feels it is not getting a fair read on the value of First Bank System's stock price," said Thomas K. Brown, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Still, he and other analysts said that the distortion of the  buybacks on the company's share price was relatively small. **********"First Bank cannot really change where its stock is trading simply by buying  back some stock," said David S. Berry, research director at Keefe Bruyette & Woods. **********The gap between the value of the two bids for First Interstate has widened during the last month. Initially, First Bank's offer was worth only $3 a share less than the Wells bid. By yesterday, the gap had widened to $11 a share, with  Wells offering $144.25 of its stock for each First Interstate share and First Bank offering $135.20 of its stock. **********Yesterday, the shares of First Bank fell 25 cents, to $52, on the New York Stock Exchange, while shares of Wells Fargo fell 50 cents, to $216.375. Shares of First Interstate closed at $137.875, down 25 cents. **********Wells has also contended that because of the buyback, First Bank will not be  able to use a favorable accounting treatment for the deal known as a pooling of  interests. **********In its announcement yesterday, First Bank said it had received a letter from  its auditors advising that the bank would be able to use the pooling method. Ultimately, the Securities and Exchange commission will decide the matter, and the S.E.C. is generally thought to be hostile to pooling of interests, especially in cases of stock buybacks. **********If companies do not qualify for pooling-of-interests accounting, they are required to deduct the "good will" of an acquisition -- the amount by which the  purchase price exceeds the book value -- from their profits during at least 15 years. Wells Fargo, breaking with banking custom, has said that it will not use  a pooling and will accept $400 million a year in good will charges if it succeeds in buying First Interstate. **********The ultimate winner of First Interstate, the nation's 14th-largest bank, will be decided by its shareholders in a vote that will probably take place late in February or early in March.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/15/world.main_headline: BALKAN ACCORD: BOSNIAN SERBS;Bosnian Serb Warriors Are Haunted in Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/15/world.print_headline: BALKAN ACCORD: BOSNIAN SERBS;Bosnian Serb Warriors Are Haunted in Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/15/world.body_text: **********Crushed by what he regards as betrayal at the negotiating table and thwarted  on the battlefield, Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb warrior charged with the massacre of thousands of Muslim men, now spends much of his time isolated in a mountain bunker surrounded by a coterie of officers. His moods are said to swing from rage to uneasy calm. **********His partner in the Bosnian Serb cause, Radovan Karadzic, the psychiatrist-turned-politician, had the foundation of his political program swept out from under him by the Bosnian peace accord. Those who have seen him say that his speech is now often slurred, apparently by medication, and his robust physique has been withered by anxiety as he faces an uncertain future that includes an indictment for war crimes. **********This is the picture acquaintances draw of the two people who were most conspicuously missing from today's peace ceremony in Paris: beaten men desperately dealing to save their jobs and stay away from the International War  Crimes tribunal at The Hague. **********The fate of General Mladic and Dr. Karadzic, yesterday's swaggering conquerors, have been left largely in the hands of the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, a man who once was their patron. But Mr. Milosevic has been  distancing himself from them for 18 months now and went so far as to tell Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke last weekend that General Mladic had "gone off the deep end," Clinton Administration officials said. **********President Milosevic has shown he can put the squeeze on the Bosnian Serbs when he needs to. The peace accord itself was evidence, as was the release on Tuesday of two French pilots who had been held for more than three months by Bosnian Serb forces. **********But Mr. Milosevic is in no hurry to make any drastic moves against the Bosnian Serb leaders, although the peace accord stipulates that all parties agree to cooperate with the war crimes tribunal and carries penalties, including the renewal of sanctions, for harboring indicted war criminals. **********The underlying reason for not wanting the Bosnian Serb leaders to appear before the tribunal at The Hague is that they would most likely argue they were  following the orders of Mr. Milosevic, a defense that would be harmful to Mr. Milosevic and uncomfortable for the Western leaders who have just orchestrated a peace with him, Western diplomats said. **********By the same token, the United States has softened its position, with the Pentagon saying that American troops will not hunt down the two men, for whom arrest warrants have been issued, but will seize them if they come across them. **********Earlier, the Pentagon had refused to deploy in Bosnia while General Mladic and Dr. Karadzic remained in office. Diplomats said the turnaround was a result  of the need for peace before justice. **********Legally, Mr. Milosevic does not recognize the legitimacy of The Hague tribunal, according to Borisav Jovic, a member of Mr. Milosevic's political party and a framer of the Serbian Constitution. Mr. Milosevic would like Dr. Karadzic and Mr. Mladic to fade away, or "go to ground," as one diplomat put it. **********Mr. Milosevic has decided the best solution for Dr. Karadzic would be for him to avoid seeking office again or to be defeated in elections scheduled for next  year. He mentioned the elections again today in his speech at the signing ceremony in Paris. **********Dr. Karadzic was asked to resign but refused, saying he would stand by the wishes of the self-styled Bosnian Serb parliament, which is expected to vote on  his continued leadership within two weeks. **********"Milosevic can only work in an oblique way," said Milorad Dodik, one of eight independent deputies in the assembly. "Milosevic is not in a position to issue orders directly. To get rid of Karadzic in a violent way would make a martyr out of him and rehabilitate his position." **********Mr. Dodik, who has seen Dr. Karadzic, said the Bosnian Serb leader "looked exhausted and has lost a lot of weight." **********The concentrated hold Dr. Karadzic once had on power has diminished sharply.  And popular feeling dismisses him as yesterday's man who brought huge bloodshed  and tragedy for no gain. **********The new power center, dominated by Mr. Milosevic's supporters in Banja Luka,  opposes Dr. Karadzic. The war profiteers who supported Dr. Karadzic in the Bosnian Serb "parliament" in Pale, a suburb of Sarajevo, are now looking to revamp factories and businesses, and they are not sure that he is the best figurehead for Bosnian Serbs as they try to make financial deals with the West. **********Some estimate that Dr. Karadzic's party, the Serbian Democratic Party, would  not win double digits in an election held now. His police, however, still control the Bosnian border with Serbia, making access for foreigners to Serbian-held areas of Bosnia virtually impossible without permission from his office. **********When Mr. Dodik asked Dr. Karadzic about his indictment, the Bosnian Serb leader said he expected to go to The Hague. **********"He said he will deny all accusations and that he can prove he's innocent," said Mr. Dodik, who is a political opponent of Dr. Karadzic. Mr. Dodik said he believed there was such open conflict between Dr. Karadzic and the Bosnian Serb  military leadership that a case could be made that he had no control over local  commanders. **********General Mladic, described as essentially a physical and psychic wreck, may be a more difficult matter. One administrator from Banja Luka said officers loyal to General Mladic were concerned because his behavior had become so erratic. **********The general mostly lives in seclusion at Han Pijesak, a warren of bunkers dug into Bosnia's mountains for the use of Tito in case of an attack on Yugoslavia. **********General Mladic is said to be drinking heavily, railing about NATO and brooding over the death of his daughter, Ana, who committed suicide last year, reportedly over a Serbian magazine article that depicted her father as a murderer. He visits his Belgrade home occasionally, in part to seek medical treatment for kidney stones and gall bladder problems. **********In a speech two weeks ago at a rally in the Bosnian Serb stronghold of Vlasenica, General Mladic said NATO troops would meet a "fiery welcome." **********"Those who bombarded us are now infiltrating like lambs, saying they wish to  protect peace," he said. The speech was an embarrassment, according to one Serb  who listened, because it took no account of reality. **********On the one hand, Mr. Milosevic would like General Mladic sidelined and preparations appear to be underway, diplomats said, for his replacement either by Gen. Milan Gvero, a deputy, or Gen. Novica Simic, the head of the East Bosnia corps of the Bosnian Serb forces. **********But the administrator in Banja Luka said Bosnian Serb officers believe that demoting General Mladic would leave him "easy prey," and that the best way to protect him was to "build him into the system." **********General Mladic is being represented by a prominent criminal lawyer from Athens, Alexandros Lykourezos. In a telephone interview, Mr. Lykourezos said the defense would take the line that it did not "recognize the competency of the Hague court." He added, however, that the real adjudicator in the situation was  the Serbian President. **********"Milosevic is the main factor and the strongman in the whole crisis," Mr. Lykourezos said. "I don't think he will want General Mladic arrested or want the army to do it."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/25/busin.main_headline: Coming Soon to Computers Everywhere, a World's Fair
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/25/busin.print_headline: Coming Soon to Computers Everywhere, a World's Fair
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/25/busin.body_text: **********It's hard to say no to Carl Malamud. **********The 36-year-old Washington-based economist has successfully pushed, prodded,  wheedled and occasionally even begged powerful corporate executives, Clinton Administration officials and foreign leaders to support his crusade to transform the Internet computer network into a combination of a global Main Street and digital Library of Alexandria. **********Earlier this year Mr. Malamud's nonprofit research group, Internet Multicasting, pushed the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Patent and Trademark Office -- both kicking and screaming, initially -- into establishing public records distribution sites on the Internet. **********Now that both sites are considered strong successes -- the S.E.C. system distributed more than two million documents in its first month of operation -- Mr. Malamud has set out on a much more ambitious effort to extend a high-speed,  multimedia version of the Internet into more than 100 countries. The first step  is to begin on New Year's Day, when he will open the first Internet world's fair, to be followed in February by the start of what he is calling the Internet railroad. (A preview of the fair can be seen at the World Wide Web site http://park.org/fair.) **********The fair itself will be a digital exhibition set up on a vast global "farm"  of computer disks located primarily in Tokyo, San Francisco, Washington and Amsterdam, and created by people in more than 60 countries during the next year. Besides offerings like an interactive history of wind energy at the Netherlands' national site, and other downloadable multimedia material specially designed for the fair, there will be recorded and live events like an interview with the Dalai Lama in early January and video coverage of the 25th anniversary of the Kennedy Center in April. **********"The impact of the fair is huge in Japan," said Joichi Ito, a Japanese business executive who is helping organizing the fair there. "We have everyone focusing on it." **********The railroad is actually an ambitious effort to create a globe-girdling digital pipe to carry the digital world's fair, fast enough to transport multimedia information -- sound, full-motion video and computer data. While the  fair is scheduled to last only through the end of 1996, Mr. Malamud hopes the railroad will become a transport medium that endures into the future. **********In the last year Mr. Malamud has circled the globe seven times himself, logging 250,000 air miles, meeting with government agencies, telephone company and computer executives and raising $100 million in contributions of technology  and service to start the fair. **********In Japan, for example, industry and government have contributed two high-speed digital backbone networks, two terabytes of computer disk space and an I.B.M. supercomputer to help turn the Tokyo neighborhood of Harajuku into a digital city, where people on the scene can tap into the Internet from cybercafes while people around the world can log in for interactive events. **********Mr. Malamud has seized on the idea for the first Internet world's fair and the global railroad as an information-age analogy to the way world fairs in the  earlier, industrial era helped to usher new technologies into widespread use. **********The traditional world fairs "taught people about the world around them, but they also challenged engineers," Mr. Malamud said. "Most importantly, the world  fairs, because of their scale and scope, proved to business and home consumers that the technology had a place in their lives." **********As he prepares to put the fair -- the Internet 1996 World Exposition -- on line, he has assembled a dedicated chain of high-speed fiber-optic links capable of sending data at speeds as high as 155 million bits a second in an arc stretching from Taiwan, Korea and Japan in Asia to Finland, Sweden and Russia in Europe. By the end of 1996 Mr. Malamud hopes to stretch the Internet railroad fiber around the entire world. Along the way he has assembled endorsements from  presidents including Bill Clinton and Boris N. Yeltsin and has occasionally left some of those who have suffered his prodding a little exasperated. **********"I've ended up doing more lobbying for Carl Malamud than I have for some heads of state," said a Federal official who has been called on repeatedly to help gain commitments for the project. **********In an era when the Internet has become synonymous with commercialism and instant fortunes, Mr. Malamud's commitment to public service has set him apart. **********"This is an individual moving companies and countries by the strength of his  will and the obvious goodness of his ideas," said Larry Landweber, a computer scientist who is president of the Internet Society, an international organization that oversees the Internet's standards. "He's an evangelist." **********For Mr. Malamud it is all part of the work that has been his passion since the early 1980's when he was first introduced to computer networking while studying economics as an undergraduate at Indiana University, where he subsequently got an M.B.A. A decade later he became an early volunteer helping to create the Interop conference, a computer-networking industry trade show that was one of the first venues to demonstrate the potential of the Internet. **********With the financial help of Dan Lynch, an Interop founder, Mr. Malamud set out in 1991 as a self-described "Official Internet Explorer," physically traveling around the world three times in his quest to visit as many nodes on the Internet as possible and meet as many of the people who were building the network infrastructure as he could. **********That project led to his 1992 book "Exploring the Internet: a Technical Travelogue," a chatty account of the then-little known elite that built the Internet, before it became a household word. **********The idea of a cyberspace world's fair was hatched in late 1994 when Mr. Malamud was talking with Vinton Cerf, a designer of the original technical protocols -- communications software standards -- for the Internet. Inspired by  the idea, he immediately hopped on a plane to persuade two Internet experts, Jan Murai of Japan and Rob Blokzijl of the Netherlands, whom he had met on his original global tour, to sign on to the idea. **********Today Mr. Malamud maintains that there are still two ways to build the Internet. One is the high-stakes, high-visibility route of initial public offerings in the stock market, the money-raising approach being pursued by people like Netscape Communication's founders, Jim Clark and Mark Andreeson. The other route, Mr. Malamud maintains, is by soliciting funds and building viable public works projects that benefit the common good. **********Mr. Malamud takes pains to point out that he hasn't organized the fair by himself. There are now hundreds of people working on the project around the world, including some of the Internet's best technical experts. **********Chris Swanson, a technical advise from SSDS, a network consulting firm in Englewood, Colo., is global project manager on a piece of the project known as the World's Central Park. Marten Tepstra, a special-projects engineer from Bay Networks Inc., is global project manager on the Internet railroad, responsible for installing and maintaining the router computers that will keep the global traffic flowing over the railroad. **********The effort, Mr. Malamud said, did not compete with the current rush to commercialize the Internet. "People don't move to towns without parks and roads  and schools," he said. "It's a viable part of the global business."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/18/busin.main_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Shrinking Inventories in Midwest Prompt Sharp Rise in Oil Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/18/busin.print_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Shrinking Inventories in Midwest Prompt Sharp Rise in Oil Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/18/busin.body_text: **********Prices of crude oil surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after a scarcity of supplies for delivery against the expiring futures contract  forced buyers to bid prices higher. **********On other markets, prices of natural gas also climbed. The Commodity Research  Bureau index of 21 commodities rose 1.04 point, to 243.81. **********Inventories of crude oil in the Midwest, where the futures contract of the New York Mercantile Exchange specifies delivery, now stand at 64.7 million barrels, 16 percent below the levels of a year ago. **********Tropical storms in the Gulf of Mexico caused Mexican imports to plunge by 31  percent in the last month. And the Interprovincial Pipeline, the world's largest, ruptured this week in Manitoba, reducing supplies from the main artery  of Canadian crude oil to the Midwest. **********"There've been a lot of companies coming in trying to buy the crude," said Dennis Schwiderski, trading manager at Conoco Inc. in Houston. "If they can't find it, they're having to pay up." **********Crude oil for December delivery surged 38 cents, to $18.57 a barrel, the highest price since Sept. 20. The active January contract climbed 28 cents, to $18.13 a barrel. December gasoline rose 1.24 cents, to 52.79 cents a gallon. **********Concerns have apparently faded that a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries next week will lead to an increase in the group's  production ceiling and put more oil on the market. The meeting starts on Tuesday. **********Prices for heating fuels surged as colder weather bolstered demand. Temperatures are expected to be 5 to 10 degrees below normal through the weekend in the Midwest and Northeast, according to the Weather Services Corporation of Lexington, Mass. **********American stockpiles of natural gas are now 7.3 percent below last year's levels, according to the American Gas Association. **********December natural gas surged 5.5 cents, to $2.024 for a thousand cubic feet.
