https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/22/world.main_headline: BALKAN ACCORD: THE WHITE HOUSE;The Next Hurdle: Clinton Must Sell Plan to Americans
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/22/world.print_headline: BALKAN ACCORD: THE WHITE HOUSE;The Next Hurdle: Clinton Must Sell Plan to Americans
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/22/world.body_text: **********Even as he triumphantly announced the Balkan accord, President Clinton today  began the difficult task of convincing a skeptical public and a hostile Congress to support sending 20,000 American troops to enforce the peace in Bosnia. **********"We are at a decisive moment," the President said in a mid-morning appearance in the White House Rose Garden. "The parties have chosen peace. America must choose peace as well." **********Clearly aiming his remarks at the American public, Mr. Clinton spoke of the  "senseless slaughter of so many innocent people that our fellow citizens had to  watch night after night after night for four long years on their television screens." **********White House advisers were keenly aware that Mr. Clinton will have to make a major personal investment in the effort to convince Americans that their country's leadership responsibilities require that their soldiers be sent to a chaotic region to patrol a peace that could yet revert to war. **********With a NATO plan to enforce a Balkans peace expected to be submitted to the President within a week -- and large-scale deployment of troops possibly only weeks away -- Mr. Clinton and his foreign policy team were preparing to mount a  quick and extensive campaign, including a televised presidential address, to overcome expected domestic opposition. **********Senior European officials have said that the promised 60,000-strong NATO peacekeeping force could only take shape if the United States carried through on its promise to send 20,000 American troops. And European countries would probably also pull their troops out at the same time the United States did, French officials said today. **********The Republican leaders of Congress quickly pronounced the troop proposal a militarily risky venture that the President has yet to justify, but which nevertheless is the President's Constitutional prerogative. **********Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich said he would oppose a troop deployment. But he urged Congress to withhold judgment until Mr. Clinton has explained his actions, saying the President "has an enormous burden in trying to lead NATO." **********At an appearance before Republican Governors in New Hampshire, Mr. Gingrich said the House of Representatives would hold hearings on the Bosnia accord next  week and would try to send a Congressional delegation to the region within the month. **********Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, said he was pleased by Mr. Clinton's promise to consult with Congress on any peacekeeping mission, but that no troops should be dispatched without the permission of Congress. **********"This is a very serious matter," Mr. Dole said. "We have no greater responsibility than to prevent the needless shedding of American blood." **********A third Republican Presidential hopeful, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, flatly  opposed a troop commitment. "American power cannot solve every awful problem in  the world," he said. **********Senator Richard Lugar of Indiana, also a Republican Presidential candidate, called Mr. Clinton's diplomatic achievement "remarkable," but added that the details of any peacekeeping mission remain thorny. **********The reaction from the rest of Congress was sharply partisan, with Republicans who spoke on the issue uniformly criticizing the White House's policy. **********Just last week, ignoring warnings that the action could sabotage the peace talks, the House voted 243 to 171 to prevent money from being spent to send American troops to Bosnia. Mr. Gingrich said today that the House would hold extensive hearings on the issue. **********Mr. Clinton's own approach to Bosnia often changed and his attention had seemed episodic until the near collapse of the United Nations peacekeeping mission last summer. At that time, he began to chart a new course of greater American involvement that culminated in today's peace agreement. **********In recent speeches, Mr. Clinton has stressed that "American leadership is indispensable" in settling conflicts from Haiti to the Middle East. But he has never delivered a formal address laying out his Administration's policy toward Bosnia and explaining the commitment he made in 1993 to send ground forces there should peace be reached. **********The President's campaign to persuade the American public got under way even before Mr. Clinton appeared in the Rose Garden today to announce the peace accord. He had already begun calling Congressional leaders to inform them of the breakthrough. **********Even though Congress is in a Thanksgiving recess, the White House planned to  send Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke, the main American peace negotiator, to start briefing Congressional members on the agreement, perhaps as early as Wednesday. **********Anticipating the concerns in Congress, Mr. Clinton said in his Rose Garden remarks that the NATO mission would be "clear and limited" and that American troops "will take their orders only from the American general who commands NATO." **********He said the troops would have the authority to meet any threat with "immediate and decisive force" and that there would be a "reasonable timetable for their withdrawal." **********Once Mr. Clinton is satisfied with the NATO plan, he said he would consult with Congress and ask it to support the American participation. **********Although Mr. Clinton has never spelled out what form he expected that support to take, Administration officials have said he would seek a nonbinding resolution similar to the one President Bush narrowly pushed through Congress before the 1991 Persian Gulf war. **********The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said Mr. Clinton still held that under his Constitutional authority as Commander in Chief he has the right to commit troops abroad without Congressional approval. But he said he thought "the case for American participation in helping make this peace will be clear to the American people and thus also clear to the American Congress." **********In fact, Congress has little power to stop the President from sending troops  except by trying to stop financing for the operation, which is expected to cost  $1.5 billion for a one-year troop deployment. **********And even Congressional critics of the President said today that they were unlikely to block deployment. More likely, they said, Congress will seek to force Mr. Clinton to agree to restrictions on any deployment before the troops go abroad. **********White House officials said they were not certain when the President would address the American people on the issue. The officials also said they were considering whether to add a visit to American troops in Germany to the President's long-planned trip next week to Britain, Ireland and Spain. **********White House officials said they were preparing two levels of arguments to make the case for American troops to be sent to the Balkans. **********Mr. Clinton would argue that America has a moral obligation to stop the killing in Europe and a strategic interest both in remaining the leader of the NATO alliance and in keeping the Balkan conflict from spreading in Europe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/20/world.main_headline: Ex-Communist Appears to Best Walesa for President of Poland
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/20/world.print_headline: Ex-Communist Appears to Best Walesa for President of Poland
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/20/world.body_text: **********In the most stunning result since the end of Communism in Eastern Europe, a telegenic, 41-year-old former Communist appeared set to defeat Lech Walesa, the  icon of democracy and anti-Communism, in Poland's presidential election today, early results showed. **********The outcome of the election, the second democratic ballot for President since the fall of the Communists, teetered all night and would probably be decided by  as few as several thousand votes, analysts said. **********With votes counted from 1,150 of 22,472 polling places, the former Communist, Aleksander Kwasniewski, led with 51.4 percent to Mr. Walesa's 48.6 percent. **********Despite the small number of votes counted, polling experts said the trend was against Mr. Walesa and public television's chief electoral analyst said he doubted the President would win a second term. **********The prospect of a victory by Mr. Kwasniewski, who has packaged himself as a social democrat with economic and foreign policies akin to Mr. Walesa's, sent deep tremors through a society that just six years ago was euphoric over the collapse of Communism. **********The downfall of Mr. Walesa, 52, would end an era that he began 14 years ago as a shipyard worker determined to topple Communism from his base as the leader  of the Solidarity trade union. **********A triumph by Mr. Kwasniewski would give the former Communists, who won legislative elections two years ago, control of Poland's Parliament, Government  and the presidency, furthering a trend throughout Central and Eastern Europe. In the last 18 months former Communists have won parliamentary elections in Hungary, Slovakia and Bulgaria. **********Mr. Walesa's supporters, bewildered and bitter as they appeared on television talk shows tonight, acknowledged that Mr. Kwasniewski's ascendancy would not mean that voters chose a return to Communism or that they even felt a deep nostalgia for the past. The election fight was more over symbols and style than  over differences on how to manage the transformation from Communism to capitalism. **********But with the highest voter turnout -- 67.2 percent -- since democratic elections returned to Poland in 1990, the results showed a society deeply divided. Speaking before early results were available, Mr. Kwasniewski recognized the divisions in a short, conciliatory statement before his supporters at a crowded headquarters in Warsaw. **********"The biggest sin would be to divide Poles," he said. "This is not about who has power or no power. Our argument is about vision. In Poland there is a lot of space." **********He added that Poland had to move toward Western Europe and could only do so with the combined efforts of his voters, Mr. Walesa's voters and those who abstained. **********Mr. Walesa's failure appeared to be largely the result of his frittering away the moral authority he earned as the imprisoned leader of the Solidarity movement. Those efforts won him the Nobel Prize for Peace and the recognition of world leaders. **********He tried to regain that authority by running a rough and demagogic anti-Communist campaign intended to raise fears about the return of the old system. He accused Mr. Kwasniewski of being part of a web of "lies" and "thugs." His television commercials showed bleak black-and-white footage of food lines in the 1980's. **********While those tactics may have gained him some votes, they also alienated his own supporters, some of whom stayed home. A philosophy professor at the Polish Academy of Sciences, Pawel Dybel, a Solidarity supporter from the 1980's, said he was so disgusted by Mr. Walesa's performance during the presidential debates that he did not vote. "If Walesa wins that's fine, but I don't want to feel responsible," he said. **********The breakdown of the vote reflected the uneven effects of Poland's fast-expanding market economy, which is expected to grow by more than six percent this year. The large urban centers, with low unemployment and streets lined with smart stores, largely voted for Mr. Walesa. Peasants and workers in small towns who have felt left out of the economic gains voted for Mr. Kwasniewski. **********The Roman Catholic Church, which lent catechism rooms and church basements to the Solidarity movement during the period of martial law under Communism, had swung behind Mr. Walesa in recent days. But it was done in a calibrated manner,  on radio stations and in pastoral letters, to avoid antagonizing voters who have expressed resentment of the church's intrusion in politics. **********In sermons this morning, several priests, like the Rev. Henryk Jankowski in Gdansk, who gave an anti-Semitic sermon in the President's presence this year, called Mr. Walesa the only candidate who could be the guardian of "religious and national identity." Jozef Cardinal Glemp said after casting his vote that the choice was between two values: "Christian" and "neo-pagan." **********In the end, Mr. Walesa had to overcome his erratic five-year tenure as President. He had been applauded by many for keeping checks and balances in the  new democratic system. But critics charged that he gradually became more obstreperous and inclined to petty interference in political issues. **********That behavior, combined with his lack of education, upset supporters who questioned his stature as head of state. On Nov. 12, in the first of two presidential television debates, he shocked even his most faithful backers. He chided a journalist who asked him about his opposition to abortion with the response: "If abortion had been legal, you would probably have gone down the drain." **********As his sense of power and grandeur increased, Mr. Walesa's popularity dwindled. At times, he seemed to act more like a Communist Party first secretary, oblivious to legal restraint. Last year, a public opinion survey showed higher esteem for Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Communist leader who imposed martial law, than for Mr. Walesa. **********Mr. Walesa repeatedly tried to strengthen his grip over the army, the police  and public television. He kept his roots in the shipyard city of Gdansk, returning there on weekends. **********But he moved out of the relatively simple presidential mansion, the Belvedere in Warsaw, in favor of an ornate 17th-century palace filled with antiques and chandeliers. **********And during negotiations on Poland's new constitution, a document yet to be finalized, Mr. Walesa kept insisting on the incorporation of strong presidential powers. His old friend, Adam Michnik, a Solidarity dissident and now editor of the largest-circulation newspaper, Gazeta Wyborcza, accused Mr. Walesa last year of preparing to establish a dictatorship. **********Nevertheless, his old friends from Solidarity insisted that he was preferable to the former Communists he had helped bring down in the 1980's. **********"Walesa was always supporting economic reform and always supporting Poland joining the European Union and NATO in a very clear way and always making very clear our independence from Russia," said Bronislaw Geremek, an intellectual leader of Solidarity. **********Mr. Kwasniewski became a strong challenger not only because of his ability on television and his appearance of modernity. He was also able to diffuse the stark differences between the old Communist system and the new democratic Poland by sending a message about the future. Photographs in campaign leaflets -- of Mr. Kwasniewski in a fashionable tuxedo and his wife, Jolanta, in a Western-style kitchen -- were designed to show them as the model Polish couple. **********He insisted that he held no differences with Mr. Walesa on foreign policy: Poland would join the European Union and the North Atlantic Treaty Alliance under his leadership too. **********In addition, he was able to marshal the organizational skills of the former Communist Party behind his new party, the Left Democratic Alliance, built on the ruins of the old Communist machine. **********The party's showing was impressive, analysts said. By gaining 35 percent of the votes in the first round of the presidential election two weeks ago, the Alliance expanded what was thought to be its universe of 25 percent of the electorate and more than doubled its vote in the parliamentary elections two years ago. **********But Mr. Kwasniewski had some last-minute political problems to overcome. He failed to report his wife's major shareholdings in an insurance company in a financial disclosure form required from all members of Parliament. **********His lack of candor contributed to an impression that the former Communists benefited more than other members of society in the transformation to a market economy. **********And in another embarrassment, Gdansk University, where Mr. Kwansiewski said he had earned his degree in economics in 1978, announced a few days before the election that he failed to complete all requirements for the degree. **********In a sign of how much Poland has changed in the six years since the fall of Communism, the investment bank Salomon Brothers considered the country of 40 million people with fast economic growth worthy of an election prognosis. **********The bank said in an analysis last week that a victory by Mr. Kwasniewski would not adversely affect the economy and would have the positive result of smoother relations between the presidency and Parliament.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/11/busin.main_headline: Huge Photo Archive Bought By the Chairman of Microsoft
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/11/busin.print_headline: Huge Photo Archive Bought By the Chairman of Microsoft
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/11/busin.body_text: **********William H. Gates, the software billionaire and champion of 21st-century technology, has purchased the Bettmann Archive, whose millions of historical photographs are a visual chronicle of the 20th century. **********For the last few years, Mr. Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, has been acquiring the electronic rights to thousands of images -- mainly works  of art -- through a small company in Bellevue, Wash., that he owns. But the purchase of Bettmann, announced yesterday, is by far his biggest step toward building a huge library of digitally stored images that can someday be sampled and sold on computer disks or over computer networks, not only to professionals  but to the public as well. **********The Bettmann acquisition is also part of the trend of converting the pictures, artworks and texts of the past into the digital code of computers. The goal is being pursued by museums and libraries throughout the world, though the  process is often slow and costly. **********The ideal of this electronic conversion is to democratize art and scholarship, enabling people who could never travel to the Library of Congress or the Hermitage to sample their intellectual treasures, and to preserve aging pictures and documents for posterity. **********Mr. Gates has shown himself eager to speed the process along with some of his own money. Yet for entrepreneurs like Mr. Gates, democracy also means mass markets, and big money could be made by collecting perhaps only a few pennies from each person who taps a computer mouse in search of cultural enrichment. And given Mr. Gates's immense wealth and shrewd business instincts, questions have been raised about whether there is a danger in having the electronic rights to so many historical images controlled by one man. **********"The cultural issue raised by the Bettmann purchase is whether we're seeing history sold to the highest bidder or we'll eventually see history made more accessible to the public as a result," said Paul Saffo, a director of the Institute for the Future, a nonprofit research group in Menlo Park, Calif. **********The terms of the Bettmann acquisition were not disclosed, though people involved in the deal said it was a "multimillion-dollar transaction." Both Mr. Gates's company, the Corbis Corporation, and the owner of Bettmann, the Kraus Organization in New York, are private companies. As such, they are not required  to make financial information public. **********For Mr. Gates, one of the nation's richest men, the money involved is small at present but likely to grow. His drive to build a digital storehouse of images is a long-term bet -- and one that suggests he believes there will be considerable demand for this so-called electronic content. **********The acquisition, his lieutenants say, is a part of the building process, but  only one step. "We want to make Corbis the premier place to come for digital content," Doug Rowan, the president of Corbis, said. **********Before acquiring Bettmann, Corbis had the electronic rights to 500,000 images including art from the National Gallery of London, the Philadelphia Museum and the Barnes Foundation, and pictures from photographers like Roger Ressmeyer and  Galen Rowell. Corbis has been negotiating with the Hermitage in St. Petersburg,  Russia, Mr. Rowan said, and a licensing deal should be announced soon. **********But the Bettmann Archive, founded by Otto L. Bettmann, who fled Germany in the 1930's, has about 16 million images. Though the archive has many medical and technical drawings -- favorites of Dr. Bettmann -- its largest holding is 11.5 million photographic images, most of which were acquired from the United Press International news service in 1990. Those pictures run the gamut from Marilyn Monroe to Malcolm X, from Depression mothers to the Duchess of Windsor, from Albert Einstein sticking out his tongue to John McEnroe doing the same. **********Today the photo-archive industry -- with worldwide revenue estimated at $500  million a year -- caters mainly to businesses. A newspaper, magazine, textbook publisher or advertising agency in need of a certain photo image can call up Bettmann and receive it quickly for a fee of $50 to thousands of dollars. **********But the long-term appeal of Bettmann as a business is the promise that digital technology will enable its images to be distributed inexpensively to a far wider market. As more people have powerful home computers with access to the Internet and the World Wide Web, a consumer market for digitized images could well emerge. **********Once set up, it would work something like this: a child is working at home on a report on World War II. He or she decides it would be nice to have a picture of Winston Churchill in the report. The child browses through a Bettmann Web site on the Internet, selects a Churchill picture and clicks. On the screen, a box pops up asking whether the user wants to pay, say, 25 cents, for one-time use of the Churchill picture and ask for credit card or bank account information, which only a parent could provide. If Mom or Dad agrees, the Churchill picture goes in the report. **********There are, to be sure, many technical and legal obstacles to overcome before  a consumer market in digital images develops. Software standards on security and payment methods must be established, for example. Trying to enforce copyright claims will be difficult. And more households will have to have inexpensive, speedy access to the Internet. **********So for the next few years, at least, the Bettmann Archive's business of selling to professionals will change little. "But the future is the use of digital images by millions of consumers instead of tens of thousands of businesses," Mr. Rowan of Corbis said. **********News of the Bettmann acquisition surprised people in the photographic archive business. But they also saw it as the real start of an inevitable shakeout in their industry. **********"Digitizing photographic images is the future of this business -- you have to move in that direction," said Alan Carey, who is president of the Picture Agency Council of America, a trade organization. "And the cost of scanning, indexing and marketing electronic images means we will see a consolidation in this industry." **********Herbert Gstalder, president of the Kraus Organization, which sold Bettmann to Mr. Gates's company, explained that it was largely the steep cost of shifting to digital technology that prompted the sale. **********Conversations between Mr. Gstalder and Corbis began 18 months ago, and a deal was struck with Mr. Gates six weeks ago on a trip to Seattle. "We recognize the  value of what we have at the Bettmann Archive in this new electronic world," Mr. Gstalder said. "But the issue was could we take the Bettmann Archive into the 21st century the way they could, with their money and long-term perspective? I doubt it."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/20/world.main_headline: U.S. Diplomat to Head Bosnia Mission
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/20/world.print_headline: U.S. Diplomat to Head Bosnia Mission
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/20/world.body_text: **********An American career diplomat, Robert Frowick, was appointed today to supervise civilian peace efforts in Bosnia. **********Mr. Frowick will head a task force supervising elections, arms control and human rights in Bosnia, as provided by the peace agreement formally signed in Paris last week. **********Robert Frowick has been appointed to the position," a spokeswoman for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe said. "He will be heading to Sarajevo on Dec. 30." **********The United States and its European allies quarreled earlier this month over who would head the mission. Washington pushed hard for Mr. Frowick, but several  European nations had misgivings that the United States would play too dominant a role in Bosnia. **********The United States led diplomatic efforts to persuade the leaders of Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia to agree to a deal to end the war in Bosnia. **********Mr. Frowick is to take up his duties immediately.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/15/busin.main_headline: Smitten by Britain, Business Rushes In
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/15/busin.print_headline: Smitten by Britain, Business Rushes In
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/15/busin.body_text: **********NORTHEAST England is littered with dead and dying industries of yore. There are the coal mines, now just holes in the ground, that fueled the Industrial Revolution. There are the shipyards, now largely desolate, that helped Britannia rule the waves. There are the steel mills, now almost silent, that once roared with the nation's economic might. **********But alongside those industrial dinosaurs, a new economy is emerging. Lucky Goldstar, the South Korean electronics company, just opened a gleaming new, $45  million television and microwave-oven factory in the area. After looking at sites all over Europe, Siemens of Germany recently announced that it would build a huge, $1.7 billion semiconductor plant here, and Fujitsu of Japan is doubling  the size of its four-year-old chip plant. Nissan of Japan is expanding its nearby car factory. **********In politics as in geography, Britain has long been on the fringes of Europe. But, as northeast England's experience suggests, it is increasingly seen as ground zero by companies all over the world needing a manufacturing base for the European single market. **********Britain draws more foreign direct investment in new factories, research centers and other business operations -- and the jobs that go with them -- than  any other country in Europe. **********The volume has clearly surged since former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher took office in 1979 and began her free-market revolution. For example, the number of foreign projects more than doubled to 434 in the 1995 fiscal year ended June 30 from 183 in 1980, while the number of jobs those projects created, or kept from moving to other countries, rose to 88,000 from 14,000. **********Japan alone announced 44 projects last year, seven more than in the entire period of 1980 to 1986, according to the Japanese Embassy here. **********The influx has by no means solved all of the Newcastle area's economic problems, or Britain's. And it is hardly unusual for jobs to migrate to regions  where unemployment is high, especially if governments and workers bend over backward to lure and accommodate employers. In an age of ruthless global competition, though, when corporate investment decisions can amount to a highly  visible plebiscite on the economic future of the countries in which the companies do business, the investment flow to Britain has drawn the attention of other European nations. **********For years, much of Europe derided Britain for creating a low-wage, low-security economy -- one far closer to the American model of flexible work forces and intense pressure to drive down costs than to the European tradition of high pay, lavish benefits, strong unions, restrictive work rules, generous social welfare systems and high taxes. **********Now, however, policy makers in other countries are looking more closely at the British experience as they grapple with high unemployment and eroding international competitiveness. France's unemployment rate this year of 11.5 percent, for example, is more than three points above Britain's, but its average manufacturing labor costs are 30 percent higher. Britain's unemployment rate in  August was 8.2 percent. Germany has a slightly lower rate at 8.1 percent, but its wage costs are nearly double Britain's. **********Bernd Pischetsrieder, chairman of the German automaker BMW, said Britain had  gotten a huge head start over the rest of Europe in making the wrenching policy  changes necessary to compete in the global economy. Last year, BMW bought the British car maker Rover. **********"Great Britain is currently the most attractive country among all European locations for the production of cars," Mr. Pischetsrieder said at an industry conference in Cambridge, England, last week. "This results from the structural reforms initiated by Margaret Thatcher in the early 1980's, the most significant factor of course being the rearrangement of industrial relations between companies and trade unions." **********Noting that the United States invested 7.5 times as much in Britain between 1986 and 1993 as in Germany, Mr. Pischetsrieder added: "The bottom line is that  what you started in Great Britain back in the early 1980's, other European countries still have to do today. They have to initiate a process of structural  renewal on all levels and in all significant areas." **********In Britain itself, some of the most economically deprived regions are grudgingly reassessing their longstanding antipathy to the policies pursued by the Conservative Government over the last 16 years, first under Mrs. Thatcher and now under her successor, John Major. Those policies include weakening the power of unions, resisting calls for a minimum wage, refusing to adopt European  Union regulations protecting workers' rights and generally letting free-market forces, rather than government intervention, shape the economy. AROUND Newcastle, those policies were seen by most people as causing considerable pain as the region's old economy died out over the last two decades, pushing unemployment rates to more than 20 percent at their peak at the end of the 1980's and creating considerable social tension and political disaffection. **********Now foreign investment is holding out the promise of an economic rebirth, albeit one shorn of the assurances of lifetime work and relatively high wages that workers once thought they could count on. While Newcastle still has some of the country's worst poverty, and the crime and other social problems that go with it, its unemployment rate has moved steadily down into the mid-teens. **********As a result, even some people suspicious of the Conservative Party's ideology are asking a prickly political question: Is the new economy, and the brighter future it promises, the legacy of Thatcherism? **********Ross Forbes, for one, is having trouble making up his mind about Mrs. Thatcher's legacy. A few years ago, Mr. Forbes was working for the National Union of Mineworkers, battling the Government's plans to close more of the region's pits and put thousands of miners out of work at a time when the other backbones of the regional economy were also breaking. (In 1975, 35 percent of the region's employment was in coal, shipbuilding and steel. Today it is less than 1 percent.) **********Now Mr. Forbes is the communications manager for the North Tyneside Council,  one of the local governments in the area, helping to promote the region's attractiveness to foreign investors. The Conservatives "did not have to go as far as they did" in closing unprofitable mines and allowing the region to go through such intense economic pain in the name of allowing the market to do its work, he said. "The treatment of the northeast region in the 1980's was bloody." **********On the other hand, Mr. Forbes said, "There are rules in the global market that the National Union of Mineworkers could not rewrite." **********The region is still a bastion of support for the opposition Labor Party. But  even Labor, which a decade ago was fighting ferociously but unsuccessfully to restore the power of unions and force the government to take a more interventionist approach to the economy, has now embraced a market-driven economic policy and is de-emphasizing its historic links to unions. **********Labor's economic policies, in fact, are increasingly difficult to distinguish from those of the Conservatives. As it has moved to the right, its popularity has risen sharply, and it now is far ahead of the Conservatives in the opinion polls. Around Newcastle, that means a growing acceptance that perhaps the changes of the Thatcher years contributed to putting Britain into something closer to international fighting trim than it was two decades ago. **********"If the object is to attract investment on a global basis, someone has got the formula right," Mr. Forbes said. **********That formula, he said, encompasses many factors, including the cooperation of unions, local and national government agencies and universities, but also undoubtedly the pro-business environment at the heart of Thatcherism. **********"Five years ago I would have been a cynic about the ability of [foreign] investment to transform an area," Mr. Forbes said. Now, he said, he is a believer. **********Thatcherism, of course, was aimed more at reinvigorating domestic industry than at attracting foreign companies. While there is a consensus that British industry is more vibrant and competitive now than 15 years ago, particularly in  industries that were privatized under the Conservatives, Britain is by no means  a world beater economically. **********But while Germany is seeing corporate trend setters like Daimler-Benz and Volkswagen moving production to lower-cost sites, and while France has retained  its traditional indifference to foreign investors, along with its high unemployment rates, Britain is at least reaping the benefits that come with new  employers and the jobs and technologies they bring. **********"The U.K. has a long tradition of welcoming inward investment, under Labor as well as under Conservative Governments before Mrs. Thatcher, but the increase has certainly been influenced by the Thatcherite changes that took place," said  Sir Geoffrey Owen, the head of the Business Policy Program at the London School  of Economics. "Certainly France and Germany are looking at the U.K. and the economic and political developments here and seeing what can be learned from it." **********American companies have a long tradition of investing in Britain, which over  the last several decades has been the site of more United States direct investment than any other country. In 1993, the most recent year for which figures were available, Britain accounted for 17.4 percent of America's direct investment worldwide and 35 percent of its direct investment in Europe. **********But Britain's appeal is now much broader. Over the last decade, Britain has become the primary European location for the three big Japanese car companies, Nissan, Toyota and Honda. In the last year or two it has emerged as the No. 1 European choice for many Asian electronics companies, including Samsung of Korea; Fujitsu, and Lucky Goldstar's LG Electronics. At the same time it is attracting more investment from German and other European manufacturers who want to expand outside of their high-cost home markets; the recent Siemens deal and BMW's acquisition of Rover are the two most prominent examples. **********THE surge of foreign investment is being driven by many factors, not least of which is that Britain, a trading nation throughout its history, has always sought out foreign investment more aggressively than its European neighbors have. **********It does not hurt that English is almost always the first or second language of international companies. At the moment, Britain has a relatively weak currency, making goods exported from here more competitive in other European markets. **********But in the end, most companies are looking for the best available combination of work force skills and flexibility and low costs. Different companies have different needs. In semiconductor manufacturing, labor costs are a small portion of total production costs. But Siemens found Britain attractive because the looser workplace restrictions made it cheaper and easier to run its new plant in the Newcastle area in three shifts around the clock than it could have elsewhere in Europe. **********Lucky Goldstar had run a smaller microwave-oven plant in the Newcastle area for several years before deciding last year to build its much bigger new plant.  But the company reviewed its British operation and its other big European plant, in Germany, where it produced televisions, and decided to move TV manufacturing  to the new British plant. **********"The cost structure in the U.K. is much more competitive than in mainland European countries," said Ray Couch, the new plant's personnel manager. "The casualty from our plant is the German factory, because we've taken their TV business from them."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/01/busin.main_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS: FUNDS WATCH;Where the New Issues Are
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/01/busin.print_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS: FUNDS WATCH;Where the New Issues Are
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/01/busin.body_text: **********THE continuing bull market is enticing large numbers of fledgling companies to go public. Mutual funds are presumed to be big buyers of these new issues, but just which funds are getting the goods is hard to gauge. **********Morningstar, the fund research company in Chicago, decided to find out. Its analysts cross-checked the latest portfolios of diversified equity and specialty funds with its own stock data base to identify holdings that had come  to market in the previous 12 months. Because funds must provide a list of holdings only twice a year, their most recent portfolios may not reflect stocks  that were bought and flipped after a short period. Furthermore, Morningstar could not identify every holding. **********Still, the new stocks that turned up were clustered in the aggressive growth and small company fund categories, particularly in momentum funds, like Twentieth Century Giftrust and PBHG Emerging Growth, which focus on stocks whose prices are gaining rapidly. Real estate funds also held quite a few new issues,  probably because growing demand oustrips the supply of seasoned stocks in that category, the analysts surmised. **********New issues have an obvious allure. Bloomberg's I.P.O. index shot up 53 percent through the end of August, nearly double the gain of the Standard & Poor's 500 index. So it should come as no surprise that among the top-performing small-cap funds this year are BT Investment Small Cap, with nearly half its assets in new issues, and Govett Smaller Companies, another small-cap fancier. **********On the darker side, the Morningstar analysts pointed out that new issues tend to fizzle quickly when the market turns bearish -- a warning for investors in such funds. **********New Guidelines On Computer Chat **********The National Association of Securities Dealers has finally caught up with the explosion in electronic media. A self-regulating body for the securities industry, the N.A.S.D. is setting specific guidelines for marketing and advertising of computer communications, like pages on the World Wide Web. **********The association cannot regulate personalized E-mail or communications posted  by the public on electronic bulletin boards sponsored by its members. In those areas, investors remain on their own. **********New N.A.S.D. members will have to have their electronic advertising approved  in advance; after a year, they simply have to file the ads with the agency within 10 days. **********Because of persistent questions about the use of telemarketing scripts, the agency is amending its definition of sales literature to include these scripts.  They are really no more than a form letter delivered orally, said Thomas A. Pappas, assistant director of the advertising regulation department. **********Finally, to stem the flow of poorly conceived ads that are submitted for its  approval, the association is requiring investment firms to have the appropriate  people, other than the ad's creators, scrutinize all ads first. **********New Funds **********Charles Schwab & Company has added a trio of asset-allocation funds with varying mixes of stocks and bonds under the name Schwab Asset Director. The High Growth Portfolio aims to be 80 percent invested in stocks, Balanced Growth aims  for 60 percent, and Conservative Growth sets a 40 percent target. Those percentages may change within target ranges based on market conditions. **********All three funds are sold without a sales charge. Annual operating expenses are expected to be 0.89 percent of assets. The minimum investment is $1,000, or  $500 in I.R.A.'s. **********In Brief **********Vincent Bajakian, who managed $11.6 billion in the Vanguard Wellington fund,  died when the plane he was piloting crashed on Long Island. He was 64. The fund, which invests in both stocks and bonds and is popular for retirement accounts, will be managed for the time being by Ernst H. Von Metzsch of Wellington Management. Mr. Von Metzsch, previously the fund's assistant portfolio manager,  has worked on the fund for more than 20 years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/30/busin.main_headline: 32 Million in Penalties Sought In Motel 6 Insider Trading Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/30/busin.print_headline: 32 Million in Penalties Sought In Motel 6 Insider Trading Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/30/busin.body_text: **********The Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking about $32 million from two  men charged in an insider trading case involving Motel 6 L.P. and the Norton Company, according to a court order made public by the S.E.C. today. **********That amount ranks among the highest penalties ever sought by the agency in an insider trading case, current and former S.E.C. officials said. **********Michael Borlinghaus of Middletown, N.J., was ordered by a Federal court in New York to pay $20 million, according to a Nov. 16 court order. The agency is seeking a similar order that would require Heinz Grein of Budapest, Hungary, to  pay about $12 million. **********"That is a very significant amount of money and clearly one of the biggest amounts when you add up" the totals, said Bruce Hiler, a former associate director in the S.E.C.'s enforcement division. **********The agency named about 23 defendants in a case brought in 1992 and named six  more in a related suit filed on March 6 of this year. **********Mr. Borlinghaus and Mr. Grein, the co-owners of a defunct brokerage called Frost & Sullivan Holding Corporation, failed to answer the charges in the March  suit, said Eric Schmidt, an assistant regional director in the enforcement division of the S.E.C.'s New York office. As a result, the S.E.C. sought to impose triple penalties on both men, the maximum allowed under insider trading laws. **********Whether the S.E.C. will be able to collect these amounts remains to be seen.  Mr. Grein couldn't be located for comment, and Mr. Borlinghaus refused to discuss the case. **********The cases of Motel 6 and Norton, which are related, involved insider trading  that the S.E.C. said took place before the Dallas-based motel chain announced that it had received a tender offer from Accor S.A. of France, which acquired Motel 6 in 1990. Compagnie de Saint-Gobain acquired 95 percent of Norton's outstanding shares the same year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/03/busin.main_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;A Lot of Pain, Minuscule Capital Gain
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/03/busin.print_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;A Lot of Pain, Minuscule Capital Gain
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/03/busin.body_text: **********IT'S that time of year when mutual fund investors often trip over the tax law. **********If they buy shares in a fund just before it makes a distribution, typically in November or December, they will probably be disappointed. The share price drops in an amount equal to the amount of the distribution, and the investor gets a tax bill even though he did not participate in those gains over the last  year. With so many funds expected to post big gains this year, the tax could be  considerable. **********Albert Dickman, an investor in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., recently encountered just such a problem. He bought shares in the Brandywine fund in late September,  and the fund made a distribution to shareholders in October. To Mr. Dickman's chagrin, he immediately became liable for taxes on $5,600 of capital gains even  though the value of his investment barely changed. "I'm a supposedly knowledgeable businessman," he said, of the common investment trap. "I think a company of that size and stature should alert investors." **********Foster S. Friess, manager of the Brandywine fund, said: "We go to exceptional lengths to enclose a notice that highlights the fact that the distribution is coming. And, it is also highlighted in our most recent annual report." Moreover, a large notice was included in the June 30 report, sent to all potential shareholders beginning in the second week of July. **********Funds that are eager to attract money at the end of the year may be paying out distributions earlier. Like the Brandywine fund, the Kaufmann fund has already done so. In advertisements, Kaufmann notes that its capital gains distribution was made on Nov. 7, meaning anyone who buys after that time does not have to worry about a nasty tax surprise early next year. **********And of course, anyone buying in a tax-deferred retirement account does not have to worry about short-term tax consequences. For other investors, it may be  time to start counting up those distribution dollars and the tax impact. **********Among stock funds that made distributions in October and November, the fund with the biggest capital gain distribution as a percent of its net asset value was Federated Growth Strategies A. It distributed $5.39 in long-term gains for each share, valued at $21.77, on Nov. 9. The distribution amounted to nearly 25  percent of the share's net asset value. **********The best hope for Federated shareholders is that Congress and the White House agree on tax relief for capital gains. Under the proposal hammered out by a House-Senate conference, half of all long-term capital gains could be excluded from tax, lowering the top rate to an effective rate of 19.8 percent from 28 percent. **********For an investor with 1,000 shares of Federated Growth Strategies, the distribution amounts to $5,390, and the tax liability would be $1,509 at the top rate. If the Congressional proposal becomes law and is made retroactive, the same investor would owe $442 less, or $1,067.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/28/busin.main_headline: Chiefs' Dispute Threat to Merger Of 2 California Health Networks
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/28/busin.print_headline: Chiefs' Dispute Threat to Merger Of 2 California Health Networks
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/28/busin.body_text: **********The proposed merger of Wellpoint Health Networks Inc. and Health Systems International Inc. appeared to be on the verge of collapse yesterday after the chief executive of Health Systems withdrew his support for the $1.89 billion deal. **********Health Systems said Dr. Malik M. Hasan, its chief executive and biggest shareholder, with a 19 percent stake, and a group of other shareholders who together have a 6 percent stake, had rescinded their stockholder agreements and  revoked proxies to vote for the deal. **********The main area of contention is how Dr. Hasan and Wellpoint's chief executive would divide their authority at the combined company. **********The two companies, both of which are based in California, would have $6 billion in combined annual revenues and 4.5 million customers. That would make the new company the biggest publicly traded operator of health maintenance organizations and discount health plans in the United States. **********The dispute unnerved investors. The shares of Health Systems fell 87.5 cents  yesterday to close at $30.625 on the New York Stock Exchange, while Wellpoint shares fell $1.125, to $29.875. **********The merger negotiations involve a host of investment bankers, and analysts said their firms stood to lose tens of millions of dollars in fees if the deal fell through. **********Health Systems and Wellpoint agreed in March to a carefully structured stock  deal, under which Wellpoint would acquire Health Systems. But with deadlines for completion approaching, Dr. Hasan and Leonard D. Schaeffer, the chief executive of Wellpoint, were still jousting over who would make decisions about  some of the most important parts of the business, including medical cost management and further mergers and acquisitions. **********Dr. Hasan said in an interview yesterday that the merger was structured as an acquisition by Wellpoint so the new company could continue to use the widely recognized Blue Cross name; the nonprofit Blue Cross of California owns 80 percent of Wellpoint. The deal was also intended to minimize the transfer of good will to the new company's balance sheet, lightening a potential drag on future earnings reports. **********Both Health Systems and Wellpoint grew from Blue Cross of California. Mr. Schaeffer, who would be chief executive of the new company, has ambitious plans  to acquire Blue Cross companies across the country. **********But Health Systems has already established outposts in Philadelphia and New England. It said that under the merger agreement, Dr. Hasan, who would become chairman of the combined company, would retain authority over mergers as well as the business of converting traditional fee-for-service health plans into managed-care plans, which put pressure on doctors to hold down costs. **********"We have a three-page, very heavily negotiated agreement on the sharing of the responsibilities," Dr. Hasan said. "Now they have come up with the interpretation that this agreement doesn't survive the closing of the deal. It's very bizarre. **********"It was supposed to be merger of equals, sharing responsibilities equally. Mr. Schaeffer can do a lot of one-handed clapping. Good luck to them." **********Mr. Schaeffer did not respond yesterday to a request for comment. **********Spokesmen for both companies said yesterday that Wellpoint and Health Systems would still try to complete the merger. "For the record, we are still pursuing the deal," David Olson, a spokesman for Health Systems, said. Dr. Hasan said special committees of the Health Systems and Wellpoint boards would meet this week to continue discussions. **********John Cygul, a spokesman for Wellpoint, said the special committees had met recently and were "discussing whether it would be productive to meet again." **********Edward B. Keaney, a health care securities analyst with Volpe, Welty in San Francisco, said, "There still is time, but there is very little time." **********The merger agreement is to expire on Dec. 31. Under Securities and Exchange Commission rules, proxies must be circulated for at least 20 business days beforehand, analysts said. There would be a $50 million penalty if either party  broke the agreement before the deadline. **********Last week, Wellpoint and Blue Cross of California told regulators at the state's Department of Corporations that they wanted to extend the deadline to Jan. 15. But Health Systems said yesterday that there was no assurance that there could be an extension on terms that all sides would accept. **********Mr. Cygul said, "We think the definitive agreement we signed on March 31 was  very clear and that any questions are to be resolved by the board of the new company." On the new board, the five Health Systems directors would be outnumbered by five Wellpoint directors plus three directors from Blue Cross. Mr. Cygul declined to discuss other details of the agreement. **********A collapse of the deal would upset plans for Wellpoint to hand over $1 billion in cash and new company stock valued at $2 billion to two health care foundations that were established to repay California taxpayers for decades of concessions to the nonprofit Blue Cross plan. **********A third organization, the California Wellness Foundation, was established when Health Net, a big, nonprofit health maintenance organization, was converted to a for-profit company before it was merged into Health Systems. That foundation would get a 23 percent stake in the new company in nonvoting stock. **********Herb Gunther, a spokesman for the California Wellness Foundation, said the group supported the merger and hoped that it would still take place. **********The shareholders supporting Dr. Hasan include two members of the Health Systems board, E. Keith Hovland and Dale T. Berkbigler, and Lawrence E. Austin,  Linda Janda and Dr. and Mrs. Jarvis Ryals, described as associates and friends of Dr. Hasan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/01/world.main_headline: Study Faults Powell Aides On Somalia
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/01/world.print_headline: Study Faults Powell Aides On Somalia
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/01/world.body_text: **********A Senate report on the ill-fated Army commando raid during the United Nations peacekeeping mission in Somalia two years ago criticizes a decision supported by Gen. Colin L. Powell's staff and, apparently, by the general himself when he was Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. **********The decision was to reject a request to send AC-130 gunships requested by commanders in Somalia. The report argues that those gunships may have indirectly protected the 18 American soldiers who died during that raid in Mogadishu, the Somali capital. **********Les Aspin was ousted as Secretary of Defense in January 1994 in large part because of the failed raid and his decision not to send tanks to Somalia, which  some officers believed might have reduced the casualties. **********But the report, released late Friday by the Senate Armed Services Committee,  suggests the decision against sending gunships may have been just as significant, and was one in which General Powell played a main role and Mr. Aspin little or none. **********The AC-130 is a slow-moving aircraft bristling with cannon and other guns that can put thousands of rounds of deadly fire on a target in night or day operations. United States commanders in Somalia said the AC-130's had a profound psychological effect on potential foes and, on earlier missions in Somalia, were one of the few American weapons the Somali militias feared. **********General Powell told Senate investigators he did not recall playing a role in  deciding whether to redeploy the AC-130's, although he did say the aircraft "wrecked a few buildings and it wasn't the greatest imagery on CNN" when used in Somalia. **********But two four-star generals recalled talking to General Powell specifically about the request for the planes. Gen. Joseph Hoar, the head of the United States Central Command, remembered a three-way phone call with General Powell and Gen. Wayne Downing, head of the United States Special Forces Command, in which General Hoar opposed sending the aircraft. **********General Downing said: "I advised that I would like to have the AC-130's. General Powell advised that we needed to keep the numbers down." **********One of the problems facing American policymakers, including Mr. Aspin and his aides, was how to support the United Nations mission in Somalia while carrying out Washington's commitment to withdraw American troops from the East African country. **********United States troops entered Somalia in December 1992 to help relieve famine  brought on by civil war, but the Americans and other foreign troops in the United Nations force that took over the mission soon became embroiled in the power struggles of Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, a Somali militia commander. **********"I was aware of and supported the Joint Staff's recommendation that AC-130's  not be included in the force package because they were unnecessary and inappropriate for the mission," Frank Wisner, who was Undersecretary of Defense, told Senate investigators, "especially considering the extensive collateral damage they could be expected to cause in an urban environment." **********But Mr. Aspin said he was never aware that the AC-130's were ever a part of the reinforcement package. **********Among the committee's conclusions, including the familiar criticism of changing the United Nations missions to hunt down General Aidid, was a strong rebuke to commanders who recommended against the AC-130's. The hunt for General  Aidid began after his forces killed 25 Pakistani peacekeepers. **********"It is difficult to understand the decision to omit the AC-130 gunships from  the Joint Task Force Ranger force package," the report concluded. "The AC-130's  were part of all the force-package options and were included in all of the training exercises. This decision is inconsistent with the principle that you fight as you train." **********Tensions in Mogadishu increased sharply in the summer of 1993 after General Aidid's men ambushed the Pakistani peacekeepers, and the United Nations put a $25,000 bounty on General Aidid's head and began a manhunt. Commanders in Somalia, included Maj. Gen. Thomas Montgomery of the United States Army, requested commandos, AC-130's and, ultimately, tanks and more armored vehicles. **********General Powell initially opposed trying to capture General Aidid but he relented after the death of several American soldiers and repeated requests from American field commanders. In a phone call to Mr. Aspin in August 1993 while the Defense Secretary was vacationing in Wisconsin, General Powell recommended sending the commandos but not the AC-130's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/10/busin.body_text: **********Gauging the Cost Of 401(k) Plans **********The amount paid for 401(k) plans can vary widely, according to the Butler Index, begun recently by the Pension Dynamics Corporation of Lafayette, Calif. **********The index shows what 12 mutual fund and other companies would charge for a plan with $1 million in assets and 50 employees -- in other words, a small plan. The annualized costs are divided into the amount paid by the employer and that paid cumulatively by the 50 employees. Though they may not realize it, employees who check on their plans will generally find that a portion is deducted from the accounts of individual participants. **********For a plan of this size, the lowest-cost providers were Principal Financial,  T. Rowe Price Century Plan and Vanguard, according to the index. **********Along with costs, a critical factor is investment performance. "A vendor may  say that, although its costs and fees are above average, you are being awarded with superior investment performance," said Stephen J. Butler, president of Pension Dynamics. "Don't take this claim on faith. Check the performance of your prospective vendors' investments in a respected source, such as Morningstar." **********Best of the Bonds? Corporates and Munis **********Buying shares in a Government bond fund is easier than buying small quantities of Government bonds. But most Government funds lag behind their benchmarks. They're expensive, and there are better alternatives, John Rekenthaler, editor of the Morningstar Investor, wrote in the most recent issue. **********About 85 percent of Government Treasury and mortgage bond funds trail the Lehman Brothers Government index, and they don't compensate by showing lower risk. The reason is that the market is very efficient, and fund managers are handicapped by expenses, which average 1.05 percent of assets a year. **********Best bets for investors are the low-cost Vanguard funds, Mr. Rekenthaler concludes. Other options are Strong Government Securities, which stretches the definition of Government to include unusual mortgages and some corporate bonds,  and Sit U.S. Government Securities, which owns mobile-home mortgages. **********Otherwise, investors in low tax brackets should now go with corporates, Mr. Rekenthaler argues. They are less costly and their market is less efficient. FPA New Income has beaten the Government indexes for a decade with less risk, he said. Other funds he recommends: Loomis Sayles Bond, Dodge & Cox Income and Harbor Bond. **********For people taxed at 28 percent or more, municipal bond funds, especially single-state funds, are the way to go. Exempt from Federal and state tax for in-state residents, the single-state funds yield more without sacrificing long-term performance. Best bets are run by Vanguard, Fidelity Investments, T. Rowe Price and Scudder, Stevens & Clark, Mr. Rekenthaler says. **********Because long-term munis carry a lot of interest-rate risk, cautious investors might consider intermediate-term muni funds even though yields are lower. **********A Rift Over Money Funds **********A proposal by the Securities and Exchange Commission to force money market funds to report their holdings quarterly is running into opposition from the industry. **********The Investment Company Institute, the mutual-fund trade group, says the proposal is neither "necessary nor appropriate" and would result in unnecessary  costs. **********Not so, says Glen King Parker, publisher of the Income Fund Outlook, an investment newsletter in Deerfield Beach, Fla. Many institutional money funds already publish portfolios monthly and make them available to shareholders, he said, and those that sell to the general public should provide more disclosure. **********In fact, he would prefer reporting monthly instead of quarterly. "Money funds have become quasi-banks," he said, "and I don't think that there's anything wrong with an increased level of scrutiny." **********A Portfolio Thinks Small **********James Oberweis, manager of the $135 million Oberweis Emerging Growth fund, is starting the Micro-Cap Portfolio, which will invest in very, very small stocks.  The average market capitalization of the stocks in the Emerging Growth portfolio is $400 million to $500 million; in the new fund it will be less than $100 million. **********The new fund is being structured to let investors get in at the starting gate. Money will be collected from mid-December, but it won't be invested until  the fund begins operating on Jan. 2. **********To stay true to his small-cap mission, Mr. Oberweis plans to close the fund when it reaches $50 million in assets. Even existing shareholders won't be allowed to add new money, though they can reinvest their earnings. **********More New Funds **********Robertson, Stephens & Company, San Francisco, is adding three funds. Its Information Age fund, managed by Ron Elijah, who already runs the company's Value and Growth fund, will concentrate on small-capitalization technology companies with unusual offerings in multimedia, wireless communications, networking, software and the like. Global Natural Resources will be managed by Andy J. Pilara Jr., who also manages the Partners and Contrarian funds. Global Low Priced Stock will buy overlooked companies with share prices of $10 or less. **********Bank of America has started three Time Horizon funds with stated maturity dates in the life-style category. The funds aim to maximize total return and then emphasize capital preservation as the fund approaches its maturity date. Time Horizon Portfolio 1 is for investors with a financial goal near the year 2005, Portfolio 2 for 2015 and Portfolio 3 for 2025. **********Fidelity Investments has added to its international lineup with six aggressive growth funds that invest in single countries and regions abroad. All  the funds carry a 3 percent sales charge and a 1.5 percent redemption fee on shares held less than 90 days. They are Fidelity France, Germany, Hong Kong and  China, Japan Small Companies, Nordic and United Kingdom. **********New Management **********Ernst H. Von Metzsch, who picked up the Vanguard Wellington fund after the death of Vincent Bajakian in September, has been named the permanent manager. **********Catherine Dudley left Phoenix Growth to join Chancellor Investments. She is replaced at the fund by William J. Newman, the company's chief investment strategist. **********In Brief **********Fidelity Investments plans to make all its prospectuses available soon on the Internet. The company has 83 prospectuses there now (http://www.fid-inv.com) and expects to put the remainder there by early next year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/15/world.main_headline: Emerging Role For the C.I.A.: Economic Spy
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/15/world.print_headline: Emerging Role For the C.I.A.: Economic Spy
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/15/world.body_text: **********During the Clinton Administration's tense negotiations with Japan last spring -- with the looming threat of sanctions to cut off Japanese luxury car imports to the United States -- American trade officials were accompanied everywhere by  a small team of intelligence officers. **********Each morning, they gave Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, and his aides inside information gathered by the Central Intelligence Agency's Tokyo station and the electronic eavesdropping equipment of the National Security Agency, sifted by C.I.A. analysts in Washington. **********Mr. Kantor received descriptions of conversations among Japanese bureaucrats and auto executives from Toyota and Nissan who were pressing for a settlement, and read about the competing pressures on Japan's Trade Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto. **********When the negotiations came to a climax in Geneva, the intelligence team was in place at the Intercontinental Hotel, working alongside Mr. Kantor's negotiators, offering assessments of how far the Japanese side could be pressed. **********"It was a remarkable performance, because the intelligence agencies finally realized this was the World Series -- the arms control talks of the new age," said one senior Administration official. **********"But in the end, did it help much? Beyond some valuable detail we could not have gotten elsewhere, did it tell us much about which way Hashimoto would go? It would be hard to make that case." **********Spying on allies for economic advantage is a crucial new assignment for the C.I.A. now that American foreign policy is focused on commercial interests abroad. President Clinton made economic intelligence a high priority of his Administration, specifically information to protect and defend American competitiveness, technology and financial security in a world where an economic  crisis can spread across global markets in minutes. **********But the transition is a rough one for an agency far less comfortable with capital flows than with Communist foes. **********At the Treasury Department, the trade representative's office and the Commerce Department, officials say they now receive a torrent of information from the C.I.A. But in the next breath, they say the quantity is not matched by  the quality. **********The agency, they complain, often cannot separate the vital from the trivial,  and its analysis of economic data is still amateurish. Recently some in the Administration have begun to wonder aloud whether much of the analysis should be farmed out to better-trained experts in Government and the private sector. **********The C.I.A. tends "too often to reproduce mainstream, middle-of-the-road views," Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers told Congress last month.  He questioned whether it "can add much value" to the financial information and analysis the private sector produces from a wealth of public information. **********With an increasing fraction of the $28 billion intelligence budget going to economic matters, the answer to that question may be crucial to the C.I.A.'s future. **********At the agency, economics is still more a buzzword than a mission. The new director, John M. Deutch, talks about it often. But in a recent interview, one of the highest-ranking officials of the C.I.A. confessed complete ignorance of the subject. Some inside the agency ridicule the idea that car exports and exchange rates -- which they call "soft stuff" -- are remotely as important as the spread of nuclear weapons and terrorism -- "hard stuff." **********Moreover, a generation of American spies trained to steal secrets from Communist enemies is having trouble adjusting to the more subtle world of trade  politics. There, economic competitors are also political allies, and a far wider range of players -- industrialists, bankers, and politicians worried about jobs  back home -- want their say. Even many who believe in economic spying are asking if the information gained is worth risking some of America's most important alliances. **********Negotiating New Territory: C.I.A. at GATT **********In 1993, the Administration asked the C.I.A. for dramatic improvement in three areas where it had previously played only a bit role: supporting trade negotiations, tracking legal and illegal tactics other countries use to win business and spotting financial troubles that can become foreign policy crises,  as happened in Mexico last year. **********One of the C.I.A.'s first explorations into the new territory came during the 1993 negotiations over the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. It provided accounts of discussions among key countries negotiating the worldwide trade accord, focusing on the thinking of the French President at the time, Francois Mitterrand; the French Prime Minister, Edouard Balladur, and the head of the European Commission, Jacques Delors. **********But in the end, the agency displayed more energy than results, Administration officials say. **********"We discovered this doesn't come to them naturally, like an arms-control negotiation," said one senior official who got C.I.A. reports. "Give them very specific direction on a limited basis, with a limited time and scope, where they can give you information that they have gathered electronically, and it's pretty helpful. But the minute that you rely on their political or economic assessments -- well, let me be delicate: their capabilities are limited." **********Another top American official was more direct: "The important stuff is garbled. And most of what you get is garbage." **********By most accounts, the agency did better in this year's high-stakes negotiations with Japan, where a key question was what the Japanese auto industry was telling -- and was being told -- by the Japanese Government. Partly prompted by intelligence reports, the Americans told the Japanese automakers that negotiators from Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry were  misrepresenting American demands. **********American negotiators also asked for details of internal discussions between the ministry and rival agencies. Thanks to Tokyo's own internecine rivalries, the C.I.A. got a break. **********Most of the secure telephones in the Japanese Government are controlled by the Foreign Ministry. But officials at the trade ministry shunned those phones,  both to keep their own diplomats from listening in and because Mr. Hashimoto's chief rival for the prime ministership at the time was the Foreign Minister. **********In the end, intelligence proved of limited use in predicting how far Mr. Hashimoto would go. Critics of the unspectacular accord, which chipped away at market barriers without removing them, question whether the result justified the effort. But a senior Administration economic official said the political prominence of the car talks sent an important message to the C.I.A.: focus more  energy on economic security. **********"We can't go into this kind of thing disarmed," one top official said. Mr. Deutch knows that, the official said: "The question is whether he will have the  time to change the culture of the agency." **********Analysis On the Big Picture, A Fuzzy Vision **********Government officials who rely on the C.I.A. for economic intelligence say it has failed at the second major task: warning Government officials about imminent changes in other nations' fiscal policies or looming financial debacles. **********"The agency is accustomed to a world where it has a monopoly on information," said one senior official who receives daily C.I.A. reports. "If you are interested in Iraq's nuclear weapons program, you don't have many other choices  for your information. But if you want to know what the Bundesbank is going to do next, or whether Brazil is thinking of devaluing its currency, there is a lot of competition. And it is hard for the agency to add value." **********Many Administration officials suggest that the agency simply does not have the talent for such analysis. "The best graduate students don't go there, and who can blame them?" said one of the Administration's top economic officials. "And yet, when you sit in a meeting, the views of the C.I.A. are often given more weight than the Council of Economic Advisors. Go figure." **********Tracking global capital flows or predicting currency crises is beyond the agency's ability, said Allan E. Goodman, a former C.I.A. official and academic dean of Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service. **********"We don't have the sources, we don't have the expertise," he said. "To develop an understanding of the people who trade currencies, their motivations,  their lifestyles, you'd have to send your people to Harvard, Stanford and Wharton for years. Currency traders keep secrets very, very well, and to penetrate that would be the equivalent of cracking all the Japanese codes in World War II." **********Enforcement Blowing a Whistle On Foreign Bribes **********When Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown went to Congress on Thursday with his annual report about how the United States is meeting foreign competition abroad, he brought with him a secret annex. **********It focused on tactics used by France, England, Germany, Japan and Canada to win deals, mostly in Asia. Most of the tactics were legal; many are practiced by Washington, including having the President press foreign countries to award business to American firms. **********But the unclassified version of the report also cited "almost 100 cases of foreign firms using bribery to undercut U.S. firms' efforts to win international contracts worth about $45 billion," adding, "The foreign firms that offer bribes typically win about 80 percent of the deals." **********The C.I.A. asserts that in several cases it has caught foreign companies bribing their way into billion-dollar contracts abroad. When that happens, the agency tells the State Department, which protests on behalf of American corporations and, on occasion, wins. "This is probably an area where our intelligence can be used most effectively," a senior official said. "It's where  the agency is getting better." **********Espionage Risks and Rewards Of Spying on Allies **********When corporate America talks to the C.I.A. about economic espionage, it often pleads for its competitors' secrets -- but in vain. **********"If we're willing to do dirty tricks for the defense part of national security, then why aren't we able to do dirty tricks for the economic part?" asks Robert Kohler, a retired C.I.A. official and general manager of TRW Avionics & Surveillance Group. **********The agency says it will not ask its officers to risk their lives for companies instead of their country. It will, however, continue to spy on American allies to understand national strategies. That entails its own risks. **********The issue has been a constant source of tension in the American Embassy in Tokyo. During the last years of the cold war, American officials told the Japanese that the station was chiefly devoted to keeping track of China, North Korea and Russia's eastern ports. But Japanese officials are increasingly unhappy as it becomes clear that they are a primary target. **********Tensions are also growing in Europe. France has spied on American companies for years, planting moles in companies like Boeing and Texas Instruments and breaking into hotel rooms to rifle through attache cases. In late 1993, the C.I.A. stepped up a counterattack. **********"No more Mr. Nice Guy," a former C.I.A. chief, R. James Woolsey, has warned publicly. The C.I.A.'s Paris station got in the game -- with disastrous results. **********A young aide to the French Prime Minister, Mr. Balladur, found himself being  courted by an American woman who introduced herself as public relations director for a save-the-rain-forest foundation. French counterintelligence officers warned the aide, Henri Plagnol, that the woman was a C.I.A. operative -- and told him to play along. **********A two-year-long sting developed. A male C.I.A. officer quizzed Mr. Plagnol about key French positions on the GATT talks, especially on agricultural issues  and limits on the importation of American movies for French television. He handed the Frenchman 500-franc notes -- about $100 each -- for his information. **********Other C.I.A. officers fell under French surveillance. Two sought GATT information from a communications ministry officer. Another tried to bribe an engineer with the state-run France Telecom for information that would help the C.I.A. bug French telecommunications. **********In February, the affair blew up when the French publicly demanded the expulsion of the C.I.A. station chief, his deputy and two other C.I.A. officers. The agency's longstanding liaison with French intelligence -- crucial for joint  operations such as tracking terrorists -- has been suspended. The C.I.A. inspector general is assessing whether the operation was worth it.
