https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/24/world.main_headline: IN REVERSAL, SERBS OF BOSNIA ACCEPT PEACE AGREEMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/24/world.print_headline: IN REVERSAL, SERBS OF BOSNIA ACCEPT PEACE AGREEMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/24/world.body_text: **********The Bosnian Serbs agreed this evening to abide by the peace accord reached in Dayton, Ohio, removing an obstacle to sending American troops to help enforce the peace. **********The Bosnian Serbs had refused to initial the agreement on Tuesday in Dayton,  where they had been represented by Slobodan Milosevic, the President of Serbia,  on whom they have relied for military and political support. The Clinton Administration had said that no American troops would be deployed unless the Bosnian Serbs accepted the accord, which has been signed by the two other parties in the Bosnian conflict, the Muslim-led Bosnian Government and the Bosnian Croats. **********The Bosnian Serb leaders initialed the very accords that they they had refused to sign on Tuesday, said Lawrence Butler, the ranking American diplomat  in Belgrade. Mr. Butler said he faxed the signed documents to Washington late tonight. **********In announcing the reversal, the official Belgrade television said the Bosnian Serbs had "fully accepted" the accord, even though they found provisions "painful." **********Nikola Koljevic, a vice president of the self-declared Bosnian Serb republic, confirmed that the Bosnian Serbs had agreed to the accords. He said, however, that they were hoping for "some improvements" in the agreement. "I can not be more specific," he said in a brief telephone interview tonight. **********The Bosnian Serb capitulation came after a meeting here today of their top leaders with President Milosevic, who may have lost his dream of a Greater Serbia but has taken another step in his drive to be seen in the West not as the man who started the war but as the moderate leader who brought it to an end. **********A Western diplomat speaking on condition of anonymity said he had thought it  would take longer for President Milosevic to bring the Bosnian Serbs around. "It was a complete humiliation of the Bosnian Serb leadership," he said. "I didn't expect it to happen so soon." **********In Washington, Administration officials greeted the Bosnian Serb announcement with relief, but cautioned that they still needed to review what the Serbs had agreed to. **********"Milosevic assured us before leaving Dayton that he'd get the Bosnian Serbs on board, but that he'd need a couple of days to calm these guys down," said a State Department official. "It sounds like he's been able to pull this off." **********Defense Department officials, in particular, had expressed concern that winning Congressional approval for the accord would be even more difficult without the Bosnian Serbs' consent. **********The acceptance suggests that moderates within the Bosnian Serb leadership, who are supported by Mr. Milosevic, have prevailed over the hard-liners, led by  Mr. Milosevic's political rival, Radovan Karadzic, political leader of the self-proclaimed Bosnian Serb republic. **********The Bosnian Serbs' capitulation would appear to spell the political end for Dr. Karadzic and for Gen. Ratko Mladic, commander of the Bosnian Serb army. The  agreement says that individuals who have been indicted by the international war  crimes tribunal in The Hague may not hold political office. Both Dr. Karadzic, a former psychiatrist, and General Mladic have been indicted on several counts. **********The hard-liners had been angry with Mr. Milosevic, who was negotiating in Dayton on behalf of the Bosnian Serbs, for having agreed that Sarajevo would be  a unified city, which would require the return of Serb-controlled suburbs to the Bosnian Government. They also felt that he had given away too much other territory that the Bosnian Serbs had gained on the battlefield. **********Dr. Karadzic was present at the meeting with Mr. Milosevic, Belgrade state television reported. General Mladic, who has been reported to be suffering from  kidney stones, was represented by his deputy. Also attending, the state television said, were Mr. Koljevic, the vice president; Biljana Plavsic, another vice president of the self-proclaimed Bosnian Serb republic, and Momcilo Krajisnik, speaker of its parliament. **********That Mr. Milosevic won over Ms. Plavsic and Mr. Krajisnik was considered of particular importance. While Mr. Koljevic is viewed as a moderate in the Bosnian Serb context, the others were considered hard-liners. **********Mr. Krajisnik, who was present in Dayton, had denounced the agreement; two years ago, Ms. Plavsic had rejected the peace proposal put together by the former American Secretary of State Cyrus Vance and Lord Owen of Britain, saying  that six million Serbian casualties was not too high a price for the Bosnian Serbs to pay for their goals. Mr. Milosevic retorted that she should probably be committed to a mental hospital. **********Reached by telephone at their headquarters in Pale, Bosnia, outside Sarajevo, the Bosnian Serbs said they would have no official comment on today's events. **********Details of the meeting between Mr. Milosevic and the Bosnian Serb leaders, including which person actually initialed the document, were not made public, but Western diplomats and Belgrade political analysts say they are certain Mr. Milosevic used some of the same strong-arm tactics on the Bosnian Serbs that the American negotiators had used in Dayton. **********"You can just about bet that they had their arms twisted far up their backs," said a Western diplomat. "They succumbed to his blandishments, and believe me, they can be pretty unattractive." **********Mr. Milosevic's position was as strong as that of the Bosnian Serb leaders was weak. **********To begin with, the United Nations Security Council had lifted economic and military sanctions, but if the Bosnian Serbs' intransigence upset the Dayton agreement, the sanctions might have been imposed again.  "You can bet that Mr. Milosevic was telling them that they would have the wrath of all the Serbs on them," a Western diplomat said. **********In Belgrade today, an extended broadcast was devoted almost exclusively to the lifting of sanctions, with interviews of people on the street who welcomed the day and praised their leader. "This is the happiest day of my life," said one woman. **********Then there is the Bosnian Serb army, which has been dependent on support from Belgrade. It has been badly routed in recent weeks by the Bosnian and Croatian armies, and was thus in no position to argue that it should fight on. **********While rogue elements of the Bosnian Serb military could still engage in guerrilla warfare, the army cannot be expected to achieve any significant military gains if Mr. Milosevic this time lives up to his promise not to support it. It is a promise he has made before, and then broken. **********As for Dr. Karadzic, "it is too early to know what he will do," said a Western diplomat. "He might try to hang on, but it will be very difficult, if not impossible, without the loyalty of the army, which he does not command." **********And the last 48 hours have accentuated a power struggle within the Bosnian Serb leadership, which had been remarkably united until recently. The hard-liners, principally Dr. Karadzic and General Mladic, have their base in Pale, but little remains there beyond their bodyguards and local residents who once catered to skiers in the winter resort village. The moderate leadership, led by Mr. Koljevic, operates out of Banja Luka.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/16/busin.main_headline: No New Hits but Many Old Favorites
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/16/busin.print_headline: No New Hits but Many Old Favorites
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/16/busin.body_text: **********High tech is old hat. This Christmas, Americans seem to yearn for tradition. **********Sure, computers will still show up under the tree, experts say, but the hottest products mostly involve cuddling up, soft candlelight and sitting around the table playing board games. Cashmere and Gucci are popular again with the affluent set. And then there is the perfume inspired by Kermit the Frog. **********This year's shoppers are spreading their money around. "There doesn't seem to be one particular product that is lighting up the Christmas tree this year,"  said Mark J. Schoifet, a spokesman for the International Council of Shopping Centers, which monitors 80 big malls. **********Nostalgia and comfort are the big draws this year. Christmas Barbie is on back order, Mickey Mouse sweatshirts are back in business and jewelry for every  taste and budget is on a lot of lists. **********Apparel in general may be selling slowly, but Polar Tec pullovers and fleecy  sweatshirts are rushing out the door at stores like Old Navy and Sears. **********Stores that sell bath goods and candles that smell like food are doing well,  according to Mr. Schoifet. Kiehl's Since 1851, which offers simply packaged personal-care products in department stores and its own retail outlets, said it  had sold thousands of coriander and grapefruit bath gels. **********No toy stands out, but board games are making a comeback, from old favorites  like Monopoly to new ones like Sue You!, which mocks the legal profession.  The  season is also seeing a revival of traditional toys like Etch-a-Sketch and Mr. Potato Head featured in the hit Walt Disney movie "Toy Story." **********All in all, it looks as if a lot of people plan to create a cabin-like intimacy this winter as they hunker down and ignore all those "I'll get to it as soon as I can" tool sets that are also selling well. **********In computers, the retailers who were counting on a blockbuster season have been disappointed so far. Mark Marcon, an analyst at Cleary Gull Reiland & McDevitt in Milwaukee, estimated that computer sales would rise 10 percent this  season. That is well below the rise of 15 percent or more that many experts were projecting in October and a long way from the 30 percent gains of the last two holiday periods. **********"The sales will still be up," Mr. Marcon said. "But not as everyone predicted. On top of that, you are seeing an extremely promotional environment." Big-screen television sets and multimedia computers are still moving, but profit margins are being squeezed on those and nearly every other high-technology product. **********While early November was solid, as colder weather created demand for winter clothes, the traditional holiday season got off to a relatively slow start after Thanksgiving, and the pace has slackened since. Sales in specialty stores in big malls fell 1.6 percent for the week that ended on Dec. 10, compared with the corresponding week last year, the shopping center council says. **********The use of credit cards continues to climb but at a slower pace than last year. And, Telecheck said this week that its tally of approvals showed a 7.2 percent decline in spending by check during the first 17 days of the shopping season. **********The popularity of some products this year defies explanation. At Bloomingdale's, one of the hottest items in cosmetics is Amphibia, a perfume based on Sesame Street's Kermit the Frog. **********With the stock market at record highs, luxury items are moving well. "Any store with vowels at the end of their names are doing well," said Alan G. Millstein, editor of the Fashion Network Report. "That would include Armani, Prada and Gucci. This is the year of the resurgence of luxury retail." **********Even the upscale merchants are cashing in on things for the home. Executives  at the Sharper Image, for instance, were surprised to see their $200 self-cleaning cat litter box selling well above expectations. Their catalogue department has received more than 1,000 orders, some of them on back order. The  full-size replica of a U.F.O. alien in a chamber, for $1,695, was moving more slowly. Still, Sydney Klevatt, senior vice president of marketing, had to confess that he was surprised. "Would you believe?" he said. "We've sold six of  them."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/world.main_headline: Help Eases Burden of Woman With Ill Children
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/world.print_headline: Help Eases Burden of Woman With Ill Children
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/world.body_text: **********On some nights, Leonora A. feels like little more than a pendulum with a purpose, swinging back and forth from one sick child to the other. **********Janigris, 4, severely asthmatic and gasping for air, needs her oxygen mask. Selena, 9, born with spina bifida, which is a spinal defect, and urinary tract problems, requires help with her catheter. Then Janigris, breathing easier, needs her mask removed. **********Perhaps Ms. A. dozes for a moment. Perhaps she dreams. But dawn, when it finally arrives, finds her groggy and sore and strapped with the same familiar burdens. **********"When I have nights like that, I don't have the strength to get up," Ms. A. said. "And if I don't feel well, it's even worse." **********The chances are good that Ms. A., who is 26, does not feel well. She suffers  from chronic migraines, sinus pains, recurring cysts, high blood pressure and severe backaches. In the last seven years, she has undergone seven operations and survived a stroke. **********In this profusion of family illness, the Children's Aid Society has given the family support. After Janigris was born three months premature, the society found a foster family for Selena, giving Ms. A. some time to focus on Janigris's special needs. Selena returned home in October, and the society has provided a homemaker to assist Ms. A. during the day. **********The society is one of seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, now in its 84th year. Since The Times pays the overhead, all donations to the fund are passed on to the charities. The drive runs through Feb. 28. **********The home attendant relieves some of the pressure on Ms. A., who otherwise is  very much alone in caring for her children. Her own mother has diabetes and is too weak to offer assistance. And Ms. A., who moved to New York from the Dominican Republic, struggles with a language barrier. She said she tried to learn English in a course run by a church but was asked not to return because she had missed too many classes. **********Rosa Hicks, the Children's Aid Society social worker assigned to the case, said Ms. A. has put up a brave front for all the suffering she has endured. "I don't think I would be like her if I had those problems," Ms. Hicks said. **********The children's conditions are permanent and not likely to improve, and Ms. A. sometimes becomes depressed about that, Ms. Hicks said. Selena, who was born after Ms. A. was raped in the Dominican Republic, has limited mental abilities and will never be able to care for herself. **********Janigris, who weighed 1.5 pounds at birth, is also chronically ill and rarely goes more than a few weeks before needing another hospital visit. **********Ms. A. has made an effort to make her Washington Heights home cheerful, with  curtains, dust ruffles and homemade flower arrangements adorning all the rooms.  The children's bedroom is full of stuffed animals and Disney characters. **********But the feeling of isolation in the apartment persists, and sometimes, when Ms. A. thinks too much about her plight, all she can do is cry. "I feel like it's a lot for me," she said. **********Previously recorded $1,769,375.04 Recorded yesterday $118,390.44 **********Total $1,887,765.48

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/busin.body_text: **********Under a disciplinary order from the Finance Ministry, Daiwa Bank of Japan said yesterday that it would reduce its overseas assets by half within a year and curtail overseas bond trading. The order was punishment for submitting false reports to the ministry covering up $97 million in losses incurred by Daiwa's United States trust banking subsidiary in the late 1980's. The case is unrelated to the $1.1 billion bond trading loss at the bank's New York branch. **********In the trust bank case, Daiwa is being punished for transferring losses to a Cayman Islands entity. Under the plan, Daiwa Bank will cut its overseas assets by 50.5 percent, or $26.7 billion, by the end of next October. The figure includes the United States operations, which have about $10 billion in assets.   (AP)

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/22/busin.snippet: Q. My boyfriend and I are moving into our first apartment in New York City. He earns about 25 percent more than I do -- and on top of that gets money from a family trust fund. Do you think it's fair that we split rent and expenses equally?
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/22/busin.main_headline: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;My TV, Your VCR? How to Avoid a House Divided
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/22/busin.print_headline: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;My TV, Your VCR? How to Avoid a House Divided
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/22/busin.body_text: **********Q. My boyfriend and I are moving into our first apartment in New York City. He earns about 25 percent more than I do -- and on top of that gets money from a family trust fund. Do you think it's fair that we split rent and expenses equally? **********A. Fair? "All's fair in love and war," wrote Francis Edward Smedley back in 1850. But seeing as Smedley wasn't setting up housekeeping in a pricey Manhattan rental, we'll disregard that advice. After all, a quest for fairness can easily  put a couple on the warpath. **********Everyday money matters require a certain finesse by cohabitants -- a significant group these days. More than three million households are composed of unmarried couples -- roommates, people trying out a relationship, those planning marriage, heterosexual and homosexual couples and committed partners not planning marriage. **********To be sure, many of these couples, especially the young ones, just make ends  meet in cities with high costs of living. "We call ourselves the new poor," says the female partner in a New York twosome with combined annual income of $135,000, which certainly amounts to middle-class comfort in most places. **********Still, a pinched pocketbook may be less disruptive than pinched expressions.  "Most financial fights in a relationship are not about a shortage of money but disorganization, lack of communication, fuzzy goals and a confusion over investment choices," says Adriane G. Berg in "Financial Planning for Couples" (Newmarket Press, 1993, $10.95).  Once people have a blueprint of what works best for them, together and as individuals, cohabitation becomes a lot less fractious. **********So, the safest course is to determine your expectations for the budding relationship before deciding whether to split expenses evenly or proportionately, based on resources. The formula, of course, will most likely change along with the relationship. **********For lack of any hard and fast rules, roommates and couples who are test driving their relationship often split expenses like rent and food. To avoid squabbles over "my cereal" and "your paper towels," many contribute equally to a joint household account. **********When Debbie Kohnstamm and Leon Baranovsky started living together, they split expenses by keeping a list on the fridge with columns marked "his" and "hers." When one paid the electric bill or bought groceries, the cost was marked in the  appropriate column. Every few months they added up the columns and balanced them out. **********"This way we weren't constantly exchanging money and didn't need a joint checking account," she said. It was the same system she had used with her college roommate. "We even bought two kittens." **********Their system was based on equality. After a few years, they decided to get married and pooled their resources. As they found, the financial arrangement usually changes when you become a "committed couple," whether marriage is in the air or not. **********"Equality and fairness are not the same thing," Ms. Berg says. "Feelings of fairness most often prevail when couples split expenses proportionately. If one  partner is making 25 percent more, then he or she should be spending 25 percent  more on necessities." **********For 18 months before being married, Kathy and Kevin McKinney lived together in San Francisco and split their expenses according to their salaries. "We sat down and figured out our total income -- he earned 70 percent, and I made only 30 percent, so we added up the rent, bills, and groceries and paid accordingly," Ms. McKinney said. "We kept separate saving accounts for personal spending, and  we never argued about money. In fact, we still use a similar system now that we're married." **********Trust funds, however, do not really belong in the pot. "If one partner has a  special asset, which may have been inherited, shares of stock, a precious antique or a piece of real estate," Ms. Berg notes, "the other partner should respect the privacy of that." **********It is not unheard of, though, for someone with additional income, to suggest  a better apartment or a more expensive vacation and to offer to pay the difference. **********Not surprisingly, feelings of unfairness among committed partners arise most  often about discretionary spending. You know, the type of disagreement in which  one person wants to buy a big-screen TV and the other longs for a 14-day Caribbean cruise. That's more the stuff of soap operas than real life, the experts say. Far more common is that one person wants to spend and the other prefers to save. Ms. Berg suggests that couples treat saving and investing as they would a car purchase -- something to plan for so both partners get what they want. **********When it is time to spend, a dash of indulgence may not be all bad. A survey by Savvy magazine showed that couples are rarely happy if they feel they are always compromising to accommodate the other. It works better to take turns getting what you want -- as long as the items are affordable. **********Suppose "he" wants a new stereo and "she" wants an expensive sofa. Rather than upgrading the old stereo by buying new speakers and settling for a cheaper  sofa, they should instead forgo some other item they both want or delay the stereo or sofa purchase a few months. **********One way to help make record keeping fair and easy is to keep separate bank accounts and open a joint checking account to cover household and other shared purchases and expenses. Many landlords prefer not to have two names on a lease and may resist the idea of two checks. **********Though some experts recommend a joint brokerage account and other investments to instill togetherness, don't overlook the tax consequences. As long as you are filing separate tax returns, how will you report capital gains, losses, dividends and interest? **********Keeping separate credit cards makes it easy to pay for personal items, and to preserve your credit identity. Most important for harmony's sake, put a car, house and big-ticket items bought with joint money in both names. For smaller items, like a TV, save receipts and note who paid how much. In case of a split, a settlement comes quicker with the original cost in hand. **********After a relationship fizzled in my early 20's, I owned the left side of a Jennifer Convertible sofa bed and the cups and plates, but not the saucers and cereal bowls, of a Pottery Barn dinnerware set. We couldn't agree on who had paid for what and how much each item had cost. **********Occasionally, committed couples revert to roommate status. Take two friends of mine who have a great deal on a West Side apartment in Manhattan. After a tumultuous five-year relationship, they broke up, but neither will give up the inexpensive living quarters. From Neil Sedaka's popular song "Love Will Keep Us  Together" has sprung a new urban refrain, "The Lease Will Keep Us Together." **********Questions about investing, careers and personal finance can be sent to Minding Your Business, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York 10036. Or they can be sent by E-mail to yourmind@nytimes.com. Questions can be answered only in the column, not by mail, E-mail or telephone.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/30/busin.body_text: **********MAF BANCORP IN DEAL TO BUY N. S. BANCORP MAF Bancorp Inc. said late yesterday that it had agreed to buy N. S. Bancorp Inc. in a stock and cash transaction valued at $277.2 million. The acquisition will give MAF Bancorp 20 branches in Chicago and its western suburbs, with about $3 billion in assets. MAF Bancorp, based in Clarendon Hills, Ill., is the parent company of Mid America Federal Savings Bank. N. S. Bancorp, based in Chicago, is the parent company of Northwestern Savings Bank. Under the agreement, each common share of N. S. Bancorp will be exchanged for 0.8466 common share of MAF Bancorp, plus $20.34 in cash. Based on yesterday's closing price of $26 a share  for MAF Bancorp, the deal values N. S. Bancorp shares at $42.35 each, $6.10 above their closing price of $36.25. Both companies trade on the Nasdaq stock market.   (Dow Jones) **********FLAGSTAR AGREES TO SELL ITS STADIUM FOODS UNIT The Flagstar Companies has agreed to sell its Volume Services unit for an undisclosed sum and has ended talks to sell its Quincy's Family Steakhouse restaurants. The nation's No. 4 restaurant company said late on Tuesday that it  would sell Volume Services, which sells food and merchandise at sports stadiums, to an investor group formed by the unit's management and Blackstone Capital Partners II. Volume Services has revenue of $200 million a year. Flagstar, based in Spartanburg, S.C., also said it had ended talks to sell its Quincy's restaurants to a management-led group. Flagstar is 47 percent owned by the investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company in New York.    (Bloomberg Business News) **********RHONE-POULENC TO SELL STAKE IN A PRODUCER OF SODA ASH Rhone-Poulenc S.A. agreed yesterday to sell its 51 percent stake in the soda ash producer Rhone-Poulenc of Wyoming to Oriental Chemical Industry for $150 million. The rest of the company is owned by the Union Pacific Resources Company, a unit of the Union Pacific Corporation. The transaction does not include Rhone-Poulenc's sodium bicarbonate business. Rhone-Poulenc of Wyoming produces more than two million tons of soda ash annually from natural deposits in Green River, Wyo. It has about 500 employees. Soda ash, or sodium carbonate,  is a raw material used primarily in making glass. It is also is used in the chemical industry and in making detergents. Oriental Chemical Industry is a Korean chemical company.   (Dow Jones) **********CONVERSE TO CUT MORE JOBS AND ELIMINATE PRODUCT LINES Converse Inc., the maker of athletic shoes, announced a reorganization yesterday that would cut jobs, eliminate some product lines and save $25 million a year, starting in 1996. The company, based in North Reading, Mass., said it would stop making its outdoor, running, walking, tennis and football shoes, and would concentrate on its basketball, cross-training, children's and "athleisure" products. Converse, which announced the elimination of 496 jobs in October, said that another 98 jobs would be lost, leaving a work force of 2,504. The company also said it expected to take a pretax charge of $2.5 million in the fourth quarter to cover the cost of the reorganization. The company's shares fell 25 cents yesterday, to $4.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.   (Reuters) **********ALLEGHENY TO BUY REMAINING INTEREST IN GENERATING UNIT Allegheny Power System Inc. of New York agreed yesterday to buy the Duquesne Light Company's half-interest in a coal-fired generating unit near Morgantown, W.Va., for about $170 million. Allegheny Power said that its AYP Capital division planned to sell the 276 megawatts of generation capacity as an independent marketer. Duquesne Light, a unit of DQE Inc. in Pittsburgh, said it  planned to use the money to help offset the reduced value of its investment in nuclear power plants. The Monongahela Power Company and the Potomac Edison Company, both units of Allegheny Power, already own the other half of the No. 1  unit at the Fort Martin Power Station. Allegheny Power subsidiaries jointly own  the No. 2 unit at Fort Martin.   (Dow Jones) **********INVESTMENT GROUPS TO BUY UNITS FROM TROUBLED INSURER Penncorp Financial Group Inc. and a related investment group said yesterday that they would buy two units of the ICH Corporation, a troubled insurance company in Dallas, for $260 million. In an auction supervised by the Bankruptcy Court, Penncorp and Knightsbridge Capital Fund I L.P. said they would pay $210 million  in cash, $40 million in convertible debt securities and $10 million in stock for the Southwestern Life Insurance Company and Union Bankers Insurance Company. Once the deal is completed, Penncorp will own 55 percent, Knightsbridge will own 27 percent and ICH will retain 18 percent, assuming the conversion of the securities. ICH began Chapter 11 proceedings last month.   (Dow Jones) BURNHAM PACIFIC PROPERTIES CUTS ITS DIVIDEND 30% Burnham Pacific Properties Inc. slashed its dividend by more than 30 percent yesterday and said it would sell part of its office portfolio in an effort to focus on retail properties. Burnham Pacific, a real estate investment trust in San Diego, said the sale of office properties would reduce its fourth-quarter earnings by about $22 million. The company said that it would record additional  expenses of $2.8 million. The company also said it had agreed to sell Beverly Garland's Holiday Inn Hotel for an undisclosed sum. The company, which had more  than 17 million shares outstanding on Sept. 30, said it would use proceeds from  the sale to buy back up to one million shares. Burnham Pacific will pay a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share, down from 36 cents.   (Dow Jones) **********COURT BLOCKS LOMAS FINANCIAL FROM SELLING ASSETS The Lomas Financial Corporation was denied court permission yesterday to sell substantially all of its remaining assets to First Nationwide Bank for $150 million. Still, Peter Walsh, a Federal Bankruptcy Court judge in Wilmington, Del., called his decision conditional and ordered the creditor committee to vote on the sale. Creditors are entitled to take the risk of shopping the company if  they believe they can get a higher offer, he said. The judge said creditors had  not been provided enough information about the proposed sale to First Nationwide to make an informed judgment. First Nationwide Bank of San Francisco, is a subsidiary of MacAndrews & Forbes Group Inc., which is controlled by the investor Ronald O. Perelman.    (Bloomberg Business News) **********INTEL ANNOUNCES PLANS FOR A CHIP FACTORY IN SHANGHAI The Intel Corporation said yesterday that it would build a semiconductor assembly and test plant in Shanghai. The computer chip maker, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said construction was scheduled to begin soon and should be completed by the end of 1997. It did not disclose how much the plant would cost. The plant will be the company's third in Asia and will employ about 900 people.  Intel also said it had signed an agreement with Shanghai officials to "preferentially recommend Intel Pentium processors" in future projects.   (Dow Jones) **********COASTAL CORP., Houston, said it planned to divest most of its generic wholesale  gasoline business in the upper Midwest to concentrate its activities near its core refineries, terminals and pipelines. **********CASE CORP., Racine, Wis., which makes construction equipment, agreed to purchase Concord Inc. of Fargo, N.D., a privately held maker of air drills used in planting grain, for an undisclosed sum. **********SURGICAL CARE AFFILIATES INC., Nashville, a health care concern, agreed to buy Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp.'s stake in Alaska Surgery Center. Terms were not disclosed. **********TII INDUSTRIES, Copiague, L.I., a telecommunication components manufacturer, said it would supply fiber optic network products for a Northern Telecom Ltd. project in Mexico.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/03/busin.main_headline: About Real Estate;White Plains Luxury Housing Revived
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/03/busin.print_headline: About Real Estate;White Plains Luxury Housing Revived
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/03/busin.body_text: **********After 12 years and two unsuccessful attempts to turn 35 acres off North Street here into housing, work is under way to build 70 luxury town houses on the site. **********Toll Brothers Inc. of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., has taken over the project, Club Pointe, where construction halted 11 years ago after three buildings containing nine homes were completed but never occupied. Toll razed those structures and revised the design and floor plans of the houses, which are to be built over the next three years. **********Toll Brothers, a major builder in the Northeast, acquired Club Pointe for $4.5 million at a sealed-bid auction in June 1994 and closed the deal six months later. The seller was London & Leeds, a Manhattan-based development company. **********The $35 million project is rising in the North Street corridor, in the city's southeastern section, where estates once stood and the last sizable tracts of land available for development exist. It is one of five developments Toll has built or plans to build within one mile of another. Together they total 268 residences in a mix of single-family detached and attached homes. Rob Parahus, vice president of Toll's New York metropolitan division, said 116 residences in  two projects had been completed and most of them had been sold at prices ranging from $369,900 to $664,900. **********All but one of the projects were thwarted by the recession, and their revival underscores an increase in development activity in the city, said Daniel E. Armstrong, assistant planner for White Plains. He said the city was continuing to hold discussions with commercial developers looking to put up supermarkets, movie theaters and a hotel. **********Wayne F. Patterson, senior vice president at Toll, said his company became involved with Club Pointe and the other four projects because "there is a demand in the White Plains market, which is large, for homes that provide quality and value." Another factor, he said, was location: the projects are close to the Hutchinson Parkway and Interstate 287. **********Mr. Parahus added that a concentration of projects in an area, an oft-used strategy of Toll, provided the company an economy of scale and enabled it to broaden its market by offering a diversity of housing. **********The two-story, cedar-sided town houses at Club Pointe, which is bordered on two sides by the private Westchester Hills Golf Club, have 2,555 to 2,775 square feet of space. Each features three bedrooms, a full basement and two-car garages. Base prices during preconstruction sales, begun in late September, range from $419,900 to $459,900. The monthly maintenance at the project, structured as a condominium association, will be $200 and annual taxes will be about $8,000. So far nine homes have been sold. **********Ed and Fran Opengart, both in their late 50's, will be moving from their home in Scarsdale to a residence at Club Pointe. "We wanted an alternative life style where someone else would do the maintenance," Mr. Opengart said. "We fell in love with the location and though the price is higher than we hoped to pay we feel we are getting a lot of value." **********In the third quarter of this year the average price of the 247 existing condominiums sold in Westchester county was $187,549; for the 37 such residences sold in White Plains and neighboring Hartsdale it was $178,500, according to data from the Westchester County Board of Realtors and Prudential RCR Realtors,  based in White Plains. **********Paul F. Stehnach, vice president at Prudential RCR Realtors, said the market  in central Westchester County "has found its level, meaning if units are realistically priced they will sell." He said residences were selling within 95  percent of their listed price. **********Club Pointe is being developed under the city's conservation development ordinance, which was passed in 1981 as a way to preserve open space. It stipulates that on tracts of five acres or more in certain residential areas developers have the option to cluster houses. This results in all the development the zoning permits, but on less land, leaving the rest undeveloped in perpetuity. **********At Club Pointe, 24 of the 35 acres will remain open. The houses are grouped in twos and threes and many back up to the conservation area or the golf course. Those closest to the course carry premiums of $6,000 to $25,000. The land left undeveloped will be owned and maintained by Club Pointe residents. Other common  amenities will include a cabana, outdoor pool and two tennis courts. **********In February Toll expects to open its fourth project, 32 single-family detached homes, with 2,800 to 3,200 square feet. Introductory prices are expected to be $534,900 to $599,900. **********The last of the five Toll projects, which is still going through the approval process, is to have 50 larger, more expensive homes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/09/world.main_headline: The Greening of U.S. Diplomacy: Focus on Ecology
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/09/world.print_headline: The Greening of U.S. Diplomacy: Focus on Ecology
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/09/world.body_text: **********Environmental threats like the beautiful water hyacinths choking Lake Victoria and the desert sands eating away the sparse pastures bordering the Sahara are some of the issues deemed urgent today by American foreign policy makers in much the same manner as military threats like new surface-to-air missile sites alarmed policy makers several decades ago. **********These days, intelligence officials are being asked to look at softer targets  -- those flowers and sand dunes -- to shed light on this decade's hot wars. Through this optic, Somalia and Rwanda can be interpreted not as spontaneous outbreaks of clan warfare or ethnic violence, but as conflicts nourished by the  underlying strains of hunger, drought and a lack of arable land in Somalia, and  huge population growth and population density in Rwanda. **********So in addition to their traditional intelligence gathering -- arms, nuclear  weapons programs, expansion of foreign armies -- American policy makers are looking more than ever before at natural phenomena in their search for the deeper roots of war and threats to global security. They are expecting more wars like Somalia, where the United States sent troops to calm a desperate situation  spawned by environmental calamities and the brutal political response to it. To  prepare for such future wars, they are analyzing subjects like the water table levels in Central Asia and the water hyacinths in Central Africa. **********In August, the Defense Intelligence Agency finished a study on the rapid spread of the water hyacinth plant in Lake Victoria, which provides 120,000 tons of fish each year to Uganda, Kenya and Tanzania. The agency noted with due seriousness how a single water hyacinth can multiply into a million plants in one year and, the report warned, these plants could ultimately strangle the lake and kill most of its fish. The consequences would be serious: famine and such political instability in neighboring countries that the United States could be called in to help. **********In looking at the underlying causes of war and crisis, the intelligence community now examines an expanded menu of subjects, including agriculture, demographics, economics and epidemiology. It looks, for instance, at China's economic boom and how it is causing considerable overcrowding in China's cities; at the AIDS epidemic in East Africa and how it is affecting the region's military and political elites; and at Mexico's industrial leap forward and how it has left millions of peasants behind. **********Some old-line intelligence officials disparage this new focus on what they call "soft stuff." But the Clinton Administration, led by Vice President Al Gore, has deliberately added this new focus on environmental and natural factors -- famine, soil erosion, rapid population growth, the expansion of deserts -- that they believe will produce many of the world crises of tomorrow. **********"During the cold war, most security threats stemmed from state-to-state aggression, so most of the analysis was of factors that could produce state-to-state aggression," said James Steinberg, the State Department's director of policy planning. "Now we're focusing more on internal factors that can destabilize governments and lead to civil wars and ethnic strife. Now we're  paying much more attention to early warning factors, like famine and the environment." **********The United States looks less than before at who is sitting where in the Kremlin and more at how good this fall's harvest will be in the Central Asian republics. **********The Central Intelligence Agency recently commissioned a study to determine whether there was a correlation between a country's infant mortality rate, the openness of a country's trading system to imports and the stability of its government, hoping that finding a way to view these factors collectively would help the C.I.A. predict where the next crisis might erupt. **********Gathering of the so-called soft intelligence has become routine. The C.I.A. now does an annual study, called "Global Humanitarian Emergencies" that forecasts which countries are most likely to suffer from natural disasters. It set up a global affairs department two years ago that analyzes environmental matters, the global food situation and other issues the agency once gave little  attention. **********"We've been looking at some of these softer issues for a long time," said one intelligence official. "What's different now is these issues have moved from the periphery to take a more central role." **********Angelo Codevilla, an intelligence expert who teaches at Boston University, said this new approach is misguided. "All this soft stuff is a silly idea," he said. "The purpose of intelligence is to ferret out secrets from people who want to keep those secrets. To turn intelligence into environmental reports is not to understand environmental problems or intelligence." **********Professor Codevilla said it was wrong to switch from harder to softer intelligence. "The hard stuff is as important as ever because guns will determine the future of the world as much as they ever did," he said. **********Toby Gati, Assistant Secretary of State for Intelligence, disagrees, saying,  "This soft stuff immediately becomes hard when you have to send in the Marines." **********George Moose, the Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, is a promoter of this new approach and says that if the intelligence community had studied Somalia's water table levels in the three years before the outbreak of famine and clan warfare there, the information might have warned diplomats of an imminent crisis. Since Africa is his responsibility, Mr. Moose is particularly sensitive to the role of natural disasters in human conflicts. He argues that the rapid spread of the Sahara desert set off the 1989 conflict between Senegal and Mauritania, when herdsmen from the two countries went to war over a dwindling amount of grazing land. **********In recent years the Pentagon has sent troops to Somalia, where American soldiers made it safe for relief groups to deliver food to starving people, and  to Zaire, where the United States set up emergency camps for Rwandan refugees. Even in the more traditional Haiti operation, American troops were called upon to restore an ousted, democratically elected president who vowed to combat poverty rather than to take up arms in a classic government-to-government confrontation like the wars in Korean and Vietnam. **********The Administration says the American people care about the problems addressed recently. "The issues of overpopulation, of refugees, of famine, of human rights problems are issues the American people have become more interested in," said one National Security Council official. **********This shift toward softer intelligence has brought with it another shift: more than ever before, the intelligence community is using public material, particularly relief reports produced by organizations like the International Committee of the Red Cross. **********In Africa, where the the C.I.A. is cutting back its presence, intelligence officials acknowledge that the thousands of relief workers there are a trove of  information about the continent. To take advantage of this, the Clinton Administration is setting up a computer information network, called "Relief Net," to speed the flow of information from the Red Cross and other relief groups to Government agencies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;HOLLYWOOD ENTERTAINMENT'S SHARES DROP NEARLY 53%
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;HOLLYWOOD ENTERTAINMENT'S SHARES DROP NEARLY 53%
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/busin.body_text: **********Shares of the Hollywood Entertainment Corporation lost more than half their value yesterday after two analysts downgraded the stock and a Forbes magazine article questioned the company's accounting practices. Shares of Hollywood, based in Beaverton, Ore., tumbled $8.625, to $7.75, or nearly 53 percent, in Nasdaq trading of almost 15.3 million shares. https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/12/world.main_headline: Germany Lifting Ban on Hemp Growing, but Not on Marijuana
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/12/world.print_headline: Germany Lifting Ban on Hemp Growing, but Not on Marijuana
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/12/world.body_text: **********The German Government announced this week that it is lifting its ban on the cultivation of hemp, a fibrous plant used to make food, textiles, fuel, soap, lubricating oils, cosmetics, building materials and other products. **********Hemp has been stigmatized because it can also produce marijuana, but Minister of Health Horst Seehofer said the action would not affect laws against marijuana cultivation and sale. **********Other European countries already permit the growing of hemp, and Germany is joining an industry that is regarded as so unremarkable that the European Union  offers subsidies to growers. **********"German farmers should be able to take advantage of the market potential for  the hemp plant, which has many uses in industry and may also be a source of energy," Mr. Seehofer said. "We now have strains of hemp which contain such small amounts of the drug THC that they cannot be used for drug production. The  principal argument against a continuing ban on hemp cultivation is therefore no  longer valid." **********Mr. Seehofer lifted the ban after Germany's Parliament recommended that he do so. He said hemp may now be legally grown as long as it contains less than 0.3 percent of tetrahydrocannabinol, or THC, the substance that gives marijuana and  hashish their psychoactive quality. **********Jochen Borchert, the Minister of Nutrition, Agriculture and Forests, said that hemp growers would have to obtain permits, and that their crops would be subject to inspection to insure that they do not grow plants potent enough to be used as intoxicants. **********Germany's principal farmers' association had lobbied for a lifting of the ban, as had representatives of textile companies and the printing industry, which is interested in hemp-based paper. **********Hemp was widely grown in Germany and across Europe until the 1930's, when an  anti-marijuana campaign in the United States led many other countries to crack down on farmers who cultivated it. There has been virtually no hemp grown in Germany since then, although the law banning it dates only from 1982. **********Although the new ruling may propel Germany to the forefront of Western Europe's producers, hemp is already cultivated on 24,000 acres in France, Spain  and Britain. Larger amounts are believed to be grown in Eastern Europe. **********As recently as two years ago, there was no visible interest in hemp production in Germany. Since then, a strong pro-hemp lobby has emerged. It is a  combination of industrial lobbies, farmers seeeking new crops and veterans of the alternative and hippie scenes of past decades. **********Interest in hemp was stimulated by the publication in 1993 of a 480-page book, "Rediscovery of the Useful Plant Hemp," which was printed on paper with a  50 percent hemp content. More than 100,000 copies have been sold. **********According to the book, hemp is one of the world's oldest cultivated crops and requires little care and little or no pesticide or fertilizer. It says that cloth made from hemp is several times stronger than cotton and that hemp paper can be recycled 10 times, as opposed to three times for most pulp-based paper. **********The book's editor, Mathias Brockers, has emerged as Germany's first hemp entrepreneur. He opened a shop in Berlin last year to sell products made from hemp, and now helps run a chain of 14 shops across the country. **********The Berlin store offers hemp products ranging from jeans and neckties to furniture oil, shampoo and lipstick, and shoppers are invited to munch on hemp seeds that fill a bowl near the cash register.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/08/busin.main_headline: Softkey Reaches Agreement to Buy Learning Company
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/08/busin.print_headline: Softkey Reaches Agreement to Buy Learning Company
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/08/busin.body_text: **********Five weeks after initiating a hostile bid, Softkey International Inc. said today that it had reached an agreement to acquire the Learning Company for a combination of cash and stock valued at about $606 million. Learning Company said it had terminated its previous merger agreement with Broderbund Software Inc., its preferred suitor. **********Coupled with Softkey's Oct. 30 agreement to acquire the Minnesota Educational Computing Corporation, known as M.E.C.C., and its agreement this month to acquire Compton's New Media from the Tribune Company, this deal would make Softkey the dominant player in educational software. Softkey's combined market share would be more than twice that of its closest competitor. **********Moreover, the company, a general producer of software that is based in Cambridge, Mass., is best known in the industry for its tactic of undercutting competitors on pricing. Analysts said that its aggressive pricing could lower the profitability of the entire educational-software sector. **********Softkey agreed to pay $67.50 a share, up from $65, or $558 million, in cash for 8.28 million shares of the Learning Company's outstanding common stock, and  is to exchange Softkey shares worth about $48 million for unvested Learning Company employee stock options. **********The price proved too high for Broderbund, but the company is looking at other possible acquisitions, a spokesman, Eric Winkler, said. "We looked at the total  market, and the stakes for this one company, and decided it was beyond the risk  we wanted to accrue for our shareholders," he said. **********Shares of the Learning Company, which is based in Fremont, Calif., closed today at $67.125, up $3.875, in Nasdaq trading, while Softkey shares rose $1.875, to $31.125. Broderbund shares fell $1, to $58. **********Bill Dinsmore, the Learning Company's president and chief executive, said in  a telephone interview that Softkey's offer represented a 73 percent premium over what the company's shares had traded for before the Broderbund deal was announced in the summer. **********"Strategically, the combination with Broderbund made a lot of sense, but in the end you really had to look out for the shareholders," Mr. Dinsmore said. **********Broderbund and the Learning Company had earlier agreed on a stock swap initially worth about $550 million, but that slipped to less than $500 million as Broderbund's share price dropped. When Softkey changed a previous cash and stock offer to all cash earlier this week, Broderbund elected not to raise its offer, which had already been sweetened once. Choosing between $67.50 in cash and a partial Broderbund share worth substantially less than that, the board took the cash. **********Founded in 1980, the Learning Company was one of the first personal computer  software companies of any kind, and among the early providers of educational programs for the Apple II, then a leading machine. With its mainstay title, Reader Rabbit, it created a lasting franchise that was unusual in crossing over  from home use to in-school, curriculum-based learning. **********Softkey has built a business by acquiring struggling software companies, repackaging and repricing their products. The company is going from almost no presence in the educational software market to a commanding lead, but analysts said there was no assurance these acquisitions would pay off. Softkey is investing more than $1 billion in M.E.C.C. and the Learning Company at a time when the entire industry has sales of less than $500 million. And though Softkey is an aggressive player, competitors like Davidson & Associates and the Microsoft Corporation are not likely to cede the market without a fight. **********Still, analysts could understand the gamble. "If Softkey applies their discounting strategy here that is going to control the market and that may hurt  Broderbund, Davidson and others which haven't pursued that strategy," said Ann Stephens, an analyst with PC Data in Reston, Va. **********But some childrens' software experts said they doubted Softkey's ability to grow its market share by cutting prices without diminishing quality. Many of Softkey's current products sell for about $12.95, compared with Learning Company titles that range from $50 to $100; developers say there is not enough profit at lower prices to support the cost of producing quality programs. **********Kevin O'Leary, Softkey's president, said that he would not alter the current  products of the Learning Company or M.E.C.C. and that he hoped to retain those companies' development staffs. He said previous comments he had made about "carving" their titles into multiple products had been misinterpreted. **********"I have no intention of changing the prices of any of the Learning Company's  products," Mr. O'Leary said in a telephone interview. "I do want to work with their developers to produce products to service that 40 percent of the market that hasn't bought educational software because of pricing issues."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/14/busin.main_headline: Bidding Starts For Wireless Cable Rights
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/14/busin.print_headline: Bidding Starts For Wireless Cable Rights
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/14/busin.body_text: **********Round one in the Federal Government's auction of video broadcast rights attracted $3.4 million in high bids today. **********Paradise Cable Inc. was the highest bidder, offering $188,750 for the right to provide wireless cable television to a Florida market. The license is one of 493 on the block. **********Altogether, 142 bidders submitted more than 1,113 bids for all but 11 of the licenses. **********Because the auction continues until there are no new bids for any of the licenses, the Federal Communications Commission said the bidding could last anywhere from a few days to a few months. The proceedings were expected to interrupted if the budget standoff between the Clinton Administration and the Republican-led Congress results in a shutdown of the Government. **********Analysts predicted that the auction would raise significantly less revenue for the United States Treasury than previous airwave auctions, because the available licenses are considered less than ideal. **********Eventually, analysts said, the proceeds could reach between $25 million and $100 million, a trifling amount compared with the $9 billion taken in by the F.C.C.'s auctions of personal communications services, the next generation of cellular phone and paging services. **********Wireless cable, a fast-growing but fledgling competitor to traditional cable  service, delivers video programming inexpensively over the airwaves to subscribers' rooftop antennas, and requires set-top boxes. **********The service is viable only in certain geographic regions because the signal cannot reach over buildings or mountains. Also, the service has little channel capacity and is perceived by many industry experts as a nonstarter. **********Still, wireless cable companies are bidding for the rights as a way to extend their reach in existing markets, and many of the local Baby Bell phone companies are looking at the technology as an inexpensive shortcut into the cable television business. **********The Grand Junction, Colo., market attracted eight bids, the largest number for any market today, while York, Pa., attracted the largest dollar volume of bids. **********Pacific Telesis Group, the GTE Corporation and a venture funded in part by the Nynex Corporation and the Bell Atlantic Corporation are among the auction's  biggest bidders, analysts said. **********"From a phone company point of view, it's not a bad deal," said Christopher Dixon of Paine Webber. "Wireless cable provides a Bell operating company a way to go to school to learn how video works." **********In the last few years, wireless cable has emerged in isolated markets as a viable, cheaper alternative to traditional cable television. Two hundred wireless cable systems serve about 800,000 subscribers in the nation, according  to the Wireless Cable Association International's vice president, Andrew T. Kreig. **********Industry consolidation is brisk, with only about 30 companies in operation, and the deep-pocketed Baby Bells' presence will only accelerate that trend, analysts said. **********Though some analysts said they expected bids by the Bells to raise the value  of the licenses, others said the Bells were unlikely to overpay for rights they  see as having temporary value. **********"There's no question that for most telephone companies, wireless cable is an  intermediate step which is limited both in scope and capacity," said Mr. Dixon of Paine Webber.
