https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/30/busin.main_headline: Asian Builder Seeks To Soothe Investors
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/30/busin.print_headline: Asian Builder Seeks To Soothe Investors
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/30/busin.body_text: **********Gordon Wu, the founder of Hopewell Holdings Ltd., one of Asia's biggest builders of bridges, highways and power plants, met with stock analysts today to lay out his plans to reduce the company's debt. **********Hopewell has seen its shares fall 39 percent since July after cost overruns and delays at several of its projects. **********Mr. Wu reiterated his plans to sell assets and to be more open with investors and analysts, according to four of the analysts who attended the meeting. The two-hour meeting at Hopewell's headquarters was closed to journalists. **********In October, Thailand officials said they were skeptical that Hopewell's elevated rail system in Bangkok would ever be completed. A month earlier, the company announced it had spent $722 million more than originally planned on its  Shenzhen-to-Guangzhou highway in China. **********Mr. Wu spoke confidently of both the projects and of Hopewell's prospects, analysts said. **********Mr. Wu told the analysts he called the meeting at the urging of William Purves, the chairman of HSBC Holdings P.L.C., which is Hopewell's main banker. By the end of the year, Hopewell's loans from HSBC will total around $1.2 billion. **********Analysts said Mr. Wu apologized for having provided insufficient information  in the past. In the future, he said, he would hold meetings with analysts every  three months. **********Analysts said that relatively little new financial data emerged from the meeting.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/16/busin.main_headline: In Japan, Aid For Developing Chip of Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/16/busin.print_headline: In Japan, Aid For Developing Chip of Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/16/busin.body_text: **********In an effort to sharpen its competitiveness in electronics, Japan is planning a large Government-financed program to develop advanced techniques for manufacturing semiconductors, displays and computers, officials said on Friday. **********The new effort, tentatively called the Super Advanced Electronics Technology  program, will be financed initially by 10 billion yen, or $100 million, included in a package of measures announced last month to stimulate Japan's sagging economy. **********The project is taking shape as Japan's manufacturers of semiconductors are feeling squeezed. South Korean companies have essentially caught up to Japan's electronic giants in their specialty, memory chips, while the United States has  maintained a lead in microprocessors and other chips that do more advanced information processing tasks. **********Japan has long been known for Government-backed efforts to move the nation into specific industries. In the 1970's, the VLSI Project -- it stands for very  large system integration -- helped Japanese companies capture the world lead in  the memory chip market. **********But as Japan's electronics companies have become bigger and stronger and able to finance their own product development, the projects run by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry have shifted more toward basic research. **********Katsuhiko Kaji, deputy director of the industrial electronics division at MITI, said the new project would work on basic materials and techniques that would be needed 10 years from now rather than on particular products. **********These will include ways for making semiconductors with circuit patterns less  than 0.1 micron in width, compared with several tenths of a micron in today's most advanced chips. The project also will work on techniques for measuring features that small. A micron is a millionth of a meter. **********Mr. Kaji said a consortium of companies was expected to be set up next year to conduct the research. He said theministry wanted to continue the project for  at least five years, but the annual financing probably would be far less than in the first year. **********Mr. Kaji said the project might be open to some "competitive" non-Japanese companies, but added, "We will not welcome free riders." **********In a separate development, 10 Japanese semiconductor companies are planning to work together to help introduce computer-chip manufacturing equipment that can handle silicon wafers that are 300 millimeters, or about 12 inches, in diameter. **********The project would require 5 billion yen, or about $50 million, to start, and  would need a budget of about $40 million a year, an industry official said, adding that there will be no Government financing. **********Currently, chips are made from silicon wafers that are 200 millimeters, or 8  inches, in diameter. The change to 12-inch wafers, which is expected to take place toward the end of the decade, would allow far more chips to be made from a single wafer, cutting manufacturing costs. **********The project is sponsored by the Semiconductor Industry Research Institute Japan, an organization formed last year by Japanese semiconductor companies to work on ways to increase the competitiveness of Japan's industry. The members of the institute include NEC, Toshiba, Hitachi and Fujitsu. **********American companies, led by the Sematech consortium, are also planning a project to help develop manufacturing equipment for 12-inch wafers. **********Taro Okabe, acting executive director of the Japanese institute, said there was a chance the two nations would cooperate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/11/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Striking Newspaper Workers Out in Cold in a Union Town
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/11/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Striking Newspaper Workers Out in Cold in a Union Town
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/11/busin.body_text: **********Nearly four months into a newspaper strike here, the companies that own this  city's two daily papers appear to be defeating their unions. **********Here, in the city that is sometimes called the labor capital of the country,  the papers have published a newspaper every day since the strike began on July 13. Since September, the two papers have each been publishing their usual separate daily editions. **********Most encouraging for the companies, about half of the 500 journalists represented by the striking Newspaper Guild have crossed the picket lines and returned to work. **********At a time the newspaper industry is nearly obsessed with cutting costs, the papers' success draws comparisons with the 1981 defeat of the air traffic controllers' union, whose striking members were replaced. But with the companies' costs of winning the bitter and sometimes violent confrontation expected to climb to pretax losses of $100 million or more, it is not clear whether such a victory would be worth the cost. **********The strike is important to the newspaper industry, in part because the Detroit papers' owners, the Gannett Company and Knight-Ridder Inc., are the nation's largest newspaper publishing companies and because they have grown increasingly confident: they recently refused a union offer to end the strike and submit to binding arbitration. And they have hired 1,500 of what they insist are permanent replacements for 2,500 striking workers. **********The Newspaper Guild is one of six striking unions at Gannett's Detroit News and Knight-Ridder's Detroit Free Press. Some in the newspaper industry view the  strike as a turning point in what has become a city-by-city battle by newspaper  managers to cut costs to satisfy investors and try to remain competitive against new challengers for advertisers' dollars and readers' attention. **********"The way the strike has developed reflects fundamental shifts in the newspaper industry and in journalism," said Charles Eisendrath, a journalism professor at the University of Michigan. "What both sides are groping for is how to survive," he said, as newspapers and employees face new pressure for profits  and new competitive challenges. **********For the labor movement nationally, a defeat would be a special blow, because  of unions' historic strength in Detroit. The leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the teamsters' union and the United Automobile Workers are giving the Detroit unions special help. **********But for newspaper unions in particular, which have been on the defensive nationally for years, a defeat here could be devastating. "This is probably the last big urban newspaper strike," said John Morton, a newspaper industry analyst with Lynch, Jones & Ryan. **********Gannett and Knight-Ridder have gained momentum partly because of what executives describe as careful planning for a strike. Some union people here   said the planning showed the companies' eagerness to send a message about how serious they were to cut costs at other union and nonunion papers. **********Knight-Ridder, for example, is in the midst of tough negotiations aimed at increasing profits at its two Philadelphia newspapers. With the Detroit strike as a backdrop, the papers won a tentative settlement this week from 9 of its 10  unions in Philadelphia after suggesting that it might even close its tabloid, The Philadelphia Daily News. Knight-Ridder executives said this week that because of union concessions, The Philadelphia Daily News would be secure at least until the year 2000. **********In Detroit, the companies hired private security guards, bused in workers from other newspapers and used a helicopter to airlift papers out of a printing  plant, circumventing picketers. Such tactics are expensive, and even if the companies prevail, they may pay a high cost in damage to their images, to the papers, and to journalism in Detroit. **********In the short term, the companies acknowledge that they have already lost more than $46 million fighting the strike, and tens of millions of additional losses  are projected by year-end. P. Anthony Ridder, chairman of Knight-Ridder, told employees in Detroit this week that his company expected to lose $56 million this year because of the strike. **********The papers have separate news units but share business operations and profits under a joint operating agreement that began in 1989. Executives have said the joint operation made a $46 million profit last year. **********But whatever the short-term calculation, some newspaper people here say there have already been immeasurable losses in diminished good will and growing hard feelings. The union leaders say they plan to fight on to inflict maximum damage. The unions were encouraged when the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board issued an unfair-labor-practice complaint in August against the  companies, saying they had not bargained in good faith. If the unions ultimately win that case, the companies could be forced to take the strikers back if they offered to return. **********Many public officials here have condemned the papers, and some have said they will work to be sure the papers pay a lasting price for their stance against the unions. **********Some journalists say the strike is likely to hasten a merger of the two papers into one, or a cut in the resources they devote to news. The companies say that they plan to put out two papers for the length of the joint operating agreement -- 100 years -- and that financially healthier newspapers would allow  them to strengthen their news coverage. **********The human toll has been large. Teamsters and pressmen, most of whom did not cross picket lines, have been unsure whether they would ever work in the industry again. Old friendships have been broken, careers have been derailed and families have been uprooted as people leave town for new jobs. **********Outside on the picket line, The Free Press's restaurant critic, Molly Abraham, said the unions had been weakened by journalists who cast their lot with the companies. The strikebreakers, she said, "are in it for themselves" and do not understand why it is important for union people to stick together. **********"If the unions can be crushed in Detroit," she said, "they probably could be  crushed anywhere." **********Linda K. Foley, the national president of the Newspaper Guild, said, "The two largest newspaper companies in the country have decided they want to bust their  unions, and we have to prove they can't do that." Among several steps the guild  announced here this week, striking workers plan to begin their own weekly Sunday paper to try to lure advertisers and readers. **********Inside at The Free Press, which has long nurtured a reputation for liberalism, Hugh McDiarmid, the political columnist, said the strike had been a  lesson in new business realities in the newspaper industry. **********Perhaps, Mr. McDiarmid said, his competitors at The Detroit News were not surprised that their corporate owner, Gannett, was so aggressive in its drive for profits. Gannett has long had a reputation for rigorously keeping costs down. **********But, Mr. McDiarmid said, "most people recognize now that Knight-Ridder is also a big company that is far more concerned than some of them thought about the bottom line." **********Mr. McDiarmid, 60, returned to work after 27 days on strike. He said he was not angry about the developments, just realistic. "Times have changed in the newspaper business," he said. **********Union leaders said the companies appeared determined to break the unions, with demands for sharp cutbacks in the number of employees, changes in staffing  rules and other concessions. For the Newspaper Guild, a primary issue was the companies' insistence on instituting a merit-pay system instead of simply granting across-the-board pay increases. The editors of both papers denied that  they were trying to break the unions. But they said they were determined to do away with the inefficiencies and "featherbedding." **********Whatever the truth, it is difficult to measure how much damage has been done  to the papers. Boycotted by some advertisers, the papers have lost revenues, though they will not say how much. And they acknowledge that they have lost 24 percent of their prestrike combined daily circulation of 886,228. **********The unions say the circulation numbers are sharply inflated, with many papers piled into garbage bins or delivered to people who do not want them. The newspapers, which deny those assertions, say distribution is returning to normal despite occasional incidents of violence, like a pipe bomb found recently in a newspaper rack. Circulation has not been audited during the strike. **********But even the acknowledged circulation decline of 24 percent could permanently hurt the papers. John Polich, a newspaper management specialist at the Fordham University Graduate School of Business, who has studied reader attitudes about newspapers after strikes in other cities, said circulation declines prompted by  strikes were often long-lasting. And once circulation falls sharply, he said, a  cycle of decline is often difficult to stop. **********"If the strike in Detroit ended tomorrow," Mr. Polich said, "management and the unions would still remain angry, the readers would have had months to find other media or give up on the reading experience entirely, and advertisers will  have been forced to exploit other means of reaching their prospects." **********Outside both newspapers' separate headquarters on West Lafayette Boulevard here, a cold wind was blowing. It was quiet on the street. Three or four strikers, bundled against the chill, moved about in front of each of the buildings. Inside, people sold advertising and planned layouts in the calm of a  normal workday. In the newsroom, reporters, some of whom were working somewhere  else until a few weeks ago, called news sources in Detroit. **********In front of The Detroit News, Dwight Fields, a member of the teamsters' union, said he thought it was too early to say that the unions had lost. "It's far from over," he said. But Joe Adams, a member of the Newspaper Guild, said it would be a long, cold winter. **********Down the street in front of The Free Press, Ms. Abraham, the restaurant critic, tried to keep a picket sign from blowing away. An acquaintance shouted to her, asking what she thought of a restaurant where, until four months ago next Monday, she used to eat for her job. **********"Everybody thinks I have such a good job, and I do," she said. **********Then she added: "I did. I loved it."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/09/busin.body_text: **********When Daniel H. Case 3d started out in investment banking in 1981, he decided  against joining Morgan Stanley & Company, or some other powerful Wall Street barony. **********Instead, the young Princeton graduate and Rhodes scholar from Hawaii, went off to San Francisco to join Hambrecht & Quist Inc., the investment banking boutique where denim mixes with pinstripes and socks are optional. Founded in 1968, Hambrecht specializes in raising capital for young, growing companies, particularly in high-technology businesses. **********I wanted to work some place that had a cross-section of strategic and financial advice work, as well as investment banking and consulting," Mr. Case said in an interview last week. William R. Hambrecht, the company's founder and  chairman "was on President Carter's committee on capital formation, and he wanted me to do some of his staff work." **********"And I had a girlfriend at Stanford," Mr. Case added. **********Things did not work out quite as Mr. Case envisaged. "The Presidential committee never met so there was no staff work, and the girlfriend dumped me within a month," he said. **********Now, just 14 years later, Mr. Case, 38 years old and still looking like a graduate student, is president and chief executive of Hambrecht, which is enjoying a record year. **********Hambrecht is hardly alone in its success. This has been a banner year for smaller investment banking and brokerage firms that specialize in raising money for high-technology companies. Such companies as Robertson, Stephens; Alex Brown & Sons; Hambrecht; Montgomery Securities; Volpe, Welty & Company and Cowen & Company have all had heavy workloads. **********The success of smaller firms in bringing so many technology companies to market also illustrates the degree to which much of the more promising business  in the American securities industry -- high-growth companies -- slips through the fingers of the big Wall Street firms and winds up in the hands of relative newcomers like Hambrecht & Quist. **********As more technology companies have chosen to go public, raising money to expand operations and invest in research into the next potentially cutting-edge  product, they have often turned to local investment firms for help. In part, this is based on a cultural affinity. All the small firms other than Alex Brown  and Cowen have headquarters near Silicon Valley, so the bankers and entrepreneurs are steeped in the same easygoing California culture. In part, it  is because many partners in the investment firms have backgrounds in engineering, and speak the same language as the high-tech entrepreneurs they serve. **********"I spend a whole lot more time in Silicon Valley than I do on Wall Street," Mr. Case said. And his firm and other smaller investment houses were already familiar with the Internet when it suddenly became one of Wall Street's favorite industries. **********Mr. Hambrecht remains chairman of Hambrecht & Quist, a privately held firm that is 90 percent owned by its employees and has equity capital of over $100 million. It has 36 partners and 470 employees worldwide, including more than 20  analysts following technology companies. The firm's other founding partner, George Quist, died in 1982. **********Not surprisingly, Mr. Case is an unabashed booster of the Internet. "The personal computer market in the 1980's, the railroad industry in the 19th century, there are a lot of metaphors for the Internet," said Mr. Case, whose colleagues at Hambrecht project it will be a $13-billion-ayear industry by the end of the decade. **********Being savvy about coming technologies, however, isn't everything.  Hambrecht, Robertson and others do not have the huge capital of their bigger New York competitors, who have billions of dollars behind them. This financial muscle quickly becomes important as companies grow. **********"Capital is very important in developing strong banking relationships," said  Carter McClelland, president and chief executive of Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in  North America, "particularly because it's so key to developing strong market support in the over-the-counter trading business." **********Larger technology offerings like those for the AVX Corporation, the ceramic capacitor maker, and MEMC Electronic Materials Inc., a silicon wafer manufacturer, are still the province of Wall Street , but in terms of the number of high-tech initial public offerings, or I.P.O.'s, it is the minnows that are gobbling up more of the meal. **********Oak Technology Inc., the Netscape Communications Corporation, Computron Software Inc., the Check Free Corporation and UUNet Technologies Inc. are among  the better-known technology companies that these smaller investment banks have helped to take public this year. **********"These people are professionals, they've done well, but the market has been with them," said John Fitzgibbon of I.P.O. Aftermarket, a securities industry publication. "They've caught lightning in a bottle." **********The majority of the high-tech I.P.O's of the last 12 months are trading above their issue prices, according to Mr. Fitzgibbon, citing Pinnacle Systems Inc., which closed Friday at $31.25, up from an issue price of $10 last November and Oak Technology, which closed Friday at $37.50, up from an issue price of $14. **********"We were very satisfied, they had good distribution to institutions and helped us win market acceptance," said George A. McMillan, chief operating and financial officer for Renaissance Solutions Inc., a consulting and systems integration company that Hambrecht and Cowen took public at $13 a share in April, and whose stock closed Friday at $23. **********Despite the healthy market, there have been some flops among Hambrecht's I.P.O.'s, including ACT Network Inc., which ended the week at $9.25 a share, down from its May issue price of $13. **********Although the market for high-technology stocks has softened slightly recently, the industry has still driven the market for stock offerings this year. "High technology has been the Florence Nightingale for the new-issue market in 1995," said David L. Menlow, president of the I.P.O. Financial Network Corporation of Springfield, N.J., a company that projects the opening prices of  initial public offerings. **********Mr. Case is careful not to seem disrespectful of the bigger Wall Street firms whose muscle can be important to his clients. "A constructive relationship is helpful to the client," he said, but Wall Street comes at high-technology investment banking "from a different cultural perspective." **********"The world needs both of us," he added. "We ultimately believe their brand is overvalued in our markets."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/10/world.main_headline: Honduras Trying to Identify Disease That Kills Infants
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/10/world.print_headline: Honduras Trying to Identify Disease That Kills Infants
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/10/world.body_text: **********The baffled health authorities here are struggling to identify and combat a mysterious disease that has apparently afflicted only infants, often killing them in a matter of hours, in the six weeks since it suddenly appeared in Honduras. **********At least 10 children under the age of 12 months have died of the disease, whose origins remain unknown. The Ministry of Health has determined that an orally transmitted bacterial infection was the cause of death, and has sent material from three autopsies to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention  in Atlanta in an effort to isolate what Honduran health officials describe as a  particularly aggressive "mutant" micro-organism. **********There are some very strange features to this disease, and we don't have the facilities we need here or in neighboring countries, so we have asked the C.D.C. for help," Dr. Enrique Zelaya, an official of the Health Ministry, said in an interview here. **********"This is an intestinal infection, but without the dehydration you would normally see, and with some other oddities, such as a very low pH level in the blood," he said. **********The first cases of the illness were reported early in November, most of them  in this capital. The Government quickly put an educational campaign into effect, urging parents to take infants to the hospital at the first sign of diarrhea, and appeared to have brought the situation under control until this week, when another infant was hospitalized and died less than 24 hours later. **********The outbreak here is the fourth major epidemic to strike the six countries of Central America this year. More than 100,000 cases of dengue, an often-fatal disease transmitted by mosquitoes, have been reported throughout Latin America and the Caribbean in 1995, but the highest and most severe levels of incidents,  more than 35,000 cases, have occurred in this region, where the rainy season has been unusually long and intense. **********Then, in October, an outbreak of what was later identified as leptospirosis,  which is transmitted by the urine of mammals, hit Nicaragua, killing at least 26 people and infecting more than 2,500 before spreading to Honduras and El Salvador. At about the same time, El Salvador was afflicted by an epidemic of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, which is not fatal but can lead to blindness. **********"The clear linkage in all these cases is poverty," said Dr. Berta Gomez, a specialist in transmissible diseases who works for the Pan-American Health Organization here. "The poor live where environmental conditions are the most precarious, where sanitation is not the best, where educational efforts arrive late, if at all." **********That seems to be the case with the disease in Honduras, the poorest country in Central America. All the young victims lived with their families in the sprawling shantytowns that have sprung up in the last decade on the sides of the mountains around Tegucigalpa, as tens of thousands of peasants have flocked here in search of jobs and a better life. **********Several of those who died lived in an area near a huge garbage dump where foods like powdered milk and cereal are supposed to be burned when their expiration dates pass. Many poor residents often rummage through the dump, scavenging for items that they can either consume themselves or sell illegally at a discount on the open market. **********Dr. Elsa Palou, president of the Honduran medical association, said she was particularly disturbed by the re-emergence of "old diseases" thought to have been vanquished. She attributed the phenomenon not only to the lack of hygiene but also to the unwillingness of governments throughout the region to spend money on disease prevention and health education programs. **********Dr. Zelaya, the Health Ministry official, said the Government increased spending on health programs by nearly two-thirds last year and by 10 percent this year. But those were the first real increases in more than a decade, he said, and have not been sufficient to address the problems that have built up over the years. **********"Our costs are obviously much higher, and it's hard to get an adequate supply of the raw materials we need, like insecticide," he said. "All of our programs have been deteriorating little by little, and we have fallen so far behind that  it is hard to catch up."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/08/busin.main_headline: FUNDS WATCH;Money Market Funds Jump $113 Billion This Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/08/busin.print_headline: FUNDS WATCH;Money Market Funds Jump $113 Billion This Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/08/busin.body_text: **********ASSETS in money market funds have really surged this year, suggesting the category will hit $1 trillion by February 1998, said Money Market Insight, a newsletter in Ashland, Mass. **********So far this year, the funds have added $113 billion, reaching $732 billion last week. The category grew by $43 billion for all of 1994. **********It's not as if money was flooding out of stock and bond funds, either. Given the strong inflows into other mutual funds, money must be coming into the money  market funds from new sources, analysts said. **********Money continues to shift out of bank certificates of deposit, in part because money fund yields have surpassed those on 6-month and 12-month C.D.'s. Investors seem to be seeking the best investment, not sticking with the old standbys. **********Other factors contributing to the growth are the increasing popularity of mutual funds and retirement plans, whether 401(k)'s or individual retirement accounts. Through these accounts, people are learning about saving and investing choices. **********Money market mutual funds are well on their way to hitting $1 trillion in assets. Then they would be overseeing a significant part of the country's liquid assets, from individuals, municipalities, small companies and Fortune 500 companies. **********Fleet Bank Adds Sales Charge **********One of the few banks to offer mutual funds without a load, or sales charge, is changing course. Fleet Financial Group, based in Providence, R.I., plans to add an up-front sales fee of 3.75 percent to its Galaxy stock and bond portfolios on Nov. 1. **********The company said the charge was prompted by its effort to offer more investment counseling services, but it follows on the heels of Fleet's merger with Shawmut Bank, which already offers fund shares with a load. **********Current shareholders would be exempt from the new charges, as would all buyers in individual retirement accounts and other retirement plans, and anyone  who uses an automatic investment plan or mutual fund wrap account. **********Galaxy II shareholders would not be affected by the new fee. **********On-Line Service For 401(k) Plans **********The Vanguard Group has started a computer service to help 401(k) participants develop a sound retirement plan. The program, called Participant Online, includes several segments on saving and investing for people with varying levels of investing experience. Each segment allows people to incorporate their own financial data and to calculate whether their savings plans are sufficient to meet their goals. **********The company toots its own horn, too; one segment gives comprehensive information about Vanguard's funds. So far, the program can be used only in the  workplace with companies providing the link, although Vanguard plans to make it  available on home computers. **********New Funds **********Eaton Vance Information will own stocks of companies of all sizes involved in the creation, processing and distribution of information in the United States and abroad. Investors can choose shares with an up-front sales charge of 4.75 percent or with a deferred sales charge of 5 percent that disappears after six years. **********MFS and Foreign and Colonial have started three new funds: International Growth and Income will own a mix of stocks and bonds mostly outside the United States; International Growth will own stocks of overseas companies, and Emerging Markets Equity will be in developing markets around the world. The sales charge  is 4.75 percent. Fee Waivers **********Stein Roe & Farnham has extended fee waivers to all individual-retirement, simplified employee-pension and rollover retirement accounts. Previously, only accounts of $5,000 or more qualified for the waiver. Investors who have paid the $12 fee for 1995 can expect a refund. **********Three Fidelity funds -- Puritan, Equity-Income and Export -- have waived their sales charges, but the waivers expire at the end of the year. **********Annuities Made Simple **********The promise of tax-deferred growth makes annuities tantalizing. To help you  decide if an annuity is a good investment, T. Rowe Price is offering free software that compares the after-tax return of annuities with various investments in mutual funds. **********Price, which introduced a low-cost annuity last month, urges investors to take advantage of individual retirement accounts, 401(k) plans, Keoghs and other tax-deferred options before considering annuities. **********The program allows you to create examples, using assumptions about life expectancy, tax rates and investment returns, both before and after retirement.  The software, for use with Windows 3.1 and an I.B.M.-compatible computer, is available by calling 800 469-5304. **********Following Up On Settlements **********Say you have a problem with a salesman who sold you fund shares. A settlement is reached in your favor in arbitration conducted by the National Association of Securities Dealers, a self-regulating body of the securities industry. But what  if the offending party fails to fulfill the settlement's requirements? **********Because the N.A.S.D. was concerned that some of its members were not honoring arbitration agreements, as of Oct. 2 it has given itself the authority to suspend or cancel the membership or registration of the a broker who won't comply with an arbitrated settlement. **********The N.A.S.D. said investor costs were rising because of delayed settlement payments and enforcement expenses. Sometimes, the N.A.S.D. has had to reschedule hearings or appoint a new arbitrator. Perhaps most important, regulators want to insure the credibility of the arbitration process. New Managers **********C. Beth Cotner, formerly the manager of Kemper Growth, has left to join Putnam Investments. Steven Reynolds, the new chief investment officer for equities at Kemper Financial Services, will manage the fund until another manager is found. Mr. Reynolds was formerly a senior vice president with Alliance Capital Management. **********Paine Webber Growth has picked up Blue Chip Growth and Communications and Technology; all three funds are or were managed by Ellen Harris. **********Tom Marsico is turning over control of the three broker-sold Idex funds -- Idex, Idex II Growth and Idex Fund 3 -- to a co-manager, Scott Schoelzel, in January, if the board approves the move. Mr. Marsico plans to focus on Janus 20  and Janus Growth & Income. **********In Brief **********Morningstar Inc., the fund research firm, now offers performance and balance  sheet information, valuation ratios and other data for 6,000 stocks through America Online.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/01/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;EXODUS OF TOP LOTUS OFFICIALS CONTINUES
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/01/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;EXODUS OF TOP LOTUS OFFICIALS CONTINUES
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/01/busin.body_text: **********Two executives at the Lotus Development Corporation, including a corporate officer, have joined the exodus of Lotus officials from the software company since it was acquired by I.B.M. in June. The resignation of June L. Rokoff, the  company's senior vice president of worldwide services and support who is highly  regarded for her management skills, will take effect on Dec. 31. The company also said yesterday that Hamang Davey, a vice president of strategic alliances,  was leaving. A Lotus spokesman said Mr. Davey had headed the company's merger and integration team following the acquisition by I.B.M. and that the work had essentially been completed. Ms. Rokoff's departure essentially ends the post-takeover presence by the company's top officials. Dave Champagne, who has been at Lotus for 12 years, will replace Ms. Rokoff. An I.B.M. spokesman declined to comment on either departure.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/14/busin.main_headline: Yield on 30-Year Bond Falls to 6.30%, Lowest Since Early 1994
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/14/busin.print_headline: Yield on 30-Year Bond Falls to 6.30%, Lowest Since Early 1994
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/14/busin.body_text: **********The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond dropped to 6.30 percent yesterday, returning to its level before the Federal Reserve began raising short-term interest rates in February 1994. **********This lower yield -- nearly two percentage points below where it was last November -- comes amid growing optimism among market participants that the economy continues to show steady growth without accelerating inflation. In addition, there is still hope that the Clinton Administration and Congress can reach a budget compromise without either shutting down the Government when the Federal borrowing ceiling is reached shortly or defaulting on the Government's debt obligations. **********The optimism was reinforced yesterday with the report that the Consumer Price Index rose one-tenth of 1 percent in September and that retail sales increased a modest three-tenths of 1 percent. **********"I felt quite strongly before the release of the number that inflation was subdued, benign and nonthreatening," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities. "Quite obviously, I still feel the same way, only more so today." **********By the close of New York trading, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond gained 1 6/32 , to 107 21/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction  from its price, dropped to 6.30 percent, from 6.39 percent Thursday. **********The yield was last at 6.30 percent on Feb. 3, 1994, a day before the Fed first tightened credit and raised the Federal funds rate a quarter of a percentage point.  Investors gained $11.88 yesterday for every $1,000 of bonds held. **********Short-term interest rates also moved slightly lower but they are still higher than a year ago. **********Robert Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities International, noted "the  two-year Treasury on the short end of the yield curve is now 5.65 percent, well  below the Federal funds rate of 5.75 percent." **********While these kinds of yields in the marketplace clearly point to an expectation that the Fed will cut rates soon, Mr. Brusca does not expect the Federal Reserve to do so. "The good inflation figure is an accommodating factor  for the Fed; what it lacks is a motivating factor," he said. **********And it is likely that the optimism about inflation and moderate growth will continue for the time being, analysts said. **********"Given the well-behaved inflation numbers, credit markets will probably be able to tolerate much faster economic activity before they panic," said Anthony  Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisers in Columbus, Ohio. **********Although concern about the debt ceiling may roil the Treasury market a little as the White House and Congress near the deadline, traders do not expect the Government to default because the debt ceiling game of chicken is played almost  every year, as Congress and the White House use the threat of default as a lever to get what they want. **********Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, however, seemed to heighten the tension yesterday when he told reporters attending a Business Council conference in Williamsburg, Va., that the Federal Government would run out of borrowing authority Oct. 31. This is two weeks earlier than the Nov. 15 date that had been the deadline. **********But, according to Bloomberg Business News, Mr. Rubin added, "In the final analysis, the Congress of the United States is not going to want to default on the full faith and credit of the United States." **********Mr. Brusca at Nikko and other analysts said they were not worried. **********"We've seen it before," Mr. Brusca said. "It's a temporary thing and some accord will eventually be reached." **********In trading in the futures market yesterday, the December bond contract reached a high for the second consecutive session as well as a new contract settlement high of 117 14/32 . "On the monthly chart, there appears to be nothing but air until we reach 118 27/32 ," said Robin Mesch, fixed-income analyst at Thomson Research in Boston, indicating there does not appear to be any resistance among buyers up to that price.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/27/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pechiney Stock Falls As Swap Plan Falters
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/27/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pechiney Stock Falls As Swap Plan Falters
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/27/busin.body_text: **********Shares in Pechiney International S.A. plunged as much as 10 percent during the day yesterday as investors abandoned the idea of swapping their shares for stock in the parent company, Pechiney S.A., and sold them instead. Pechiney International stock recovered by the close, ending down 1.5 French francs at 89.5 francs ($18.27). The stock had fallen as much as 9 francs, or 10 percent, to 82 francs ($16.73). **********"Pechiney is at such a low price that it's better to sell now," said Laurent Mace, a trader at Nomura Bourse. Pechiney S.A. shares fell to a 52-week low of 169.7 francs, down 0.3 franc from Friday, a 9.3 percent drop from the 187 francs of the French Government's public offering a week ago. France sold most of its 56 percent stake in Pechiney then.  The offer of 5 Pechiney S.A. shares for 9 Pechiney International shares ends Jan. 9, said the Paris brokerage firm Transbourse. (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/02/world.main_headline: Ottawa Moves Quickly in Effort to Mollify Quebec
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/02/world.print_headline: Ottawa Moves Quickly in Effort to Mollify Quebec
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/02/world.body_text: **********Jarred by the narrow defeat of the Quebec independence referendum, Canadian leaders today promised quick action aimed at meeting the restive province's demands for greater autonomy. **********But some Canadians said the moves came too late to contain the separatist anger that has taken hold in Quebec. **********Prime Minister Jean Chretien is seeking a consensus from the premiers of Canada's provinces for constitutional changes that would recognize Quebec's distinct status -- an idea the other provinces have resisted in the past. Mr. Chretien also wants to give Quebec a veto over future constitutional changes affecting the province and to speed the decentralization of other powers to all  provinces, including greater authority over immigration, job training and higher education. **********"I will bring about these changes very quickly," Mr. Chretien said in Ottawa  today. And in an address to business leaders tonight in Toronto, he promised that the House of Commons "will speak out" in the near future on a resolution to give Quebec "distinct society" status. He also said he would "find a way for the people of Quebec to be sure that we do not change the Constitition without their consent." **********In his first address since the Monday vote, the Prime Minister said, "The time has come to turn the page on endless referendums, and the time has come to  make the necessary changes to keep this country united." **********Vowing to end the separatist threat once and for all, he said to the cheers of the 2,400 executives, "This country has the right to political stability." **********Mr. Chretien did not say how he would stop another referendum in Quebec, but  asserted that separatists "must respect the wishes of the Quebec people." **********Criticized for his handling of the referendum, which federalist forces came within a whisker of losing, Mr. Chretien scrapped plans to attend a meeting in Tokyo this week in favor of beginning talks with the premiers. **********Separatists led by Lucien Bouchard, head of the Bloc Quebecois, and Jacques Parizeau who resigned on Tuesday as Quebec's premier, have indicated no interest in improving the way federalism works in Canada. They want an independent country, not just a distinct society, and in their concession speeches Monday promised a new independence referendum is around the corner. **********"Mr. Chretien has learned nothing from the referendum and is simply spouting  the same old meaningless cliches about change that almost put this country over  the edge," said Preston Manning, leader of the weatern-based Reform Party, the third-largest in Parlilament after the Bloc Quebecois and the Liberals. **********In the last quarter-century, Canada's political life has been dominated by the Quebec question and by trying to alter Canadian federalism to accommodate Quebec's demands. **********Twice in the last 10 years, in the Meech Lake and Charlottetown accords, Ottawa failed to win the necessary national backing to grant Quebec the "distinct society" status it wants to protect its Francophone culture in a sea of English speakers. Quebec also has a significant population of immigrants, many of whom principally speak a language other than French or English. **********In light of the failed earlier initiatives, analysts give the Chretien reforms little more than a 50-50 chance of heading off a new independence drive  in the province. **********"It strikes me as awfully late in the day to be making such minimal gestures," said Mel Watkins, a political economist at the University of Toronto. **********One of the main problems is that many Canadians, especially those in western  Canada, believe that all provinces should be equal and that Quebec is not entitled to special treatment. **********During the Quebec referendum campaign, Mr. Bouchard, who rescued the flagging separatist effort and brought it close to victory, made much of the unwillingness of English Canada to recognize Quebec's differences. The new reforms are intended to take some wind out of Mr. Bouchard's sails in the event  a new referendum is actually called. **********Quebec's referendum law prevents the provincial Government from holding another vote on the same issue within the same term of office. The present Quebec Government's term expires in September 1999. **********But if Mr. Bouchard replaces Mr. Parizeau as Premier of Quebec and forms a new provincial government, he could call for another referendum as early as next year. A new provincial government also could simply amend the referendum law. **********Still another option is a referendum-election, meaning that if the Parti Quebecois, the ruling separatist party in the province, were re-elected, it would have an automatic mandate for sovereignty. **********But the Parti Quebecois provincial cabinet, which met today in Quebec after Mr. Parizeau's surprise resignation announcement on Tuesday, is divided on whether a quick new referendum should be held. **********"To have only one referendum per mandate is a wise choice," Serge Menard, the province's public security minister, said in Quebec City today. "It requires a lot of energy from politicians and citizens." **********Daniel Johnson, Quebec's Liberal Party leader and the leader of the forces wanting to remain a part of Canada in the referendum, said that holding another  vote so soon would be tantamount to insulting Quebecers' intelligence. **********"The last thing that Quebecers want is another referendum or another election in the near future," he said in Montreal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/13/busin.main_headline: Technolog: ON THE NET;Today's Willie Suttons mug corporate users, not the little guy from Hackensack.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/13/busin.print_headline: Technolog: ON THE NET;Today's Willie Suttons mug corporate users, not the little guy from Hackensack.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/13/busin.body_text: **********DOZENS of electronic merchants are dreaming of a byte Christmas. But is this  the year that all the pieces for electronic consumerism will fall into place? **********Don't unhitch those reindeer just yet. The merchants point to surveys that show a growing dissatisfaction with surly and poorly trained clerks, with the crowds, the parking headaches and other drawbacks of the retail shopping experience. **********More important still, for many people, is the lack of time available for physical shopping. Virtual shopping malls are open all night, and one can shop in robe and pajamas, bathed in the warm glow of a Pentium processor. **********But there are many remaining obstacles -- some technical, some psychological. The highest barriers are those needed to assure secure transactions and privacy. **********Many people are reluctant to send their credit card information over the Internet, their fears heightened by news accounts of computer bandits vacuuming  gigabytes of financial data from computer systems around the world. **********The truth is that sending a credit card number to an electronic merchant over the Internet is probably the safest way to make such a transaction. **********In the last week, for example, I handed my credit card to a waiter who disappeared with it for five minutes. I faxed my credit card information to a business in New Jersey, and the fax probably lay exposed to everyone in that office for hours and perhaps to the cleaning crew that night. **********I called a hotel and gave my card data to a reservations clerk and continued  my recklessness by ordering some merchandise from a clothing catalogue, again by reading my credit card information to some unseen operator. **********Yes, there is a risk that someone was tapping my telephone when I read my credit card number aloud or faxed it. (A reminder: Never, ever, give a credit card number over a cordless or cellular phone.) A spy might have snapped a picture of my credit card with a hidden camera when I handed it to the waiter. A hacker might have intercepted my numbers as they passed through an Internet router in Hackensack, N.J. **********But compared with the risk of handing my credit card to a stranger, which I do nearly every day, sending it over the Internet is pretty secure. **********The real risk of sending my unencrypted number is not that some cyberspace cowboy will intercept it en route to the electronic merchant, but rather that the receiving company will store my credit information in an insecure computer.  (No, not one racked with doubt about whether its hard disk is big enough, but one that lacks firewall, authentication, authorization and physical protections.) **********My credit card number was probably among the 30,000 or so that were lifted last year from unsecured computers of Netcom On-Line Communications Services by  any number of hackers, possibly including the notorious Kevin Mitnick. As far as I know, no one has charged a powerful work station or a vacation to the Caymans  to my account. **********How did Netcom get my credit card number in the first place? I read it to them over the telephone, because they warned me that it was insecure to send it  over the Internet. Then they typed it into their computer, which was connected to the Internet, and left a door open. **********Willie Sutton did not mug individuals for their wallets; he robbed banks, because, as he noted, that's where the money was. A hacker bright enough to break into an Internet server is also bright enough not to waste time picking isolated Mastercard and Visa numbers from the data stream. **********Today's Willie Suttons rob corporate computers, because that's where the data are. The people who should be really nervous about electronic commerce are the banks, brokerage houses and those who do business-to-business transactions. **********As an individual, I can shrug off the recent news that two students cracked the security mechanism in World Wide Web servers of Netscape Communications. But if I were a business about to risk my future on electronic commerce based on the Netscape server or any other Web server, I would want to wait a while longer until I was confident that the security issue had been resolved. **********It will not be resolved before Christmas. **********According to a recent survey by Commerce Net and Nielsen, 2.5 million American and Canadian adults have purchased something over a computer network. There are plenty of places for them to shop. **********For example, CyberShop (http:// cybershop.com), in Montclair, N.J., is trying to lure customers with a sweepstakes, in which the winner gets a $25,000 on-line shopping spree for items including fine china, towels and cameras. **********The Internet Shopping Network (http://www.internet.net) of Palo Alto, Calif., boasts about 25,000 computer products, plus flowers, steaks and lobsters. **********A new electronic shopping mall called eShop Plaza, from a company called eShop Inc., allows "virtual 3-D" shopping of Tower Records, (800) Flowers and Spiegel catalogues, among other offerings, for users with the proper Windows software. **********The eShop Web site can be found, along with scores of other Internet shopping areas, through the Yahoo directory (http://www.yahoo.com/ BusinessandEconomy/Companies/ShoppingCenters/). **********Yet, as David Kline pointed out in a recent opinion article in the on-line magazine Hotwired (http:// www.hotwired.com/market/95/43/ index1a.html), the amount of shopping done on line is dwarfed by the amount done over insecure telephone lines. **********"The real reason people aren't buying very much on line yet is that there's nothing much to buy on line that can't be bought more easily or less expensively and with better service in more familiar surroundings," Mr. Kline said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/24/busin.main_headline: INVESTING IT;Why the January Effect Might Take a Vacation
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/24/busin.print_headline: INVESTING IT;Why the January Effect Might Take a Vacation
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/24/busin.body_text: **********JANUARY 1996 may turn out to be a cold month for investors who seek out the so-called January effect. **********The effect is a decades-old market quirk in which small stocks have often been given a big bounce in January. In January 1994, for example, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, made up predominantly of large-capitalization stocks, rose 3.35 percent, while small stocks, defined as the smallest fifth of companies traded on the New York Stock Exchange, gained 6.18 percent, according  to Ibbotson Associates, a research firm. **********And in the previous January, when the S.& P. 500 rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, small stocks jumped 5.43 percent. In about six out of seven Januaries since the mid-1920's, small stocks have outperformed the market by an average of about five percentage points. **********But next month -- like January 1995, when the S.& P. 500 and small stocks rose 2.60 percent and 2.83 percent, respectively -- may be one of the exceptions. **********A common theory behind the effect is that many investors sell losers for tax  purposes in December, and that those castoffs are often small issues. The selloff reduces the prices of these stocks in January, making them attractive and prompting a run-up for the month. **********But the surge in stocks -- large and small -- in 1995 might be bad news for the January effect. **********"This market is up so much there aren't a whole lot of losses to take," said  Gus Sauter, a vice president at the Vanguard Group of mutual funds. Without losses, there might not be much tax-driven selling. **********Then come the pending Congressional bills to cut the capital gains tax. Uncertainty over whether Congress will do so, and the effective date if it does, have led some investors to defer selling their stocks that have appreciated in value. "People are holding out until the last minute," said Claudia E. Mott, an  analyst at Prudential Securities. "Some selling that might ordinarily take place has not." **********But the mystery will soon end, either with the bills' defeat or with their passage, probably with an effective date of Jan. 1. In either case, investors who have held stocks only to see what happens on Capitol Hill will no longer have a reason to defer their decisions. **********Robert Willens, a tax expert at Lehman Brothers, has been thinking along those lines, because many investors seem to fit this profile. "We expect a great selling of pent-up assets early in 1996," he said. If there is such a market selloff in January, of course, investors are unlikely to make strong profits from small stocks during the month. **********"The January effect may be turned on its ear this year," Mr. Willens said. **********But other factors suggest that the effect will not be upended, or at least not completely. Having been treated so well by the 1995 market, investors may hold their stocks even after the fate of the tax bills is known, and thus help prevent a January selloff. And there is a second part of the pending legislation that may influence the January effect. **********Under current law, investors can offset long-term capital gains with long-term capital losses. Any leftover losses, up to $3,000 a year, can be written off dollar for dollar against ordinary income. The bills, however, would substitute a 2-to-1 ratio starting next year, so $6,000 in losses would be needed for the same tax benefit that $3,000 brings today. **********Given this prospect, investors who fear losing half their tax benefit may now be scurrying to realize losses. And although Mr. Willens sees the market's strong 1995 performance as limiting the impact of this provision, any rush to sell now would portend a stronger January effect, other things being equal. **********Moreover, tax-driven selling is just one possible explanation of the January  effect, and the others don't look any weaker this year than in the past. Some experts say the investment of Christmas bonuses plays a role in the January jump in small stocks. Others explain the effect as the greater willingness of money managers to place risky bets on stocks at the beginning of the year. **********ROBERT A. EISTHEN, equity analyst with Bartlett & Company in Cincinnati, which is soon to be a unit of Legg Mason, is confident of at least a selective January effect. His candidates include yearlong losers in the energy and retail  industries. **********Ms. Mott, of Prudential, has a list of 29 small-capitalization candidates for possible January gains, including Coltec Industries, a maker of automotive and aerospace equipment, which closed Friday at $11.50, down 32.9 percent this year, and Zenith Electronics, which closed at $7 on Friday and is down 39.8 percent in 1995. **********But betting on bad performers is risky, even more so in a year when the January effect may or may not appear. A safer play may be small-stock mutual funds, like Fidelity Low-Priced Stock and Hancock Special Equities, two of the 18 best-rated such funds tracked by Morningstar, the fund research company. **********Investors can also consult their brokers about futures, options and other sophisticated ways to ride the January effect. But whatever the tactic, there will be much bated breath as 1996 rolls in. "This is going to be a weird year,"  Ms. Mott said.
