https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/04/busin.print_headline: Business Travel;Executives are scouting opportunities in Cuba these days, despite the problems of getting there.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/04/busin.body_text: **********CUBA is a potentially profitable market that is not emerging, thanks to the American economic embargo. Even so, executives or foreign representatives of American companies are scouting it like crazy these days, mostly flying there through Canada, the Bahamas, Mexico -- and even directly from the United States. **********For those who want to go there, a good starting point is the U.S.-Cuba Trade  and Economic Council, a nonprofit organization discreetly supported by major American companies, which has its headquarters in New York at 30 Rockefeller Plaza; the telephone number is (212) 246-1444. "Last year some 500 American business people visited Cuba," said John S. Kavulich 2d, the group's president,  who commutes to Havana once or twice a month, "but it's double that number this  year." **********Despite Cuba's off-limits status, United States law allows business executives to pursue commercial opportunities in fields like communications, entertainment, medical equipment, pharmaceuticals and publishing. If a Cuban "sponsor" does not pick up expenses, an American must apply for a license -- in  effect, to spend money in Cuba -- from the Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control. **********Travelers can apply for a visa by sending a letter to the Cuban Interests Section, 2630 16th St. N.W., Washington, D. C. 20009. The fax number is (202) 797-8521; the telephone is (202) 797-8518. **********Properly documented, a traveler can book a round trip between Miami and Cuba  on one of two charter airlines: ABC (305 871-1260) or C&T; (305 876-7660). Both operate several flights weekly. The round-trip fare is about $250. **********Most business travelers to Havana stay at the small, well-connected Victoria  (telephone 53-7-33-35-10, fax 53-7-33-31-09). But the new Spanish-run Melia Cohiba (53-7-33-36-36) is more stylish. The hottest business bistro in town? Dine alfresco at El Aljibe, where it's chicken done every which way. **********If you want an update on what's going on in Cuba, try a new web site on the Internet -- http://ix.urz.uni-heidelberg.de/ pklee/Cuba. The host is in Germany, but it informs in English. **********X-Raying Your Computer **********With airport security again tightened this week under a "general alert," you  may wonder about the safety of your $4,000 to $7,000 notebook computer when subjected to X-ray probes. **********You should not worry, according to James D. Barlett Jr., head of strategic marketing at I.B.M. Mobile Computing. His employer makes the highly regarded line of Think Pads, and Mr. Barlett -- on the road year round -- clocks travel miles faster than a Pentium chip. **********"X-ray machines are very safe," he said. "Out of all the people I know who've run their laptops through security barriers, I've never known anyone to lose data. X-rays aren't the problem. It's the motor that drives the moving belt. But the electromagnetic field it can generate dissipates rapidly within inches of the motor." **********Mr. Bartlett would not say there is zero risk -- but almost, partly because of computer design. **********"There's a fair amount of shielding inside a notebook so the components don't interfere with each other," he said, "and that helps prevent a magnetic field from penetrating. You have more to worry about around your home -- the magnets in the loudspeakers or on refrigerators -- than you do while traveling." **********High-Tech Etiquette **********One executive traveler's cozy corner that has not totally surrendered to high technology is the Mansion on Turtle Creek, a dreamy palace in Dallas owned by the oil millionaire Caroline Hunt and rated the nation's best hotel in the latest Zagat Survey. Here, fluffy pillows count more than personal computers. **********"Our biggest feeder city is New York," said Jeff Trigger, the perky and precise general manager. "Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley, Cap Cities -- they all  come here. We're not just for the rich and famous like Elizabeth Taylor. We have a Rolls and two stretch Caddies -- but also two sedans if you're conducting a meeting with a client." **********He added: "We have a little business center. But that's not why guests stay here. The vast majority are at a level where -- well, they let the bellman send  a fax. They want a concierge to arrange for a secretary to take shorthand. If you're doing a multimillion-dollar deal, it's the attorneys carrying briefcases  and the accountants lugging the laptops." **********It is positively jarring to see a guest with a cellular phone glued to his ear amid the Mansion's antiques and finery. **********"We've had to make rules on etiquette," Mr. Trigger said. "We want guests to  enjoy their meals without phone calls intruding. If a guest is disturbing others -- treating our restaurant like an office -- we handle it in a subtle manner. We gently move them to a quiet corner." **********"Besides," he continued. "guests tend to patrol each other. They give offenders a look."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/busin.body_text: **********BLACK & DECKER TO SELL A TECHNOLOGY UNIT The Black & Decker Corporation of Towson, Md., agreed yesterday to sell PRC Inc., its information technology and services business, to Litton Industries for $425 million. The sale will allow Black & Decker, best known for its power tools and household appliances, to improve its balance sheet and to focus on core businesses, the company said. Proceeds will be used to pay down debt. Litton, of Woodland Hills, Calif., said PRC had estimated sales of about $720 million in 1995. PRC designs and supports computer-based information systems for the Federal Government, commercial customers and state and local governments.   (Dow Jones) **********RIGEL ENERGY TO ACQUIRE AN OIL COMPANY IN ALBERTA The Rigel Energy Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire all of the outstanding  common stock of Inverness Petroleum Ltd. in a transaction valued at $380 million (Canadian), or $275 million (United States). Under the terms of the offer, Inverness shareholders will receive 0.625 of a Rigel share for each of the 31.5  million common shares held. A combination of the two oil and gas concerns based  in Calgary, Alberta, would significantly increase Rigel's resources. Proven gas  reserves would rise 79 percent, while proven liquid reserves would increase 58 percent. Production of liquids by the combined operations would rise 74 percent, while natural gas production would increase 144 percent.   (Dow Jones) **********DU PONT AGREES TO SELL IN-VITRO DIAGNOSTICS BUSINESS E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company agreed yesterday to sell the in-vitro diagnostics business of its medical products unit to Dade International Inc. of  Deerfield, Ill., a medical diagnostic concern. The terms were not disclosed. Du  Pont, which is based in Wilmington, Del., said the sale was part of its plan to  divest itself of four medical products businesses. The in-vitro business supplies chemistry analysis equipment and has annual sales of about $335 million. Dade is a privately held company controlled by Bain Capital Inc., which acquired it from Baxter International Inc. in December 1994.   (Dow Jones) **********FOREST OIL TO BUY CANADIAN COMPANY FOR $135 MILLION The Forest Oil Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Atcor Resources Ltd., a Canadian oil and gas exploration and production company, for $186 million (Canadian), or about $135 million (United States). Atcor, based in Calgary, Alberta, owns properties concentrated in Alberta and British Columbia. The company is also engaged in gas processing and marketing in Canada and has an interest in undeveloped land. The offer is valued at $4.88 (Canadian) a share. Atcor's class A shares closed at $4.55 yesterday, up 45 cents, on the Toronto Stock Exchange. To help pay for the acquisition, Denver-based Forest Oil plans to sell 60 million shares to the public. About 5.3 million shares will be sold by Saxon Petroleum Inc., a Forest Oil shareholder.   (Dow Jones) **********BRISTOL-MYERS TO ACQUIRE HUNGARIAN DRUG MAKER The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company agreed yesterday to buy Pharmavit Gyogyszer, a  Hungarian drug maker and provider of health care products, for $110 million in cash. Bristol-Myers, the New York-based pharmaceutical company, said it would offer $62.35 for each Pharmavit share and $12.47 for each global depository share, which represents one-fifth of a share. The transaction requires regulatory approval. Bristol-Myers said Pharmavit's products are sold primarily  in Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Poland and Romania.   (Bloomberg Business News) **********FEDERAL-MOGUL TO CLOSE OPERATIONS AND TAKE CHARGE The Federal-Mogul Corporation said yesterday that it would sell or close some operations and take a fourth-quarter charge of $52 million. The company, based in Southfield, Mich., also said it would post a fourth-quarter gain of $10 million from the sale of its minority stake in Westwind Air Bearings Ltd., making the net effect of the charge $42 million, or 99 cents a share. The company said it planned to sell its United States ball bearing manufacturer and  its German BHW bearing division. It will also close its St. Louis research center, resulting in some job cuts. The company's shares were up 25 cents yesterday, closing at $20.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.   (Bloomberg Business News) **********SBARRO TO SHUT ABOUT 40 RESTAURANTS BY MARCH 31 Sbarro Inc., a restaurant chain offering pizza and Italian foods, said yesterday that it planned to close about 40 of its underperforming restaurants by March 31 and to take a pretax charge of about $16 million. The charge will reduce the company's net income by about $10 million, or 50 cents a share, for the fourth quarter, ending on Dec. 31. The moves by Sbarro, based in Commack, L.I., were announced after the close of trading yesterday. The company's shares fell 50 cents, to $22.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.   (Bloomberg Business News) **********SNACK FOOD COMPANY LANCE INC. TO TRIM 507 JOBS Lance Inc., a snack food company in Charlotte, N.C., said yesterday that it would cut 507 jobs, or 9 percent of its work force, as it closes a plant in Columbia, S.C., and trims operations in Greenville, Tex. The company will take a $40 million charge for the moves, resulting in a loss for the fourth quarter, ending on Dec. 30, and probably a small loss for the year. Lance said it would lay off 213 employees at its Columbia Vista Bakery plant and 294 in Greenville in 60 days.   (Reuters) **********CITATION SHARES DROP 22% ON EARNINGS ESTIMATE Shares of the Citation Corporation fell 22 percent yesterday after the company said that based on preliminary information, it would not meet analysts' earnings expectations for the quarter ending on Dec. 31. According to First Call Inc., Citation, which is based in Birmingham, Ala., was expected to earn 28 cents a share in the first quarter. The company, a maker of iron, steel and aluminum casting, did not disclose a reason for the expected weak results. In last year's first quarter, Citation earned $3.1 million, or 24 cents a share, on sales of $59.3 million. Citation shares fell $3.25, to $11.50, in Nasdaq trading.   (Dow  Jones) **********PCS WIRELESS AND ADC TELECOMMUNICATIONS IN ALLIANCE PCS Wireless Inc. signed a letter of intent yesterday to form a strategic alliance with ADC Telecommunications Inc. Under the alliance, ADC Telecommunications agreed to subscribe for five million PCS Wireless common shares, representing 15.1 percent of the issued stock. PCS Wireless, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, also said an ADC Telecommunications appointee would join its board. The companies will also establish a joint venture to be owned 50 percent by each company. PCS Wireless said the new venture would be capitalized  at $5 million in cash and cash equivalents. ADC Telecommunications, of Minneapolis, is a supplier of transmission and networking systems used to deliver voice, data and video services.   (Dow Jones) **********J. P. MORGAN & CO., New York, raised its dividend 8 percent and said it planned  to buy back as many as seven million shares, or about 3.5 percent of its outstanding stock. **********COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INTERNATIONAL INC., Islandia, L.I., said its newly acquired  Legent unit had sold its information technology division to a management-led group in a transaction valued at more than $20 million. **********BIRMINGHAM STEEL CORP., Birmingham, Ala., which produces steel reinforcing bar and merchant products, acquired Richmond Steel Recycling Ltd. of Vancouver, British Columbia, from a unit of Ipsco Inc. for an undisclosed price. **********AIR PRODUCTS AND CHEMICAL INC., Allentown, Pa., an industrial concern, will invest more than $20 million in a new air separation plant near Decatur, Ala., which will supply gaseous oxygen, argon and compressed dry air to Trico Steel, a joint venture of LTV Corp. and British Steel P.L.C..

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/17/world.main_headline: Bosnian Talks Snag on Fate Of Two Serbs
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/17/world.print_headline: Bosnian Talks Snag on Fate Of Two Serbs
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/17/world.body_text: **********With peace talks in Dayton, Ohio, at a crucial stage, the Bosnian Government  and Serbia are wrangling over the fate of the two Bosnian Serb leaders indicted  by the international war crimes tribunal, senior officials familiar with the talks said today. **********The matter took on new urgency with an announcement today from the tribunal's headquarters in The Hague of new indictments against the two, Radovan Karadzic,  the political leader, and Gen. Ratko Mladic, the military leader, charging them  with genocide in the days after the Serbs invaded the Muslim enclave of Srebrenica in July. The indictment details numerous instances in which Muslim captives, in small and large numbers, were summarily shot. **********Thousands of men executed and buried in mass graves, hundreds of men buried alive, men and women mutilated and slaughtered, children killed before their mothers' eyes, a grandfather forced to eat the liver of his own grandson," a judge for the tribunal wrote, citing prosecutorial evidence that led to the indictments. **********The indictment charged that the attack was authorized by Dr. Karadzic and carried out by forces under the command of General Mladic, who was seen at several sites of systematic mass killings. **********The two men have already been indicted for genocide and crimes against humanity in connection with the killing, shelling and deportation of Bosnian civilians. **********The prosecutor for the tribunal met with Administration officials in Washington today, pleading that they make the surrender of indicted suspects a condition of any accord. **********At the peace talks, President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, who is negotiating on behalf of the Bosnian Serbs, has refused to turn in the indicted  men, saying that while he would like the men out of the politicalpicture, they should be allowed to leave office eventually through the electoral process, an official connected to the talks said today. **********An official close to Mr. Milosevic said the Serbian President believes that such a gesture warrants removing all economic and diplomatic sanctions against his country in the event of a peace agreement. **********But the Bosnian Government today demanded in writing that the peace agreement require that the signers commit themselves to "arrest, detain and transfer" indicted individuals to the tribunal's custody, people close to its delegation said. **********The Bosnians have also asked that the final peace agreement include a threat  that any parties that do not cooperate would be subject to mandated United Nations sanctions. **********Alarmed by reports that the framework agreement might produce only a vague commitment from the parties to "cooperate" with the tribunal and might not force those indicted out of office immediately, the tribunal prosecutor, Judge Richard J. Goldstone, spent two days meeting with top officials from the White House, State Department, Pentagon and Central Intelligence Agency on that and other issues. **********But Judge Goldstone, a South African, acknowledged in interviews that he did  not receive a clear-cut assurance that the agreement would specifically require  warring parties to turn over indicted suspects. **********Judge Goldstone said he told Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and John Shattuck, the Assistant Secretary of State for human rights, in separate meetings today that any peace agreement that does not specifically require indicted war criminals to be turned over to the international court is unacceptable. **********"I asked specifically that the peace agreement require strict compliance with the war crimes tribunal, and I specifically asked that it include the surrender of those indicted," Mr. Goldstone said. "It would be unthinkable if it isn't. They said that is entirely in accordance with U.S. policy. But I got no firm commitment." **********If the peace agreement does not require Serbia to surrender Dr. Karadzic and  General Mladic, Mr. Goldstone said he feared that they could end up living as private citizens in a de facto safe haven in the Serbian capital of Belgrade. **********Referring to Richard C. Holbrooke, Mr. Goldstone said that he had the utmost  respect for the chief American negotiator, but that he would not embrace an agreement that traded justice for peace. **********"While I understand the attitude of Richard Holbrooke might be, 'Look here, I'm not going to forgo peace and endanger the lives of tens of thousands more people of the former Yugoslavia,' if that's the choice, I don't accept it," Mr.  Goldstone said. **********The judge also said he told American officials that some sanctions should be  retained against Serbia, specificially restrictions on membership and participation in international organizations and lending insitutions, until Mr.  Milosevic surrenders the Bosnian Serb leaders he controls. **********But it is not at all certain that the so-called outer wall of sanctions will  remain if the Serbs make peace, and the American position is unclear. **********At the State Department briefing on Wednesday, a spokesman, Nicholas Burns said such sanctions will "perhaps be extended beyond the implementation of a peace agreement," adding that although the United States believed it was important to keep sanctions, there might not be universal support to do so. **********During today's briefing, Mr. Burns took a tougher line, saying, "The United States will support the maintenance of this so-called outer wall of the sanctions until we are fully satisfied that Serbia is cooperating with the war crimes tribunal on the indictments that have been handed down." **********The use of sanctions as a tool of the tribunal has become more important because of the decision by President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia earlier this week to promote a military officer indicted for war crimes. **********American negotiators and representatives of the four other countries involved in the peace talks -- France, Germany, Britain and Russia -- protested to Mr. Tudjman on Wednesday about the promotion of Gen. Tihomir Blaskic to a senior position in the Croat Army. **********The Croatian President replied that he would cooperate with the tribunal but  did not offer to rescind the promotion, Mr. Burns said today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/01/world.main_headline: 3 Violent Incidents Raise Tension in West Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/01/world.print_headline: 3 Violent Incidents Raise Tension in West Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/01/world.body_text: **********Tensions rippled through the West Bank today after two Israeli soldiers were  taken hostage in one town, troops clashed with stone-throwing Palestinians in another, and two other soldiers were wounded in an ambush. **********The Israeli commander in the West Bank, Maj. Gen. Gabi Ofir, announced that Israel was freezing its staged withdrawal from West Bank cities pending a meeting with the commander of Palestinian forces in the West Bank, Ismail Jaber. But both Israeli and Palestinian officials insisted that the pullout would continue. **********The first incident began late Wednesday when Israeli soldiers tried to arrest a Palestinian in the village of Qabatiya, south of Jenin, a Palestinian city in the north of the West Bank that was turned over to Palestinian control this month. Qabatiya is in a Palestinian self-rule zone where Israel has overall responsibility for security. **********The man, Samir Zakarneh, was among several hundred prisoners freed by Israel  under the Palestinian-Israeli agreement signed in September, and the Israelis reportedly tried to arrest him because he was restricted to Jericho, which is also under Palestinian control. **********But Mr. Zakarneh, who was said to have been armed, took refuge in a cafe in Qabatiya, where residents surrounded him and refused to let the Israelis approach. As tensions rose there, members of a militant Palestinian organization known as the Black Panthers kidnapped two members of the Israeli paramilitary border police in Jenin. The Black Panthers are a wing of Fatah, the main group in the Palestine Liberation Organization. After negotiations through the night between Israeli and Palestinian officials, the two Israelis were released, and Mr. Zakarneh was allowed to surrender to the Palestinian authorities, who said they would take him back to Jericho. The Palestinian officials also said they had arrested the Black Panthers responsible for the kidnapping. The Israelis sealed off Jenin. **********Later in the evening, a military patrol accompanying a bus carrying Israeli settlers west of Jenin was fired on, and the Israeli radio said two Israeli soldiers had been slightly wounded. **********In Nablus, a Palestinian city 20 miles south of Jenin that is still under Israeli control, Palestinian demonstrators went into the streets in commemoration of the sixth anniversary of the killing of four Black Panther leaders by the Israelis, pelting Israeli patrols with stones. **********The Israelis opened fire in response, and 18 Palestinians were reported wounded, two seriously. The clashes lasted four hours. **********The clashes in Jenin and Nablus are certain to be used by critics of the peace agreements as evidence of the dangers to security posed by the Israeli withdrawals. Israeli forces were also active in southern Lebanon, with aircraft  attacking suspected guerrilla targets with rockets for the third day in a row in retaliation for rockets fired into northern Israel by guerrillas of the Party of God.  There were no immediate reports of casualties or damage.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/06/busin.main_headline: Wallachs's Parent Files For Chapter 11 Protection
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/06/busin.print_headline: Wallachs's Parent Files For Chapter 11 Protection
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/06/busin.body_text: **********Wallachs clothing stores, a New York institution for more than 100 years, is  conducting a "going out of business" sale at its 12 stores in New York, New Jersey and New Hampshire. Also joining in the sale are Roots, F. R. Tripler and  other retail stores that, with Wallachs, make up the 19-state chain of 50 stores owned and operated by the Hastings Group. **********As recently as three years ago, before demand plummeted for the tailored suits and other clothing in which it specialized, the group owned almost 200 stores. **********According to the Chapter 11 filing by Hastings, the company intends to liquidate the business or sell its "small core" of profitable locations. The papers were filed Oct. 23 in the United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., where the Hastings Group is incorporated. **********Either way, it could spell the end for most of the group's stores -- including the venerable Wallachs chain, which in the mid-1970's offered classes  in how to tie a scarf, and which at one time invited customers and passers-by alike to stop in and have loose buttons sewn on or missing buttons replaced at no cost. **********With annual sales of about $100 million, the Hastings Group -- including Hastings (USA) Inc. and West Belt Distributors -- estimated its assets at the time of the filing at approximately $34.6 million and liabilities at about $38.3 million. The liquidation sales, which include store equipment, fixtures and furniture, are intended to stem what Hastings described as "losses that are occurring on a daily basis." **********In recent weeks, vendors have stopped shipments of merchandise. But a hint of the group's financial difficulties appeared this spring when Wallachs, which carries men's suits priced at about $375 to more than $1,000, closed its 20,000-square-foot store in lower Manhattan and opened a 9,000-square-foot store four blocks away, at 52 Broadway, at Exchange Place. The other Wallachs store in Manhattan is at 555 Fifth Avenue, at 46th Street. **********Specialty apparel stores have struggled for most of this decade, except for that relative handful of stores frequented by the carriage trade. Most of the suffering was caused by America's trend toward more casual attire, particularly  in the workplace, by widespread layoffs among white-collar workers, and by customers who were skittish about the economy and switched to department stores  or discount stores. Even when the economy improved, many former customers did not return to the specialty stores. **********The Hastings Group, based in Chicago, acquired the stores in August 1994 from the HSSA investment group, which had been operating under Chapter 11 proceedings for nine months. After HSSA had bought the stores in October 1992 from the Hartmarx Corporation for a $43 million note due in two years, it closed about 100 of the 187 stores by year's end. These included the Raleighs stores in the Washington area, Hanny's in Phoenix, Arthur Frank in Salt Lake City, Peer Gordon in Cleveland and Kleinhans in Buffalo. **********But those measures were not enough. Hastings said that before its purchase the business had suffered several years of contraction and a deeper erosion of its customer base than Hastings had anticipated. **********Representatives of Hastings could not be reached for comment on closings or layoffs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/26/busin.main_headline: Claiming Fraud, Florida Seeks to Bar E.D.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/26/busin.print_headline: Claiming Fraud, Florida Seeks to Bar E.D.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/26/busin.body_text: **********Florida's top law-enforcement official filed suit today against the Electronic Data Services Corporation, the computer services unit of the General  Motors Corporation, saying it had defrauded the state by selling a troublesome system to track welfare payments. **********The state seeks $60 million in damages and an order that prevents E.D.S. from doing business in Florida. The company also runs computers for Florida's lottery system and serves hundreds of other customers in the state. **********The state and company have battled over a computer system designed in 1991 to handle welfare payments. The system repeatedly broke down, causing long lines at welfare offices and often paying too much in benefits. **********The company sued Florida in 1992 after the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services stopped making payments on the system. **********William Webster, a former director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency, has overseen the dispute as a special master during the last year. He recommended in August that the state pay E.D.S. $50 million to end the legal wrangling. **********Mr. Webster said the system, which has cost about $240 million, worked adequately when the state took it over. But he also found that E.D.S. failed to  disclose information about the computer system's ability to handle millions of welfare payments. **********E.D.S., based in Plano, Tex., is the nation's largest provider of computer services, and had more than $10 billion in revenue last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/06/busin.main_headline: Rykoff-Sexton Announces Accord to Purchase US Foodservice
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/06/busin.print_headline: Rykoff-Sexton Announces Accord to Purchase US Foodservice
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/06/busin.body_text: **********Rykoff-Sexton Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy US Foodservice Inc. for at least $270.5 million in another sign of the rapid consolidation in the food industry. **********Rykoff-Sexton, a food distributor based in Lisle, Ill., said it would pay $25 a share in stock, or $220 million, for each of US Foodservice's 8.8 million shares outstanding. The company will also pay about $50.5 million to redeem US Foodservice preferred stock. In addition, Rykoff-Sexton will assume or refinance about $350 million of debt. **********Rykoff-Sexton would issue 11 million to 12.9 million new shares to make the  acquisition. It now has 14.8 million shares outstanding. **********The announced acquisition follows a number of recent deals in food distribution. Last week, the Sara Lee Corporation offered to sell its food distribution business to JP Foodservice Inc. in exchange for JP stock, a combination that would make JP the third-largest food distributor to restaurants and hotels. And last month, Rykoff-Sexton said it had completed its acquisition  of H & O Foods for an undisclosed amount. **********But some analysts said they were concerned that Rykoff's latest acquisition might be too much. **********Moody's Investor Service said it had placed its Ba3 rating on Rykoff-Sexton's senior subordinated notes on review for a possible lower rating. **********A definitive agreement between Rykoff-Sexton and US Foodservice is subject to further negotiation, refinancing commitments, and board, shareholder and regulatory approvals. Rykoff-Sexton said it was still negotiating how to handle  outstanding options to acquire about one million US Foodservice shares. **********US Foodservice, based in Wilkes- Barre, Pa., is a closely held food distributor, with 1994 sales of about $1.5 billion. **********Rykoff-Sexton, with 1995 sales of $1.6 billion, distributes and manufactures  foods and related products nationwide for restaurants and other locations where  food is prepared away from home. The company is also one of the nation's largest providers of equipment, services and contract design to restaurants.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/05/busin.main_headline: Market Place;Last Big Wall St. Bear Defects to Optimists
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/05/busin.print_headline: Market Place;Last Big Wall St. Bear Defects to Optimists
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/05/busin.body_text: **********The last of Wall Street's prominent bears has turned cautiously bullish, concluding that "a fundamental shift" in the way investors evaluate shares probably means that stock prices will be far higher than he had thought possible. **********"The powerful 1995 stock rally is not a bubble, but rather a signal that the  valuation paradigm has changed for the third time in 40 years," wrote David Shulman, chief equity strategist for Salomon Brothers, in a report released yesterday. **********Mr. Shulman also turned more bullish on bonds, and his move was cited as helping both the stock and bond markets, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 52.39 points to 5,139.52, its 66th record this year. [Page D12.] The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.02 percent, trading intraday below 6 percent, the first time in more than two years. [Page D20.] **********A year ago, when there were more bulls than bears among strategists at big Wall Street firms, Mr. Shulman was still not alone in his bearishness. But the others have since changed their opinions or lost their jobs, and he was the last of the holdouts. For a brokerage-house official, whose opinions are cited by brokers trying to make sales, it is painful to be both bearish and wrong because the brokers want to make trades. **********It is an old Wall Street adage that prices peak when the last bear gives up,  and then decline. Asked if he was concerned that he might be that last bear, and that the market was therefore likely to fall with him being cited as a determining factor, Mr. Shulman allowed that he had considered this. And he indicated in the title of his new report, "1996: Stock Market Bubble or Paradigm Shift?" that the alternate explanation for the market's rise remained what he formerly believed -- that it was in a bubble that would eventually burst. **********Even in turning bullish, Mr. Shulman remained more cautious than many of his  rivals, saying that his new valuation method created a fair-value range for the  Standard & Poor's 500 index of about 550 to 585. That is far above the range of  400-430 that he had been using, based on his old valuation methodology, but it is far below current levels. Yesterday, the index rose 6.70 points to close at 613.68, or 5 percent above the high end of the new range. **********Mr. Shulman forecast, though, that over the next year the index would trade between 540 and 640, and he recommended that balanced accounts raise their stock allocations from to 50 percent from 45 percent, with the bond allocation going to 35 percent from 30 percent. The cash allocation was slashed to 15 percent from 25 percent. **********At current prices, he said in an interview, "I couldn't jump in with both feet, so I jumped in with one foot." **********Mr. Shulman said that this year's leap in stock prices -- the Dow industrials up 34 percent -- was evidence that investors were no longer worried about inflation, and were therefore willing to pay more for a dollar of future earnings. **********"Inflation has been much more subdued than we ever expected, and profits have been much stronger, given the sluggishness of the economy," he wrote. "Thus we are beginning to allow for the possibility that the valuation clocks we are using have been broken." **********He said the market's movement was reminiscent of 1958, when share prices surged as fears of an inevitable postwar depression were finally vanquished and  the dividend yield on stocks permanently fell below the yields on corporate bonds. **********And he recalled that in 1962, Benjamin Graham and David Dodd, two legendary market analysts known for their conservative approach, sharply raised their estimates of fair value for the Dow, citing investor confidence that the Government would hold off any depression. **********The next great shift in investor perceptions, Mr. Shulman wrote, came in 1974, when the reality of inflation depressed investors' views of proper valuations. "Instead of depression, the new trauma for investors became inflation," he said, arguing that now that trauma had been vanquished. **********Mr. Shulman, far more than most analysts, has focused on dividends since he turned more negative on stocks at the end of August 1994, when the Dow was at 3,913 and the S.& P. 500, at 475. "I was right for three months," he said yesterday, but then prices took off. **********The dividend yield on the S.& P. 500 -- the return you'd get from dividends if you bought all 500 issues -- had never before fallen below 2.65 percent without dire consequences. Now it is down to 2.3 percent. **********"I paid a lot of attention to dividends and it has been leading me astray," Mr. Shulman said, adding that his revised methodology placed far more emphasis on interest rates, whose plunge this year has buoyed stock prices. **********As recently as September, Mr. Shulman had stuck to his bearish view, citing six factors that he said had been associated with market tops and were again present. They included a new wave of mergers and acquisitions, corporate executives as cultural heroes, money managers as cultural heroes, glorification  of equities in the mass media, academic articles that emphasize the long-run infallibility of equity investing, and a belief in the ability of new technologies to permanently change society. **********But now, while conceding all those things seemed to still be present, he has  concluded that he was probably wrong. Whereas he had been looking for a relatively strong economy, he now thinks that the greater risk is a weaker economy -- an outcome that he thinks would lower interest rates and lead to higher price-to-earnings ratios for many companies. **********His stock recommendations are concentrated in consumer cyclical companies, while avoiding most issues in basic industries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/12/busin.body_text: **********Sizzler International announced today that it was reducing its administrative staff by 30 percent, or 72 workers, in a revamping intended to save $5 million a year. The low-price restaurant chain, which grew rapidly for decades, has suffered in the 1990's, in part because of weakness in the California economy and locations too close together. The company operates or licenses 592 Sizzler restaurants worldwide; 91 Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurants and one Italian Oven restaurant in Australia, and seven Buffalo Ranch restaurants in the United  States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/05/world.main_headline: Johannesburg Journal;Sitcom's Ticklish Idea: Will South Africa Laugh?
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/05/world.print_headline: Johannesburg Journal;Sitcom's Ticklish Idea: Will South Africa Laugh?
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/05/world.body_text: **********Billy and Kobie Dwyer, an Afrikaner couple, are in a panic. Ike Maloi, their  most valued black employee, has just demanded a 20 percent stake in their furniture business. **********No one in the Dwyer family has the nerve to tell Grandpa, an uninhibited racist. (Even when Grandpa thinks all Ike wants is a raise, his response is "Shoot him.") **********This is the setting of South Africa's newest sitcom, "Suburban Bliss." **********By Episode Two, Ike is a partner and he and the Dwyers both buy new houses, each family lying about the fancy neighborhood it has moved to. To their horror, they turn out to be next-door neighbors. The plots, naturally, thicken. **********There are signs of change -- big and small -- all over South Africa, and "Suburban Bliss" is certainly one of them. After more than 40 years of having race divide them, record numbers of South Africans have been tuning in to have their racism pilloried -- no barb withheld, no stereotype unexplored -- as the Dwyers and the Malois have at each other. **********The show would have been unthinkable only a few years ago. But during its first week on the air, in October, it won the top slot in South Africa's equivalent of the Nielsen ratings. Since then it has hovered at No. 2. Whether it is truly funny or simply vulgar has been the subject of talk shows and the mainstay of cocktail parties lately as South Africans debate whether they are ready to laugh at themselves, a characteristic that has hardly been in evidence  until now. **********"The show is extremely valuable, extremely necessary for us and a definite ground-breaker," said Barry Ronge, culture editor of The Star, the largest newspaper in Johannesburg. "Finally we have a show that looks at race relations  in a South African context -- a reflection of our own reality, not an American one." **********Indeed, the dreams and strains of the new South Africa, which held its first  free elections only 19 months ago, are there in every twist and turn. In one episode, the two wives, ever competing, decide they must have maids. Ike's wife, Thando, the epitome of South Africa's new upwardly mobile blacks, revels in the  sound of being called "Madam." Next door, Kobie, busy trying to prove she is not a racist, finds herself cooking breakfast of bacon and eggs for the maid and giving her a shorter and shorter workday. **********But the most vicious exchanges are between the older generation. In one scene, the grandfather of the Dwyer family introduces himself over the garden fence, assuming the elderly black women he sees is the maid in the household next door. He demands that she address him as "baas," the Afrikaans equivalent of "master." The woman, actually Ike's mother, doesn't bother to correct him. Instead, she brags about her huge salary, leaving the old man totally intimidated about keeping up in the new neighborhood. **********The creators of the show say they hope it will be as provocative and influential as "All in the Family" was for Americans in the 1970's. The principal writer is an American, Craig Gardner, who has lived in South Africa for 16 years and is married to an Afrikaner. Mr. Gardner, a former actor, has never written a sitcom before. **********"My aim is to make South Africa stand back and laugh at how ludicrous they have been, and hopefully by doing this help dilute some of the racism," Mr. Gardner said. "I think that is what Archie Bunker did. I would be delighted if we accomplish anything like that." **********The show does not have any of the polish of American sitcoms. But then South  African television does not remotely resemble television in the United States. It did not even exist until 1976, as it was considered to be a dangerous and corrupting influence. And it has always been in the control of the Government. Changes are on the horizon, but right now most households get only three channels. The most successful shows tend to be American imports. **********The creator of "Suburban Bliss," Gray Hofmeyr, says he came up with the idea  when TV1, the channel that catered to whites under apartheid, asked him to create a show that would attract black viewers. The current hit is actually a remake of a show that he tried to create in 1986, but that failed miserably back then. **********Before going ahead, TV1 did some testing to see whether South Africans were indeed ready. The surveys indicated that most black South Africans and those of  English origin loved the idea. Afrikaners did not. But Afrikaners are a small minority and could be ignored, said Paul Kemp, who heads the English drama department for the TV1. So "Suburban Bliss" is shown only in English, without dubbing or subtitles for other languages. The station has ordered 104 episodes,  the largest advance order in its history, Mr. Kemp said. **********"The wounds were too raw a few years ago," Mr. Hofmeyr said. "Now, I think, people are ready for this. "

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/12/busin.main_headline: Blue-Chip Stocks Climb, With Dow Up by 27.46
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/12/busin.print_headline: Blue-Chip Stocks Climb, With Dow Up by 27.46
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/12/busin.body_text: **********Blue-chip stocks ended higher yesterday, bolstered by a strong rally in oil stocks. **********The Dow Jones industrial average rose 27.46 points, to 5,184.32, recovering part of the ground lost in the two days since closing at a record 5,199.13 on Dec. 6. The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 2.04 points, to 619.52, just short of its Dec. 6 record of 620.18. But the Nasdaq composite index fell 0.91 point, to 1,061.50. **********Shares of oil companies rose after frigid temperatures in the Midwest and Northeast briefly sent the price of oil past $19 a barrel to a six-month high. The crude oil price later retreated to $18.66 a barrel. The weather, coupled with the companies' above-average dividends, led investors to bet oil stocks may outpace the rest of the stock market this winter. **********The rally sent the Standard & Poor's International Oil Index up 13.34, or 2.5 percent, to a record 529.91. During the last six months, the index gained 12.6 percent, lagging behind the 16.7 percent gain of the S.& P. 500. **********"Step outside -- there's probably some decent demand for heating oil," said Dirk van Dijk, equity strategist at Dean Investment Associates of Dayton, Ohio,  which oversees about $3.7 billion. **********Among oil issues that reached records, Exxon rose 2 3/8, to a record 84 1/8;  Chevron surged 19/16 , to an all-time high of 52 3/4; Amoco rose 2 1/2, to a record 71 1/4; Texaco Inc. gained 3/4, to a record 79 1/8 and Mobil rose 3 1/8,  to a record 113 5/8. **********The gain in oil stocks was partly offset by losses in paper issues. Paper stocks fell amid concern that increased production to take advantage of high prices will eventually flood the market with too much product and cause prices to fall. **********International Paper fell 1/2, to 36 1/2; Bowater Inc. fell 1, to 35 1/4; Georgia-Pacific lost 2 1/4, to 71; Champion International shed 1 5/8, to 42 7/8, and Louisiana-Pacific dropped 5/8, to 24 7/8. **********Banking issues fell amid concern interest rates may not decline soon. When rates fall, banks can borrow money for less and keep more of the money they take in from loans. **********Citicorp fell 21/16 to 67 3/4; Norwest fell 7/8, to 33 1/8; Nationsbank dropped 5/8, to 73; Fleet Financial Group fell 5/8, to 41 1/4, and Bank of Boston gave up 7/8, to 46 5/8. **********Maybelline surged 5 1/4, to 36 1/4. https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/06/world.main_headline: The Press Be Hanged! Britain's Judges Prefer Order in the Court
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/06/world.print_headline: The Press Be Hanged! Britain's Judges Prefer Order in the Court
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/06/world.body_text: **********In a move that contrasts markedly with the way the court handled the news media in the O. J. Simpson trial, a judge here has thrown out an assault case and threatened editors of eight newspapers with contempt charges because of pretrial publicity. **********Judge Roger Sanders called newspaper coverage "unfair, outrageous and oppressive" in throwing out the case on Wednesday and said it had damaged the rights of the defendant, Geoffrey Knights, to a fair trial. Mr. Knights, a businessman who is often the subject of tabloid newspaper articles, was facing assault charges from an altercation with the driver of a cab carrying a soap opera star he has been dating for seven years. **********The collapse of the case at the pretrial-hearing stage shows how differently Britain grapples with the complicated free-press, fair-trial issue. Here, newspapers and broadcasters operate under strict rules that prohibit publishing  or offering details on the air that could influence a jury. Those who flout the  rules can receive fines that usually run to the tens of thousand of pounds. **********Juries are rarely sequestered to keep them away from news reports. Instead, the reports themselves are usually bare bones and contain none of the lurid details familiar to readers of American trial coverage -- although the tabloids  are known to engage in excesses in the course of the coverage of other events. **********Cameras are not permitted in British courtrooms, although one was allowed several months ago inside a courtroom in Scotland as an experiment. It was not widely seen as a success, and the fallout from the Simpson case now makes it doubly unlikely that the idea will spread. The Simpson case is widely seen here  as one in which justice went haywire, in part because of frenzied coverage. Still, broadcasts of the trial drew large audiences. **********As an example, a sensational trial opened on Tuesday in Winchester, that of Rosemary West. She is accused of joining her husband, who has since committed suicide, in murdering ten young women and girls, including her own daughter. **********The jurors were sent home on Tuesday with an admonition not to read or listen to news reports about the case, and in any case legal restrictions prevent the news media from reporting what goes on in the courtroom in the jurors' absence.  Until the trial is finished, lawyers are not allowed to comment publicly. **********Restrictions on trial coverage were tightened by a new law in 1981, the Contempt of Court Act. Essentially it said that in bringing a case against editors or owners of news organizations, the Attorney General did not have to prove that they intended to create a substantial risk of serious prejudice to a  trial, merely that they did create it. **********"I think that in both the United States and Britain the balance between free  speech and other public interest needs to be adjusted," said Lord Lester, who often argues before the European Court of Human Rights. "In the U.S. it's slanted too much in favor of free speech against fair trial. In this country it's traditionally been too much in favor of fair trial and against free speech." **********The tabloids' fascination with Mr. Knights stems in part from his stormy relationship with Gillian Taylforth, who is a star in the soap opera "Eastenders." Last year they lost a libel action against a tabloid that said they had performed a sex act in a parked car. **********Today Attorney General Nicholas Lyell said he was examining the case against  the eight newspapers, which printed headlines such as "Knights Beats Me to a Pulp." He said he would contact the editors to hear their side and then decide whether or not to bring contempt charges.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/12/busin.body_text: **********The Nationsbank Corporation has agreed to spend $30 million to settle class-action lawsuits from more than 18,000 customers who contended that they had been misled about the risks of buying two Nationsbank bond funds and lost $40 million to $50 million. **********The settlement covers the Nations Government Income term trusts 2003 and 2004. The funds invest in government bonds and derivatives, which are risky contracts whose value derives from the price of an underlying security. **********If approved by the courts, the settlement will resolve the class-action lawsuit filed in January by Ivy and Synclara Shipp, an elderly couple in Austin, Tex. Their lawyer, Jeff Ross, said Nationsbank employees had persuaded the Shipps that investing in the fund was as safe as putting their money in a certificate of deposit. But the funds were a "witches brew of derivatives," Mr.  Ross said. **********"While we vigorously deny the allegations against us, we wanted to end this matter in a way that would benefit our customers," Pat Phillips, Nationsbank's president of financial products, said on Friday. **********Nationsbank will compensate investors two ways. It will create a $5 million pool to pay the approximately 2,500 individuals who sold their investments at a  loss. It will also spend $25 million on government bonds to raise the funds' value for the investors who have not sold.  Lawyers will get up to $6 million. **********The settlement will also resolve a Florida class-action suit by Carl Mullen,  another elderly customer who invested in the funds. The bank still faces similar customer lawsuits involving other funds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/01/busin.body_text: **********Silicon Graphics Inc. and Dreamworks, the new entertainment company formed by Steven Spielberg, Jeffrey Katzenberg and David Geffen, said today that they would jointly develop a system for computer animation. **********The companies said that together they expected to provide about $50 million in financing to cover development costs and related hardware and software. **********The alliance would solidify Silicon Graphics' position as technological leader in special effects for the movie industry. Its powerful computer work stations were used to create the herds of genetically engineered dinosaurs in "Jurassic Park" and more recently the ghostly image of "Casper." For Dreamworks, the deal is a way to gain early access to advanced tools for digital animation. **********"This alliance was almost inevitable in the formation of Dreamworks," Mr. Spielberg said in a telephone interview. "I had such a wonderful, and revolutionary, experience working with Silicon Graphics on 'Jurassic Park,' " he said. "It's like 'Field of Dreams' in reverse: If I ask for it, they will build  it." **********The deal would include the creation of a computer animation production system to be named DAD, for digital animation dream machine, which would be produced by Silicon Graphics in alliance with Cambridge Animation Systems Ltd., an animation software company based in Cambridge, England. Silicon Graphics, based in Mountain View, Calif., said it would make these systems available to the entire  industry and ultimately expected to see a $1 billion market. **********The deal follows by two years a similar arrangement between Silicon Graphics  and Industrial Light and Magic, the special effects unit of Lucasfilm Ltd., to create a production plant for the creation of digital imagery in entertainment.  It also follows last month's announcement that Dreamworks and the Microsoft Corporation would form Dreamworks Interactive, a joint venture to create interactive multimedia. **********The founders of Dreamworks and the Silicon Graphics' executives said all three relationships were complementary, and that the hardware and software tools created would all work together. "Dreamworks will plug and play off the same data base," Thomas Jermoluk, president of Silicon Graphics, said. **********Although the first feature-length animated film from Dreamworks would not appear until 1998, Mr. Katzenberg said results of its collaboration with Silicon Graphics would be apparent in the studio's first or second film, to be released  next year. **********"Creatively, DAD will give us the tools to produce sophisticated optical effects, an unlimited color palette and the ability to take audiences into the picture for unique visual and dramatic entertainment experiences," Mr. Katzenberg said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/21/busin.body_text: **********Britain's economy slowed in the third quarter to its most sluggish growth pace in nearly three years, the Central Statistical Office said yesterday. The rise in gross domestic product was revised down to four-tenths of 1 percent for  the three months that ended on Sept. 30 from initial estimates of five-tenths of 1 percent.
