https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/26/busin.body_text: **********WHEN it comes to business ethics, few American corporations have a better image than the H.B. Fuller Company of St. Paul, a leading manufacturer of industrial glues, coatings and paints. Awards, honors and inclusion in various socially conscious mutual funds attest to its standing as a good corporate citizen. **********But that reputation is being clouded by the company's handling of a stubborn  image-staining problem: the illegal abuse of its shoemaker's glue by homeless Central American children, who have become addicted to the product's intoxicating but dangerous fumes. **********Some child welfare advocates, led by Covenant House in New York City, have demanded for years that the company add a noxious oil to its glue to discourage  abusers. The company has resisted that approach -- possibly because it might reduce the glue's effectiveness, possibly because the smell would be irritating  to legitimate users. Fuller will say only that it is doing all it reasonably can to prevent abuse. **********Now this simmering dispute may boil over into something more serious for the  company's image, and for its shareholders. Lawyers will decide by the end of the year whether to press ahead with a wrongful-death suit against Fuller on behalf  of the family of a Guatemalan teen-ager who died in 1993. The legal team is also weighing the expansion of that suit into a class action, said one of the lawyers, Scott Hendler of Austin, Tex. By some estimates, tens of thousands of Central American children sniff some sort of glue. **********Officers of Covenant House's Latin American subsidiary are "anxious that we go forward with this case," Mr. Hendler said, "because they are absolutely convinced that Fuller's glue was responsible for the boy's death and that Fuller has been negligent in dealing with this problem." **********William Belknap, a Fuller spokesman, would not respond to specific questions  but provided a one-page statement. "We are a law-abiding company with a long history of concern for product safety," it said. "We make and sell only legitimate products for legitimate purposes." The statement also listed briefly  the steps the company has taken in recent years "to reduce the likelihood" of its glue being abused, including substituting a slightly less toxic formulation  and curbs on retail sales in Honduras and Guatemala. **********The Fuller experience provides a textbook example of the thorny moral equations that lie beyond the simple arithmetic of the bottom line. But few agree on what lessons it offers: Does it teach that those who pursue the "good citizen" label too aggressively leave themselves vulnerable to attack? Or does it simply underscore how important it is for a corporate citizen to live up to its self-created image? **********And Fuller does repeatedly present itself as a good citizen. Year after year  it sprinkles its annual reports with statements proclaiming that it has a commendable corporate conscience. In 1992, for instance, its "mission statement" said the company "will conduct business legally and ethically, support the activities of its employees in their communities and be a responsible corporate  citizen." In material sent to shareholders, it chose as one benchmark for its overall performance an index of socially responsible companies, thus underscoring that that is a peer group it considers important. And it has endowed a chair in business ethics at the University of Minnesota. **********Fuller, of course, is not the only company to be accused of not living up to  its own good-citizen image. In September 1994, the Body Shop International P.L.C., the cosmetics retailer whose advertisements stress a commitment to natural products, high environmental standards and philanthropy, was accused of  exaggerating its adherence to those principles. And the founders of Ben and Jerry's Homemade Inc. have been tweaked frequently for preaching corporate democracy while practicing a more autocratic management style. **********Nor is glue-sniffing a new issue for the makers of solvent-based adhesives. The Testor Corporation added a noxious ingredient to discourage abuse of its hobby glue in July 1969. And Henkel, a German chemical company that competes with Fuller, stopped making certain toxic glues in Central America last year. **********But Fuller, which dominates the Central American market with its Resistol brand of glue, seems to have been singled out for more than its share of recent  criticism, one industry consultant said. For four years, protesters have demonstrated outside Fuller's annual meetings, often in Minnesota's cold and rain. And some have bought Fuller shares and tried to get their complaints on the record at those meetings. **********"If they had a lesser reputation they would be less of a target," said William Broxterman, president of Chemquest Group, a consulting firm in Cincinnati. **********Timothy Smith, executive director of the Interfaith Center for Corporate Responsibility, which coordinates the work of 275 religious investors with about $50 billion in assets, agreed that a high profile in the corporate citizenship arena can invite attack. "But as I see it, the hazard is not in acting in a socially responsible way," he said. "The hazard is in over-marketing yourself as a saint." **********Whatever the lesson one draws, however, the Fuller case should be required reading for corporate directors, said Lawrence Bear, a New York University professor and co-author of the textbook "Free Markets, Finance, Ethics, and Law." As Professor Bear sees it, "the question of how directors ought to act in  circumstances like this is a terribly serious one, because when it gets out of hand, it gets into court." **********Even if Fuller loses the wrongful-death suit, it would be unlikely to affect, in any meaningful way, the bottom line of a company with more than $30 million in profits on $1 billion in revenues. But if it is expanded to a class action, the impact is more difficult to predict, since that step would make the case more difficult for the plaintiffs and more potentially damaging for the company. **********The litigation will also be an important test for Fuller's reputation not only at home but in Latin America. In 1994, fully 27 percent of its operating profits of $66 million came from Latin American operations. **********The company -- no relation to Fuller Brush -- has deep roots. Founded in 1887 by Harvey Benjamin Fuller as a one-man wallpaper-paste shop, it now has operations worldwide. Its glues -- in more than 10,000 varieties -- hold together everything from cars to cigarettes to disposable diapers. The company was run for years by Elmer L. Andersen, a former Minnesota Governor, whose son Anthony L. is now chairman. **********HOW did the Fuller dispute become so bitter? Most participants agree that the answer lies in the events of the summer of 1992, when Fuller's board adopted a resolution that seemed to be a victory for the company's critics. **********For years, the directors had been under pressure by a loose alliance of child advocacy groups concerned about the hazards of glue-sniffing among the homeless  children of Central America. Those young glue-sniffers are widely called "resistoleros" -- for Fuller's Resistol -- regardless of which brand they actually abuse. As that summer began, a national television news magazine was preparing to feature Fuller's product as part of the glue-sniffing problem. **********Then, on July 16, 1992, the board abruptly but unanimously voted to stop selling Resistol adhesives in Central America. As the company explained in its 1992 annual report: "Faced with the realizations that a suitable replacement product would not be available in the near future and that the illegitimate distribution was continuing, the Board of Directors decided that our Central American operations should stop selling those solvent-based Resistol adhesives that were commonly being abused by children." **********Local newspapers quoted Mr. Belknap as saying that until an alternative was found, "we simply don't believe it is the right decision to keep our solvent product on the market." **********Mary Swenson, a member of the informal Coalition on Resistoleros in St. Paul, said her group was "ecstatic." "We had a party," she recalled. "We had champagne." **********But jubilation soon turned to anger. By October 1992, the advocates had learned that Fuller had not stopped selling Resistol in Central America -- and did not intend to. It no longer sold the glue to retailers and small-scale users in Honduras and Guatemala, but it did sell large tubs and barrels of it to industrial customers in those countries, and to a broader list of commercial and industrial users in neighboring countries. **********According to the company's statement, it has since taken other steps to address the abuse. It has changed the product's formula, dropping the sweet-smelling but highly toxic solvent toluene and substituting the slightly less toxic chemical cyclohexane. It has tried to develop a water-based glue, which is not intoxicating. It has studied the issue "thoroughly and carefully" and has contributed to community programs for homeless children in Central America. **********But those who expected Resistol sales in Central America to stop in 1992 describe those steps as mere image-polishing. Bruce Harris, the director of Latin American programs for Covenant House, asserts that Resistol is still readily available to children in Nicaragua and El Salvador and, to a lesser degree, in Costa Rica. "If they are genuinely concerned about the children," he  asked, "why haven't they pulled out of all the countries -- as their board mandated?" **********Mr. Harris is not alone in wondering about the gap between the board resolution of 1992 and the company's subsequent action. Indeed, among experts in business ethics, that remains the biggest mystery. **********"They shot themselves in the foot," said Mr. Smith of the Interfaith Center for Corporate Responsibility, who nevertheless gives Fuller high marks for corporate conduct. The company has been praised for a high level of corporate philanthropy, including giving 5 percent of its profits to charity in each country where it operates. Moreover, the company has committed itself to safe environmental practices worldwide -- practices "often more stringent than local  government standards," Fuller said in an S.E.C. filing last year.    ALICE TEPPER MARLIN, executive director of the Council on Economic Priorities, a leading advocate for socially responsible corporate conduct, agreed that that the 1992 episode damaged Fuller's credibility. "If a company seems to go back on its commitments, they have sowed such distrust that it makes it very difficult to proceed," she said. "And that is the board's responsibility." **********Mr. Belknap, the Fuller spokesman, said none of the company's directors would comment about their handling of the issue, which he said has not been the subject of any other board resolution since the July 1992 action. "I'd have to say that the position statement I provided you with is consistent with the thinking of our board," he said. "I can't really go beyond that." **********Whatever happens with the threatened litigation, the dispute has certainly tarnished the company's once-pristine reputation as a good citizen. The attacks  are coming on several fronts, including accusations that its paints made and sold abroad exceed United States limits on lead and a quarrel over the company's role as a big supplier of glue to the tobacco industry. **********According to Mr. Harris and Ms. Swenson, paints purchased from hardware stores throughout Central America were tested in a St. Paul laboratory. The test results, which were provided to The New York Times, show high levels of lead in many, of the samples, including some but not all that are identified by  the group as being Fuller products. Even though selling such paint is legal in Central America, critics point out that high lead levels are a known hazard, especially to children. **********Asked about the group's accusation, Mr. Belknap said, "We have publicly stated at our annual meeting that all of our products are within the U.S. standards for lead in paint." He would not respond to questions about whether Fuller's Central American paints have always conformed with United States lead standards, and if not, when the formula was adjusted. **********Given this history of mutual mistrust and frustration, it is not surprising that the Fuller dispute ultimately wound up in lawyers' hands. On Jan. 3, 1995,  Mr. Hendler and a co-counsel, Michael Brickman of Charleston, S.C., filed their  wrongful-death claim against Fuller in state court in Dallas. **********The case was filed in Texas to stop the clock until Mr. Hendler could determine that the statute of limitations for such cases was three years in Minnesota, his preferred venue because he wants to take the case right to Fuller's home town. He then obtained court permission to withdraw the case in Texas, but must refile it in Minnesota before the first week in January. **********A class action against Fuller is "something that is under consideration," Mr. Hendler said, adding, "We are still evaluating certain factors, such as how much of their product was out there, how many children are affected, and the extent of the impairment caused in the children who use the glue chronically -- that's  the most significant factor." **********But, according to Mr. Smith of the Interfaith Center, Fuller's board may soon face another test in the treacherous world of corporate citizenship, regardless  of what Mr. Hendler decides about his lawsuit. "Fuller is a major seller of adhesives to the tobacco industry," Mr. Smith noted. "They are selling glues that go into a lethal product. That is another corporate-responsibility issue that Fuller's shareholders will be raising this coming year."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/world.main_headline: Judge Sets Date for Trial In Rabin Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/world.print_headline: Judge Sets Date for Trial In Rabin Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/world.body_text: **********A court in Tel Aviv today set Dec. 19 as a trial date for the confessed killer of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin as attention shifted to his possible line of defense. **********Arraigned this morning at the Tel Aviv District Court on charges of premeditated murder, the assassin, Yigal Amir, was represented by two lawyers who live in Jewish settlements in the West Bank. One of them said the defense would not use political arguments, but did not specify an alternative strategy. **********In previous court appearances Mr. Amir had appeared without legal counsel, saying he alone could best explain his motives for shooting Mr. Rabin on Nov. 4. **********He said he had acted to alert Israelis to the dangers of a handover of land to the Palestinians, a step he said had brought on deadly Arab attacks and would lead to war. **********"There's a command more important than 'Thou shalt not kill,' and that is saving a life," Mr. Amir, an Orthodox Jewish student, told a hearing on Nov. 6.  "When you kill in war it is also illegal, but the goal is lofty, so it is permitted. People are apathetic about the creation here of a Palestinian state with an army of terrorists." **********But one of Mr. Amir's lawyers, Mordechai Ofri from the settlement of Efrat, today ruled out a political defense of his client when the trial opens before a  tribunal of three judges. **********"If anyone thinks that my line as a lawyer in this case will be linked to a political direction, he is wrong," Mr. Ofri said. "I'm a lawyer, and I've made unequivocally clear that I'm not a public representative, I'm not a political mouthpiece." **********The second lawyer is Jonathan Goldberg, who immigrated from Houston to Israel seven years ago and now lives in the strictly religious settlement of Emmanuel. **********He has represented right-wing militants in the past, including a member of the outlawed group, Kahane Chai, or Kahane Lives, who was convicted in a grenade attack three years ago that killed an Arab in the Old City of Jerusalem. **********Neither lawyer has disclosed who is paying for their services, although press reports said money for Mr. Goldberg was coming from a legal defense fund set up  for Mr. Amir by supporters in the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/busin.body_text: **********Two executives of the Manhattan Bagel Company will resign following a report  published in The New York Times on Sunday that they face criminal indictments on charges of toxic-waste dumping by a company they own in Los Angeles, one of the  executives said. **********The two executives, Allan Boren and Eric Cano, who face 24 felony charges relating to their Chatsworth Plating Company, a Los Angeles metal-plating company, joined Manhattan Bagel as executives in June, when it acquired their 16-store bagel chain, I. & Joy Bagels. **********Late today, Mr. Boren, chairman of the I.& J. Bagels unit, said he and the unit's president, Eric Cano, had decided to resign. "It's in the best interests  of the company," he said. **********Vincent Sato, the prosecutor, said the case involved dumping "very high levels of cyanide into a flood control channel, in close proximity to a mobile home." The pair face maximum penalties of three years in prison and a $100,000 fine on each count. Lawyers for the executives contend the case is weak. **********Jack Grumet, Manhattan Bagel's chairman and chief executive, said the company was not aware of charges when it acquired the chain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/30/world.main_headline: Russians Begin to Gild the Communist Past
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/30/world.print_headline: Russians Begin to Gild the Communist Past
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/30/world.body_text: **********On New Year's Eve, Russia's largest television network is to broadcast a three-hour special intended to tap into the growing nostalgia for Soviet times. **********This slick tribute to Stalinist propaganda films that idealize life on the collective farm stars Russia's best-known pop singers recreating vignettes from creaky classics like the 1950 musical "Cossacks of the Kuban." **********Everyone is sick of American movies and tired of having an inferiority complex," said Leonid Parfyonov, a young television star who was the co-producer of the $3 million extravaganza. "These old Soviet films are very sentimental and immensely popular." **********The film tribute, he said, is part of a new trend in Russian life and self-awareness. "It's about admitting that there were things that were good," he said, "that there is nothing to be ashamed of, and that we don't have any other  history. What else can we reflect?" He paused, then said, "Why should we struggle with ourselves?" **********His question was reflected in the results of the Russian parliamentary elections this month. Nostalgia was at least partly responsible for the Communists' first-place finish.  And nostalgia -- some call it amnesia -- might  help a Communist or nationalist get elected President next June. **********As young entertainment moguls like Mr. Parfyonov try to cash in on the trend  sweeping Russian popular culture, they are also dancing around the edges of a political revival that could nip their brash, breezy capitalism in the bud. **********"It became absolutely clear the week after the election that there is a common mood among the people," said Anatoly Smelyansky, director of the Moscow Arts Theater. "People are longing for the lost paradise -- the lost Communist paradise." **********The infatuation with Western culture and democracy that gripped Russia after  the collapse of Communism and the Soviet state in 1991 has long worn off. Russians are increasingly looking inward, sifting through their Soviet past in search of a palatable identity. **********And Communism, once again, is selling. Not the orthodox party line that once  tethered Russian life, but some of the order and economic certainty of Soviet power. There are those who regret the loss of empire, but most are caught up in  remembrances of a shared past that included simple childhood pleasures along with mass suffering, and one that looks better and better as it recedes. **********Particularly at New Year's, nostalgia is as unmistakable among established artists, entrepreneurs and entertainment figures as it is among the tens of millions of poor, mostly older Russians who voted for the Communists this month. **********There is one difference, however. **********The new intelligentsia of Moscow and St. Petersburg, and particularly the raffish young professionals who attend Come-as-You-Were parties, watch campy old Stalinist movies, dance to Soviet-era hits in expensive nightclubs, collect Revolutionary poster art and shop at chic Soviet thrift shops, do so with ironical detachment, certain that whatever happens, the Soviet system will never return -- that it is safe to look back not in anger, but with wry affection. **********The angry, impoverished Russians who speak mistily of the days of subsidized  meat, free rent and a guaranteed income say they are voting for pensions and a strong social safety net and not the Communist repression of the Soviet state. But they are not averse to the kind of strict Government control that could put  irreverent young capitalists like Mr. Parfyonov, who works at the independent network NTV, out of the free enterprise business. **********Mr. Smelyansky described the current nostalgia as a kind of backlash, a revolt against the abrupt break with the past that occurred in the initial euphoria of 1991. **********"This is not Eastern Europe," he said. "Communism here was more organic. After 75 years, it leaked into the genetic pool. It was the everyday life of millions, and they wanted to be recognized and respected." **********Those Russians take their nostalgia like vodka -- neat, undiluted by irony or self-mockery. **********Yet the happy few who have prospered under Russia's rocky transformation to capitalism believe they will continue to do so, whatever government comes to power next. **********"I don't believe radical Communists will ever get into office," said Vladimir Pelsh, 28, the host of a hot new television game show, "Name the Tune," which features Russian and Soviet golden oldies and has ridden the nostalgia wave to become the second-highest rated show in the country. "But if they do, I'll survive anyway," he said with a grin. "I'll just do a show called 'Name the Red  Tune.' " **********The revival of Soviet kitsch can also be found outside Moscow. At the Kirov Park in St. Petersburg, park managers plan a new attraction, Retropark, a $100 million Soviet theme park expected to open next summer as a kind of Leninland. **********After paying a hefty admittance fee, as yet undetermined, visitors will be issued kopeks minted before 1961 to work the antique slot machines and soda-water fountains. They will roam around flowerbeds arranged in the shape of  Soviet symbols beneath Communist-era banners and dance as 1940's bandstand orchestras play the old songs. **********Young park attendants will be dressed as Soviet Pioneers. Policemen will wear the white uniforms they wore under Stalin. **********One of the most successful FM radio stations in Moscow is Rossiskaya Radio (Russian Radio), which in the last five months has become one of the top five stations by playing only Russian music -- mainly pop tunes of the Brezhnev era. **********"The audience is fed up with Western music," said Aleksandr Bunin, the station manager. "Fifteen-year-olds call in to request songs that were hits in the 1970's and 1980's." **********Among intellectuals and artists, there is a strong urge to isolate the esthetics of the Soviet era from its politics. **********"Those Communist demonstrations across Red Square were very beautiful," said  Yelena Yazykova, the art director of a chic art gallery-thrift shop, Roza Azora. "I remember the balloons, the smell of candy, the big dinners afterwards around  the kitchen table." **********"The important thing is that it is the past, that now life is normal, and that we don't have to be afraid of our history -- we can remember it with humor  and sympathy." **********On Nov. 7, the anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917, Mrs. Yazykova gave a tongue-in-cheek Soviet costume party at her gallery a fashionable section of Moscow. **********The theme was the 1917 Revolution, and fashionable actors, artists, writers and television personalities shed their Armani jackets and Versace ties to dress up as Soviet Pioneers, party apparatchiks in wide ties and bulky suits, and aproned workers decorated with the Order of Lenin. A retired professor of political economics at Moscow State University delivered a mock Marxist-Leninist lecture, to giddy laughter and applause. **********Mrs. Yazykova explained that she and her guests feel nostalgia for the sounds, sights and smells of their youth, not the politics. But the election results this month, she admitted, were troubling. "I think it is impossible to be a little bit Communist," she said uneasily. **********At ORT, the once state-owned network that was partly privatized last year, giving the Government 51 percent and 49 percent to a consortium of banks and major businesses, there is no complacency about the future. Communists and nationalists are intent on passing legislation to renationalize ORT. **********"This nostalgia movement is not just a passing fad, it is complicated and important," said Aleksei Pushkov, the network spokesman. "It's an image of the Soviet Union based on memory, and also on the old glossy propaganda, and it's an image that the Communists are playing on now." **********ORT did not hesitate to broadcast the New Year's Eve special based on old, beloved propaganda movies.  "ORT is not interested in boosting this nostalgia, but we cannot be immune to it," Mr. Pushkov said. "We are a commercial enterprise now and we have to take into account what is commercial in this country." **********The rival, privately owned network, NTV, is also trying to feed viewers' nostalgia. NTV's New Year's special is a tribute to Soviet Pioneer childhood, with famous performers singing old Soviet children's classics. **********The network's top executives will also appear on the air, wearing red Pioneer scarves around their necks. Even Yevgeny Kiselyov, the urbane, high-minded host  of the respected weekly news program "Itogi," is expected to wear the red scarf, the emblem of Communist Youth. **********Those who can afford it plan to revel in their Soviet past in adopted capitalist comfort. **********"On New Year's Eve, we'll sit in front of a Sony TV, drinking Absolut vodka as we watch Russian films and sing Russian songs," Mr. Parfyonov said with a wicked smile. "Of course, the film is a remake shot in 35-millimeter Kodak film  and cost millions of American dollars. We're nostalgic, but we're not crazy."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/20/busin.print_headline: 2 of Brazil's Big Banks Combine Operations
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/20/busin.body_text: **********Brazil's central bank said this weekend that Banco Nacional had been taken over by Unibanco, ending speculation about a possible merger and creating one of the country's largest privately owned banks. Banco Nacional said it paid about 1 billion reals, or $1.04 billion. **********Unibanco had been Brazil's sixth-largest bank and Nacional was seventh. Each  had total assets of about $13 billion at the end of 1994. The new Unibanco will  be one of Brazil's three largest private banks. **********The president of the central bank, Gustavo Loyola, said on Saturday that depositors' money would be available to them immediately and that "they will be  able to use their accounts normally in branches of Banco Nacional that will be taken over by Unibanco."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/09/world.main_headline: U.S. Promises Data to War Crimes Panel
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/09/world.print_headline: U.S. Promises Data to War Crimes Panel
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/09/world.body_text: **********The State Department said today that it would insure that the international tribunal on war crimes committed in the former Yugoslavia would receive any intelligence information relevant to its inquiries. **********"If we have any information, whether it's open-source information, unclassified information or intelligence information, that we believe is pertinent to the question of war crimes, we will find a way to get that to Judge Goldstone," said Nicholas Burns, a department spokesman, referring to Judge Richard Goldstone, the tribunal's chief prosecutor. He added that Washington would protect intelligence sources. **********His statement at a briefing today apparently marked a shift from Tuesday, when the White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said there were "certain types of intelligence information that our Government cannot share with the international community" for security reasons. **********Mr. McCurry was commenting on reports that Judge Goldstone had complained to  the United States that he was disappointed in the "quality and timeliness" of information given to the tribunal by the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/04/world.main_headline: Ciudad Juarez Journal;At U.S. Door, Huddled Masses Yearn for Better Pay
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/04/world.print_headline: Ciudad Juarez Journal;At U.S. Door, Huddled Masses Yearn for Better Pay
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/04/world.body_text: **********Sometimes Ana Serratos pauses outside a McDonald's restaurant here, but she resists the temptation to stop in. Fast food is way beyond her means. **********A Big Mac, medium Coke and fries cost $3.05, and for Ms. Serratos, who earns  35 cents an hour wrapping tape around bundles of electrical wires in one of Juarez's assembly plants, that is a full day's wages. **********What people in your country make in an hour, we work a whole day for," Ms.  Serratos, 32, said to an American visitor during a recent family gathering in one of Ciudad Juarez's dirt-street suburbs. "These companies from the United States and Japan don't pay people what they ought to. They come to kill us with  work." **********Then she paused, reflecting. "But we have to recognize that they're important for Juarez." **********During the last 25 years, 310 mostly foreign-owned assembly plants, called maquiladoras, have set up operations to take advantage of cheap labor and special tax breaks. They have come to dominate life in this sand-blown city across the Rio Grande from El Paso. Like Ms. Serratos, six of her siblings work  in maquiladoras, and there are thousands of other families also marching to the  daily rhythm of the assembly plants, which employ more than 150,000 of Juarez's  1.2 million residents. **********The city is growing fast, and Juarez's 40-year-old Mayor, Ramon Galindo, who  belongs to the pro-business National Action Party, says he hopes to attract still more maquiladoras to Juarez. But in an interview in his City Hall offices  he also said the fact that a vast majority of taxpayers earn the minimum wage of about $18 a week or not much more is a critical problem for the city. **********"We're creating an enormous mass of wretchedly poor people," he said. **********Mexico's minimum wage, which varies from region to region, is to increase by  10 percent on Dec. 4, bringing Juarez's minimum up to about $20 a week. The increase comes after a 30 percent decline in Mexican wages this year. **********Because most Juarez residents have little to give, and the maquiladoras are required to give little, the city raises only meager tax revenues, Mr. Galindo said. And to make matters worse, the federal Government keeps 90 percent of the  minimal taxes the maquiladoras pay to Mexico City. **********"Our problem is, where is the money going to come from to provide services for all these people?" Mr. Galindo asked. **********Juarez's entire 1995 budget was just $37 million, said Jesus Abrego Lopez, Juarez's economic development director. Even if the city were not to grow at all and were to spend its entire budget for 15 years on paving projects, many streets would still be unsurfaced in 2010, Mr. Abrego said. **********Other huge challenges confront the city. Juarez's working-class sections, where many residents already must buy their drinking water by the jug from tank  trucks, now sprawl across the desert horizon, and the water is running out. **********"We need huge investments to dig deeper wells, but the city doesn't have the  money," said Vicente Jaime, managing editor of the newspaper Norte. **********Along a potholed track off the main highway near the Juarez airport, five young men, all maquiladora employees, were repairing a car. Their wages, they said, ranged from 68 cents an hour, which Gerardo Hernandez earns for punching holes in electric motor covers, to the $1.06 an hour Ivan Villanueva makes as a  maintenance mechanic in a seat-cover factory. Theirs were good jobs, they said.  And what is attractive about Juarez, they said, is that there are plenty more available. **********"If you don't like one job, you can walk down the street and get another," said Ruben Hernandez, Gerardo's brother. **********Cesar de la Rosa, 26, a foreman in an appliance repair plant, listed the benefits of maquiladora employment: workers qualify for membership in Mexico's social security system, which provides low-cost medical care, and another Government agency extends accessible home loans. Mr. de la Rosa said he also gets five days of vacation each year, with his full $37-a-week salary paid. **********Two miles away in another working-class enclave, seven of the Serratos siblings were listening from the edges of their father's cramped living room as  Ana talked about life in the maquiladoras. The smell of sausage and chiles wafted from the kitchen, and Ana's brother Jorge, 24, moved from glass to glass, pouring beer. **********Jorge betrayed a hint of bravado when he said that as a fork-lift driver in a plant called Productos Electronicos Diversificados, he earns a good deal more than a mere assembly line worker: 53 cents an hour. **********A visitor asked whether there were unions in Juarez, and Jorge looked puzzled. **********"What's a union?" he asked. **********A brother-in-law, Ramon Lopez, helped out from a couch. "That's a situation where if you have a problem at work, people try to help you out with the boss." **********There was a pause. **********"No, I haven't heard about anything like that," Jorge said. **********Ana described her commute to her plant, a two-hour battle that involves two ramshackle buses and requires her to rise at 4 A.M. to arrive at 7. **********Her older sister, Leticia, said, "Look how you have to suffer to earn a few pennies!"

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/17/world.main_headline: Conservative Who Helped Save Canada Tries to Save Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/17/world.print_headline: Conservative Who Helped Save Canada Tries to Save Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/17/world.body_text: **********He was by many accounts the most effective federal voice in the campaign against Quebec independence in October, a major force behind the narrow victory  for Canadian unity. **********But if Jean Charest, a 37-year-old bilingual Quebecer, helped save Canada, his next task is even more formidable: to rebuild his shattered Progressive Conservative Party. **********Mr. Charest took over as party leader after the 1993 general election, in which the party went from 153 seats to 2 in the House of Commons. The rout, coming after Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's nine years in office and nine more  months by another Progressive Conservative, Kim Campbell, was the most punishing blow to a governing party in Canadian history. **********Mr. Charest (pronounced sha-RAY) used to be Deputy Prime Minister, entitled to one of the most impressive offices on Parliament Hill. Now, political satirists do routines in which his office is a remote broom closet. The real thing is a little bigger, but just as hard to find. **********But since the referendum, in which even political opponents acknowledged him  as the key federalist foil to the fiery separatist leader Lucien Bouchard, Mr. Charest is climbing back onto the political screen. **********Polls give the Conservatives national support of 12 to 14 percent, about even with the largely Western-based Reform Party, but well behind the governing Liberals, who are backed by more than half the voters. **********Mr. Charest, who roused Quebec crowds with powerful, emotional speeches about national unity, actually won a standing ovation from Liberal members of the House. Prime Minister Jean Chretien, himself a Quebecer, called the boyish-faced, curly-haired Quebecer his "comrade in arms." **********Lately, feelers have gone out for Mr. Charest to join the Liberal Government  to strengthen its Quebec Cabinet contingent, or take over from the Quebec provincial Liberal leader, Daniel Johnson. **********Mr. Johnson could face an election next year against Mr. Bouchard, who is set to replace Quebec's Premier, Jacques Parizeau, who is retiring. Mr. Bouchard is  heavily favored to win any Quebec election, and has promised another referendum. **********But Mr. Charest has said no to the feelers. "I've always been very active at  the federal level and am very committed to rebuilding the federal Conservative Party," he said. **********His strategy, still vague, is to work for unity and make that the key to the  party's comeback. "We're a national party and have always been," he said. "The best idea the Conservative Party ever had was its first, and that was the idea of Canada." **********Under John A. MacDonald, who became Canada's first Prime Minister in 1867, Canadian conservatism was rooted in British Toryism with its respect for authority and tradition. The party later added "Progressive" to its name, and developed welfare programs and started public enterprises in transportation, broadcasting, banking, grain marketing and hydroelectric power. **********Though center-right in today's political spectrum, Mr. Charest seems more comfortable at the center than the right. But he has supported the sharp budget  cuts of the Conservative premiers who, despite the party's debacle at the national level, still run 3 of Canada's 10 provinces -- Ontario, Alberta and Manitoba. **********But Michael Adams, president of the Environics Research Group, a national polling organization, says that unfortunately for Mr. Charest, the unpopularity  of former Prime Minister Mulroney "has deep-sixed Conservatism for a while."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Florida Names 10 Semifinalists
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Florida Names 10 Semifinalists
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/busin.body_text: **********The Florida Department of Citrus said yesterday that it had selected 10 agencies as semifinalists in a mandated review for its orange juice and grapefruit juice advertising accounts, with billings estimated at $27 million. Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide in New York has handled the accounts for the last 25 years. **********Eight agencies will compete for the orange juice and grapefruit juice accounts: Saatchi & Saatchi, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C.; Ammirati & Puris/Lintas  in New York, owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies; Beber Silverstein & Partners in Miami; Grey Advertising in New York; the Martin Agency in Richmond,  also owned by Interpublic; the Richards Group in Dallas; the West Group in Tampa, and the New York and Miami offices of Young & Rubicam Inc. **********Two agencies will compete only for the grapefruit juice account: the Advertising Partnership in Bronxville, N.Y., and Nissen Advertising in Lakeland, Fla. A committee of officials from the citrus department in Lakeland will narrow the review to three or four finalists at a meeting on Jan. 17 and then make a decision on Feb. 21.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/06/busin.main_headline: Bruised, but Buoyant;The Chief of Apple Computer Says the Worst Is Over
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/06/busin.print_headline: Bruised, but Buoyant;The Chief of Apple Computer Says the Worst Is Over
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/06/busin.body_text: **********Give us one strong quarter and all this will go away." **********That was the response today from Michael H. Spindler, chief executive of Apple Computer Inc., a day after his top lieutenant resigned and the board gave Mr. Spindler what was widely perceived as merely a pro forma vote of confidence. **********In an interview at Apple's headquarters here, Mr. Spindler conceded that the  company had made mistakes -- but not fatal ones -- and that it would continue to be profitable, only more so. And discounting reports that Apple, the nation's third-largest maker of personal computers, has been seeking a merger partner, he implied that the company intended to remain independent -- even if in a scaled-down version. **********After hitting production snags and underestimating demand for its Power PC line of Macintosh desktop and laptop computers, Mr. Spindler said, the company is on the upturn and ready to make up lost ground in an industry that has seen explosive growth in the last year, especially in the consumer market. Because its hardware and software designs do not conform to the industry standards, Apple feels the effect of production shortfalls more severely than other computer makers. It has been working on a product transition to a new processor chip, the Power PC, that it jointly designed with Motorola Inc. and I.B.M. Apple began the transition a year ago, but customers have rushed to adopt it more rapidly than the company had anticipated, with unfilled orders reaching  a staggering $1 billion in June. **********Apple's fourth quarter, which ended on Sept. 30, was especially trying, as the company scrambled to finish converting its entire product line to the Power  PC. In mid-September, the company said its earnings for the quarter, which some  analysts had forecast at $1.03 a share, would be much lower. **********"This has been the most difficult quarter in the history of Apple Computer,"  Mr. Spindler said today in an interview in a conference room down the hall from  his office. "With all the media attention the stress is very high," he said. "I've been around the block a couple of times, but there are days when I have trouble looking in the mirror. But if we fundamentally believe in Apple, then focus, focus, focus will eventually pay off and we have to communicate that." Mr. Spindler drew an analogy to the San Francisco 49ers, the champions of the National Football League. "They lose one game and they're calling for the coach's head," he said. **********Mr. Spindler, who offered a well-publicized critique of his industry peers last year -- "too many visionaries" -- said he saw no reason to change Apple's basic business strategy. That plan is to shift Apple from a "product oriented" company, competing head-to-head with Compaq Computer, International Business Machines and other computer makers, to a "market oriented" company that specializes in areas like education and publishing, as well as home PC's. **********Helping create the air of crisis at Apple was what some analysts called an insurrection by Apple's chief financial officer, Joseph A. Graziano, who resigned on Tuesday after Apple's board, led by the chairman, A. C. (Mike) Markkula Jr., reaffirmed its support for Mr. Spindler. Mr. Graziano was reported to have been campaigning for Apple to find a buyer, arguing that the company could no longer survive independently in an industry that many see as increasingly monolithic, under the dominance of the chip leader, the Intel Corporation, and the software leader, the Microsoft Corporation. In personal computer sales, Apple's market share has lately declined to less than 8 percent. Mr. Graziano has been unavailable for comment, and Mr. Spindler was not willing  today to address the uprising directly, although he did hint that new alliances  might be in Apple's future. I.B.M., which has several alliances with Apple, has  frequently been mentioned as a potential partner. "What's going on right now with I.B.M. is a continuation of our technical relationship," Mr. Spindler said. Many industry executives say I.B.M. should have moved more quickly to adopt Apple's Macintosh software for the alliance to  prove strong, but it has not, for corporate reasons. "Why don't you ask them why they haven't adopted Macintosh software?" he said. Talks on alliances continue with I.B.M. and other companies rumored to be possible Apple suitors, he acknowledged, but no decisions have been made. "The big question is, how will we stand together," he said. The issue is facing  Apple and other companies that are trying to slow the Intel-Microsoft axis, including Sun Microsystems, the work-station maker, and the Oracle Corporation,  the software company. Declining to discuss specifics, Mr. Spindler hinted that Apple might be forced to sell part of its business in order to focus on areas in which it is best positioned to compete. "There are crucial decisions that are going to have to be made about letting go of some parts of a business that are quite unnerving to some people, including ourselves," Mr. Spindler said. **********Critics of Apple contend that its failure to correctly forecast demand can be traced in part to its planning process, in which Apple sales executives have incentives to keep sales projections artificially low so it is easier to exceed  targets and receive annual bonuses. But Mr. Spindler disputed this analysis, calling it simplistic. **********In his view, Apple failed to anticipate two important industry trends. One was the explosion of the home computer market in the fall of 1994, when consumer specialists like Packard Bell Electronics were able to gain market share with low-priced machines. When Apple raced to catch up, it found that suppliers of its key hardware components required six-month lead times to expand production to adequate levels. The other failure, he said, was Apple's slowness to upgrade its line of popular  Powerbook portable computers, which were seen for several years as exemplars of  innovation, but which were eventually surpassed by various brands of Intel-chip  portables with superior screens, better power supplies and other embellishments. But Mr. Spindler said he believed that both strategic errors had been addressed  in the Power PC transition from which Apple is now emerging. **********To be sure, many computer industry analysts say Mr. Spinder has not received  enough credit for the company's deft handling of important facets of its technology transition. Such migrations can be risky, but customers who made the  switch from Apple's former Motorola 68000 chips to the Power PC found that their old software ran just as fast on the new machines, and that new software designed specifically for the new chips could substantially outperform comparable software on Intel-based equipment. **********Mr. Spindler said Apple was not yet willing to give up on two new businesses  started by his predecessor, John Sculley. Apple has given up looking for partners on its eWorld on-line service, a laggard in the market, but the company has no plans to kill the service, he said. Instead, Apple is repositioning eWorld to serve as the platform for the company's Internet offerings. Nor is Apple ready to give up on the hand-held Newton personal digital assistant, although Mr. Spindler said the company was seeking partners to share  development work on future generations of the product, which has generated more  ridicule than sales in its two years on the market. **********For Mr. Spindler, two criticisms may be the toughest to shake. Some in the industry say that he guards his power too closely and that the company's view of the changing industry landscape is too narrow. Mr. Graziano's departure on Tuesday follows the resignation last year of the previous No. 2 executive, Ian W. Diery. **********But Mr. Spindler rejected the notion that he was intentionally leaving a power vacuum below him in the Apple organization. "I'm flabbergasted by those comments," he said of his industry critics. "I'm working very hard to distribute power inside Apple." **********He conceded that he had not yet decided whether to proceed with a management  model he has contemplated -- an office of the president, in which top duties would be shared by several key executives. Part of his reluctance apparently stems from the inevitable line-of-succession handicapping that would ensue. **********"People will say, 'So he's picked his heir!' but that's irrelevant," Mr. Spindler said. "What I'm trying to build is a corporation that is substantial, and which can win in this marketplace." **********And he figures he deserves at least another quarter to show he can do it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/28/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;I.B.M. PLANS TO CREATE INTERNET SOFTWARE UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/28/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;I.B.M. PLANS TO CREATE INTERNET SOFTWARE UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/28/busin.body_text: **********The International Business Machines Corporation plans to start a new business unit to focus on developing software products for the Internet. An I.B.M. spokeswoman, confirming a report in Computer Reseller News, an industry publication, said the company hoped to create new division by the end of the year. An example of the type of software that the new unit would be expected to  develop is I.B.M.'s Web Explorer, which helps users navigate the World Wide Web on the Internet, the company said. I.B.M. has not decided who will run the division, which will report to John Thompson, senior vice president and head of  software operations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/world.main_headline: Israel and Syria Gingerly Reopen Peace Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/world.print_headline: Israel and Syria Gingerly Reopen Peace Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/world.body_text: **********Negotiators for Syria, Israel and the United States convened today in rural tranquillity on the Eastern Shore of Maryland to try once again to forge a comprehensive peace settlement to end nearly 48 years of hostility between Israel and its Arab neighbors. **********No breakthrough is expected at the initial round, which is set up to allow the negotiators to measure each others' intentions -- and sincerity -- and to probe for shifts in position. **********These meetings are meetings without heavy agendas, without place cards, without name cards," said Glyn Davies, the deputy spokesman for the State Department. He said the negotiators "will meet as long as they see fit" over the next few days. **********As a biting winter wind chilled the eastern fork of the Wye River, the negotiators began talking over lunch at the River House of the Wye Conference Center, 70 miles east of Washington, reopening a mutually suspicious dialogue that collapsed six months ago. **********The deliberate informality -- choreo-graphed by the American hosts -- extended to a crackling wood fire and bowls of hard candy placed within reach of all 10 participants at a round mahagony table. The police units cordoning off the conference site also maintained a low profile. **********The current session is to end on Friday, allowing the negotiators nearly a week to consult with their home governments before they return early next month for another three days. **********Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who arranged the talks on a trip to the Middle East less than two weeks ago, plans to return to the region about Jan. 10 and shuttle between Israel and Syria as the framework for an accord becomes clearer. **********The three-man Israeli delegation was led by Uri Savir, director general of the Foreign Ministry. The Syrian side was represented by Walid al-Moualem, Syria's Ambassador to Washington, and two officials from the Foreign Ministry. **********The American presence was equally low key. Dennis B. Ross, the special Middle East coordinator for the State Department, headed a four-member team from the State Department and the National Security Council. Mr. Ross met separately with each delegation last night to prepare for the talks. **********The first peace talks between Syria and Israel, which were held in Madrid in  1991, collapsed; so have subsequent attempts. But Mr. Christopher and the Israeli and Syrian leaders say this time they have detected signals that the two longstanding enemies are serious about finding a solution. **********When Mr. Christopher recently visited President Hafez el-Assad of Syria, Mr.  Assad agreed to revive the talks. Mr. Assad also spoke in Cairo on Saturday of "some general ideas and general concepts, the aim of which is to accelerate the  peace process, and Syria supports this." **********One reason for President Assad's apparent new interest is that Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization reached their own accommodations with Israel,  as Egypt did in 1979. Another reason is that Mr. Assad thinks Prime Minister Shimon Peres will be more accommodating than his predecessor, Yitzhak Rabin, who was assassinated by an Israeli militant on Nov. 4. **********Mr. Peres has echoed Mr. Assad's cautious optimism, telling Israeli students  in Haifa on Tuesday he was "happy about the new tone" in Syria. **********Lebanon has also not made peace with Israel. But Syria exerts such influence  over its weaker western neighbor that Beirut is expected to fall into line with  whatever Damascus decides. Prime Minister Peres said earlier this month that the new talks would also have a Lebanon component. **********Mr. Peres said earlier this month that the new talks, which are closed to the press, "will be flexible, not rigid -- open." **********"Each side will be able to bring up anything they want," he said. **********But the talks are bound to involve the future of the Golan Heights, a barren  mountain plateau between the two countries that Israeli troops seized in the 1967 Mideast war. **********Until now, Syria has demanded return of the entire plateau as a condition for peace. Israel has been unwilling to relinquish such strategic terrain, which overlooks its heartland and forms the watershed that supplies nearly a third of  Israel's fresh water. **********As a result, Israel has insisted that the extent to which it gives back the Golan Heights depends on the extent to which Syria cooperates in a genuine peace. Israel has also demanded guarantees that the plateau heights will be demilitarized and that the supply of water will not be cut off.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/world.main_headline: BALKAN ACCORD;Vote on Sending Troops to Bosnia
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/world.print_headline: BALKAN ACCORD;Vote on Sending Troops to Bosnia
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/world.body_text: **********Following is the 69-30 roll-call today by which the Senate voted to support United States troops in Bosnia and Herzegovina but limit their deployment to approximately one year. The measure was proposed by the majority leader, Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, and John S. McCain, Rebuplican of Arizona. **********A "yes" vote was a vote to approve the sending of troops; a "no" vote was a  vote to reject the sending of troops. Voting "yes" were 45 Democrats and 24 Republicans. To take the same approach with your portfolio, you would strip away the most volatile investments -- like  technology-...
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/12/busin.main_headline: INVESTING IT;Trouble Ahead? 7 Funds Take Few Chances in the Long Run
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/12/busin.print_headline: INVESTING IT;Trouble Ahead? 7 Funds Take Few Chances in the Long Run
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/12/busin.body_text: **********IF you've quit smoking, lost 10 pounds, cut fat out of your diet and started  exercising, you know what it means to reduce risk. To take the same approach with your portfolio, you would strip away the most volatile investments -- like  technology-laden mutual funds -- that would probably plummet in a market downturn. **********What you would replace them with, however, is not so obvious. **********It's easy to buy a low-risk fund," said Thurman L. Smith, editor of Equity  Fund Outlook, a newsletter published in Boston. "But that's not the ultimate goal of an investor. You have to make some money." **********Though most low-risk stock funds have generated very low returns, at least a  handful have managed to keep pace with the stock market the last 10 years. These funds are intended for the long run, not to dazzle in a roaring bull market. Most are in the growth and income and equity income categories, meaning they have steady income from dividends or other sources to cushion them should stock  prices fall. Often adhering to a value style of investing, they are what Mr. Smith called "good choices if you are in a defensive mood." **********And who isn't feeling a little defensive, what with the Dow Jones industrial  average toying with new highs last week and with pundits noting how long it has  been since the last market correction (the last time the Dow industrials fell 10 percent was in 1990). **********Among the 340 diversified equity funds with 10-year records tracked by Morningstar Inc., the fund analyst in Chicago, 7 funds in the lowest 10 percent in risk have produced average returns of at least 14 percent a year -- roughly even with broad market gauges. **********There are many measures of risk. For this purpose, the proprietary scale from Morningstar was used. On its scale, the average for equity funds is 1.0, and to  find the 10 percent of funds with the lowest risk, Morningstar searched for funds with a risk measure of 0.7 or less. The seven funds have fallen 30 percent less than the average equity fund in down months over the last 10 years. **********MUTUAL SERIES Run from the Short Hills, N.J., headquarters of the investor Michael Price, the Mutual Series funds are perennial favorites of value investors. Three of the family's funds, Mutual Beacon, Mutual Qualified and Mutual Shares, made the low-risk, solid-performance list. **********Bill Mahoney, an investment adviser at the Rise Company in Oxford, Mass., said, "What I love about Price's funds right now is that they're really low in technology, so when the 20 percent correction hits, these funds shouldn't be hurt as much as other funds." **********Each of the three funds has produced average total returns of more than 15 percent in the last decade, and none have a 10-year Morningstar risk measure over 0.55. That means they have roughly half the risk of the average diversified equity fund. **********The Mutual Series funds are virtual clones of each other, investing primarily in midsize companies. Mr. Price's strategy is to buy cheap and hold. He favors corporations on the mend from failures and in the process of reorganizing, often buying huge stakes in such companies, like Sunbeam-Oster, and taking an active role on their boards. It was Mr. Price who stampeded Chase Manhattan Bank into a merger with Chemical Bank earlier this year, by taking a big stake in Chase and  publicly hounding its management to strengthen the stock price. **********T. ROWE PRICE EQUITY-INCOME "I love this fund," said Clint Willis, editor of the Independent T. Rowe Price Adviser, a monthly newsletter. "You have two forms of  protection on the downside: They buy really cheap stuff, and you've also got above-average income." **********Since 1993, the fund has been managed solely by Brian Rogers. Before that, Tom Broadus was co-manager. They share a zeal for value, buying large company stocks when out of favor and holding on. Among the top holdings are stocks once  or continually despised: Philip Morris, Exxon, Upjohn, Mellon Bank. Turnover was a scant 27 percent last year, and a minuscule 4 percent in the last bear market, in 1990. **********"Sometimes they are early in their calls," Mr. Willis said, "but, judging from their record, not too early too often." **********The fund's performance record is third best on the low-risk list, with annual average returns of 15.36 percent over 10 years. The Morningstar risk measure is  0.60, meaning that, in market downturns, this equity income fund has fallen 40 percent less than the average equity fund. Meanwhile, the fund is yielding 3.2 percent, significantly more than the Standard & Poor's 500 index. **********PUTNAM GROWTH AND INCOME Managed since 1993 by Anthony Kreisel and David King, the Putnam fund has attributes of both the value and the growth styles of investing. Once or often-controversial names like Philip Morris, Eastman Kodak and Exxon abound in its portfolio, but it also has industrial stocks like General Motors and utilities like US West and Nynex, stocks that tend to rise and fall with the economy. **********Having gained an average of 14.86 percent a year over the last decade, the Putnam fund is ahead about 29 percent this year. Its managers called the big bond rally of 1995, at one point holding 6 percent of assets in Government bonds, then taking profits. The portfolio is about 90 percent invested in the S.& P. 500. Pat Regnier, a Morningstar analyst, called it "a good choice for investors who don't want to venture much beyond the S.& P. 500, but who can't quite bring themselves to index." With a Morningstar risk measure of 0.55, the Putnam fund is much less volatile than the S.& P. index. **********SCUDDER GROWTH AND INCOME Howard Stein, the longtime boss at Scudder, has been bearish since 1980, and most Scudder equity funds have been dismal performers as a result. This one, however, has a 10-year performance record of 14.28 percent a year and only 70 percent of the risk of the average equity fund. **********Robert Hoffman, who has led a team of managers on the fund since 1991, produced a 2.6 percent gain last year, when most stock funds posted declines. Part of the fund's success is a yield consistently one percentage point higher than the group average, gleaned both from high-yielding common stocks and from convertible securities, which may account for 20 percent of assets. **********The manager's investing style is a blend of growth and value. The biggest holding in the $2.49 billion fund recently was Eli Lilly, which the fund bought  amid the health-care gloom of 1993 and watched rise in value. **********MAP-EQUITY This little-known fund, with a mere $53.5 million of assets, has badly trailed the market in 1995. But as a tortoise, it hasn't lost the most important race, producing 14.27 percent average gains for investors since 1987. **********The fund's management at Markston Investment Management in Newark has been in place since the mid-1980's, and it marches to its own drummer. While the average equity fund recently had 41 percent of assets devoted to just three sectors -- technology, finance and health care -- MAP-Equity had only 16 percent in those areas. For that reason, performance has been far behind the market this year, but the managers, who keep turnover low, are not budging. **********The iconoclastic portfolio looks like one chosen by committee: Rite Aid, Panhandle Eastern, McDonald's and Gillette. Large-cap stocks are leavened with enough small-cap and mid-cap issues to produce a blend in terms of stock size and investing style. The managers -- John Stone, Michael Mullarky and Roger Lob  -- look for strong management, product and market-share dominance and a low stock price. The combination has produced very consistent returns and a Morningstar risk rating of 0.68. **********Aside from the well-known Price offerings, few of the seven low-risk funds find their way into financial advisers' model portfolios. Mr. Willis, for example, favors T. Rowe Price Blue-Chip over its equity-income fund, because of  higher returns. **********The funds are not necessarily bear-market funds either. "The Mutual Series funds had terrible results in 1990," the year of the last bear market, said Amy  Arnott, senior editor of the Morningstar Mutual Funds newsletter. Contrarian funds with large stashes of cash hold up the best in bear markets, but they cannot match these funds in long-term results. **********Nor do these funds fit everybody's definition of low risk. Colette Coffman, manager of the Value Line Mutual Fund Survey, recommends Lindner Dividend Fund for investors worried about a market setback.  The Lindner fund fell less than a third the amount of the average equity fund in the bear markets of 1987 and 1990. Lindner Dividend, however, has 10-year average returns of 12.5 percent, three percentage points below the market average and too low to make the short list here. **********For investors, finding the right balance between risk and reward is like the  right combination of healthful foods and a satisfying diet. Guidelines help, but it is a personal decision.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/30/busin.main_headline: Key Official In Japan Quits Finance Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/30/busin.print_headline: Key Official In Japan Quits Finance Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/30/busin.body_text: **********The Finance Ministry's top bureaucrat resigned today, leaving behind an organization in near turmoil as it struggles to mop up a mess of bad loans and to fend off criticism over financial scandals at home. **********Kyosuke Shinozawa, the Vice Minister of Finance, apparently resigned to take  indirect responsibility for a series of scandals in the financial world. It is a tradition in Japan for officials to resign for mistakes made under their tenure. **********I have accepted Shinozawa's resignation to improve the morale of the ministry, which is under an oppressive atmosphere following scandals involving ministry officials," the Finance Minister, Masayoshi Takemura, said today, according to Kyodo News Service. **********Mr. Shinozawa is a far more important person than his title would suggest. In Japan, Government ministers are politicians who often wield less power than a career bureaucrat who has risen to the post of vice minister. **********The Finance Ministry is at the apex of Japan's bureaucracy, each year attracting the very best of the nation's university graduates; it exercises control over the nation's economy, taxes, budget, markets and banking system. **********Mr. Shinozawa had been in his post only since May, but was thrust into a storm of criticism of the ministry's handling of financial scandals. It was not  immediately clear whether Mr. Shinozawa's resignation would affect a number of measures pending in the ministry, including a plan announced this week to reshape management of the nation's financial institutions. **********Besides having to dispose of $400 billion in bad bank debt, the ministry has  seen a number of its senior officials caught up in cozy relationships with credit union executives who are now being investigated for illicit lending activities. **********Mr. Takemura, the Finance Minister, suggested that Mr. Shinozawa was resigning less because of the troubled banking sector than to take responsibility for the misbehavior of ministry officials. **********"Shinozawa is not quitting to take the blame for any individual incident, such as the failure of two Tokyo credit unions or the ministry's decision to use taxpayers' money for the liquidation of ailing housing loan companies," Mr. Takemura said. **********Earlier this month, the ministry announced an elaborate plan to use $6.8 billion in taxpayers' money to help pay for losses incurred by housing loan companies. The plan has already provoked criticism of the ministry. **********In what appeared as an effort to help remake itself, the ministry also disclosed this week sweeping measures to reshape its current method of evaluating and managing financial institutions. **********The ministry has also been criticized for its handling of the Daiwa Bank scandal, in which a bond trader in New York hid losses of $1.1 billion over nearly a dozen years. But there was no indication that the Daiwa scandal prompted Mr. Shinozawa's resignation, and in Japan the episode in some ways has  been dwarfed by the bailout of the housing loan companies. **********Mr. Shinozawa is to be replaced by Tadashi Ogawa, director general of the National Tax Administration Agency.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/16/busin.print_headline: Mexico to Bail Out Its Biggest Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/16/busin.body_text: **********Mexican officials have agreed to a $2 billion bailout of the country's largest bank, Banamex, as part of an increasingly costly bid to save the troubled banking system from collapse. **********Mexico's Government-run Bank Insurance Fund, known as Fobaproa, will take over some 15 billion pesos ($2 billion) of Banamex's loans, the bank said late on Thursday. **********Banamex is the latest and largest bank to seek refuge in a Government plan to avoid bank failures by shouldering the risk for part of banks' bad debts. The bank accounts for a quarter of the Mexican banking system. **********The deal is also part of a recent rash of bad news about a growing bank crisis that threatens to undo the recently privatized system and cost Mexican taxpayers up to $15 billion, economists say. **********Every major Mexican bank except the No. 2 Bancomer has handed part of its debts to the Government so far this year, totaling $6 billion. Bancomer is scheduled to join in with up to $1 billion more by the end of the month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/02/busin.body_text: **********Apple Computer Inc. cut its recommended prices for six desktop computers by an average of 15 percent today, aiming for more sales during the busiest shopping season of the year. **********The cuts ranged from 8 percent to 25 percent, with the deepest cuts on the oldest models. Two Power Macintosh 7200 models, which have been on sale just since August, were cut 8 percent to 11 percent. **********The price cuts affect Apple's Power Macintosh 6100 DOS-compatible, 7100-80, 7200-75 and 7200-90 as well as the Performa 5215 and Performa 640CD DOS-compatible machines. **********In absolute terms, the price cuts range from $150 to $500. The steepest is on the Performa 640CD, which has 12 megabytes of main memory, a 500 megabyte hard drive and a 15-inch monitor. Its suggested price was cut from $1,999 to $1,499.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/28/busin.main_headline: With a European Currency, The Currency Is Conflict
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/28/busin.print_headline: With a European Currency, The Currency Is Conflict
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/28/busin.body_text: **********Though Europe is moving toward creating a single currency sometime around the end of the century, the path will be fraught with dispute, backbiting and squabbling. **********That was plainly demonstrated at an important meeting of European finance ministers here today. Representatives of the Continent's two biggest economic powers, Germany and France, bickered for much of the day over procedural issues  and tried to win support for their positions from other Governments of the European Union. **********The issues debated included which economic figures were reliable to show whether a country qualified for participation in the single-currency arrangement, how quickly national debt should be issued in the new currency, how soon to make the new currency legal tender, and how soon European leaders should decide who would be the first nations to join in the common currency. **********And almost invariably, France and Germany were at odds. **********But despite the disagreements, officials were optimistic that in Madrid next  month, the leaders of the 15 European Union countries would be able to sign perhaps the most important economic accord since the Maastricht treaty of 1992,  an agreement that clears the way for the creation of the first stage of a new currency on Jan. 1, 1999. **********"There are some issues that are not resolved, but we are in a position to take a package to Madrid for approval by heads of state where the final issues will be resolved," Finance Minister Pedro Solbes of Spain said at a news conference. **********While there are skeptics, including those who think that Germany will pull out at the last minute, not wanting to give up the mark, officials of European Governments are doing more than just putting down agreements on paper for such a currency. Many are making painful cuts in their budget deficits to meet a tough  set of economic-performance criteria set out in the Maastricht treaty. **********The two most rigorous standards require a country to have a budget deficit of less than 3 percent of its gross domestic product by the end of 1997 and total debt not exceeding 60 percent of G.D.P. Only Germany and Luxembourg now meet those criteria, but almost a half-dozen other countries are expected to bring down their deficits over the next two years to qualify. **********Most economists agree that without German and French involvement, a European  currency would be meaningless. The two together would create a big economic market -- one that could draw in Britain, which is skeptical about giving up the pound, as well as other European countries. Eventually, it is envisaged, a monetary bloc roughly equal to the United States would emerge. **********But between now and 2002, the projected date when the new bank notes could be in full use and old national currencies no longer accepted as legal, there will  be plenty of moments that can weaken and slow the process. **********Today was one such time. France, for instance, wanted a decision on which countries qualified for monetary union at the end of 1997, using projections for debt levels that year. Germany wanted to delay the decision until early in 1998  to have confirmed figures on 1997 economic performance. **********In addition, France wanted countries that will use the single currency to begin issuing all debt in that new currency as of early 1999. Germany wanted that decision left to the individual governments. Both disputes were put off, to be decided by the heads of government in Madrid over the weekend of Dec. 16. **********A big decision in Madrid will be the name of the new currency. Though the French want the name ECU -- the current European Currency Unit, used in many accounts and already the issuance of some debt -- the Germans insist on Euro, a  name its Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, floated in September when the finance ministers last met. **********Delegates predicted that Germany would prevail in most of the disputes with France, including the dispute over the currency's name. **********"I think Euro's won, even though it's a terrible name," a Brussels official said today.
