https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/08/busin.main_headline: Real Estate;The first new suburban mall in nearly 20 years in the Cleveland region is going  up.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/08/busin.print_headline: Real Estate;The first new suburban mall in nearly 20 years in the Cleveland region is going  up.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/08/busin.body_text: **********BIG national retailers are increasingly being drawn to the outer suburbs of Cleveland, spurring the development of the first new suburban mall in the region in nearly 20 years. **********In the last two years, chains like the Target division of Dayton Hudson, Best Buy, Circuit City, Walgreen's and Kohl's have opened their first stores in the Cleveland area. And Nordstrom plans to open its first department store in Ohio in an suburb east of Cleveland in 1997. **********But the most significant sign of renewed interest by retailers in this market is the development of Southpark Center, the metropolitan area's first suburban mall since 1978. It is being built on 187 acres of former farmland in Strongsville, about 15 miles southwest of Cleveland. **********The two-story mall, with 362,000 square feet, is scheduled to open in October 1996 after a delay of more than two decades by a sluggish economy, development hurdles and a commercial real estate slump. **********"It took that long for the area to mature and for the department stores to realize it had matured," said Donald M. Jones, vice president of real estate development for the Richard E. Jacobs Group, the project's developer. **********The $215 million mall will have about 130 stores, a 10-store food court, parking for 5,500 cars and 4 department stores within the mall, with space for a fifth on the 1.2- million-square-foot construction site. **********The tenants anchoring the mall will be Dillard's, J. C. Penney, Kaufmann's and Sears, Roebuck. Each department store will own its own store and land parcel. A Kohl's department store will also open on a lot next to the mall. **********"It will be the only mall on the west side with at least four major department stores," Samuel W. Schaul, a Cleveland retail broker, said. "It has the full boat of retail." **********The developer calculates that 486,000 residents will live within 15 to 20 minutes of the mall by 1998. Shoppers in those suburbs now drive at least 30 minutes to the nearest malls. **********The start of Southpark Center took much longer than the developer, Richard E. Jacobs, had expected. **********Mr. Jacobs and the late Edward J. DeBartolo bought the former grain farm together in 1973, had it rezoned for retail use and planned to develop the project jointly. But a sluggish local economy delayed development. **********"You had recession after recession that curbed the growth of many tenants and made financing more difficult," said Mr. Jacobs, who also owns the Cleveland Indians baseball team. "And you had a plethora of shopping centers entering the  market." **********Mr. Jacobs, who owns and manages 40 million square feet of office and retail  space nationally, was able to ride out the slump in the market.  His company's portfolio includes 38 regional malls, mostly in the Midwest and Southeast. **********Last February, the DeBartolo Realty Corporation sold its interest in the Southpark project to Mr. Jacobs for $10 million. **********Retailers are now being drawn to Strongsville and other growing outer suburbs to the east and west by desirable demographics and highway access. **********"The site always made sense for a regional mall," Mr. Schaul said. "The problem was they had to wait for the population to grow in sufficient numbers so the retailer could survive out there." **********Strongsville, for example, has averaged 400 home-building permits annually for the last 17 years. About 5,000 new houses have been built in the last five years. **********National retailers have entered the market with plans for continued expansion. Target, a Minneapolis-based discount chain, will anchor a new $18 million, 300,000-square-foot strip shopping center being built about a mile from the Southpark site. **********"Strongsville was always kind of a quiet, sleepy little town," said the town's Mayor, Walter F. Ehrnfelt. "The growth that has happened in here in the last few years has been phenomenal." **********Remaking the suburb has not been without its growing pains. Mall approval took three public votes. The mere widening of access roads to five and seven lanes has snarled traffic. **********Southpark Center received no tax abatement or other incentives from the city. It is expected to generate about $1.5 million a year in real estate, sales and income taxes, Don Batke, Strongsville's finance director, estimated.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/02/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;A cigar maker features its manager and spiritual home.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/02/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;A cigar maker features its manager and spiritual home.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/02/busin.body_text: **********WHEN Ramon Cifuentes fled Cuba in 1960, 22 months after Fidel Castro came to  power, he carried $100 in his pocket, and two photos: a passport snapshot and a  portrait of him with his German short-haired pointer, Sukui. **********This seemed hardly enough of a treasure trove to inspire an ambitious advertising campaign, but McCaffery & Ratner, the Manhattan agency for Partagas cigars, managed to make do. In a series of four magazine ads, the agency has used a minimal supply of mementos to create a maximum amount of ambiance in evoking the pre-Castro era, when Mr. Cifuentes and his brothers managed the legendary Partagas cigar company. **********The $4 million campaign is running in Details, Esquire, Forbes, Rolling Stone, Smart Money, Wine Spectator, Cigar Aficionado and half a dozen other consumer and specialty magazines. **********Under the slogan "Partagas: the cigar that knew Cuba when," McCaffery & Ratner has used photographic ingenuity, archival images and male models in an attempt to recreate the lost world of the pre-Castro cigar. **********As might be expected, the ads extol the excellence of Partagas: not those Partagas cigars now made in Cuba in the factory that Mr. Castro's regime appropriated from Mr. Cifuentes's family, but the ones now created by Mr. Cifuentes in the Dominican Republic. **********Mr. Cifuentes helped build the new Partagas into one of the world's best-selling premium cigar brands, which, in the United States, is a strong rival to Macanudo. Premiums sell for $2.50 or more apiece. **********"I think the Partagas campaign is a clever and distinctive way to set the line apart from other companies' cigars," said Bob Forbes, a cigar aficionado who happens to be president of Forbes FYI, the life-style quarterly of Forbes. **********His magazine, as well as Forbes, is running the Partagas campaign, "which evokes the romance of the fine cigar and the reminiscence of time past," he said. "The pre-Castro era in Cuba has assumed a mythical aura for cigar smokers." It has long been illegal to import or sell Cuban tobacco or cigars in  the United States. **********Partagas is trying to capitalize on this aura in the persona of Mr. Cifuentes, who still oversees the company's cigar-making operations in the Dominican Republic. "He is the sole living cigar maker still actively involved in cigars today who was a manager in the pre-Castro period," said Austin T. McNamara, president of the General Cigar Company, which owns both Partagas and Macanudo. Mr. Cifuentes declines to give his age, which some say is the best-kept secret in the cigar industry, but he is believed to be 82. **********The campaign was introduced last spring with a Partagas ad that featured the  sepia-toned 1951 picture of Mr. Cifuentes and Sukui. The second advertisement carried the message "I wanted to grow up to be a cowboy, until my father taught me how to make a Partagas." The ad depicts Ramon as a little boy, astride a horse outside a Cuban estate. **********The third ad shows the Partagas factory store in Havana with 1950's cars parked in front, and the youthful Ramon striding across the street. The last in  the series portrays a pensive adult Ramon, smoking a cigar at the mantelpiece of the ancestral manse. **********Given the reality of Mr. Cifuentes's journey to America, only the picture in  the first ad is authentic. The rest are "ingenious" fictions, as Mr. Forbes described them. **********For example, the little boy on the pony is not Mr. Cifuentes, but "an authenticated picture from Cuba of the 1950's from a private collection," said Bill McCaffery, the agency's president and creative director. **********"Even as a boy Ramon was involved in cigar-making," said Mr. McCaffery's wife, Sheila, the agency's associate creative director. The Partagas store in Havana was shot only last spring by the photographer Sheila Metzner, who snapped the pictures while playing the tourist. The store is still open and unchanged after its appropriation by the Castro Government. The two cars were rentals -- they cost $15 each -- and the Ramon-like pedestrian was a photography assistant. **********As for the image of Mr. Cifuentes at the mantelpiece, Warren Pfaff, an executive vice president at McCaffery, said, "We photographed it in the most similar setting we could find: the Woolworth mansion in Manhattan." **********McCaffery & Ratner has handled General Cigar's account for five years, mounting campaigns for the top-selling Macanudo as well as the Temple Hall and Ramon Allones brands. **********But what does the founding father himself think of all this? "I like the campaign because it reveals the past but looks forward to the future," said Mr.  Cifuentes, who says he still smokes 10 cigars a day. **********Thanks to the campaign, "now he is becoming something of a celebrity," said Celia, his wife of 60 years. She laughed. "People say they like his picture. But then, he was always a very handsome man."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/09/busin.body_text: **********The Hoechst Celanese Corporation, the United States unit of the German chemical company Hoechst A.G., said today that it and Shell Oil had agreed to pay $950 million to settle a class-action lawsuit concerning faulty plumbing systems. **********That represents an increase of $100 million from the $850 million amount in the original settlement agreement. **********The suit involves polybutylene plumbing. Shell Oil, a unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, made the resin used to manufacture the pipes; Hoechst Celanese made the fittings. **********Thousands of homeowners in several states began suing the companies in the 1980's after the plumbing began to leak, damaging their homes. **********Neither company admitted liability in the case. A Hoechst Celanese spokeswoman said the payment was increased because the two companies had expected a third defendant, E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, to join the settlement. She said Du Pont was refusing to participate. **********At a hearing today, the court agreed to combine the Tennessee suit with a class-action suit in Alabama courts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/world.main_headline: Jordan Offers To Organize Opponents Of Iraq Leader
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/world.print_headline: Jordan Offers To Organize Opponents Of Iraq Leader
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/07/world.body_text: **********King Hussein of Jordan has offered to be host to what would be an extraordinary gathering of Iraqi opposition leaders to discuss arrangements for  governing Iraq after President Saddam Hussein. **********With Amman already playing host to prominent Iraqi defectors, the step would  mark an important new break with Baghdad by the King, who sided with the Iraqi leader during the Persian Gulf war. **********There is no sign that President Hussein is in jeopardy, and some Arab countries have expressed skepticism about the Jordanian initiative. But Jordanian officials and Western diplomats here say the new overture by King Hussein to Iraqi dissidents -- including Kurds, Sunnis and Shiite Muslims -- has left no doubt that the King is now committed to playing a leading role in Iraq's future. **********"We're questioning the wisdom of continuing to talk about pluralism in Iraq without inviting the actors themselves to come and say to the world exactly what their definition of pluralism is," Crown Prince Hassan said in an interview here this week. **********The differences between and within the ethnic-based organizations make it unlikely that a single conference could untangle questions about how a future Iraqi federation might divide power among the Shiite Muslim majority in the south, the Kurds in the north and the Sunni Muslim minority that provides Mr. Hussein's current power base. **********Any gathering would also be complicated by the likely presence of Lieut. Gen. Hussein Kamel, the brother-in-law of the Iraqi leader and architect of Iraq's weapons buildup whose defection to Jordan last August prompted King Hussein to call for the first time for a change in the Iraqi Government. **********General Kamel remains ensconced with his family in a royal palace here, but his past role in quashing opposition within Iraq has caused many dissidents to regard him with unease. **********But with Jordan continuing to suffer economically from the United Nations sanctions in effect since 1990 on what was once its largest trading partner, diplomats here say that King Hussein had concluded that more should be done now  to lay the groundwork for a change in the Iraqi Government. **********"He feels very strongly that Iraqis have to begin to come to grips with and talk about the structure of a post-Saddam Hussein environment," a Western diplomat said. "He clearly appears to have concluded that Jordan's interests are best served by a change in the regime in Baghdad. He can be impatient, and he clearly believes that the sooner such change comes about, the better for Jordan." **********Jordan still imports all its oil from Iraq as part of an arrangement permitted by the United Nations that sees about $450 million worth of goods, mostly food and medicine, flow from Amman to Baghdad in return. But sanctions on sales to Iraq have deprived Jordan of $300 million to $400 million a year in exports. **********Some diplomats here said a meeting could be held as early as next month, and  they said they expected it to be accompanied by the transplantation of some Iraqi opposition groups to new headquarters in Jordan. That could establish Amman as the base for a kind of Iraqi government in exile, and would serve as a  further sign that King Hussein did not fear retaliation from Baghdad. **********Lees Kobba, a leading Iraqi Shiite opposition figure based in London, said he welcomed King Hussein's initiative and hoped the Jordanian would "sponsor an administration that operates from Amman until the Iraqis cross to the side of change." **********But in the interview here, Crown Prince Hassan declined to discuss a specific timetable for the Jordanian initiative, and he referred ruefully to the fact that Syria, Egypt and Saudi Arabia have all expressed skepticism about it. **********"Have you heard the Israeli political joke?" he asked during a 75-minute conversation in the sitting room of his elegant home in the Royal Palace compound here. "The Israeli says to the Jordanian -- the usual Israeli complaint -- 'We're surrounded by enemies.' **********"And the Jordanian says, 'You think you have a problem? We're surrounded by friends!' " **********Among those fellow Arab countries, Syria, which also hopes to establish trading ties with a new Iraqi Government, has accused Jordan of seeking to divide Iraq among its ethnic groups. Egyptian officials have suggested that King Hussein's real aim is to restore the reach of his Hashemite monarchy to Iraq, which was ruled by his cousin King Faisal II he was killed in a 1958 coup. **********But King Hussein has insisted that he has no such ambition, and Crown Prince  Hassan, his younger brother, said Jordan also has no interest in an arrangement  that would leave Iraq partitioned. "Why would we be interested in inviting a debate of the three parties on the fabric of Iraqi society if we were interested in dividing them?" he asked.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/03/busin.snippet: CORPORATE America has generally seen itself as being at the wrong end of whistle-blower lawsuits brought under the Federal False Claims Act, and views the statute as a weapon to be used against it. https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/03/busin.body_text: **********CORPORATE America has generally seen itself as being at the wrong end of whistle-blower lawsuits brought under the Federal False Claims Act, and views the statute as a weapon to be used against it. But a recent Federal case, Wells v. Huntleigh Technology, shows that corporations themselves can blow the whistle on rivals, make money for themselves and be seen as heroes that clean up their industries and recoup taxpayer dollars. **********The whistle-blower -- or qui tam -- provisions of the Federal False Claims Act (qui tam being Latin shorthand for "he who acts as much for the king as for  himself") and state equivalents in California, Florida, Tennessee and Illinois,  allow a private citizen, whether corporate or individual, with unique knowledge  of fraud against the Government to bring a lawsuit in the name of the Government and to receive a percentage of the recoveries. **********The Wells case shows that the qui tam law, like the civil RICO statute, can  be used by companies to act effectively against what they see as fraud in their  own industry and potentially turn a profit at the same time. The settlement of the case for nearly $5 million is a wake-up call to the business community. **********RON WELLS of Florida was a self-employed dealer in medical equipment for more than a decade when he hired our law firm to file his qui tam case against Huntleigh. He contended that Huntleigh was defrauding the Medicare system, and he gave these details: **********He was approached in 1991 by a Huntleigh sales manager with a "new" lymphedema pump, which is used by patients at home to treat swelling of the limbs. Huntleigh was selling the pump to dealers for less than $500 but asserted that the pump had design features making it eligible for Medicare reimbursement  at the highest rate -- $4,000. **********Mr. Wells examined the pump, named the Flowplus, and concluded that it was the same as Huntleigh's low-grade pump in virtually every respect but color. He  told this to Huntleigh and to Medicare officials. **********Meanwhile, Flowplus sales through other dealers soared -- as did Medicare reimbursements for the device. After Mr. Wells went to trade shows displaying the pump with a sign "Medicare rip-off," Huntleigh threatened to sue him. **********In early 1993, Medicare downgraded the reimbursement for the Flowplus from the highest to the lowest payment (about $475), but Mr. Wells felt that was not  enough. After 18 months, he became discouraged that Huntleigh and the dealers who sold the Flowplus had not been compelled to repay their earlier gains, and he acted to file the qui tam case. Huntleigh settled the suit in July for $4.9 million. Mr. Wells's share was $882,000, with the Government getting the rest.    MR. WELLS'S decision to blow the whistle, beyond being public-spirited, was also a business decision intended to benefit the company he owned and his industry. Mr. Wells believed that Huntleigh was not only committing a fraud on the Government, but that it was also ruining the market by forcing other manufacturers to bring out substandard pumps in order to compete. His decision to refuse to participate in what he saw as rampant profiteering, and finally to  avail himself of the qui tam provisions of the False Claims Act, protected his own business interests as well as those of United States taxpayers. **********Had Metpath and Metwest made a similar decision to blow the whistle on industry practices described to them by Jack Dowden, their fortunes might have taken a strikingly different turn than they did. **********Mr. Dowden was a sales manager for Metwest in the late 1980's when he reported to company executives that a rival diagnostic testing group, National Health Laboratories, was engaging in Medicare billing practices involving the "unbundling" of blood test packages that he -- and later the Federal Government  -- characterized as fraudulent.  Metwest's response, Mr. Dowden said, was to ignore his warning not to follow National Health's example. **********Believing that National Health was damaging his sales in his region, and in order to prevent his employer from also engaging in such practices, Mr. Dowden went to the authorities. Ultimately, he filed a qui tam suit against National Health as well as the Metpath unit of Corning Inc. and Metwest, which had adopted National Health's billing practices. The three settled with the Government for $150 million, of which Mr. Dowden received around $23 million. Had Metpath and Metwest joined Mr. Dowden in his lawsuit instead of copying National Health's billing practices, they would have likewise been awarded millions of dollars rather than having to pay $40 million in the settlement. **********These cases demonstrate a simple truth: "anti-fraud" is not "anti-business."  Like RICO, the False Claims Act can be a powerful weapon in the service of the business community. **********Indeed, in an era in which corporate compliance and self-policing are necessitated by the Federal Corporate Sentencing Guidelines, law-abiding companies need to take action to protect their ability to compete honestly in an honest market. **********Companies routinely do so now under the antitrust laws when confronted with anti-competitive practices by rivals. The False Claims Act permits companies that adhere to the law to level the playing field by exposing questionable practices of competitors for Federal dollars and offsetting the business losses  incurred as a result of them. It does so not only with an eye to bottom-line profitability, but also to the greater public good.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/20/busin.main_headline: Fox Opens Its Checkbook in a Search for Hit Comedies
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/20/busin.print_headline: Fox Opens Its Checkbook in a Search for Hit Comedies
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/20/busin.body_text: **********Can money buy laughter? **********Rupert Murdoch certainly seems to think so. Twentieth Century Fox Television  -- trying to improve its poor record of comedy hits -- has paid an estimated $60 million in the last month to sign a handful of established comedy writers and producers to develop new half-hour comedies. **********All the writer-producers were given four-year contracts and some, according  to people in the industry, will earn up to $5 million a year. **********"They've probably doubled what these people were making under their last contracts," said Gavin Polone, a prominent Hollywood agent with the United Talent Agency, whose clients include leading writer-producers on shows like "Seinfeld" and "The Larry Sanders Show." **********For Fox, the money is part of an aggressive new strategy. **********"Admittedly, we raised the bar," said Peter Roth, president of Fox Television, the American TV production arm of Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation. "But we did it with very careful calculation." **********Fox's signing binge, Mr. Roth said, was a "pre-emptive strike" against rival  studios like Warner Brothers, Universal and Walt Disney, which he said were too  distracted by mergers and management changes involving their parent companies to snatch up prime free agents. **********The studio, which Mr. Roth has headed since 1993, has produced several hit hourlong dramas for both the Fox network and the other broadcast networks in the last few years, most notably "The X-Files" on Fox and "Picket Fences" and "Chicago Hope" on CBS. But the last sitcom hit that Fox produced was ABC's "Mr.  Belvedere," which was canceled by the network in 1990. (Most of the hit comedies on the Fox network, like "Married . . . With Children," are produced by other studios.) **********Fox Television's push into comedy reflects the current reality in the TV industry that half-hour programs are much more profitable than hourlong dramas,  particularly in the syndication market, Mr. Roth said. By attracting top writing and producing talent, Fox hopes to create hit shows that will run long enough to make them hot commodities in the second-run syndication market. **********"All we need is one big hit like 'Home Improvement,' which can bring in hundreds of millions of dollars," Mr. Roth said. **********He added that the high-priced hirings also reflected a desire to create successful comedy series for the far-flung outposts of Mr. Murdoch's television  empire, which include the Fox network and its owned-and-operated station group in the United States, and satellite services in Britain, South America and Australia. **********To develop a fresh batch of new comedies to sell, Fox Television has signed three writer-producers and two teams: Chuck Lorre of ABC's "Roseanne" and "Grace Under Fire" and CBS's "Cybill"; Danny Jacobson, co-creator of NBC's "Mad About You" and one of the original writers on "Roseanne"; Eric Gilliland of "Roseanne"; the team of Vic Rauseo and Linda Morris of NBC's "Frasier," and Jeff Strauss and Jeff Greenstein, who were writers on NBC's "Friends" and who now run "Partners," a Universal Television-produced series now running on the Fox network. **********The highest-paid member of the group is believed to be Mr. Jacobson, whose contract is estimated to be worth $20 million. Mr. Lorre is said to be receiving $12 million to $13 million. Several others, who are currently working on shows created by other production companies, will not be available to work for Fox Television until the 1997 season. **********In paying such high prices, Fox has underlined the importance of so-called show runners, an unofficial title earned by each of the new hires. These are the people given responsibility for both creative and organizational control of a weekly series, and who write many of the scripts, supervise the writing of the rest and make budget and casting decisions. **********All the show runners signed by Fox have been given credit -- how much credit  is a matter of fierce debate within the industry -- for the success of one or more of the prime-time shows they have worked on. **********Some of Fox's rivals contend that pouring millions of dollars into the bank accounts of comedy writers -- and their agents -- might ultimately serve only to raise the cost of producing unsold scripts and pilot episodes. **********"It makes life harder for me," said Larry Lyttle, president of Big Ticket Television, a year-old division of Blockbuster Entertainment that has several network series and pilots in the works. "A couple of years ago $6 million was a  good development fund. Now it's not so good. I'm pretty well funded, but I'm not going to spend $13 million on three writers who haven't proven they can come up  with a hit series." **********Mr. Lyttle said several of the new Fox writer-producers gained their reputations not by creating new shows but by running the sixth or seventh seasons of long-running series. All have produced at least one dud -- some, two  or three -- for every hit show they've worked on. **********"It's tough enough to get one hit," Mr. Lyttle said. "The question is: Can they do it again? When you look at the history of television, you realize that's a tough question." **********Other critics of the Fox deals noted that 5 of the top 10 network shows last  season starred stand-up comics who successfully translated their stand-up routines and personas into a sitcom format. **********Mr. Roth was a bit impatient in responding to rival executives who questioned the wisdom of awarding such large contracts to behind-the-scenes talent. "The fact of the matter is that we will support our writing talent with the best acting talent -- some of which will be stand-up talent -- that we can possibly put together," he said. **********This sounds fine to the newly signed writers, all of whom work long hours in  an extremely high-pressure environment, but who already earn more than perhaps 99 percent of all those who have ever put words to paper for a living. **********"I feel like I kind of understand those hot-shot rookie sports stars now," said Mr. Strauss, 32, who has been writing for television for 10 years. "They thank their parents and they thank God. How can you possibly make sense of a financial gain of this size?" **********Mr. Lorre, 43, a former Long Island-based musician who made the transition 10 years ago to sitcom writing, said, "I guess if I don't come through, Rupert Murdoch will shoot me with a death ray from one of his satellites."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/27/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Whitbread to Bid For Forte Operations
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/27/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Whitbread to Bid For Forte Operations
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/27/busin.body_text: **********Whitbread P.L.C. has agreed to offer L1 billion ($1.54 billion) for the restaurant operations of Forte P.L.C., which is fighting a hostile bid from the  Granada Group, British newspapers reported yesterday. One report said that Forte and Whitbread, a British brewing and leisure company, had reached agreement in principle on the restaurant sale and that advisers worked on the deal during the Christmas holiday. **********Another report said that a deal had been confirmed by Forte insiders, who said a bid would be made within two weeks for the company's roadside restaurants and motorway service stations in Britain and France. As part of its defense against the L3.3 billion ($5.1 billion) hostile Granada bid, Forte has already begun to divest itself of some of its hotel interests, and has said it is ready  to consider offers for its restaurant business. A deal would significantly cut Forte's L1.3 billion ($2 billion) debt and possibly allow the company to pay a special dividend to retain shareholder loyalty. (Reuters)

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/world.main_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Bolivia Skeleton Believed To Be Che Guevara Aide
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/world.print_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Bolivia Skeleton Believed To Be Che Guevara Aide
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/world.body_text: **********A human skeleton has been unearthed on the outskirts of this small town in the mountains of southern Bolivia where a search is under way for the remains of Ernesto (Che) Guevara, the revolutionary killed 28 years ago. Buried in a shallow grave on a local farmer's land, the unidentified remains, unclothed but still wearing black socks and leather boots, are believed to belong to one of the Marxist guerrillas who fought with the Argentina-born revolutionary in Bolivia in 1967. **********Following a disastrous Cuban-backed guerrilla campaign, Mr. Guevara was captured on Oct. 8, 1967, and executed by the Bolivian armed forces the next day. Later, his body and those of two dozen Cuban, Peruvian and Bolivian comrades were secretly buried in Valle Grande. **********Today, Hugo San Martin, Bolivia's Deputy Minister for Internal Security and  the head of the presidential commission, said that the discovery has renewed his hopes of finding the body of Mr. Guevara. Commission members also say that a Cuban Government official is on his way to Valle Grande bringing the vital statistics of about a dozen Cuban guerrillas who died along with Mr. Guevara.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/24/world.main_headline: THE U.N. AT 50: TRAFFIC;For Motorists, It All Depended On Where You Were, and When
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/24/world.print_headline: THE U.N. AT 50: TRAFFIC;For Motorists, It All Depended On Where You Were, and When
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/24/world.body_text: **********It was a dickens of a day for traffic yesterday -- the best of times or the worst of times, depending on one's destination and how one tried to get there. **********The city Transportation Department said it was the former. The agency claimed victory in its campaign to persuade motorists to heed its gridlock alert for Manhattan and leave their cars at home. Traffic was lighter than usual at most bridges and tunnels; the wait at the Lincoln Tunnel yesterday morning was 15 to  20 minutes, about a third less than on a normal Monday. **********But drivers who braved the warnings and the prospect of sudden "freeze zones" in the East 40's and 50's, as diplomats barreled to and from the United Nations behind fast-moving police escorts, ended up regretting it. "It's a big headache," said Roberto Jose, who replaces air filters in restaurants and delicatessens. "I was supposed to go to 13 places. I only made it to 10." **********On Second Avenue in the 40's, beer deliveries were late -- truck drivers had  to park several blocks away and walk their wares to thirsty bars. On Park Avenue, moguls abandoned stretch limousines and walked to meetings, leaving chauffeurs stranded in bumper-to-bumper traffic. **********"I felt I could kill an hour waiting for my boss to come back without even circling the block the way I usually do," said Tim McMahon, a chauffeur who was  going nowhere fast in his steel-gray limousine. "You just have to be patient." **********Which was harder than usual for some dashboard-pounding drivers yesterday. "I can't even talk, I'm so aggravated," said Tony Johnson, a beer-truck driver who  was two hours behind schedule on his rounds in Grand Central Terminal. **********He said that he had guided his 32-foot truck through snail-pace traffic before finding a parking space on East 41st Street near the Tudor City apartments. From there, he loaded cases of beer onto a hand cart and hauled them to a supermarket on Second Avenue at 40th Street, fuming all the way. **********Last night, as many of the world's leaders gathered at Lincoln Center for a performance of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, several streets were blocked off in the area starting at 6 P.M. Streets from Broadway to West End Avenue in the 60's turned into slow-moving parking lots for much of the evening. **********But Alan J. Fromberg, a spokesman for the Transportation Department, was upbeat. "By and large the city is mobile and moving," he said.  Drivers anticipating trouble apparently got up and out of the house earlier than usual,  a plus on a day when Mr. Fromberg had been warning against gridlock. The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, which runs the Queens-Midtown Tunnel, said the morning rush began at 6 A.M., 30 minutes earlier than on a typical weekday, and was over by 9:15 A.M., an hour sooner than normal. **********And there were places where it was the best of times -- in midtown, mainly on the West Side. "It's like a ghost town," said John Rivero, an orange juice deliverer, on West 41st Street between the Avenue of the Americas and Broadway. "You can actually park here." (Not legally, of course, but that is another story.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/busin.main_headline: Report on Leading Indicators Is Delayed
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/busin.print_headline: Report on Leading Indicators Is Delayed
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/busin.body_text: **********The partial shutdown of the Federal Government has forced the Conference Board to postpone its first release of the newly privatized report on leading economic indicators. **********In a statement released today, the business group said the report, for November, would be delayed because economic data compiled by the Government were unavailable. **********The availability of this important information hinges on a return to work by the relevant Government agencies," the Conference Board said. **********The board said it expected sufficient data to be available in early January,  allowing it to release the leading indicators report in the second week of next  month. The board did not provide a specific date, partly because it was unclear  when the Government would be fully functional again. **********On Sept. 7, the Commerce Department announced that the Conference Board had won the bidding to publish the report. Privatization of the indicators was designed to save the Government about $450,000 a year.

Ogden said that it would seek buyers or merger partners for its noncore businesses -- including  facilities services operations, with revenues of $357 million in 1994; the technology services business, with $212 million in revenues in 1994, and the environmental services business, which had revenues of $142 million in 1994.
