https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/09/world.main_headline: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: EGYPT;Apathy Tinged With Anger In Cairo Over Mubarak Trip
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/09/world.print_headline: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: EGYPT;Apathy Tinged With Anger In Cairo Over Mubarak Trip
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/09/world.body_text: **********In the heart of this sprawling capital's biggest slum, Sheik Mayhoub Nasser is not the only one still seething at the sight of President Hosni Mubarak standing on Israeli soil. **********Mr. Mubarak's journey to pay tribute to Yitzhak Rabin has been welcomed elsewhere as a noble if overdue gesture. But in slums like Imbaba, whose poverty makes it fertile soil for Islamic militants, the President's visit to Jerusalem  is seen by some as a crucial mistake. **********"Mubarak has just signed his own death certificate," Sheik Nasser said this  afternoon, speaking in his apartment here. **********Although the sheik commands wide respect among his neighbors, he insisted he  was not making a threat. And even in this impoverished neighborhood, the notion  that Egypt's President is now at greater risk is an extreme view. **********But the shiek expressed the frustration of many in saying that Muslims cannot tolerate a leader who would visit Israel when it still controls Jerusalem. Mr. Mubarak's predecessor, Anwar el-Sadat, visited Jerusalem in 1977, even before Egypt made peace with Israel. Four years later, he was assassinated by Islamic militants who were angered both by the peace accord the two nations reached in 1979 and by Mr. Sadat's visit. **********Despite the peace, many in Egypt still look upon Israel as an enemy. And while Mr. Mubarak's careful words at Mr. Rabin's funeral on Monday stopped well short of an embrace, his supporters have hurried to head off charges that the President's presence was an affront to Islam. **********The Government has taken pains to insist that Mr. Mubarak's first trip to Jerusalem since he took office in 1981 was a human gesture that did not carry political weight. **********A lengthy editorial this morning in Al Ahram, the main Government newspaper,  offered seven reasons for the visit, saying that on balance it had been justified by "the exceptional situation." And Mr. Mubarak, who had previously refused repeated invitations to Israel, has told reporters, "I don't consider this a visit." **********With parliamentary elections just three weeks away, the Government is plainly concerned that opposition parties may seize on the visit to strengthen their attacks against a Government that some portray as hostile to Islamic leaders. **********In interviews across Cairo today, it was evident that Mr. Mubarak's hope of avoiding a public backlash has been strengthened by comparisons between him and  King Hussein of Jordan, whose more effusive eulogy to Mr. Rabin is being widely  described here as offensive. **********Indeed, by the standards of the student protests that followed Sadat's visit  to Jerusalem 18 years ago, the reaction to Mr. Mubarak's journey has been muted. Under emergency laws that have banned street demonstrations since the Government began its crackdown against Islamic militants three years ago, only opposition newspapers like Al Shaab have called critical attention to what it described as  Mr. Mubarak's visit to "occupied Jerusalem." **********While many ordinary Egyptians said they were untroubled by the visit, the forceful antipathy expressed by Islamic militants suggested that the step so welcomed in the West may carry domestic consequences. **********"It is not befitting an Arab and a Muslim leader to visit Jerusalem when it is still occupied," said Mohammed Ezzat, 21, a leader of Islamic students at Cairo University, where student union elections today pitted Islamic candidates  against those from a Government-supported secular society. **********"We should never have had relations in the first place with anyone who still  occupies our land," he said. **********In a barbershop in Imbaba, Hatem Gharieb, a restaurant worker, pointed with frustration to last month's vote by the United States Congress to move the American Embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem by 1999, and said Mr. Mubarak's visit was "bad timing." **********"This is a mistake," Mr. Gharieb said, adding that Mr. Mubara "was not adding anything to Egypt by going there." **********Only three years ago the Government dispatched 14,000 troops to Imbaba as part of its crackdown on Islamic militants, and the firm hand Cairo has wielded  across Egypt has left many people reluctant to express dissent. **********Sheik Nasser, one of several imams in his local mosque, was unusual in his neighborhood today only for allowing his name to be used as he criticized Mr. Mubarak's visit as an endorsement of Israel's control of Jerusalem. **********"It is bad for both Arabs and Muslims," said the religious leader, an impoverished former chicken merchant who had to tug at his shabby djellabah to hide its holes. **********In its editorial, Al Ahram defended Mr. Mubarak's journey as necessary because Menachem Begin, then Israel's Prime Minister, attended Sadat's funeral. **********The newspaper also said right-wing Israeli forces would have seized on Mr. Mubarak's absence to obstruct the peace effort. It said the unusual circumstance of Mr. Rabin's death provided Egypt with an "ideal opportunity" to put an end to American and Israeli complaints about the Egyptian President's long-standing refusal to visit Jerusalem. **********On Cairo's crowded sidewalks, bustling campuses and dusty back streets, men like Mukhtar Ali made it clear that they were more concerned with their own affairs than with such debate. Smoking a water pipe in a coffee shop in Imbaba,  Mr. Ali, a 33-year-old civil servant, shrugged his shoulders and told a visitor  that what Mr. Mubarak did was "a human gesture." **********But Hend Mohammed, 21, a Cairo University student whose hair and face were shrouded in a veil, said Mr. Mubarak's visit was a major misstep. "For the President to visit Jerusalem, it is a big risk," she said. "For Rabin to be buried in Jerusalem, that's a tragedy." **********-------------------- **********16 Wounded in Train Attacks **********ASYUT, Egypt, Nov. 8 (Reuters) -- Two Egyptians and two tourists were wounded in an attack tonight on a passenger train near Farshut, in southern Egypt, the authorities said. **********It was the second shooting attack on a train in two days. Twelve Egyptians were wounded on Tuesday night when a train speeding through southern Egypt was raked with bullets. **********Security officials said today that they suspected the attackers in both instances were Muslim militants. The Tuesday attack was the first of its kind since March, when four Egyptians were killed in a train attack. **********Foreign tourists have been a prime target for Muslim militants trying to weaken the Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/busin.main_headline: Communication Legislation Stirs Talk of Mergers By Baby Bells
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/busin.print_headline: Communication Legislation Stirs Talk of Mergers By Baby Bells
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/19/busin.body_text: **********With Congress on the verge of sweeping away six decades of communications laws, the nation's telephone companies are jockeying furiously in preparation for a wide-open race for customers and profit. **********Two regional Bell telephone companies, Nynex and Bell Atlantic, are reportedly exploring a merger that would create the second-largest telephone company in the United States. Only AT&T, the largest long-distance provider, would have more customer lines. **********At the same time, Wall Street executives said that a third regional Bell, the Pacific Telesis Group, was trying to negotiate deals with several phone companies, including Nynex and Bell Atlantic. **********Investment bankers and communications executives floated an array of other potential deals yesterday that would pair local phone companies with long-distance carriers or overseas phone companies. **********These days, picking up a rumor about a telecommunications deal is about as easy as picking up the phone. "With the starting gate going up, the Bells are going to have AT&T in their business tomorrow," said Robert Waldman, corporate bond research chief at Salomon Brothers, "They want people to know that they can potentially serve far more customers, too." **********For Wall Street, a frenzy of deals would be a bonanza. For many consumers, though, the activity is unlikely to make much difference in the price or quality of their phone service. Only in metropolitan areas, where the lure of lucrative  markets might intensify competition, could the small customer hope to see much benefit. **********Congress has yet to pass the telecommunications bill, which would allow the local and long-distance carriers to compete in each other's markets. But a House-Senate conference has nearly completed a compromise measure. And if a bill does not make it to the White House before the end of the year, many industry executives and lawmakers expect it to do so early next year. **********A report of discussions between Nynex and Bell Atlantic, something long assumed in the industry and the subject of a Wall Street Journal article yesterday, caused little stir in Washington, where the conference did not hold a meeting. **********But Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, who has harshly criticized the  monopoly power of the regional Bells companies, threatened to mount a filibuster against the bill when it reaches the Senate floor. "This is a signal of where the industry is going after the legislation," he said, "and it is toward greater concentration." **********Industry consolidation, though, may be a fact of the future, with or without  a law, as companies seek the advantages that size and economies of scale can bring. The antitrust consent decree, the court-supervised settlement that has governed the seven so-called Baby Bells since they were spun off from AT&T in 1984, does not prohibit two of these companies from merging. Nor does it prohibit a long-distance company other than AT&T from acquiring or merging with  a Baby Bell. **********Although telephone executives are still treading lightly around regulators for fear of derailing the bill, most are scrambling behind the scenes to line up partners and allies to help them compete. **********And in a public gesture, AT&T announced a move yesterday to further distance  itself from the local phone companies with which it expects to soon be competing. It said it would begin billing some customers in Florida, Texas and California directly for long-distance service. Until now, AT&T has generally paid local phone companies to add its charges to their monthly bills. **********A merger of Nynex and Bell Atlantic has been talked about in recent months as increasingly likely, a powerful local-phone franchise stretching from Maine to Virginia. The companies have merged their cellular properties, and they are partners with Pacific Telesis in a television programming venture, Tele-TV. **********Nynex and Bell Atlantic declined to comment on the talks yesterday. And an investment banker familiar with the discussions cautioned that the two were at least weeks away from any deal. **********Ivan G. Seidenberg, chairman and chief executive of Nynex, said in an interview yesterday that his company was exploring a broad range of relationships with other phone companies, ranging from joint ventures to marketing alliances. **********"This industry is so dynamic that we have to be flexible," Mr. Seidenberg said. "We have explored any number of options to do that, and we will continue to do so. But any discussion that we've had with any company is inappropriate to comment on." **********He noted that Nynex had not waited for telecommunications legislation to strike several of its deals. But he acknowledged that the bill, if it became law, would open the door to new relationships. Mr. Seidenberg said Nynex would try to gain some share of the huge number of international calls in and out of New York City. To do that, analysts said, Nynex could conceivably form an alliance with an overseas carrier. **********In seeking to compete against AT&T in the domestic market, analysts said Nynex and Bell Atlantic would each benefit by consolidating their local-phone franchise on the Eastern Seaboard. "What you need to have is a large footprint to reach more customers with one network," Mr. Waldman said, "There's no reason  on God's earth why you have to have seven Bell companies." **********If a merger would help both companies, most analysts said that on balance, it would be more beneficial to Nynex. Mr. Waldman said Bell Atlantic -- which covers the area from New Jersey to Virginia -- had better debt ratings and was viewed as one of the best run of the regional Bell companies. Though Nynex, serving New England and New York, had improved its reputation under Mr. Seidenberg, it was viewed as the weaker of the two. **********Nynex shares bucked a sharp stock-market decline yesterday, rising 25 cents,  to $49.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Bell Atlantic shares dropped $1.625, to $67. **********Regional Bell companies are not the only candidates for deals. Several analysts said MCI Communications was an obvious partner for a local phone company because it could gain access to local customers while offering access to its long-distance network in return. **********Analysts regard GTE as another natural candidate for a deal because it controlled local markets throughout the country. Indeed, an investment banker said Pacific Telesis had expressed interest in merging with GTE because the two  companies both controlled lucrative local phone markets in California. **********Consumer advocates, however, were alarmed by a linkup of regional Bell companies. "In a merger like this, you're talking about two companies that border each other," said Bradley Stillman, director of telecommunications policy at the Consumer Federation of America. "This assures that they will never compete in each other's markets." **********Critics of the legislation, including Senator Kerrey and Mr. Stillman, want the Justice Department to help determine whether there is adequate competition in the local phone business before the regional Bells are let loose in the long-distance business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/13/busin.main_headline: Singing the Steelworker Blues;A Mini-Mill Deal at LTV Leaves Union Feeling Jilted
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/13/busin.print_headline: Singing the Steelworker Blues;A Mini-Mill Deal at LTV Leaves Union Feeling Jilted
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/13/busin.body_text: **********For seven long years, the steelworkers here say, they stood by the LTV Corporation as it fought its way back from the brink of collapse. Thousands lost their jobs, and the survivors made numerous wage and benefit concessions to ease LTV's load. **********Today, with the company prospering again, the workers say they are reaping the fruit of their collaboration: betrayal. **********The source of their anger lies 600 miles away, in Decatur, Ala., the heart of right-to-work country, where unions have never gained a firm foothold. There, LTV is joining two foreign steel giants in building a $450 million mini-mill, a  high-technology wonder that will be able to produce 2.2 million tons of sheet steel a year with only 300 workers. **********The company says nonunion mini-mills -- which do not require hot blast furnaces and eliminate many of the costly and labor-intensive aspects of steelmaking -- are the wave of the future and its only hope for staying competitive in the global economy. But the local steelworkers' union, based in this Cleveland suburb, sees it differently. It says LTV never consulted the union about the investment and is purposely pursuing a policy that will eventually lead to the shutdown of its aging mills in Cleveland and East Chicago, Ind., which together still employ 8,500 workers. **********Many of the union's members are furious at what they view as LTV's greed and  ingratitude. "When they were in trouble, the company called us 'brother' and was glad to have our help," said George Lapp, a member of Local 1098 of the United Steelworkers of America. "Now they are trying to stab us in the back." **********Whatever its outcome, the dispute has wider implications than just the future of LTV's work force. Management and labor, particularly in the steel and automobile industries, made hard-won strides toward collaboration that helped revive industrial productivity and competitiveness during the free fall of American manufacturing in the 1980's. If workers widely judge that path to have  been fruitless, analysts say, it could add ammunition to those in the labor movement who are preaching a new militancy to reverse decades of membership decline. **********In October, the 13-million-member A.F.L.-C.I.O. elected a new president, John J. Sweeney, who vowed to take a much more aggressive approach to promoting workers' interests than his predecessor, Lane Kirkland. Mr. Sweeney promised to  "pour our resources into organizing at a pace and scale that is unprecedented." **********The United Steelworkers, whose membership has plummeted to 140,000 from 380,000 in 1979, is likely to prove a receptive audience to Mr. Sweeney's message. **********For the moment, there does not seem to be much the union can do about the mini-mill in Alabama, which is scheduled to open in 1997. Michael Scarver, a former local union president in Cleveland who is now on the national organization's staff, says workers are following a rule-book strategy to slow production and are staging noisy demonstrations in Cleveland and Alabama to alert steel buyers that labor relations in the older plants are poor. **********But LTV, cheered on by the rest of the industry, is determined to move forward with its plans. David H. Hoag, chairman of the company, said the joint venture would enable the company to cope with foreign competition and the technology revolution that together have forced the restructuring of American industry during the last decade. "It is important that this company grow, and grow profitably," he said. **********LTV holds a 50 percent stake in the mini-mill venture, called the Trico Steel Company L.L.C., while Sumitomo Metal Industries Ltd. of Japan and British Steel  P.L.C. each own 25 percent. **********LTV is the first large American steel company to switch to mini-mills from the old integrated plants that have been the norm since the turn of the century. And analysts leave no doubt that its strategic reasoning is sound. **********"Not only are these new mills less capital intensive, but they have production cycles measured in hours, rather than days," said Michael F. Gambardella, a steel analyst with J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. "That makes them  more flexible in meeting shifts in the market." **********He added that other traditional steel companies in the United States would have to move in a similar direction if they wanted to remain competitive. **********The new mill could have a formidable cost advantage. Based on its planned output and announced manning level, Trico should be able to produce steel with less than half a man-hour of labor per ton. Even the most efficient integrated mills require at least two man-hours per ton. **********LTV says that overall wages and benefits will be roughly the same for its workers in Alabama but that the pay package will be more flexible, with a lot of pay tied to incentives related to production. But if both companies pay $35 a hour in pay and benefits, Trico would have a labor cost of $17 a ton, compared with about $70 for a traditional steelmaker like LTV. With a product that sells  for about $300 a ton, that arithmetic provides a compelling argument in favor of mini-mills. **********Union officials argue that the new mini-mills are crowding into a business with too much production capacity already, particularly during the industry's periodic downturns. **********"Mini-mills represent 25 percent of the capacity for making steel in the United States," said George Becker, president of the steelmakers' union. "The new mills are being built to take business away from the integrated companies and shut them down." While the industry is thriving now, that could happen in the next big downturn, union officials say. **********For Mr. Becker, the company's abandonment of its workers would be the worst sort of ingratitude. LTV spent nearly seven years operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, paring away nearly 60 percent of its work force before emerging from bankruptcy in June 1993. In 1986, LTV's workers agreed to a wage cut of $1.60 an hour from an average wage then of $12 an hour and gave up a week of vacation and other benefits. The cuts were rescinded starting in 1992 and the company says that subsequent profit sharing has made up more than half the lost  income. **********"LTV survived the 1980's with the help of the workers," Mr. Becker said. "If  the union had not convinced workers to give concessions, the company would not be in existence today." **********Mr. Scarver echoed his boss's bitterness. He contends that the company has reneged on a solemn compact. "We worked out partnership agreements with LTV," he said. "We were going to get away from adversarial relationships and move into the 1990's." **********But the company says the labor leaders are misguided. "The decision to invest in Trico had nothing to do with the union," said Mr. Hoag, the chairman. He said the products made at Trico, at least initially, would be low-priced sheet steel, which has little overlap with the more highly processed coils from the Cleveland and Indiana plants. **********LTV officials acknowledge that the union's work-to-rule campaign is souring the atmosphere at the two Midwestern plants, but maintain that the protest is having little impact on production. "The most troubling part is that local presidents are not working with us to improve the productivity of our facilities," said A. Cole Tremain, the company's vice president for industrial relations. "They will not even come to safety meetings, which is shortsighted." **********Though they say they deplore the deterioration of labor relations, LTV executives are refusing to support the union's efforts to organize workers at the Alabama mill. "The union ought to compete and make an effort at organizing Trico," Mr. Hoag said. "Unions have to be competitive like everybody else." **********For Mr. Becker and others in the steelworkers' union, that stance adds insult to injury. They say big corporations in general have grown sophisticated in thwarting organizing drives, especially by screening out workers with pro-union  attitudes. And they fear that the traditional antipathy in the South to unions can only play into the hands of LTV's management. **********"A company that is willing to spend enough money can bust up an organizing drive," Mr. Becker said. **********Contrary to the union's contention, Trico will produce a form of sheet steel  that will not directly compete -- at least initially -- with LTV's products. But it may nibble away at the edges of the only market left to the integrated producers: the high-quality sheet metal that goes into automobiles and appliances.    LTV is the first American integrated steel company to get into the mini-mill  business, but it is not the first to recognize the advantages of the process. Dofasco Inc., an integrated producer in Canada, is one of the investors in Gallatin Steel Inc., a mini-mill that began making sheet steel in northern Kentucky early this year. And Broken Hill Proprietary, an Australian steelmaker, is a partner in a mini-mill being built near Toledo, Ohio, that is to go into operation late next year. In all, more than a dozen new sheet-making mini-mills  are in operation or under construction in the United States. **********According to Mr. Hoag, it was the threat from the new mills plus a desire to  get on the technology bandwagon that drove LTV to form Trico, despite a personal appeal from Mr. Becker not to build the mill. Under the terms of the latest contract between LTV and the union, which was adopted in 1994, the union has the right to name a member to the board of directors and to address the board on important issues. **********"Within the next 20 to 30 years steel will be made by entirely different methods," Mr. Hoag said. "We are in a transition away from the capital-intensive ways of the past." **********These methods may include making steel in one step from treated iron ore rather than relying on the multiple steps needed now, and casting liquid steel into its final shape, eliminating the costly rolling mills currently in use. **********LTV has longstanding links with Sumitomo, one of its partners in Trico. The company operates two electrogalvanizing mills in Cleveland and Columbus, Ohio, that use the Japanese company's technology. **********British Steel already operates a mill in Alabama, Tuscaloosa Steel, and is planning to move two iron ore preparation mills from Scotland to the Mobile area. The output of those plants, which is called direct reduced iron, could be  used in the electric furnaces of Trico. **********The Trico project is being closely watched by steel industry executives, particularly those in the older mills where the union is strong. "If Dave Hoag can stand up to the union and pull this off," said the chief executive of another company, who requested anonymity, "the whole industry will be in his debt."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/16/busin.main_headline: At AT&T, Nerves on Edge but Few Signs of Gloom
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/16/busin.print_headline: At AT&T, Nerves on Edge but Few Signs of Gloom
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/16/busin.body_text: **********With the adroitness of the world's largest communications company, AT&T reached around the world today to deliver "voluntary termination" notices to 77,800 managers. **********Thick envelopes containing the buyout offer went by overnight mail to reach managers on vacation in Europe or on sun-splashed beaches. It went to the homes  of those who were out sick and followed women on maternity leave. **********William Shay, a law division researcher at AT&T's world headquarters here, like most of the managers included in the offer -- half the company's supervisory work force -- got his delivered to his desk. **********It was a 91-page document, stuffed with details of a plan that gives those who receive it until Dec. 29 to decide whether to take it. **********Mr. Shay, 29, did not require much contemplation. Leaving work before 5 P.M., he said he would spurn the offer and hoped enough people would accept it so that he and others would not face "involuntary termination" in January, when the company announces how many jobs it will cut in a broad down-sizing program. **********"It's not something I would consider at this point in my career," Mr. Shay remarked confidently as he walked from the giant building that houses 4,000 employees, part of the more than 50,000 AT&T workers in New Jersey alone. **********It was not a confidence shared by everyone. **********"I have a mortgage and two kids in college," said another target of the buyout, who, like many co-workers, refused to identify himself. **********"There are a lot of people here like me who hope there are enough takers of the buyout so there's no bloodletting in January," he said. "The big problem is  no one knows, not even the company, how many jobs they need to cut." **********It was a tense day -- one everyone knew was coming -- but little gloom and doom was evident in an area that has bloomed since AT&T began moving many of its operations two decades ago to the horse and gentry country of western New Jersey. **********A manager close to retirement age expressed some sorrow that no buyouts had been offered to his marketing unit. "If they offered me one, I'd grab it along with other guys my age," he said before entering his car in an underground garage. **********The main worry appeared to be a lack of clarity over how many jobs will finally be cut, he said. "If the offer fetches enough people who walk out of here whistling, it will be good for everyone," he continued, but the fear is that "some people will be cut against their will." **********Executive offices have remained in New York City since 1885, but the heartbeat of planning, research and analysis takes place in a building of endless corridors in the wooded hills of northern Somerset County. Even the company's symbol, the "Spirit of Communications," a 24-foot-high gold-plated statue clutching lightning bolts and coils of telephone cables, stands outside the entrance here, long gone from Manhattan. **********In AT&T's corporate lexicon, a "manager" may head a department or oversee only a personal computer, a cellular phone and a four-cylinder car, Burke Stinson, a company spokesman, said. **********"We have more managers on the payroll than in 1984 when the divestiture occurred, and there were 373,000 employees," Mr. Stinson said. There are now 302,000 employees and 151,000 managers, he added. **********The typical manager, he said, is 42 years old, has 16 years with AT&T and earns $1,000 a week. **********Mr. Stinson, who has been at AT&T 26 years, opened a sealed package this morning and learned that if he took the buyout option, he would be entitled to 30 weeks of pay, and an additional 20 percent of that total would be paid to him. **********"After divestiture," he mused, "there was a feeling around here of a divorce  in the family. Now there's more a feeling that the kids have grown up and need a house of their own." **********The long-awaited buyout offer was the talk of Basking Ridge today. **********"Most of the AT&T guys I know don't know what January will bring," said Rich  Peacher, managing partner of the Store, a popular local restaurant and bar. **********Recalling a big 1989 buyout, which some 12,000 AT&T workers took, he said, "We used to do a big business with retirement parties, picnics and other events, which seem to have been hurt by budget cuts." **********"Guys who used to come in for a martini lunch and leave at 4 o'clock now are  in their offices." **********But Evelyn Pruiskema, who owns the Somerset Hills flower shop filled with the smell of roses, peonies and lilies, expressed confidence. "There's still a lot of old money and estates here that are a world apart from the corporate world,"  she said. **********Mary Lanzara, manager of a Weichert real estate office here, agreed that home values, which start at $300,000 and quickly run up to $500,000 or more in better locations, would not be hurt. **********"We're getting calls from young couples who ask if there are going to be any  great deals on houses now that AT&T is cutting back," said one of her agents, Sue Pinzuti. "But I don't see it happening. People love the 07920 Zip Code too much." **********Yet down deep some people were apprehensive. **********"This town is not a company town, but it's pretty close," said a woman who asked not to be identified. "My husband took an AT&T buyout in 1989, my cousin will probably accept this one, and my daughter who just had twins is worried about losing her manager's job." Still, she continued, a lot of big companies "have followed AT&T out here, so it isn't like there are no other opportunities."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/07/busin.main_headline: Technology Shares Up a Bit But Other Issues Are Mixed
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/07/busin.print_headline: Technology Shares Up a Bit But Other Issues Are Mixed
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/07/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices were mixed yesterday, while some technology issues made a modest recovery. **********The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.50 points, to 4,769.21. The Standard  & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.14 point, to 582.49, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 2.16 points, to 1,012.04. **********The stock market was directionless, motionless, trendless and friendless,"  said Hugh A. Johnson, senior vice president of the First Albany Corporation. "It clearly reflected the employment data." **********The Labor Department reported yesterday that employers added 121,000 jobs in  September, much fewer than expected. The August employment figure was revised upward by 13,000 jobs, to 262,000. **********"The bottom line is that the economy continues to limp along at a no-boom, no-bust pace," Mr. Johnson said. "The earnings season is fast approaching and most investors are very edgy." The initial batch of third-quarter earnings reports -- including some from big corporations like Chrysler, Motorola and Texas Instruments -- is scheduled to be released week. **********A number of technology stocks, which had been pushed down recently, managed to achieve modest gains, despite afternoon profit taking. Intel jumped 1 1/8, to 62, after being upgraded by Merrill Lynch.  Other technology gainers included Computer Associates, up 1, to 40, and Cyrix, up 2 3/4, to 42 1/2. The initial public offering of ESS Technology ended the session at 16, up 1. **********But shares of DSC Communications, a maker of telephone and cable television equipment, fell sharply after the company said third-quarter earnings would fall short of expectations. The stock fell 8, to 44 3/8, in very heavy trading. **********Banking issues benefited from the belief by traders that interest rates would continue their decline. Citicorp advanced 1/8, to 72 7/8; J. P. Morgan increased 3/8, to 78 1/4; Mellon Bank gained 1, to 47 5/8, and Wells Fargo rose 1 7/8, to  199 5/8. **********Big name household-products companies also finished on the upside. Procter &  Gamble climbed 1 1/8, to 80 1/8, a record, and Johnson & Johnson rose 1 3/4, to  77 1/4. **********The Dow Jones utility index slumped 1.25 points, to 215.07, after one of its  components, Niagara Mohawk Power, announced plans to split itself into two companies. Niagara Mohawk shares fell 1 1/4, to 11 5/8.  Consolidated Edison closed at 30 1/8, down 1/2; Commonwealth Energy closed at 41 3/4, down 5/8, and  New York State Electric and Gas closed at 25 7/8, down 1/4. **********Oil stocks were lower as concerns grew about various downward pressures on energy prices. ARCO declined 7/8, to 105 3/4; Texaco fell 1/8, to 66 3/8; Mobil dropped 1/4, to 101 7/8, and Chevron slipped 1/4, to 49 1/8. **********Alcoa, which said that third-quarter profits more than tripled from the corresponding period last year, rose 1 1/2, to 53 1/8. Iomega, which projected a doubling of its third-quarter revenues, increased 3/4, to 19 3/4. And Sybase, which was upgraded by Soundview Financial, advanced 2 1/4,to 33 7/8. **********Wal-Mart Stores traded down 1/8, to 23 3/4, after being downgraded by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. **********Advances topped declines on the New York Stock Exchange by 1,197 to 993. Turnover on the Big Board dropped to 313.7 million shares, from 367.5 million on Thursday; the average daily volume this year has been slightly less than 338 million shares. **********Earlier yesterday, stocks in Tokyo ended sharply higher. The Nikkei index of  225 issues closed up 285.87 points, or 1.57 percent, at 18,506.28, after hitting a high of 18,547.43.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/21/busin.body_text: **********The Nissan Motor Company said today that it would invest 5 billion yen ($49 million) to build a transmission plant in Decherd, Tenn., next to an engine plant that Nissan plans to build by early 1997. The transmission plant is expected to start operating in the spring of 1998 and is to make 300,000 transmissions annually. Nissan said the two plants were scheduled to create 200  jobs each. The transmissions will be used in Altima cars made at Nissan's plant  in Smyrna, Tenn., as well as in Nissan and Ford mini-vans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/08/world.main_headline: U.N. Aides See Congress As Impeding Reforms
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/08/world.print_headline: U.N. Aides See Congress As Impeding Reforms
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/08/world.body_text: **********Keenly aware of repeated calls from Washington for reform, the highest-ranking American official in the United Nations system asked the leaders of the international organization to come to a meeting later in October with concrete, written proposals for better management and cost-cutting. He was prepared for action. **********The meeting, which would have brought together agency directors from headquarters around the world, has now been canceled. It was a victim of a budget crisis brought on in large measure by the United States' failure to pay its past assessments and threats from Congress of severe future cuts in contributions. **********The tragedy is that those who say they want United Nations reform are cutting off at the knees the Americans who are able to deliver it," said James Gustave Speth, the official whose meeting was scratched. "The United States will pay dearly for squandering years of past investment in the United Nations, right at the moment it is beginning to pay off." **********Mr. Speth, who is administrator of the United Nations Development Program and holds the rank of Under Secretary General, is also the coordinator and adviser on reform to Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali. A Clinton Administration appointee, Mr. Speth directs much of his criticism at Congress, where committees dealing with spending on foreign affairs are now controlled by Republicans opposed to participation in many international organizations. **********Mr. Speth's agency, which assists 136 poor nations with development and represents the United Nations in a diplomatic role in capitals abroad, faces a cut. It could lose up to 45 percent of its budget request, down to $60 million to $70 million, when a Congressional conference committee meets on Wednesday to  decide on what are called voluntary contributions beyond the fixed assessments owed to the United Nations organizational budget and peacekeeping. **********Mr. Speth, a founder of the independent World Resources Institute and its president until 1993, said in an interview on Wednesday that Congress was "making reform synonymous with cuts." **********"The whole reform effort has become associated in the minds of many countries here with severe financial cuts in all U.N. budgets," he said. "Many governments see this as an effort to create a small 'boutique' U.N. and not an institution that can help the world overcome the huge problems it faces." **********But to people at the United Nations, the American policy looks bipartisan. Despite President Clinton's speech on Friday in which he called for the United States to pay its bills, the Administration is still linking reform and payments. An Administration official said in an interview after the speech that  this was deliberate and would not change. **********"The reality of the U.N. system is that without a strong and powerful motivation, nothing really changes," this official said. "That's why we're determined to combine reform and financial issues and not pretend there is no linkage." **********Throughout the United Nations system and in its missions, officials say that  if the trend continues, it will not be long before the United States will begin  to lose leadership positions in major agencies. Americans now head Unicef and the World Food Program, in addition to the Development Program. **********Europeans, who argue that the aggregate contributions of the European Union are overtaking American payments in many areas, waged a strong campaign to capture Unicef earlier this year. After intense lobbying by Madeleine K. Albright, the American representative at the United Nations, aided by Hillary Rodham Clinton, Carol Bellamy, former City Council Chairman in New York, was selected instead of a European. **********"It's not much fun to be an American working here these days," an administrative staff member said this week, adding that there had been a significant rise in resentment toward Americans not felt since the end of the cold war. **********John L. Washburn, a former State Department official and political adviser to the previous Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, said, "The law of perverse consequences has set in on reform." **********But Mr. Washburn, who serves on the board of the United Nations Association of New York, a support group, said the United Nations must take a lot of the blame for Congressional and public attitudes because it did not "stand up for itself" or explain better what it does. He added that the United Nations also did not draw enough on private American organizations working on similar world issues, groups that could build bridges to the public. **********"We're dealing in Congress with people who don't know the United Nations at all," an official who monitors Congress said recently. Another United Nations Congressional liaison officer said that over the last year, hostility toward the organization had become so pronounced that requests for meetings even to present information had been denied. **********Congressional leaders, including Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, the New York Republican who heads the House International Relations Committee, and Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, have directed much of their criticism at the bloated size of the United Nations bureaucracy and waste. **********Mr. Speth, calling this image of the United Nations "simply wrong," said that the institution had already improved its management and that it was the best vehicle to deal effectively with huge global social problems like disease, hunger, population, migration and the environment. **********"Poverty is growing faster than population," he said. "There are scores of countries where progress is going backwards rather than forwards. Rich countries are not going to be able to build a wall around themselves and shut themselves off. These problems don't need passports. **********"If we don't, as an international community, deal with these problems in a preventive, early, humane way, we will pay very dearly down the road for the neglect."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/11/busin.main_headline: Dow Sets Another Record But Overall Market Is Off
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/11/busin.print_headline: Dow Sets Another Record But Overall Market Is Off
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/11/busin.body_text: **********Even though the Dow Jones industrial average set a high for the third consecutive session, stock prices were under pressure yesterday as investors worried that the Federal Government might default on its debt because of political conflicts over the budget. **********The 30-stock Dow average gained 6.14 points, to 4,870.37, buoyed by a round of computer-guided buy orders and the strength of its large-capitalization cyclical issues. For the week, the Dow had a gain of 44.80 points. But in yesterday's trading the broader averages turned lower, and there were more declines than advances on the New York Stock Exchange. **********People fear the implications of a Government default," said Edwin C. Walczak, chief investment officer of Vontobel U.S.A., explaining what he called  "a cloud over the market." **********With Congress and the Clinton Administration in an impasse over raising the $4.9 trillion debt ceiling, bond prices fell yesterday. The bellwether 30-year Treasury bond slumped 23/32 and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.33 percent, from 6.28 percent on Thursday. **********Falling bond prices led to weakness in the overall stock market.  Among the other indicators, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index eased 0.54 point, to 592.72, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 1.72 points, to 1,063.87. Declining issues on the Big Board outnumbered advances by 1,246 to 975. Volume was light, with 298.7 million shares changing hands, down from 380.8 million shares on Thursday. **********The Federal Open Market Committee is scheduled to meet next week and there has been talk of a possible reduction in the Federal funds rate, which is charged on overnight bank loans. But many analysts do not expect any action on rates at this meeting. **********The stocks of brokerage firms, which are sensitive to changes in interest rates, suffered some big losses yesterday. Morgan Stanley dropped 1 7/8, to 87 3/4, and Merrill Lynch declined 1 5/8, to 58 7/8. **********Among the big movers in the market, American Greetings, which announced that  it would take a charge for a corporate revamping in its third quarter, declined  3 7/8, to 27.  Canandaigua Wine, which reported lower-than-expected earnings for its fourth quarter, plunged 1813/16 , to 311/16 . And Marvel Entertainment, which said that third-quarter profits dropped, fell 2, to 11 7/8. **********Drug companies that sell heavily in overseas markets also fell. Johnson & Johnson closed at 79 3/4, down 1 1/4; Abbott Laboratories ended at 39 1/4, down  3/8, and Pfizer closed at 58 1/2, down 1 1/8. **********On the other hand, stocks involved with the Internet continued their upward push. Spyglass increased 8 1/2, to 92; Netcom On-Line advanced 3/4, to 79, and Sun Microsystems rose 4 3/4, to 89 7/8.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/09/busin.body_text: **********Knight-Ridder Inc. said this week that it would dismiss 125 people, or 10 percent of the work force, at its Knight-Ridder Financial unit, which provides financial news and data. **********The job cuts are part of a reorganization of the unit to improve profitability, Knight-Ridder said. **********The unit, based in New York, will be organized along business lines rather than by geography. "We've had a regional structure, which is unwieldy for a business of our size," Patrick J. Tierney, president of Knight-Ridder Financial, said in an interview last week. **********As an example, he said many European bureaus at the unit had full-time accountants, a job that could be performed at a central site. **********Pat O'Grady, global sales manager of Knight-Ridder Financial, said the cuts included sales and marketing, product development and finance positions. Few news employees will lose their jobs, she said. **********Knight-Ridder Financial provides news and data to more than 44,000 users.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/23/busin.main_headline: Edper to Acquire Stake of a Bronfman
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/23/busin.print_headline: Edper to Acquire Stake of a Bronfman
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/23/busin.body_text: **********The Edper Group will acquire Peter Bronfman's majority voting stake in the company. Edper is an entity through which the Bronfman family controls one of Canada's biggest conglomerates. **********The move, announced on Thursday, is part of Mr. Bronfman's plan to streamline the organization's complex structure to make it more attractive to investors. **********Mr. Bronfman, 66, now will become one of 25 management partners of a group of companies that has investments in real estate, banking, power generation and  natural resources. **********The move will leave Edper Group owning controlling stakes in all of the units and affiliated companies. **********Mr. Bronfman, who is chairman of Edper Group, will receive 1.6 million class  A shares of Edper Group in return for his voting stake, which was undisclosed. The new shares have no voting rights. **********The Bronfman family in Toronto is related to the Bronfmans of Montreal, who control the Seagram Company, the distiller and beverage company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/22/world.main_headline: Top Separatist Will Seek Quebec Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/22/world.print_headline: Top Separatist Will Seek Quebec Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/22/world.body_text: **********The popular Quebec politician who led a referendum campaign that almost caused the province to break with Canada, said today that he would seek the leadership of the Parti Quebecois, a post that is almost certain to make him the next Premier of Quebec. **********Lucien Bouchard, the referendum leader, also said he would not press for another independence vote for at least two years, initially committing his anticipated premiership to straightening out public finances of what has become  the most debt-strapped of all 10 Canadian provinces. "It is an imperative duty owed to the integrity of the state," he told a news conference in Montreal. **********Mr. Bouchard now heads the Bloc Quebecois, a group of separatist members of  the House of Commons. He said he would seek to replace Jacques Parizeau as the leader of the nationalist Parti Quebecois, which now governs the province. The day after the Oct. 30 referendum, which the separatists lost by a razor-thin margin, Mr. Parizeau said he would step down. **********Mr. Bouchard has been described as a shoo-in for the leadership. Those with the standing to replace Mr. Parizeau have said they would bow out should Mr. Bouchard decide to run. Under the parliamentary system, whoever is chosen to replace a departing leader of the ruling party automatically becomes Premier. **********Tackling Quebec's economic issues may be a double-edged sword for Mr. Bouchard. While he could gain overall credit for strengthening the economy, any  cutbacks in social spending could hurt his image. **********"Certainly Bouchard will lose some of his luster," said Pierre Drouilly, a sociologist at the University of Quebec at Montreal. "Never before has he governed anything and the problems are enormous. But his great popularity gives  him more leeway than anyone else." **********Mr. Bouchard, a 56-year-old former lawyer and the son of a truck driver from  a remote village in the Lac St. Jean region of Quebec, had said after the referendum that he might quit politics to spend more time with his wife, Audrey, and their two young sons. A year ago Mr. Bouchard had his left leg amputated at  the thigh to check the advance of flesh-eating bacteria.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/09/busin.main_headline: KLM Suing Investors in Deal for Northwest
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/09/busin.print_headline: KLM Suing Investors in Deal for Northwest
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/09/busin.body_text: **********KLM Royal Dutch Airlines sued investors in the 1989 leveraged buyout of the Northwest Airlines Corporation yesterday, saying that changes in the buyout agreement limited its power as Northwest's largest shareholder. **********KLM denied that the suit was tied to Northwest's plans to approve a "poison pill" takeover defense and change rules of corporate governance. Both moves would limit KLM's ability to buy more shares in Northwest and influence corporate decisions. **********Northwest, the fourth-largest airline in the United States, said it suspected the Dutch airline was resisting anything that would dilute its voting  power at Northwest -- now about 40 percent of the investor group and 21.5 percent of Northwest over all. **********The poison pill and other proposed changes will be decided at a Northwest board meeting next week. **********KLM said the lawsuit, filed in New York State Supreme Court, names Northwest's co-chairmen, Alfred A. Checchi and Gary L. Wilson; Frederic Malek; the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, and Richard Blum & Associates. All five  either are directors or have representatives on Northwest's 15-member board. KLM controls three board seats. **********The lawsuit was filed shortly after Northwest said it would pay off the final $837 million it owed for the leveraged buyout, using cash and a new unsecured loan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/15/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Alvin Chereskin, a longtime force in beauty advertising, gives up retirement for Fresh Carats.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/15/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Alvin Chereskin, a longtime force in beauty advertising, gives up retirement for Fresh Carats.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/15/busin.body_text: **********AN agency creative executive who dominated beauty and fashion advertising for more than three decades before retiring a year ago is back at work. **********Alvin Chereskin, the linchpin of the Estee Lauder account at AC& R Advertising, where he served in capacities including chairman, chief executive and executive creative director, is opening an advertising and marketing consulting company in New York with clients that include the designer Vera Wang. **********For his comeback effort, Mr. Chereskin is teaming with Joan Evans, a onetime professional nose -- that is, a scent odor evaluator -- who has also long specialized in selling so-called image products like cosmetics and fragrances. **********The company in which Mr. Chereskin and Ms. Evans are partners is named Fresh  Carats Ltd. Appropriately enough, the moniker was inspired by an advertisement:  a sign in a luncheonette where the pair were meeting to talk over their fledgling venture. **********"It's a place where they make great carrot juice and the sign said 'fresh carrots,' " Ms. Evans recalled. "I said why don't we just change the spelling." **********Ms. Evans described Fresh Carats as offering clients "gemlike thinking in the simplest of settings." (Pause here for loud groans.) It also offers the services of "creative problem-solvers," she said, rather than those available from a conventional agency. **********In that regard, Fresh Carats is emblematic of a trend that has enabled advertisers to consider using small, creatively focused shops or boutique consulting outfits for tasks ranging from the evaluation of campaign concepts to media services and product naming. Such companies often handle a short- or long-term project, a brainstorming session and other assignments separate from the work performed on an account by an agency. **********"Whether it's skywriting or the Internet, it all comes down to -- it all begins with -- the idea," said Mr. Chereskin, 67, who joined Ms. Evans, 46, for  an interview at which they discussed Fresh Carats. **********Mr. Chereskin, trained as an art director, began in advertising in 1950 at a  New York agency known as Hockaday Associates. He co-founded AC& R 15 years later and began working for Lauder soon after. **********"I saw the Estee Lauder budget go from a couple hundred thousand dollars to $80 million," he said. Fueled by other accounts like Seiko, the Wool Bureau and  Foot Locker -- and with the backing of Ted Bates Worldwide, which bought AC& R shortly after its founding -- the agency grew to $360 million in billings by the late 1980's. **********But serious problems began eating away at the agency, which was shaken by the loss of accounts and the departures -- some bitter -- of top executives. Billings fell to $150 million, a large entertainment division in Los Angeles was closed and in 1991, the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, which had bought Bates, shifted AC& R to an autonomous unit of Bates rather than a stand-alone shop. **********In May 1994, Mr. Chereskin said he would retire that December. In July 1994,  Saatchi & Saatchi, by then called Cordiant P.L.C., merged AC& R into Bates and the AC& R name vanished. The portion of the agency handling Lauder became Bates  Manhattan, which recently survived a lengthy review on the Lauder account. **********Asked his reaction to the rise and fall of AC& R, Mr. Chereskin replied: "I'm not disappointed. I didn't sit around feeling sorry for myself. I helped 100 people in this business; that's a better legacy than a name on a door." **********In the last few months, which Mr. Chereskin puckishly referred to as "going into the Saatchi retirement system," he said he busied himself with Japanese gardening and "becoming computer literate -- up to a point. I'm not going to say I'm a techie." **********He started considering a return to ad work during the summer, he said, after  being called by acquaintances with one-day consulting offers and other requests  for advice. **********"I think there's an urge in all of us," Mr. Chereskin said. "You can slow down but you can't stop." **********Besides Ms. Wang, known for her bridal gowns, Fresh Carats is working for Annick Goutal Parfums in Paris, which sells a collection of fragrances in specialty and department stores like Barneys, Bergdorf Goodman, Neiman Marcus and Saks Fifth Avenue. **********An ad for Goutal in the December issue of Vogue magazine shows a woman asleep on a bed of autumn leaves with the headline "Perfume is the music of my dreams." **********Mr. Chereskin said, "It's fashion plus, how people live rather than what they wear." **********Fresh Carats also hopes to land assignments in categories that Ms. Evans has  handled at her own companies, the Joan Evans Marketing Group and Adrian & Evans. Besides cosmetics and fragrances, they include distilled spirits, magazines and premium-priced foods.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/09/world.main_headline: C.I.A. Chief's Report Says Moscow Duped Washington With Help FromDouble Agent
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/09/world.print_headline: C.I.A. Chief's Report Says Moscow Duped Washington With Help FromDouble Agent
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/09/world.body_text: **********With the help of a mole inside the Central Intelligence Agency, Moscow warped Washington's perceptions of crucial political, military and diplomatic developments inside the Soviet Union and Russia for nine years, the Director of  Central Intelligence said in a report released today. **********The deception scheme "diminished our ability to understand" what was really happening in Moscow from 1986 to 1994, said the director, John M. Deutch. The consequences were enormous. **********The United States failed to see the deep decline of the Soviet and Russian military and sped up spending on Pentagon programs. It misapprehended the hard-line resistance in the K.G.B. and the old Communist Party to the reforms of the last Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. And it did not fully fathom President Boris N. Yeltsin, especially his policies on the spread of weapons and his sometimes violent attitudes toward the former Soviet republics **********The scheme to manipulate American intelligence began after the mole, the C.I.A.'s Aldrich Ames, began working for Moscow in 1985. It grew to involve a team of Soviet double agents who whispered falsehoods salted with grains of truth into the C.I.A.'s ears for nine years. **********And it succeeded when the agency passed along at least 95 top-secret reports  without warning Presidents, Pentagon officials and policy makers that it knew or suspected the reports came from spies controlled by Moscow. **********The deception "had a substantial role in framing the debate" over military policy and strategy toward Moscow, Mr. Deutch said. While no one weapon or strategy was created solely on the basis of the deception operation, "the overall effect was to sustain our view of the U.S.S.R. as a credible military and technological opponent," he said. **********"The net effect," he concluded, "was that we overestimated their capability." The C.I.A. thus failed in its central mission of the cold war: understanding the depth of the Soviet threat. While the C.I.A. was criticized in the past for failing to foresee major events in the Soviet Union -- for example, the invasions of Hungary in 1956 and Afghanistan in 1979 -- the double agents' reports appeared to have colored many of its most crucial analyses in every sphere. **********The Pentagon used the reports "as part of an overall justification for multibillion-dollar investments in weapons system," and stepped up its spending  by hundreds of millions of dollars, the chairman and deputy chairman of the Senate intelligence committee said. **********Why would Moscow want to inflate its military prowess in Washington's eyes? "We take credit for the fact that we bankrupted the Soviet Union by getting them to build more than what they needed," said the deputy chairman, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, "and I presume that they may have had the same thing in mind." **********While the full extent of the operation will never be publicly known, Mr. Deutch's report, released by the committee today, provides the most detailed look yet at a sophisticated scheme run by the Soviet and Russian intelligence services and aimed at the highest levels of American Government. **********The double agents under Moscow's control fed the C.I.A. a carefully crafted mixture of truth and falsehood. To the extent they succeed in manipulating Washington's perceptions, they were helped immeasurably by the C.I.A. itself. **********Senior C.I.A. officials delivered the information to the Pentagon and the White House without revealing that they knew or suspected that the information came from double agents. This self-deception was crucial to the success of the scheme. **********The deception operation began in late 1985 or early 1986, after Mr. Ames, a counterintelligence branch chief in the C.I.A.'s Soviet division, secretly sold  Moscow the identities of every important Soviet military and intelligence officer secretly working for the United States. These agents were arrested and,  in most cases, executed. Soon new Soviet officials offered their services to the C.I.A. -- but they were double agents, under Moscow's control. **********Mr. Ames said in an interview last year that his Soviet handler, Vladimir Metchulayev, a senior K.G.B. counterintelligence officer, told him at an October 1986 meeting in Rome that his spy service would do "everything we can to divert, to mislead" the C.I.A. **********The double agents protected Mr. Ames by feeding false theories to the agency  about the disappearances and deaths of the agents Mr. Ames betrayed. And until Mr. Ames was arrested in February 1994, they fed carefully selected facts and falsehoods about the inner workings of the Kremlin to the agency. **********"One of the primary purposes of the perception management program was to convince us that the Soviets remained a superpower and that their military research and development program was robust," Mr. Deutch said. But after 18 months of internal investigations, which are continuing, the extent to which the program influenced the Pentagon's decisions to build or upgrade weapons systems  remains unclear. **********"It's difficult to pin them down as to exactly what decision was made based on this information and how much money it cost," said the intelligence committee chairman, Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania. In one instance, he said, a Pentagon official spoke of spending $200 million to speed the development of one weapon system. Pentagon officials identified it as the F-22 fighter plane. **********Some senior Pentagon officials are "reluctant to state" that the deception influenced billion-dollar decisions, Mr. Deutch said. But the Pentagon's chief spokesman, Ken Bacon, said that since "the amount of information that goes into  making decisions about weapons systems is so large, and the amount of information in these channels was a very small slice of the pie, our initial conclusion was that we probably would not have done anything differently." **********That attitude, Mr. Kerrey said, is "revisionist, in my judgment," given the "shock and outrage" throughout the Defense Department when the agency's duplicity was revealed. **********"No single strand of intelligence information ever serves as the full justification for undertaking a large program," said Mr. Deutch, who served as a senior Pentagon official in 1993 and 1994 and was exposed to some of the double-agent reports. But the intelligence reports clearly had the capacity "to influence U.S. military research and development and procurement programs costing billions of dollars," he said.
