https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/12/world.main_headline: Amazon Is Burning Again, as Furiously as Ever
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/12/world.print_headline: Amazon Is Burning Again, as Furiously as Ever
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/12/world.body_text: **********Three years after Brazil was host to the Earth Summit, shepherding ambitious  international accords on biodiversity and climate change, burnings in the Amazon region appear to be approaching the worst levels ever, while information on the  country's most explosive ecological issue -- the extent of forest clearing in the Amazon -- has virtually dried up. **********The burnings, aggravated by six months of little or no rain in the region, are leaving a thick blanket of gray smoke over forest and savanna. At the height of the recent burning season, the forest was cloaked in shadow, the sun appeared veiled and neither stars nor moon could be seen in the night sky. **********The vast fires are not runaway blazes alone, but an annual ritual from early July to November as ranchers, farmers and developers clear land for cattle grazing, planting or building. Much of the smoke rises from regrown forests in areas that were felled years ago, along with pastures and savannas. But the locations of some fires suggest a large amount of virgin rain forest is being cleared as well. **********Airports in much of the Amazon have been closed for at least part of every day because of the thick smoke. Doctors at one hospital in Rondonia said they were seeing many more patients as a result of the burnings this year than last,  with many children suffering from respiratory problems. **********"According to our statistics, this year is the worst year as far as fires are concerned," Marcio Nogueira Barbosa, director general of the Brazilian Government's National Institute for Space Research, said in an interview. "We know that the situation in some parts is very dire." **********The increase comes after several years of claims by the Government that destruction of the Amazon rain forest had slowed thanks to steps it had taken, including the elimination of Government subsidies for clearing virgin forest. But environmental experts contend the country's failure to analyze the extent of deforestation since 1991, along with the stepped-up levels of burnings in the Amazon region, raise doubts about those claims. **********The fate of the Amazon rain forest has drawn worldwide interest because it is believed to be home to a large share of the world's species. Atmospheric scientists also say that extensive clearing of the rain forest may contribute to the threat of global warming. **********Alberto Setzer, who tracks burnings in the Amazon for the National Institute  for Space Research, said that in July, weather satellites detected 39,900 fires, more than four times the 8,503 fires a year earlier. In the first half of August alone, his agency's weather satellites showed 72,200 fires. In August 1994, the  figure was 61,000 for the entire month. **********"In general we notice a very strong increase in fires in the Amazon region, and in regions where we didn't expect to see the fires," Mr. Setzer said. "It means that for sure we'll have a very high figure of new deforestation this year." **********Elaine Prinz, a professor at the University of Wisconsin who has been studying the Amazon region using a geostationary satellite that transmits data every three hours, said the burnings were not limited to Brazil. **********"There are millions of square kilometers covered with smoke in the Amazon basin," she said. "On one day, around Aug. 30, we saw a smoke plume, over six million square kilometers covered by smoke." Smoke hovered over parts of Brazil, Bolivia, Paraguay and Uruguay, she said. **********While starting fires in the virgin rain forest takes deliberate action, in this year's brittle heat the chance cigarette thrown out a car window can start  dramatic conflagrations in previously cleared areas, with the flames rolling over twigs, shrubs and dry leaves. **********Mr. Setzer and other ecologists could not be certain about the extent to which the fires involve first-time clearing of virgin rain forest because after  the 1992 Earth Summit, Brazil virtually stopped analyzing the 230 or so annual Landsat satellite images that provide an overview of deforestation, government officials said. Apart from isolated areas within the Amazon, the most recent wall-to-wall analysis of deforestation is based on images from 1991. **********Though officials here say that international accords require Brazil to analyze the images only every five years, government ecologists acknowledged that analyzing them steadily was crucial to understanding the extent of destruction. **********To critics, the gap in monitoring also throws into doubt repeated assertions  by the Brazilian Government that destruction of the rain forest has slowed in recent years. **********"To the extent that the images are the only real data on the total deforestation of the Amazon, then the absence of the data would suggest that Brazil's claims are, shall we say, smoke and mirrors," said Stephan Schwartzman, a senior scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund, a private American group. **********Mr. Schwartzman, who works in Washington and Brasilia, said officials from Brazil's environmental agency were typically upbeat when questioned in Congress  about cracking down on illegal logging and deforestation. "But I've never heard  a coherent account of what they're actually doing on the ground," Mr. Schwartzman said. **********Mr. Barbosa, the space research director, said the analysis of the data had stopped because the Brazilian Congress had stopped allocating the $500,000 a year needed to contract the 50 or so scientists to do it, though the Institute's total budget amounts to some $25 million. "It's simply because we didn't have the money to do it," he said. **********After the enormous expense of the Earth Summit and the international attention it received, Mr. Barbosa said, he appealed to government and congressional officials for money to continue analyzing deforestation, but interest seemed to wane. **********"After that, we did not receive the same priority to maintain this study," he said. "It's a strange thing to have $25 million to fund a variety of programs and not $500,000 to get this very basic information." **********Thelma Krug, head of the government institute's remote sensing department, said her agency could still answer isolated questions by analyzing spot data. "But when you think we have to answer broader questions about global change, this information is really necessary and extremely fundamental," she said. **********Mr. Barbosa said that based on the images from 1989 to 1991, he believed destruction of the rain forest had slowed as a result of Government initiatives, but he had no complete information to substantiate the claim. **********He said that in recent months, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso had ordered the space agency to resume analysis of the Landsat images, which the agency had been collecting but not analyzing, and had provided the money through a special allocation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Forte Selling Budget Hotels To Whitbread
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Forte Selling Budget Hotels To Whitbread
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/28/busin.body_text: **********Forte P.L.C. of Britain, taking another big step in its defense against a hostile takeover bid by the Granada Group P.L.C., announced plans today to sell  its restaurants and budget hotels in Britain to Whitbread P.L.C. for L1.05 billion ($1.62 billion). **********Forte, trying to show shareholders that it can raise cash from the company's  holdings faster than Granada, has recently raised about $1.7 billion through asset sales. **********The deal with Whitbread, a British brewing concern, is conditional on Forte's fending off Granada's buyout offer of L3.2 billion ($4.9 billion) initiated in November. **********Granada's chief executive, Gerry Robinson, deplored the Forte deal with Whitbread as "bad news for shareholders" and said it should help persuade them to sell to his company. **********"It is a poor price," Mr. Robinson asserted. "It is tax inefficient. But most damning is, it is the sale of a business with huge potential by a management bereft of ideas and strategy for growth." **********The sale would focus Forte as an international lodging concern with several chains of midpriced-to-expensive hotels under the Posthouse, Heritage, Meridien  and Exclusive names, the company said. **********"The resulting, highly focused international hotels company will enjoy a very strong financial position and cash flow," said Sir Rocco Forte, the company's chairman. **********Whitbread's purchase would include 127 Travelodge hotels, most of them in Britain; 430 Little Chef and Happy Eater budget restaurants in Britain; 23 Welcome Break highway service centers, which compete with Granada outlets, as well as Cote France road stops. **********With Granada's bid, Forte had considered spinning off its restaurant businesses into a separate company. **********The Whitbread offer will be submitted to shareholders at a meeting late in January. If successful, the deal is expected to close in March. **********Granada, a big broadcasting company whose interests also include leisure businesses, has given Forte's shareholders until Jan. 27 to accept its offer, and the company said today that Forte's deal with Whitbread should help make the choice clearer. **********One key to Forte's fight will be the publication on Jan. 2 of new valuations  of its properties and a profit forecast. **********The deal with Whitbread comes a week after Forte announced a deal to sell its North American Travelodge business to a United States group for about $170 million. Forte has also announced plans to dispose of its 68 percent holding in  the Savoy Hotel group, which owns five-star London hotels including the Savoy, Berkeley and Claridges.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/15/world.main_headline: Colombia Panel Backs President In Campaign Gifts of Drug Cartel
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/15/world.print_headline: Colombia Panel Backs President In Campaign Gifts of Drug Cartel
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/15/world.body_text: **********The threat of impeachment for President Ernesto Samper was eased today when a Colombian congressional committee voted against opening a formal investigation into charges that the President personally approved the acceptance of millions of dollars in contributions from the Cali drug cartel to help him win election last year. **********"There are no merits to open a formal investigation," said Jorge Humberto Mantilla, a member of the Colombian House of Representatives, whose committee voted 14 to 1 against the inquiry. "But if definitive proof arises, the investigation will be reopened. This does not mean that he is guilty or innocent." **********The decision by the committee, which had been expected, is unlikely to put an end to the general climate of uncertainty that has accompanied Colombia's most serious political crisis in decades, since Colombian justice officials are  continuing to gather evidence of wrongdoing in the campaign. **********While the President's role in the acceptance of drug money is unclear, prosecutors say that they have proven beyond doubt that the 1994 campaign did indeed receive millions of dollars from members of the Cali cartel and that their remaining task is to determine how much money there was and who is responsible for the contribution. **********"The political crisis is far from over," said Fernando Cepeda, a former cabinet minister. "If anything, it is just beginning." **********Since April, the chief prosecutor's office and the Supreme Court have been investigating at least a dozen congressmen, politicians close to the President and sports and entertainment figures for their alleged ties to the Cali cartel in what has become the country's first official inquiry into drug-related corruption. **********The investigations reached a new height in August when Defense Minister Fernando Botero, who served as Mr. Samper's campaign manager, resigned after the campaign's treasurer, Santiago Medina, told prosecutors that he had received over $5.8 million from the Cali cartel at the behest of Mr. Botero and of the President. Days later, Mr. Botero was arrested. **********Confronted by increasing calls for his resignation, Mr. Samper announced that he had asked the committee to open a preliminary investigation against him. **********Chief Prosecutor Alfonso Valdivieso has said his office's investigation of Mr. Samper's campaign financing will not be affected by the congressional committee's decision. **********"This decision is bound to produce controversy," said Alfonso Gomez Mendez, a lawyer and expert on constitutional law. "The investigation by the committee was not thorough enough. I do not think the President technically committed a crime, but that is not the point. The issue should be political."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/02/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene;Welfare time limits raise the specter of more street dwellers.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/02/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene;Welfare time limits raise the specter of more street dwellers.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/02/busin.body_text: **********NEWT GINGRICH and Bill Clinton agree: the time for time limits on welfare has come. But what happens when the welfare checks stop? "Not a lot of people have thought about it," says LaDonna Pavetti, a researcher at the Urban Institute. **********They will soon have to. A dozen states have already received Federal waivers  to set time limits. The others will probably not even have to ask: both the House and Senate welfare bills would drop any requirement to provide monthly stipends. But researchers who watched the states cope in haphazard fashion with  rising caseloads in the early 1990's are not sanguine about the consequences. **********At best, they say, time limits on cash benefits will force the dependent poor and the bureaucrats who serve them to focus on finding work for the able-bodied. Those who cannot find work on their own will be shunted into public service jobs that teach the value of work and help to break the cycle of dependence. **********But it is also possible that welfare will become meaner as well as leaner. Tens of thousands now live on the streets. Perhaps Americans will learn to turn  their backs on tens of thousands more. **********The idea of time limits was part of what Judy Gueron, president of the nonprofit Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, calls "the liberal-conservative consensus" that dominated thinking about welfare for much of the last decade. From this perspective, public assistance was a right -- but  only as long as those who needed it did their best to get off it. **********Society would never abandon the irredeemably dependent. But the notion of a fixed limit on cash grants meshed with the new emphasis on "workfare." Some, it  was assumed, would find jobs before the time limit. The rest would earn their welfare checks raking leaves, helping in child-care centers or cleaning storm drains. **********The catch, well known to policy specialists if not to taxpayers, is that workfare is very expensive unless a high percentage of chronic welfare recipients find jobs. For even if public service jobs pay little, the cost of providing day care and administering the programs would far exceed the cost of welfare as usual. Indeed, it was fear of the price tag that stood in the way of  welfare reform on the workfare model during the Bush and early Clinton years. **********But the liberal-conservative consensus is gone, victim to the priorities of the new Republican majority in Congress. If the Republicans have their way, there will be no new money for public service jobs. Indeed, there will be $100 billion less for welfare over the next seven years. What's more, states will be  free to spend fixed block grants any way they please. **********How they please will almost certainly include time limits: 24 states have already applied for waivers to set limits. And while a few are committed to workfare, the link between time limits and jobs of last resort is fraying and will likely be severed once state legislatures understand that Federal aid is no longer linked to the ambitions of state welfare programs. **********Everyone expects deadlines to create "a sense of urgency" among welfare recipients, says David Butler, a policy analyst at the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation and the co-author of the organization's first study of time-limited welfare. But just how far will a kick in the pants move the welfare system? **********The typical user of welfare is off the dole within two years. But the majority of those on welfare at any one time are there to stay: Ms. Pavetti estimates that three-quarters of four million to five million adults currently on welfare will remain dependent for at least five years. And she is skeptical that a large proportion of them can soon be bullied or cajoled into private-sector jobs. **********Even if they could, it is far from clear that the bitterly competitive market for unskilled labor would make room for them. Sheila and Sheldon Danziger of the University of Michigan found that just one-third of the nonelderly adults without children forced off Michigan's "general assistance" welfare roles in 1992 snagged full-time jobs within two years. And those were years of falling unemployment. "All bets are off for recessions," Mr. Danziger concludes. **********So what happens to the losers? Those who subscribe to the old workfare consensus hope that the prospect of poor families living on the streets will force Americans to face up to the reality that reducing dependence is a time-consuming and expensive business. **********But Gary Burtless of the Brookings Institution is skeptical it will come to that. More likely, extreme poverty will be driven underground, as families stripped of welfare grants get by on a combination of temporary work, food stamps, Medicaid, charity and help from relatives. **********"We shouldn't kid ourselves that time limits will make most recipients' lives better," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/23/world.main_headline: World News Briefs;Serial Murderer Is Jailed For Life in Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/23/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;Serial Murderer Is Jailed For Life in Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/23/world.body_text: **********One of Britain's most infamous murderers was sentenced to prison for life today, protesting she was innocent of torturing and killing 10 women and girls,  including a daughter and a stepdaughter. **********The lawyer for the killer, Rosemary West, 41, said afterward, "We are actively pursuing an appeal." **********Throughout the seven-week trial, Mrs. West blamed all the killings on her husband, Frederick West. He hanged himself in his prison cell on New Year's Day. All but one victim were buried at the Wests' home. **********Britain abolished the death penalty for most crimes in 1965.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/01/busin.main_headline: MARKET WATCH;It Begins: The S.E.C. Tightens Its Belt
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/01/busin.print_headline: MARKET WATCH;It Begins: The S.E.C. Tightens Its Belt
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/01/busin.body_text: **********Today is the first day of the new Federal fiscal year. It also is the first day of what looks like a long siege of uncertainty and belt-tightening for the Securities and Exchange Commission, the chief regulator of the nation's securities markets. **********When it opens for business tomorrow, the S.E.C. will be operating under a Federal stop-gap spending plan that will entail at least a temporary cut in its  budget. (By the way, anyone filing a new securities offering tomorrow should check to see if the plan has altered the S.E.C.'s fee schedule.) **********Even beyond this short-term budget squeeze, the S.E.C. faces 1996 with prospects that bode ill for its ability to keep pace with the expanding size and accelerating pace of the American markets. Indeed, the best it can hope for seems to be a freezing of its 1996 budget at 1995 levels - about $297 million, a figure already endorsed by the House. **********It might fare worse: until the 11th hour last week, Republican Senator Phil Gramm of Texas was pushing for a 20 percent budget cut. By late Thursday, Republican Senator Alfonse D'Amato of New York had written Mr. Gramm to urge him to agree to a zero-cut budget for the commission. As the week ended, the Senate  had agreed to an amendment calling for a 10 percent cut. A zero-cut budget may yet emerge from the senatorial thicket, but its fate in the ill-named congressional reconciliation process is uncertain. **********What is quite certain, of course, is that no one expects -- or even wants --  the S.E.C.'s workload to remain frozen at current levels. On average, since 1980, the volume of shares traded in markets has grown by about 15 percent a year; the number of mutual funds has grown by more than 8 percent a year; and the number of registered investment advisers has grown by nearly 14 percent a year. **********Almost as certain is that the outlook is bleak for the S.E.C.'s tiny Office of Investor Education and Assistance, which Mr.  Gramm wants to eliminate as being beyond the S.E.C.'s mission -- despite arguments by the S.E.C. chairman, Arthur Levitt Jr., that fully 18 percent of the commission's enforcement cases are triggered by complaints the unit receives from investors. **********Whatever the deregulatory spirits in Congress assume, Wall Street does not support these initiatives. John L. Steffens, an executive vice president at Merrill Lynch & Company and chairman of the Securities Industry Association, said cutting the S.E.C.'s budget when its regulatory burden is growing "just doesn't make any sense." Nor does the industry favor scrapping the investor education office: "Speaking both personally and for the S.I.A., the whole issue  of educating the public is one of the things that should be a primary mission of the S.E.C.," he said. **********So why does the S.E.C. appear so friendless in Congress? Perhaps because its  Wall Street friends have spoken too softly in its defense. Mr. Gramm is the powerful chairman of the Senate securities subcommittee, and Wall Street is wary of alienating him. And the industry has found much that it likes in the deregulatory campaign that encompasses the S.E.C. budget issue. "So it is hard to get people ignited on the issue," one industry executive said privately. For  all Wall Street's support for a strong S.E.C., he added, "nobody has called Phil Gramm to say this is a crazy idea." **********The S.E.C. may well have ideological foes in Congress. But with friends like  these, its enemies are perhaps superfluous.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/world.main_headline: Embattled Guerrilla Group in Peru Shifts Tactics Against Government
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/world.print_headline: Embattled Guerrilla Group in Peru Shifts Tactics Against Government
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/world.body_text: **********The Marxist revolutionaries who were arrested last month as they planned what officials describe as an attack on the Peruvian Congress belong to a little-known guerrilla group that was believed to have been defeated two years ago, after the police captured its top commanders. **********But the detention on Nov. 30 of 23 people, including a New York woman, who are accused of being members of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement has shown that the group is still functioning and capable of considerable violence. **********Tupac Amaru was never as powerful or as violent as the notorious Shining Path movement, which shook the Peruvian Government in the late 1980's. But the experts said that both groups still pose a threat to Peru's stability, even in their weakened state. **********"If you have a small group of 20 or 30 people who are well-armed, well-trained and ideologically controlled, you can pull off a major attack like  taking over Congress or killing a general or hijacking an airplane," said Enrique Obando, an expert on Peru's guerrilla insurgency. "I believe it was possible for Tupac Amaru to capture the Congress." **********Those detained on Nov. 30 were taken into custody after an all-night gun battle with the police at a hideout in an affluent Lima neighborhood. Three guerrillas and one police officer were killed in the battle. **********Police discovered a formidable cache of weapons, including machine guns, mortars, rocket launchers, hand grenades, cases of ammunition and military and police uniforms. The police also found diagrams of the Congress building inside  the house and documents indicating the location of military guards in the Congress and their hours of rotation. **********The police said the rebels planned to storm the Congress by posing as police  and military guards and to hold members of Congress hostage in exchange for the  release of captured guerrilla leaders. **********"These types of attacks and kidnappings in exchange for their comrades in prison are easy to pull off," Mr. Obando said. "We were lucky this time that the police struck first." **********A Western diplomat here said he had been caught off guard by the level of preparation for the attack on Congress. **********"We never thought that M.R.T.A. was dead, because it had been pulling off small attacks, and we knew it was trying to reorganize," he said, referring to the group by its Spanish initials. "But what surprised us was the large arsenal  that they had amassed in their hideout. That is a reason for concern because there could be other safe houses in Lima and other parts of Peru." **********The latest arrests come at a time when President Alberto Fujimori has been claiming victory over terrorism in Peru, a poor Andean country of 22 million people that is undergoing an economic revitalization. More than 35,000 people, mostly civilians killed by soldiers and rebels, have died in the fighting since  the early 1980's, when Shining Path and Tupac Amaru began their insurgencies. **********Mr. Fujimori, who was re-elected to a second term in April, seized dictatorial control of Peru in 1992 saying that Congress was hindering the fight against terrorism. **********But experts and diplomats said that, in response to Mr. Fujimori's aggressive and successful counterinsurgency campaign, Tupac Amaru has shifted tactics, no longer concerning itself with controlling territory or ambushing army or police  patrols. Instead, the group is undertaking "commando-style" missions intended to destabilize the Government and capture world attention by such as actions as capturing Congress or kidnappings. **********Tupac Amaru, which is estimated to have between 300 and 600 members, operates mainly in the upper Huallaga Valley, an area in eastern Peru controlled by guerrillas and drug traffickers. Named for an 18th-century rebel leader who fought Spanish colonial control, Tupac Amaru was founded in Lima and took up arms in 1984. **********The group had been led by Victor Polay, who was a college roommate of a former President, Alan Garcia, in the early 1970's. Mr. Polay was captured in June 1992 and is serving a life prison term, as is his lieutenant, Peter Cardenas. **********Shining Path, which has about 2,000 active members, considers Tupac Amaru a traitor to Communism, and the two groups have often warred against each other for "taxes" from cocaine smugglers in the Huallaga. Abimael Guzman, Shining Path's founder, was captured in Lima in 1993. **********While the Shining Path has been responsible for carrying out most guerrilla attacks in Peru, Tupac Amaru has attacked Western embassies, robbed banks, kidnapped business executives, bombed American fast-food restaurants and battled army units. **********It is believed to have tens of millions of dollars in foreign bank accounts,  mainly from levies on drug dealers and from kidnappings of businessmen and wealthy individuals who were held for ransoms often exceeding $1 million. **********In addition to its violent streak, the group had a Robin Hood image of stealing from the rich to help the poor. As a condition of releasing its kidnap  victims, the group often required that food be distributed in shantytowns. **********In last month's raid against the Tupac Amaru, the police captured the group's second-in-command, Miguel Rincon Rincon, who is known as Francisco. **********When the police presented Mr. Rincon to the public at a news conference this  week, the rebel leader said that he accepted full responsibility for his group's actions and that "I do not repent anything." The group's new leader, Serpa Cartolini, remains at large. **********Lawyers for Lori Helen Berenson, the New York woman who was also arrested in  the raid, said their client had been duped into providing information that Tupac Amaru used to plan the attack on Congress. But the police have said that Ms. Berenson was a main organizer of the attack. She is expected to tried in a military court on charges of treason.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/05/busin.body_text: **********An investment group led by Freeman Spogli & Company, a buyout firm, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Pantry Inc., a closely held convenience-store chain based in Sanford, N.C. Terms were not disclosed. Pantry  operates 400 stores in the Southeast with annual revenue of $375 million. Freeman Spogli would own 75 percent of the chain after the purchase is completed. The other members of investment group are Chase Manhattan Capital, a unit of the Chase Manahattan Corporation, and Pantry management, who would have 18 percent and 7 percent stakes, respectively, after the transaction.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/02/world.main_headline: Austria Agrees To Compensate Nazis' Victims
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/02/world.print_headline: Austria Agrees To Compensate Nazis' Victims
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/02/world.body_text: **********The Parliament voted today to to pay compensation to an estimated 30,000 victims persecuted during Nazi rule, seeking to resolve an issue that has divided the nation since the end of World War II. **********Lawmakers across the political spectrum, including the far-right party, supported a Government bill to establish a $50 million fund to compensate those  who were sent to concentration camps because they were Jews, Communists or homosexuals, and for those who fled into exile. **********The Greens, who called the 50-year delay in setting up the fund a disgrace,  voted against the bill, arguing that the money being offered was "little more than a poor box," as one Greens deputy put it. The Greens had demanded that the  Government make $150 million available over five years. **********The ruling coalition of Social Democrats and conservatives plans to compensate Austrians persecuted between Nazi Germany's 1938 annexation of Austria and the end of World War II. Austrians who returned after 1945 have already received some compensation. **********Chancellor Franz Vranitzky's office said it already had the names and addresses of 12,000 people who were eligible. More were expected to register their claims. **********The far-right leader, Jorg Haider, whose party won nearly a quarter of the votes in a general election last October, backed down from his earlier opposition to the fund and voted for it. The far-right party had sought to include eligibility for Austrians who suffered from the Allied occupation after  the war. **********Paul Grosz, a leader of Vienna's Jews, said he was concerned because the bill did not specify how much money each person would receive or address the question of whether former victims could apply for extra cash in special circumstances. "I cannot view this as a victory," he said. **********Only a few hundred of the 300,000 Jews who lived in Vienna before 1938 were still in the capital when Soviet troops captured the city in April 1945.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/03/world.main_headline: Alarm Raised Over Oil Spill in Russian Quake
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/03/world.print_headline: Alarm Raised Over Oil Spill in Russian Quake
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/03/world.body_text: **********Serafima Varlamova stared at the empty bulldozer parked on the side of the sandy road cutting through the birch and pine forest of northern Sakhalin Island and cursed the missing driver. **********"Drunk," she said, scowling as she pushed back her camouflage hat.  "We are looking at an ecological disaster in the wake of this human tragedy, and all anyone can think about is drinking vodka." **********Mrs. Varlamova is head of a section on oceanographic research in the Russian Ecology Ministry. She is trying to bring official attention to a disaster parallel to the earthquake that killed more than half of the 3,200 residents of  the small oil town of Neftegorsk on Sunday. **********She is worried about the growing oil spill resulting from the leakage of 21,000 barrels of crude oil from the pipeline that runs 17 miles across the austere Sakhalin landscape from offshore fields in the Sea of Okhotsk to terminals in mainland Russia. **********"The problem is that all the people who ran the pumping stations and knew the pipeline are dead, missing or so distressed that they can't possibly work," Mrs. Varlamova said.  "Neftegorsk was not just an oil town. It was a town created exactly to house those who worked in the industry. Now it -- and they -- are gone, and no one else seems to know what is where or what to do." **********Rescue work continued today, but at a lower scale. No survivors were found overnight, though a badly injured teen-ager was found today, along with 95 bodies. Workers concentrated on a single site, one of the prefabricated five-story apartment blocks that crumbled immediately in the earthquake. **********The official toll so far is 866 bodies and 405 survivors recovered. Up to 2,000 people may have died. **********The damage from the oil spill is not impressive as far as oil spills go. Blackish green petrochemical pools have collected in declivities along the line, marking the 18 different spots where the 11.8-inch diameter pipeline moved as much as 15 inches and snapped, while buried nearly 6 feet beneath the sandy surface. **********The spill is now seeping into the Sakhalin natural drainage system and running into the rich salmon and crab grounds that surround the island. **********More important to Mrs. Varlamova is the attitude of many working in the oil sector, who continue to regard production as the paramount concern. "There is heavy pressure on us to reopen the pipeline immediately, without thoroughly checking it," she said during a tour of the damaged line. **********"It is almost like the bad old days of the command economy, when production numbers were the paramount concern," she said. "Haven't we learned anything?" **********Sakhalin was once considered, or considered itself, a rich and pampered part  of the Soviet Union. In addition to bonuses and high salaries for working in the oil and fishing sectors in this remote region, 4,500 miles from Moscow, workers  and their families were treated to three-month vacations at Black Sea resorts and had a more regular and varied supply of food and supplies than most other citizens of the Soviet Union. **********That all ended with the Soviet collapse in 1991, and the replacement of the command economy, and its perks, by the chaos associated with Russia's transition to a market economy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/02/busin.main_headline: G.M. SALES OFF AS A CHRYSLER REPORTS A RECORD NOVEMBER
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/02/busin.print_headline: G.M. SALES OFF AS A CHRYSLER REPORTS A RECORD NOVEMBER
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/02/busin.body_text: **********The General Motors Corporation reported today that its sales in November had  declined about 3.8 percent from a year earlier as the No. 1 auto maker felt lingering effects from a monthlong strike that shut down its major car hauler. **********Meanwhile, the Chrysler Corporation reported a record November, with sales up 5.3 percent from last year, proving that hot trucks and price cuts on cars can create showroom traffic. Among other major auto makers issuing American sales reports today, Honda and Toyota also showed increases, while Nissan, Mazda and Mitsubishi posted declines. **********G.M.'s truck sales were off an estimated 11 percent, while the company's car sales dropped 1.4 percent. **********"We know that for the first part of the month we still had some availability  problems due to the transportation strike," said Thomas Klipstin, a G.M. spokesman. **********G.M.'s truck deliveries were hit hardest by the teamsters' strike against Ryder System Inc., the nation's largest car hauling company. It ended in early October, but its effects were felt until mid-November, he said. **********Chrysler's record was stoked by the popularity of a new generation of mini-vans, the Jeep Grand Cherokee sport-utility vehicle and full-size Dodge pickups. The company's combined truck sales were up more than 11 percent, with November records in those three segments. **********Chrysler car sales were off 5.2 percent from the 1994 period -- a decline that probably would have been larger without a round of rebates the company announced as the month began. **********The Toyota Motor Corporation's sales were 1.5 percent higher than a year ago  and the Honda Motor Company reported an increase of 8.5 percent from November 1994. **********The numbers from other Asian auto makers were less rosy. The Nissan Motor Company was off 7.9 percent from last year. The Mazda Motor Corporation's sales  dropped more than 38 percent and the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation's were off more than 31 percent. **********Most of the European companies report sales next week, along with the Ford Motor Company, the No. 2 auto maker. Without them, the industry's overall American sales were off about 1.8 percent in November.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/12/world.main_headline: Zeal of Rabin's Assassin Linked To Rabbis of the Religious Right
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/12/world.print_headline: Zeal of Rabin's Assassin Linked To Rabbis of the Religious Right
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/12/world.body_text: **********The men arrested in the killing of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin are part of a new, deeply religious Jewish underground movement whose fury was fueled by the Israeli-Palestinian peace accord, Israeli police officials and political analysts say. **********A week after the assassination, the picture emerging from the police investigation is of a small band with many of its adherents coming out of religious schools, a spinoff from the Kach organization founded by Rabbi Meir Kahane that revolved around the killer, Yigal Amir, and his brother Hagai. **********The Amir brothers come from a religious family of Yemeni origin. Their father is a Torah scribe, who painstakingly copies the holy words on parchment with a quill pen. **********The brothers learned combat skills in the Israeli Army and stole arms and explosives. But what is most shocking to many in this already stunned country is that, according to the police, the killing of the Jewish leader of the Jewish state had the blessing of a rabbi. **********The Israeli police say they believe that a religious decree in effect declaring Mr. Rabin a mortal enemy of the Jewish people who must be killed, compelled Yigal Amir, an intense 25-year-old religious scholar, to sidle up to the Prime Minister at a peace rally in Tel Aviv and fire three shots from a 9-millimeter Beretta pistol. **********Israeli military radio reported today that an Israeli Army solider and his father had been taken into custody in connection with the assassination. [Page 12.] Of the eight men now under arrest, five are Israeli-born religious students. **********Ehud Sprinzak, a professor at Hebrew University and a leading Israeli expert  on the radical right, said the anger of the religious right has been building since the peace agreement between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization two years ago, which was reached after secret talks in Oslo. **********The accord paved the way for Israel to start handing over parts of the West Bank to the Palestinians, a process that began this fall and that has led many Israeli settlers in the West Bank to accuse the Rabin Government of betraying them. The religious right took up the settlers' cause, fervent in their conviction that the region is part of Israel's biblical heritage. **********"It has welled up in the last year or so, a conviction among the Yeshiva students that Rabin is a traitor," Mr. Sprinzak said. **********"There was a process of radicalization in the late 80's with the intifada" -- the Palestinian uprising -- "but the real change came after Oslo. This is a disaster of the first degree for these people, a theological crisis. **********"These are true believers," Mr. Sprinzak said. "They believe it was God, not  so much the Israeli Army, but the hand of God that gave them back these lands in 1967. It was God sending a message that he was ready to redeem them. They have built a world of Torah, with Yeshivas, schools, a religious life style. Now this is committing a huge religious sin, a sin against God." **********At a court hearing after the shooting, Mr. Amir, according to the Hebrew transcript, said: "According to Jewish law, the minute a Jew gives over his people and his land to the enemy, he must be killed. My whole life has been studying the Talmud and I have all the data." **********One conservative rabbi said that rabbis invoking religious law against Israeli leaders were also naming Acting Prime Minister Shimon Peres as a possible target. **********Police on Trail Of Spiritual Adviser **********Police Minister Moishe Shalal declined to give any names on Friday night when he spoke of a rabbinical link to the slaying. But the police are believed to be on the trail of a man they say is a spiritual adviser to those arrested, and a prominent rabbi among Jewish settlers has threatened to reveal the identity of the rabbi he says sanctioned the killing. **********"This will be a very, very dramatic crisis," Mr. Sprinzak said. "This could involve several important rabbis, very revered authorities." **********The rabbinical ruling of a moral imperative to kill Mr. Rabin has its roots not only in the dismay of Jewish zealots over the peace accord that will turn over what they believe to be their biblical land to the Palestinians, but also in the long-running conflicts between right and left, sacred and secular, that have marked Israel's history. **********It came amid mounting passion among the settlers and the religious right over the imminent withdrawal of the Israeli Army from the West Bank and a wave of bombings by Palestinian Islamic militants who also oppose the peace accord. **********Mr. Sprinzak recalled in an interview that this fall, after speaking on the radio, he got a call from a student at the Tomb of Joseph Yeshiva in Nablus who  said "the situation is worse than you thought." Rabbis at his yeshiva, or religious school, were saying the Prime Minister must be killed, the student said. **********Indeed, Mr. Sprinzak said that only a week before the shooting he met with top security officials to discuss "the very real possibility" of a Jewish plot to assassinate Israeli leaders. But, he added, "we just couldn't bring ourselves to really believe it." **********And by then, the police now say, there had been at least two occasions on which Mr. Amir had set out to kill Mr. Rabin, but had been thwarted. **********Unusual Interpretation Of 'Pursuer' Concept **********The lethal interpretation of religious law, according to both the police and Rabbi Yoel Ben Nun, a founder of the settlers movement who charged at an emotional meeting of the religious right that other rabbis had sanctioned the killings, revolves around the concept of the "rodef," or pursuer. **********Under Jewish law, if a pursuer is chasing a Jew with the intent to kill him,  one is required to kill the pursuer to save the life of the intended victim. This is one of the few exceptions to the general rule against killing. Some settlers have considered Arabs to be rodef as a class. The Talmudic reasoning here appeared to be that Mr. Rabin's policies had put Jews in such danger that he in effect had become a pursuer himself. **********Mr. Amir's motives, Police Minister Shahal said, "drew on Halachic rulings made by rabbis who decreed that the 'pursuer's decree' has effect on Rabin." Halachic rulings are oral interpretations of religious law. **********Rabbi Ben Nun, who is threatening to expose the rabbis involved unless they resign their religious posts, warned, "there are people still callng certain people pursuers, invoking the law of pursuer about Shimon Peres." **********Mr. Sprinzak also suggested another religious concept, that of a "moiser," meaning a Jew who surrenders other Jews to the Gentiles. The Halachic rule there, he said, "is that the person who commits this crime should be killed." **********Almost as if in confirmation of such views, the agreement with the Palestinians was soon followed by scores of Jewish deaths at the hands of Islamic militants, frequently suicide bombers, who launched a wave of attacks. **********The West Bank settlers are fearful, too, that once the Israeli Army withdraws, their isolated compounds will be in great danger from Palestinian terrorists and even the Palestinian police, whom they regard as recently uniformed terrorists. **********Sparks of the Past Ignite Present Anger **********The beliefs of the religious settlers, particularly Gush Emunim, or Bloc of  the Faithful, is based largely on the teachings of Rabbi Zvi Yehuda Kook, who was brought in tears from his yeshiva in 1967, after the Israeli Army seized eastern Jerusalem, to the Western Wall by two paratroopers who were his former students. **********If Jews were to regain the land of biblical Israel, he held, it would be possible for the Messiah to come. **********The debate over the settlements in the occupied territories in part reflects  the struggle over the vision of Israel between the secular left and the right-wing Zionism generally known as Revisionism. **********There are constant, eerie echoes. Mr. Rabin, for example, was remembered not  only as the general who led Israel to victory in the 1967 war but also as a young officer in the Labor movement's Palmach commandoes who in 1948 fired on the Altalena, a ship bringing illegal arms to the Irgun underground. One Irgun leader, Menachem Begin, would later become Prime Minister. **********It was with the electoral victory of Mr. Begin's Likud Party in 1977 that settlement of the West Bank rapidly expanded as a matter of policy. **********There are now more than 100 Jewish settlements, ranging from clusters of prefabricated huts to virtual cities along the stony hilltops. And, in recent years, religion has come to exercise a greater role in Israeli political life as small Orthodox religious parties became critical in forming governing coalitions and extracted their price in return. **********"In 1948, the religious were a tiny minority," recalled Yisrael Harel, chairman of the council of Judea and Samaria, the biblical names the settlers use for the West Bank. "It was after the Holocaust. The big theological thinkers had been killed and there was resentment because many rabbis had been anti-Zionist. **********"But slowly, slowly the religious have become more powerful politically," said Mr. Harel, who along with Rabbi Ben Nun lives in Ofra, the original Gush Emunim settlement. "Now, Oslo has put us in a corner. The agreement is a danger to our very existence." **********A Deadly Parallel To an Old Underground **********The new Jewish underground that killed Mr. Rabin, the police say, appears to have almost uncanny parallels with the earlier Jewish underground growing out of Gush Emunium in 1984. **********That underground was galvanized by shock at the Camp David accords, in which  Egypt and Israel made peace and Israel promised to address the Palestinian issue. The underground set off car bombs that crippled two Palstinian mayors, and plannned to bomb five Arab commuter buses and and blow up Al-Aksa Mosque in  Jerusalem, partly in hopes of provoking a war so cataclysmic that it would hasten the arrival of the Messiah. **********Members of the group, which included a founder of the Ofra settlement, were arrested before most of the plans could be carried out. **********Like the earlier underground, the new group apparently has also consulted rabbis for approval of its plans. And, as is happening today, Rabbi Ben Nun, a moderate figure among the settlers, openly criticized the religious approval of the Jewish terrorist group, breaking sharply with other rabbis who were widely believed to be sympathetic to the underground. **********A Rabbi Warns: 'Woe Is Us!' **********Shaking with emotion, Rabbi Ben Nun vowed at a gathering of figures on the religious right Wednesday night to "fight them before the whole people of Israel; I'm going to fight them even if I die." **********"Woe is us," Rabbi Ben Nun cried. "If this terrible thing is not rooted out,  if, God forbid, there will be another killing, it is doubtful there will be a Jewish state." **********He demanded that the rabbis resign their positions by the end of the mourning period, which will come Sunday, or else he would identify them. And, he suggested, they were prominent. "These are not weeds or wild growths, these are  great authorities," he said. **********As the police continued to search for more suspects, details emerged about those arrested and their alleged terrorist cell, which seemed to have developed  from a more militant offshoot of Rabbi Kahane's Kach organization called Eyal. **********An article in the Yediot Aharonot newspaper discussed arms training and code  names and recounted a trip of young people to Hebron to support the settlers there, in which the two Amir brothers took part. **********Such trips to Hebron were one of the brothers' frequent activities. Several weeks ago, witnesses say, the two swaggered in the lead of such a group, some of whom broke ranks and attacked a line of Christian women peace activists who regularly placed themselves between the Jews and Palestinians, knocking two of them down and dragging them by their hair.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/23/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;QUALITY DINING PURCHASES GRADY'S RESTAURANT CHAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;QUALITY DINING PURCHASES GRADY'S RESTAURANT CHAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/23/busin.body_text: **********Quality Dining Inc. said yesterday that it had bought the 42-restaurant Grady's American Grill chain for $74.4 million. Quality Dining, owner and operator of fast-food and casual dining restaurants, bought Grady's from Brinker International, a restaurant operator based in Dallas. Quality Dining, based in Mishawaka, Ind., said it had also acquired the United States rights to Brinker's Spageddies Italian Kitchen concept. Financial terms were not disclosed. Grady's and Spageddies are both midpriced, casual dining restaurants.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/13/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Anderson & Lembke seeks global reach in its agreement to be acquired by the Interpublic Group.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/13/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Anderson & Lembke seeks global reach in its agreement to be acquired by the Interpublic Group.
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/13/busin.body_text: **********IN an unexpected move, Anderson & Lembke, a fast-growing agency that specializes in business-to-business advertising for information-technology marketers, announced yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Interpublic Group of Companies. The deal, the terms of which were not disclosed, is another example of the accelerating, seemingly relentless consolidation of the agency industry. **********Anderson & Lembke, as an independent shop, has been praised for its creative  skills in selling technical products from computer chips and operating systems to modems and fax machines. Billings from clients like AT&T, Agfa, Microsoft, Motorola, SAP and 3Com have doubled in the last two years, to $200 million. Interpublic, the world's third-largest agency company, with billings of $15 billion, owns global behemoths like Lintas Worldwide, the Lowe Group and McCann-Erickson Worldwide. **********Anderson & Lembke, which traces its roots to a Swedish agency started in 1970, began American operations in Stamford, Conn., in 1982. It now has 220 employees in offices in New York, San Francisco and Amsterdam. A cover article this month in the trade publication Advertising Age's Creativity described Anderson & Lembke as "perhaps the consummate business-to-business agency," which "might at last be ready to cross over into the mainstream" because many of the products it pitches are now being aimed at consumers as well as business users. **********"It's a really terrific agency with a very different philosophy of doing business that focuses on the creative product," said John J. Dooner Jr., chairman and chief executive of McCann Worldwide in New York. Though Anderson & Lembke will report directly to him, he added, it will operate autonomously under present management. **********"Domestically we'll give them systems, media and management support," Mr. Dooner said, while overseas, "I'm hoping we'll be able to expand their capabilities," for instance, by helping Anderson & Lembke open additional offices. **********From 1989 to 1992, Anderson & Lembke was owned by another large agency company, Chiat/Day/Mojo, but regained its independence in a buyout by top managers. Those same executives -- Steve Trygg, 48, chairman and chief creative  officer, and Hans Ullmark, 49, president and chief executive -- have now agreed  to sell the agency to Interpublic. William S. Keating, associate general counsel of Interpublic in New York, said the two parties expected the transaction to be  completed by the end of the month. **********This is the most recent in a skein of Interpublic purchases during the last two years, which included Scali, McCabe, Sloves; the Martin Agency; Ammirati & Puris; Western International Media, and half of Campbell Mithun Esty. **********Interpublic was involved in a second transaction yesterday, agreeing to form  a joint venture with All American Communications in Santa Monica, Calif., to buy substantially all of the assets of Mark Goodson Productions in Los Angeles, which produces and licenses game shows like "The Price is Right," for $50 million and future bonus payments. **********Those transactions are emblematic of an industrywide buying binge by giants like Interpublic, the Omnicom Group and True North Communications, which have strong cash flow and little debt. They are eager to extend their dominance by snapping up successful smaller shops. **********"One factor is a practical realization that clients want and need power," Mr. Dooner said, "especially to take brands globally in an efficient way." **********Mr. Ullmark, speaking from San Francisco, agreed that "the driving force" of  the deal, as he put it, was meeting the increasingly multinational demands of clients rather than "the personal greed thing." **********"Steve and I felt limited," he said, referring to Mr. Trygg, "because all of  our clients are going global on a large scale. **********"They kept asking over and over, 'How can you help us in Latin America, in the Pacific Rim?' and we had to say we couldn't," he added. "Now we can offer them ways of getting to global advertising." **********For example, Mr. Ullmark said, "we're already working with McCann on an office in Hong Kong," though in the United States "we're going to compete; we're actually in a couple of pitches against McCann." **********Mr. Dooner traced the deal to a meeting he said he had with Mr. Trygg perhaps eight months ago. **********"The more we talked, the more we felt we shared some ideals and dreams," he added. **********Mr. Ullmark said the acquisition was appealing because Mr. Dooner said Anderson & Lembke "can be very independent," adding that he and Mr. Trygg were looking to "what we call the Goodby model." His reference was to the autonomy enjoyed by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, the creatively focused agency in San  Francisco owned by Omnicom. **********"I can't have bosses, personally," Mr. Ullmark said, "but John Dooner is an interesting guy and I don't mind working with him, to tell the truth." **********Mr. Ullmark said he and Mr. Trygg would give part of the sale proceeds to all of Anderson & Lembke's other employees, based on a "share value plan" devised a  year and a half ago. **********One jewel in the Anderson & Lembke crown is a relationship with the Microsoft Corporation, for which the agency's San Francisco office has created print product campaigns with spending estimated at $75 million. Those ads complement the work produced by Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., which handles the consumer portion of the Microsoft account. Interestingly, Wieden & Kennedy has teamed up with McCann Worldwide to serve the Nike Inc. account overseas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/world.main_headline: 500 Million in Aid Is Pledged for Bosnia
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/world.print_headline: 500 Million in Aid Is Pledged for Bosnia
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/22/world.body_text: **********A conference organized by the European Commission and the World Bank pledged  $500 million today toward rebuilding Bosnia, the first installment toward a multibillion-dollar effort to put the wartorn region back on its feet. **********The aid was pledged at a two-day meeting attended by representatives of 50 countries and 27 international organizations. The money is to be used over the next three months to start restructuring projects in areas such as energy and transport. **********The amount pledged was less than the $518 million the World Bank said was needed to cover immediate needs. But officials said they expected another $30 to $40 million in the next few weeks. **********Of the $500 million in new pledges, the World Bank promised $150 million, the European Union $88 million and the United States $50 million. **********Including previous pledges, Europe and the United States are giving $114 million and $62.7 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/08/world.main_headline: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: THE MOURNERS;Grief and Guilt Soak Gravesite Like the Rain
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/08/world.print_headline: ASSASSINATION IN ISRAEL: THE MOURNERS;Grief and Guilt Soak Gravesite Like the Rain
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/08/world.body_text: **********By late afternoon today the skies had turned gray, and an chill rain soaked candles and letters placed next to the wreath-covered grave of Yitzhak Rabin at  the Mount Herzl cemetery. **********But Israelis streamed there into the night to stand in silence, leaving behind notes, poems and makeshift signs that have become part of a landscape of  grief across the country. **********Farewell, Daddy," said one placard. **********"Goodbye, light at the end of the tunnel of war," said another. "Thank you." **********A woman placed flowers and a note on the grave, then crouched next to it in tearful silence. **********"Thank you for every minute and year in which you lead the country to peace and hope, to quiet and tranquillity," she wrote in a Hebrew rhyme, signing it: "A citizen in pain." **********In their written messages, and in emotional remarks broadcast on radio call-in shows, people seemed to be in the throes of a collective soul-searching  that has deepened since Mr. Rabin's funeral on Monday. **********Many said they felt guilty for not speaking out earlier to prevent the swell  of hatred that led to Mr. Rabin's assassination. **********Many who have come to mourn Mr. Rabin in public are young, liberal, nonreligious Israelis of the type who were Mr. Rabin's main reservoir of support. But until the peace rally last Saturday night at which Mr. Rabin was killed, their voices were often drowned out in the streets by opposition protests. **********"My silence killed him," said a young woman on the radio. Many notes asked Mr. Rabin for forgiveness. **********"What have we come to?" murmured a woman near the grave, wondering whether the profound political divisions exposed by the killing could be healed. **********Some notes offered answers. **********"I didn't agree with your opinions," wrote Army Sgt. Yitzhak Elbaz in a letter addressed to Mr. Rabin. "But on such a day we all have to be united, as the verse says: 'Love thy neighbor as thyself.' " **********Many messages were left by children, and at the Tel Aviv square where Mr. Rabin was gunned down, boys and girls sat at tables today and wrote memorial letters to his widow. **********"Why have you gone?" asked a note by 11-year-old Shiran Shimoni. "You were our father. We are waiting, but there's no hope." **********Some people wrote that they would never be the same again. **********"When you died, something of me died with you," said one note. **********Many people vowed to carry on Mr. Rabin's work. "Peace cannot be stopped," wrote one man. **********At nearly every makeshift shrine there was a page with the words of "Song for Peace," sung by Mr. Rabin and others at the rally minutes before he was slain. A controversial anti-war song that was once banned from the airwaves, it has now become Israel's anthem of grief, broadcast repeatedly over radio. **********"Lift up your eyes to gaze with hope, not through gunsights," it goes. "Sing  a song for love and not for wars."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/08/world.body_text: **********Sporadic shooting sounded through Burundi's capital today, one day after ethnic fighting between Hutu and Tutsi reportedly killed 26 people. **********One aid worker said he saw army troops in the national university courtyard firing mortars into the hills around the capital, where Hutu extremists took refuge. **********Burundi's Government is largely made up of majority Hutu, but the army is controlled by Tutsi. **********The two groups have been waging a low-level civil war since 1993, when Burundi's first elected Hutu President was killed in a failed army coup.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/16/world.main_headline: 5 Islamic Soldiers Die in Shootout With Croats
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/16/world.print_headline: 5 Islamic Soldiers Die in Shootout With Croats
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/16/world.body_text: **********Five Islamic fundamentalist soldiers, foreign volunteers who came to fight alongside the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Army, have been killed in a shootout with Croatian militia at a roadblock here, Bosnian police officials said today. Two Bosnian Croat police officers were wounded. **********The attack, which occurred at the same time as Thursday's signing of the Bosnian peace accord in Paris, was the worst confrontation yet between the fundamentalists and Croats, who are in the majority in this town. **********On Wednesday there was a large explosion in a car at the fundamentalists' military camp in Podbrezje, near here. The Bosnian police said today that their  investigation indicated that the explosion occurred when people trying to rig a  car bomb accidentally triggered it. One man was killed. **********Deadly confrontations involving foreign Islamic militants in Bosnia began on  Oct. 5, when a British soldier in the United Nations force killed a fundamentalist who had pointed a gun at him. British officials say the Islamic volunteers threatened to kill five Britons in retaliation. **********United Nations officials said they believe the shootout on Thursday may worsen tensions between Croats in this area and the fundamentalists, called mujahedeen, who are based here. Bosnian Croat soldiers said they had been ordered to prepare for car bombings and assaults on isolated villages. **********The role of the Islamic fundamentalist soldiers has been shadowy since their  arrival more than two years ago, and now threatens to make the peace more difficult to implement. French and British military intelligence reports estimate there are as many as 2,000 mujahedeen in Bosnia, though some Western diplomats suggest there may be twice that number. **********Some mujahedeen in Bosnia are second- or third-generation European Arabs, according to United Nations officials. The man killed in the explosion at the fundamentalists' base on Wednesday was a British citizen, Bosnian authorities said. **********The Bosnia peace accord requires that foreign forces who have fought in the war leave Bosnia. Mujahedeen leaders and President Alija Izetbegovic have announced their willingness to comply, and a Government official in Zenica, the  district capital, said 136 fundamentalists had already left Bosnia. **********A senior police official here, reflecting on how the shootout could contribute to tensions, said: "This could start serious problems again. We know  how it has been here, and we don't have any reason to believe it will change just because of an agreement in Dayton or a ceremony in Paris." **********A Croatian Catholic priest conceded that Muslims are still occasionally harassed by Croats here with beatings and illegal evictions, but he said mujahedeen also harass Croats in areas controlled by Muslims.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/15/busin.main_headline: Forgetting a Merger, Wellpoint and Health Systems Work to Avoid CostlyLegal Battle
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/15/busin.print_headline: Forgetting a Merger, Wellpoint and Health Systems Work to Avoid CostlyLegal Battle
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/15/busin.body_text: **********Preparing to break off their star-crossed marriage plans, Wellpoint Health Networks and Health Systems International said yesterday that they had been discussing "mutual termination" of their agreement to create a giant managed health care company with $6 billion of annual revenues. **********With at least six investment banking firms and 10 law firms involved in aspects of the disintegrating deal, analysts said there would be a rush to find  new merger or acquisition partners for the two California-based companies. Under the deal, Wellpoint would have acquired Health Systems, its neighbor in the Los  Angeles suburb of Woodland Hills, for $1.89 billion in stock. **********Several analysts said Health Systems was a likely prospect for a takeover by another managed care health insurer. Besides Wellpoint, two other California companies, the Foundation Health Corporation and the FHP International Corporation, had approached Health Systems independently with merger proposals last year. **********Similarly, Wellpoint's effort to merge with Health Systems followed a takeover proposal to Wellpoint by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout firm, and a cash acquisition offer by Blue Shield of California. **********The companies' strong-willed chief executives, Leonard Schaeffer of Wellpoint and Dr. Malik M. Hasan of Health Systems, waited in the wings this week as phalanxes of lawyers and board members representing Health Systems, Wellpoint and Blue Cross of California, which owns 80 percent of Wellpoint, discussed plans for breaking up the merger . **********The objective of the current discussions is to fend off a costly legal battle between the parties and dodge a $50 million penalty against either side for walking away from the agreement that the companies signed last March. **********Both Mr. Schaeffer and Dr. Hasan have said they would pursue other merger and acquisition deals, whether or not their marriage was consummated. Don Prial, a Health Systems spokesman, said yesterday that the company intended to seek more  acquisitions in the Northeast. **********Mr. Schaeffer said last week that he had held discussions with a dozen Blue Cross associations across the country about mergers, joint ventures and "technical assistance." **********Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield in New York, for example, is considering a  proposal to cooperate with Wellpoint in a national managed care information system. **********Indeed, one of the crucial disputes between Mr. Schaeffer and Dr. Hasan, according to a letter sent to Wellpoint by lawyers for Health Systems, was over who would be in charge of future negotiations with other Blue Cross plans -- including Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey. **********Though a number of nonprofit Blue Cross associations, including the New Jersey plan, are moving to form publicly traded companies -- thereby subjecting  themselves to market play -- analysts said many of them might be strong enough to spurn takeover moves by Wellpoint. **********The Wellpoint-Health Systems deal began falling apart when Mr. Schaeffer and  Dr. Hasan could not agree on how they would share power in the merged company. Each accused the other of trying to impose new conditions in order to wrest ultimate control. **********What the companies agreed on yesterday was that an attempt to patch up their  differences with the help of a mediator had failed. They said they were "currently engaged in discussions regarding a mutual termination and release of  all claims against one another related to the proposed business combination." **********The breakup would leave Wellpoint and Blue Cross with an obligation to California's Commissioner of Corporations, Gary Mendoza, to hand over $3.2 billion in cash and stock to public interest foundations. The money is due under a California law that treats Blue Cross and other nonprofit associations as assets created by the state's citizens. **********Mr. Mendoza said yesterday that if the merger deal indeed collapsed, he "expects Blue Cross of California will promptly submit an alternative proposal to meet its responsibilities" to finance the foundations. **********The value of Blue Cross is tied to the Wellpoint stock price. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday Wellpoint closed up 62.5 cents, at $33.25, and Health Systems closed down $1, at $32.50. **********Analysts disagreed about the prospects for the two companies. "I would be surprised if by the end of 1996 both players hadn't been involved as part of a major merger or acquisition," said Todd Richter, a health care analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds. But Kenneth S. Abramowitz, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein, said Mr. Schaeffer and Dr. Hasan were not under the gun to make deals. "They could do well by themselves," he said. **********Indeed, the failure of their merger plans suggests both companies could have  a hard time finding a comfortable fit with another partner. **********Mr. Schaeffer was no more willing to share his authority with Kohlberg Kravis than with Dr. Hasan, people with knowledge of the various deal discussions said. **********Wayne Moon, chief executive of California Blue Shield, said yesterday that he would still like to bring "the two Blues together." **********Health Systems, meanwhile, has a relatively heavy debt load, having borrowed  to buy health plans in Connecticut and Philadelphia recently in two cash deals for $100 million each. Analysts added that a California nonprofit foundation that owns a big chunk of the company would like to cash out its stake.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/26/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;MANITOWOC TO BUY REFRIGERATOR MAKER FOR $126 MILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/26/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;MANITOWOC TO BUY REFRIGERATOR MAKER FOR $126 MILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/26/busin.body_text: **********The Manitowoc Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Shannon Group  Inc., a privately held refrigerator and freezer maker, for about $126 million. Manitowoc might also make an additional payment of up to $7 million, depending on Shannon's earnings. Shannon, based in Brentwood, Tenn., is expected to have 1995 sales of $125 million to $140 million. Manitowoc, based in Manitowoc, Wis., is a maker of construction cranes and refrigeration products.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/04/world.body_text: **********During the three days of peace talks on Bosnia this week, human rights abuses and reports of massacres have been pushed high on the agenda as the Bosnian Government has demanded that the Serbs do more to uncover abuses and punish those responsible. **********Washington plans to send an envoy to the Balkans on Saturday to confront the  human rights issues so the three parties can focus on a draft peace agreement and on elections, constitutional issues and the separation of military forces. **********Today the envoy, John H. F. Shattuck, the State Department's top human rights official, went to Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, near Dayton, Ohio, to  meet with President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia and seek his cooperation. The talks are being held at the air base. **********Nicholas Burns, the State Department spokesman, said Mr. Milosevic promised that the United States, the Red Cross and the United Nations would have direct access to sites in Banja Luka, Srebrenica and Zepa, towns in Bosnia and Herzegovina where the United States believes vast human rights abuses, even slaughters, have occurred. **********The United States is taking great pains not to criticize Mr. Milosevic -- who is negotiating for the Bosnian Serbs at Dayton -- for allowing the reported massacres to happen. But the American side clearly believes he could be more cooperative in reining in the Bosnian Serbs. **********"The oral commitment has been good," Mr. Burns said. "The practice has been pretty good. We'd like to have a higher degree perhaps of performance, and we continue to make that point." **********The purpose of Mr. Shattuck's trip is "to have him, as our chief official here concerned with human rights, look into and investigate the allegations of human rights abuses," said Mr. Burns, adding that the United States finds the allegations credible. **********By getting Mr. Shattuck involved on the scene in Bosnia, the United States hopes to deflect criticism that it has elevated Mr. Milosevic to a negotiating partner with the same standing as the Bosnian and Croatian Presidents. The Bush  Administration branded Mr. Milosevic a probable war criminal. **********Washington also hopes to allay some of the concerns of Bosnian officials, who insist that "you cannot speak of peace in Dayton and still have ethnic cleansing in Banja Luka," as one put it. **********In the opening session on Wednesday, President Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia appealed to Mr. Milosevic and to the American, French, German, British and Russian delegations to take measures to end atrocities in Banja Luka. **********Mr. Shattuck is also to pursue the case of David Rohde, a correspondent from  The Christian Science Monitor, who has not been heard from since Sunday. **********The State Department sharply criticized the Bosnian Serbs who, according to the Bosnian Serb press agency, detained Mr. Rohde in Zvornik on charges that he  had illegally crossed the border into Bosnian Serb territory with false documents. **********Mr. Rohde, 28, headed into the area on Sunday, apparently intending to follow up stories he had written about atrocities that ethnic Serbs were accused of committing when the Muslim enclave at Srebrenica was overrun. **********"We are demanding two things: we want to have immediate consular access to him and want him released immediately," Mr. Burns said. "There is no justification for holding him." **********Earlier in the day, Mr. Burns suggested that Mr. Milosevic himself could be more helpful on this matter, saying, "We expect that President Milosevic, as leader of the Serb-Bosnian Serb delegation, will use his influence to help in this. He has said he will do so." **********At the talks today in Dayton, the three delegations spent much of the day poring over four draft agreements presented to them on Thursday by the United States. **********Saturday will be largely a day of recreation. Some of the Serbs, Bosnians and Croats will be "seeing movies, going bowling, swimming, and there's a soccer match planned," Mr. Burns said. Muhamed Sacirbey, the Bosnian Foreign Minister,  who attended Tulane University on a football scholarship, will take a contingent to Louisville to see his alma mater play the University of Louisville.
