https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/05/world.main_headline: German Parliament Is Caught Trying to Sneak Itself a Raise
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/05/world.print_headline: German Parliament Is Caught Trying to Sneak Itself a Raise
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/05/world.body_text: **********It's the same the world over: few things bring politicians together more than the prospect of a raise in salary. And nothing so provokes the public's ire. **********German legislators have made headlines in recent weeks as word leaked out that supposed parliamentary adversaries had quietly worked together to raise their salaries by 60 percent over the next five years. **********What especially upset many people was that the legislators have tried to change the rules so they could do it in secret. **********The plan misfired and now, in the bright gaze of public scrutiny, Bonn's power-brokers are divided on what some commentators call greed among politicans  who are calling on ordinary Germans to tighten their belts. **********One respected figure, Stefan Heym, a writer who at 82 had been the oldest member of the German Parliament, resigned in protest. He asserted that the legislators "behaved very stupidly in trying to sneak more money into its own pockets." **********"In the English system, my job is called the father of the house," Mr. Heym said. "And sometimes when the children try to gorge themselves on too many sweets, the father must act." **********What Germans have come to call the "stipend scandal" has managed to drive wedges not just through the governing coalition of Christian Democrats and Free  Democrats, but also between the opposition Social Democrats in Bonn and their allies in the provinces. **********The affair is not, so far, on the scale of Italy's shedding of a corrupt political generation, or Britain's putative questioning of its legislators' private business affairs or the increasing talk of shady dealing in France. **********But it has thrown light on an aspect of Parliament that few legislators wish  to dwell on: members may work for private business alongside their public affairs, and are under no obligation to declare their interest to the general public. **********Indeed, as the debate over parliamentary salaries widened, the one thing legislators did agree on was that there should be no change in the way they may  take directorships and other positions in private business at the same time that they serve in Parliament. **********The 622 legislators in Germany's lower house, the Bundestag, are paid about $7,500 a month in taxable income, and they also receive an untaxed expense allowance of around $4,500 a month. **********Last month, the dominant Christian Democrats and the opposition Social Democrats quietly agreed to press for a change in the rule that allows them to set their own pay levels after full, public debate. **********They said legislators' salaries should be increased by the year 2000 to those of the "highest federal judges" -- around $11,000 a month before taxes. **********The expense allowances, the legislators said, should also be increased automatically without public discussion. **********The first to blow the whistle were the Free Democrats, the junior coalition partner, and the opposition Greens. **********Their protests were ignored and the big parties pushed the new rules through  the Bundestag. **********Then came the question of approval by the upper house -- the Bundesrat, which has 68 representatives. Many Bundesrat representatives, including those from the Social Democrats, said no. And there the matter rests until the Bundesrat votes  formally on Oct. 13.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/15/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mexico Vows Restraint and Markets Yawn
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/15/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mexico Vows Restraint and Markets Yawn
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/15/busin.body_text: **********Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz responded today to the volatility of the peso markets by insisting that Mexico will stick to the tight fiscal policies it has outlined, but his remarks failed to hearten nervous investors. **********The Mexican central bank intervened in the currency markets, buying pesos after Mr. Ortiz made his annual budget address to the lower house of Congress, and the purchases gave some lift to the currency, which had been down earlier in the day. It was its second intervention this month. The peso had weakened to more than 8 to the dollar, a little more than 12 cents. With the purchases, it rebounded to settle here at 7.7 to the dollar. The peso has lost a little more than 17 percent of its value since early October. **********Mr. Ortiz remained steadfast in his speech, his first broad statement since  the peso went into its recent slide. "Speculators will not make us change our course," he said. The Finance Minister had chosen to remain silent and wait for  this long-scheduled appearance before the House of Deputies to answer the markets with an overview of Mexico's economic plan for 1996. **********Today, he did not announce any major economic changes, and he reiterated projections for Mexican economic performance next year that many private economists had already rejected as unrealistic. **********The Government says that it expects the peso to hold to an average rate in 1996 of 7.7 to the dollar. Growth, it predicts, will be about 3 percent after inflation, which will not exceed 21 percent, Mr. Ortiz said. **********He repeated his 1996 growth estimate -- one that the Government has given for months -- even while saying that the economy this year would shrink by about 6 percent, a greater retraction than forecast early in 1995. Mexico is in the midst of a recession set in motion by a bungled, two-stage devaluation of the peso in December 1994. **********Analysts said they hoped that Mr. Ortiz would announce a more forceful program to fortify the nation's weakened banking system, which received new blows this week as the Government raised short-term interest rates above 50 percent. Some reports said overnight lending rates had reached 75 percent. **********Economists did not find in Mr. Ortiz's speech any initiative that would generate the growth that big investors want to see before they begin returning to Mexico. The stock market was down modestly, off just over one-half of 1 percent, at 2,241.53. **********"This Government has been able to bring the patient to a stable condition," said Jorge Mariscal, director for Latin American equity research at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "But now, the markets are asking when the patient will be able  to get up and walk out of the hospital. It's still not clear." **********Mr. Ortiz dismissed the recent peso turmoil as the result of "purely speculative attitudes" that "have nothing to do with the real conditions of our  economy." He said the peso would eventually stabilize, but cautioned that this might take several weeks. The Government, he added, would keep interest rates high to support the peso, but only as a temporary measure. **********Mr. Ortiz's budget was a compendium of careful fiscal policies that agencies  like the International Monetary Fund have long required for wayward economies. Overall spending will slightly decrease, and the central bank will keep firm control on inflation. **********His strategy is to pursue these policies consistently, in a way that restores foreign investors' faith in Mexico's reliability. But those investors do not seem to be satisfied with reliability alone. **********They are eager to spot signs that Mexico can find ways to spur growth, and seem to regard Mr. Ortiz's restatements of policy as evidence of a lack of imagination to take the necessary steps. **********Traders estimate that the central bank entered the market today with about $75 million to buy pesos. Officials at the bank confirmed that the amount was less than a peso purchase last Thursday, estimated at $200 million, but did not  disclose the figure. **********Central bank officials denied that they were forced to move after Mr. Ortiz's speech failed to stem the peso's fall. They said the intervention had been timed to sting speculators.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/10/busin.body_text: **********Technology stocks fell sharply yesterday in a broad retreat that many analysts interpreted as the beginning of the long-awaited selloff in this high-flying group. **********The dive in technology stocks dragged the Nasdaq composite index down 27.30 points, or 2.7 percent, to close at 984.74. The negative sentiment also spilled  over into blue-chip stocks, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 42.99 points, to 4,726.22. [Page D14.] **********The initial catalyst for the decline was an announcement late Friday by Novell Inc. that its fourth-quarter financial results would fall far short of Wall Street estimates. But analysts noted that Novell was only the latest in a series of big technology companies to disappoint in the September quarter, and they expected more to follow. **********Technology stocks, which have led the broader stock market higher all year, have had a series of one-day selloffs in the last few months that were followed  by immediate rebounds. But because there was more bad news after the close of the market yesterday, some analysts concluded that this decline might last longer. **********Motorola Inc. reported earnings of 81 cents a share, slightly below the average estimate of 83 cents, based on 25 analysts surveyed by IBES International. Sequent Computer Systems also said that its earnings would fall below estimates. **********In addition, orders for computer chips dropped 2.1 percent in September, although the ratio of new orders to sales remained positive, an industry association reported. **********"We're going to see a selloff until you see some flow of good numbers," said  Michael Murphy, editor of the California Technology Stock Letter, "and that will not happen until next week, if it happens at all. The rest of this week is going to be anticipation and fear of more negative surprises." **********The Microsoft Corporation is to report its third-quarter earnings next week,  and many analysts expect them to be positive. But if they are disappointing -- or perhaps, just on target -- this could lead to more selling. **********After any sharp run-up in the market, analysts worry about what they call corrections -- sharp selloffs as investors decide that the rally is over or that it has just gone too far too fast. Because of such correction jitters, bad news  is more damaging and even usually positive news can be interpreted negatively, setting off selling as money managers try to lock in profits before prices plunge. **********But corrections are also seen as positive because once over, there is room for stocks to rally again. **********Novell attributed its expectation of lower earnings to a steep drop in the sales of its Wordperfect line of personal computer applications, primarily due to the fact that the company had not yet shipped versions of the programs tailored to Microsoft's new operating system, Windows 95. **********Novell said applications sales could fall 56 percent, to $59 million, from $134 million in the period a year earlier, and that it expected earnings of 15 cents to 18 cents a share while the consensus estimate had been for the company  to earn 28 cents. **********In response, Novell shares plummeted $2.75 yesterday, to $14.625, in Nasdaq trading. **********Although Novell's problems in the quarter were partly predictable, and partly specific to the company, analysts said they contributed to a growing anxiety among investors about technology stocks in general. After a dramatic run-up in the first eight months of the year, many analysts have suggested that the group  is ripe for a selloff, and any piece of bad news from a major company can act as a catalyst. I.B.M. began a series of earnings warnings from large companies on Sept. 13. **********"Anybody who follows Novell closely was probably not surprised by the announcement Friday, but in terms of the technology-stock anxiety, it just reinforced what was already going on," said Peter Rogers, an analyst with Bear,  Stearns & Company in San Francisco. He noted that his index of 31 software stocks was up 135 percent since June 1994, so some sort of correction was inevitable. **********"One has to view this as painful in the short term, but healthy in the long run," Mr. Rogers said. **********Technology companies appeared to defy their usual seasonal dip this summer, and confident analysts began talking about a "secular change," spurred largely by the unexpected growth of the consumer computer market and a similarly unexpected surge in use of the Internet. The introduction of Windows 95 in August was also seen as a spur to continued growth. **********But as third-quarter results begin to be announced, there is a growing perception that growth has slowed, and indeed, that Windows 95 may not have met  analysts' high expectations. **********Mr. Murphy said that after a few false starts, technology stocks had entered  the long-anticipated correction. **********"It's what we had feared; the industry had built up too much inventory in anticipation of Windows 95," he said. "They believed the Microsoft hype, and it  clearly is not happening." He said he expected canceled orders for chips and other components, and retail price cuts that would keep technology stocks depressed for three to four months. **********Firm numbers for Windows 95 sales are not yet available, and will not be until Microsoft reports its results next week, but anecdotal evidence is beginning to show up indicating that its sales are strong, but not up to the most optimistic estimates. Microsoft's European president, Bernard Vergnes, said yesterday that there was excess Windows 95 stock in distribution channels. **********"The problem is they shipped 8 million to 10 million copies on Day One, and we only expect them to sell 10 million copies in total over the next 18 months," said Rick Sherlund, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs. "The distribution channel was reluctant to under-order -- they didn't know what would happen -- so everyone over-ordered," he said. "The sell-through rate is not living up to the  original hype."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/23/busin.main_headline: New Disclosure on Arakis Head's Stock Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/23/busin.print_headline: New Disclosure on Arakis Head's Stock Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/23/busin.body_text: **********The president of the Arakis Energy Corporation, Terry Alexander, sold 198,837 shares of the company's stock in August, an insider trading report filed recently with the British Columbia Securities Commission shows, even though Mr.  Alexander said at the time that he had not sold any stock. **********The disclosure is likely to raise questions among Arakis shareholders, who saw their investment plunge in the weeks after Mr. Alexander's stock sale. **********Mr. Alexander could not be reached for comment today on the securities filing. **********Shares in Arakis, which is seeking to develop oilfields and a pipeline in the Sudan, were among the most active issues on the Nasdaq market last summer. They  soared on news in July of a $750 million financing deal with Saudi Arabian investors and then collapsed as the deal unraveled in September. **********Arakis is still trying to arrange alternative financing. **********At a news conference on Aug. 24, Mr. Alexander said he had recently bought 174,000 Arakis shares and had sold none since Arakis shares began to rise in March. **********But a filing by Mr. Alexander dated Oct. 19 shows that he acquired 198,837 Arakis shares using options at $4.71 (Canadian) apiece on Aug. 3. The next day he sold the shares for $9 (Canadian) apiece, well below their market value, reaping an indicated profit of $853,011 (Canadian), or $630,460 (United States). **********At the Aug. 24 news conference, Mr. Alexander was asked if he had sold any Arakis shares since March. "I haven't because I believe in this project," he said, referring to the company's Sudan oil development. **********In his October filing with the securities commission, Mr. Alexander said he sold the shares in August "to others as per an agreement dated May 1995 with them to provide consulting services to the company." **********No other details were given and it was unclear why the sale price was below market value. Arakis stock was trading at the time at about $22.50 (Canadian) on the Vancouver Stock Exchange and $15.50 on the Nasdaq. **********The report was due to be filed at the securities commission by Sept. 10 but did not arrive until Oct. 19. **********The securities commission is continuing an inquiry first reported by Reuters  on Sept. 22 into possible insider trading and breach of disclosure requirements  by Arakis officials, sources familiar with the case said. **********Arakis voluntarily delisted from the Vancouver exchange in August after the exchange said the stock portion of its financing deal did not comply with exchange rules. It continues to trade on the Nasdaq, where its shares closed unchanged today at $4.875. **********The filing by Mr. Alexander said he had also sold for $9 (Canadian) apiece 22,836 "bonus" shares that he acquired on Aug. 4 for $7.05 (Canadian) apiece but did not give a date for the sale. In accompanying remarks, he said the redemption was "because of a loan to the company." **********An Arakis director, Stephen McCoach, conducted a short sale of 10,000 Arakis  shares at $25.82 (Canadian) and 14,600 shares at $24.63 (Canadian) each on Aug.  23, the securities commission reported in its weekly bulletin of new insider filings distributed this week. **********The timing of the transaction is unusual because the bulletin lists the transactions as being carried out Aug. 23 in the open market, but Arakis shares  were halted from trading on Aug. 22 by the Vancouver exchange and Nasdaq. **********The stock did not resume trading for a month and then when it reopened on the Nasdaq lost roughly half its value. **********The securities commission bulletin shows Mr. McCoach then covered the position by acquiring 24,600 shares at $7.92 (Canadian) apiece on Aug. 30 through the exercise of options. **********Mr. McCoach was not available for comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/26/world.main_headline: IRISH VOTE TO END THE DIVORCE BAN BY A TINY MARGIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/26/world.print_headline: IRISH VOTE TO END THE DIVORCE BAN BY A TINY MARGIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/26/world.body_text: **********By a minuscule margin and after a bitter campaign that pitted the Government  against the Roman Catholic hierarchy, Ireland has voted to remove its constitutional ban on divorce and remarriage, ballots tallied today showed. **********Because of the closeness of the results in Friday's vote -- 50.3 to 49.7 percent -- an official recount was ordered, but the recount showed that the percentages held. **********Anti-divorce campaigners raised the threat of a court challenge to the referendum's constitutionality. **********The right to divorce and remarry was approved by a margin of slightly over 9,100 votes out of more than 1.6 million cast in this country of 3.5 million people, 95 percent of them Catholic. After a day of counting papers marked in Gaelic and English, "Ta-Yes" to end the ban or "Nil-No," the country had to wait until this evening for the result. **********The "yes" result came as the Dublin area, home to a third of Ireland's population, voted heavily to allow divorce and as rural areas, while voting mostly "no," gave measure more support than in 1986, when the last divorce referendum proposal was defeated 2 to 1. **********"It's been a very worrying day, but it was a clear verdict," said Prime Minister John Bruton, whose Government proposed and fought vigorously to remove  the prohibition. **********There was no immediate comment from church leaders. **********The change to the Constitution will make it possible for a couple to obtain a divorce after living apart for four years, and means that one partner can secure a divorce without the other's consent. There are an estimated 80,000 people now  involved in broken marriages, many living with new partners and children. **********The referendum was in part a test of the authority of the church, whose leaders acknowledge that its image, and possibly its influence, have been weakened by a series of cases involving priests accused of sexually abusing children. **********Although priests spoke against divorce from their pulpits, bishops said that  Catholics could vote their conscience, and that a "yes" vote would not be a sin. **********One leader of the anti-divorce campaign, Des Hanafin, said as he conceded defeat, "I believe that divorce will have a terrible effect." **********Another opponent, Rory O'Hanlon, a well-known retired judge, said he was considering a court challenge to invalidate the result. He noted that the Supreme Court had already ruled that the Government had to stop spending public money in the campaign, and said that might be grounds for arguing that the vote was invalid. **********If there is no challenge in the high court within 21 days, the approved amendment will go to the Prime Minister, who will pass it to the President, who  signs it into effect. **********In the rancorous campaign, the anti-divorce groups, led by the influential church hierarchy, argued that a "yes" vote would introduce a divorce culture that would undermine the country's Christian values, weaken the value of Catholic wedding vows and send Ireland reeling into an irreligious way of life.  They cited statistics to show that divorce had corrupted other Catholic countries, like Italy and France, where divorce rates are rising. **********Opponents also argued that divorce would lead to the division of farms into small parcels. In Ireland, land ownership is almost as sacred as religion, as the national memory recalls the centuries in which the Irish were denied property rights under English colonialism. Divorce, they argued, would lead to the formation of new families that would deprive original families of their land. **********They said divorce would lead as well to a tax increase to support broken families. **********They also argued that children would be hurt by divorce and remarriage. One of the campaign's most striking billboards said: "Hello Divorce. Bye-Bye Daddy." **********The opponents largely ignored statistics showing that most separations in Ireland are now sought by women, often by wives who have been repeatedly assaulted by their husbands, or whose children had been subjected to paternal incest. **********The Bruton Government and all the major political parties supported the "yes" campaign. They said that couples who are now legally separated should have the civil right of divorce and remarriage, and that statistics showed that Italy, which allows divorce, has a lower rate of broken marriages than Ireland. **********The Government denied that there would be a tax increase. It also said that the division of farmland was already possible under existing Irish law regarding separations. It brushed aside as a scare tactic the opponents' statement that a  future Parliament could pass laws that would discriminate in favor of families created by remarriage. **********Those favoring the end of the ban on divorce said it was an outrage when one  Bishop said Catholics who divorced and remarried would be denied the sacraments, including Communion and Last Rites for the dying. **********When Pope John Paul II intervened with a statement urging Ireland to vote "no," the views of many who supported ending the divorce ban were reflected in an editorial in The Irish Times, which suggested that if the Pope were serious about morals in Ireland, he could have addressed the scandals within the church, like the sexual abuse of children by priests. **********Prime Minister Bruton even brought the Northern Ireland peace effort into the campaign, saying it would be difficult for him to argue for the rights of the Catholic minority in the predominantly Protestant British province if the Irish  Republic voted against giving the right to divorce and remarriage to the minority of people in broken marriages. **********Opponents of the divorce ban were annoyed by the publication of a hand-written letter from Mother Teresa urging a "no" vote. And they were quietly pleased when President Mary Robinson, who is constitutionally forbidden to make  public political statements, indicated in an interview on British television that she favored a "yes" vote.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/09/world.main_headline: 20 Jailed Arab Women Say No to Israeli Offer of Freedom
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/09/world.print_headline: 20 Jailed Arab Women Say No to Israeli Offer of Freedom
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/09/world.body_text: **********The latest Israeli-Palestinian agreement got off to a shaky start today when  imprisoned Palestinian women refused to accept a presidential pardon, charging that Israel had reneged on a pledge to free all female Palestinian prisoners. **********But on other fronts, work to carry out the agreement moved ahead. Israel and  the Palestinians reported that a Palestinian election could come as early as January, and the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, freed a senior Hamas leader in a quickening campaign to strike a truce with the militant Islamic opposition. **********Israel had announced that 21 women would be freed from detention today in what was to be the start of a three-stage prisoner release. But only one woman -- 18-year-old Bashayer Abu Laban -- walked free, and only because she had been  in isolation in prison and was not aware of the boycott. **********The others refused to sign a statement demanded by Israel forswearing any further attacks against Israelis and remained in detention. Palestinian officials said they were protesting Israel's failure to release four women accused of committing murder. According to the agreement signed on Sept. 28 in Washington, Israel was to release "all female detainees and prisoners" as soon as the agreement went into effect. **********But President Ezer Weizman refused to give pardons to two women who had been  convicted of murder, and military officials followed suit with two other murder  suspects held by the West Bank occupation authorities. **********Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres publicly treated the refusal as a minor glitch. But Mr. Weizman's action on a treaty that both of these officials had signed was an embarrassing public rejection by the head of state, who is supposed to play a largely ceremonial role. **********Mr. Weizman has stepped out of that role more than once to voice public criticism of the treaty, drawing sharp criticism from the governing Labor Party. But it was unlikely that Mr. Rabin would risk a public confrontation with the popular President on an issue over which the Israeli public is sharply divided. **********Miss Abu Laban, the prisoner who did leave prison, had served three years of  an eight-year sentence on charges of trying to stab an Israeli soldier. Back home in the Mount of Olives section of East Jerusalem, she sat smiling and hugging her mother as dozens of relatives and friends gathered to celebrate. **********A spokesman for Mr. Arafat said the Palestinian Authority would demand the release of all the women. "It's not our problem what President Weizman or the Knesset think," said the spokesman, Nabil Abu Rdaineh. "The Israeli Government pledged very clearly to release all the women, and any other justifications will not be acceptable." **********But Mr. Arafat indicated at a meeting with Mr. Peres on Saturday that carrying out the agreement would not be affected by the dispute. He said the issue would be taken up in discussions between Mr. Weizman and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. Mr. Arafat and Mr. Peres met at Erez, on the border of the Gaza Strip, to discuss concrete arrangements for the withdrawal of Israeli troops and the beginning of Palestinian self-rule in Arab-populated areas of the West Bank. **********Israeli officials said they would formally begin closing military administration offices in the West Bank this week, starting with four villages,  and that the P.L.O. would move in the Palestinian police. **********In Mr. Arafat's conciliatory gesture toward Hamas today, he released a senior Hamas leader held in detention in Gaza. The leader, Mahmoud al-Zahar, has been in jail since June 26. **********The release came as five moderate Hamas officials from Gaza were reported meeting with militant exile leaders in Khartoum, the Sudan, in an effort to hammer out a truce between them and the P.L.O. The five traveled to the Sudan last week after drafting a proposed agreement with Mr. Arafat under which Hamas  would gain political rights in Palestinian areas in exchange for suspending terror attacks on Israel. **********The Islamic opposition is reported to be split between militants who reject the Israeli-Palestinian agreement and moderates who want to take part in the coming elections. Western diplomats who monitor Palestinian affairs say they believe that the moderate wing is gaining strength. An aide to Mr. Arafat who arranged Mr. Zahar's release indicated that more Hamas prisoners might be released soon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/02/world.body_text: **********President Clinton is preparing to relax restrictions on the export of high-performance computers, handing a long-sought victory to the technology companies whose executives were among the most ardent supporters of his 1992 campaign. **********Opponents of the move, including some on Capitol Hill and within the Administration, fear that the powerful American computers will be diverted to military uses, like the design of missiles or nuclear weapons. **********Administration officials who support the proposal that is before Mr. Clinton say it recognizes a technological reality: computer manufacturers are making vastly more powerful machines every year. What the Administration defined two years ago as a supercomputer requiring Government approval for sale abroad is today a widely available desktop computer used by businesses from banks to movie animators. **********The proposal, Administration officials said, would help American manufacturers sell billions of dollars of powerful computers to civilian customers in China, Russia, Israel, Pakistan and India. **********They said exports to military customers in those countries would remain under tighter controls. **********"If you try to control the uncontrollable, it's not tough and pious," one senior official said. "It's feckless and wasteful of Government resources. We'd  like to target our resources to where we think we could make a difference." **********But Gary Milhollin, director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control, said the Administration was about to make a crucial tool available to countries building missiles and nuclear weapons. **********He denounced the proposal to relax export controls as a "political decision designed to help California" and said the Chinese, among others, would inevitably order the computers for civilian uses and then give them to the military. **********Mr. Clinton has not yet formally approved the proposal, which was worked out  after months of wrangling among the Defense, State, Energy and Commerce Departments. **********But an Administration official said Mr. Clinton told Israeli officials last week that he intended to liberalize the rules that have made it difficult for Israel and many other countries to buy advanced computers from the United States. **********Announcement of a decision, which Administration officials said was expected  within days, is likely to stir criticism on Capitol Hill. Several lawmakers, including Representative Floyd Spence, the South Carolina Republican who is chairman of the House National Security Committee, have already written to Mr. Clinton and urged him to reconsider. **********The letter expressed particular concern that India, Pakistan and China -- countries with "major nuclear and other advanced weapons programs" -- might obtain computers as powerful as those used to design this country's most sophisticated weapons. **********The proposal was sent to Mr. Clinton after months of intense lobbying by the  computer industry. Several Washington-based advocates for the industry said they had been reminding the White House in recent weeks of the computer industry's importance to California, Texas and Massachusetts. **********"For years and years, Administrations have had this attitude: when in doubt,  control it, without taking a serious look at what the technology is used for and whether or not we can actually control it," said Greg Garcia, senior manager of  the American Electronics Association. "This Administration is asking those questions appropriately." **********Current rules require computer manufacturers to apply for Commerce Department licenses to export any computer more powerful than 1,500 MTOP's, or million theoretical operations per second. Lower thresholds are set country by country.  The MTOP is a standard measure of how fast a computer operates. **********Industry officials complain that proposed sales are sometimes delayed for months while the Government reviews whether the buyer is involved in illicit weapons programs. Sometimes Government officials will allow the sale only if the manufacturers take expensive security precautions like monitoring the machines 24 hours a day. **********Administration officials said the plan before Mr. Clinton would create a multi-tiered system that would determine the appropriate treatment for a country based on its history, the state of its nuclear and missile programs and the identity of the customer planning to use the computer. **********Officials said the Clinton Administration planned to maintain the ban on exports of powerful computers to Iran, Iraq, North Korea and Libya. American intelligence agencies say each of these countries is actively trying to develop  nuclear weapons. **********On the other hand, most remaining restrictions on sales to allies like Britain or France would be lifted. And friendly countries without nuclear arms programs could import machines of up to 10,000 MTOP's for civilian uses. Anything larger would still require an export license. **********The plan before Mr. Clinton would lift restrictions on exports of American computers of less than 2,000 MTOP's, both civilian and military. A rule that forbids American manufacturers from selling powerful computers to anyone using them to make nuclear weapons would remain in effect, and the Administration intends to give companies additional training in how to recognize suspect users. This change alone is important to manufacturers because it permits companies to  sell the more powerful work stations, which are the heart of a modern computing  network. **********Administration officials said the most hotly debated issue among the agencies was how much to loosen controls over sales of powerful computers to Israel, India, Pakistan, Syria, Egypt, China and Russia. These countries are classified  by American officials as having a nuclear arsenal or having attempted in the past to produce missiles and other weapons of mass destruction. **********Under a plan advanced by the Pentagon and eventually adopted by the other agencies, civilian customers in these countries could import computers slower than 7,000 MTOP's without Commerce Department review and approval. Officials said the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency had suggested that the Government be given 20 to 30 days to veto such sales, but that option was rejected by other agencies. **********Military users in those countries could import computers of 2,000 to 7,000 MTOP's, but only after obtaining an export license. **********Several Administration officials expressed concern that more powerful computers sold to China or other countries in this category might be diverted from civilian to military uses. They said the line between military and civilian uses was hazy in several of these countries, particularly China, which has been  largely unsuccessful in developing its own high-performance computers. **********With the advent of the nuclear test ban next year, they said, nuclear powers  like China will have to rely on computer simulations to test the designs for new warheads. **********Controls over the export of computers date to the cold war. As recently as 1991, the United States and Japan -- which dominate the high-performance computer industry and have agreed to cooperate on setting rules for exports -- defined supercomputers as 195 MTOP's. After negotiating with Japan, the Clinton Administration raised the level to 1,500 in late 1993. **********By February of this year, the computer industry was pressing the Clinton Administration to revisit the issue. A study financed by the Commerce Department and completed in August concluded that the industry had leapfrogged past the controls. **********It said the basic work for a nuclear program could be done on widely available machines, and more powerful computers were needed only for "second generation" bombs. **********Some industry officials, including Mr. Garcia of the American Electronics Association, are arguing for an end to all controls. He said countries could already evade the rules by buying smaller computers and lashing them together with software allowing them to work in parallel, or by interlinking them in networks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/19/world.main_headline: Haitian Leader's Angry Words Unnerve Elite and Worry Allies
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/19/world.print_headline: Haitian Leader's Angry Words Unnerve Elite and Worry Allies
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/19/world.body_text: **********With an emotional outburst at the funeral of a slain relative a week ago, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide set off an outbreak of street violence, provoked panic among Haiti's elite and undermined his relations with the United  States and other members of the international coalition that restored him to power a year ago. **********At least seven people have been killed and more than a score wounded in the unrest that erupted after Mr. Aristide urged his followers a week ago today to "go to the neighborhoods where there are big houses and heavy weapons" to help the police disarm "the big men with heavy weapons" and other suspected wrongdoers. **********Do not sit idly by, do not wait," he demanded in an impassioned eulogy for  Jean-Hubert Feuille, a cousin and close political associate. **********Since then, dozens of homes of suspected Aristide opponents have been burned  or looted, a radio station critical of the President has been attacked and vigilante squads have erected roadblocks and stopped and searched vehicles. In the coastal town of Gonaives earlier this week, Nepalese soldiers who are part of the United Nations peacekeeping force clashed with a pro-Aristide mob, firing shots into the air to disperse them, while in the northern town of Limbe, 21 foreign relief workers, 16 of them Americans, took refuge in a hospital after a  band of Aristide supporters became unruly. **********Mr. Aristide's tirade also included sharp criticism of what he described as the failure of the United Nations mission here to disarm Tontons Macoutes and other members of hostile paramilitary groups. Foreign officials who have been working closely with the Aristide Government in efforts to build democracy here  after nearly three decades of dictatorship described themselves as shocked and even betrayed by the President's unexpected behavior. **********"He wanted to flex some muscle and take aim at an issue important to all Haitians, but he went way too far, and has brought the process of national reconciliation almost to a halt," one diplomat said. Another said: "He played with fire a little bit, and I'm sure he did it on purpose. He was sending everyone a message." **********But a close aide to Mr. Aristide said he had not intended to encourage violence in the streets, only to get the attention of the international community before the scheduled departure of the United Nations troops at the end of February. **********"Some slogans against the United Nations mission have been appearing, and he  was telling them they must do more disarmament so that the people will kiss them and dance with them again," the aide said. **********After meeting with Mr. Aristide on Monday, Lakhdar Brahimi, who heads the United Nations mission here, scoffed at the idea of a widening rift between Haiti's Government and the United Nations. **********"We have no problems or difficulties," Mr. Brahimi said. Disarmament efforts  will continue, he said, adding, "One cannot find things which are only said to be here or there." But he also urged Haitians not to respond to Mr. Aristide's call for vigilantism. **********"The Constitution and the law say that it is the police who are responsible for keeping order, and not self-declared volunteers who say they are," he said. **********With Haitians scheduled to go to the polls Dec. 17 to choose a successor to Mr. Aristide, "the latest violence has thrown a shadow over the presidential campaign," the Port-au-Prince newspaper Le Nouvelliste declared this week. **********The incidents of violence by vigilantes and intimidation against perceived opponents of Mr. Aristide coincided with the registration period for presidential candidates, and dropped off as it came to an end on Wednesday. Many of Mr. Aristide's most fervent supporters have called for the vote to be canceled altogether so he would remain in office. Under Haiti's Constitution, the President cannot serve two consecutive terms. **********The crisis began on Nov. 7, when Mr. Feuille, a newly seated member of Parliament, was shot and killed by unknown assailants as he arrived at the home  of another lawmaker. The two men had earlier that day attended the swearing-in ceremony of Haiti's new Prime Minister, Claudette Werleigh, and stopped at a bank, where they withdrew several thousand dollars. That money disappeared in the shooting, but the Haitian Government has said it regarded Mr. Feuille's death as an assassination. Within hours, the police began searching for suspected arms caches among supporters of the former military rulers. **********One of those whose arrest was sought was Gen. Prosper Avril, a former military dictator. But since taking refuge in the Colombian Embassy on the day of the killing, General Avril has been granted asylum and negotiations are under way to gain his safe passage out of the country. **********Last Saturday's outburst was uncharacteristic for Mr. Aristide, who since returning from three years in exile on Oct. 15, 1994, has steadfastly preached reconciliation, peace and patience. **********"It is the first time that I have spoken like this since my return to Haiti," he acknowledged toward the end of the eulogy, delivered from a church pulpit as  Haitians cheered wildly and the diplomatic corps sat by silently and grimly. **********For the political and economic elite that has always distrusted Mr. Aristide, his remarks stirred memories of the incendiary oratory he employed shortly before being overthrown by the military in September 1991. Fearing the worst, some prominent political and business figures have quietly left the country, while others have approached friends at foreign embassies, seeking guarantees of protection. **********"The private sector has a great deal of fear," said a businessman who has generally supported Mr. Aristide. "Things are very tense." **********Mr. Aristide's aides and supporters maintain that his outburst, and the violence it provoked, were spontaneous responses to a deeply felt personal tragedy. **********"It was an emotional reaction," said Jean-Robert Sabalat, who was briefly Mr. Aristide's Foreign Minister in 1991 and is now a member of the Senate. "Now everything is calm and back to normal." **********But Mr. Aristide's opponents argue that his real motives are otherwise. "There is a political strategy behind this campaign," intended to make the presidential election meaningless, said Evans Paul, a former ally and Mayor of Port-au-Prince who broke with the President after this summer's parliamentary elections. **********On Wednesday, Mr. Aristide's Lavalas movement chose Rene Preval, a former Prime Minister who heads a foundation that finances small development projects,  as its candidate, and he is expected to win handily. Most major opposition parties are boycotting the election, and the field of 14 includes candidates from such obscure entities as the Virgin Mary Party and Haitian Party of God as  well as three senators running as independents. **********Relations between Mr. Aristide's Government and the United Nations coalition  that brought him back to power have been fraying since Prime Minister Smarck Michel stepped down last month. Mr. Michel resigned and was replaced by Mrs. Werleigh after failing to persuade Mr. Aristide to carry out an agreement signed with Haiti's creditors to privatize nine state companies. **********As a result of the Government's failure to move ahead with that program, the  United States is withholding $4.6 million in aid, some $100 million in other foreign assistance is also in jeopardy, and the value of the gourde has dropped  by 20 percent. That has not only frustrated the Government, which sent Finance Jean-Marie Cherestal off to Taiwan in an unsuccessful quest for money, but also appears to have reduced the leverage of the United States and its allies over Mr. Aristide. **********Mr. Aristide's funeral eulogy, which was broadcast repeatedly on television and radio for several days afterward, included what many interpreted as a jab at the United States Ambassador here, William L. Swing, and Mr. Brahimi, the chief  of the United Nations mission, who were seated together at the funeral. **********"I am reminding you that until further notice there are not two or three heads of state, but just one," Mr. Aristide said. **********In addition, he suggested that a second term for the Clinton Administration is linked to his success or failure here. **********"The month of November 1995 must be a month of peace, a month of success, so  the month of November 1996 can be a success also in the United States," he said. **********Mr. Aristide also pointedly reminded American and United Nations officials of the profound emotional hold and bond he has with the Haitian people. "Dear friends of the international community, I know you need me just as I need you,"  he said. **********To many diplomats here, that is perhaps the chief lesson of the week's unrest. **********"It doesn't matter whether Aristide is sitting in the presidential palace, or retires to his home in Tabarre" after his scheduled departure from office on   Feb. 7, one diplomat said. "He will still be the one who has the power in this country."

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;BLACK & DECKER TO SELL A TECHNOLOGY UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;BLACK & DECKER TO SELL A TECHNOLOGY UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/14/busin.body_text: **********The Black & Decker Corporation of Towson, Md., agreed yesterday to sell PRC Inc., its information technology and services business, to Litton Industries for $425 million. The sale will allow Black & Decker, best known for its power tools and household appliances, to improve its balance sheet and to focus on core businesses, the company said. Proceeds will be used to pay down debt. Litton, of Woodland Hills, Calif., said PRC had estimated sales of about $720 million in 1995. PRC designs and supports computer-based information systems for the Federal Government, commercial customers and state and local governments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/11/busin.body_text: **********The Jefferson-Pilot Corporation said today that it would sell about $104 million in unusual senior debt securities to pay for last month's acquisition of the Alexander Hamilton Life Insurance Company. **********Jefferson-Pilot, a life insurer based here, said it would repay purchasers of the approximately 1.5 million automatic common exchange securities, or aces, either in shares of the Nationsbank Corporation or in cash. **********The securities give Jefferson-Pilot the flexibility of liquidating some of its Nationsbank stake, the insurer's largest single equity holding. It holds about four million shares of Nationsbank, worth almost $280 million. **********The proceeds will be used to retire short-term debt from Jefferson-Pilot's $575 million cash purchase of Alexander Hamilton Life from Household International Inc.

Assa, a Swedish lock concern, said the purchase would give it a market-leading position in the United States. https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/25/busin.body_text: **********The shares of the Cott Corporation fell 14.5 percent yesterday after the company disclosed a surprising third-quarter loss on Wednesday and announced plans to cut jobs, sell assets and put international expansion on hold. Cott, a  Canadian company that makes private-label soft drinks, said it would report restructuring expenses totaling $40 million (Canadian), or $29.6 million (United States), in its third and fourth fiscal quarters. Cott said it would cut about 230 jobs, reduce store-delivery service, consolidate its United States bottling  program and take other measures to save about $35 million (Canadian) a year. The company also plans to sell noncore assets.
